title: GOVERNOR PUSHING DEVELOPMENT LOANS
description: Governor Rockefeller joined several civic groups yesterday in urging the voters to support a proposed amendment to the State Constitution that would permit the state to lend or give money to private businesses or individuals for community development purposes.

title: E. RAY LOCKHART, 59, EL PASO EXECUTIVE
description: E. Ray Lockhart, chairman and president of the El Paso (Tex.) Electric Company, died yesterday in El Paso at the age of 59.

title: HENRY M. WILSON
description: Henry M. Wilson, who recently retired from the engineering staff of the New York Telephone Company, died Wednesday in New York Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 12 Holden Lane, Madison, N. J.

title: PULLOUT DEADLINE VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Senate, reaffirming its past support of a deadline for ending the Vietnam war, went on record today in favor of the total withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina in six months, provided American prisoners of war were released.

title: For Weekend Chefs: A Pie, a Beef Stew
description: In the menus below the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Baseball Highlights
description: Bill Melton of the Chicago White Sox hit his third home run in 18 hours to win the American League home run championship with 33 as the White Sox beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 21.

title: Cronkite and Professor Differ on Press Freedom
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Walter Cronkite, the television journalist, said today that the Government had too much power over the press, but a law professor asserted that the press had too much power over public expression.

title: 074040 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: MOORESTOWN, N. J., Sept. 30 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 074040.

title: HOSPITAL CHIEFS SCORE DR. ENGLISH
description: The directors of the 18 municipal hospitals here charged yesterday that Dr. Joseph English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, had concentrated greater power in the central office rather than giving them more local autonomy as promised when the corporation took over the system 15 months ago.

title: Advertising:
description: Nestle's Taster's Choice freezedried coffee, which has the largest market share in its category, now has a companion brand, Taster's Choice Decaffeinated, which is being introduced in western New York, Cincinnati and northern California.

title: PROPOSALS GIVEN NIXON FOR PHASE 2
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Cost of Living Council sent to the White House today its proposals for Phase Two of the Administration's economic stabilization program to follow the current 90day wageprice freeze.

title: Prepackaged Hospitals Urged for Use of Poor
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Senator George McGovern urged today that some of the 2,500 prepackaged hospitals that the Government keeps in storage for disaster relief be converted into community health centers for the urban and rural poor.

title: SOME COAL MINERS ARE WALKING OUT
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Oct. 1Miners in scattered areas of the Appalachian softcoal region began walking out of the mines as negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the mine operators passed midnight deadline this morning without reaching agreement on a new contract.

title: U.S. Reports Soviet Ship Fired on a Havy Plane
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  The Pentagon reported today that a Soviet warship fired on a United States Navy patrol plane Tuesday in the Sea of Japan; The commander of the Seventh Fleet patrol force, the Pentagon said, reported that the firings were not considered by him to be hostile and that the plane was not endangered.

title: Report on Safeguard ABM Testimony Finds Unprofessional and Misleading Comments on Both Sides
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Much of the supposedly expert testimony during the 1969 Senate debate on the Safeguard antiballistic missile program was unprofessional and often misleading, in the view of the principal professional society of costeffectiveness analysts.

title: WILLIAM LEE WILBANKS
description: A native of Temple, Tex., now a graduate student in criminal justice at the State University of New York, Albany... Has a bachelor's and master's degree in Bible from Abilene Christian University... Has first draft of his master's thesis in criminology and corrections at Sam Houston State University, Huntsville, Tex., and Albany ...Both concerned with predicting parole performance statistically ... Says he fell into the field, worked one summer in state penitentiary at Huntsville ... Thirty years old, unmarried... Hopes to teach, do research.

title: DISPUTE IN PRISONS ENDS IN BAY STATE
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Sept. 30  A fourdayold strike for prison reform that spread through three state prisons here this week ended this afternoon when inmates at Norfolk Prison agreed to return to work.

title: GOLD CUP IS WON BY TWICE WORTHY
description: CHICAGO, Sept, 30 (AP)Saddle Rock Farm's Twice Worthy, invading from New York and the 95 favorite, scored a fivelength victory in the 36th running of the $122,880 Hawthorne Gold Cup at Hawthorne today.

title: Guard Tells How He Killed Jackson in Trying to Shoot at His Legs
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30Warden L. S. Nelson of San Quentin Prison said today that George Jackson was killed by a prison guard who was trying to shoot his legs, who had seen the gun Jackson carried and who was in a position to shoot only because he was moving from one gun station to another.

title: Transit Workers Act to Replace Bargaining Unit
description: An insurgent group of rankandfile transit workers filed pledge cards 64 support yesterday with the State Public Employment Relations Board in a campaign to displace the Transport Workers Union as bargaining agent for 30,000 Transit Authority workers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I would like to take serious objection to the editorial column entitled Rockefeller Revisited by John A. Hamilton (Sept. 20).

title: Broadcast Aides to See Community Chiefs on F.C.C. Renewals
description: Political and community leaders in New York and New Jersey soon will be coming face to face with the latest creation of the Federal Communications Commission  the inquiring broadcast executive.

title: News Analysis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30President Nguyen Van Thieu, who concluded his campain for reelection tonight, can now step back and await what he undoubtedly will regard as a public mandate to govern for another four years.

title: Draft Treaty to Ban Biological Arms Sent to U.N.
description: GENEVA, Sept. 30The 25member Geneva disarmament conference ended its work on draft convention for the prohibition of biological warfare today and sent it to the United Nations General Assembly.

title: George D. Boinet, Teacher Of French at New School
description: George D. Boinet, who had taught French at the New School for Social Research since 1954 and lectured at the Ecole Libre des Hautes Etudes here, died Wednesday at his home, 171 West 12th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: Chou Sees Japanese
description: HONG KONG, Sept. 30 (Reuters)Premier Chou and other prominent officials had an audience last night with a group of visiting Japanese members of parliament who favor establishing diplomatic relations with Peking, Hsiuhua, the Chinese press agency, reported today.

title: An Appraisal
description: The exhibition that opened at the Whitney Museum yesterday is the renunciation of just about everything the architectural profession holds sacred according to the design doctrines of the 20th century, including much of its most suave and serious work. Its symbol is the high way billboard and its watchwords are dumb and ordinary. The work deals heavily in symbols and images, and dumb and ordinary refers to vernacular construction that grows out of realities of cost and function as a spontaneous response to the highspeed road and instant environment.

title: YIELDS PLUMMET FOR TAXEXEMPTS
description: The bond market continued to climb yesterday, and the advance pushed interest rates on taxexempt securities to their lowest levels in nearly six months.

title: Blacks Urged to Nominate a Negro in '72
description: CHICAGO, Sept. 30Percy E. Sutton, Manhattan Borough president, proposed today that blacks select and support black Presidential candidate in the Democratic National Convention next year.

title: Petrosian Defeated by Fischer in First Game of Match
description: BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30International Grandmaster Bobby Fischer of the United States defeated Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, in 40 moves tonight in the first game of the final candidates elimination tournament. At the end, with only seconds left on his clock, Petrosian had to lose a knight in a hopeless position.

title: MORTGAGE LENDING UP AT SAVINGS UNITS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Mortgage lending by savings and loan associations remained at nearrecord volume in August despite a reduced savings flow, Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, announced today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Jets Get Hinton From Steelers for Onkotz
description: There was a mixture of sadness, gladness and relief in Dennis Onkotz yesterday after the 6footlinch 220pound linebacker learned he had been traded by the New York Jets to the Pittsburgh Steelers for Chuck Hinton, a 65, 260pound defensive tackle.

title: Soldier Repays Stranger for '67 Favor
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30While serving with the Army in 1967 in Vietnam, Michael Delaney saved the life of a wounded American soldier he had never seen by talking to the man for 16 hours by radio, to keep him from sinking into a coma. In a courtroom here today, Army Sgt. James P. Dempsey repaid Mr. Delaney by pledging his stripes to salvage Mr. Delaney's future.

title: Two Held Upstate In Kidnapping Tied To Dispute on Coins
description: The owner of a Hudson Valley restaurant and his wife were held in $75,000 bail each at their arraignment in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on charges of kidnapping a 54yearold Queens man in dispute over the disappearance of $600,000 worth of rare coins.

title: CLINGAN ATTACKS BEAUMONT PLAN
description: The controversy over the proposed purchase and reconstruction of the Vivian Beaumont Theater in Lincoln Center by the City Center with $5.2million in city funds continued yesterday with Councilman Eldon R. Clingan verbally attacking Councilman Carter Burden for his support of, the plan.

title: JOSEPH L. ROTH, ACCOUNTING AIDE
description: Joseph L. Roth, a partner in the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Co., died of cerebral hemorrhage here Wednesday. He was 57 years old and lived at 56 Spring Brook Road in Morristown, N. J.

title: Bridge:
description: The vast majority of players, in domestic games as well as club and tournament play, employ methods that were originally called after their leading propagandists, successively Ely Culbertson and Charles Goren, but are now more commonly described as Standard American.

title: OFFICER DISCOUNTED REPORTS ON MYLAI
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 30 A former intelligence officer who worked for Col. Oran K. Henderson said today that while in Vietnam he considered reports of civilian slayings at Mylai 4 to be Vietcong propaganda.

title: HARLEIGH G. WATHEN
description: Harleigh G. Wathen, for 40 years a worldwide toy exporter and importer, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 655 Park Avenue.

title: A. B. A. Panel to Meet Tomorrow on Poff
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Judiciary will meet Saturday morning in New York to consider the qualifications of Representative Richard H. Poff, Republican of Virginia, for the Supreme Court.

title: Guidelines on Dividends
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Following is Dividend Guideline No. 3 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest guidelines relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: U. S. and Soviet Sign Two Nuclear Control Accords
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The United States and the Soviet Union signed two nuclear control agreements today that a high Administration source described as appetizers to a comprehensive strategicarms pact that we and members of Congress. The pacts provide for modernization of the existing hot line link between Washington and Moscow and common procedures to prevent the accidental outbreak of nuclear war between the two countries. have good hope of negotiating in the near future. Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko signed the agreement in a formal ceremony at the State Department attended by several hundred foreign ambassadors, Administration officials and members of Congress. The pacts provide for modernization of the existing hot line link between Washington and Moscow and common procedures to prevent the accidental outbreak of nuclear war between the two countries. Both Mr. Rogers and Mr. Gromyko praised the agreements as the first practical results of the twoyear strategicarms limitation talks. Both added the hope that a broader agreement could be reached when the talks resume in Nov. 15 in Vienna.

title: Police in Springfield, Mass., Arrest 7 in New Disorders
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30 (AP)Groups of white and Puerto Rican youths armed with rocks and clubs roamed the streets again tonight.

title: SYNOD OF BISHOPS OPENS IN VATICAN
description: ROME, Sept. 30  Roman Catholic bishops from around the world opened the third Synod of Bishops here today with an 80minute mass in the Renaissance grandeur of the Sistine Chapel.

title: FORMER COLLEAGUES BACK COLLEGE HEAD
description: DURHAM, N. H., Sept. 30Dr. Thomas N. Bonner was inaugurated as president of the University of New Hampshire today after a delegation of administrators and faculty members from the University of Cincinnati came here to attack news reports critical of him.

title: U.S. COMBAT DEATHS PUT AT 29 FOR WEEK
description: SAIGON, Sept. 30 (AP)The United States command announced today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week. It was the first time in 11 weeks that United States combat deaths exceeded 20.

title: N,A,A.C,P. SCORES OCEAN HILL BOARD
description: The metropolitan council of branches of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called yesterday for the resignation of all members of the controversial Ocean HillBrownsville District 23 local school board and the election of a more representative board.

title: Pound Circulation Decreases 4.37Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: ROBERT LEE CARTER
description: Former general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ... Resigned after 20 years in 1068 in a dispute over dismissal of a white lawyer on his staff who criticized Supreme Court as not going far enough in civil rights rulings ... Now a senior partner in the New York law firm of Poletti, Freidin, Prashker, Feldman & Gartner . . . In his early fifties ... Married ... Has two sons . . . Lives in Harlem ... President of the National Committee Against Discrimination in Housing ... A cochairman of the National Conference of Black Lawyers.

title: South Yemen Chief in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP)The Premier of Southern Yemen, Ali Nasser Mohammed, arrived In Moscow today for a visit that his Soviet hosts see as certain to improve already friendly relations between the two countries.

title: We Don't Have Any Friends There
description: This nation's relationship with Latin America is about to be drastically, perhaps permanently, damaged as the result of narrow and inflexible commerial pressures.

title: AMEX STOCKS RISE IN ACTIVE TRADING
Text of Draft Convention on Prohibition of Biological Weapons
description: GENEVA. Sept. 30  Following is the official English version of a draft convention as the prohibition of biological warfare and of the production of biological weapons, as referred to the United Nations General Assembly today by the Geneva disarmament conference:

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.4 From WeekAgo Level
HARRIS ASKS CURB ON BIG COMPANIES
description: Senator Fred R. Harris, who a week ago declared his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, came to New York yesterday and called for the breakup of most of the country's major corporations.

title: PANEL HERE TOLD OF HOUSING SNAGS
description: Some kind of centralized, Federal housing program is needed to replace the layers of local, state, regional and Federal agencies now involved in the construction of publicly aided housing, speakers said yesterday at a Federal Trade Commission hearing.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WINDSOR, Vt., Sept. 30 (AP)The authorities reported minor trouble tonight at Windsor State Prison, where inmates have refused to return to work until 14 demands are satisfied. Officials said a small group of prisoners, all of whom were returned to their cells, had pounded metal objects against thte bars of their cells, yelled at guards and set small fires with magazines.

title: Loomis of S.E.C. Talks
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 30Philip A. Loomis Jr., making his first address since becoming a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, plunged into substantive issues here tonight and offered his views on several problems of the securities industry.

title: Advertising:
description: Two officials of General Foods, which last year spent over $90million on TV advertising, yesterday called on advertisers to contribute toward improving the programing.

title: Tinajero Eats, Trainer Worries
description: The television crews had left, but Laz Barrera hadn't stopped worrying.

title: Protestant Workers in Belfast Battle Catholics After a Blast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 30  Protestants fought with Roman Catholics on a Belfast construction site today after a blast last night in a bar frequented by Protestants killed two men and injured 27.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: (Sept. 30, 1971) THE PRESIDENT

title: Paperwork Agency Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)  A Senate securities subcommittee heard proposals today that a nongovernmental coordinating agency be created to handle a mounting paperwork logjam that, it was said, threatened to inundate the stock certificate transfer process.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $825million up 19 per cent from the yearearlier $692million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,644,000,000, up 13 per cent from $6,761,000,000.

title: Kheel Pails Out of Race Without Entering It
description: Theodore W. Kheel yesterday became the first public figure this year to pull his hat out of the ring.

title: N.Y. Reserve Picks Director
description: Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, has been appointed director of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York to fill the unexpired term of the late Whitney M. Young Jr. Mr. Pifer, 50 years old, became president of the Carnegie Corporation in 1967.

title: Urgent Call for Peace
description: The 57to38 majority by which the Senate has once again passed Senator Mansfield's amendment for withdrawal of all United States forces from Indochina within six monthsa cutdown from the original time limit of nine monthsreflects spreading national disillusionment with President Nixon's Vietnamization policy. The vote is an impressive demonstration of the determination in Congress to reassert legislative authority, if necessary, to bring the war to the early end the President has promised but not delivered.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OLIVER W. NICOLL, 67, A STAGE MANAGER
description: Oliver W. Nicoll, a company manager of stage, concert and ballet presentations, died yesterday of pneumonia in Midtown Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 820 West End Avenue.

title: WALTER N. ROTHSCHILD JR.
description: A 51yearold native New Yorker... resigned two years ago as president of Abraham & Straus to spend more time on social causes ... shortly after was named chairman of the New York Urban Coalition, a nonprofit organization seeking solutions to the problems of poverty and urban decay . . . Graduated 1942 cum laude from Harvard with bachelor of arts degree... Was associated with Bloomingdale's before joining A.&S. in 1950 as manager of its Hempstead store ... Married to former Virginia Trott... They have four children and live in Laurel Hollow, L. I.

title: RESERVE SPURRED MONEY MARKET
description: The Federal Reserve System pumped $1.1billion into the money market during the week ended Wednesday, the central bank's weekly statement, showed yeseterday.

title: Theater: Anderson's Solitaire, Double Solitaire
description: The death of a civilization and the death of a marriage these are the formidable topics Robert Anderson takes on in his double bill Solitaire, Double Solitaire, which opened last night at the John Golden Theater. This is the first new play, or playsof the sluggard Broadway season, and their craftsmanship and insights are most welcome.

title: MISS WELTING SINGS OSCAR AT CITY OPERA
description: Ruth Welting, a childsized soprano whose voice is already much too big to ride halffare, and probably still growing, sang, her first Oscar with the New York City Opera on Wednesday in Verdi's Un Ballo in Maschera.

description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily correspond to those in other financial centers but generally indicate market trends.

A California highway patrolman here said that about 10 inches of snow fell overnight on Donner Summit and four inches iS the lower areas.

title: Dr. Bunche, Ailing, Retires From U.N.; Is Back in Hospital
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30Ralph J. Bunche, Under Secretary General for Special Political Affairs and winner of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1950, has retired from the United Nations.

title: STOCKS REVERSE A LOSING STREAK
description: The stock market, shaking its recent lethargy, posted a gain yesterday. The DowJones industrial average, the market's most closelywatched barometer, had declined seven times in the last eight sessions, prior to yesterday's mild snapback.

title: ALBERT A. BRENNAN
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 30 (UPI) Albert Andrews Brennan, a retired treasurer of the New York Yankees baseball team, died yesterday at a nursing home here. He was 97 years old.

title: Check of PayPrice Freeze Finds a Violation Rate of 5%
description: Government agents who made 1,728 spot checks across the country on the wageprice freeze last week turned up violations in 88 cases, 5 per cent of the total, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday in response to an inquiry.

title: Banks to Fund Alabama Payroll
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30Three of Alabama's largest banks came to the financial rescue of Gov. George C. Wallace's administration today by agreeing to meet a $3.4million state employes' payroll from their own funds.

title: 6 Antiwar Sailors Given Refugein Catholic Church
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 (AP) Six sailors who are opposed to the war were given refuge in a Roman Catholic church today as their ship, the aircraft carrier Constellation, prepared to return to Vietnam.

title: House Republicans Elect
description: WASHINGTON. Sept. 29 (AP) House Republicans today elected. Representative Samuel L. Devine of Ohio vice chairman of the Republican Conference. The conference, headed by Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, is composed of all House Republicans. It meets periodically to discuss legislation and patty policy.

title: AMALIA GUERRERO
description: An actress, singer and dancer of Yabucoa, P. R., retired from the American stage in 1939 when she married and became Mrs. Mariano Guerrero . . . For nearly 20 years she traveled all over Latin America with her husband, now retired but then a chemical company vice president . . . Settled at 1035 Fifth Avenue . . . She became active in the Hudson Guild and the Community Service Society . . . In 1956 she founded and became president of the Society of Friends of Puerto Rico to bring to mainlanders' awareness Puerto Rican achievein the creative arts.

title: Lee A. White, Journalist With The Detroit News, 84
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30 (UPI)Lee A. White, who was associated in various capacities with The Detroit News until his retirement in 1952, died last night in his home in Birmingham, Mich., after suffering a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: After Decade, Maris Resents Asterisk
description: Ten years ago today, Roger Maris of the New York Yankees hit his 61st home run to surpass by one baseball's most revered accomplishment  60 homers by Babe Ruth in 1927. Now a beer salesman in Gainesville, Fla., Maris said that his memories of 1961 are punctuated with an asterisk.

title: NoStrings Funds for Colleges Are Backed by House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The House Education and Labor Committee adopted legislation today that would, for the first time, provide nonearmarked Federal grants to every college and university in the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Plans U.S. Pact
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 30  A South Korean official said today that the Government had decided to conclude an agreement restricting textile exports with the United States by Oct. 15.

title: HEARINGS ARE SET BY KNAPP INQUIRY
description: Public hearings on the findings of a commission that is investigating corruption in the New York Police Department will begin Oct. 8.

title: Mr. Agnew's Greek Visit
description: Vice President Agnew's official visit to Greece later this month will give the military dictatorship there the biggest prestige boost it has enjoyed since it seized power in 1967. It will strip the last vestige of credibility from Washington's pious claim that it disapproves of the Athens regime and has tried to persuade the ruling colonels to restore democracy.

title: British Identify Russian Agent Who Defected With List of Spies
description: LONDON, Sept. 30  The Foreign Office today identified the Soviet agent who defected to Britain early in September as Oleg Lyalin.

title: DEMOCRATS ELECT ROSSETTI 3D TIME
description: Frank G. Rossetti, who looks like the stereotype of an oldtime Tammany leader but who wields considerably less power, was elected Manhattan Democratic leader yesterday over the opposition of Reform Democrats.

title: The Screen: Matthau Portrays 'Kotch' in Lemmon's Debut as Director:A Garrulous Old Man Aids Unwed Mother Young Woman Played by Deborah Winters
description: The best, or, at least, the most interesting comedy usually has to do with a person in a situation of such fearful desperation that he can only recognize it at the risk of his sanity. It can be physical comedy (Harold Lloyd, hanging onto the hands of a clock, 50 floors above the street in "Safety Last"), or poetic comedy (Antoine Doinel, coping, rather badly, with a bourgeoise marriage in "Bed and Board"), or satiric comedy (George Segal accepting with good grace the fact that he can't scare his mother to death in "Where's Poppa?").In extreme situations, these films seem to say, gallantry is the only recourse, as well as the only solution.There is, however, another kind of comedy, which, because it is less rigorous, is more reassuring and much more popular, epecially on television. This is the comedy that places a person in a situation that really isn't desperate at all, although the person reacts to it in desperate ways. At its most ridiculous, it's Lucille Ball disguising herself as her own maid to fool a bill collector who really wants to return some money. These are comedies for which there are always solutions."Kotch," the first film to be directed by Jack Lemmon, takes what is essentially a desperate situationwhat to do with a lonely, garrulous old man who is a nuisance to his son and daughter-in-lawand transform it into a nice, sentimental Life-Can-Be-Beautiful comedy of the second order. It's theme song is called "Life Is What You Make It," which is about as equivocal as the movie ever gets.It's apparent, quite early in the film, that Kotch (Walter Matthau) is not fit material for one of those euphemistically designated retirement homes his son and daughter-in-law try to dump him into.Although he is supposed to be in his 70's, he is athletic in his movements and his hair is so fakely white that I never believed for a moment that he was more than 50. He has $15,000 or $20,000 in the bank. Children love him. He has a writer's enthusiasm for words (a babysitter is a "teenage mercenary"), and he is more than a match for all of the plastic people who come up against him (his daughter-in-law, a park police officer, a humorless psychologist).How the old man finds new happinessmostly by seeing a sweet, unwed mother through her pregnancy (right through her delivery, in fact, in the ladies room of a filling station)is the awfully lovable substance of a movie that mistakes sentimentality for gallantry.Matthau, who is a fine, un-tricky actor, plays old Kotch with as few affectations as can be allowed by a film that pretends to an innocence it never has. I also liked Deborah Winters as the pregnant teenager he befriends, but Felicia Farr, Charles Aidman and all the other cast members never have an opportunity to be more than the situation-comedy stereotypes they were obviously meant to be.Lemmon's ability as a director must be judged, I think, as much by the material with which he chose to make his debut, as by the end product. Both are so unadventurous as to be downright depressing."Kotch" opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall, which, for the duration of this run, becomes the world's most gigantic television set.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: HENRY MODELL IS 80 TODAY! God bless a wonderful man. Advt.

title: PAIL I EIGHT OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Sept. 25 was below the volume in the corresponding week last year. Intercity truck tonnage increased 4.1 per cent in the week.

title: COLLEGES ADVISED TO STOP COMPETING
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 30Dr. William J. McGill, the president of Columbia University, was among a number of speakers here today who urged greatly increased cooperation between the state's public and private colleges during the current period of financial difficulty in higher education.

title: 10,000 DRAFT CALL SET FOR 3 MONTHS
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The Defense Department issued a draft call today for 10,000 men spread over October, November and December.

title: Dodgers Go Out 21 Victors, but to No Avail
Meeting With Nixon, Educators Propose Fivefold Rise in Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The leaders of nine national education organizations told President Nixon today that the Federal share of public education costs should be increased from 8 per cent to 40 per cent to relieve the heavy tax burden on property owners.

title: COURTLAND KELSEY
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 30Courtland Kelsey, who retired from the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett in 1952, died yesterday in the Hospital Center at Orange. He was 83 years old and lived at 157 South Harrison Street).

title: Diversity Endangered
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30  In the whole mysterious gift of life, what most astonishes and excites is diversity. No two human beings are the same. The tiniest snowflake, the most distant star, the intricately veined leaf of a tree are each unique. From jack rabbit to giraffe, from crocodile to swan, from tiger to hummingbird, nature delights in varieties of form and phenomena.

title: Legislator Offers Plan to Decentralize City's Government
description: A comprehensive plan to decentralize city government and give wide powers to elected community boards, including limited power to tax, was advanced yesterday by Assemblyman Andrew Stein, Manhattan Democrat.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Union Pacific Corporation announced yesterday the election of John C. Kenefick, 49, as president of Union Pacific Railroad Company, a subsidiary. Mr. Kenefick, who has been chief executive officer of Union Pacific's transportation division, will replace Edd H. Bailey who is retiring. Mr. Bailey will continue as a director of both Union Pacific Railroad Company and the Union Pacific Corporation.

title: Japanese Predict Early Revaluation
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 (Reuters)  Japanese economists and businessmen today discussed what they considered the optimum or most likely margin for an upward revaluation of the yen, with predictions ranging to almost 15 per cent.

title: Regional Theater Making Inroads Along Broadway
description: It's almost impossible to do a straight play on Broadway from scratch, said Arvin Brown, a director, who has taken an alternate paththe regional theater.

title: Foe Attacks 2 Camps Near Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30The Saigon command said today that Communist forces attacked two South Vietnamese base camps along the Cambodian border northwest of here yesterday.

title: Hospital Campaign Opens
description: The 1971 campaign of the United Hospital Fund opens today in a time of great need. There is a financial crisis in hospitals that is threatening patient care and programs of medical education. One hospital, a member of the fund, said: It will be virtually impossible to fulfill our commitment unless we have adequate support for our programs. Give generously to the United Hospital Fund, 3 East 54th Street, New York, N. Y. 10022.

title: Marichal Beats PadresHomer by Kingman
description: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 The San Francisco Giants finally fell across the finish line tonight with the Western championship of the National League when they defeated the San Diego Padres, 51, in their 162d and final game of the regular season.

title: DAY CARE SERVICE FOR ALL IS VOTED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The House voted tonight to create a vast network of day care centers and social services for children of all economic levels.

title: Ruth Kenworthy, Manager Of the Schola Cantorum
description: Ruth Dewolfe Kenworthy, chorus manager of the Schola Cantorum since 1942, died Monday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 82 years old and lived at 181 Claremont Avenue.

title: United Air and INA Reshape Structure
description: United Air Lines and the INA Corporation, in moves designed to strengthen management, announced major reorganization plans yesterday.

title: Texts of U. S.Soviet Pacts on Averting Atom War and on Hot Line
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 20Following as made public here today, are the texts of a United StatesSoviet agreement on measures to reduce the risk of nuclear warfare between the two countries and of an agreement to improve the direct communications link between them. The communications accord also contains an annex, not included here, that details technical and procedural aspects.

title: U.S. OFFERS PLAN FOR TERMINATION OF IMPORT SURTAX
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30The United States offered today to remove its new import surcharge if other leading countries let their currencies float freely upward against the dollar and if some take specific measures in the coming weeks to reduce barriers to United States exports.

title: Dock Shutdown Begins As Talks Here Break Off
description: Dockworkers will not he on their jobs today, as negotiations broke off early this morning here between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New, York Shipping Association.

title: ROBERT BUDGE McKAY
description: Dean of New York University School of Law since 1967 .. Chairman of the Citizens' Union .... Nationally known authority on constitutional law and the criminal justice system who has frequently served on factfinding committees studying critical issues for the state and city governments . . . Chairman of the 1965 Advisory Council on Reapportionment ... Graduate of Yale University Law School . . . Born in Wichita, Kan., Aug. 11, 1919 . . . Professor at N.Y.U. since 1956, associate dean since 1963.

title: NeoIsolationismOr Anti?
description: President Nixon has sought to reassure the finance ministers and central bankers at the International Monetary Fund sessions in Washington that he is no isolationist. Indeed, he criticized the growing and disturbing isolationism in our countrya mood to which the President himself had contributed heavily with the chauvinistic tone of his address to Congress last month.

title: JUDGES APPOINT 9 TO STUDY UPRISING AT ATTICA PRISON
description: A ninemember citizens committee with instructions to conduct a full end impartial investigation of all aspects of the Attica prison uprising in which 30 hostages and 32 prisoners were killed was named yesterday by five judges.

title: FamilyCare Center Will Open At Harlem's Sydenham Hospital
description: Sydenham Hospital announced yesterday that it, would open a comprehensives, familycare center next week that was expected to replace the emergency room as the family doctor.

title: CONNECTICUT GETS DISTRICTING PLAN
description: HARTFORD, Sept. 30  The General Assembly of Connecticut received its longawaited reapportionment plan this afternoon and the usual political controversy ensued.

title: White and Black Play the 'Skin Game' in Film
description: Despite a theme that is expressed usually in terms of ponderous imponderables, Paul Bogart's "Skin Game," which opened yesterday at Loew's State 1 and Loew's Cine, is a race-relations comedy that really means to be about how people relate to one another.It isn't a very consistant movie, and its comedy misses much more often than it hits. But it is at least willing to kid the weightiest of its issues, and sometimes it' is pretty funny, and it is never so dully dishonest as to pretend to any pieties it hasn't earned.Its heroes are a white man (James Garner) and a black man (Lou Gossett) who at a time not long before the Civil War wander around the South playing master and slave in a fairly profitable game in which Garner auctions off Gossett, pockets the cash, and then secretly frees his pal so he can sell him all over again at the next town they come across.The two men are equals, buddies, who enjoy a kind of personal freedom that it is difficult to credit given the times, and given the country, and that is always in dangeras much from love or extracurricular loyalties as from the crusading zeal of a John Brown or the greed of a slave trader who really means his business.It is the serious slave trader, somehow abetted by John Brownthe plot has a good many lacunae, and I suspect extensive and rather sloppy cutting  who unbalances things by selling Lou Gossett into real bondage and thus opening up the movie to a range of intellectual complications that are largely to its credit but mostly beyond its control.In a curious way, "Skin Game" tries to apply a set of traditional emotional responses to a set of new, sophisticated, highly ironic observations, and so there is never enough contact between what the movie knows and what it seems able to feel.When Gossett finds himself herded together with a crew of silent, naked black slaves from Africa (he's from New Jersey), whose special skill is to tame, and thus, I guess, enslave, wild horses, we find ourselves in the presence of attitudes that the film can locate well enough but cannot develop without violating its own ground rules, without becoming a much more bitter and universal comedy than it wants to be.Through the beginning of their adventures, moving from towns like "Fair Shake" to towns like "Dirty Shame" and conning the local worthies, Garner and Gossett seem like originals out of American humor, and in a better movie they might have continued that way. But "Skin Game" is neither written nor directed with enough toughness, or enough compassion, to realize its potential.And so it falls into a series of teasing and unsatisfying propositions about a pair of scoundrels not quite clever enough for their life's work and too easily redeemed for their own souls' sake.Odd things happen to performances in a situation in which almost everybody is consciously playing a part. Susan Clark and Brenda Sykes, the heroes' love interests, have insufficient stake in the game really to matter. Garner, who plays broadly, is appealing at first and finally tiresome. But Lou Gossett, whose various roles entail genuine risk and who is always parodying reality, comes at times to a multilevel characterization that is very agile, very antic, and very right for a man who lives by turning his own peril into profit.

title: France's Croesus Is Set Back Again
description: PARIS, Sept. 30The news fell quietly in Franceone more reverse for the man whose name in the prewar and earlier postwar period was practically synonymous with Croesus, the king who acquired great wealth.

title: U.S. GIVES JAPAN PLAN ON TEXTILES
description: TOKYO, Sept, 30 (Reuters) The United States told Tapan today that import quotas would be imposed on Japanese textiles on Oct. 15, unless a olan for settlement of the longstanding dispute was accepted.

title: Police Say Women Led Theft Ring
description: A stealtoorder ring that specialized in heavyconstruction equipment was smashed yesterday after Federal and local authorities ended a fourmonth investigation, uncovering more than $100,000 worth of equipment that included bulldozers, tractortrailers and dump trucks.

title: Ward B. Arbury, ExState Aide On Discrimination, Dies at 82
description: Ward B. Arbury, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination from 1953 to 1956 and a member of the commission until 1958, died yesterday at his home, 465 West 23d Street. His age was 82.

title: PODGORNY LEAVES ON TRIP TO HANOI
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30President Nikolai V. Podgorny left here today for Hanoi at the head of a highranking economic and military delegation in what was viewed as an attempt to court North Vietnam's favor after similar effort by Peking.

title: Japanese Concern Pays $810,000 to Victims in Pollution Poisoning Casel
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30In an ancient Buddhist temple here this morning, the president of leading chemical company paid courtordered compensation to the representatives of 77 victims of mercury poisoning caused by industrial wastes dumped by his company.

title: Bossism Wins in Manhattan
description: Balloting by members of the Democratic party's executive committee in Manhattan yesterday has perpetuated a political anachronism. Assemblyman Frank G. Rossetti, once chauffeur for Tammanyboss Carmine DeSapio, remains in the driver's seat as Manhattan county leader. He won rather handily on the first ballot when more progressive members of the regular organization refused to support a challenger endorsed by Reform Democrats.

title: Largest Japanese Bank Is Formed by a Merger
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 Japan's largest commercial bank is scheduled to open its doors tomorrow when the merger of the Dai Ichi and Nippon Kangyo banks is completed.

title: Federal Judge Raises Issue Of Freeze's Constitutionality
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that President Nixon's wageprice freeze and the act of Congress giving him authority to impose the controls raised substantial constitutional questions. The judge said the matler should be reviewed by threejudge panel.

title: TV: Some Pleasant Surprises in Children's Fare
description: After several weekends of watching television programs for children, I have to admit that I still don't know much about children's televisionbut I know what I like. And what I like, so far at least, may not jibe too closely with the theories of some determined reformers.

title: On to the Poorhouse
description: New York State's economy is in serious trouble. Despite a facade of stability, the state's fiscal conditiononce the envy of the nationis slowly rotting. Its population, until recently a rich blend of all ages, races and economic classes, is now increasingly dominated by the helplessly poor, by civil servants and retirees.

title: CHINA'S TOP AIDES NOT AT RECEPTION
description: HONG KONG, Friday, Oct. 1 The absence of Premier Chou Enlai and other topranking officials from the reception in Peking last night on the eve of China's National Day has deepened speculation here that the Peking Government has serious problems.

title: G.M. Recalls 100,000 Opels
description: DETROIT, Sept. 30The General Motors Corporation said today it was recalling 100,000 of its 1970, 1971 and 1972 Opel cars to correct a safety defect. During a highimpact collision it is possible for the windshield to be dislodged, G.M. said.

title: SILENT MAJORITY 52 PICK IN PACE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 30 Silent Majority is the early 5to2 favorite to capture tomorrow night's $81,216 Roosevelt Futurity for 2yearold pacers. The 12yearold mile race has attracted 10 starters.

title: Mongolia Reports Crash
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30  The Mongolian press agency said today that a Chinese Air Force plane, having apparently lost its bearings on a night flight, penetrated deep into Mongolia earlier this month and crashed, killing nine persons aboard.

title: Black Firm Joins Big Board
description: The First Harlem Securities Corporation yesterday was voted into membership on the New York Stock Exchange. The new firm, which is blackowned and operated, grew out of a branch office of Shearson, Hammill & Co. in Harlem. Its decision to join the Big Board and its probable acceptance had been indicated previously.

title: Market Place: Profit Seeking  vs. Social Aims
description: There's a native of West Virginia who takes the once scenic route between Wheeling, W. Va., and St. Clairsvile, Ohio, on his way to Columbus every other week. What he sees makes him cynical about stripmine reclamation programs and the social responsibility of corporations.

title: Merger News
description: The Foster Grant Company, Inc., and the FMC Corporation announced yesterday they were conducting preliminary investigations in connection with a possible merger of Foster Grant into FMC.

title: About Pro Football
description: The game of the weekend is in Dallas, where the Cowboys and Redskins, both unbeaten, meet in the Cotton Bowl. But that one will not be on television here. Instead the Sunday fare is San Francisco at Philadelphia, Channel 2, 1 P.M., followed by the Giants' game from St. Louis.

title: Uncontested Saigon Election Is Assailed at Paris Talks
description: PARIS, Sept. 30 (Reuters)The uncontested South Vietnamese presidential election Sunday came in for some harsh words from Hanoi and the Vietcong today as the stalled Paris peace talks resumed after twoweek break.

title: Big Board Seeking Views Of Companies on Changes
description: The New York Stock Exchange, in a break with tradition, disclosed yesterday that it was seeking advice from the heads of all its listed companies on how the exchange should be reorganized. The Big Board has been criticized at times for having what has been described as a parochial attitude and for being operated as a socalled private club that did not have the public interest as its paramount concern.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Meany Criticizes Policies on Freeze and China
description: George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., warned yesterday against what he called tendency to govern by propaganda and scientific deception.

title: GAS SWAP PLANNED BY BROOKLYN UNION
description: The Brooklyn Union Gas Company has arranged a seasonal swap of natural gas with the Consolidated Edison Company, Gordon C. Griswold, president, told a luncheon meeting of security analysts yesterday.

title: Goodell to Head a Prison Study Panel
description: Former Senator Charles E. Goodell announced yesterday the formation of a committee of leading scholars to examine the validity of all our assumptions about prisonsand about prison reform.

title: 2 Opposition Candidates Apparently Win in Spain
description: MADRID, Sept. 30 (UPI)Nearly complete returns indicated today that the only two candidates in Spain's general election who showed some opposition to the Government had been elected to Parliament.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Just before the start of the 1910 season, a fouralarm fire raged through the wooden stands of the Washington Senators' ball park and left a tangle of charred timbers. The mustached fire chief inspected the ruins the next day and offered an expert opinion.

title: FactFinding for Attica
description: Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals and the presiding justices of the four departments of the state's Appellate Division, given an unusual responsibility, have discharged it well. In the wake of the tragedy at Attica, with its aftermath of outright falsifications and unanswered questions, Governor Rockefeller properly turned to the bench for impartial selection of factfinding group that would itself be free of bias. The Governor's only mandate to the judges was that they name panel members representing all elements of the community.

title: F.D.A. Officials Dispate Report of Ban on PCB
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Officials of the Food and Drug Administration objected to an article that appeared in The New York Times today that stated that they had been amazed that a ban on the chemical contaminant PCB had existed in Britain.

title: ITALIAN PARTY ENDS CONFERENCE IN SPLIT
description: ROME, Sept. 30 A tense sixday leadership meeting of the Christian Democratic party, Italy's strongest political group, ended today in bitter disagreement between a majority of moderates and a leftwing group.

title: New Florida Countdown: Disney World Is Opening
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Sept. 30 Disney World opens to the public tomorrow, and the atmosphere among Florida business interests is as thick with tension as a Cape Kennedy countdown.

title: Standard Oil Fined on Spill
description: RICHMOND, Calif., Sept. 30 (UPI)Standard Oil Company was fined $1,000 today on charges of being responsible for a 30,000gallon oil spill last July 28.

title: Weapons Are Sought
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 30State officials disclosed today that anxiety over possible weapons hidden inside Attica prison was so great that five teams of security men armed with mobile metaldetecting devices had been set to searching the prison compound.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: Brown opens its Ivy League campaign tomorrow against Penn, and Coach Len Jardine has devoted much of the Bruins' preparations to the defensive secondary. The Bruins tied the score in the fourth quarter last week against Rhode Island only to succumb to an aerial attack that carried the Rams to victory. Jardine is well aware of Penn's new find, Tom Pinto, a sopho more quarterback who directed a Penn attack that gained more than 400 yards in defeating Lehigh.

title: 45 Drug Arrests in Europe Are Based On Evidence Compiled by U. S. Agents
description: Over the last three weeks small teams of French policemen have quietly arrested 43 suspected members of one of the major European rings supplying heroin to organized crime in the United States. At the same time the Spanish police tracked down two Corsican gangsters, living in Madrid, who are believed to head the ring.

title: Hurricane Pounds and Floods North Carolina Area
description: MOREHEAD CITY, N. C., Sept. 30 (AP)Hurricane Ginger pounded 70 miles of the North Carolina shoreline with winds, tides and rains today, then stalled slightly inland and caused serious flooding to the north. She was downgraded to a tropical storm.

title: EDWIN B. BRODERICK
description: Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Albany ... Consecrated in May, 1969... Favored state aid to parochial schools during last Legislature, an issue the Governor also stanchly supported ... Born Jan. 16, 1917, in New York City ... Ordained in 1942 after graduating from St. Joseph's Seminary in Yonkers ... Assistant pastor at St. Patrick's Cathedral here, 1947 to 1954 ... Secretary to Cardinal Spellman until 1964 when named president of St. Joseph's ... In 1967 was appointed auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of New York.

title: KNICKS DOWN PACERS FOR 5 IN ROW, 9896
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 30 The New York Knickerbockers kept their unbeaten preseason streak alive tonight by defeating the American Basketball Association's Indiana Pacers, 9896, before a crowd of 9,479.

title: Polling Places Are Open Today for Registering
description: Polling places will be open today and tomorrow in the metropolitan area for the registration of voters in the 18to20 year age group and for others who have moved or [have not voted in the last two elections.

title: CHARLES MORRISON
description: Charles Morrison, a film editor at WPIXTV since the station went on the air in 1948, died last Tuesday while vacationing in New Mexico. He was 67 years old and lived at 440 East 56th Street.

title: Solitaire Opens Theater Season
description: The Broadway theater season, opened last night as the curtain rang up on Solitaire, Double Solitaire, Robert Anderson's program of two plays, at the John Golden Theater, and all indications were that the big midtown houses would be busier than they were last season.

title: RollsRoyce Holders Urged To Vote for Its Liquidation
description: LONDON, Sept. 30 (AP)Rupert Nicholson, receiver for RollsRoyce, Ltd., strongly urged shareholders today to vote for voluntary liquidation of the bankrupt company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Recently the New York Telephone Company reduced the number of message units included in the flat monthly rate from 75 to 50. This led to an increase in most people's bills, which, in view of the increase in the flat rate that went into effect several months ago, is an arbitrary and highhanded imposition on the goodwill and purses of all telephone subscribers.

title: Senator Harris Speaks Here On His Antimonopoly Bill
description: Senator Fred R. Harris, the Oklahoma Democrat who is running for the nomination for President, came to New York yesterday to underscore a major theme of his populist campaignbreaking up business monopolies.

title: Mrs. Reventlow Married Here
description: Mrs. Margaret Drayton Reventlow, widow of Count Court Haugwitz Hardenberg Reventlow and a descendant of John Jacob Astor, was married here yesterday to Lewis Carlton Davis, president of Happenstance, a division of the Puritan Fashions Corporation. The Rev. Kenneth Jones performed the private ceremony in the vestry at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Baghdad Says Kurdish Chief Escaped Attempt on His Life
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30 Mustafa Barzani, the Kurdish leader in northern Iraq, escaped unharmed in an attempt on his life yesterday, the Baghdad radio reported tonight.

title: Dr. LeRoy Bowman, Sociologist And Liberal Party Leader, Dies
description: Dr. LeRoy Bowman, professor emeritus of sociology at Brooklyn College and a longtime leader in the Liberal party, died yesterday of congestive heart failure in Long Island City Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 110 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

title: FAYROUZ HIGHLIGHTS ARAB MUSIC EVENT
description: Since music from Arab countries is seldom performed in our concert halls, the appearance of Fayrouz, La Troupe Populaire Libanaise and the Kerakalla Dancers at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night offered an opportunity to sample some Arab musical styles as heard currently in Lebanon.

title: Books of The Times
description: SHAKESPEARE, SPENSER, DONNE. Renaissance Essays by Frank Kermode. 308 pages. Viking. $7.95.

title: Petition for Vote on Statehood With 55,398 Names Is Rejected
description: The drive for a November referendum to make New York City a separate state was set back yesterday when City Clerk Herman Katz rejected a petition with more than 50,000 signatures.

title: Aleksandr Vologdin Dies; Soviet Paleontology Expert
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30Aleksandr G. Vologdin, a Soviet paleontologist, died here Tuesday at the age of 75, it was announced today.

title: Shop Talk
description: There isn't so much talk these days of cultural deprivation on Manhattan's West Side. After all, besides Lincoln Center, there are Chinese restaurants and burgeoning boutiques. One of the first and liveliest of the fashion shops to recognize that swingers were dwelling in the high rise apartment houses along West End Avenue and Riverside Drive as well as on Lexington and Third Avenue is Charivari, which has prospered so much it has moved a few blocks south to Broadway and 83d Street. Everybody says this reminds them of the Valentino and Saint Laurent shops on Madison Avenue, the proprietor, Selma Weiser, said the other day. Indeed, the dcor, with its dark brown walls and steel and glass displays, is reminiscent of those Madison Avenue designers' shops.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Soling Class Racers Fail To Finish Within Time Limit
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Sept. 30 Dying winds kept the boats from finishing before the expiration of the 3hour time limit today in the world Soling Class sailing championships on Long Island Sound.

title: A Women's Lib Parableof 449 B. C.
description: Tamut, the Egyptian handmaiden, will not be found in any anthology of the women's liberation movement. But a new scholarly examination of her 2420yearold marriage contract has disclosed that she was well ahead of her time in asserting a wife's equality in such matters as property and divorce.

title: Boston Exchange Elects
description: Phil David Fine, president of the Commonwealth National Corporation, has been elected to the board of governors of the Boston Stock Exchange. The governors voted last June to open board membership to representatives of companies listed on the exchange. Mr. Fine is the first to be named to the governing board under this new policy.

title: SENATE IN IMPASSE OVER RHODESIAN ORE
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 The Senate got caught in a parliamentary impasse tonight over whether to permit the United States to import Rhodesian ore in defiance of a United Nations embargo.

title: Newport Sailboat Show Begins
description: NEWPORT, R. I., Sept. 30With the scissor snip of a yellow ribbon and the firing of a frigate's cannon, the Newport International Sailboat Show officially opened today for the marine trade. The public will get its chance to see the exhibitian for three days starting tomorrow.

title: Prisons Tour May Cost Dunne Chairmanship of Study Panel
description: The majority leader of the State Senate, Earl W. Brydges, reportedly upset by State Senator John R. Dunne's widely publicized oneman tour of the state's prisons, probably will not recommend Mr. Dunne to be chairman of a commission that will suggest legislative penal reform in the light of the Attica revolt. The commission is expected to be named soon.

title: Cities on Jobless List Set a 10Year Record
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI)The Labor Department today added the San FranciscoOakland and the GaryHammondEast Chicago, Ind., areas to its list of major cities with substantial unemployment, raising the number to 64, the highest in a decade.

title: ANTITRUST BILLS FOR SPORTS FILED
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30Legislation to strip professional baseball and football of antitrust exemptions was introduced in Congress today by Senator Sam J. Ervin, Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, and Representative Emmanuel Celler, Democrat of New York.

title: Nabisco Weighs Moving Offices to North Jersey
description: The 78yearold National Biscuit Company, which has a purchase option on a 120acre golf course near Morristown, N. J., confirmed yesterday that it was considering moving its national headquarters from New York City.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is as an Englishman on holiday in the City of New York that I want to comment on the Attica prison storming and subsequent official pronouncements. The impression I got was of a place and a people gone mad. No, mad is too kind a word.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES TRIM EARLY LOSS
description: New buying and short covering helped greatly to trim price losses of soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: Democratic Delegate Rule Aiding Big States Is Upset
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30A formula for allocating Democratic Convention delegates that would have given more power to the large states was overturned today by the United States Court of Appeals here. The unanimous formula of the threejudge appeals court reinstated a formula approved last February by the Democratic National Committee.

title: DOROTHY WADSWORTH
description: The wife of Dr. Robert H. Wadsworth, a dentist in Rochester, and the mother of two daughters, she describes herself as a fairly fulltime community volunteer . . . Born in Geneseo, N. Y. . . Fifty years old . . . Graduated from Mount Holyoke College, where she majored in economics and sociology . . President of Monroe County Neighborhood Health Center, set up to establish network of centers in county . . . Active with many community organizations . . . Hopes to do the best possible job in panel position.

title: 3 ININATES CHARGE THREATS IN ATTICA
description: BUFFALO, Sept. 30Three inmates of the Attica Correctional Facility testified today that guards had beaten them, and repeatedly threatened their lives since the rebellion at the prison was quelled Sept. 13.

title: THOMAS J. REDDINGTON
description: Thomas J. Reddington, a retired police sergeant who had served in Queens for more than 35 years, died Tuesday at his home, 6015 Woodside Avenue, Woodside, Queens. He was 80 years old.

title: FAISAL AND ARAFAT CONFER IN LEBANON
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 30King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, who is on a state visit to Lebanon, met here today with the Palestinian commando leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: These Wives Found Cure to Some of the Ills of Suburban Life
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y. The question is a painful one, and the women here waited a long while before they started asking it, even of themselves.

title: Giants Win Western Title
description: The San Francisco Giants clinched the Western Division title of the National League last night with a 51 victory over the Padres at San Diego. (Details on Page 49.)

title: Reserves Climb In Japan
description: TOKYO, Sept. 30 (UPI)Japan's reserves of gold and forgeign currency today stood at $13.38billion, an increase of $870million during September, the Finance Ministry estimated today.

title: B'nai B'rith Protests to U.N. Remark on Jews by Soviet
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith protested to the United Nations Security Council yesterday what it termed the blatant attack on Jews by Yakov A. Malik, the Soviet delegate, at a Council meeting last Saturday.

title: East and West Germans End Deadlock
description: BERLIN. Sept. 30The East and the West Germans today broke the deadlock that had stalled their talks on implementing the Big Four agreement on Berlin. They agreed to meet again tomorrow.

title: Man in the News
description: MOSCOW, Sept. 30The position of President of the Soviet Union, long viewed as peripheral to decision making here, has significantly gained in stature under Nikolai Viktorovich Podgorny, a 68yearold Ukrainian who began his career as an engineer in a sugarrefinery. In the years that followed the downfall of Nikita S. Khrushchev in 1964, Mr. Podgorny emerged as one of the principal leaders of the Soviet Union, after Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party chief, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Celebration in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, Sept. 30China's National Day was celebrated in Warsaw as usual this evening with a gala reception in the embassy.

title: Notes on People
description: Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg accepted an appointment as a university professor of law and diplomacy at American University in Washington, effective Jan. 1.

title: Yen Rises in Value
description: TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 1 (ReutersThe value of the yen rose today to a new high of almost 8 per cent above parity, with the Bank of Japan intervening at 33.51 yen to the dollar. Exchange banks were continuing to sell dollars, some of them expecting the yen to climb further to 320 per dollar, or 12.5 per cent above par.

title: I.R.A. Denies Responsibility
description: DUBLIN, Sept. 30The two wings of the Irish Republican Army, the official and the more militant provisional, denied tonight that they were responsible for the explosion in Belfast public house.

title: Economic, Governmental and Legal Factors Cited as Reason
description: Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines announced jointly yesterday that they had ended merger discussions that had been held intermittently for the last several months.

title: Books of The Times
description: MAURICE. By E. M. Forster. 256 pages. Norton. $6.95.

title: Eban, at U.N., Asks Talks Here With Riad of Egypt
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30Foreign Minister Abha of Israel proposed today that he And Foreign Min?? Mahmoud triad of Egypt ?? here in the immediate future to discuss peace in the Middle East.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I never cease to be amazed at how quickly you express your fears that our Constitution will be undermined editorial of Sept. 23 Prayers and Politics  whenever the words prayer and religion are used in any bill introduced by a member of the legislative branch of government.

title: Most Girls Just Pray
description: The High School Women's Coalition was formed several years ago to unite girls from high schools all over New York City. The members of the coalition were primarily concerned with issues relevant to girls in high schools. After meetings and discussions about what life is like for high school girls, we unanimously concluded that our curriculum was severely lacking in topic of vital concern to a large percentage of high school students; namely, contraception.

title: BURKE MARSHALL
description: Headed the Justice Department's civil rights division from 1961 to 1965 at the request of President John F. Kennedy and then Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy ... Fortynine years old today ... Named deputy dean of the Yale University Law School in April, 1970... Born in Plainfield, N. J.... Graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale Law School ... Practiced law in Washington for 10 years before assuming Justice Department post ... Author of book Federalism and Civil Rights, published in 1964.

title: TAIWAN IS LOSING BACKING OF LATINS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30At least three LatinAmerican countries were reported by diplomats today to be planning to abandon their support for the United States efforts to preserve Nationalist China's seat in the United Nations.

title: $290,000 Involved
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 30 Lehman Brothers has agreed to an outofcourt settlement of a stockholder suit charging it with improperly executing portfolio transactions on behalf of Lehman's corporation, a large closedend investment company it sponsors.

title: Weekend Fishing Outlook for Area
description: AREA AAnchored boats in the Farms and Klondike areas doing well with bluefish. Choppers, ranging from 3 to 8 pounds, being enticed by chummers using ground bunkerbacks and smelts. Lots of pansized porgies and white perch reported in the Manasquan River, while Barnegat Bay is producing some winter flounders and perch.

title: National Exchange Head Sets Retirement Nov. 1
description: Edward T. McCormick, president of the National Stock Exchange and a former president of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he would retire Nov. 1 and leave Wall Street after a 36year relationship with the securities industry.

title: Police Group Cites Roush
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) Representative J. Edward Roush, Democrat of Indiana, was honored today for his efforts in establishing 911 as a nationwide emergency telephone number. The National Fraternal Order of Police Detectives and Special Police awarded him a certificate.

title: Restaurant Boasts Natural Foods in a Serene Setting
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and ddcor (four triangles to none).

title: Miss Bacon's Arrest In Capitol Bombing Is Voided on Appeal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30The Federal Government acted illegally when it arrested Leslie Bacon in Washington to force her to testify before a Seattle grand jury about a bombing in the national Capitol, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held today.

title: SHIRLEY IMPECCABLE IN MET'S RIGOLETTO
description: One of the more versatileand one of the most musicianly and dependabletenors at the Metropolitan Opera is George Shirley. It sometimes seems as if each appearance finds him in a new role. Thus, when he sang the Duke in Verdi's Rigoletto on Wednesday night, it was for the first time with the company.His performance was typical in its impeccable style. It was a pleasure to hear the rhythmic accuracy of his Questa quella and the long phrasing in Fermi veder le lagrime. (It was a pity he wasn't allowed to sing the generally omitted cabaletta to the latter aria; he is one tenor who could sing it.)

title: AMOS HENIX
description: Executive director of Reality House, a rehabilitation center for narcotics addicts ... Born 42 years ago in Harlem Hospital... Is a former narcotics addict and convict... As a youth lived in Washington Heights and attended public schools there ... Dropped out of school in World War II to work as longshoreman... In 1967 was a member of a group that split with Exodus House, a narcotics treatment center, to form Reality House... Divorced and now lives in the Bronx with his second wife, the former Carole Rogavin, and their two young sons.

title: Board of Estimate Stalls Stadium Development Plan
description: A redevelopment plan linked to the city's proposed purchase of Yankee Stadium was stalled yesterday in the Board of Estimate.

title: Prices of Raw Farm Products Fell in Month Ended Sept. 15
description: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP)  Prices farmers receive for raw products, exempt from the Nixon Administration's freeze, dropped 2 per cent in September from the August level and averaged only 1 per cent more than a year before, the Agriculture Department announced today.

title: Lynn Oestreicher Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Lynn Oestreicher, daughter of Gerard Oestreicher of New York and Mrs. William Garson of New York and Westport, Conn., was married here yesterday to Noel Jeffrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton M. Raffer of Fort Lee, N. J. Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Grill.

title: Nixon Arrives in Florida
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Sept. 30 (AP)President Nixon and his party arrived at Homestead Air Force Base tonight aboard the Presidential aircraft and went to the Florida White House. The President, Mrs. Nixon and their daughter Julie Nixon Eisenhower boarded helicopter for Key Biscayne.

title: DEPOSITORY EYE IS CALLED AN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Nationwide extension of a New Yorkbased securities depository could reduce physical movement of stock certificates by 75 yer cent, Congress was told today.

title: Racial Justice Is a Goal of Church Union Delegates
description: DENVER, Oct. 1  Delegates to the Consultation on Church Union stressed their commitment to racial justice yesterday as they approved a series of recommendations to revitalize their goal of uniting nine Protestant denominations.

title: WIDE PEP PILL USE IN TRUCKING CITED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Four truck drivers told a Congressional panel today that from 75 per cent to perhaps as many as 90 per cent of all truck drivers use pep pills and amphetamines at least occasionally to stay awake during long hauls.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR WIRETAPPING CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) The Administration asked the Supreme Court today to permit it to wiretap without a court order whenever the President or the Attorney General determined it is required by the national security.

title: CHARLES N. ZABERER
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 Charles N. Zaberer, owner of Zaberer's Restaurant on Black Horse Pike near here, died yesterday in Atlantic City Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: BREAD AND ROSES TOO. Reporting About America. By Jack Newfield. 429 pages. Dutton. $8.95.

title: COLONEL'S LAWYERS OBJECT TO WITNESS
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 1The courtmartial of Col. Oran K. Henderson was conducted out of the presence of the jury today to allow for argument and testimony on a defense motion to prevent a key witness from appearing.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED IN THE WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 Daily Index numbers and spot primary market commodity prices Sept. 21, 1971, to Sept. 28, 1971:

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: I.M.F. ASKS FIXING OF MONEY RATES, CUT IN TRADE MRS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The member nations of the International Monetary Fund unanimously adopted today a nonbinding resolution urging as promptly as possible a return to relatively fixed exchange rates among currencies together with the reduction of restrictive trade and exchange practices.

title: Walkouts Are Cited
description: The Chesapeake & Ohio Railway and its more than 90 per cent controlled subsidiary, the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad, reported yesterday that consolidated system earnings had plummeted in the September quarter to $2million, or 21 cents a share, from $12million, or $1.39 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year.

title: U.S. Athens Envoy Confers With Caramanlis in Paris
description: ATHENS, Oct. 1The American Embassy confirmed tonght that United States Ambassador Henry J. Tasca met yesterday, in Paris with Constantine Caramanlis, the rightwing critic of the Athens regime whom many Greeks believe will figure strongly in any civilian government succeeding the country's present military one. Caramanlist, expremier of Greece, has lived in Paris since 1963.

title: TEENAGE COUPLE HELD IN A SLAYING
description: A tenage couple, characterized by the police as a prostitute and her pimp working West Side streets, were arrested yesterday in the slaying of a former official of New Jersey military academy.

title: Enemy Again Attacks Base in Cambodial
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2 (AP)Despite a nightlong pounding by allied aircraft, North Vietnamese troops were reported to have launched another ground attack early today against a South Vietnamese artillery base in eastern Cambodia.

title: Federal Employes Rally Here To Protest Delay in Pay Raise
description: Federal employes from the New York and New Jersey area marched down Broadway and held a twohour rally at Manhattan Center yesterday to protest President Nixon's freeze of their wages.

title: 4 of 6 New Issues Advance in Week
description: The new issue market, in which shares of companies are traded publicly for the first time, turned in a good performance this week although the number of stocks going public declined.

title: Confiscation in Chile
description: During his eleven months in office, President Allende has often promised fair compensation for American and other foreign enterprises nationalized in Chile. He has now defaulted on that pledge with a bizarre bookkeeping maneuver that effectively nullifies the possibility of any payment for three nationalized copper mines previously owned by two American firms.

title: Franco Marks 35 Years of Rule, Vows to Continue
description: MADRID, Oct. 1Generalissimo Francisco Franco observed the 35th anniversary of his rule today, saying to an applauding crowd that he would remain in power as long as God gives me life and a clear mind. He also ordered a wide amnesty.

title: Music: A Liszt Revival
description: It is the aim of the New York Philharmonic to shed light on Franz Liszt this season by reviving a series of longneglected works. Thursday night's concert was dedicated in its entirety to Liszt's The Legend of St. Elizabeth, and already the Philharmonic is accomplishing its aim.

title: D.A.R. Members Proud of Role
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 1Mrs. Sara Allison a member of the Guyanoga chapter of the New York State Daughters of the American Revolution, places her hands on the piano and the music begins.

title: McGovern to Face Problems at Liberals' Dinners
description: Senator George McGovern, in his first major political appearance here next week, will walk squarely into a Liberal party fight.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 1 (AP) Mrs. Nancy Gunter downed Frangoise Durr of France, 46, 62, 62, to reach the semifinals of the Thunderbird women's tennis tournament today.

title: Giants' Fatigue Key to Game With Pirates
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1The San Francisco Giants, who who almost didn't make it, regrouped today for the National League playoff, which opens in Candlestick Park tomorrow with Gaylord Perry pitching against Steve Blass of the Pittsburgh Pirates. The game, which starts at 4 P.M., New York time, will be televised by the National Broadcasting Company (Channel 4).

title: CELIBACY DEBATE OPENS AT SYNOD
description: ROME, Oct. 1Roman Catholic bishops today began talks on the crisis in the Roman Catholic priesthood.Shortly afterwards Joseph Cardinal Malula, Archbishop of Kinshasa, in the Congo, declared that celibacy was problem in Africa in part because of what he described as the greater spontaneity with which Africans approached family life and sexuality.

title: Building Outlays Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)New construction spending rose $2.4billion in August to a seasonally adjusted annual rate, of $108.3billion after a $400million increase in July, according to preliminary Commerce Department estimates today.

title: Ali to Face Mathis in Houston Nov. 17
description: With his planned Tokyo bout with Mac Foster on Nov. 2 canceled because the people didn't get up the money, Muhammad Ali will oppose Buster Mathis in a 12round heavyweight bout on Wednesday, Nov. 17, at the Houston Astrodome.

title: ARTHUR W. WEYMAN
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 1Arthur W. Weyman, who had operated a travel agency here for thirtyfive years, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Glen Ridge. He was 67 years old and lived at 20 Harrison Avenue.

title: Former Bus Company Official Testifies on Payment to Cohn
description: A former official of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines testified yesterday that the bus company had paid $300,000 to Roy M. Cohn to enable him to repay money he had borrowed from, the company's top officials.

title: POMPIDOU SCORES U.S. IN GREETING CHINESE
