description: PARIS, Oct. 1  President Pompidou had the nine members of a Chinese delegation in for lunch at the Elysde Palace today and took the occasion to criticize the presidential election in South Vietnam Sunday and the American bombing of North Vietnam.

title: Jaeger Sets Special Meeting
description: The Jaeger Machine Company yesterday set Oct. 16 for a special meeting at which shareholders will consider a new slate of directors. The new board was previously agreeded upon and announced by the Danmont Corporation and a group of Jaeger shareholders fighting the proposed merger of Jaeger into Danmont. A merger of the two companies was to be voted upon in June, but dissidents obtained a Federal injunction preventing the meeting.

title: LIBRARY TO AUCTION STAGE MEMORABILIA
description: The great marble hall of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street will become a mart for bibliophiles and film buffs on Thursday with an auction and overthecounter sale of duplicate libraly possessions.

title: Liu Said to Have Fled
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1 (Reuters) Jiji Press, a news agency, reported from Moscow today that Liu Shaochi, deposed Chinese head of state, had escaped to the Soviet Union. It said he was in Moscow but had no other details.

title: Judge Scores Ban at Attica on News Interviews With Inmates
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 1  Federal Judge John T. Curtin said today that the public was receiving a onesided view of the revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility because newsmen had been barred from interviewing inmates since the uprising was crushed Sept. 13.

title: PIER ACTION HALTS SHIPMENTS BY RAIL
description: The nation's railroads placed an embargo yesterday on virtually all freight shipments to struck West Coast ports and announced that a similar ban on rail shipments would go into effect at midnight tomorrow at East and Gulf Coast ports also dosed by the longshoremen's strike.

title: DAMAGE SUIT NAMES 4 BREAD COMPANIES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (UPI)A $45million antitrust damage suit against the four largest makers of white bread in the United States was filed today in Federal District Court.

title: Uganda's President Invited To Pay Visit to South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 1  The Government has invited President Idi Amin of Uganda to visit here.

title: U.S.TAIWAN TALKS ON TEXTILES PAIL
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 1 (Reuters) American and Nationalist Chinese textile negotiators failed today to reach agreement on limiting exports to the United States and will meet again tomorrow, official sources said tonight.

title: Hanging Up on War
description: WEEHAWKEN, N. J.Richard Mozdiak of the Internal Revenue Service telephoned me recently and offered me a last chance to pay three telephone tax bills from last year. No I said, won't paynot while the Government uses my money for its illegal, immoral, inhumane and purposeless war in Indochina.

title: Reversible Vasectomy Described at Seminar Here
description: Clinical trials have begun on a reversible vasectomy device that would make it possible for a man's fertility to be turned off or on through a simple operation in a doctor's office.

title: Soviet Congratulations Call for Improved Ties
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today marked 22 years of Communist rule in China with a new call for better relations.

title: Yiddish Film Revivals Planned for Weekends
description: A weekend revival program of Yiddishlanguage feature films with English subtitles, produced here and abroad. will start today at the Anderson Theater, Second Avenue and Fourth Street.

title: Health Chief Again Opposes Nonphosphate Detergents
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, reiterated today the Government's advice to housewives to buy detergents that are not required to carry a warning label. In most cases, he said, these will be phosphate detergents.

title: Shop Talk
description: Classics, as everybody knows, constitute the big fashion news for Mall for both men and women. So when Ohrbach's presented its international collection of men's clothes yesterday in a show that is a modest version of its women's importcopy gala, it made sure it included classic British tweeds, classic cowboy denims, classic Army fatigues and classic Chinese proletariat suits. Maybe they mean tomorrow's classics, remarked a, bystander in the noontime crowd that included threedeep standees as the Chinese suit appeared. Are they trying to tell us something?

title: British Disclose Soviet Woman Aide Also Defected
description: LONDON, Oct. 1The Home Office disclosed today that a Soviet woman official had defected to Britain at the same time as a K.G.B. agent, Oleg Lyalin.

title: 6 QUEENS YOUTHS ACCUSED OF ARSON
description: Six youths were accused yesterday of throwing four Molotov cocktails at a house owned by a Negro in the Rosedale section of Queens on Sept. 12.

title: Thurston Blodgett, Consultant On Investments, Is Dead at 72
description: Thurston P. Blodgett, consultant to Union Service Corporation, an investment research organization, 65 Broadway, died yesterday of cancer in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 1 East End Avenue,

title: Trouble Shooter for the World
description: For more than two decades, the chief trouble shooter for three Secretaries General of the United Nations has been Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, an American activistscholar with an extraordinary flair for diplomatic conciliation and an untiring commitment to peace and justice.

title: Coast Guard Panel Investigating Governors Island Racial Fights
description: The Coast Guard command on Governors Island convened a board of inquiry yesterday to investigate sporadic brawls between black and white coastguardsmen on the island recently and allegations of discrimination against black servicemen.

title: Bacon Lawyer Studies Suit
description: An attorney for Leslie Bacon, the 19yearold antiwar activist, said yesterday that he was considering filing suit against the Federal Government for false arrest of his client. Miss Bacon was arrested on April 27 as a material witness in the bombing of the United States Capitol last spring and held for three weeks in Seattle. She later was jailed for contempt of court. On Thursday a Federal Court of Appeals in San Francisco ruled that she had been illegally arrested because the Government's assumption she would flee rather than testify was unwarranted.

title: PAYMENTS BALANCE HITS PEAK IN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1The Finance Ministry and the Bank of Japan said today that Japan's balance of international payments reached a record surplus of $3.3billion in August.

title: Federal Official Is Slain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  A Federal official was stabbed to death today in a men's room of the new Executive Office Building in a violent struggle, apparently trying to ward off a robber, the police said, They said they believed Richie H. Reed, 30 years old, of suburban Cheverly, Md., director of economics research for the Commission on Population Growth and American Future, was surprised by someone waiting in the room. They said no wallet was found, indicating a robbery.

title: Thousands Delayed On L.I.R. by Train Stalled in Tunnel
description: Thousands on the Long Island, Railroad were delayed up to an hour during the evening rush yesterday when a train from Great Neck to Pennsylvania Station stalled midway through a tunnel underneath the East River.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Police Commissioner Murphy deserves and, indeed, needs the support of all residents of New York in his efforts to restore discipline and maximum integrity at all levels of the police force.. His efforts are not merely correct administrative and managerial steps. Their result can be greater safety for all in New York City.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Two recent reports in the magazine Science have revealed a most significant fact about some of the most noxious gaseous constituents that contribute to air pollution. The authors of these articles have shown that such gases as nitrogen oxides and especially carbon monoxide are removed with remarkable speed and efficiency by soil, particularly potting soil.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AMEX STOCKS GAIN AS TRADING RISES
description: The American Stock Exchange finished the week on an uptick yesterday as the list advanced in the heaviest trading n more than three weeks.

title: A's Banking on Blue Against the Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 1  Vida Blue, one of baseball's most electrifying personalities this season, was as gloomy as the weather today as he and the rest of the Oakland Athletics prepared for their American League playoff opener with Baltimore tomorrow.

title: Europe Is Cautious on Connally's Plan
description: PARIS, Oct. 1We will notl make unilateral trade concessions to get the American 10 per cent import surtax removed, a high Common Market official said today as Europeans weighed Treasury Secretary John B. Connally's statement of American monetary and trade objectives in the dollar crisis.

title: WILLIAM R. KATZENBERG
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 1William R. Katzenberg, president of Jacob Spern & Sons, hide brokers, died today in St. Agnes Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 18 Beechwood Road, Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: Art: 5 New Galleries at Metropolitan
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art opened five new permanent galleries for American painting and sculpture yesterday, and the most succinct comment would be Hooray? The American collection has been visible only occasionally and spottily for a long, long time, and the new installation is not only a reminder but also in many ways a revelation of its richness. Alongisde familiar masterpieces from Colonial times to the early 20th century (the limits of the installation), you find painting after painting by artists of the second and third rank who at their best were the equals of the great reputations.

title: Chou and Other Officials Attend National Day Rites
description: PEKING, Oct. 1Premier Chou Enlai and other Government leaders, along with tens of thousands of ordinary Chinese, took part in National Day celebrations here today. The celebrations, with the customary giant parade omitted, took place in the capital's parks.

title: USERS WIN, 8881, END KNICKS' SKEIN
description: MILLERSVILLE, Pa., Oct. 1Despite a 20point performance by Dick Barnett, who played 24 minutes, the New York Knickerbockers suffered their first preseason loss tonight, bowing to the Philadelphia 76ers, 8881, at Millersville State College.

title: U.S. BRITAIN WARY ON SECURITY TALKS
description: The United States and Britain agreed yesterday that the Soviet Union and its allies must clarify the aims and dimensions of their proposed European security conference before the West could join them in preparations for it.

title: Blacks and Whites Stop Weapons Race in Georgia
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 1 (UPI)The arms race in tiny Hancock County, where opposing governmental groups brought weapons by the dozens, has come to an end, Gov. Jimmy Carter said tonight.

title: Correction Aide Appointed
description: ALBANY, Oct. 1James J. Morrow, 59 years old, has been appointed deputy commissioner for correctional facilities, the State Department of Correctional Services announced today. Mr. Morrow, a 33year vetertan in the field of correctional rehabilitation, will become responsible for the operation of the prisons, state hospitals and youth camps under the jurisdiction of the department. He will receive $31,500 annually.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1A State Department spokesman, announcing Mr. Bergus's reassignment today, said it was in no way related to a controiversial memorandum that Mr. Bergus submitted to Egyptian lofficials last summer that included recommendations on a possible agreement for reopening the Suez Canal.

title: Vanatta Gets Pros' Post
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 1 (AP) Bob Vanatta, a basketball coach for 25 years, was named executive director today of the Memphis Pros of the American Basketball Association.

title: BECK ASKED TO SET CONDITIONS OF SALE
description: Judge John M. Canella of the United States Southern District Court in New York yesterday asked attorneys for trustees of Beck Industries, Inc., in reorganization, to submit their recommendations for selling the company assets by next Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICER IN INQUIRY AT ATTICA SCORED
description: ATTICA, N.Y., Oct. 1The committee set up by Governor Rockefeller to oversee conditions at the Attica Correctional Facility called today for the withdrawal of a state police captain from the state's investigation of last month's rebellion.

title: CHIEF U.S. DELEGATE IN EGYPT RETURNING
description: CAIRO, Oct. 1The chief United States diplomatic representative in Cairo for the last four years, Donald C. Bergus, will be reassigned to Washington soon, it was disclosed here today.

title: Market Place: Analyst Expects Money Disaster
description: One winter day in 1964, William H. Tehan was driving through the Catskills when he rounded a curve and skidded on a sheet of ice into the opposite lane. In a fraction of a second his car tit another car headon and he hurtled through the windshield.

title: Sales of Interstate Stores Up by 3.7% in September
description: Interstate Stores, Inc., the first major retail chain to announce its September sales results, said yesterday that it had a 3.7 per cent increase in sales for the four weeks ended Sept. 26 compared to the yearago period. Total sales were $52,483,800 against $50,634,000.

title: Hinton Is Greeted by Jets Who Recall How He Hits
description: The locker was all ready for Chuck Hinton, the newest Jet, when he arrived yesterday at Shea Stadium.

title: Tass Issues Denial
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1Tass, the Soviet press agency, denied today that it had circulated information to the effect that Mr. Liu had fled to the Soviet Union.

title: Pinder Outpoints Vasquez In 12Round Bout at Forum
description: Enrique Pinder of Colon, Panama, showed his superior ring savvy last night by scoring a unanimous 12round decision over Davey Vasquez, the local Puerto Rican favorite. A bipartisan crowd of 4,012 attended the bout in the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden.

title: Coast Publisher Retires
description: OXNARD, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP) Thomas H. Fleming is retiring for health reasons after four years as publisher of The Oxnard PressCourier and 45 years in the newspaper business.

title: Refinancing by Fox Stirs New Support
description: The announcement by the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation Thursday of an agreement to refinance its debt brought an expression of support yesterday from a large shareholder.

title: GAINS REPORTED IN BERLIN TALKS
description: BONN, Oct. 1  West and East Germany today resumed their negotiations on implementing the Big Four agreement on West Berlin, and after a fourandahalfhour session both sides reported progress.

title: 3 Named to Loan Program as Council Sets Hearing
description: The appointment of three new top executives of the Municipal Loan Program as a further step in its reorganization in the wake of disclosures of alleged corruption and misuse of funds was announced yesterday.

title: Plight of Sugar Workers Major Issue in Philippines
description: BACOLOD, the Philippines, Sept. 20The exploitation of labor on the rich sugar plantations of Occidental Province on Negros Island nas in recent years become a principal issue for social reformers and is widely regarded as a glaring example of social injustice.

title: Frohlich Funeral Service Is Attended by 900 Here
description: About 900 people attended a funeral service yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church for L. W. Frohlich, founder and chairman of FrohlichIntercon International, Inc., advertising agency. Mr. Frohlich died at his home here on Tuesday at the age of 58.

title: Maazel to Head Cleveland Orchestra
description: Lorin Maazel, the 41yearold American conductor, has been appointed music director of the Cleveland Orchestra despite an informal poll taken by the orchestra players in August in which, by a vote of 77 to 2, they indicated that he was not their choice.

title: U.S. NEGROES SET AFRICA TRADE TIE
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1  Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie of Illinois announced today that his office had helped to set up a trading venture between Negro businessmen in this state and African businessmen in Ghana and Nigeria that should have a dollar value of nearly $50million over the next two years in business contracts. Mr. Ogilvie spoke at a breakfast meeting at Chicago's Amphitheater attended by nearly 1,000 black and white purchasing agents.

title: GOLDBERG ASSERTS LETTER IS FORGERY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that a forged letter represented as having been written by him to Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel is being circulated and that he had asked the Justice Department to investigate.

title: Rostropovich Now in Vienna; Plans Tour of Japan and U.S.
description: VIENNA, Oct. 1Mstislav Rostropovich, the Soviet cellist and conductor, who had reportedly been banned from traveling abroad, has arrived in Vienna to conduct three guest performances of the opera company of Moscow's Bolshoi Theater. He will tour the United States before the end of the year after giving 30 concerts in Japan from Oct. 16 to Nov. 17.

title: GIANTS PREPARING NEW LOOK ATTACK
description: Ron Johnson will probably start for the New York Giants against the St. Louis Cardinals tomorrow, as part of a new look offense on which the Giants will rely.

title: 2 Seized in Statue Defacing
description: Two men were arrested early yesterday after they allegedly dumped a can of red paint over the head of a statue of Theodore Roosevelt at 79th Street and Central Park West. The police said Mark Dornstreich, 30, years old, an instructor at Rutgers University Livingston campus in New Brunswick, N. J., and James McCarthy, 19, of Norristown, Pa., a Rutgers student, were captured as they ran from the scene about 3:30 A.M.

title: Ashland Completes Deal
description: Ashland Oil, Inc., and the Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that Ashland had completed its purchase of all the stock of the Union Carbide Petroleum Corporation. The transaction involves approximately $88million in cash plus possible additional payments.

title: Experts Hail Army's Program For Drug Addicts in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1  A team of six experts on rehabilitation of drug addicts returned from two weeks in Vietnam today with the message that the Army was doing firstclass job of treating soldiers involved with drugs. The team called the soldiers chances of recovery excellent.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There has been such a mountain of material written about the Middle East problem by writers with varying measures of expertise that one hesitates to add to the verbiage. Yet Norman Dacey's letter of Sept. 25 contained a degree of speciosity that cannot go unchallenged.

title: BRITISH SOLDIER DIES IN BELFAST VIOLENCE
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 1 (Reuters)A British soldier was killed and a civilian sniper shot and captured in separate incidents in Belfast today.

title: William J. Alford, 82, Led Continental Paper Company
description: NORFOLK, Conn., Oct. 1William J. Alford, chairman of Continental Paper Company of Ridgefield Park, N. J., from 1943 to 1968, died Wednesday in Winsted Memorial Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 82 years old and had homes here and in Naples, Fla.

title: WILLIAM WINES, A COMPOSER, DIES
description: EAST NORWICH, L. I., Oct. 1  William Wirges, a composer, conductor and publisher, died Tuesday in Syosset Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: ARGENTINE FANS FOCUS ON FISCHER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 1 Bibby Fischer, the 28yearold Brooklyn school dropout who won the United States chess championship eight times in the last 13 years, had decided it was time to take the world title away from Boris Spassky of Moscow. That's what excited the 1,000 chess fans who jammed the San Martin municipal theater here last night.The fans saw the lanky, moody bachelor beat Tigran Petrosian of Moscow in the first game of their elimination match, the final hurdle before facing the world champion. Fischer and Petrosian  who ost the championship to Spassky  are scheduled to play 12 games, but the match could be decided on as few as seven games, because it takes only 6 points to clinch the victory.

title: Mayor Daley's Biggest Fan
description: CHICAGO, Oct, 1 (AP)Ever since she met him more than 40 years ago at a Sunday afternoon neighborhood ballgame, the biggest fan of Mayor Richard J. Daley has been his wife, Eleanorknown to close friends as Sis.The store manager and company officials refused to comment and Mrs. Daley has been unavailable for comment. Mr. Daley said only that his wife joined many others in complaining that the food chain handled the books.

title: Egyptians Criticize Eban Call for Talks As a Bar to Peace
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1The Egyptian mission to the United Nations said today that the proposal for talks on the Middle East made here yesterday by the Israeli Foreign Minister, Abba Eban, contained the same Israeli obstructions to all United Nations efforts to end Israeli hostilities and to bring a just and durable peace to the Middle East.

title: 9 Ashore as Carrier Sails; Navy Calls Them Deserters
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (AP)Nine young crewmen of the Constellation stayed inside a Roman Catholic church as the attack carrier sailed on schedule today for Vietnam. They were then declared deserters by the Navy.

title: CITY OPERA GIVES REVIVAL OF COSI
description: Musicians love to analyze Cosi fan tutte, trying to decide whether the characters in Da Ponte's libretto are wholly artificial or have some real blood in them and whether, Mozart's music is wholly satiric or reflects genuine human emotions. In the end, the analyses matter little; because the beauty of the score, even when it is being deliberately funny, sweeps every other consideration aside.

title: Airborne Atomic Clocks to Test Einstein Time Theory
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Two scientists and four atomic clocks will fly around the world next week to test one of the crucial implications of Einstein's theory of relativity.

title: The Talk of Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1The crowd of about a thousand pushed its way into the old French opera house across the street from the United States Embassy in what seemed at first to be a gathering of political figures to mark the end of the presidential election campaign. As it turned out, the oneman candidacy of President Nguyen Van Thieu and the voting this Sun day were far from the thoughts of the Vietnamese in the Thong Nhut Theater, with its 14 swirling overhead fans. They were attending the weekly drawing of the national lottery and the number that emerged, 124916, brought someone somewhere 4 million piasters, or the equivalent of about $15.000.

title: Sales of Blue Jeans Are Booming in Japan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1While Japanese textile makers fight to maintain and expand their American markets, they are getting their pants beat off in their own country by Americans.

title: N.B.C. IS GUILTY IN PRIVACY CASE
description: PIERRE, S.D., Oct 1 (AP)A United States District Court jury yesterday found the National Broadcasting Company guilty of invading the privacy of a South Dakota rancher and awarded him $25,000.

title: Goldsmith Captures 5th Soling Class Sail And Gains 2d Place
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 1Bruce Goldsmith's Schroeder from Chicago won the fifth race in the world Soling Class championship today on Long Island Sound and moved into second place in the series standing.

title: Storm Ginger Poses a Flood Threat
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 1 (UPI)  Tropical depression Ginger, no longer a hurricane but still posing a flood threat in the already hard hit North Carolina farm belt, continued its slow movement northwestward today, dumping heavy rains along the way.

title: Jazz Veterans Meet Challenge Of Familiarity in Repertory
description: In jazz, familiarity is less likely to breed contempt than to set up a challenge. What, for example, can you do with such spavined warhorses of the traditional jazz repertory as Muskrat Ramble, Fidgety Feet, At the Jazz Band Ball or Bill Bailey?

title: Sato Pressing Industry
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 1 (UPI) Prime Minister Eisaku Sato said today that he will not negotiate an agreement with the United States Government for control of Japanese textile exhorts unless the Japanese textile industry consents to it.

title: ASHE, LAVER REACH TENNIS SEMIFINALS
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP)Arthur Ashe toppled Cliff Drysdale today and became the only American to reach the semifinals of the $50,000 Redwood Bank international open tennis tournament.

title: RIGHT TO SHELTER URGRD BY PRIRIEST
description: A Roman Catholic priest yesterday said the right to shelter should outweigh any right to private property, and a builder in northern New Jersey told how zoning regulations were used to keep him from constructing low or moderatecost apartments on a piece of property he owns.

title: Swarthmore President To Resign Next June
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 1Dr. Robert D. Cross, president of Swarthmore College, submitted his resignation today to the board of managers.

title: DR. CORSAN REID, N.Y.U. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. L. Corsan Reid, who retired as Rush H. Kress Professor of Research Surgery at New York University PostGraduate Medical School in 1963, died yesterday in the Bronx Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at Midland Gardens, Bronxville, N. Y.

title: Value of Contracts And Fund Transfers Nearing Standstill
description: ARLINGTON, Va., Oct. 1Transfers of mutualfund advisory contracts to new owners have come to a virtual standstill in recent weeks and the value of such contracts has plummeted.

title: Lindsay Says Nixon Follows A Doctrine of Unpredictability
description: BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Oct. 1Mayor Lindsay charged tonight that President Nixon apparently believed it was to this country's advantage to create the greatest amount of doubt about what we intend to do and when we intend to do it.

title: Bodies of Two Attica Convicts Are Buried in Cemetery on S.I.
description: The bodies of two inmates of the Attica Correction Facility were buried yesterday beneath an oak tree in simple ceremonies at a Staten Island cemetery.

title: Podgorny Makes Stop in India; Visit Is Seen as Act of Support
description: NEW DELHI, Oct 1President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union arrived for a brief visit in India this afternoon. His visit is another public demonstration of the closer ties that the two countries have been promoting since they signed a friendship and cooperation treaty in August.

title: Lawyer and 6 San Quentin Convicts Are Indicted
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 1 (AP)  A Marin County grand jury indicted Stephen M. Bingham, a missing lawyer, and six San Quentin convicts on murder charges today in the Aug. 21 violence at the prison in which George Jackson and five others died. The indicted inmates include Fleeta Drumgo, one of the two surviving socalled Soledad Brothers.

title: U.A.W. Officer Says Profits Keep Pace With Wages
description: Pat Greathouse, vice president of the United Auto Workers of America, entered into the lion's den yesterday and told an American Management Association seminar that profits had kept pace with wages.

title: Two Shows in the Revival of Realism
description: The current revival of what, for want of a better name, must be called realism among a great many painters of the younger generation in New Yorkand indeed, a great many painters outside New Yorkis a subject guaranteed to send entrenched partisans of the modern movement into paroxysms of complaint, criticism and paranoia. Whatever else the champions of modernist art may argue aboutand they argue about a great dealthey are more or less agreed that anything answering to the specifications of traditional realism lies well beyond the boundary lines of respectable artistic utterance. Yet the critical disapproval of doctrinaire modernistsa moral judgment as much as an esthetic onemeans nothing to the new breed of realists. They are quite prepared to be characterized as reactionaries, for they are convinced that the integrity of painting as an art lies entirely in their hands.

title: Seoul Rejects Deadline
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 1 (UPI)  South Korea has rejected a United States demand for a final decision by today on conclusion of an agreement limiting Korean textile exports to America, but has kept the door open for continuation of Government talks.

title: FIVE OHIO UTILITIES LIMIT GAS TO USERS
description: Five natural gas companies in Ohio announced yesterday that because of short supplies they could not accept any new or additional gas loads for industrial customers, effective immediately. They are also imposing limits on new commercial loads to 2,000 cubic feet an hour. Residential customers are not affected by the moves.

title: Stewart's Time Fastest for Grand Prix
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 1  Autumn in the Finger Lakes district is heralded not only by the fall colors that emblazon the rolling countryside, but also by the shattering roar of Grand Prix racing cars.

title: Straight to the Vein
description: At the age of 17 I had a habit. I was addicted to heroin. I began using heroin shortly after my 17th birthday at the insistence of a friend who had long been going that route himself.

title: Tinajero Belmont Pick With Bold Reason Out
description: If difference of opinion makes a good race, then today's $115,000 Woodward Stakes at Belmont Park already has passed its first test.

title: Horsemen Seek a Larger Share of OTB Handle as Ontrack Wagering Declines
description: Alarmed by the decline in attendance and handle at Belmont Park that will result in a reduction of $7,000 a day in purses, representatives of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association met yesterday for two hours with Howard J. Samuels, the president of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Text of Resolution by Fund Governors.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Following is the text of a resolution adopted today by the board of governors of the International Monetary Fund:

title: Dollar Trading
description: Following are closing quotes for leading foreign currencies in the New York market. The prices do not necessarily correspond to those in other financial centers but generally indicate market trends.

title: Dean Witter & Co. President Resigns
description: Dean Witter & Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced yesterday that Lawrence B. Morris Jr. had resigned as president and said the firm had no immediate plans to replace him.

title: F.T.C. Seeking Information On I.C. Industries Merger
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Illinois Central Industries, Inc., said today the Federal Trade Commission has requested information on I.C. Industries' acquisitions of PepsiCola General Bottlers, Inc., in 1970 and the recent acquisition of the Dad's Root Beer Company.

title: Senate Acts to Force Rise In Aid for School Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Senate voted today to direct the Nixon Administration to borrow sufficient funds to feed the nation's needy school children.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE 2D STRAIGHT DAY
description: The stock market, putting together two consecutive gains, moved higher yesterday. In the forefront of the advance were some automotive, retailing, drugchain, mobilehome and recreationalvehicle issues.

title: Capacity Audiences Envisaged For Lincoln Center Film Fete
description: The ninth annual New York Film Festival opened at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater last night with the presentation of a Russian film and the prospect of capacity audiences for all 18 performances.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1A California company specializing in pollution control received patents this week for a smogfree automobile. Richard D. Smith, president, and. Dale A. Furlong, chief engineer of the Combustion Power Company, Menlo Park, were grant ed Patents 3,608,529 and 3,608,660. The HyOx engine, which has been built but not yet roadtested, is designed to burn pure hydrogen or gasoline as fuel, with the injection of pure liquid oxygen. The cylinders are cooled by a water spray. According to a spokesman, as no air is drawn in there is no generation of nitrogen oxide, the air pollutant.

title: Bomb Alert in Cairo Reported Along With AntiSoviet Unrest
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29Mysterious happenings in Cairo, cloaked by an Egyptian information blackout, were related here today by travelers from the Egyptian capital.

title: Notes on People
description: To mark his 90th birthday Oct. 25, Pablo Picasso will receive a unique gift from the French government. He will become the first living artist to have his work displayed in the grand gallery of the Louvre.

title: Seventh Avenue, for the Moment, Is Playing It Safe
description: No, Seventh Avenue is not backsliding. It doesn't dare, now that women are happy about buying clothes again. The next wave of fashions, geared to cruise and resort (meaning hot weather clothes), holiday (mostly party clothes) and early spring (things to wear from midwinter through Easter Sunday), isn't grim, ghastly or even slightly insane. The new collections, unveiled last month to start arriving in the, stores in six weeks or so, continue the safe and sane policy that proved so winning in fall clothes.

title: GRAIN CONTRACTS ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: The possibility of a prolonged longshoremen's strike, with a resultant depletion of stocks, caused considerable buying of grain and soybean futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: HUGHES CASE IS SET FOR SUPREME COURT
description: The intricate litigation that led to a $145million default levy against Howard R. Hughes and the Hughes Tool Company in favor of Trans World Airlines is headed for the United States Supreme Court.

title: 1,000 Students Boycott College In Nassau Over Strike Impasse
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 1More than 1,000 students from Nassau Community College boycotted classes today and marched to the State Supreme Court Building here to protest the continued impasse in contract negotiations between the county and the teachers.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 1Wesley Hall, M.D., the president of the American Medical Association, visited Britain last summer and went away distressed. He observed the National Health Service in a small mining town in Scotland and found it so bad that Americans would never tolerate it.

title: CHILEAN, AT U.N., BACKS TAKEOVERS
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 1Foreign Minister Clodomiro Almeyda of Chile declared today that his Government's policy of nationalizing foreign mining interests was covered by a solemnly declared United Nations principle  the right to economic independence.

title: A Dollar a Day
description: MIAMI, W. Va.Most articles written about the coal miners are by people with little or no knowledge of truth in regard to these men and their families. The miners have no way to fight back and defend themselves.

title: MARTIN KRAUS DIES; CIVIL COURT JUDGE
description: Judge Martin Kraus of the City Civil Court died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 75 East End Avenue. He was 69 years old.

title: Soviet Reaction Intensifies
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 1The Soviet reaction to the British expulsion of 90 officials from Britain and the ban on the return of 15 others intensified today as the Government newspaper Izvestia published a purported interview with H.A.R. (Kim) Philby, the former British intelligence agent, charging that London was seeking to disrupt the relaxation of tension in Europe.

title: Car Rental Concern Sued Over Law Violations
description: A Manhattan carrental concern whose employes allegedly assaulted customers, threatened investigators and lured clients to its office with false promises of low rates was sued this week by the city, the Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Closed: Docks and Mines
description: In other years a virtually complete shutdown of the country's deepsea ports and its softcoal mines would have brought swift White House moves for national emergency injunctions under the TaftHartley Act. But President Nixon, despite his recent shift to economic activism, is hoping that he will be spared the necessity for such backtowork orders by quick settlements of the strikes now paralyzing the waterfronts and the mines.

title: CONNECTICUT EASES HOMOSEXUAL LAW
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 1A new Connecticut Penal Code permitting homosexual relations between consenting adults went into effect today.

title: Disney World Opens Without Expected Crush
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA. Fla.. Oct. 1Walt Disney World, widely heralded as the new colossus of Florida tourism, opened today on a day that was perfect except for one thing: The $400million attraction drew only a paperthin crowd.It's the best thing I've ever seen, exclaimed Dennis Myers, a 23yearold honeymooner from York, Pa. The first thing I'm going to do when I get back home is convince my friends they should come here.

title: Executive Changes
description: Tektronix, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Earl Wantland, 40 years old, as president. Mr. Wantland succeeds Howard Vollum, 58, the company's president throughout its 25year history. Mr. Vollum will continue as chairman. Mr. Wantland continues as chief operations officer, a responsibility he has exercised since 1969 as executive vice president. Donald Alvey, Leslie F. Stevens, William Walker and William Polits were elected group vice presidents.

title: Student Registering Decreed
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 1 (AP) Judge Willam E. Steckler in United States District Court ordered the Delaware County voters registration board today to register Ball State University students who live on the campus and meet state voting requirernents.

title: Bayh Lists Net Worth And His 1970 Income
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  Senator Birch Bayh reported today that his net worth was about $163,000 and his income last year was $100,321.

title: Gold Price Falls Sharply
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The price of gold slumped sharply on European bullion markets today following yesterday's clear hint from Secretary Connally that there was little likelihood of the United States' agreeing to raise the official price of gold.

title: Help Wanted Ads Steady
description: The helpwanted advertising index leveled off in August, The Conference Board reported yesterday. At 85 per cent of the 1967 base, the index remained unchanged, from the July figure, but was four points below its level of August, 1970.

title: Court Voids Ban On Exams to Fill Model Cities Jobs
description: The Appellate Division reversed yesterday a ruling haded down on Tuesday by State Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino that had postponed examinations to qualify fesidents of Model Cities areas for the fire, police and housing patrol forces here.

title: Spies for the Kremlin
description: The Soviet Government once insisted piously that only treacherous imperialist states engaged in international espionage. A dramatic public turnabout in Moscow's approach took place roughly a decade ago when a group of Soviet master spiesmen such as Victor Sorge, Col. Rudolf Abel and Kim Philbywere acclaimed heroes.

title: Auto Production
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1 (AP)Domestic auto production dropped by 3,000 units this week even though five plants are scheduled for overtime tomorrow.

title: WheelingPittsburgh Steel Set to Resume Operations
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (UPI)The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation hopes that by the middle of October it will be able to resume operations at its large plant in Monessen, Pa., and gradually recall 2,100 workers.

title: Fewer Bricks, More Schools
description: Chancellor Harvey Scribner has properly called attention to the fact that school reform must mean more than the redistribution of powers; the heart of the matter is the reshaping of institutions.

title: Nixon Hails Bunche, Says He'll Be Missed at U.N.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 1 (AP)  President Nixon paid tribute to Dr. Ralph J. Bunche, whose retirement as Under Secretary General was announced officially at the United Nations today.

title: Monsanto Rebukes Pros' Bid to Halt Turf Installation
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1  Monsanto Company, the leading producer of synthetic turf, denounced today demands made recently by the National Football League Players Association calling for a moratorium on further installations of artificial turf pending completion of a study on incidence of injuries by Dr. James G. Garrick of Seattle.

title: SoftCoal Mines Are Shut Down as 80,000 Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1About 80,000 miners walked out of their pits and strip mines today, effectively shutting down the nation's softcoal industry. The strike spread across the coal fields after negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the Bituminous Coal Operators Association failed to reach an agreement at midnight last night, when the old national contract expired. The strike is not expected to have any immediate impact on the public. Stocks of coal held in reserve by power companies and other utilities were described by Government offi cials today as adequate. The union and management negotiators met again this morning but recessed by noon. A new bargaining session is not scheduled until early next week, according to a joint statement, and talks are not expected to resume sooner than Tuesday. Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, announced at President Nixons retreat at Key Biscayne, Fla., that Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson would meet separately with W. A. Boyle, president of the union, and Joseph Moody, president of the operators association, to help reach an agreement.

title: Oil Price Rise Planned
description: The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and the Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday plans to raise the price of Middle Eastern crude oil in Japan on an ierage of 5 cents a barrel. Toa Renryo Kogyo, the Japanese buyer, said it was studying the request of the two American concerns.

title: TRANSIT OFFICIALS SHIFTED BY RONAN
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, yesterday reorganized the top management of the New York City Transit Authority, which runs the city's subways and buses.

title: Hospital Patients' Cost to Rise Under Medicare by $8, to $68
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The Department of Health, Education and Welfare announced today that, starting in January, Medicare recipients would have to pay the first $68 of their hospital bill instead of $60 as at present.

title: Both Parties Acknowledge Exceeding Spending Limits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) The nation's two major political parties conceded today that they solicit and spend individual campaign contributions larger than the law allows, but that there is nothing illegal about it.

title: Police Report No Leads in Rape Case
description: Chief of Detectives Albert A. Seedman said yesterday that he had no firm leads on the man who raped a 31yearold woman Thursday night in a 12thfloor penthouse while another woman fell to her death trying to escape.

title: Governor Expects Deficit Of $470Million for State
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that because of lagging tax revenues attributable to persistent national economic difficulties the state faced $470million deficit for the 197172 state fiscal year, which ends March 31.

title: WILLIAM L. NEUMANN; TAUGHT AT GOUCHER
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 1Dr. William L. Neumann, professor of history and chairman of the American studies department at Goucher College, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in nearby Timonium. He was 56 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NIXON WON'T USE STRIKE CURB NOW IN DOCK DISPUTES
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 1 The White House said today that it would not immediately invoke the TaftHartley Act to suspend the East or West Coast dock strikes.

title: Usually Genteel Senate Boils Over in a Tempest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1The normally gentlemanly Senate got into one of its rare squabbles last night. Before it was over, the majority leader and his assistant had incurred the displeasure of the liberals, Southern conservatives found themselves openly fighting with their Northern colleagues, and Hubert H. Humphrey had reasserted his old role as a leader in the Senate.

title: Japanese Are Worried
description: TOKYO, Oct. 1 (Reuters)Japan appears worried that she might be placed in an embarrassing position by Secretary Connally's call for free floating of currencies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is, of course, futile, but some of us shall miss English money. Crowns, shillings, pence, thruppence; somehow they had a ring to them that is lacking in their decimal usurpers. I realize that in this nation where plastic and the clock are chief deities, it is heresy to cry out against efficiency, to plead for delay and confusion, but those of us who love man's few distinguishing traits will sorely miss one of the last remaining vestiges of his irrationality.

title: U.S. Steel Imports Up 60% In First Eight Months of '71
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)  Foreign producers exported 60 per cent more steel to the United States in the first eight months of this year than in the comparable period of 1970, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: Split Reported in Council On Controls for Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said today that there was still a disagreement among members of the Cost of Living Council about the kind of controls that should be instituted in Phase Two of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

title: Auto Worker Savors First Day of Early Retirement
description: DETROIT, Oct. 1  Neal Kizer, after getting up at 5 A.M. for most of his 35 years at the Cadillac assembly plant here, slept until 7 today, the first day of his retirement.

title: Fresh Yankee Triumphs
description: Fresh Yankee, the great American  bred, Canadianowned trotting mare, registered her 15th success in 24 outings this season, beating Dart Hanover, Trinidad and others in a $25,000 open handicap onemile trot in 2:02 1/5.

title: Five Black American Catholics Will Take Grievances to Pope
description: Five black Roman Catholics a priest, a nun and three lay personsplan to leave tonight for Rome to discuss with Pope Paul VI what they describe as the disastrously poor relationship of the church in this country to black Americans.

title: G.I.'s Yield to Civilians On KP at Fort Campbell
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP)  Nearly 2,000 GIs woke up today to a day they may have dreamed about, but never thought would come. Civilians, not soldiers, were on kitchen police duty.

title: Buddhist AntiThieu Rally Is Attacked by the Police
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2South Vietnamese riot policemen made a teargas attack last night on a Buddhist rally of about 300 people who were protesting tomorrow's uncontested presidential election.

title: Two Youths Arrested
description: SAIGON, Oct. 1 (AP)Two youths were arrested at the An Quang Pagoda today, one with a firebomb in his hand. The latter was beaten by the police and taken away in a jeep.

title: Old Army Game Is Back Again
description: The M.P. at West Point's Washington Gate can expect a restful tour on a mild, fall Sunday afternoon. He'll wave on a handful of sightseers or occasionally snap to and salute an officer leaving that northwest portal for a round on the nearby West Point Golf Course.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the obituary on J. D. Bernal [Sept. 19] you quote Home Secretary Sir John Anderson, who appointed the scientist to the Home Office at the outset of World War II, as telling critics of the appointment that he would employ Bernal even if he was as red as the flames of hell.

title: Man in the News
description: I got one world, Anthony Thomas Palmigiano was saying yesterday, Pier 11, and my home. The poles of the 47yearold longshoreman's world are separated by seven blocks of South Brooklyn, and more than twothirds of his life has been spent between the two.

title: Chain's Volume Off
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, made its poorest showing in sales and earnings in more than 10 years, according to results issued yesterday for the second fiscal quarter and halfyear periods ended with August.

title: Registration Will End Today for 1820 Group
description: Neighborhood polling places throughout the state open today for the final day of registration for the November election for potential voters in the 18to20 year age group and for others who have moved or did not vote in the last two elections and thus lost their permanent registration.

title: INJUNCTION ON I.O.S. IS LIFTED BY COURT
description: FREDERICTON, New Brunswick, Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) An injunction against management officials of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., was dissolved today by the appeals division of the New Brunswick Supreme Court. The injunction, obtained by dissident shareholders following a stormy I.O.S annual meeting June 30 in Toronto, prevented management from performing any but routine company duties.

title: Scores on WQXR
description: Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times or WQXR for scores; the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

title: Antiques: Further Back
description: Clever collectors interested in bronze and brass have been turning to 16thcentury work because of the difficulties in locating examples of the 18th century.

title: UPSTATE TIE DENIED TO BANKERS TRUST
description: The New York State Banking Board denied yesterday an application by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation to acquire a small bank upstate.

title: Miami Routs Baylor On 20Point Spree In 2d Period, 4115
description: MIAMI, Oct. 1 (UPI)Chuck Foreman, who scored two touchdowns, led Miami to a 4115 victory over Baylor tonight. The victors poured across 20 points in the second quarter.

title: N. Y. P. L., I Love You
description: This is a report. It is also, unavoidably, a love letter.

title: Principal Opposes Reading Criterion Of Promotion Rules
description: An elementary school principal in a poor neighborhood in Brooklyn yesterday challenged district rules that, he said, arbitrarily denied promotion to 10 per cent of fifthgrade pupils, those with reading problems.

title: AMY PORTER, WRITER, MAGAZINE EDITOR
description: Amy Porter, newspaper and magazine writer and editor, died Wednesday evening in New York Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived at 142 East 71st Street.

title: Tannenbaum Rites Friday
description: A memorial service for Dr. Gerald Tannenbaum will be held Friday at 11 A.M. in the 6th floor auditorium of Metropolitan Hospital, 1901 First Avenue. Dr. Tannenbaum died last Saturday in a motorcycle accident at Park Avenue and East .80th Street. An Associate Professor of Psychiatry at New York Medical College, he was also director of InPatient Psychiatric Services at Metropolitan Hospital. He is survived by his widow, the former Betty Koppelman; two sons, Kenneth and David, his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Tannenbaum of Scranton, Pa., and a brother, Donald of Philadelphia.

title: WILLIAM B. BROWN
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Oct. 1William B. Brown of 8 English Village, formerly head of the invoice and price department in the New York office of the Singer Company, died yesterday in Memorial General Hospital, Union. His age was 87.

title: Film Festival: 'Debut':Russian Comedy Bows at Lincoln Center
description: The Ninth New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, which almost didn't happen because of financial difficulties, opened last night with the first Russian film to be shown by the festival in four years."The Debut," a comedy that manages to make gentle fun of both the Russian movie industry and Russian provincial life, is, comparatively speaking, a lot less stimulating than the controversy that surrounds the theater in which it was shown. That is the Vivian Beaumont Theater, most of the time the home of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company.The Beaumont, a legitimate theater whose sight lines aren't the best for movies, is the centerpiece of a building that soon will be partially converted to the purposes of film, specifically, the New York City Center-Henri Langlois Cinemathequea decision that has prompted almost as much mail as would the discovery of a bald eagle nesting at Gracie Mansion.The film buffs, of course, are pleased, and the lovers of theater are having fits, some less literate than others. It continues to shock many people that movies can be taken so seriously as the theatera reflection of the double standard that persists in the fact that people who are a little nutty about movies are called buffs, while their theater equivalents are described as lovers, as much in snobbery as in reverence.Because the New York Film Festival opening nights tend to be social occasions, largely attended by the Lincoln Center Film Society's patrons and friendspeople who do not necessarily have to love movies as much as they love their association with them, "The Debut" was probably a wise choice to lead off with. It could neither offend nor bore the sort of moviegoers who, in the past, were offended and bored by Bul's "The Exterminating Angel" and Godard's "Alphaville," which were, in their artistic orneriness, perfect festival films."The Debut" isn't. It's a nice, fairly conventional narrative film, about a spirited but hardly beautiful factory girl who suddenly finds herself playing the lead in a film biography of Joan of Arc. "The Debut" is black-and-white, which is still the mark of a "serious" film in some circles; it is Russian, which certifies it as being educational since we don't see that many Russian films (for good reason, I might add); and at its best, it recalls the humor and humanism that all of us were so surprised to find in the Czechoslovak films of Jiri Menzel, Milos Forman and Ivan Passer in the late 1960's.I must say that I like the movie, although with something less than a grand passion. At its center is an absolutely lovely performance by Inna Churikova as Pasha, a girl who is a good deal of the witch she is playing in a factory theatrical when she is discovered by the Moscow film director.Miss Churikova seems truly unbeautiful at first. Her peasant figure has the unyielding grace of a hay mattress, and no matter how she tries to control it, when she smiles, her upper lip is always rising to expose a lot more tooth and gum than one ordinarily wants to see. Very quickly, however, the magic of a complex personality begins to work to transform the actress into a most appealing heroine, awkward and terribly self-conscious, yet as ambitious and determined about her love life as about her career.One of the basic ironies of the film is the manner in which the director, Gleb Panfilov, cuts between the "Joan of Arc" that Pasha is making (which looks like a very ordinary, post-Eisenstein production) and her hilariously muddled love affair with a married zoologist (L. Kuravlev); a handsome, rather dumb fellow who is clearly not worthy of her. When pressed to examine himself, about all that he can find to recommend is the fact that he doesn't drink.Panfilov shares with Milos Forman die ability to build straight comedy, very delicately, into farce, and then to bring it back to reality again, without destroying the continuity of mood. He also possesses a point of view that never condescends to his characters, although he obviously finds their situations simultaneously sad and ridiculous. The scope of the film is small, but its emotions are true."The Debut," which starts its regular commercial run today at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, is a quiet film, made special by its star performance.

title: All Nite Soul Program Is Scheduled for Oct. 10
description: The second annual All Nite Soul, a 12hour program of jazz, folksong, dance and worship, will be held at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, starting at 5 P.M. on Sunday, Oct. 10, and continuing until 5 A.M. the following morning. The marathon program will be in celebration of the sixth anniversary of Jazz Vespers, held at St. Peter's every Sunday at 5 P.M.

title: Strike Frees Miners From Dungeon Peril
description: DANTE, Va., Oct. 1They squatted in the bright sunlight, joking and whittling and waiting for their last shift of coal mining for perhaps a month or two.

title: 4 Die in Dakota Air Crash
description: SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Oct. 1 (AP)Four persons from the Minneapolis area were killed when the light plane they were in crashed about 12 miles west of Sioux Falls during a thunderstorm today, the authorities said. The victims were identified by Dr. Richard Shultz, Minnehaha County coroner, as Jerome Heilman, 37 years old, pilot and owner of the plane, and his wife, Anna, 36, of Minneapolis, and Adam Silbernagel, 49, and his wife, Ann, 48, of Richfield.

title: STEADY STAR'S 1:52 WORLD PACING MARK
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP)Steady Star, with Joe O'Brien driving, set a world pacing record today at the Lexington Trots. He did a mile in 1:52 in a time trial to wipe out the old mark of 1:53 35 held by Bret Hanover.

title: A.M.A. Urges Wider Medical School Enrollment
description: An editorial in this week's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association urges that a large number of qualified American applicants be accepted into American medical schools to reduce a growing tendency of rejected applicants to seek their training abroad.

title: FACTORY ORDERS OFF 0.5% IN MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) Manufacturers' orders tumbled 0.5 per cent in August after a strong advance the previous month, the Government reported today.

title: Sports of The Times
description: John Riggins, the New York Jets' running back, soared above a pile of linemen toward the goal line. Touchdown or not?

title: Mrs. Cudone, on 236, Wins U.S. Senior Women's Golf
description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., Oct. (AP)Mrs. Carolyn Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S. C., shot a finalround of 78 today to win her fourth consecutive United States Golf Association's senior women's amateur tournament championship. Mrs. Cudone totaled 236 on rounds of 77, 81 and 78. Finishing one stroke behind on the 36, 3975 Sea Island Golf Course was Mrs. Ann Gregory of Gary, Ind.

title: Interest Rate Is Reduced On U.S. Development Loans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The Commerce Department announced today a  per cent reduction in interest rates on Federaldevelopment loans effective today.

title: Citing Freeze, C.A.B. Defers Action on Some Cargo Rates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board withheld approval late yesterday of a number of proposed international air cargo rate increases that appeared to contravene President Nixon's order freezing rates and prices.

title: Bridge: PostMortem More Painful Than Usual for Defender
description: It is always somewhat painful for a defender to discover in the postmortem that he has missed an inspired play that would have defeated the contract.

title: No Comment on Coast Talks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1Neither side would comment today on the course of negotiations in the 90dayold West Coast strike.

title: STRIKE OUT WINS $81,216 FUTURITY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 1Strike Out, one of two outstanding Canadianowned standardbreds, cast a strong vote for himself in the competition for the season's pacing honors among 2yearolds by winning the $81,216 Roosevelt Futurity tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: British Bill Rate Drops
description: LONDON, Oct. 1 (Reuters)The average rate at today's tender of Treasury bills was 4.7235 per cent, compared with 4.7531 per cent last week. This week's 120million offer met applications of 463.5million.

title: FloridaGrown Tomato vs. Mexico's
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 The tomato, that solanaceous perennial beloved of salad makers, will come under the scrutiny of consumers next Monday as to size, quality and nutritional value.

title: Ellsberg Friend, Held 47 Days, Agrees to Testify and Is Freed
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1  Anthony J. Russo, who has been imprisoned for 47 days for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon papers case, agreed today to appear and was set free.

title: Health Care for Aged Gains
description: GREAT NECK, L. I.A new concept in the care of the aged has begun to take shape on Long Island to accommodate the growing numbers of elderly people living in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Festival of Succoth To Begin at Sundown
description: The weeklong Jewish Festival of Succoth, the Feast of the Tabernacles, will begin tonight at sundown.

title: Baseball Playoffs Start
description: The National League baseball pennant playoff began yesterday as the Giants heat the Pittsburgh Pirates at San Francisco, 54. The American League series opener between the Orioles and Oakland Athletics was rained out at Baltimore. After completing the threeoffivegame series, the winners will meet in the World Series starting Saturday in Baltimore or Oakland. (Details in Section 5.)

title: Washington Paper Sold
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 2 (AP)The Seattle Times has purchased controlling interest of the Walla Wall, Wash., UnionBulletin.

title: Police Chiefs Split on Tough Gun Curb
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 2The country's police chiefs, meeting here this week, devoted a halfdozen seminars to the rising incidence of violence in the streets and the killing of policemen by senseless and unprovoked gunfire.

title: Birth Rate Declines Here, Reversing a 3Year Trend
description: A downturn in the number of births and in the birth rate is being recorded by the city's Health Department this year, reversing a trend of annual increases that began in 1968.

title: Preps
description: MILTON, MASS., Oct. 2Milton opened its season with a 200 victory over Belmont Hill. Tad Staley passed for one score and tallied a touchdown himself.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Everything about THE CANDYWINE DEVELOPMENT by John Morris (Citadel, $5.95) is very much a la mode. One member ofthe detective team is a nubile black lady  and that is of course intensely a la mode these days. The writing is lean, objective and smooth in its postAmbler style. The plotting is complicated: half the time, it is hard to figure out what the hell is going on. That too is a la mode. The idea is to wrap up, most neatly, the apparently diverse elements. All detective stories do that, but in the classic ones there is no obfuscation aside from false clues. In the modern detectiveespionage story things can be so confused that the basic plot line is unclear until the final resolution.

title: Anne D. McCutcheon Is Bride Of Ronald B. Lewis, a Lawyer
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., Oct. 2 Miss Anne Dart McCutcheon, an architect with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill in Washington, was married here today to Ronald Burton Lewis, a lawyer with Caplin & Drysdale in Washington.

title: Twin Time Takes Atlantic City Handicap by Four Lengths for 7th Triumph
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 2 (AP) Gene Mori's Twin Time turned in a stirring exhibition of speed and courage today in capturing the Atlantic City Handicap by four lengths.

title: SUPER WAVE BOWS TO RUM CUSTOMER
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 2 (AP) Rum Customer took an early lead and held it in a stretch drive to turn back Super Wave in the $25,000 Dr. Stanton Pace tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Blacks in Chicago Suburb Sign To Construct Housing Complex
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 2The black Mayor of a Chicago suburban village and a black contractor signed contracts today for the building of a $15million, 47acre housing and shopping complex.

title: The Nation
description: The Age of the Atom always seemed a blessing to the people of Grand Junction, Colo. They even added an atomic symbol to the city shield. For this small town on the western slope of the Ricky Mountains was a center of raw materials operations for the Atomic Energy Commission, with its own uranium ore processing mill along the Colorado River.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2Daybreak arrived with a scowl. It was gray and dismal and rainy. It was not one of those lovely days meant for baseball. It offered an invitation to catch up on sleep and it gave an instant sense of uneasiness. This is only the third year of the preliminary divisional playoffs and they had been ripped off thus far with disconcerting swiftness, all winners racing into their World Series slots by taking three in a row, without a hitch and without a delay.

title: Martin G. Smith Weds Elise Becket
description: SALISBURY, Conn., Oct. 2  Miss Elise Barr Becket, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Campbell Becket of Lakeville, was married here this afternoon to Martin Gregory Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Gregory Smith of St. Alban's, England.

title: Bembridge Wins Dunlop Golf By Two Strokes With 273
description: CHEPSTOW, Wales, Oct. 2 (UPI)Maurice Bembridge, a British Ryder Cup player, closed out his round with two birdies today to beat a teammate, Peter Oosterhuis, and win the $24,000 Dunlop Masters golf tournament.

title: Nassau South
description: Mel Lewis was Interviewed on television during the halftime of the Bellmore KennedyLong Beach football game yesterday for his twotouchdown effort for Long Beach. The second half, however, belonged to the Bellmore Kennedy team that rallied for a 1412, South Shore Division II victory.

title: The Nation
description: On the docks and in the softcoal fields, President Nixon found himself faced last week with the first major strikes since he froze wages and prices, and he met both challenges by reverting to the hands off approach of his first 30 months in the White House.

title: MOBILE MUSEUM FOR ART UNVEILED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Art Fleet, a portable museum designed to take important art collections 10 isolated sections of America, was unvejled today by Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts. It is expected to go on the road within a year.

title: Poff Factors: Civil Rights and Privacy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The four imperatives cited by Representative Richard H. Poff in withdrawing his frontrunning candidacy for nomination to the Supreme Court may have been dictated by two other Poff imperatives of longer standing, the Virginia Congressman's Representative's associates said today.

title: Texas Tech 1310 Victor
description: TUCSON, Ariz, Oct. 2 (AP)Dale Rebold recovered two fumbles and intercepted a pass to stop Arizona's scoring drives and lead Texas Tech to a 1310 victory today.

title: Women Bartenders Upheld
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 2 (UPI)Attorney General Richard Israel has upheld the right of women to tend bar in Rhode Island. Mr. Israel, issuing an opinion Thursday at the request of the State Commission on Human Rights, said that an old state law banning female bartenders was inconsistent with a fair employment practices act adopted by the General Assembly this year.

title: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY SOVIET TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2The Nixon Administration has emerged from its latest round of discussions with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, persuaded that its relations with Moscow are better now than at any time in the last three years.

title: Pop
description: IN the past month, I've attended at least 10 rock concerts at Carnegie Hall. Concerts, that is, in which virtually every decibel of the music was pushed through massive loudspeaker systems. And the advance schedule for the next month doesn't suggest that there will be much reduction in rock music activity at this most venerable of New York's concert halls.

title: The World
description: SANTIAGOIt did not seem like a solemn, historic occasion. Reporters mingled with Cabinet ministers, military commanders joked with leftwing political leaders, and only a slight air of tension and the klieg lights of the television cameramen gave the scene last Tuesday a sense of importance.

title: Growing Shortage Of Power in Cuba Bringing Blackouts
description: MIAMI, Oct. 2A few months ago, an important conference held in a provincial Cuban town between Premier Fidel Castro and several high Soviet officials was abruptly interrupted.

title: We Have to Choose Least of the Bad, Professor Says
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2Prof. Nguyen Ngoc Huy, who intends to cast his Vote for President Nguyen Van Thieu in the one  man election tomorrow, knows that opponents of the Government have sonic legitimate complaints. But he insists that President Thieu, though he is the only choice is a good choice.

title: R.P.I. Routs Hamilton, 4871
description: TROY, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP)Hamilton College's Andy Sopchak intercepted a Bob Baron pass early in the first quarter and ran it back for a touchdown, but that was all the scoring Hamilton did as Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute rebounded today for a 487 victory. Baron completed 26 passes for 264 yards, including four touchdown passes, three of them to Kalle Kontson.

title: WORLDSOLING TITLE GOES TO MOSBACHER
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 2Bob Mosbacher of Houston, the North American champion, was awarded the world Soling Class championship today when lack of wind canceled the sixth race of the weeklong series on Long Island Sound.

title: 49 GOALS SCORED IN POLO CONTEST
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 2The Monroe Pitchforks and the Ox Ridge Hunt Club scored at the rate of better than a goal minute in a firstround game of the Northeast Circuit Governor's Cup 5goal tournament last Tuesday.

title: M'COVEY GAUGED HOMER OFF BLASS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (UPI) Steve Blass, the Pirate pitcher, found out today that it doesn't pa yto try to embarrass Willie McCovey, the gimpykneed first baseman of the San Francisco Giants.

title: what a Honeymoon!
description: ANTILOVE means never having to say you're sorry for leaving your bride on your honeymoon for another woman. At least, that seems to be the message of The Heartbreak Kid, an upcoming movie written by Neil Simon and based on Bruce Jay Friedman's short story, A Change of Plan. If all goes according to the plan of Edgar J. Scherick, the enterprising man behind Palomar Pictures, the production should get under way here in December, before moving on to Miami and Minnesota.

title: Chrysler Has 53 Outboard Models
description: A 130horsepower, fourcylinder outboard and a 150horsepower, precision engine are Chrysler Corporation's new additions to its 1972 outboard line, which includes 53 models in all.

title: M.O.R.C. Title Race Nov. 2127
description: The Midget Ocean Racing Club, composed of yachts under 30 feet in length, will hold its first national championship Nov. 2127 in Miami. The regatta will consist of four races of 15, 127, 58 and 28 miles respectively, the longest race an overnighter across the Gulf Stream to Great Isaac Light in the Bahamas and back.

title: Syracuse Wins, 70
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind. Oct. (AP)Syracuse scored an early touchdown and Indiana failed to score for the second straight week as the Orangemen won, 70, today.

title: Dance
description: WHAT is the future for rock ballet? What for that matter is the past? There is no doubt that just as in the past choreographers have shown a consid?? interest in symphonic swing and the glossier forms of jazz, so more recently have choreographers been experimenting with rock music.

title: The Freeze and the Boat Industry
description: The Boating Industry. Association recently quizzed the Office of Emergency Preparedness about how the Nixon Administration's freeze would affect the marine bithiness. The following in question and answer form is what the B. I. A. found out:

title: ERNEST H. MILLIGAN
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 2Ernest H. Milligan, president of Lee Brothers, Inc., a New York storage company, and a founder of Allied Van Lines, a moving concern, died here yesterday. He was 88 years old and lived at 277 Greenfield Hill Road.

title: Nichols Wins on Field Goal
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP)Russ Wenzel kicked 30yard field goal with 30 seconds remaining today to give Nichols College a 107 victory over Plattsburgh State.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: EDUCATORS BACK FREEZE ON PH.D.'S
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 2A 12month moratorium on approval of any new Ph.D. programs at all of New York's universities, which began yesterday as ordered by the State Education Commissioner, has received the general approval of many of the state's leading educators.

title: ...And the Young Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: A FEW weeks ago I expressed some surprise that members of the younger generation should find themselves so heartily enjoying a Broadway comedy as conventional as Butterflies Are Fee, Shortly thereafter a press agent called me to suggest that conventional comedy was by no means the only thing the younger generation was ready to enjoy. If I wanted to find out for myself how else the land might lie I could drop down to the MereerHasberry and see One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

title: Brooklyn Libraries Will Extend Hours
description: The Brooklyn public library system will resume weekend service on Oct. 9, thanks to an easing of the freeze on new employes.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Not Forgotten

title: Health Department to Monitor Cost Rise for Hospital Services
description: The city's Health Department has developed plans to monitor hospital services to slow down a cost rise that has skyrocketed from $30 a day here in 1955 to $110 in 1968 and about $140 to $150 now.

title: SADAT CHALLENGE TO SOVIET IS SEEN
description: CAIRO, Oct. 2A visit to Moscow this month by President Anwar elSadat and highpowered delegation including Egypt's Minister of War, Gen. Mohammed Sadek, may prove decisive to the future course of SovietEgyptian relations and to Egyptian strategy regarding Israel, in the view of diplomats in Cairo.

title: Bates Beaten by Trinity For 3d Loss in Row, 177
description: LEWISTOW, Me., Oct. 2. Trinity College broke open tight defensive battle and defeated Bates in football today, 177. It was Bates's third loss in a row.

title: Preps
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Oct. Peddie, loser of its first game last week, scored three times in the first half today and then hold on for a 2014 victory over Cheshire. It was the visitors second loss of the season.

title: Bicentennial Parley Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) The American Revolution Bicentennial Commission will hold a regional meeting in Chicago Oct. 7 and 8.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: ALLENDE BACKERS ATTACKING PRESS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 2Chile' President, Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, is proud of his record of defending freedom of the press. His followers, however, are trying to discredit newspapers, magazines and radio stations that oppose the Government's political point of view.

title: Texas Routs Oregon, 357, and Extends RegularSeason Streak to 31 Games
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 2 (UPI)Two substitutes, Donnie Wigginton and Dennis Ladd, scored tivo touchdowns apiece today to pace thirdranked Texas to a 35.7 victory over Oregon and stretch the Longhorns' regular season winning streak to 31 games.

title: Recordings
description: STRAVINSKY is gone, but no great composer of history remains more eerily with us, thanks to that most mixed of blessings, 20th Century technology. Under his hand, or under his supervision, virtually everything he considered worthwhile was set down, mostly on Columbia recordings, and can be consulted by anyone curious as to how the artist himself thought his work should be performed. Columbia still has a few pieces to release before the jigsaw puzzle on Stravinsky is complete, and three such documentary items appear along with more familiar ones on Stravinsky Conducts Music for Chamber and Jazz Ensembles. It is as entertaining a diskful as its title suggests. The most substantial new entry is the Concertino for 12 Instruments, which the composer arranged in 1952 from the 1920 Concertino for String Quaetet.

title: Marceau Robbed of $200
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 2 (UPI)Marcel Marceau was the victim of a $200theft iast night while performing his pantomime act at the City Music Hall. The money, along with jacket, was stolen from his dressing room.

title: Ode to South Fork by a Newcomer
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.As a freshly minted resident of the South Fork of Long Islandminted in AprilI have recently been adding up the pros and cons of life in this exurban area 100 miles as the Long Island Expressway crawls from New York. And I find that the pros far outbalance the cons, although there are some rather weighty, negative factors.

title: MIAMI (OHIO) TOPS MARSHALL BY 666
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 2 (UN) Bob Hitchens ran for three of his teams nine touchdowns today as Miami routed Marshall, 666, for its fourth victory. The losers were held to a minus 21 yards in rushing.

title: Wolff Gets Knick Telecasts, Ryan Will Announce Hockey
description: Bob Wolff and Tim Ryan have been named the playbyplay announcers for the cable television games of the Knicks and the Rangers, respectively, at Madison Square Garden and the WORTV (Channel 9) telecasts of selected road games.

title: Bergen
description: East Paterson, held to a tie last week, stunned heavily favored Clifton yesterday with a 277 upset in East Paterson to give Bergen County football prestige a big lift.

title: U.S. Court Orders Refund Of War Protesters' Bond
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered the District to refund collateral forfeited by many of the 12,000 persons arrested during the Mayday antiwar demonstrations.

title: Haakawa to Fight Job Bias
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)S. I. Hayakawa, president of San Francisco State College, says that not enough has been done to end job discrimination, and he has ordered that persons hired in the next two years be predominantly blacks or other minority members.

title: 12 Sail for Amchitka to Fight Atom Test
