description: OTTAWA, Oct. 2Last week 12 angry men, as they call themselves, sailed their 85foot halibut boat, the Greepeace, out of Vancouver for a point just outside the threemile territorial limit off the Aleutian island of Amchitka.

title: Miss Goldstein Married Here
description: Miss Wendy H. Goldstein and Donald E. Weckstein both of New York, were married here last evening (8:30) at the Plaza Hotel where Rabbi Irving Koslowe performed the ceremony assisted by Cantor David Putterman.

title: Falmouth a Very Special Place
description: FALMOUTH, Mass. A boat and a dock at sunset, the neverceasing wonder of waterthose are the signs of Falmouth, a historic town at the western end of Cape Cod, where sailing has dreamlike quality.

title: Wash. State Sinks Utah
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 2 (UPI)Ty Paine, a quarterback, galloped on touchdown runs of 63, 45 and 8 yards and Bernie Jackson raced for a 74yard score today as Washington State registered a 3412 victory over Utah.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Peter MacDonald is chairman of the tribal council of the Navajo nation. In that role, which includes responsibility for managing $200million or so of his people's readily liquid investments, he has become accustomed to the white man's waysup to, but not including, white man's fishing.

title: The Good Word: The P.E.N. Joke Again
description: That will be a funny subject for you, won't it? is what they say when you tell them you're doing a piece on P.E.N. Experience warns to watch out for subjects like thatthe joke has already been made many times, if these people have heard about it. So I spent the 38th annual conference in Dublin trying to work out whether an unfunny piece could possibly be written about P.E.N., cheap novelty though that might be.

title: Eastern Patriarch Defends Ordination of Married
description: ROME, Oct. 2Leaders of Eastern rite Roman Catholic churches vigorously challenged Western attitudes toward priestly celibacy during opening debates today at the Synod of Bishops.

title: OHIO STATE ROUTS CALIFORNIA, 353
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2(UPI) Morris Bradshaw, a sophomore, scored two touchdowns and a substitute quarterback, Greg Hare, ran 40 yards for touchdown early in the final period today as Ohio State scored a 353 victory over California.

title: UNREST MOUNTING IN BRITISH PRISONS
description: LONDON, Oct. 2A group of Dartmoor convicts, declaring that militant action brings results, have asked for immediate investigation of their prison, one of Britain's oldest.

title: Oilers Activate Moseley
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The Houston Oilers of the National Football League placed Braden Beck, a kicker, on waivers today and activated Mark Moseley.

title: Local
description: Robert Stuart of Boys ran back the opening kickoff 70 yards for a touchdown kit after that it was all Thomas Jefferson yesterday in a Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League contest at Boys Field.

title: News of Dogs
description: Westbury, one of the hardy pioneers of the dog show world, will hold its 49th annual allbreed show today on the grounds of C. W. Post College at Brookville, L. 1. For the educated set, the Nassau Dog Training Club stages its 23d trial in conjunction with Westbury. For the comfort of the exhibitors, Westbury limited its entry to 1,800. Actually there will be 1,834, since all the letters in the batch accompanying No. 1,800 were accepted.

title: MAN, 27, IS SLAIN NEAR BUS TERMINAL
description: A 27yearold man was fatally stabbed shortly after 6 P. M. yesterday on Eighth Avenue, across the street from the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Preps
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 2Providence Country Day spotted St. George's a touchdown in the opening period today and then came back with two tallies to win, 156. It was the first game this season for the teams.

title: Tennessee Tops Florida, 2013, Behind 3dString Quarterback
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 2 (UPI)Phil Pierce, a thirdstring quarterback, hit Stan Trott with a 20yard touchdown pass play tonight that carried Tennessee to a 2013 victory over Florida. The score capped a 99yard drive in the third period.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Leader Pledges New Mexico Reform Drive
description: ALBUQERQUE, N. M., Oct. 2 With a pledge to carry the lonely cry of the consumer out of the wilderness and into the market place and to the halls of the Legislature, Dr. Lee Brown, an assistant professor of economics at the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque, has taken over as president of the newly formed Albuquerque Consumer Federation.

title: Rostrevor Scores by Neck At Freehold, Pays $15.40
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 2Happy Times stable's Rostrevor, owned by the partnership of Al Bragin, Aaron M. Kipnes and Johanna Newsom of West New York, N. J., unset five rivals today in the $10,000 Triple Dead Heat Pace at Freehold Raceway.

title: AROUND THE
description: Leaves will start falling soon. Is the compost area ready? ...Wild flowers of the fieldsasters, goldenrod, daisiesare good for casual displays indoors and for drying, too. Be on the lookout for fall fruits that can be collected and used for Christmas wreaths and decorations .... Move house plants indoors.

title: Cards to Start Beathard
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2Distinct underdogs (by 9 points) and deservedly so on the basis of performances to date, the New York Giants will expect a revived, offense to protect their defense today if they are to upset the St. Louis Cardinals in a game that starts at 4 P.M., New York time. It will be televised on Channel 2.

title: President Flies to Bahamas To Visit Home of Abplanalp
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 2 President Nixon left by helicopter this afternoon for Grand Cay Island in the Bahamas to visit the home of a friend, Robert Abplanalp, a New York industrialist.

title: Gibson Is Widely Regarded as Successful in Restoring Integrity to City Hall
description: NEWARKAfter more than a year in office as the first black mayor of this predominantly black city, Kenneth A. Gibson, in the eyes of many residents and officials, has begun to restore City Hall's reputation as an honest and workable institution.

title: Doing the College Hop Hampshire, Haverford And Harvard, Too
description: IT sometimes seems as if the last two years of high school are a series of frustrations and anxieties centering on admission to college. At least for a couple of uppermiddle class, white, suburban, intellectually oriented kids like ourselves it does.

title: John B. Ford 4th Weds Miss Janice M. Marr
description: PARK RIDGE, N. J., Oct. 2 Miss Janice Marie Marr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Thomas Marr of River Vale, was married in Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to John Battice Ford 4tb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford 3d of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Joseph Flanagan performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. William Kearney.

title: Offshore Oil: Debate Is On
description: COMMACK, L. I.Worried ecologists on Long Island are painting visions of oil derricks as tall as the Washington Monument sprouting from the Atlantic. mammoth oil slicks washing onto the clean white beaches and an industrial seashore where once children frolicked.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The New York metropolitan area has no major racing plant, and no promoter has tried to build one near the city. From this negative circumstance, it has long been assumed that racing promotions would not draw here. That premise was tested few weeks ago when Good year Tire and Rubber Company, one of the strongest economic forces in motor racing, brought its permanent barnstorming racingcar exhibit, Meet the Hot Ones, to the Bronx for three days.

title: P.O.W. Politics
description: Issues of war and peace have splintered the movement to secure the release of American servicemen held by the Communists in Indochina. To the dismay of nearly all the wives and relatives of the men, clashes between the factions have become increasingly public and bitter.

title: Mrs. Dickholtz Has Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. David Dickholtz on Sept. 18 at Doctors Hospital. The child has been named Andrew James.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Accent Will Be on Youth as National Hockey League Embarks on New Era
description: Althobgh it is still a few light years from being radicalized, the National Hockey League moves into the era of the youngster when it begins play next weekend. Perhaps the most dramatic symbol of the change is the departure of two starsGordie Howe and Jean Beliveauwho were among the dominant players of the 1950's and 1960's.

title: Died Doing a Favor
description: LONDON, Oct. 2 (Reuters) The captain of the plane that crashed in Belgium today was aboard because he did a favor, his wife said tonight. Captain Probert, whose wife and fiveyearold son live in Maindenhead, 25 miles west of London, changed places with another pilot who wanted to see his son off to boarding school.

title: EXEMPTION REQUESTS IN FREEZE DOWN 50%
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) The Cost of Living Council reported today that requests for exemptions from President Nixons's wageprice freeze dropped by more than 50 per cent in the week that ended Tuesday, as compared to the previous seven days, while complaints of violations rose.

title: Industrialist Who Financed Medina's Defense Heads Diversified Business Empire Built in Five Years
description: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 2The career of Glenn W. Turner, the man who financed the defense in the courtmartial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, hardly fits me pattern of ordinary industrialists.

title: Education
description: Only recently, colleges and universities seemed headed for a great overhaul stimulated by students and young professors who were bored with old courses, scornful of rigid degree requirements. and frustrated by the impersonality of institutions that were more accustomed to issuing edicts than talking things over.

title: Molly gloom would have blushed
description: Since she moved from a factory town in Connecticut to New York City, Jane Castle, now a frantic 36, has learned a lot: how to use people, how to shoplift at Ohrbach's, how to be a love machine, how to eat rotisserie chicken. She also knows that pursuing a life of pleasure is hard work, that she is a marketable commodity, that if you satisfy the need the ethic will take care of itself, and that analysis is the modern religion: There is only your doctor, who is god the father, and if his name isn't hallowed mine is mud. She is sure that pity is only false concern hiding contempt, that depression is beyond despair, aloneness bleaker than loneliness, and that reading the Sunday Times gives alone people an illusion of weight and force and substance against a world without counterforce. And she tells all, with no reticence whatever, via Philip Greene's taperecorder

title: ST. PETER'S BEATEN BY FORDHAM, 40 TO 0
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 2Fordham University won its first game tonight, a 400 triumph over St. Peter's at Roosevelt Stadium.

title: Patrolman Is Suspended fin Theft of Services Charge
description: A 44yearold patrolman with nearly 19 years of service was arrested and suspended from the force last Thursday for what the Police Department said was a theft of services.

title: Horse Show News
description: With the Olympic Games in Munich still almost a year away, the arrangements for the equestrian events are virtually complete.

title: Dear President Nixon, The last 24 hours has again been another day of pure hell for Americans in prison camps, cells ' cages in Southeast Asia
description: THE Air Force sends regular newsletters to the families of all the men it lists as captured by this country's enemies in Southeast Asia or missing in action there. Usually these communications are appropriately solemn, but sometimes they fall into a chatty, upbeat tone as they describe for the relatives the grassroots campaigninvolving the writing of letters and sending petitions to Hanoithat Legionnaires, Jaycees, church women and highschool students have undertaken on behalf of their husbands, sons and brothers. Most of this huge outpouring (amounting now to more than 50 million letters) has never reached Hanoi, and there is scant reason to suppose that Vietnamese officials able to read letters in English from Salinas, Kan., or Sante Fe, N.M., bother to do so. Yet such students of Vietnamese psychology as the Dallas multimultimillionaire H. Ross Perot have promised that making the treatment of our men a visible issue in the United States will bring the North Vietnamese to their knees. Vietnament Communists, Perot has discovered, suffer from an inferiority complex that leads them to crave.

title: Elizabeth M. Blettner Is Engaged
description: WINNETKA, Ill., Oct. 2Miss Elizabeth Mary Blettner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Blettner, and Sp/ 5 Kurt David Moses, U.S.A., who is stationed in Munich, Germany, plan to be married here Nov. 6 in the Congregational Church chapel.

title: Will Ranks Three Wives: $100,000, $10,000 and $1
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP)Fuller E. Callaway 3d, socialite yachtsman who died from what a corner called an apparent overdose of sleeping pills, willed $100,000 to his first wife, Wanda: $10,000 to his second wife, Pia Lindstrom, and $1 to his third wife, Annette Cash.

title: Preps
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 2 Joe Brooking carried for the first two touchdowns and passed long to Steve Smith for his team's last score today as Hackley defeated New York Military Academy, 2414. Steve Ciampi broke through right tackle for 29 yards for the Other touchdown.

title: Headliners
description: Exit Bunche

title: 4 Scores Against Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 2Ed Marinaro gained 246 yards and scored four touchdowns against Rutgers today to lead Cornell to its second victory, 3117, before a Rutgers homecoming crowd of 15,000.

title: Preps
description: Doug Miller, continued his spectacular passing yesterday as he led Poly Prep to its seventh straight victory, 358, over Brooklyn Prep at Poly. Miller completed 8 of 11 passes for 200 yards and two touchdowns. One of the scores was a 36yard pass to. Marshall Miller, Doug's brother. Doug has now thrown five scoring passes in Poly's two games.

title: Bouzy Rouge to Come to U.S.; Red Wine From Champagne
description: BOUZY, France  There is no such thing as a red champagne, but the champagne country does produce a few red wines, of which the only one at all wellknown is Bouzy rouge. With a name like that, it would seem a a natural for the transAtlantic market, but Bouzy is a notoriously poor traveler; even at home, it is unstable, and only a few Paris restauants handle it.

title: Et Al.
description: A familiar chronicle  the political and sociological sojourn of blacks in America. The author explains the failure of the Reconstruction (conflicts between radicals and the conservative Democrats), the advent of Jim Crow, the beginnings of black protest and how it split along integrationist and separatist lines. He then shows how the country's lack of response to black demands for equality has led to the development of revolutionary groups. Nothing new; an introduction to black American history.

title: Corporate Look: Is It About to Change?
description: Last spring, before he surrendered the reins at the International Business Machines Corporation, Thomas J. Watson Jr. tried to reas sert control over the way his employes looked. While he stopped short of demanding the white shirts that legend and widespread practice had ordained for visible I.B.M troops and officers, Mr. Watson directed managers to establish and enforce conservative dress and appearance standards.

title: Architecture
description: THE current word in architecture is nonarchitecture. When the structures of such diverse institutions of the top and bottom of society as prisons and cultural centers lead to the same word in the same week, it is more than coinsidence.

title: A TwoLane Mississippi
description: Once again it has taken a Federal court to block, at least for the moment, a project of such dubious environmental effect that it should never have been launched without a thorough airing of its potential consequences. The Army Corps of Engineers, with its characteristic zeal for great ditches, was on the point of moving earth for the TennesseeTombigbee Waterway when District Court Judge John Lewis Smith Jr. stopped preliminary operations on the ground that the Corps had failed comply with the Environmental Policy Act.

title: Mary Block Bride of a Professor
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 2Miss Mary Lee Block and John Lawrence Landsman were married here this evening at the Losantiville Country Club. Rabbis Solomon Greenberg and Brooks Susman officiated at the ceremony.

title: Chris Evert Leaning Toward a Pro Career
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Oct. 2 (Reuters)Chris Evert, the 16yearold who surprised everybody by reaching the semifinals of the United States Open tennis championship thinks she would like to turn pro when she finishes high school.

title: Preps
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 2  McBurney relied on Rick Strace's 14yard touchdown run and a rugged defense that turned in two safeties to beat Locust Valley Friends, 126, today. Friends scored in the final period on an 18yard run by Steve Getter.

title: Nassau North
description: Those who think Suffolk County football has reached a level of play comparable to neighboring Nassau had their opinions bolstered yesterday by Cold Spring Harbor's 1814 upset of Carle Place, the perennial North Shore Division IV champion.

title: T. J. Poulos to Wed Miss Gassenheimer
description: PERTH AMBOY, N. J., Oct. 2  Mrs. Walter Tenbroeck Gassenheimer of Perth Amboy and Normandy Beach has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Bernadette Eleanore Gassenheimer, to Thomas James Poulos, son of Mrs. Anne P. Poulos of New Hyde Park, L. I., and James Thomas Poulos of Rego Park, Queens. The wedding is planned for May.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONIt might have seemed just another exercise in the mysteries of high finance. But the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund here last weekheld in an atmosphere of crisiswas in fact of potential consequence to the working man and his employer all over the world. These were some of the concerns:

title: Pass Caps Late Comeback
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 2Yale, which has dominated its 62year series with Colgate, dominated only the middle phases of today's struggle with the Red Raiders and suffered surprising 2821 defeat.

title: THREE NEW WORKS BY CONCERT GROUP
description: Since it generally requires a complex mechanism of foundations, militant composers' alliances and special pleading to bring new music before the public these days, it was pleasant to see an ad hoc group of musicians gathering in Carnegie Recital Hall Friday night to introduce three works simply for the sheer fun of it.

title: Montana Upset, 2112
description: MISSOULA, Mont., Oct. 2 (UPI)Rick Seefried sprinted 64 yards for one touchdown and Fred Riley scored twice on short plunges today as Idaho posted a 2112 upset victory over previously unbeaten Montana.

title: New Plea For Bigger Gateway By Lindsay
description: WASHINGTONWith prospects fading for quick House approval this year of the Gateway National Recreation Area, Mayor Lindsay has made a new push to include the beaches at the northern edge of Jamaica Bay and a federally financed transportation experiment in the project.

title: Pop
description: PAUL STOOKEY: Paul And (Warner Bros.). Just as the 60's was the era of group music, the 70's seems to be the time for group members to perform individually. As a result, we get four times as much music from the Beaties and so far twice as much from Peter, Paul & Mary. (Only Peter Yarrow hasn't yet taken his solo album plunge.) But the parts aren't always as good as the whole and throughout Paul Stookey's first solo disk I kept wishing for those Peter, Paul & Mary vocal dynamics. Particularly on the first side, Stookey's voice tends to get monotonous  perhaps because he's not used to recording alone. The second side of the disk, however, does offer far more vocal and musical range than the first.

title: ITALIAN OFFICIALS CAUTION ON PILLS
description: ROME, Oct. 2Italians will soon get a piece of sound advice with their morning mail: Take medicines only in case of need.

title: Youth. 20. Shot at Dance At N.Y.Y. Student Center
description: A 20yearold youth was shot and critically wounded at about midnight at a dance in the Loch Student Center of New Yrok University at 565 La Guardia Place and Washington Square South.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: LOUISIANA STATE ROUTS RICE, 383
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 2 (AP)Louisiana State, penerating the Rice defense practicllly at will, rolled to a 383 victory tonight.

title: UCONN VICTOR, 2821, ON A 72YARD RUN
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 2Lou Allen raced 72 yards for the deciding touchdown to give Connecticut a 2821 victory over New Hampshire today after the Huskies trailed, 217, at halftime.

title: ULSTER MAN KILLED IN BOMB EXPLOSION
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 2 (Reuters)Soldiers and policemen investigating a bomb blast in the council offices of a twon south of Belfast today found the body of a civilian killed by the explosion.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: MILLIONS VOTING IN ONEMAN RACE IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sun. day, Oct. 3Millions of South Vietnamese are voting today to reelect Prsident Nguyen Van Thicu, the only candidate in an election that has brought embarrasment to American officials and distress to many Vietnamese.

title: Music
description: WHAT happens to a celebrated American composer  one accustomed to the sweet smell of success  when he is suddenly overcome by the foul fumes of failure? Does he quietly slink off to foreign lands licking his wounds, or does he merely shrug his shoulders and say, If I must have a fiasco, it may as well be a monumental one?

title: CONSERVATIONISTS SEE ALASKA RAID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Spokesmen for 12 conservation organizations called on President Nixon today to prevent a raid upon the public domain in Atlaska by speculators and exploiters in timber, mining, of and other developments.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Wyoming Triumphs by 176
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 2 (UPI) The University of Wyoming eleven capitalized on three Colorado State University miscues today en route to a 176 Western Athletic Conference victory.

title: Princeton Harriers First
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 2  Rutgers University's Bruce Carpenter set the fifthfastest time in the history of Buccleuch Park today, but Princeton University's crosscountry team came away with two victories.

title: Colby Downs Tufts, 210
description: MEDFORD, Mass., Oct. 2 (AP) Pete Gorniewicz, a freshman, gained 177 yards rushing and scored twice today in powering Colby to a 210 victory over Tufts.

title: Malamud's best book in years, about a black and a Jew
description: Out of the torrent of Jewish novels published in the last 20 years, which for a time became the central current of our literature, it seems now that three books  all flawed but all more or less justly celebrated stand out as having added something inalienable to the stock of American selfknowledge: Malamud's The Assistant, which (along with the related stories in The Magic Barrel) turned the firstgeneration immigrant experience into timeless Jewish parable of suffering and redemption, Bellow's Herzog, his best book, a manically buoyant epic of Jewish intellectuality, and Portnoy's Complaint, Philip Roth's raunchy summa of the Jewish family romance.

title: Many Farm Labor Offices Favor Growers
description: SEBASTOPOL, Calif., Oct. 2  In much of the country, farmers may violate minimum wage, health, housing, immigration and child labor laws without fear of losing the services of the federally funded, stateoperated farm labor offices that recruit seasonal workers for them.

title: CONGRESS WARNED BY NIXON ON RAISE
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 2 (UPI)President Nixon said today that if Congress overruled his plan to defer scheduled pay raises for more than four million Federal military and civilian employes, it would torpedo efforts to restore prosperity.

title: Look's Workers Get Aid From Magazine In Finding New Jobs
description: A placement service designed to help about 250 employes of Look magazine find new jobs when publication ceases with the Oct. 19 issue has been set up by Cowles Communications, Inc., in its corporate offices at 488 Madison Avenue.

title: Penn Turns Back Brown Eleven, 1716
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2Penn and Brown, whose teams have been in the depths of Ivy League football longer than their fundraisers care to remember, served notice on the brethren today they are going to raise some hell on the circuit this season. Opening the Ivy action at Franklin Field before 15,105, Penn edged the Bruins, 1716, in an exciting game full of good football, most of it offensive.

title: For Young Readers
description: There was a poor young boy who left his country home/And came to the city to seek employment, recounts the grand old W. C. Fields number, and everyone knows what traps and trials await youthful innocence in the sinful city. Nearly as prominent in folk tradition is the urban easternergonewest.

title: Danbury Rally Urges Prison Reform
description: DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 2More than 2,000 persons rallied in Kenosia Park today to urge prison reform as 300 inmates of the Federal Correctional Institution several miles away, held a memorial service for all deceased correction officers and Inmates of Attica prison.

title: Preps
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 2 Dave Johnson, a senior halfback, scored all of his team's points today as Suffield downed Hotchkiss 120. Johnson's two firsthalf touchdowns came on runs of 29 and 12 yards.

title: Elizabeth Jarvis Nichols Wed To Richard H. Troy, a Lawyer
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 2Miss Elizabeth Jarvis Nichols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Slocum Nichols of Laurel Hollow, Syosset, was married here today to Richard Hershey Troy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Edward Troy of Melrose, Mass.

title: ARSENAL GROWS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 2  The development of a South African air missile, announced by Ministry of Defense here month, has added another weapon to the formidable of armaments the country now manufacturing for herself.

title: Diesel Engines From Abroad Make Inroads in Boat Market
description: The small gasoline engine, lightweight, compact and fairly quiet, is welt established on American yachts as the standard sailboat kicker, while, with few exceptions, the rest of the world's small sailing yachts are traditionally dieselpowered.

title: New Queens Buses To Run to Manhattan
description: Two express bus lines will begin taking commuters from southeastern Queens into Manhattan this month, the Transit Authority announced last week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Aide in Cyprus Quits
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Oct. 2 (AP) The United Nations' special representative in Cyprus, Bibiano F. OsorioTafall, said today he was resigning because the feuding Greek and Turkish Cypriote communities had rejected his peacemaking efforts. Mr. OsorioTafall then left Nicosia for New York to advise Secretary General Thant on the latest developments in Cyprus.

title: Sagamore Toccoa, Ascob Cocker Spaniel, Captures 9th BestinShowAward
description: LAKE GROVE, L.I., Oct. 2The topwinning cocker spaniel in America, Ch. Sagamore Toccoa, who has been cutting quite a swath on the dog show, trail, romped out of the ring today on the Lake Grove School grounds as the No. 1 dog of 1,202 competitors in the Suffolk County Kennel Club show.

title: Miss Brown Sets Nuptials
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct 2Mrs. Barbara Lennox Brown has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Brown, to D. Scott Ketner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Clough Ketner of New York and Stonington, Conn.

title: Music. A New Series at Philharmonic
description: Pierre Boulez had a busy schedule Thursday and Friday. Thursday evening and Friday afternoon he conducted the New York Philharmonic subscription series. After the Friday concert, he immediately went downtown to the Martinson Hall of the Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. There he directed the first of the Philharmonic's new seriesthe Prospective Encounters.

title: Crisis at Volkswagen
description: BONN  Sure, there is Ralph Nader, said a young German businessman just back from the United States, but despite his warnings most Americans seem to consider Volkswagen a swell automobile.

title: Computer Is Used To Monitor Health Of 150 Teamsters
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., Oct. 2  The automated, computerized health screening of upstate members of the teamsters union finished its first week yesterday, and three of the 150 persons tested were referred for medical followup.

title: SEASON'S FIRSTS ARE GIVEN AT MET
description: A season's first for Irene Dalis as Santuzza in Cavalleria Rusticana and a Metropolitan Opera first for the Canio of Ludovic Spiess in the Pagliacci nightcap were the important cast changes in the twin productions Friday night.

title: Gandhi Site Dedicated
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 2 (Reuters) India marked the 102d anniversary of the birth of Gandhi today by dedicating to the nation the place in New Delhi where the independence lead was shot dead by a Hindi fanatic in 1948. The house on the grounds where Gandhi was killed was dedicated by President V. V. Giri.

title: New York at Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 2After having lost their first two games, the Jets will be confronted with a crisis tomorrow against the Miami Dolphins.

title: Lunches for Hungry Children
description: The 75to5 vote in the Senate to provide more Federal money for school lunches should be a prod to the Administration to fulfill its pledges to banish hunger among America's schoolchildren.

title: Miss Heller Engaged
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 2?? and Mrs. Jerome Heller have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Elizabeth Gordon Heller, to Eugene Rosenberg, son of Mr. end Mrs. Louis Rosenberg of Hewlett. The couple, recent graduates of the University of Cincinnati, plan a January wedding.

title: Isabel Kline Rock, Served As Connecticut Legislator
description: NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 2Mrs. Isabel Kline Rock, a former member of the Connecticut House of Representative from Wilton and Weston, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital at the age of 81. She was the widow of Philip R. Rock, an architect: and lived at 7 Kensett Avenue, Wilton.

title: Pop
description: LOUDON WAINWRIGHT III: Album II (Atlantic). Thanks to the overexposure of James Taylor, the solo male singer  guitarist  songwriter has snatched the spotlight away from the rock bands. Alas, too many of the soloists harp on lengthy, sometimes dense, and often dreary tales of the trials and tribulations of being young, hip and hairy. Not Loudon Wainwright III. Rarely do I reach for superlatives, but Wainwright is the most original talent to have turned up in the 70's.

title: Eleanor Steber Sings In a Theatrical Crisis
description: Eleanor Steber, the Metropolitan Opera soprano, made an unscheduled and impromptu Off Broadway appearance Friday evening and received a threeminute ovation.

title: Guardsman at Kent State Wins Ruling for Discharge
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 (AP)The Ohio National Guard has been ordered to discharge a guardsman who declared himself a conscientious objector after the shooting deaths of four students at Kent State University.

title: Photography
description: LAST year a strange book of photographs appeared from a new publisher, Lustrum Press. The hook, The Somnambulist, by Ralph Gibson, described itself as a dream sequence, and indeed it conveyed the atmosphere of a dream verging on a nightmare. The only text was a cryptic note to the reader less than 20 lines long. After that, a sequence of blackandwhite photographs made up body of the book; photographs that were bizarre enough in themselves, and that followed one another in an order whose meaning was by no means apparent, even after repeated looks.

title: Schooner Race Victor To Get Two Trophies
description: The fifth annual schooner race for the Mayor's Cup, sponsored by the South Street Seaport Museum and the Department of Marine and Aviation will offer an added incentive this year.

title: Minnesota Beats Kansas
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (AP) Minnesota, ending the Big Eight's fouryear domination of Big Ten football teams, beat Kansas, 3820, today with a strong rushing attack, led by the Gophers' quarterback, Craig Curry.

title: Patricia Wolff Married
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 2 Miss Patricia Kingsley Wolff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Willson Wolff, was married here this afternoon to Joseph Henry Schubert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Schubert of Glendale, Queens, New York. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence McColl Horton performed the ceremony in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

title: Mother With Sons Injured in the War Has Burned Her Voting Card
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2A Buddhist housewife who has seen her five sons go to war expressed her anger and disgust with the Saigon Government by burning her yellow voting card last week. It was a small demonstrationone in a series that was started here two weeks ago by housewives, students and disabled veteransand it went unnoticed by the rest of the city.

title: Buffalo State Nine Downs Scranton, Rochester Tech
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y., Oct. 2 (AP)State University at Buffalo scored a 76 baseball victory over the University of Scranton and beat Rochester Institute of Technology 10, in a tripleheader today.

title: Et Al.
description: In 1736 John Wesley, a preacher naive beyond his 32 years, went to Savannah to bring the Word to the first English settlers of Georgia. In short order he found himself tempted by one Sophy Hokey, 18yearold niece of a local magistrate and already tentatively engaged to a blade serving time for counterfeiting. The two spent many an hour together discussing salvation, but John could not bring himself to blurt out what would have been a welcome proposal. Finally Sophy eloped with still another man, causing John to deny her communion and cast doubt on the legitimacy of her marriage. He returned to England soon after. Religionists regard the outcome as happy because it left him free to pursue his extraordinary career as missionary and founder of Methodism. Wesley kept a diary (not decoded till this century), which, together with the standard biographies and histories, provides the material for Mrs. Ethridge's book. Her account falls between two stools: no news to scholars and not much entertainment for amateurs of romance. Also, it is padded and awkwardly organized.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: JOFFREY'S SEASON STARTS WEDNESDAY
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet will open a sixweek season at the City Center Wednesday with the first of four new productions for this fall, Feast of Ashes. Based on GarciaLorca's The House of Bernarda Alba, the ballet by Alvin Ailey with music by Carlos Surinach was created for the Joffrey Ballet in 1962. It was restaged under Mr. Ailey's supervision with the assistance of Karina Rieger.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Florida State Triumphs
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 2 (AP)  Gary Huff riddled Virginia Tech with passes today as Florida State trounced the Gobblers, 173.

title: SATO OPPONENTS WAX OPTIMISTIC
description: KARUIZAWA, Japan, Oct. 2 Former foreign Minister Takeo Mika outlined his views for a cheering group of 300 supporters in this mountain resort this week, and told them that A change of government is the demand of the times.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Every Sunday The New York Times includes a separate section, lA, on Brooklyn. Queens and Long Island. It contains news and features of interest these areas and appears in copies distributed Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: SO. METHODIST RUNS TOP N.M. STATE, 2825
description: DALLAS, Oct. 2 (AP)Gary Hammond tallied three touchdowns and Calvin Maxson dashed for another score today as Southern Methodist edged New Mexico State, 2825.

title: Germany Stresses Safety
description: WEST GERMANY will issue rolls of stamps  similar to American coil stamps in its permanent series under the title Unfallverhutung (accident prevention) aimed at safety on the highway  directly at drivers who drink alcoholic beverages, and also at children playing on the street.

title: A CARNEGIE GRANT TO AID CHILD CARE
description: The Carnegie Corporation has announced a grant of $161,000 to Brookline, Mass., to plan a program of care and education for children from birth to age 5.

title: GA. TECH DEFEATS CLEMSON, 24 TO 14
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 2 (UPl)Eddie McAshan, threatened with disciplinary action earlier in the week for publicly criticizing Georgia Tech's offense, scored two firsthalf touchdowns today to lead the Yellow Jackets to a 2414 victory over Clemson.

title: Young Salts Turned Out In Six Days
description: MYSTIC, Conn.  Marilyn Turner, a Girl Scout from Charlotte, N.C., could have visited the Grand Canyon this summer. Instead, she chose to spend the time scrubbing decks and polishing brass aboard the Joseph Conrad, a ship moored in Mystic harbor.

title: Wyoming Praised by Udall
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 2 (UPI) Stewart L. Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, says it is a happy historical accident that Wyoming has a slow growth and has failed to gain in population in the nineteensixties. Wyoming is one of the three or four states with the best environment and the least pollution, Mr. Udall told students at the University of Wyoming last Thursday. He urged the students to keep it that way.

title: Vacations End for Tenderlings
description: AS anyone knows, has read Heidi knows, sheep and goats turned loose in the spring to roam the mountain fields must be rounded up at summer's end and brought back to the farmhouse, there to live right under the same roof with the family.

title: Coast Newspaper Post Filled
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 2 (AP)Lyle A. Johnson has been named president and general manager of the San Francisco Newspaper Printing Company, it has been announced. The company handles all noneditorial functions for The San Francisco Chronicle, The San Francisco Examiner and The Sanday Examiner and Chronicle.

title: Movies
description: I KNOW somebody who is Jewish and homosexual, said John Schlesinger. His parents told him, We know. We know the life you lead. But you must marry. After that, you can carry on whatever way you want. I consider that the most awful piece of family advice I've ever heard. Of course, they're an American family, and Americans seem to have more hangups about these things than the Europeans do.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Bob Curtis, a veteran retailing security man, has a lot to say in this book about how inventory shortages develop in American stores. Beginning with the assumption that onequarter to onehalf of these shortages are caused by outside thieves (another book about internal theft is in the works), he describes how merchants are taken by outsiders and what can be done to prevent this situation.

title: City Council Profile
description: Again this year, the Brooklyn regular Democratic organization will run on its hallowed slogan: Honesty is no substitute for experience.

title: New Indonesian Parliament
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. (Reuters)The Indonesian Parliament dissolved itself today to make way for the country's first elected parliament since 1957. The new Parliament, comprising 360 members who won seats during the general elections July 3 and 100 appointed members, will be sworn in Oct: 28.

title: King Midas, at 101, Is Sweeps Winner
description: NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 2King Midas, a 101 outsider, scored a threelength victory today in the 1mile Cambridgeshire Handicap. He rewarded those who had drawn him in the Irish Sweepstakes with $120,000.

title: Humphrey, McGovern Give Minnesota Talks
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota raised more money but Senator George McGovern of South Dakota drew a bigger crowd.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Victiory at at Sea Music to Builder's Ears
description: NORTH PALM BEACH, Fla.Not many individual boat builderi will spend thousands of dollars to turn out, a single contender for one particular event. America's Cup hopefuls do it, but even then a syndicate is usually involved.

title: William Owen Cowgfer, 49, Dies; Former Kentucky Representative
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP)Former Kentucky Representative William Owen Cowger died here tonight in Kentucky Baptist Hospital at the age of 49. Hospital physicians said he suffered an apparent heart attack.

title: Blue Cross Gets 16% Raise
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP)Citing the substantial increased cost of medical care, the Florida Insurance Commissioner, Tom O'Malley approved yesterday an average 16 per cent rate increase on some Blue CrossBlue Shield policies.

title: North Korea Says South Delays on Red Cross Parley
description: TOKYO, Oct. 2 (AP)North Korea accused the South Korean Red Cross today of delay and insincerity in preliminary talks aimed at reuniting families split apart by the division of Korea.

title: 500 HOMOSEXUALS STAGE A PROTEST
description: About 500 members of the Gay Activists Alliance, an organization of homosexuals, marched to the home of City Councilman Saul Sharison early this morning to protest what the group called his inaction on a bill banning discrimination against homosexuals.

title: Miss Balboni Has Nuptials
description: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Oct. 2  Miss Christina Fletcher Balboni was married here this afternoon to Robert Edward Patterson. The Rev. Donald Bitsberger performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer.

title: Preps
description: WILBRAHAM, Mass., Oct. 2 The Wilbraham and Monson eleven registered its second viatory of the season today as Harry Wilson scored three touchdowns in a 226 rout of Loomis.

title: The Queens That Gatsby Knew
description: Although F. Scott Fitzgerald never lived in Queens and his best known work. The Great Gatsby, in not a novel about the borough, the book does offer a glimpse of what Queens must have been like half a century ago to a sharpeyed if somewhat romantic observer.

title: Home for the working artist
description: The artist's garret is now a mythif indeed it ever existed. Contemporary paintings are so large that both their making and their display require immense spacedrawing artists, as always, to the least desirable neighborhoods. In converting a flophouse in SoHo, the loft area south Houston Street, for residence and studio, artist Kenneth Noland sought to create a type of museum space with places to feel and experience art. He had been impressed by museums where benches invite lingering and relaxing amid the art. His building, anonymous from the street, expresses this theory. The spaces unfold: the gallery on the first level, studio on the second, and on the topa 40foot expanse of paintings and sculpture. Noland called upon friendsdesigners Mica Ertegun and Chessie Rayner and architect Gilles Lesieurin the building's design. But the spare bands of color that are a trademark of Noland's paintings seem echoed in his spare use of furnishings. Everything but what might be called the essence of living is deleted.

title: CITY'S BRONX MAP IS DRAWN ASKEW
description: Yankee Stadium is in the upper Bronx, right?

title: Rabbi Gets Bible Rarities To Sell to Aid Charities
description: A rare collection of Biblical incunabulaincluding a volume of the Scriptures translated from the Greek into Latin by Martin Luther before the Protestant Reformation and a compilation of 15thcentury Roman Catholic lawwas given last weeek to Rabbi Philip Hiat of Mount Neboh Congregation here by a Polishborn Jewish physician from Cadiz, Ohio.

title: Hawks Rout Bullets
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 3 (UPI)Lou Hudson's 30 points led the Atlanta Hawks to a 136101 victory over the Baltimore Bullets tonight, leaving the Hawks undefeated in seven perseason games. Kevin Loughery led the Bullets with. 19 points. It was Baltimore's sixth loss in seven exhibition, games.

title: Broader U.S. Parks Permit Urged by Senator Church
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, says the Interior Department should issue a nationwide permit that would pay for nearly all fees encountered by visitors to national parks and other Federal recreation areas.

title: My Turf Is Not a Ghetto
description: We live on a quiet street in the borough of Brooklyn in the county of Kings. Softly silent is our treelined block, save for the squealing laughter of children, the chirping of birds, the chattering of crazy crickets and the gentle rustling of wind in the trees that make the world around our house sound like continuous summer showers.

title: The tent city set up in Persepolis, Iran, where heads of state will live during celebration of 2,500th anniversary of Persian Empire
description: The nearly 50 heads of state who will be in Persepolis, Iran, the week of Oct. 10 to help the Persians celebrate the 2,500th anniversary of their empire will live in tent city set up for the occasion.

title: NOTRE DAME TOPS MICH. STATE, 142
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 2So often a memorable item on the national television schedule in other years, today's Notre Dame  Michigan State football game was an artistic flop as the Irish won, 142, and remained unbeaten through three games this season.

title: Miss French, A. Y. M'Ferran Married on L.I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 2.  St. John's Episcopal Church of Lattingtown was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Frederica Pearson French, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seth Barton French Jr., to Alexander Young McFerran, son of Ferman H. McFerran of Bridgeport, W. Va.. and the late Mrs. McFerran. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell and was followed by a reception at the Piping Rock Club.

title: CLARENCE AXMAN
description: Clarence Axman, retired editor of the Eastern Underwriter, a trade journal now known as Insurance, died in a nursing home in Florida on Sept. 9. He was 94 years old.

title: Justices Face New Issues Tomorrow As Term Opens
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2With two empty seats as a reminder of the changes that are overtaking the Supreme Court, the Justices will meet Monday to begin a new Court term that will raise a wide range of new constitutional issues.

title: Photography
description: A NEW adapter recently introduced allows owners of InstamaticX cameras to use all popular electronic flash units with their cameras. Designed to Clip firmly into the cube socket on top of the camera, the adapter has a hot shoe and PC cord connection, and it enables owners of this type of camera to shoot repeated indoor pictures with no need for changing bulbs. Called the Kalimar InstamaticX Strobe Adapter, it is priced at $9.95 and is distributed by Kalimar, Inc., 2644 Michigan Avenue, St. Louis, Mo. 63118.

title: Ford Tried Dissuasion
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP)The House Republican leader, Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, said that Mr. Poff telephoned him today before making his withdrawal announcement and told him of his decision. Mr. Ford said he had urged Mr. Poff not to withdraw his name, but his action was irrevocable.

title: October
description: The outdoor world is putting on its finery now, the harvest finery that represents a season's summary. The ancient gods are smiling and the shape of the earth begins to clarify for those who would look. Fall winds are blowing, clarifying the air. The blue skies of October look down on a spectacle that speaks for the earth itself, for its enduring vitality, its strength of creation and fulfillment. The color comes, not in one leaf or one tree, but through the whole woodland, across the breadth of the land, all the way to the horizon and beyond.

title: ST. JOHN'S CRUSHES PACE ELEVEN, 400
description: Using a consistent ground attack coupled with a strong defense St. John's University's club football team overwhelmed Pace, 400, before a rainsoaked crowd of 1,000 yesterday at the winners' field in Hillcrest, Queens.

title: RAINMAKER TAKES 2 HUNTER CROWNS
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 2Rainmaker, owned and ridden by Mrs. Robin Holdsworth, captured two championshipsboth by narrow marginstoday at the Greenbrier Horse Show.

title: Art
description: HAVING, suffered occasionally, like anyone else, from the effusions of new converts to this or to that, feel that a degree of restraint must be observed in expressing my enthusiasm for a new exhibition at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where, for the first time, Chinese calligraphy struck me as being everything that its fans crack it up to be. It is an art that is much written about, and you can read and read, agreeing all the while with what is said about the expressiveness of the calligraphic characters as symbols, their beauty as abstract patterns (which is easy), and the amazing combination of spontaneity and control that characterizes the work of all proficient Chinese calligraphers.

title: New Bar President Urges Aid to MiddleIncome Group
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 2 (UPI)  The Presidentelect of the American Bar Association says that the poor are getting more legal help, the rich have always bee nable to afford it, but the legal profession has overlooked middleincome persons.

title: CRIME IN TOKYO A MINOR PROBLEM
description: TOKYO, Oct. 2The Japanese National Police obtained warrant this week for the arrest of a rightist leader who trailed to Premier Eisaku Sato a pistol, 175 cartridges, and note demanding that he shoot himself for failing to crack down on leftist radicals.

title: Michigan Trounces Navy, 460, as Defense Registers Third Shutout in Row
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 2 (AP)  Secondranked Michigan's offense found stiff resistance in the first half, but the defense had little trouble recording its third consecutive shutout as the Wolverines trounced Navy, 460 today.

title: The FourStage Cycle of the Wankel
description: THE hottest thing on wheels these days is also on wings. And on boats, snowmobiles, power tools and factory floors. It is the Wankel rotary enginean internalcombustion machine of unusual design that is more compact, lighter and mechanically far simpler than a reciprocating piston motor of equivalent horsepower. These are precisely the sort of advantages that make engineers stand up and take notice, and, judging from the increasing number of firms around the world that are taking out licenses to manufacture this German invention, it seems safe to predict that there's Wankel in your future.

title: A.B.A. Clubs Standing Much Taller
description: The American Basketball Association has grown considerably since Alex Hannum said that the A.B.A.'s redwhiteandblueball belonged on the nose of a seal. With the start of its fifth season on Oct. 13 (Denver at Utah), the A.B.A. has finally reached the sevenfoot level.

title: MICHIGAN INDIANS IN FISHING DISPUTE
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 2A. B. LeBlanc, a Chippewa Indian and a commercial fisherman, sat quietly in his boat one afternoon this week, his nets set in the waters of Lake Superior's Whitefish Bay.

title: Will the Real Majority Stand Up for Scoop Jackson?
description: ONE day in the early spring of 1969, a highranking aide to President Nixon and a trusted friend from Capitol Hill sat talking in a West Wing office in the White House. The aide lowered his voice and spoke, as politicians say, within the family. The President's proposed Safeguard ABM system, the subject of this strategy meeting, was in trouble in the Senate, he said. Beyond that, he foresaw no end of trouble on a wide range of defense and foreignpolicy issues, especially the Vietnam war. Soon, he said, it would be Nixon's War.

title: Et Al.
description: Not everything you always wanted to know about campaign financing; but, stilt, an exhaustive analysis of the figures involved in the 1968 election. A total of $100million was spent on the entire campaign and $60million on the Presidential, both sums enormous jumps over 1964. This was due in part to the highly contested nature of the campaign, in part to rising costs of TV time. A worthwhile document by Mr. Alexander, of the Citizens' Research Foundation, who did similar books on the two previous Presidential elections.

If I had the power to do so, I would wish homosexuality off the face of the earth. He went on to declare that if his sons became gay, I should know them condemned to a state of permanent niggerdom among men, their lives, whatever adjustment they might make to their condition, to be lived as part of the pain of earth.

title: For Malamud It's Story
description: Bernard Malamud is no procrastinator. The idea is to get the pencil moving quickly, he said. Once you've got some words looking back at you, you can take two or three  or throw them away and look for others. I go over and over a page. Either it bleeds and shows it's beginning to be human, or the form emits shadows of itself and I'm off. I have terrifying will that way.

title: All that was left was the private truth within himself
description: Conceivably, by a drastic flourish of Occam's famous razor, one could reduce the long, populous history of Western drama to no more than three pivotal figures: Aeschylus, Shakespeare and Ibsen. The first originated the art; the second brought it to a dazzling consummation, becoming the measure for all other subsequent measures; while the third initiated its present, centuryold, revolutionary phase by setting drama firmly on now irreversible course of perpetual selftransformation.

We all felt that the way the pledge had been done was embarrassing, that it was sort of a disgraceful thing with the fans and players all yelling for the kickoff.

title: The Freedom to Speak

We can never rest on the laurels won by our ancestors, nor can we delude ourselves into thinking that our liberties, once having neen obtained, are forever secure.

Four large tents will be filled with garden displays, cut flowers, house plants and educational exhibits. The show will be open daily from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. through Oct. 12. It is free to the public.

description: ALBANY, Oct. 2An electronic voting system, virtually unused since it was installed in the State Senate five years ago, will he removed prior to the coming legislative session, it was announced yesterday.

title: The Nation

Meanwhile, back in the carpeted offices and the tiled warrens at City Hall, Lindsay sides were aggressively striding in the same direction. They have worked out a preliminary game plan for The Making of a President and have even come up with a theme that attempts to transform a poisible liability, the Mayor's hometown problems, into an asset.

description: PONTIAC, Ill., Oct. 2A fourandahalfhour fight at the Illinois State Penitentiary branch here tonight left six guards and nine inmates injured, none seriously, prison officials said.

title: Music
description: LAST season the Central Presbyterian Church put on a paid professional series of concerts in Its sanctuary. It was believed to be the first of its kind. Churches and temples have been used for standard concert series, particularly in cities and towns where they provided the best auditoriums. The same institutions also give programs of sacred music, usually on Friday evenings or Sunday afternoons, the fee being whatever the visitor chooses to give. These are different matters.

title: All 63 on British Airliner Killed in Crash in Belgium
description: GHENT, Belgium, Oct. 2A British European Airways plane crashed near here today, killing all 63 persons aboard. Six of the dead were reported to be Americans.

title: As Simple As One, Two, Three
description: AVOCADO surely must be replacing philodendron as the most popular house plant. First of all, it's freeif you like avocados. Just save the pit after using the wellripened fruit in a salad or dip. Allow the pit to dry for a day or two and the onionlike skin will come off. Then the growing begins. The pit can be planted directly in soil, but the more fun way is to watch it start growing. 1. Poke three or four toothpicks in the sides of the pit and suspend it over a glass of water. Just the bottom should be kept wet. 2. Keep the glass in a bright, not necessarily sunny place, and in two to three weeks a thick root will push downward and as the pit splits, a sprout will push upward. 3. Cut the sprout short and then plant the pit in a large clay pot. Nothing smaller than 6 inches; a 7  or 8inch may be better. Use packaged house plant soil. 4. Once established in soil, the avocado will grow with abandon. Prune the top again to avoid a palmtree look, and encourage branching. 5. If the avocado is off to a good start, it may be necessary to transplant it to an even larger pot. This time a decorative tub would suit for the plant has earned its entry into the home's dcor as feature greenery. The avocado may thrive for many years in a bright window, but don't plan on harvesting any fruits.

title: AIRMAN FIREBOMBED AND SHOT IN FLORIDA
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP)In a third night of racial violence here, a 19yearold airman's car was firebombed and he was shot as he fled with his hair and clothes afire, witnesses said.

title: The Bible of criminology, without directions for salvation
description: In a society that looks instinctively to experts for its solutions, to be a criminologist is a precarious calling. Crime, according to J. Edgar Hoover's latest calculations, is growing 14 times faster than the population. The Republicans, having deplored the high crime rate on the way to the White House in 1968, have since presided over a 25 per cent increase in the annual volume of reported crimes. The Democrats' last gesture came in January of 1970, when the party chairman, Fred P. Harris, solemnly announced that his side would deal with the problem at an upcoming Democratic Action Conference on Crimea conference that was never held, apparently because the Democrats did not know what action to take against crime.

title: The World
description: UNITED NATIONSThe delegates from 46 countries, most of them in dark business suits, some In flowing robes and one in general's uniform, took an average of 40 minutes each last week to address the world from the rostrum of the General Assembly.

title: U.S.Bred Mill Reef Choice in French L.'Arc de Triomphe Today
description: PARIS, Oct. 2Paul Mellon's diminutive champion colt, Mill Reef, will go off the oddson favorite tomorrow in the 50th running of the $471,000 Prix de L'Arc de Triomphe, the world's richest thoroughbred race.

description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 2Six years ago, Alberto Vitiello played soccer, attended school and helped his family tun its bar and espresso lounge in Naples, Italy, while his father made plans to move the family to the United States. Little 13yearold Alberto knew nothing of American football.

title: Georgetown Isn't What It Used to Be
description: WASHINGTON  In front of a little gray brick house trimmed with lavender awnings stood Per Hellekjaer known as Mr. Per of Georgetown a tall, spectacled Norwegian who has been primping the hair of Washington's elegant women for 19 years.

title: Rangers Top Red Wings, 31, For Fourth Preseason Victory
description: DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP)The New York Rangers scored a goal in each period tonight to defeat the Detroit Red Wings, 31, in a National Hockey League exhibition game.

title: OrioleA's Opener Postponed by Rain
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 2Rain forced postponement of the opening game of the American League playoffs today and sent Vida Blue, Dave McNally and their Oakland and Baltimore teammates to their television sets for an afternoon of football and baseball viewing.

title: Art
description: IN the history of modern art in South America, the name that sounds with the greatest resonance  at least to European and North American earsis that of Joaquin TorresGarcia. No doubt one of the reasons for this distinction lies in the fact that TorresGarcia's peculiar career belongs quite as much to the familiar art historical terrain of Paris and New York as it does to the art history of South America. Indeed, the exact extent to which his art may be said to belongestheticallyto the culture of South America or to his native Uruguay is still unclear, at least to outsiders like myself, whereas his profound debt to the European avantgarde is only too obvious.

title: ENGINEERS URGE POWERUSE CURBS
description: Organized professional engineers asserted yesterday that New York City faced ecological disaster if electric demands continued their present increases with unchanged policies.

title: Navy Yard Revives on a Grand Scale
description: The shipbuilding industry that thrived in the Brooklyn Navy Yard for 164 years until the last vessel was launched in 1965 is stirring again with the construction of the first of a fleet of six tankers, including the largest ever built in the United States.

title: Singing Comedienne Creating Quite a Commotion in Debut
description: Bette Midler, a singing comedienne with a lusty voice that is backed by a lot of energy and brash selfconfidence, is creating quite a commotion in her nightclub debut at the Downstairs at the Upstairs, 37 West 56th Street.

description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Selfdetermination day in Saigon, once a pivotal date in President Nixon's withdrawal plan, comes now as just another long Sunday in the Vietnam agony. Around the White House, they smiled a little at the sick jokes of satirists of President Thieu's strenuous oneman campaign against naysaying ballotrippers. President Nixon choked a little when he tried to pass off the exercise as at least better than Hanoi's kind of election.

title: CITY TOLD TO PLAN FOR '72 REM RISE
description: New York officials have been told by Washington to continue planning the complex computerized program that would raise rents next Jan. 1 in many of the 1.2 million apartments subject to the city's rent control law.

title: A TOP EUROPEAN BERATES SYSTEM
description: PARIS, Oct. 20A 42yearold West German sociologist holding one of the highest positions in the European Common market has ruffled his colleagues by challenging the concept of the European establishment in Brussels and acerbically criticizing the body he works for.

description: LANDER, Wyo.  In Lander, warmhearted people and a magnificent, awesome land combine to move a visitor to superlatives and to leave him sad at the parting.

title: Middle East: The Next Step
description: NEW HAVENThe risks of any alternative require the foreign ministers assembling at the United Nations finally to insist that the parties carry out the Security Council resolution of Nov. 22, 1967, which calls on them to make an agreement of peace for the Middle East.

title: New York
description: The New York City Board of Education calls them cyesis girls (from the Greek, kyesis, meaning pregnancy). Cyesis  a relatively comfortable way of dealing with a very discomforting situation.

description: In the first official expression of the Administration's concern over events in China. Secretary of State William P. Rogers said yesterday that the United States hoped they would not affect President Nixon's plans to visit Peking.

title: Suffolk
description: Lindenhurst held off a belated Bay Shore rally yesterday to post its second straight triumph of the season, 2214. The highly regarded Maroon battled back for two lastperiod touchdowns and appeared to be on the way to another when Chris Sutton intercepted a pass in the end zone to stall the drive and to preserve the Lindenhurst victory.

description: It was a long wait, but Columbia football team finally beat Princeton yesterday.

title: DEMOCRATS VOTE TO REVISE RULES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 2A special Democratic state rules convention approved today major changes in the way state and national convention delegates are named.

title: For Young Readers
description: This rueful and funny little book comes very near to being a minor masterpiece, so sure is its understanding of the ingredients which make up life's more humble, quiet desperations. It is a child's book but the eight truths it catalogues are universal in their implications. They deal, for instance, with the sun that always shines on a new raincoat, the disloyalty of a best friend and the fragile nature of good intentions, and all are told in red type face with penandink drawings which are so relaxed and charming that only after two or three readings do you realize that every segment ends in frustration, tears, rage or all three: the rumplehaired owner of the new raincoat laments: I know I will have to face another AWFUL, TERRIBLE, MISERABLE, ROTTEN, MEAN, NASTY beautiful new day. But the tears and the rage are the only appropriate reactions. It could not be otherwise.

title: Robert Billigs Have Son
description: A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Billig of Valley Stream, L. I., on Sept. 9 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Far Rockaway, Queens. The child has been named Dianne Cindy. Mrs. Billig is the former Miss Judi Froma Dobin.

Muskie of Maine, in the Rock Spring Congregational Church. The Rev. George Booth performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi E. William Seaman of the Washington Hebrew Congregation.

title: Music
description: PULL Franciscan, Pull Zigeuner. So Ernest Newman heads one of the chapters in his unflattering study of Liszt the man. Newman was alluding to the polarities of Liszt's characterto the pull that religion, on the one hand, exerted on Liszt (and Newman believed that Liszt was just about the phoniest religioso in the history of the Church), and that the flesh exerted on the other.

South Vietnam's second largest city, Buddhist monks and youths, students and veterans threw stones and firebombs and blocked intersections near at least nine major polling stations. They made it virtually impossible for voters to get in.

description: Gerard Tonachel, who retired as senior vice president of Standard & Poor's Corporation, publishers of investment services, died Wednesday of a heart attack in Rouen, France. He was 70 years old and lived at 7 Lexington Avenue and in Paris.

description: An exponent or new methods of planning and using schools has been named head of the Board of Education's school planning and research division.

description: ATTICA, N. Y., Oct. 2State troopers, Genessee and Wyoming County deputy sheriffs, and local police maintained constant patrols of this village and the state prison a few miles away today in the wake of persistent rumors that there would be demonstrations protesting the treatment of prisoners.

title: The Last Word: Two Old Men
description: As chance or the Zeitgeist would have it, in the past year two great American writers, Saul Bellow and Edmund Wilson, have written books that center on the figure of an old man. both books this figure represents the civilized life and delivers a judgment on contemporary American culture with all the authority that long experience and moral and intellectual depth can provide.

title: Preps
description: WALLINGFORD, Conn., Oct. 2  Exeter and Choate rate among the best prep schools in the East in academics, but Exeter was clearly superior on the football field in today's 210 victory on Choate's field.

description: MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 2  Miss Patricia Sinnott, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward F. Sinnott of Brooklyn and Wardsboro, Vt., was married here this afternoon to Arthur M. Hayes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hayes of Manhasset. The Rev. John J. Wiest performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church. Dr. Sinnott is a dentist in Brooklyn. The bridegroom's father is general tax counsel of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in New York. The bridegroom is a tax specialist in the international department of Renst & Ernst.

title: REUBEN HASKELL, EXJUDGE, DEAD
description: WESTWOOD, N. J., Oct. 2Reuben L. Haskell, formerly a Representative from Brooklyn, a judge of the Kings County Court and a member of the onetime New York Transit Commission, died today in Valley Nursing Home. He would have been 93 years old Tuesday. His home was at 19 Brookside Place, Hillsdale.

description: To the Editor: Eli Siegel is worthy to teach you. He is worthy to teach your Sunday editor and your pubfisher... . It is my careful judgment that he is worthy to teach Socrates.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 2 Brandon Trotter's pinpoint passing highlighted a 57yard first quarter drive as Deerfield defeated Lawrenceville, 70, today. Deerfield is now 10 wonlost while the Larries have two losses.

title: The keeper and the kepta report from the kept
description: By a stroke of good fortune this book by four convicts in the Indiana State Prison arrived for review while I was attending the 101st Congress of the American Correctional Association in Miami Beach. To the uninitiated I should explain that this organization, composed of wardens, jailers and others in the business of locking people up, was formerly known as the American Prison Association. The name was changed in 1952 by the prison bureaucracy as part of a general move to package their product under a more agreeable name and incidentally to upgrade their jobs: guards have become correctional officers or correctional counsellors; solitary confinement is seclusion, adjustment or even meditation; the prison is a correctional therapeutic community.

title: Transportation
description: You can't depend on a mother to boil all the milk her child drinks. You pasteurize it. And you can't depend on people in cars to put on their seat belts. The Department of Transportation official had these facts in mind: About 30 per cent of the nation's motorists actually use their seat belts, which are mandatory on all cars sold in the United States, and the belts save about 5,000 lives a year  but if everyone used them, it is thought that 10,000 more lives would be saved.

title: That madness is a sane
description: In a moment of anger in his new book, R. D. Laing writes, Our own cities are our own animal factories; families, schools, churches, are the slaughterhouses of our children; colleges and other places are the kitchens. As adults in marriages and business we eat the product These charges may all be true, but they are tiresome, written in such a way that the reader turns them off. The strongest impression I have after reading The Politics of the Family and Other Essays is that Laing has substituted an easy rhetoric of accusation and condemnation for the struggle to understand people's feelings that dignified his earlier work.

title: Et Al.
description: Segments of the far right described from the left. Mr. Turner covers such exotica as the Birchers, the Minutemen, various Christian antiCommunist groups. Some of this is not new, some is and brings the situation up to date. Not surprisingly the author speculates on the involvement of the Minutemen and/or Klan in the Kennedy assassination, which seems like poking old bones. All told, good reporting but lacking in historical perspective.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: The World
description: MEXICO CITY  I've never been in a country where I have had less idea of what is going on, a European diplomat here said in despair last week. For every event there are ten different explanations, and probeably none of them is true.

title: Margaret Mary Hennelly Married Here to George F. Sweeny
description: Miss Margaret Mary Hennelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Hennelly of Jersey City, was married here yesterday afternoon to George F. Sweeny of New York, son of New York Supreme Court Justice John W. Sweeny and Mrs. Sweeny of Goshen, N.Y.

title: NoFault Idea Advances; Extent of Gain Is Disputed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2Legislation for automobile insurance reform has been enacted by five states this year, but the extent of meaningful improvement is in dispute.

title: After the Fall
description: THE counterculture is dying. Left behind are a thousand hopeful articles about the New Consciousness, a thousand photographs of halfnaked, acidrich bodies jumbled together in some urban pad in mockery of the straights. Countless people still live their own versions of the old HaightAshbury dream, but there it ends. Eaten away from within by its Establishment heritage, the movement has lost its energy, is left with nowhere to go.

title: Heroin Suspect Cleared After Accuser Recants
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., Oct. 2 (UPI)John Atkins spent three weeks in jail, lost his job and faced possible imprisonment after being accused of selling heroin.

title: North Carolina Triumphs
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 2 (UPI)  North Carolina downed North Carolina State, 277, today behind the running of Ike Oglesby who provided most of the offensive thrust and scored on 1yard runs in the first and second quarters.

title: Religion
description: One of the very last of the giant figures in the postWorld War II confrontations between church and state in Eastern Europe moved from the stage into the wings of history last week, when Hungary's Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty left the sanctuary of the American Embassy in Budapest and traveled out of Hungary, never to return.

title: Penelope Johnson, Food Editor, Is Married to David E. Wartels
description: PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Oct. 2Miss Penelope Wyatt Johnson and David Emanuel Wartels were married here this afternoon in Christ Episcopal Church by the Rev. David Stewart Hoag.

title: Jack Newfield, visvis a wounded dinosaur
description: There is no middle way to approach Jack Newfield. A reader either blusters, grits his teeth and curses or he nods, murmurs right on and again curses, but not at Jack Newfield. As the paladin of advocacy journalism, Newfield has brought a form of method acting to nonfiction; for advocates of the old forms, he too often uses the first person singular. But his style is less pretentious than that of Norman Mailer, for whom Newfield professes admiration. In this collection of pieces from The Village Voice, New York, The Nation and other publications, Newfield, unfrivolously and unpompously, focuses on a simple theme: a desperate love for what he calls this wounded dinosaur of a country. He chronicles America's 1960's and his own twenties with cleareyed sharpness and without apology. His perceptions of under30 America ought to be shared by parents, college deans, managing editors and certainly all Presidential candidates.

title: The Other Fire Island
description: WATCH HILL, Fire Island They tell here of a deer with 16point antlers and weighing 240 pounds that roams the entire length of Fire Island during the winter. Rangers have seen him, and so has Tom Columbus, one of the two solitary humans living in the eastern sector all year round.

title: ECOLOGY IS BASIS FOR ZONING RULING
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 30  A State Supreme Court Justice, deciding on ecological grounds alone, has denied a builders' petition to overturn zoning ordinance of the town of Wappinger.

title: Could Be Jets Are Homesick
description: MIAMI, Oct. 2They're known as the New York Jets, but Orphans might be a better nickname, or Gypsies.

title: Mailbox
description: To the Editor:

title: We Could Hear the Ting of Bullets Striking
description: ONE minute I was a tourist comfortably seated in a hydrofoil skimming over a scenic body of water. The next minute, without warning, I was a target, with rifles and machine guns blazing away at me from the nearby shore, bullets tinging off the side of the craft, people screaming, weapons being broken out aboard and all pandemonium loose. The time was about six weeks ago, the scenic body of water was Lake Titicaca, and I was caught in the middle of a Bolivian revolution.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Baltimore Colts, befitting the Super Bowl champions, pay the highest salaries in the National Football League. The Cincinnati Bengals, the newest expansion team, average the lowest salaries. The Colts' figure is $31,300 per man; the Bengals' $18,600.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: LETTERS
description: I refer to Shepard Kurnit's article entitled Yesterday's Answer to Compensation (Sept. 19).

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: On Sept. 10, the chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, Ralph DeNunzio, announced his strong dissatisfaction with the exchange's standards of performance of specialists. Mr. DeNunzio promised that the nation's largest securities market would establish new criteria in October of this year for the regulation of the specialist.

title: The World
description: LONDON  If the Irish problem is ever to be solved, logic suggests that the political leaders of Britain, her Ulster province and the Irish Republic should play a critical role. And so it was a symhol of hope when the three Prime Ministers met last week for the first time in decades, talked in a constructive atmosphere for two days and agreed on the need for political reconciliation in Northern Ireland.

title: WISCONSIN LOSES TO NORTHWESTERN
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 2 (AP) Randy Anderson plunged for three touchdowns and a rugged Northwestern defense kept Wisconsin's offense in check today for a 2411 Big Ten football victory.

title: TV Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2After the British accused the Russians the other day of supporting 105 spies in their embassy in London, a telephone call was made to one of the Russian spies in the embassy here in Washington. His name is Boris. He said, yes, he could get out for a rendezvous, provided it produced a secret document which he could send to Moscow to justify his expense account.

title: Navy Saves Alaskan Salmon
description: NAKNEK, Alaska, Oct. 2, (Reuters)The Navy has come to the rescue of salmon returning to the Kvichak River system for spawning. When the salmon were pursued into the river mouth by white whales the Navy repulsed the assault by playing recordings of killer whale sounds and scared the white whales back out to sea.

title: United Fund Sets High Goal
description: The United Fund of Long Island is seeking to raise $4million in the 1971 fall campaign, which opened Friday.

title: Temple Defeats Boston U. As Loughran Stars, 3410
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 (UPt) Paul Loughran scored three touchdowns, oneon a 96yard kickoff return, to lead Temple to a 3410 victory over Boston University in at thick fog tonight.

title: Preps
