description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, Oct. 3 (AP)Ken Nagle of Australia won the Volvo open proAm golf tournament today with fourround 286.

title: A Druse Leader in Israel Named a Deputy Minister
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 (AP)The Israeli Government has appointed a Druse leader, Sheik Jaber Muadi, as Deputy Minister of Communications, making him one of two Arabs to have achieved deputy ministerial status in Israel. The other Arab is Abdel Aziz Zuabi, a Nazareth Moslem appointed Deputy Health Minister in May.

title: U.S. Fertility Rate Drops To Lowest Level Since 30's
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The American fertility rate, adjusted for seasonal variations, declined in July to the lowest monthly rate since the late nineteenthirties.

title: Louise Frumkin a Bride
description: CEDARHURST, LT., Oct. 3 The marriage of Miss Louise F. Frumkin and Kenneth D. Klipper took place today in the Sephardic Temple. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Arnold B. Marans. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Barnett Frumkin of Old Bethpage and Mr. and Mrs. Robert Klipper of Plainview. The bride a teacher at the St. James Elementary School in Smithtown is an alumna of Cortlandt State University. Her husband is a graduate of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

title: 15Month Outlook Cheers Argus Research Executive
description: The Argus Research Corporation provides economic and research services for the securities industry. Herman I. Roseman, 43, is a vice, president of Argus and a member of its investment policy committee. The other day, he talked with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times.

title: Unrest in the Philippines Is More Talk Than Deed
description: MANILA, Sept. 29In the Philippines, a nation of extreme contrasts, no contrast is greater than that of the violence of public talk and gesture and the general peacefulness of the country.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Screen
description: Nelson Lyon, who wrote and directed The Telephone Book, which was opened yesterday at the Lincoln Art Theater with what might even be called a leer, fitfully succeeds in kidding the pornographicfilm genre. But in eliciting a few authentic giggles while ribbing sex fantasies, perverts, analysts and the like, he and his enthusiastic troupe also present a good deal more of visceral views, actions and language than is absolutely necessary to make a satirical point. Who, one is left wondering, is kidding whom?

title: Hirohito Visits the Louvre
description: PARIS, Oct. 3 (AP)  Emperor Hirohito of Japan and his wife, Empress Nagako, visited the Louvre today. A small crowd cheering them as they left their hotel on the Place de la Concorde for the short drive to the museum.

title: AIRLINER WRECKAGE YIELDS BLACK BOX
description: LONDON, Oct. 3 (AP)The black box flight recorder of the British European Airways plane that crashed in Belgium yesterday was found in good condition, aviation officials reported today.

title: Police Commanders Get New Power to Discipline Men
description: Individual police commanding officers, rather than department headquarters, will be solely responsible for disciplining men in their commands who commit violations of the department's rules and regulations.

title: Luna 19 Is in Moon Orbit, Its Mission Still a Secret
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3  The Soviet Union's latest moon exploration craft, Luna 19, went into lunar orbit early todaywith its ultimate objective still a secret.

title: ALEXANDER S. HENRY
description: BERGENFIELD, N.J., Oct. 3Alexander Sutherland Henry, former president of Little Jones Company, New York importers, and of the National Gift and Art Association, died Friday in Englewood Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 27 Dover Court.

title: Special Edition, Lakeland Terrier, Named Best in Shovel
description: BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 3The Lakeland terrier is known for his tenaciousness, and a doughty, little representative of the breed, Ch. Special Edition, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., demonstrated that characteristic today when he was named best of 1,817 dogs at the 49th annual show of the Westbury Kennel Association.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (AP)The elderly mother of a Russian dissident, Vladimir Bukovsky, appealed today to all people of goodwill to help save her son from being turned into a complete cripple by Soviet prison psychiatrists. The 28yearold Mr. Bukovsky was arrested last March.

title: Burton Elicits Tips From Tito for Film
description: DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia Once again German Stukas are wheeling and diving over the Sutjeska River gorge in southwestern Yugoslavia, their guns seeking groups of armed men scattering Into the steep forests.

title: TOWNS PUSH FIGHT ON MOBILE HOMES
description: They used to be called trailers, politely, and now they are mobile homes, and often mentioned as a means of easing the nation's housing crisis. But whatever they are called most communities just don't want them.

title: Giants Turn Back Cards;
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3Firsthalf razzledazzle and secondhalf cliffhanging brought the New York Giants a gratifying 2120 upset victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today, while a crowd of 49.571 booed the home team lustily.

title: ELIZABETH HELD TO SCORELESS TIE
description: UNION, N. J., Oct. 3Cruz Azul of Mexico held Elizabeth of New Jersey, the United States soccer champion in 1970, to a scoreless tie at Farchers Grove today before 2,500 fans in the first round of Middle and Central American championship competition.

title: Dublin: The Flourishing Trend of OneMan Shows
description: Arts Abroad

title: CHINA MITES FOR JAPANESE TIE
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 3The Chinese Communists spelled out in considerable detail the kind of relationship they want with Japan in a joint communiqu signed yesterday in Peking with a visiting group of Japanese legislators.

title: K.G.B.'s Efforts to Neutralize A Spy's Defection Are Outlined
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 Within hours of the defection of a Soviet spysuch as Oleg Lyalin, who defected to Britain last monththe Soviet K.G.B., or State Security Committee, begins immediate, sweeping protective measures within and outside the Soviet Union, experts here say.

title: Three Sought in Shooting of Detective in Harlem
description: An offduty city detective was shot and critically wounded by two gunmen early yesterday morning after he was apparently lured to a Harlem parking lot by a young woman, the police said.

title: U.S. and Albany ShortChange City, Panel Reports
description: Mayor Lindsay's Commission on StateCity Relations made public yesterday the first of what its chairman said would he several reports demonstrating how the city suffers shortchanging in relations with both the state and Federal Governments.

title: James Mahony Dies at 70; Stock Exchange Examiner
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., Oct. 3James P. Mahony, former chief examiner of the New York Stock Exchange, died here yesterday in Mercy Hospital at the age of 70. Mr. Mahony, who lived at 87 Adams Street, Garden City, had been ill with a heart ailment since his retirement in 1965.

title: GREENBERG VICTOR IN ETCHELLS CLASS
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Oct. 3  Woody Greenberg's Green Power won the Etchells22 Class as 64 boats sailed with the Kickerbocker Yacht Club today in the Cow Bay Area Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Soundt competition.

title: U.S. TENNIS TEAM KEEPS DUBLER CUP
description: RANCHO LA COSTA, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP)Bobby Riggs and Tom Brown beat Swedish opponents in straight sets today as the United States retained the tennis Dubler Cup for seniors.

title: CEVERT CAPTURES U. S. GRAND PRIX IN TYRRELLFORD
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y., Oct. 3  Francois Cevert, a 27yearold French driver with a moviestar smile, today won the 13th annual United States Grand Prix, the first Grand Prix victory of his career.

title: Monroe Riders Turn Back Fairfield for Title, 74
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 3Adie Von Gontard Jr. scored three goals today to lead the Monroe, Conn., Pitchforks to a 74 victory over the Fairfield County Hunt Club in the final round of the Northeast circuit Governor's Cup fivegoal polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: OFFFARM DRIFT WORRIES MOSCOW
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 3A growing flight from the Russian countryside, especially by young people drawn to cities by higher wages, is giving increasing concern to the Soviet authorities.

title: Kidney Surgery Nearly Halted Robertson's Climb to Majors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Bob Robertson, the muscular 205pounder who was the Pirates' batting star today, has been hitting homers in clusters since becoming a professional in 1964.

title: BUCK COMPOSERS SHOW HIDE RANGE.
description: If the concert at Tully Hall on Saturday night had not been presented by the Society of Black Composers, there would have been no way of knowing that the composers of the six works performed had anything more than music in common. Which is to say the obviousthere is no difference between compositions by black men and white men with similar skills and talents.

title: Flyers Beat Canadiens
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) A pair of goals early in the final period lifted the Philadelphia Flyers to a 21 victory over the Montreal Canadiens in the final National Hockey League exhibition game for both teams tonight.

title: Unanswered Questions About Rebellion
description: Three weeks after the end of the revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility, major questions about official planning and decisionmaking and about the psychology and aims of the rebels have only been partially answered.

title: MRS. CHISHOLM SAYS SUPPORT IS GROWING
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 3Representative Shirley Chisholm, Democrat of Brooklyn, reported today that 21 organizations in 21 states and 40 national fundraising groups had been set up to support her bid for the Presidency.

title: Why Brandt Looks East
description: Willy Brandt accepted Leonid Brezhnev's invitation to confer in the Crimea last month without consulting West Germany's American, British and French allies. The fact that the Chancellor saw no need to consult before going to meet the Soviet Communist leader is symbolic of two developments:

title: Follmer Scores in Javelin
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 3 (UPI)George Folimer, a winner of two TransAm races in a Mustang this year, made his switch to a Javelin a success today when he captured the Mission Bell 200 at the Riverside International Raceway. He finished 42 seconds, ahead of his Javelin teammate, Vic Elford of England.

title: Judge Orders Free Access To Migrant Labor Camps
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 2  In a landmark case this weekend, a Federal judge ordered a grower of fruits and vegetables to pay $4,500 in damages for interfering with visits to a family in one of his migrant labor camps.

title: Screen: Life in a Shabby Texas Town on the Plains
description: Peter Bogdanovich's fine second film, The Last Picture Show, adapted from Larry McMurtry's novel by McMurtry and Bogdanovich, has the effect of a lovely, leisurely, horizontal panshot across the life of Anarene, Tex., a small, shabby town on a plain so flat that to raise the eye even 10 degrees would be to see only an endless sky.

title: Scientists in a Minisub Seek Effect of Dumping Off the City
description: SANDY HOOK, N. J., Oct. 3Scientists in a little yellow submarine equipped with headlights have found that constant dumping on the ocean floor just outside New York harbor leaves a thick layer of ooze with the consistency and color of licorice pudding.

title: For Rogers, No Golf, but an Endless Round of Talks
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers, a man who thrives on frantic activity and excels at quiet persuasion, has been devoting himself to both pursuits virtually around the clock since he set up field headquarters in New York last Thursday to direct major American diplomatic campaigns.

title: H.R.A. SEES RELIEF DOWN BY ONLY 4% UNDER WORK LAW
description: The state's new workrelief law has had only a marginal effect in reducing the city's welfare rolls while arousing unjustified suspicions of widespread abuse that have hurt welfare reform efforts, the city's Human Resources Administrator said yesterday.

title: From Korea, an Array of Fabric Designs
description: Last year, Doris and Leslie Tillett, the husband and wife team of textile design geniuses, put a small, new fabrics producer in Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant on the map as a manufacturer of prestigious prints.

title: Miss Fisher Bride Of Lloyd Cooper
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 3Miss Stephanie Hope Fisher and Lloyd Cooper were married here this afternoon at Temple Beth Sholom by Rabbi Leon Kornish.

title: Patricia Perullo Wed
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 3Miss Patricia Mary Perullo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Perullo of Forest Hills, Queens, was married here today to Brett Joel Meyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace E. Meyer.

title: Paul Salsburg, ExSpeaker Of Jersey Assembly, Dies
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 3 (AP) Paul M. Salsburg of Ventnor, retired judge of the Atlantic County Court and former Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, died yesterday. His age was 75.

title: McCarthy Is Acting Like a Candidate
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 Eugene J. McCarthy, private citizen and professor of poetry, came to California last week, making speeches, talking politics, and looking more and more like a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Officials in Michigan to Seek a Court Ruling on School Support
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 3Top Michigan officials have pladged to seek a State Supreme Court ruling that Michigan's system of financing public schools is unconstitutional.

title: MRS. KING POSTS EARNINGS RECORD
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 3 (AP) Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif., won the Virginia SlimsThunderbird tennis tournament today and became the first woman athlete in history, to earn $100,000 in a single year.

title: Detroit Police Alter Tests for Recruits; Seek More Blacks
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3Detroit's police department has announced that it is using new tests to recruit policemen, putting less emphasis on intelligence and more on ability to operate under stress.

title: Gamble in the Aleutians
description: In recent weeks reports have come out of Washington that President Nixon plans to cancel the projected underground atomic test at Amchitka and other reports that he will shortly give it his required approval. The official word from the White House is that the President has yet to make up his mind on the test known as Cannikin. The conflicting storiesprobably betraying no more than wishful thinkingare a measure of the division, even within the Administration, on this ominous project.

title: United Nations Notes
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, has finally accepted what others here have long felt to be truethat Secretary General Thant's decision not to serve another term is, as he says, irrevocable. As a consequence, Mr. Gromyko in a first exploratory meeting on the matter with Secretary of State William P. Rogers in Washington last week agreed that the two powers should proceed to discuss a replacement.

title: Enemy Shelling of Hamlet Makes the Voters Wary
description: ANDUOC, South Vietnam, Oct. 3The Vietcong fired a mortar shell into this hamlet 22 miles northwest of Saigon a half hour before the polls opened this morning, and only an intrepid handful of villagers came early to cast their ballots for President Nguyen Van Thieu or to deposit them as a negative vote, into the wastebaskets provided In each curtained booth.

title: U.S. Gold Mining Industry Loses Its Glitter
description: Last week as the world's finance ministers debated the future of gold as a backing for currency, the beleaguered United States gold mining industry sat forlornly in the wings, hoping in vain for some action that would result in a sharp increase in the price of gold.

title: Personal Finance
description: Now is the time for all good taxpayers to take a shrewd look at their tax status for 1971. While taxfiling dayApril 15is still months away, there are some new approaches to ponder and some actions that can he taken before the yearend. Earlier this year the Internal Revenue Service warned that because of the way the withholding tables are set up, many taxpayers will find they owe more money than they expected next April. Because extra tax requirements of $1,000 or $1,500 or more in the middleincome groups can come as a rude shock, it's a good idea to make rough estimates now of the amount of income expected, the tax withheld and the possible obligation.

title: Knights' Armorers Live On at Museum Here
description: The armourers, accomplishing the knights.

title: B. MARCUS PRITECA
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 3 (AP)B. Marcus Priteca, an architect who designed more than 200 theaters, including the Pantages in Hollywood, died here Friday at the age of 82.

title: Mill Reef Wins $448,256 Arc de Triomphe by Three Lengths in Record Time
description: PARIS, Oct. 3Paul Mellon's 3yearold bay colt, Mill Reef, blazed home free today to win the 50th Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe by three lengths from Mrs. Alec Head's filly. Pistol Packer, in record time at Longchamp.

title: Easing the Education Crisis
description: Congress, in moving toward a new policy of aid to education, is filling a leadership vacuum created by the Administration's apparent lack of either sense of urgency or direction. A growing group of educational experts in Congress has evolved legislation dealing with a wide range of needsfrom infant care to the university.

title: Film Festival: Polish Family Life
description: Krzysztof Zanussi's Family Life, a new Polish film that played Saturday night in the New York Film Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, begins with one of the longest, and perhaps the loveliest, gentlest, coolest and most subtly sustained precredit sequence I have ever seen in a movie.

title: CANADA IS WARY OF NEW VIOLENCE
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 3Recent events have heightened fears in police and diplomatic circles of new violence on the anniversary of last October's doublekidnapping by the Front for the Liberation of Quebec.

title: Lawyer Gets Ecology Post
description: The appointment of Dennis B. Farrar as executive director of the New York State Council of Environmental Advisers was announced yesterday by John L. Loeb Jr., its chairman. Mr. Farrar was formerly with the law firm of Debevoise, Plimpton, Lyons & Gates. He has been active in environmental groups for several years. He has also been a member of Mayor Lindsay's transportation task force.

title: Protest in New Bedford
description: NEW BEDFORD, Mass, Oct. (AP)About 100 of the 111 inmates of the Bristol County House of Correction staged demonstration today to further their demands for improved conditions. Sheriff Edward K. Dabrowski met with a committee of eight of the prisoners and said he would take the demands under advisement.

title: OPTIMISTS PACE PURCHASE GROUP
description: For the first time in two and onehalf years, optimists outnumbered pessimists when purchasing agents were asked recently how they felt about the next 12 months.

title: MRS. JOHN A. FINNERAN
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 3 Mrs. Dorothy Buckley Finneran, widow of John A. Finneran, who headed his own advertising agency after having been classified advertising manager of The New York Times and then of The JournalAmerican, died today at her home, 1880 Palmer Avenue. She was 60 years old.

title: Master Builder Due Oct. 17
description: Ibsen's The Master Builder, costarring Jill O'Hara and Paul Sparer, will be presented by the Roundabout Theater on Oct. 17. Michael Meyer, whose biography of Ibsen was recently published by Doubleday, has translated the play.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Newhouse Beats Amuke In 200Meter Run in Kenya
description: MOMBASA, Kenya, Oct 3 (AP)Fred Newhouse of the United States slipped at the start but won the 200 meters in a near dead heat with Kenya's Dan Amuka today at an international track meet. Each was timed in 21.8 seconds.

title: Pirates Win, 9 to 4, Tie Playoff;
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3Bob Robertson hit three home runs and a double today as the Pittsburgh Pirates tied the playoff for the National League pennant with a resounding 94 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Richardson Foresees Medical Cost Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) Elliot L. Richardson, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said today that the second phase of President Nixon's economic program would include controls on medical and hospital costs.

title: M.T.A. Agrees to Station At 96th St. on 2d Ave. Line
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that a station would be built at 96th Street for the new Second Avenue subway system.

title: DIP IN BOND RATES MAY LINGER A BIT
description: The credit markets have been heading toward lower interest rates for more than a week, and investment bankers see no reason why the trend should not continue.

title: House Backs Nixon Delay Of Federal Pay Increases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Administration weathered the first direct Congressional challenge to its new economic, policy today as the House endorsed President Nixon's decision to postpone a Federal pay increase scheduled for next January.

title: COMMON MARKET HITS U.S. TAX AID
description: PARIS, Oct. 4The six European Common Market countries and Britain, a prospective member, have formally protested protectionist tax credit proposals of the Nixon Administration and warned that they might lead to retaliatory measures if passed by Congress.

title: Dictatorship in Saigon
description: The lopsided election results announced by the Saigon Government can give no comfort to Americans or for that matter to democratically inclined South Vietnamese. President Thieu's proclaimed 91.5 per cent mandate in oneman vote is the kind of result that could be expected from the regime in Hanoi, to which Saigon was supposed to offer a democratic alternative.

title: A. W. O. L. Soldier Returns to Ft. Dix After Exoneration on Rioting Charges
description: An Army private who was convicted of riot and arson charges stemming from the 1969 Fort Dix stockade uprising, then later escaped custody and was A.W.O.L. for almost, two years, turned himself in WI Fort Dix yesterday, 12 days after an Army court had overturned his convictions.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A VACCINE REPORTED FOR THREE DISEASES
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)A combination vaccine has been developed to combat measles, mumps and rubella with a single vaccination, according to an article in the current issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: ISRAEL AND EGYPT URGED BY ROGERS TO AGREE ON SUEZ
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4Secretary of State William P. Rogers appealed to Israel and Egypt today to enter into an interim agreement on the opening of the Suez Canal as the next practical and immediately attainable step toward peace in the Middle East.

title: Consumer Debt Soars;
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)  Consumer installment credit rose by a seasonally adjusted $827million in August following a $761million July increase, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CEMETERY STRIKE SPURS GUARD PLEA
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 4 (UPI)Mourning relatives protesting a cemetary strike that has left 1,400 bodies unburied in the San Francisco area asked Gov. Ronald Reagan today to call out the National Guard to bury their dead.

title: Powell Hits 2 in Second Playoff Victory in Row
description: BALTIMORE, Oct 4 Boog Powell, a 260pound slugger whose right hand hurt so badly that he had resorted to bunting, smashed two home runs today as the playoffperfect Baltimore Orioles whipped the Oakland Athletics. 51, and all but wrapped up their third consecutive American League pennant.

title: Dance: Edward Villella's Ensemble Opens Series
description: The annual Brooklyn College Dance Series got under way on Sunday night with the first local engagement of the Edward Villella Dance Ensemble. Other companies included later in the series are the Merce Cunningham Company and the Dance Theater of Harlem.

title: Supreme Court Vacancy
description: The entirely honorable decision of Representative Richard H. Poff of Virginia to withdraw his name from consideration for one of the two vacant seats on the United States Supreme Court reflects great credit on him for his sensitivity to the public interest. It reflects something less than credit on the White House for having proposed a candidate whose nomination would be certain to reawaken all the bitter divisiveness of the inflammatory civil rights issue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Sea Mammal Bill Asked
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) A bill to give the Interior Department authority to manage the taking of all sea mammals was introduced today by Senator Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon. Any taking of seals, sea otters, whales, polar bears, walruses and other mammals in waters subject to United States jurisdiction would be prohibited without a permit.

title: EXRELOCATION HEAD REJECTS A CITY JOB
description: Former City Relocation Commissioner Earl A. Rawlins, who was indicted but later cleared on a charge of conspiring to violate immigration laws, announced yesterday that he has refused an offer to return to the Housing and Development Administration.

title: SAIGON RELIEF FORCE AT CAMBODIAN BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 (AP)A tankled South Vietnamese rescue column fought its way through North Vietnamese lines this evening to relieve a besieged artillery base inside Cambodia, South Vietnamese spokesmen said.

title: U. S. Aides Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)United States officials today reiterated their misgivings about South Vietnam's oneman presidential election, but expressed satisfaction at the high voter turnout.

title: French Student Dies of Wound Suffered During Holdup in City
description: Jean Crez, a 24yearold exchange student from France who was shot and paralyzed after surrendering $58 to two holdup men last summer in the elevator of a West Side apartment house, died early yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: S.E.C. SETS HEARING IN STOCKSALE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered administrative proceedings today in a case involving alleged illegal transactions in the stock of the Transceiver Corporation of America by a New York brokerage house and a Dallas hank.

title: Ellis Pays $50 Hotel Bill, Calls Pirates Cheapskates
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 (AP) Controversial Dock Ellis described Pittsburgh. Pirates' management as cheapskates today and said they didn't deserve a winner.

title: INJURED JET DUE TO FACE PATRIOTS
description: Ralph Baker, the New York Jets' left linebacker, has a fractured navicular bone at the base of his right wrist  the same injury that finished Joe Namath's season last year by hand Xrays disclosed yesterday. But Baker will play against the New England Patroits next Sunday at Foxboro, Mass.

title: M.T.A. Will Unveil 4 New Subway Cars Today
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will display its newest subway cars today at the IND station at 57th Street and the Avenue of the Americasnine months after they originally were scheduled for delivery.

title: LEONARD SEELIG
description: Leonard Seelig, vice president of Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Employment Union, died Sunday in an automobile accident on the Taconic Parkway, near Chatham, N. Y. He was 41 years old and lived at 20 West 10th Street.

title: Westchester Banker Indicted On Embezzlement Charge
description: Raymond Peter Johnson, Westchester County bank manager, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges that he had embezzled almost $100,000.

title: Nixon Urges Young People To Help Battle Narcotics
description: MONROE, La., Oct. 4 (Reuters)  President Nixon urged young people today to help the Government in its battle against narcotics, which he termed the nation's No. 1 enemy.

title: CBWLHayden, Stone Becomes Publicly Held
description: CBWLHayden, Stone, Inc., a leading investment concern, went public yesterday with onemillionshare offering at $12.50 a share. The offering price was somewhat below the maximum price of $17 that had been filed originally with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Postal Service May Seek New Rise in Stamp Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The Postal Service said today that it would probably seek another rise in the price of stamps next spring, meaning that it would cost at least cents to mail a first class letter.

title: Made in FrancePersia's Splendorous Anniversary Celebration
description: Think, in this batter'd Caravanseral Whose Portals are alternate Night and Day.

title: Haile Selassie Off to China
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Oct. 4 (Agence FrancePresse) Emperor Haile Selassie left here by air today for a sixday visit to China. Traveling with the Emperor is his recently appointed envoy to Peking, Makonnen Kibret.

title: Oil Find Is Reported
description: Mobil Oil Canada, Ltd., and the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation announced yesterday that testing at their Tetco Sable Island E48 discovery well had disclosed number of zones bearing natural gas condensate and crude oil. The well is about 175 miles east of Halifax, Nova Scotia, on Sable Island.

title: House Votes Protection For Mustangs in West
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI)The House voted unanimously today to make it a crime to kill or harass the 17,000 wild mustangs and burros that still roam the West.

title: School Bus Strike Ended; Service to Resume Today
description: School bus service was scheduled to be resumed this morning after a surprise strike by 1,800 drivers and mechanics yesterday stranded 103,000 public and parochial school pupils.

title: JESUIT BIDS CHURCH DROP PATERNALISM
description: ROME, Oct. 4The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, superior general of the Society of Jesus, urged leaders of the Roman Catholic Church today to abandon authoritarian or paternalistic attitudes as a way of restoring the lost confidence of many priests in church leadership.

title: Stopping the Subway
description: Concern for community sentiment has rarely been a determinant in decisions of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. That makes all the more welcome its decision to incorporate into its plans for the new Second Avenue subway a muchneeded station at 96th Street.

title: Msgr. James Lynch Dies at 68; Led Catholic Charities Here
description: Msgr. James J. Lynch, former executive director of New York Catholic Charities and pastor emeritus director of Holy Trinity Church in Manhattan, died Friday in St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 68.

title: South Korea Seeks Shift in U.S. Curbs On Textile imports
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 4 The South Korean Government instructed its Ambassador in Washington, Kim Dong Jo, today to negotiate again with the American Government for the modification of the United States'; position on textile import restrictions.

title: McCloskey Urges Outlays of $30Billion in Fight Against Pollution of Rivers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4A leading Congressional conservationist urged today a radical overhaul in the nation's water pollution abatement efforts to make all rivers of recreational quality by 1980.

title: Books of The Times
description: HONOR THY FATHER. By Gay Talese. 526 pages. Illustrated. World. $10.

title: Britain's Reserves Rose in September
description: LONDON, Oct. 4Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currencies climbed an additional $206million in September, despite official attempts to discourage the continued inflow of dollars.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Parkinson to Quit as Chairman Of Anaconda Company Oct. 28
description: The Anaconda Company announced yesterday that C. Jay Parkinson had resigned as chairman and a director, effective Oct. 28, to devote a portion of his time to public activities of a civic and personal nature.

title: Dunne on Committee
description: ALBANY, Oct. 4Earl W. Brydges, Senate majority leader, said today that he would name Senators John R. Dunne of Garden City, L. I., and Thomas F. McGowan of Buffalo as his appointees to a 15member temporary commission to study the state penal system.

title: U.S. Aide Asserts Japan Has Payments Obligation
description: A highranking State Department official asserted here yesterday that Japan had an obligation, as any other country with a consistent surplus in its international balance of payments, to help the United States improve its payments situation.

title: Mr. Rogers on China
description: The pernicious theory that President Nixon's interest in visiting Peking involves abandonment of Taiwanand that the United States is merely going through the motions of defending Taipei's seat in the United Nations General Assemblyhas now been demolished by Secretary of State Rogers.

title: Envoy to U.S. Sees Tito
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 4 (UPI)Toma Granfil, Yugoslavia's new Ambassador to the United States, called on President Tito today before leaving for Washington. Mr. Granfil, 58yearold economic expert, had been in charge of economic relations with Western countries.

title: Pan Am Is Expected To Fill Executive Posts
description: William M. Crilly, who about two years ago decided to leave Eastern Air Lines, where he was senior vice president  planning, has decided he wants to go back into the business.

title: Excerpts From U.N. Assembly Address by Secretary Rogers
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 4Following are excerpts from the address by Secretary of State William P. Rogers before the General Assembly today:

title: Pennsylvania Student Sits On Board of Lincoln Bank
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 (AP) A 21yearold University of Pennsylvania student has been named to the board of directors of the Lincoln National Bank.

title: Negro Candidates in Mississippi Combat White Is Right Feeling
description: FAYETTE, Miss., Sept. 28 Robert Vanderson, a 38yearold mathematics teacher who is a candidate for county sheriff, trudged the back roads of Jefferson County, which is poor and threefourths black, seeking the cotton farmers and field hands he has known all his lifeand he worried.

title: WagePrice Tie to Productivity Decried
description: Any Phase Two plan to link wage and price increases to productivity increases on an industrybyindustry basis would be doomed to failure, according to Victor R. Fuchs, vice president for research of the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: Mexican President Arrives
description: President Luis Echeverra Alvarez of Mexico arrived in New York by plane last night to address the United Nations General Assembly this morning.

title: Blount Urges Boycott of Goods From France in Heroin Fight
description: DALLAS, Oct., 4 (Reuters)Postmaster General Winton M. Blount, warning that drug abuse has reached a critical stage, today called on the American people to boycott all French goods in an effort to force France to take more effective action against the flow of heroin into the United States.

title: Borough Presidents Urge More Local Powers
description: Joining other borough presidents yesterday in a call for true neighborhood government, Manhattan's Percy E., Sutton proposed a referendum in 1972 to amend the City Charter to transfer some powers, to local communities.

title: ALVIN JACKMAN
description: Alvin Jackman, a supervisor in the plant protection department of The New York Times, died on Friday at his home, 2318 102d Street, Elmhurst, Queens, of a heart condition. He was 52 years old.

title: SOLDIER IS KILLED IN BELFAST BLAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 4A British soldier was killed and 10 others were wounded today in a bomb attack on an army observation post by the Irish Republican Army.

title: OBSERVER
description: The families must keep up with the Jonesesand there's the boredom of hiding out to be contended with.

title: High Russian Aide Of the U.N. Denies That He Is a Spy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4A Soviet member of the United Nations staff denied today as slanderous and false allegations that he was an espionage agent.

title: MARAVICH TO MISS GAME WITH KNICKS
description: The Atlanta Hawks arrived here yesterday for a preseason game against the Knicks without Pete Maravich, their glamour backcourt man.

title: Ellsberg Wins a Motion For Inventory of Property
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP)A motion for an independent inventory of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's records and other property was granted to the defense today by a United States District Court judge, William M. Bryne Jr.

title: Greece Plans to Curb Foreign Envoys
description: ATHENS, Oct. 4  Greece's military  backed Government, vexed by the American Ambassador's contacts with its political opponents, warned tonight that it proposed to curb they activities of foreign diplomats and deny them access to former politicians.

title: Israel Believed Producing Missile of Atom Capability
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Israel has started to manufacture modest quantities of a missile capable of carrying a 1,000pound to 1,500pound warhead 300 miles or more, according to wellplaced American and other Western intelligence reports.

title: Patricia Kirkland at C.B.S.
description: Patricia Kirkland, daughter of the late Nancy Carroll, film star, and the late Jack Kirkland, playwright, has been named New York casting director for the television network of the Columbia Broadcasting System, effective immediately. She succeeds Jean Arley, who becomes associate producer of Where the Heart Is, daytime serial.

title: Inca Queen Scores by Nose in Field of 9 on Belmont Turf
description: A stirring finish, in which C. V. Whitney's Inca Queen nipped True Davis's Able Jan at the wire, thrilled the crowd of 24.581 at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Ronan Calls BondIssue Vote Key to Stable Subway Fares
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, insisted yesterday that the subway fare would go to 45 or 50 cents if Governor Rockefeller's $2.5billion transportation bond issue, was not passed in next month's election.

title: 2 Men Indicted in Theft Of $1Million in Securities
description: A hank clerk and a cigar salesman were indicted by Federal grand jury here yesterday on charges of stealing more than $1million in securities from the Bankers Trust Company in July.

title: Raiders' 4thPeriod Rally Overcomes Browns, 3420
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 4 (AP)The Oakland Raiders rallied for 24 points in the fourth quarter behind Daryle Lamonica's passing and a key interception by George Atkinson to defeat the Cleveland Browns, 3420, in nationally televised game tonight.

title: Nature Preserve Planned
description: UPTON, L. I., Oct. 4The 2,137 acres will be operated by the Long Island State Park Commission as a park and nature preserve.

title: '70 Imports $942Million
description: Imports of French goods into the United States last year totaled about $942million, while United States exports to France came to $1.434billion, leaving this country with a trade surplus of $542million.

title: MSGR. JAMES J. GRIFFIN
description: Msgr. James J. Griffin, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Incarnation, Bellaire, Queens, since 1046, and for 50 years a priest of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn, died Sunday in Mary Magdalen Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: BERKING WILL KEEP WEST CHESTER POST
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 4Max Berking was elected as Westchester County Democratic leader at the party's tumultuous convention, attended by more than 1,000 delegates at the Glen Island Casino here tonight.

title: OBSERVER
description: Living on the moon is not for the faint of heart: you gotta be tough and quick on your toes, the gravity's weak (a lighterthanair fair), you're liable to float away, and the atmosphere, of course, is poison. But it's come to this, we're on the moon, and live here we must, since the great valleys of death won't have usnow, perhaps forever. New York City is the moon, Lunacy reigns here, we're on it, we're on it.

title: TeachIns on Prison Set For 20 College Campuses
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 Teachins on prisons and prison reforms have been set for more than 20 college campuses for Oct. 20, the National Student Association announced today.

title: A Contender in Bonn
description: Man in the News

title: Riley Victor in Archery
description: SUMTER, S.C., Oct. 4Jim Riley of Bellbrook, Ohio, defeated Rick Gilley of Temple, Tex., on the 29th arrow of shootoff yesterday in the Santee Cooper Country Open for professional archers. Ann Butz of Suffern, N.Y., retained her women's championship with score of 576x600.

title: PRESIDENT USES TAFTHARTLEY ACT IN DOCK WALKOUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4President Nixon tonight signed an Executive order invoking the TaftHartley Act in the current dock strikes.

title: Sexual Therapy Center To Open on Long Island
description: NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Oct. 4The establishment of the country's first hospitalbased program to deal with the problems of sexual malfunction or inadequacy was announced here today by the Long Island Jewish Medical Center.

title: MOSBACHER WINS 3 SOLING CUP RACES
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 4Bob Mosbacher of Houston, the world Soling Class champion, won all three of his match races today in the Seawanhaka International Challenge Cup competition on Long Island Sound.

title: DANIEL BELL, 80, RETIRED BANKER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Daniel W. Bell, former Under Secretary of the Treasury and board chairman of the American Security and Trust Company, died at his home last night. He was 80 years old.

title: School Buses Must Roll
description: The oneday walkout by the city's school bus drivers and mechanics was an inexcusable strike against more than 100,000 pupils. It would be excessively charitable to say that Local 1181 of the Amalgamated Transit Union merely disregarded the children's welfare; the fact that those children, including 13,000 who are handicapped, were deliberately used as pawns in an unsavory fight between the union and the bus operators.

title: Bible Reading in Schools Of Alabama Unconstitutional
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 4 A Federal judge ruled today that Alabama's 1927 law requiring daily Bible reading in the schools was unconstitutional.

title: LAUREL DASH WON BY LIGHT SPLASH
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 4Light Splash, a fleet daughter of Nashver from the Pelican Stable, took the lead at the start and never was headed as she defeated 11 other Marylandbred 2yearold fillies in the $24,700 Cameo Stakes on opening day of Laurel Race Course's 60th anniversary meeting today.

title: ARMY UNIT FAVORS TOCKS ISLAND PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP)The Army Corps of Engineers today recommended proceeding with the controversial Tocks Island dam project despite some anticipated damage to fish and wildlife quality and a controlled risk that a planned 37rilelong reservoir in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania will be polluted.

title: $718,652 OTB Handle Sets a Daily Record
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation reported a handle of $718,652 yesterday, the largest since the corporation was formed.

title: Hughes Contract Expanded
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company received yesterday a $137.1million addition to a Navy contract for firecontrol systems for the Phoenix missile used by the F14A fighter.

title: Colonel's Mylai Report Is Called Untrue
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 4The former commander of helicopter battalion flying in support of attacking infantrymen at Mylai 4 said today that a report he had read of the incident while In Vietnam didn't tell the truth.

title: C.B.S. Comes Out on Top In Second Nielsen Report
description: The season's second A.C. Nielsen rating report, covering the popularity of television programs in the week of Sept. 20 to 26, listed the Columbia Broadcasting System in first place. The report was released yesterday.

title: Jury Hears Opening Arguments in $2.3Million FeeSplitting Trial of Alioto and 3 Others
description: VANCOUVER, Wash., Oct. 4 John J. O'Connell waited until he received his first feesplitting check of $101,250 before signing a letter that more than doubled the sum collected by Joseph L. Alioto, a jury was told here today.

title: PLAYOFF RIVALS TO SWITCH COASTS FOR GAMES TODAY
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4The baseball playoffs switched coasts today, with growing doubt that San Francisco and Oakland could swing the first freeway series.

title: Kidnapped Dominican Aide Is Expelled From Venezuela
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 4 (Reuters)The Dominican Republic's consul, Mrs. Thelma Frias de Rodriguez, accused of arranging her own milliondollar kidnapping, was expelled from Venezuela today with her adopted son. Fausto Frias, the Dominican Vice Consul.

title: MISSING MARINE WINS DISCHARGE
description: Pvt. Nicholas G. Pavlik left on a belated honeymoon yesterday after receiving an honorable discharge from the Marine Corps.

title: Fischer Plays Petrosian In 2d Chess Game Today
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4The second game of the 12game final qualifying chess match between Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union will begin here tomorrow.

title: Staff Cutback Announced
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 (AP) Representative McCloskey has cut back his staffs in California and Washington because of shortage of funds, his office announced today.

title: THIEU SAYS VOTING SHOWS DEMOCRACY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his victory in the oneman presidential election yesterday was a clear example of democracy in action.

title: OBSERVER
description: I received the impression that most people were unaware . . of ... an offer of secret talks by the N.L.F.

title: U.S. Embassy Replies
description: PARIS. Oct. 4 (AP)  The United States Embassy here termed Mr. Blount's appeal for a boycott totally contrary to the views of the Nixon Administration.

title: DONALD L. EMMETT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 3Donald L. Emmett, senior vice president here of Gray Advertising, which has its headquarters in New York, died today of cancer in a Toronto hospital. He was 40 years old.

title: BARBERS OFFICIAL ADMITS LOAN PLOT
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI)Joseph D. De Paola, president of the Journeymen Barbers Union, pleaded guilty today to a charge that he conspired with a financial adviser to arrange kickbacks on loans from the union's pension fund.

title: SCHOOL BOARD 5 ENDS ITS REVOLT
description: Community School Board 5 and Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, who had been In a dispute over budget allocations, reached a settlement yesterday In which the local board agreed to spend within its allotted budget.

title: CORPORATE MERGERS ROSE IN 3D QUARTER
description: The number of corporate merger announcements, which had been dwindling in the first half of this year, showed a good increase in the third quarter, W. T. Grimm & Co., merger and acquisition consultants, announced yesterday. This is the first indication of an uptrend in merger activity in many months.

title: Notes on People
description: Two former Crown Princes, Emperor Hirohito of Japan and the Duke of Windsor, held a reunion in Paris; the last meeting was 50 years ago. As part of a European four with Empress Nagako, Hirohito took tea with the Duke and his Duchess.

title: OHIO SEMINARY AIDE FOUND SHOT TO DEATH
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 4Mrs. Abraham Glueck Brown of the administrative staff of the Hebrew Union CollegeJewish Institute of Religion was found fatally shot last night in her car in a parking lot in the rear of the apartment building where she lived in Hartwell, a suburb north of Cincinnati. She was 59 years old.

title: Attica Proposal for Monitors Ignored, Inquiry Head Testifies
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 4The cochairman of the committee set up at Governor Rockefeller's request to oversee conditions at the Attica Correctional Facility in the wake of last month's revolt testified today that the state had not yet acted on recommendation that an independent monitor force be placed in the prison.

title: Store Sales Up
description: New stores in the suburbs, as well as improving sales in both women's and men's wear, offset the adverse effects of a heavy rainfall last month on volume of the city's largest stores.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES CAMPAIGN CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The House Administration Committee approved today a campaign finance bill with stricter limits on political contributions and spending than the Senate passed two months ago.

title: METHADONE CLINIC DIVIDES RED HOOK
description: An attempt by Long Island College Hospital to establish methadone clinic in an Episcopal parochial school in Brooklyn was blocked yesterday by 300 parents who expressed fears that their children would he exposed to drug addicts.

title: WILLIAM S. HASWELL
description: William S. Haswell, managing director of the National Builders' Hardware Association, died Saturday of a heart attack in a Riverdale nursing home. He lived at 75 East End Avenue.

title: STATE GETS LAND ON L. I. FROM U.S.

description: New American security assurances to Israel are reported under discussion to encourage the Israeli Government to accent an interim Suez agreement under which it would draw its forces back from the canal's bank and Egypt would be committed to reopen the waterway.

description: AUBURN, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) The Philadelphia Phillies of the National League have become the parent team of Auburn in the New YorkPennsylvania League, the club announced today. Auburn had been affiliated with Minnesota of the American League.

description: The International Longshoremen's Association and stevedore interests here broke off negotiations after a twoanda half hour meeting yesterday. The talks ended amid uncertainty as to whether the President would seek a TaftHartley injunction against a work stoppage that has closed down most major Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports.

description: Peter Kihss of The New York Times has been chosen to receive the 1971 quartercentury news achievement award of the Society of the Silurians, an organization of past and present newspapermen.

description: DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 4High American officials, Buddhist opposition leaders and independent observers today sharply challenged the Government's claims of a heavy turnout of voters in Danang and Hue in yesterday's presidential election.

description: Stock prices continued to push upward yesterday morning but faded steadily in the afternoon.

description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 4Indian artillery and mortar fire has killed 27 East Pakistani villagers and wounded 53 in the last two days, the Pakistani radio said today.

title: William A. Thomson, 94, Dead; Headed Publishers' Ad Bureau

title: Hijacker Kills Wife, Pilot and Himself
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 4 (AP)Posing as a doctor with a patient, George M. Giffe Jr. dragged his screaming young wife aboard a private plane in Nashville today, forced the pilot to fly here, then killed his wife, the pilot and himself when cornered by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Pasolini's 'Decameron' at the Film Festival
description: Pier Paolo Pasolini, the Italian director, has always been something of a puzzle for American critics, not simply because we have to reconcile his announced Marxism with what appears to be a kind of reformed Christianity (as reflected by the neo-realistic "The Gospel According to St. Matthew," as well as by the austerely allegorical "Teorema"), but because he forces us to keep shifting critical gears. No three Pasolinis are ever quite alike. At best, they come in pairs, like "Oedipus Rex" and "Medea," neither of which have yet been released here.There is, however, a peculiar kind of romanticism throughout all of his films. It is a middle-class romanticism that idealizes the spiritual and emotional freedom that Pasolini sees in what we used to call The Common Man, who, in slightly more straightforward, class-conscious Europe, is still The Peasant. As if he were some medieval maiden locked in a tower, Pasolini seems to long for the freedom to do what the simple folk do, which, to Pasolini, evokes sexual liberation as much as anything else.In none of his films has this been more apparent than in his marvelous new work, "The Decameron," which is as close to being uninhibited and joyful as anything he's ever done.Taking 10 tales out of the 100 in Boccaccio's "Decameron," Pasolini has created one of the most beautiful, turbulent and uproarious panoramas of early Renaissance life ever put on film. It is also one of the most obscene, if obscene defines something that is offensive to ordinary concepts of chastity, delicacy and decency, although I'd hardly call the film offensive to morals.Pasolini's "Decameron" is faithful to the original texts, but it is not Boccaccio's. This is not because Pasolini has dispensed with Boccaccio's frame, which has seven women and three men, refugees from the plague that settled on Florence in 1348, each tell one story a day for the 10 days they are marooned in country villa. Pasolini uses no frame except a single setting, Naples, where the stories grow one out of the other as do the scenes in a frieze.Rather, the difference between the two works has to do with the difference between the two works has to the delicate euphemisms of Boccaccio's storytellers become the blunt unequivocal images of filmed reality. The difference also has to do with Pasolini's conscious recreation of a world that is as strange and bizarre as that of the pre-Christian "Fellini Satyricon," which Pasolini's film recalls by its pagan beauty, and by its concern with life as art, if not by its comic temperament.In his "Satyricon," Fellini contented himself by playing God, the artist, off screen. Pasolini is not quite so modest. About halfway through "The Decameron" he himself shows up as Giotto, one of the founding fathers of the Renaissance. Thereafter we see him periodically, surrounded by his students, at work on a giant fresco, the holy faces of which are those of the thieves, whores, merchants, nuns, friars, rubes, deceived husband and not-so-virginal lovers, whose stories we've been watching.When his work is finally completed, Giotto is spent, drained, empty of feeling. "Why produce a work of art," he says to himself, "when it's so nice to dream about it?"Pasolini's dream is composed of the tales he tells us, takes as its theme a frenzied Giotto nightmare, in which the artist's religious visions are overwhelmed by the more attractive visions of a pagan orgy.With the exception of Franco Citti, Ninetto Davoli and Silvana Mangano (who appears in an unbilled cameo), the cast is mostly composed of amateurs, for Pasolini, like Giotto, is fascinated by the truth of unprepared faces. They are all either extraordinarily beautiful or extraordinarily ugly, as if they were different classes of beings. There is, however, something about their awkwardness and self-consciousness that gives a special dimension of truth to the film itself.I must say that, at the beginning of the movie, I feared we were in for another one of Franco Zefferelli's rather fruitily lush, medieval window displays. However, because Pasolini is a sterner poet than Zefferelli, "The Decameron" becomes an epic, instead of just another unruly and inverted fashion show.The film, which was shown last night at the New York Film Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, will be released commercially later in the year.

title: Advertising:

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Organized labor's chief spokesman, George Meany, urged Congress today to take control of the nation's economy away from President Nixon.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally suggested today that more steps needed to be taken in the tax fieldas well as the areas of monetary policy and trade  if all nations were to have a fair opportunity to participate in the betterment of the world economy.

description: Laurence Steinhardt and Milton Kaye, the violinist and the pianist who gave a duo recital Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, made a wellmatched pair of solid musicians whose serious approach to whatever they played earned one's respect.

Still the photograph is a fitting symbol of the elite, disciplined, almost cavalrylike, image that the organization likes to project.

title: Couple Killed in Plane Crash
description: HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 4 (UPI) A couple from the Shamokin area were killed today when their singleengine plane exploded over a golf course, lost its wings and spun to a fiery crash. The state police identified them as Curtis Q. McWilliams, 42 years old, the pilot, and his wife, Jean.

description: The investor with a strong social conscience is often perplexed. How does he increase his capital without supporting corporate practices he deems destructive or antisocial?

description: HONG KONG, Oct. 4 (AP)American and Hong Kong officials refused today to disclose any details of their current textile talks here or even say what meetings are taking place.

description: Mrs. Billie Jean King learned what $100,000 in prize money cannot buy in New York successful phone call the first time around.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission came out today in opposition to a bill to require advertisers to substantiate their claims.

title: Advertising:
description: Salem cigarettes, which you can't take the country out of, has just brought, it into Grand Central Terminal. R. J. Reynolds, the William Esty ad agency and Douglas Leigh, the super sign maker (the same team that gave Times Square the man blowing smoke rings for Camels), have just created a 30footlong permanent garden exhibit on the northwest balcony. Tall trees, pretty flowers (all individually and automatically watered), a bubbling fountain, today's temperature, tomorrow's weather and a sixfoot Salem pack. The health warning, one astute reporter noted, is in the underbrush.

title: Japanese Plans Reported
description: TOKYO, Oct. 4 (Agence France Presse)  The Foreign Ministry is preparing a five point program aimed at remedying the JapanUnited States trade balance now largely in Japan's favor; including the conclusion of a governmenttogovernment textile agreement and an early upward revaluation of the yen by more than 10 per cent, the Nihon Keizai, Japan's leading economic daily newspaper reported today.

title: Orioles Beat A's Again
description: The Orioles defeated the Athletics, 51, yesterday for their second straight American league playoff victory. Baltimore can clinch the pennant by winning today at Oakland. (Details, Page 51.)

title: Pennsylvania Inmates Get New Rights
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 4 State Attorney General J. Shane Creamer announced today the promulgation of a Bill of Rights for prisoners in Pennsylvania state prisons that he said insured them the right to be treated with dignity as human beings while imprisoned.

title: PECK TO MAKE FILM OF CATONSVILLE 9
description: The Trial of the Catonsville Nine, the play by the Rev. Daniel Berrigan, the activist Roman Catholic priestauthor, has been acquired for filming by Melville Productions, headed by Gregory Peck.

title: Safeway Stores, Inc., Raises Earnings for Quarter by 12.4%
description: Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's secondlargest food chain, realized a 12.4 per cent increase in earnings for the 12 weeks ended Sept. 11 and gain of 12 per cent for the 36week period. The report yesterday from the company's Oakland, Calif., headquarters showed sales gains of 11.5 and 13 per cent for the respective periods.

title: Dr. Aldo Castellani, a Specialist On Sleeping Sickness, Is Dead
description: LISBON, Oct. 4 (AP)Dr. Aldo Castellani, a world authority on tropical diseases, died yesterday, the Italian Embassy announced today. He was 97 years old.

title: The Murder of Fred Hampton'
description: History is, or should be, recorded after exhaustive contemplation, but "The Murder of Fred Hampton," the documentary about the slain Chicago Black Panther leader that was shown yesterday and is being screened again today at the Museum of Modern Art, makes immediacy an attribute of history. Although it is unabashedly biased and it is flawed in technical execution, it emerges as a disturbingly somber illustration of some of the ills that beset us and our social system.MGA, Inc., the producers, turned out a number of TV and other commercial subjects, including "American Revolution II," a documentary about the teaming of the Chicago Black Panthers and the white Young Patriots, before starting on "Fred Hampton" in 1968 as a documentary study of the work of Hampton and his Panthers. With word of the shooting of Hampton and Fred Clark in a police raid on Panther headquarters on Dec. 4, 1969, Mr. Gray and his camera crew rushed to the scene. This footage, plus extensive TV documentation of the slayings and subsequent coverage, as well as the previous documentation of Hampton's career, constitute a remarkable, if uneven, case history.It is, in sum, an unleavened indictment of Edward V. Hanrahan, the Illinois State's Attorney, the policemen in the raid and the Chicago political Establishment. It opens with the aftermath of the slaying and quickly switches back to Hampton, then 21 years old, and to Bobby Rush, Doc Satchel and other Panther leaders. Hampton, constantly haranguing his enthusiastic followers with, for example, "I believe I will he able to die as a revolutionary," makes a startlingly prescient impression, even in the grainy, disjoined footage.The subsequent events are made all too lucid in the second half of the film, as Mr. Hanrahan's often angry testimony, as well as the police officers' reports, are rebutted, sometimes heatedly but often calmly, by Panther witnesses and their legal representatives. The evidence, both verbal and at the scene of the slayings, forces an impartial viewer to question the official version.Whether "murder" is the official word for the case seems a moot point. A Federal grand jury has criticized the police and its investigation of the shooting. And, Mr. Hanrahan, one of his assistants and 12 policemen were indicted in August by a special grand jury for allegedly having conspired to prevent prosecution of the policemen participating in the raid. But Mr. Gray: Howard Alk, his editor, and the rest of their company, who are declining formal credits on the film, which thus far has been seen only at the Cannes festival and in Chicago, Washington, and Stratford, Ontario, deserve credit for presenting their impassioned case, which certainly rates a wider audience.

title: JOBS ARE RESISTED BY RELIEF CLIENTS
description: The State Labor Department reported yesterday that nearly a third of the welfare recipients who showed up to get relief checks in August and said they were available for jobs had resisted department efforts to put them to work.

title: Futures Prices Cut By Export Decline; Soybeans Off Most
description: With exports of agricultural products off in recent weeks and now expected to drop even further as a result of the longshoremen's strike, commodity prices fell yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Mediator Foresees Move
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct, 4 (AP)The chief Federal mediator announced today, that negotiations in the 96day West Coast dock strike had reached an impasse.

title: FREDERICKSON PUT ON MOVE STATUS
description: Forced to make room for newly acquired wide receiver, the New York Giants put Tucker Frederickson on the move list yesterday, making him unavailable for the next two games. Frederickson had suffered a pulled hamstring muscle in Sunday's 2120 victory at St. Louis, but there was no indication then that his injury was that serious.

title: A. F. HETHERINGTON, SECURITIES BROKER
description: Arthur F. Hetherington, who was active for 60 years in Wall Street concerns, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Bound Brook, N. J., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: West German Opposition Picks Chief
description: SAARBRUCKEN, West Germany, Oct. 4Rainer C. Barzel, the Parliamentary floor leader of the powerful Christian Democratic Union, won overwhelming endorsement tonight as the new chairman of the party and, in effect, the designated candidate for the chancellorship in the 1973 elections.

title: Montane and Edwards Spark Un Ballo
description: Carlos Montane and Ryan Edwards joined the cast of the City Opera's Un Ballo in Maschera Sunday night, their vital, involving performances enhancing the already high standards of the production. Both men are young, agile and dramatically convincing, with strong, clear voices that augur well for the future strength of the company.

title: 6 Civilian Specialists Join Police as Murphy's Aides
description: The city Police Department will get its first civilian efficiency experts this weeksix men who have been named special assistants to Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: Labor Party Opposes Entry Into Market
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 4 The Labor party conference voted overwhelmingly today against British entry into the European Common Market on the negotiated terms.

title: MULLIGAN GUILTY IN CONTEMPT CASE
description: Hugh Mulligan, a major figure in an 18month grand jury investigation of police corruption and other crimes, was convicted on 12 counts of criminal contempt yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: KLM to Cut Fares For Senior Citizens On Atlantic Flights
description: Introducing a new twist to the spreading price war in transAtlantic air travel, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that it would offer a senior citizen discount fare between the United States and Amsterdam starting Feb. 1.

title: OBSERVER
description: John Mitchell, Attorney General and chief political strategist to the President of the United States, having drawn up the chief political strategy, for the Presidential campaign of 1972 and sent it ahead to his chief, reported to the White House the other day to see how the chief liked it.

title: Rulings on Access to Price Records

title: Mayor Opens Drug Abuse Week With a Warning
description: Saying that drug addiction is no longer an innercity problem alone, Mayor Lindsay chose Queens Borough Hall as his forum yesterday to proclaim the start of National Drug Abuse Week in the city.

title: CONNECTICUT TOLD IT CAN CUT COSTS
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 4A special state government study commission headed by Edwin D. Etherington, former president of the American Stock Exchange, recommended today a reorganization of the state government structure that it said would save a potential $153,616,250 annually.

title: MINE UNION IS GIVEN A PROGRESS REPORT
description: The policy committee of the United Mine Workers heard a progress report yesterday on the fourdayold soft coal strike but it appeared there was little progress to report.

title: Compact Set Up for PostRacial South
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 4The ever  changing American South has produced an interstate compact designed to deal with the problems of rapid change in a postracial period of growth and expansion.

description: Reynolds Securities, Inc., announced yesterday the election of Joseph H. McConnell to its board of directors. Presently chairman of the Communications Satellite Corporation. Mr, McConnell has served as president of the Reynolds Metals Company, the ColgatePalmolive Company and the National Broadcasting Company.

title: LIMIT ON LAOS AID VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4The Senate voted today to place $350million ceiling on military and economic assistance to Laos.

title: Maury of France Triumphs In 2d Finn Gold Cup Sail
description: TORONTO, Oct. 4 (Canadian Press). Serge Maury of France held off determined attempts by four Swedish sailors and an Australian today and won the second race of the Finn Gold Cup competition on Lake Ontario.

title: City Library Service to Assist Local Communities Is Proposed
description: A plan to put community information and referral services into 181 city branch libraries has been submitted for Federal approval and financing, according to Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello.

Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetth, exhibited documents today that he described as indicating that the Defense Department was offering military materiel to Pakistan as recently as July 20, despite State Department testimony to Congress June 28 that such offers ended March 25.

Carter Paul Yuen, 21 years old, was also indicted on charges of attempting to murder a 14yearold Ronald Gong, who was in good condition at Sierra Valley Hospital in Loyalton. The dead youths were Russell K. Wong, Wendell Lee, and Daniel Yen Woo.

title: Olmi's 'In the Summertime'
description: Ermanno Olmi's critical reputation has rested mostly on two early films of social alienation, "Il Posto" (called here "The Sound of Trumpets," 1961) and "The Fiancs" (1962). I'm not sure that his new film, "In the Summertime," which played Sunday night in the New York Film Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, is likely to please too many of Olmi's former admirers. It is not so much that "In the Summertime" is vastly less good than his previous work. It is merely every bit as bad, but in new and somewhat different ways.The film is about a man (Renato Paracchi), slight, polite, a bit shy, middle-aged, a Milanese who carries his schoolboy nickname of Professor, who survives by coloring maps for an encyclopedia publisher, but really lives for his avocationwhich is drawing up coats of arms and conferring phony patents of nobility on guileless citizens to whom he writeswith ball-point goose quilland whom, of course he charges for his researches.The Professor honors only those strangers in whose faces he detects innate nobility, and so his coats of arms are intended as outward signs of an inward state. So also, when he finds a girl (Rosanna Callegari), a door-to-door saleswoman of bath powder, he can assure her with much eloquent protestation that she is, in every sense that matters, a bonafide princess.In am not exactly sure just when I lost my last shred of patience with this mild, genuinely well-intentioned fable, but I think it was during the 20 minutes or so given over to the Professor's sprained ankle. He had taken the Princess on an outing and got caught in somebody else's rose garden (where, by grace of their poetic souls, only he and she really belonged), and twisted his foot while running away in what must be one of the least resourceful comic-chase sequences ever filmed. The ankle sprain, boring in itself, gave time to contemplate all that was not done during "In the Summertime," or was done wrong, or had better been left undone.So much of what is wrong with "In the Summertime" seems to result from sheer ineptitude in shaping a scene or from the weak contrivances of the screenplay that one is tempted to chalk up its failures to faulty mechanics and let them go at that. But Olmi is really striving for a higher pathos, as in the Chaplin tragicomedies  and there is something about this amibition that positively magifies his lack of achievement. Like the telephone calls the Professor makes throughout the film without ever finding his party in. According to Olmi, these are his hero's attempt to make contact with a society with which he can't make contact. But in fact they are no more than the the idea for an imageand it is the audience with whom contact is not made.Neither of the film's leading players can sustain the sentimental fervor for which it strivesthough Renato Renato Paracchi, a nonprofessional, possesses a good sensitive face and at least the manner of the gentility that he calls noble. Miss Callegari is very beautiful, and in better circumstances might very well embody that tough fragility of flesh and spirit that is her role.One night, the Professor takes his Princess to visit a "Count" who keeps old music machines, including a palyer piano on which he, with fervent intensity, controls pedal and volume. "He isn't playing," the Princess observes. "The provides the expression," answers the Professorand I think we are meant to understand that the feeling makes the art. But the art is an amalgam of many things, including skill and discipline and thought and imagination, and it is these that earn "the expression," as in the great Chaplin films. Without them, fine feeling is mere inexpressive indulgence, and that is how I should characterize "In the Summertime."

title: BOND PRICES RISE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The credit markets, which have been moving toward higher fixedincome security prices and lower interest rates for nearly two weeks, continued these trends yesterday.

title: MORTON STUDYING ALASKAN PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton declined to say today when he would authorize construction of the $1billion transAlaska oil pipeline.

title: Bridge: Swiss Team Play Provides For Some Exciting Finishes
description: Swiss team championships, in which short matches are played and teams with similar records are paired against each other, tend to produce exciting finishes. The New YorkNew Jersey Swiss event played Sunday at Swan Lake, N.Y., was no exception.

title: NIXON HEALTH PLAN CRITICIZED BY MILLS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) The Administration's health insurance proposals would only add to the problems we now have, Representative Wilbur D. Mills, Democrat of Arkansas, said today.

title: Amex Prices Edge Up as Volume Gains
description: The American Stock Exchange just managed to finish higher yesterday after some late selling erased part of the earlier gains in steppedup trading.

title: I.D.S. Subsidiary Rejected For Seat on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange has rejected the membership application of Jefferies & Co., a brokerage subsidiary of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the huge mutualfund organization.

title: PETROFINA PLANS $150MILLION DEAL
description: Merger News

title: Judge Calls for Plan Adding the Suburbs To Detroit Schools
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4  A Federal judge told the Michigan Board of Education today to propose within 120 days a plan for a metropolitan school district covering Detroit and some of its suburbs.

title: SADAT NAMED CHIEF OF ARAB FEDERATION
description: CAIRO, Oct. 4 President Anwar elSadat of Egypt was chosen tonight as the first President of the Federation of Arab Republics, which links Egypt with Syria and Libya and is envisaged as a nucleus of eventual Arabworld unity.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4Being comparatively new, the system has not had time enough to enlist the fervent support of any appreciable number of fans. Maybe it never will. But the current procedure of having divisional playoffs in each major league to produce pennant winners and World Series contestants is something that baseball traditionalists find hard to swallow. They even may be choking on it.

title: Taiwan to Cut Exports
description: TAIPEI, Oct. 4 (UPI)Nationalist China's noncotton textile exports to the United States will be cut by 30 to 40 per cent under an initial GovernmenttoGovernment agreement reached Saturday, Y. T. Wong, director of the Board of Foreign Trade, confirmed today.

title: 16,711 Fans See Rangers Rout Injured Bruins, 41
description: Evoking gusty reactions from their delirious fans, even when killing penalties, the Rangers treated a crowd of 16,711 at Madison Square Garden last night to a 41 victory over half a Boston Bruins' team.

title: Union Says That Cutbacks Hurt Care for Mental Patients
description: A job freeze and other fiscal cutbacks at state institutions for the mentally ill and retarded have caused critical deterioration in patient care, the Civil Service Employes Association charged yesterday.

title: Woodcock Assesses Freeze
description: DETROIT, Oct. 4 (UPI)The president of the United Automobile Workers, Leonard Woodcock, conceded today that the wageprice freeze was succeeding in maintaining price levels and was restraining wage levels most enthusiastically.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Book Season: 36,000 Titles, and Problems
description: The annual flow of books, choked to a mere trickle in the summer months, is cresting this week as the new titles of the 197172 fall and winter seasons move into the nation's warehouses and bookstores.

title: Man Aboard a Stolen Boat Kills Himself as Police Near
description: A 21yearold man shot himself to death last night in al, motor launch he had stolen as police patrol boats converged on him in the upper East River, the police reported.

title: Surtax Removal Urged
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 5 Leading resident American businessmen from nine countries and territories in the AsianPacific area urged the United States Government today to promptly remove the 10 per cent import surcharge. They also opposed unilateral imposition of quotas on American textile imports.

title: Peking Trip Raises Problems for White House Advance Men
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 5No one ever thought that Henry A. Kissinger would be recorded in history as a White House advance man.

title: Lowenstein Joins Nassau Race For County Democrat Chairman
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 5Allard K. Lowenstein, national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action and a former Representative from Nassau County's Fifth Congressional District, announced today that he would seek the post of county Democratic chairman.

title: A Kiss for Mrs. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP)  Mrs. Richard Nixon signed autographs for 15 minutes and got a kiss from Mickey Mouse at opening night of the Disney on Parade show before 3,200 fans here tonight. The show at the Washington Coliseum featured 100 Walt Disney characters.

title: Man in the News
description: He has the coolest head and most even temper of any human being I know, a colleague said yesterday of J. Keith Mann. He manages to keep his perspective on any problem in the heat of the moment  something that's beyond most mortals and which is why I assume he's been chosen for this job. The job he referred to is one for which President Nixon selected the 47 year  old Professor Mannas head of a board of inquiry into the extended West Coast dock strike.

title: RoundClock Racing Runs Down
description: About Motor Sports

title: New City Subway Cars Assailed by Councilmen
description: Two Democratic City Council members took an unannounced trip on the city's newest subway cars yesterday and went away unimpressed. The two were Carol Greitzer, of Greenwich Village and Bertram R. Gelfand of the Bronx, who also is chairman of the Council's Transportation Committee.

title: Reserve Board Names Aide
