And at times, as when the Southern military school boys march out to do battle in "The Horse Soldiers" (1959), I am moved literally to tears by "Directed by John Ford."

title: MAYOR CHARGES BAR IS APATHETIC
description: Mayor Lindsay criticized the overwhelming majority of lawyers yesterday for remaining silent and unconcerned and failing in their obligations to the system of criminal justice in this country.

title: Goldberg Favors Limiting President's War Powers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Ar thur J. Goldberg argued today that the future salvation and even survival of the nation depended on placing limitations on the warmaking powers of the Presidency.

title: Rep. Celler Urges a Review Of National Steel Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, has urged the Justice Department to review the recent merger of the National Steel Corporation and the Granite City Steel Corporation. Representative Celler said the combination seems sufficiently anticompetitive to have warranted Justice Department opposition.

title: Bartels Named General Counsel Of State Unit Investigating City
description: Two major appointments to the Temporary State Commission to Make a Study of the Governmental Operation of the City of New York were announced yesterday by Stuart N. Scott commission chairman.

title: Airline Bookings Show a Gain
description: Advance bookings, a leading indicator for the airlines, are running at a higher rate for the first time in more than year, according to Donald LloydJones, executive vice presidentfinance of American Airlines.

title: BondIssue Defeat Urged Unless State Aids Subways
description: Assemblyman Albert M. Blumenthal said yesterday that New York City voters should reject the state's $2.5billion transportation bond issue unless Governor Rockefeller agreed to do as much for the subways as he already had done for the Long Island Railroad.

title: Edit Angold, 76, Actress Of Stage and Screen, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6Edit Angold, an actress who appeared in many Broadway and Hollywood productions, died on Monday at the age of 76.

title: U. N. Debate on China Expected to Open Thursday, Four Days Early
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6The crucial debate on Chinese representation in the United Nations is expected to begin next Thursday under a plan devised by the General, Assembly's president, Adam Malik of Indonesia.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 A timebomb hidden in a suitcase exploded at Beirut Airport this afternoon minutes before it was to have been put on board a Jordanian airliner for a flight to Amman. The explosion caused no damage or casualties.

title: White Sox Renew Link
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP)The Chicago White Sox said today they had renewed their affiliation with Tucson of the Pacific Coast League.

title: L.I. Bank Robbed of $10,000
description: Two men, one armed with a sawedoff shotgun, stole about $10,000 from a Queens hank yesterday. The police said the two entered the National Bank of North America branch at 19202 Northern Boulevard shortly before 10 A.M., forced four women employes into a rest room and tok he money from the tellers' cash drawers.

title: Chrysler Unit to Form Link
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Chrysler Corporation said today that the Chrysler Financial Corporation and Mercantile Credit, Ltd., of Britain would form two joint finance subsidiaries, one to finance wholesale sales of Chrysler cars and the other to finance retail sales of automobiles in the United Kingdom.

title: Feast of Ashes Begins 6Week Joffrey Season
description: The New York ballet season got started last night when the City Center Joffrey Ballet opened, a week or so later than usual, its sixweek fall season at the New York City Center. The novelty of the first night was a new production of Alvin Ailey's Feast of Ashes, a ballet created for the company in 1962.

title: Heart Pump Patient Ailing
description: DETROIT, Oct. 6 (UPI) Haskell Shanks, released from Sinai Hospital 17 days ago with a mechanical heart pump, has been readmitted to the hospital with a minor pulmonary problem, a hospital spokesman said today. Dr. Adrian Kantrowitz implanted the pump, known as a patch booster, in a fivehour operation on Aug. 11. Mr. Shanks is the first successful recipient of a permanently implanted mechanical heart device.

title: Denmark Seeks New Cabinet
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 6 (Reuters)King Frederik IX today asked the Social Democratic party leader, Jens Otto Krag, to form a new government following an indecisive general election Sept. 21.

title: O'Brien Tells Democrats Attacks Alone Can't Win
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI)Lawrence F. O'Brien said today that the Democratic party would court almost certain disaster if it based its 1972 campaign for the White House primarily on criticism of President Nixon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Amex Sells Seat for $80,000
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday announced a scat sale at $80,000, down $20,000 from the preceding sale Sept. 30. The current market is $75,000 hid, $100,000 offered.

title: Mrs. Banuelos Sees Politics Behind Raid
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6President Nixon's nominee for Treasurer of the United States contended today, that opposition Democrats might have motivated yesterday's roundup of illegal aliens at a factory, she owns.

title: Yen Move Tied to Others
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Japanese Ambassador Nohubiko Ushiha said today that Japan would revalue the yen upward as part of a general realignment of major world currency exchange rates. However, he indicated his Government would not allow the yen meanwhile to float freely in international money markets, a condition that Treasury Secretary John B. Connally said was necessary before the United States would consider lifting its import surcharge.

title: John C. Lee, ExPresident Of Cotton Exchange Here
description: John C. Lee, president of the New York Cotton Exchange from 1951 to 1953, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 370 First Avenue.

title: Labor Against Europe
description: There is only one crumb of comfort to be salvaged from the savage assault on the European Economic Community at the British Labor party's annual conference. As expected, delegates voted by a fivetoone margin against membership in the Common Market on terms negotiated by the Conservative Government; but the party leadership blocked efforts to bind a future Labor Government to yank Britain back out if it does join.

title: U.S. Judge Declines to Act on Attica Inmates' Pleas
description: BUFFALO. Oct. 6  Federal Judge John T. Curtin dismissed today a series of requests for orders to protect the constitutional rights of all the inmates, at the Attica Correctional Facility.

title: Brazilian Takes 4th Race In Finn Cup World Sailing
description: TORONTO, Oct. 6 (AP) Joerg Bruder of Brazil, the defending champion, won the fourth race of the Finn Gold Cup in heavy seas today.

title: SENATE APPROVES DEFENSE BILL, 824
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Senate passed today a $21billion military procurement bill containing a Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment and a provision permitting the importation of Rhodesian chrome in defiance of a United Nations embargo.

title: 4 French Textile Tycoons Linked to Land Scandal
description: PARIS, Oct. 6The four Willot brothers from Lille, who built up the largest textile company in the European Common Market through razzledazzle methods that shook the French old guard, stand accused of fraud in France's growing realestate scandal.

title: 2 State University Systems In Wisconsin to Be Merged
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 6 (AP) Legislation providing for the merger of Wisconsin's two public university systems received final approval in the Wisconsin Legislature when the State Assembly passed it yesterday.

title: GATT SHOWDOWN IS SOUGHT BY U.S.
description: GENEVA, Oct. 6  The United States moved today toward a showdown over what it considers to be a failure by the European Common Market to abide by its international trade commitments.

title: Lowenstein Loses Race for Nassau Democratic Chief
description: FRANKLIN SQUARE, L.I., Oct. 6  Marvin D. Cristenfeld was reelected chairman of the Nassau County Democratic party tonight in a hotly fought contest with Allard K. Lowenstein.

title: Arthur Butterworth, Inventor And Marine Engineer, Is Dead
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Oct. 6Arthur B. Butterworth, a retired marine engineer and inventor of the internationally known Butterworth system for cleaning tankers, died today after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Boston Vote Rally Backed
description: BOSTON, Oct. 6 (AP)The Boston School Committee approved today a proposal by the Massachusetts Voter Registration Coalition to excuse seniors from city schools Friday at 12:30 P.M. for a youth voter registration rally.

title: OTB, Monticello Agree To Televising of Races
description: Despite opposition by other harness tracks, Monticello Raceway and the Offtrack setting Corporation have signed a contract for a nightly telecast of races.

title: House Votes TaxCut Bill; Senate Revision Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The House of Representatives passed the tax bill today without the formality of a rollcall vote. At the same time, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which will open hearings on the bill tomorrow, predicted that the Senate would add to the tax relief for individuals that is contained in the bill and would eliminate some of the tax relief for business.

title: RUSKIN WARNING ON LOANS IS CITED
description: More than a year ago the City Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin, told the Housing and Development Administrator, Albert A. Walsh, to reform the Municipal Loan Program, according to a confidential memorandum released yesterday.

title: Reds Let French Expert Work at Angkor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6  A noted French archeologist is being permitted by the North Vietnamese to cross back and forth through Communist lines in Cambodia to continue his lifelong work of preserving the ruins of Angkor.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
President of Gimbels New York to Resign
description: Bernard B. Zients, president of Gimbels New York a director of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., will resign these posts on Oct. 15.

title: MASSENGALE 139 LEADS BY STROKE
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 6Don Massengale, who has won the Canadian open and the Bing Crosby Tournament, led at the halfway mark today in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship with a 36hole aggregate of 139.

title: CHARLES J. O'CONNOR
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 6 Charles J. O'Connor, a retired newspaper executive and a founding member of the New England Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, died today at his home here. He was 65 years old and lived on West Ridge Road.

title: COURT CLEARS PLAN BY EXECUTIVE HOUSE
description: Executive House, Inc., announced yesterday that the United States District Court of Chicago had confirmed a plan of arrangement filed last month by the company and had released the company from court jurisdiction under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy Act. Attorney's for Executive House reported last week that the plan had been approved by a majority of its creditors.

title: Market Place:
description: Perhaps you own the shares with a mutual fund whose price seems to run counter to market trendsor so it seems when you check the price after strong stock market moves.

title: Muskie Bids Liberals Form A Coalition to Win Change
description: With Mayor Lindsay and Senator George McGovern sharing the dais and a Liberal party dinner as his forum, Senator Edmund S. Muskie declared lash night that American liberalism had failed to solve the nation's major problems.

description: To the Editor:

title: Four L.I. Parents Challenge Law on Austerity School Budgets
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 6The constitutionality of the State Education Law that allows public school districts operating under austerity budgets to charge pupils for textbooks, instructional materials, and new library hooks has bee challenged by four parents here.

title: For the Junior Size, It's All ThereAnd on One Floor
description: Shop Talk

title: Yearling Sold for $210,000, Record for PacingBred Colt
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 6The highest prices paid in stand ardbred history for a pacingbred yearling and a trottingbred yearling were recorded today at the Tattersalls Sales.

title: Pirates Win, 95, Take Pennant
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6  In the words of Steve Blass, Pittsburgh's starting pitcher today, We got bombed, but we're going to Baltimore anyway.

title: GIANTS RUSHING IN TO HELP GOGOLAK
description: In that small fraternity of soccerstyle kickers playing professional football in the United States, Pete Gogolak of the New York Giants is undoubtedly the senior member, but yesterday he asked his teammates to rush him again and that's exactly what they did.

title: ADVANCED TICKET WINS JUMP TITLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6Michele McEvoy's Advanced Ticket captured the stake and the 5 points he collected for the victory enabled him to win the amateur  owner jumper championship tonight at the Philadelphia Horse Show.

title: WEISS DENOUNCES CITY ON NOISE CODE
description: The Lindsay administration was charged yesterday by Councilman Theodore S. Weiss with paying only lip service to its proposed noise control program and providing no visible demonstration that it is committed to alleviating the problem.

title: Mockery of Prison Reform
description: The agreement reached between Governor Rockefeller's office and the union of state prison guards makes a mockery of prison reform. The union won a promise from the state to establish a maximummaximum security prison for incorrigible criminals. The guards prevailed in this key demand by threatening to stage a lockin of all the state's prisonerskeeping them locked up around the clock, except for meals. Any institution, born in this spirit, is bound to incorporate the animalcage concept of correctional facility.

title: Tokyo Apparently Nears A Textile Pact With U. S.
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6The textile dispute between the United States and Japan was evolving into a major political feud within Japan as the Government appeared today to be moving toward the completion of an agreement with Washington to restrict noncotton textile exports.

title: Knick Sale Begins Today
description: Available tickets for the first nine Knick home games will go on sale today at 10 A.M. at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum box office, Eighth Avenue between 31st and 33d Streets. The tickets will cover the period from the National Basketball Association opening game, Tuesday night, through Saturday, Nov. 13.

title: Newsweek Plans TV Spots
description: Newsweek magazine has announced that it will begin producing a television news and feature service for local stations. The national weekly news magazine said the weekly service will consist of 12 to 15 segments, each 90 seconds long, with most of the material coming from Newsweek's feature pages.

title: G.O.P. Rebuffed on Campaign Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The campaign spending issue moved into the arena of partisan politics today.

title: Yen Rate Sets a High
description: TOKYO, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Japanese yen today reached its highest rate in dollar transactions on the Tokyo foreignexchange market since Aug. 28 when it was set floating.

title: N.S.A. to Hold Parley With Foreign Students
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Students from more than 30 countries will meet here Oct. 1416 in an international conference sponsored by the National Student Association.

title: HANS E. NACHBUR
description: Hans E. Nachbur, cofounder of Alltransport, Ltd., of London and of Alltransport, Inc., of New York, died Tuesday after a short illness. He was 77 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: Lakers to Oppose Knicks Tonight
description: Coach Red Holzman of the Knickerbockers, who have won six of seven National Basketball Association preseason games, will continue to ponder a pleasurable problem tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. Doctors Are Skeptical of Acupuncture In Treatment of Purely Physical Diseases
description: American physicians who have examined the ancient Chinese Practice of acupuncture and heard the extraordinary reports of its use in China in recent months remain skeptical of the technique's value in treating purely physical diseases.

title: Personal Finance
description: Legislators in just about every state, encouraged by the general apathy of most constituents and intimidated by the strong opposition of most lawyers, have failed to show much interest so far in nofault automobile insurance.

title: Creditors Vote Plan Of Swift de la Plata
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 The Swift de la Plata meat packing company, which accounts for more than a quarter of Argentina's beefproduct exports, won a victory in bankruptcy court that will keep it functioning.

title: State Charges Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The State of New York told the Supreme Court today that lawyers for a group of prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility were attempting to impede the state's investigation of last month's prisoner rebellion.

title: Efforts to Reform 1972 Democratic Convention Endangered by Challenge Procedures
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Imperfect and uncertain enforcement machinery is endangering the success of diligent Democratic efforts to reform the party's 1972 convention.

title: Cleaver Sees a Threat to Blacks in U.S.China Thaw
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 6The Chinese invitation to President) Nixon to visit Peking has) thrown the revolutionary movement into disarray, according to Eldridge Cleaver, the extremist black American leader.

title: Appling Released as Coach
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (UPI)Luke Appling was released from the White Sox coaching staff yesterday. Appling's career as a player, coach and manager spanned 41 years. He was voted into the Hall of Fame in 1934.

title: CITY BANK NET UP; MORGAN ADVANCES
description: Two of the nation's largest banking companies reported sharp increases in profits yesterday, indicating that the worst of the earnings squeeze that the banking industry experienced in the spring may now be past.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Meet Cookie. The year's most unlikely heroine. $8.03 at your bookstore.Advt.

title: MEDICARE FUND RULE CHALLENGED IN SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Two elderly citizens' groups and a San Francisco health clinic filed suit today in United States District Court to enjoin the Department of Health, Education and Welfare from distributing Medicare funds through the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Hospitals.

title: HARRIS ADDRESSES DEMOCRATS HERE
description: Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma took his new populism campaign for the Democratic nomination for President to New York City and Connecticut yesterday.

title: Cowboys Activate Thomas
description: DALLAS, Oct. 6 (UPI)The Dallas Cowboys activated the controversial running back, Duane Thomas, today, the deadline Pete Rozelle, National Football League commissioner, had given them to take Thomas back or put him on waivers.

title: VARIED PROGRAM OF DANCE IS GIVEN
description: Presenting dance and dancers to the public in a flexible and enjoyable format has been one of the great successes of Choreocancerts & Critiques, which opened its fifth season Tuesday evening, at the New School

title: Chou Tells Americans Mao Made Decision to Invite U.S. Table Tennis Team
description: The following dispatch was written for United Press International by Julian Schuman, an American who has been in China for many years and who works as a translator for a Chinese Government agency in Peking.

title: Soviet Union Taps Big New Gas Field In Southern Urals
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6The Soviet Union announced today the start of operations at a vast new gas field in the southern Urals, further strengthening this country's potential position as a supplier of natural gas for Western Europe.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Protest ATest
description: VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 6 Reuters  Naerly 9,000 elementary and high school students gathered at the United States Consulate here today in a peaceful protest against the planned nuclear test at Amchitka Island in the Aleutions. No serious incident occured at the demonstration, although the police said that a few youths tried to remove an American flag from the consulate building.

title: Stony Brook Gets Grant
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 6 A oneyear planning grant of $49,060 to develop resources and programs in earlychildhood education and day care has been awarded the State University of New York at Stony Brook by the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children.

title: Neinas of N.C.A.A. Gets Chief Post in Big Eight
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 6 (UPI) Charles M. Neinas, assistant executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association for 10 years, was named commissioner of the Big Eight Conference today.

title: RALLY LIFTS DOW BY 9.41 TO 900.55
description: A late rally sent stock prices briskly higher yesterday as traders and institutions took an optimistic view of the Phase Two possibilities of President Nixon's economic stabilization program.

title: Vermeer Recovered After Belgian Theft
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 6 (Reuters) A stolen Vermeer masterpiece, The Love Letter, was recovered today and the alleged thief arrested because of a gasoline pump attendant's curiosity.

title: Film: A Moving 'Sacco and Vanzetti':Lawyers' Statements Have Current Validity
description: On May 5, 1920, two Italian immigrants, Nicola Sacco, a shoemaker, and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, a fish peddler, were arrested by the police of Brockton, Mass., and subsequently charged with responsibility for a South Braintree payroll robbery, three weeks before, that had resulted in two deaths.Seven years later, Sacco and Vanzetti, their convictions upheld, were executed by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts not, according to their defenders, because they had been proved guilty, but because they were admitted anarchists and because they had been transformed into awesome symbols.To middle class, Anglo-Saxon America, they were the Red Menace that Attorney General A. Mitchell Palmer had been ranting against. To Communists, socialists and liberals, as well as to a good many New England church ladies, jurists, newspapermen and students of the democratic processes, their convictions represented what could go wrong with a system that, depending on the point of view, was everything from criminally oppressive to sorrowfully imperfect.If you believe, as I do, that Sacco and Vanzetti were innocent, then you will probably be movedin spite of your better cinematic judgmentby "Sacco and Vanzetti," an Italian film that elects to play on our best prejudices rather than make a reasonable or eloquent plea for truth.It's a measure of just what Giuliano Montaldo, the director, is up to that he frames his movie with an absolutely dreadful soundtrack song, "The Ballad of Sacco and Vanzetti" (one lyric of which goes: "Here's to you, Sacco and Bart/Something something forever in my heart"), sung by Joan Baez, Miss Protest of 1968. Her voice is thus used to certify the movie's noble intentions, but through the cheapest of means.Any film that attempts to cover seven years of complex legal proceedings and social history must, inevitably, condense events and foreshorten perspectives, but Montaldo's simplication takes the form of not particularly stylish political cartooning. This is especially true of the supporting performances he has gotten from Cyril Cusack as Katzman, the prosecuting attorney, and Geoffrey Keen, as Judge Thayer, the judge who presided at the trial and, under Massachusetts law, had the unfortunate right to rule on a second trial when new evidence was presented to him.They are blandly evil, cutout figures, as are all of the intimidated witnesses, bigoted observers and political opportunists who swarm across the film.Milo O'Shea, the Irish actor ("Ulysses"), plays Fred H. Moore, the original defense attorney (who, it's generally agreed, mishandled the case with fatal results), as if he were playing good old Clarence Darrow, with such a large amount of impressive eye-ball rolling that it comes as a complete surprise, late in the film, to learn that he has botched things. But this, I suspect, is just another confusion of the script.Curiously enough, Sacco and Vanzetti themselves, who always remain the most mysterious players in most of the written accounts of their drama, emerge in the film as something like flesh-and-blood characters. This is not because Montaldo and his co-author on the screenplay, Fabrizio Onofri, have taken legitimately bold steps to give them idiosyncratic identities. It is, rather, the result of the screen presence of the two intelligent actors who play them  Gian Maria Volonte (who was so fine in "Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion"), as Vanzetti, and Ricardo Cucciolla, as Sacco.Then, too, each man has an opportunity to speak (at least portions of) those speeches that were originally spoken in the Dedham court, final statements that are so simple and beautiful that it seems as if the English language were still in the process of being discovered, which, of course, it was for the two defendants.Considering the fact that this is an Italian film, it is amazingly free of anachronisms of time and place. Nor was I bothered by the apparently postsynchronized soundtrack; all of the Americans (even when played by non-English-speaking Italian actors) speak English, as do Sacco and Vanzetti, who speak Italian (translated by subtitles) only when talking to each other.Although "Sacco and Vanzetti," which opened yesterday at the Baronet, is not a good movie, I refuse to be put off from it, as have some friends of mine, on the grounds that it's just another left-wing, European blast at the United States. This is beside the point. If only because it calls to our attention a terrible chapter in American history, it can't be easily dismissed. Said the defense attorney, who argued for a new trial for Sacco and Vanzetti: ". . . a government which has come to value its own secrets more than the lives of its citizens has become a tyranny, whether you call it a republic, a monarchy, or anything else."

title: Colleges Get Controllers
description: SYDNEY, Australia (Reuters) The three universities in Sydney have appointed special controllers with power to order undesirables from the campus.

title: TEACHERS TO RETURN AT NASSAU COLLEGE
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 6Teachers at Nassau Community College voted early today to obey a court injunction and teach 15 hours of classes a week, as demanded by the county.

title: NORMAN C. GODFREY, A BANKER ON L.I., 85
description: HICKSVILLE, L. I., Oct. 6Norman C. Godfrey, a director and vice president of the Long Island National Bank since 1936, died today in Syosset General Hospital after a brief illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 505 South Broadway.

title: A Viennese Night at Hunter Concert
description: Short of serving strudel and schlagobers at intermission, the planners of Tuesday night's concert at Hunter College Playhouse could hardly have made it more Viennese. Ernst Maerzendorfer, who conducts regularly at the Vienna State. Opera, led the Vienna Chamber Orchestra in a program of music by composers whom the Viennese claim by adoption, if not by birth. The result was always good, if always less than utterly beguiling, musicmaking.

title: Arlen Realty Reports a Sharp Gain in Its Income
description: The Arlen Realty & Developnient. Corporation, in its report yesterday covering the second fiscal quarter and half year ended Aug. 31, showed a substantial improvement in its results over the first quarter ended May 31.

title: Times Writer Wins Award From Antipollution Group
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 Gladwin Hill, national environmental correspondent of The New York Times, tonight received the Harry E. Schlenz Medal of the Water Pollution Control Federation.

title: F. D. A. to Start an Inventory Of Drug Products Sold in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Food and Drug Administration is ahout to start an inventory of all drug products marketed in the United States for human use.

title: House Debates Amendment to End Sex Discrimination
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The House of Representatives began debate today on a modified version of the equal rights amendment, which is aimed at ending discrimination based on sex.

title: University Computing Set To Acquire 71% Subsidiary
description: The University Computing Company announced yesterday that its board and the board of its 71 per centowned subsidiary, Computer Technology, Inc., had approved a previously reported agreement in principle for the merger of the two concerns.

title: Happy Way and Big Shot II Take Divisions of Manhattan Handicap
description: The Manhattan Handicap at Belmont Park was run in two divisions yesterday. Although scratches reduced the original number of entrants, enough were left in each section of the 1mile turf contest to provide interesting competition for the 20,260 fans.

title: Phase Two Expectations Increase Prices of Bonds
description: The credit markets yesterday afternoon decided that Phase Two of President Nixon's new, economic program  scheduled to be outlined this eveningwill keep interest rates rolling lower. Bond prices rallied and activity picked up speed.

title: Two Mine Union Officials Sentenced for Conspiracy
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 6 (UPI) Two top officials of the United Mine Workers of America District 5 were each sentenced today to one year on probation and fined $500 for conspiracy and falsifying union records.

title: Advertising:
description: From across the barren plain there comes the faroff thunder of thousands of hoofs and then in the distance appears a stampeding herd of cattle that charges right into your living room. The message is there for all to see, Merrill Lynch is bullish on America.

title: AN ATTEMPT TO KILL ARAFAT REPORTED
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 6 (AP)The Palestinian guerrilla leader, Yasir Arafat escaped an assassination attempt today, the Fatah guerrilla group reported. His driver was killed advanced guerrilla bases near the SyrianIsraeli ceasefire line in the Golan heights when his automobile was ambushed, a statement said.

title: A.&P. Tells Crime Inquiry Of Pressure on Detergent
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 Three officials of the A. & P. chain told Congress today that two New Jersey labor leaders had tried repeatedly to have the company buy a detergent made by the North American Chemical Corporation.

title: ELIGIBILITY EASED ON SCHOOL POSTS
description: The Board of Education approved a new policy yesterday that will enable the 31 decentralized school districts to fill acting supervisory posts with personnel who hold state certification but arc not on the city's examinationbased eligibility list.

title: PANAMA INFORMS U.N. OF U.S. TALKS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6Panama has placed her case for a new canal treaty with the United States before the United Nations membership.

title: Bergen Group Pays Tax on Wilderness Acreage
description: WEST MILFORD, N. J., Oct. 6A 3,200acre tract of wilderness in northern New Jersey was saved today from an imminent tax foreclosure action by a group of anonymous Bergen County residents interested in preserving it for public conservation.

title: Prices of Silver Futures Rally; Trading in Soybeans Is Heavy
description: Silver futures prices, which had dropped to new lifeofcontract lows on the Commodity Exchange the day before, rebounded yesterday and closed 1.40 to 1.30 cent an ounce higher. There were only 1,977 sales, however, compared with 2,880 in the previous session.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon appointed Mrs. Constance E. Newman, to run the Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA) program, a major division of Action, an agency that includes the Peace Corps and antipoverty programs.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Some days it seems that everybody is in love with catastrophe. The imminent destruction of the country is forecast casually over hamburgers. Unless, of course, certain conditions are met. I'm telling you here and now that unless something is done, and done quickly, about the quality of hamburger rolls in this country, America is going to be destroyed.

title: Lufhansa to Fly Nonstop To Moscow Under Accord
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 6  Lufthansa, the West German airline, will fly nonstop between Frankfurt and Moscow without landing in West Berlin under an agreement initialed here yesterday, a West German Embassy spokesman said today.

title: HighLevel Table Tennis
description: MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 6 (AP)A French Cabinet minister and a Chinese minister squared off with tabletennis paddles yesterday aboard a Chinese ship in the harbor here. The opponents were Jean Bailly, French Secretary for Commerce, and Pai Hsiangkuo, Chinese Minister of Foreign Trade, who is heading a delegation on a visit to France.

title: Chef Injured as Fire Hits Discotheque on East Side
description: A twoalarm fire at Yellowfingers, a discothque and restaurant at Third Avenue and 60th Street, destroyed the restaurant and three upstairs apartments early today.

title: Safeway Stores Boycotted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The United Farm Workers Union announced today a nationwide boycott of Safeway Stores, the nation's second largest food chain, because of what the union called a deliberate policy of purchasing grapes which are not harvested under union contract.

title: Israel Assails Rogers Plan
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 6Premier Golda Meir tonight rejected some of the basic points for an accord to reopen the Suez Canal outlined by Secretary of State William P. Rogers in his speech to the United Nations General Assembly Tuesday.

title: Subway Strike in Paris Clogs Streets a 2d Day
description: PARIS, Oct. 6The 2,300 motormen who run the city's subway trains have been refusing to do so for the last two days. Negotiations between their unions and the city transit authority were broken off Monday and, as both sides refuse to yield, the public is getting increasingly footsore, hornweary and irritated.

title: One Community Mobilizes Itself to Do The Real Thing: A Project in Ecology
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J.Life is rarely dull in the John Gannon household. The six youngsters, ranging in age from 10 to 21, assorted pets and a host of domestic chores keep things hopping. But in recent weeks, for the Cannons and their neighbors, things have been busier than ever. Mrs. Gannon has been making forays to a local department store to man a booth signing up volunteers for a countrywide ecological project.

title: Fire Destroys Four Sailboats in Mystic Shipyard
description: WEST MYSTIC, Conn., Oct. 6An earlymorning blaze destroyed four sailboats in the 123yearold Mystic Shipyard today, causing $200,000 in damage.

title: KOSYGIN APPROVES CANADIAN ITINERARY
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 6Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union has approved an eightday crosscountry tour of Canada starting in Ottawa Oct. 17, and ending in Toronto on Oct. 25.

title: A Man of Decisions
description: Man in the News

title: Advances Are Reported For BlackOwned Banks
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Andrew F. Brimmer, a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, gave an optimistic report today on recent developments in the nation's 26 blackowned and operated banks.

title: RODNEY'S IMAGE WINS SIRE STAKE
description: WESTBURY, L. L, Oct. 6The first of eight straight rich New York Sire Stakes events to be presented at Roosevelt Raceway between tonight and Oct. 14's closing card was a onemile test for 3yearold trotting fillies bred in this state.

title: DANIEL SMITH JR., RETIRED ADMIRAL
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 6 (AP)  Rear Adm. Daniel F. Smith Jr., known for his exploits as a Navy flier in World War II, died yesterday in the Navy hospital here of heart failure. He was 61 years old.

title: Let Soviet Citizens Emigrate
description: MOSCOWThe trials of recent months have once again reminded us of the tragic conflicts faced by Soviet citizens who wish to emigrate and resettle in another country as well as the legal, social, psychological and political aspects of this problem.

title: Sato Hints at Accord
description: MIYAZAKI, Japan, Oct. 6 (AP)Prime Minister Sato indicated today that Japan is ready to complete a governmenttogovernment agreement with the United States on voluntarily restricting Japanese textile exports to the United Stales.

title: L.I. LaginGrowth Speech Rebutted
description: UPTON, L. I., Oct. 6The executive director of the NassauSuffolk Regional Planning Board today attacked the vice president of the New York Regional Plan Association for myopic manipulation of facts and data In asserting that the growth of Long Island had slowed to the Lowest in the New York metropolitan region.

title: Quebec Police Seize 7
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 6 (AP)The police said today that they had arrested six men and a woman suspected of membership in the extremist Quebec Liberation Front on the anniversary of last year's crisis involving the kidnapping and death of Pierre La Porte, the Quebec Labor Minister.

title: 5 SCHOOL CHIEFS ASK AID TO BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The superintendents of three Southern and two Northern school systems pleaded before a Senate committee today for Federal financial assistance to help pay for the busing of schoolchildren as part of their desegregation programs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Groups Oppose Busing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) Leaders of antibusing groups from 11 cities joined with the Liberty Lobby today in a campaign to outlaw forced transportation of children to integrate schools.

title: Disputed TV Segment on F.B.I. To Co on Channel 13 Tomorrow
description: Channel 13 will televise locally tomorrow the disputed portion of The Great American Dream Machine that the Public Broadcasting Service refused to distribute to the country's public TV stations last night.Selling of the Pentagon and Banks and the Poor, each of which stirred controversy. It may run as long as 90 minutes. The 15minute segment, which had been submitted to and rejected by P.B.S., will include portions of letters received from F.B.I. personnel, among them the bureau's director, J. Edgar Hoover.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Snoopy, Everyfan in dog's clothing, has been denied once again. The National Hockey League season begins tomorrow night. Charles M. Schulz, the creator of Peanuts, said somewhat sadly: Snoopy thinks he's a great player. He's going to be disappointed when he gets to Detroit this year and finds that Gordie Howe has retired Snoopy wanted to give him an oboe.

title: Executive Changes
description: CPC International, the large food company, has named Walther Kniep an executive vice president. Mr. Kniep is president of CPC Europe, an operating division.

title: Sowells Will Start Again for Jets
description: Coach Weeb Ewbank indicated yesterday that Rich Sowells, a rookie, would continue as the starting left cornerback instead of Steve Tannen, who apparently had recovered sufficiently from his ailing knee to play against the New England Patriots on Sunday.

title: AntiNegro Group Vexing Police in Wilmington, N.C.
description: WILMINGTON, N. C., Oct. 6  A new antiNegro organization called Rights of White People, considered by local lawenforcement officials as more dangerous than the Ku Klux Klan, has complicated efforts to halt the civil strife that has beset this port city since last February.

title: MRS. GLENN JOHNSTON
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 6Mrs. Aldeane (Kit) Spikes Johnston, wife of Glenn W. Johnston, executive vice president of Sterling Drug, Inc., died yesterday in New York Hospital of hepatitis. She was 48 years old and lived at 71 Glenville Road.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Injunction on the Docks
description: President Nixon's decision to invoke the TaftHartley Act to halt the strikes that have shut down all Pacific Coast ports and nine Chicago grain elevatorswhile leaving unhalted the tieup in Atlantic and Gulf ports represents at least a small step away from the elastic standards that have operated in the past to determine when an industrial dispute constitutes a national emergency.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by large stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange has not issued a report this week.

title: N.B.C. Decides to Defer Sale of 12 Radio Outlets
description: The National Broadcasting Company decided yesterday not to sell immediately its 12 radio stations, and it named Robert L. Stone to be president of the network's radio division.

title: WEAVER PUTS OFF NAMING A STARTER
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 6 The Baltimore Orioles rested for the World Series today following a oneday scourge of the Bay Area that produced their third straight American League pennant.

title: Zeppelin' Carries Flimsy Tale
description: World War I, a lukewarm conflagration judged by subsequent holocausts and sputteringly rekindled on screen in "The Blue Max" and "Von Richthofen and Brown," is touched off again by "Zeppelin," which arrived at local houses yesterday. This time the storied, giant, silver, cigar-shaped dirigible is carrying a flimsy, lighter-than-air spy tale that wouldn't burden a carrier pigeon.Under the commonplace guidance of Etienne Perier, a Belgian director, Michael York portrays a square-jawed Scots lieutenant with strong family ties in Germany. He is surreptitiously recruited in 1915 to check on those dastardly Zeppelin guys in Friedrichshafen. Marius Goring, as a professor who wouldn't hurt a fly, has developed the LR-36, which can soar above British aircraft and ack-ack and is, therefore, a decided threat.As a man supposedly torn between allegiances to country and family, York is merely tense, even though the climactic shoot-out ends with the Zeppelin down in flames and the Magna Carta and British morale intact.Elke Sommer as the professor's wife and unlikely assistant is pretty but dowdy in vintage get-ups and a brown wig. The rest of the cast is simply athletic."For a spy, you're getting your money's worth," Miss Sommer tells York. An extravagant claim. Shortchanged would be closer to the mark.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Gets a Court Order Halting Coast Dock Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6President Nixon obtained temporary Federal court restraining orders tonight ordering striking longshoremen to return to work on the Pacific Coast and in the Port of Chicago.

title: House Rules Panel Backs Consumer Agency Measure
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (UPI) The House Rules Committee approved unanimously today legislation to create a Federal agency to protect consumers.

title: COMPANY IS FINED IN BUS CHARTERS
description: The Tedesco Bus Company of Jersey City, operator of the chartered bus in which seven Long Island childrend died last year in an accident during an outing to the Pennsylvania Dutch country, has been fined $3,000 for operating illegal charter trips.

title: Watershed Project Backed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) The House Agriculture Committee approved today a small watershed project in Missouri named in honor of the late Representative Clarence Cannon, Democrat of Missouri. The project covers 29,180 acres In Lincoln County and is expected to cost $1,453,000.

title: Safety Law's Enforcement Is Called Lax by Williams
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP)  Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. accused the Nixon Administration today of outrageous indifference to enforcing the new Federal job health and safety law.

title: TROOPS IN GUNFIGHT ON ULSTER'S BORDER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 6 (AP)British troops and Irish guerrillas fought a gunbattle across the border between the Irish Republic and Northern Ireland early today, military headquarters said.

title: Recovery of Mainland Still Taiwan's Stated Goal
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 6Despite the growing international recognition of the government in Peking as the Government of China and President Nixon's plans to visit the Chinese mainland, Chinese Nationalist officials proclaim as regularly as before that their party will succeed in returning to power.

title: President and Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Supreme Court is the most ingenious political institution invented by Americans. It is the highest court of appeal such as all lawful societies have but it is also the third chamber of the national legislature.

title: 5 U.S. MAYORS PAY A VISIT TO GDANSK
description: GDANSK, POLAND, Oct. 6 The question by Detroit's Mayor, Roman S. Gribbs, was simple: Do the workers here share in the shipyard's profits? The reply, by Jan Talaga, assistant personnel director of the Lenin yards, was equally straightforward: Yes.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: One of the more noteworthy big  game angling achievements of the year, the conquering of a 448pound Atlantic blue marlin on 12pound test line, has now entered the record hooks of the International GameFish Association (I.G.V.A.).

title: Chou Host at Banquet For Ethiopian Emperor
description: PEKING, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Emperor Haile Solassic of Ethiopia was given a tumultuous welcome on his arrival today for a state visit and was entertained this evening at a banquet in Peking's Great Hall of the People.

title: FEDERAL RAISES BACKED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 The Senate voted today, 60 to 27, to partly thaw President Nixon's sixmonth freeze on pay increases for Federal employes.

title: Italy's Payments Surplus Rose to Record in August
description: ROME, Oct. 6 (Reuters) The Bank of Italy said today that Italy had a record balanceofpayments surplus in August of 290 billion lire compared with a surplus of 14.4 billion in August, 1970. The lire is the equivalent of 0.16 American cent. The surplus was largely due to a marked increase in tourist revenue and in the trade balance.

title: Occasion Called a Party
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 6Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, reported today that more than 70 people attended a party in Peking last night as guests of Premier Chou Enlai.

title: Eskimo Suit Challenges Alaska On Land Claims and Oil Leases
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) Alaskan Eskimos have laid claim to the entire 76,000squaremile North Slope of their state, including 413,000 acres of oil field already leased to private companies by the state government for almost $1billion.

title: INSOLVENCY NEAR, THANT WARNS U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 6  Secretary General Thant told the Budget Committee of the General Assembly today that the United Nations was, as of now, to a state of near and hopeless insolvency and literally living from hand to mouth.

title: ARGENTINA PUTS CURB ON FOREIGN AIRLINES
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 6 The Government has enveloped the 22 schedule foreign airlines serving Argentina in a financial squeeze that may force some to suspend flights here, according to industry sources.

title: Former P.O.W. Shouts Abuse A. Hirohito During London Ride
description: LONDON, Oct. 6A man who said he had been tortured as a prisoner of war of the Japanese shouted abuse at Emperor Hirohito today as the Japanese monarch drove in an open carriage to a diplomatic reception. The Emperor is in the second day of his threeday state visit to Britain.

title: U.S. SEEN GAINING IN WATER CLEANUP
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 William D. Ruckelshaus, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, estimated today that most of the nation's industrial water pollution had come under regulation in the new Federal licensing program.

title: B52'S BOMB FOE NORTH OF SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Thursday, Oct. 7 (AP)Three Iwaves of B52 bombers pounded enemy positions along the Cambodian border today in a second day of followup raids after a week and a half of frontier fighting.

title: PRESIDENT TO GIVE POSTFREEZE PLAN IN SPEECH TONIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6President Nixon will disclose his plans for Phase Two of the Administration's economic stabilization program tomorrow evening, the White House announced today.

title: Amex Stocks Are Up on a Late Rally
description: A late rally helped send prices up on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in heavier trading.

title: GoodBy to Sampson: I Love You. I'll Miss You
description: WILLARD, N. Y., Oct. 6Sandy Rice adjusted a black armband on her white nurse's uniform this morning and walked down a long, immaculate corridor of the Sampson State School here.

title: New Grill in the Life of Guy Lombardo
description: Guy Lombardo, whose 32year association with the Roosevelt Grill ended eight years ago, now has a new grill in his life.

title: PETER Z. SIVERE
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., Oct. 6Peter Z. Sivere, president of the Hempstead Heath Corporation and for many years in the building field, died at his home here yesterday. He was 68 years old.

title: Luck of a Draw Starts a Kennel
description: News of Dogs

title: Utility to Build Big Unit
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (Reuters)The Commonwealth Edison Company said today it would build Li second 840,000kilowat generating unit at its coalfired Powerton station near Peking Ill., at a cost of more that $100million, exclusive of major expenditures for environ mental control facilities.

title: Viliam Siroky, Former Premier Of Czechoslovakia, 69, Dies
description: PRAGUE, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Viliam Siroky, former Premier of Czechoslovakia, died today after a long illness, the Ceteka news agency reported. He was 69 years old.

title: CITY OFFERS PLAN TO SAVE 30C FARE; GOVERNOR SAYS NO
description: A new plan to save the 30cent transit fare through 1973 by a temporary borrowing of $100million from the transportation bond issue that will be on the ballot Nov. 2was offered yesterday by a coalition of city officials.

title: 5 BODIES IN CAMBODIA SAID TO BE OF TV MEN
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 6 (Agence FrancePresse) five bodies believed to be those of television journalists who disappeared on May 31, 1970, official sources stated here today. The bodies were found about 30 miles south of here, near Route 3.

title: Court Upholds Driver in BreathTest Dispute
description: The refusal of a drunkendriving suspect to submit to a breath test does not justify revocation of his license if the police have turned down his request that his lawyer be present during the test, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: Hearings on Postage Increase End
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6The Postal Rate Commission moved a step closer today toward decling whether to make permanent a temporary $1.45billion rise in the cost of postage.

title: White House Aide Urges Major Changes for TV
description: The White House Office of Telecommunications called yesterday for elimination of the fairness doctrine in radio and television, alteration of the station license renewal process to get the Government out of programing and the beginning of the deregulation of radio.

title: Radio and TV to Carry Nixon Address Tonight
description: President Nixon's speech on the second phase of his economic policy will be carried live at 7:30 P.M. today on radio and television.

title: NATO AIDE TO OPEN TALKS WITH SOVIET
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 6  The North Atlantic alliance today assigned its former Secretary General, Manlio Brosio, to visit the Soviet Union and explore the possibility of talks on EastWest troop cuts in Europe.

title: Rep. James G. Fulton, 68, Dead; Dean of Pennsylvania Delegation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6Representative James G. Fulton of Pennsylvania, a Republican who was serving his 13th term representing a predominantly Democratic district, died tonight, apparently of a heart attack, in the Walter Reed Army Medical Center. He was 68 years old.

title: Mountbatten Meets Emperor
description: LONDON. Oct. 6 (Reuters)Emperor Hirohito of Japan tonight met Earl Mountbatten of Burma, the man who in 1945 accepted the Japanese surrender in Southeast Asia.

title: A Saigon General Told a Lie To Boost His Troops' Morale
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP)Lieut. Gen Nguyen Van Minh, commander of the military region that includes Saigon, said today that he had told a lie to raise the morale of his troops during the recent fighting along the Cambodian border.

title: POLL BACKS CLASSES IN DRIVER TRAINING
description: The vast majority of Americans favor legislation that would make driver education a prerequisite to high school graduation, according to the Gallup poll.

title: GEORGE BLAKE, LED UTILITY IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, Oct. 6George H. Blake, who retired in 1954 as president of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, died today at his home in the Llewellyn Park section of nearby West Orange. He was 87 years old.

title: Delegation Fights Relief Point Setup
description: Leaders of 16 organizations across the state, including the city's Council Against Poverty and Roman Catholic and Protestant welfare agencies, will ask the state government today to withdraw two planned welfare demonstration projects.

title: New Trial Sought for Ray
description: JACKSON, Tenn., Oct. 6 (AP) Lawyers for James Earl Ray, serving a 99year sentence for the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., asked the Tennessee Court of Criminal Appeals today for a new trial for Ray. They were appealing the Feb. 26 decision of Criminal Court Judge William H. Williams of Memphis, who denied the trial request.

title: Red Cross Talks Advance in Korea As North Yields
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 6 The North Korean Red Cross agreed today to a South Korean proposal to hold talks in Seoul and Pyongyang alternately.

title: Eastern College Football
description: National Collegiate Sports Services, that very accurate statistical bureau of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, has proven conclusively that Miami of Ohio produces more college head football coaches per graduate than any other major college in the association. The latest on Miami's growing list is Neil Putnam, who is doing amazing things at Lafayette. The 1958 graduate of Miami has the Leopards off to their best start in 15 years, undefeated and almost ready to play a big, strong unbeaten Delaware team Saturday.

title: CONALCO LOWERS ITS INGOT PRICES
description: The Consolidated Aluminum Corporation announced yesterday that it was posting a new published price of 23 cents a pound for aluminum ingot sharply lower than the 29 cent list price posted by other aluIminum makers.

title: Operation Breadbasket Reaches Agreement With Bohack Chain
description: The Bohack Corporation, which has 168 supermarkets in the metropolitan area, agreed yesterday to hire more blacks, to channel funds into blackowned banks and to place more business with black suppliers over the next six months.

title: SAMUEL KATZMAN
description: Samuel Katzman, president since 1937 of the Dandy Dry Goods Company of 552 Broadway, a wholesale distributor of general merchandise, died Tuesday at the home of his son, Stephen, 155 East 34th Street. He was 68 years old and lived at 10615 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Cemetery Workers Back
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 (UPI)  Cemetery workers went back to work today digging graves for the first of the 1,800 bodies left unburied during a fourmonth strike. Cemetery spokesmen said it would take six weeks to catch up.

title: MetalDetecting Device Leads to Drags Arrest
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (UPI)When Una Cecilia Tutson of San Francisco walked past a metaldetecting device at International Airport here today, her purse touched off an alarm.

title: Embarrassed Ohio Governor, a Democrat, Tangles With Labor on Income Tax
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 6Gov. John J. Gilligan, frustrated by a Republican Legislature and embarrassed by an unexpected attack from organized labor, has refused to sign an interim budget designed to keep the state operating through the end of October.

title: REA EXPRESS SUES 58 MAJOR RAILROADS
description: REA Express, Inc., filed a second suit yesterday in Federal Court here against 58 major railroads that formerly owned the company claiming treble damages of more than $150million.

title: Ocean Hill Board Ratifies Ouster of
description: The community school hoard of District 23 in Brooklyn, which includes the former Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration district, publicly ratified last night its controversial reassignment of two popular acting principals to work in district headquarters.

title: FOES OF THIEU SEEK TO NULLIFY ELECTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct  Opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu today filed a suit in the Supreme Court calling upon the justices to declare last Sunday's oneman Presidential election unconstitutional and to nullify the results.

title: EL SHAFEI UPSETS ASHE, 16, 63, 64
description: VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 6 (AP)  Ismail El Shafei of the United Arab Republic scored an upset yesterday at the start of the $50,000 Rothmans international tennis tournament by I defeating fifthseeded Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., 1.6 63, 64.

title: Black Envoys Visit Pretoria
description: PETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 6 (Reuters)  A threeman delegation headed by the Ivory Coast Minister of State, Blaise N'dia Koffi, arrived in South Africa today for an official threeday visit, marking a new chapter in contacts between black African states and the whiteruled republic.

title: BRITISH ADD CURBS ON INFLOW OF FUNDS
description: LONDON, Oct. 6 (Reuters)Britain today instituted controls to stop a continuing inflow of money that has been pouring into London during the dollar crisis.

title: Chess: Ample Drama Is Provided In PetrosianFischer Play
description: The 12game qualifying match between Bobby Fischer of New York and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, for the right to challenge the world champion, Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union, for the title had plenty of drama in the first two games, which resulted in one victory a piece.

title: The Colonel and the Army
description: After a delay of more than one year, Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke has agreed under Congressional pressure to review the disturbing case of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert. The career of this upfromtheranks professional soldier with an outstanding combat and command record was shattered by a still unresolved conflict between him and his superior officers. At issue is whether Colonel Herbert's efforts, first to stop and then to report atrocities allegedly committed by. American and South Vietnamese military personnel led, as he maintains, to the reprisals against him.

title: Students Burn Truck
description: SAIGON, Thursday, Oct. 7 (Reuters)  Buddhist students burried a Government truck parked outside an American billet here today in violent protest over the reelection of President Nguyen Van Thieu in Sunday's election.

title: Retroactive Benefits Ruled Out For the 90 Days of the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Wageearners whose pay increases were blocked or businessmen whose price increases were negated by the 90day freeze on wages and prices will not be able to regain the lost income, the White House said today.

title: COUNCIL REVOLTS ON TRANSIT PASSES
description: A majority of the City Council threatened yesterday to block any budget modifications proposed by the Lindsay administration until a compromise was reached to provide reducedfare bus and train passes for about 60,000 parochialand publicschool students.

title: Executive Changes
description: Macy's New York announced yesterday the appointment of three new vice presidents. Richard H. Blume has been named vice president and store manager of Flatbush; Edward Korn has been made vice president and general merchandise manager for the Herald Square store and Raymond LaJoie was appointed vice president and general manager for operations and customer service at the Herald Square store.

title: Weekend Cookery
description: In the menu below, dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: RONAN DENOUNCES BEAME FARE PLAN
description: Dr. William J. Ronan, visibly irritated, lashed out yesterday at what he called the Beame scheme to save the 30cent transit fare. Ponzilike, political nonsense, and funny money, were among the terms he used to characterize the plan, advanced by some city officials Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALLEN V. HANSON
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Oct. 7Allen V. Hanson, dean of Rockland Community College, died at his home here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 41 years old and lived at 8 Kevin Drive.

title: Photos Taken by Mao's Wife Are Displayed in Peking Magazine
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 7Chiang Ching, wife of Chairman Mao Tsetung, is disclosed to he a portrait, news and art photographer in the JulyAugust issue of the illustrated Peking propaganda magazine China Pictorial, copies of which are on sale here.

title: CHILEAN HINTS CUT IN LEVY ON MINES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Chile's Foreign Minister hinted strongly today that his Government might reduce by about onehalf the excess profits to be deducted from compensation to United States copper interests for their nationaiized properties in Chile.

title: Incidents Mar Last Day Of Hirohito in Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 7Emperor Hirohito of Japan concluded his threeday state visit to Britain today with a day of sightseeing. Tomorrow he begins a state visit to the Netherlands.

title: I.L.A. Orders Working Longshoremen to Stop
description: The International Longshoremen's Association executive council yesterday ordered more than 30 Gulf Coast locals which have not joined in a sixdayold job action, to cease work immediately on all ships, apparently under the threat of fines or expulsion.

title: Sears Has SecondBest Gain of Fiscal YearPenney Advances
description: Whether it was directly a reflection of public confidence in the Nixon price freeze or not, millions of American consumers sharply increased their buying of goods in department stores in September, sales reports of leading merchandising companies showed yesterday.

title: NO TIME LIMIT SET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7President Nixon announced to night that the present wageprice freeze would be followed by an indefinite period of close Government supervision of the economy to limit prices, wages and rent without direct controls on profits.

title: British Fugitive Captured
description: BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 7 (AP)Britain's most wanted fugitive, 39yearold Frederick Joseph Sewell, was captured in a London apartment today after a 45day hunt and was brought back here to stand trial on charges of having murdered Blackpool's police chief during a holdup of a jewelry store in August.

title: Miss Young Wed to a Stockbroker
description: Miss Brooke Buchanan Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard August Young of Roseburg, Ore., was married here yesterday afternoon to Henry Lyttleton Constable Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Constable of Elkton, Md. The Rev. Ralph Warren Jr. performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church.

description: To the Editor:

description: BONN, Oct. 7Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, has suggested that completion of the Big Four agreement on West Berlin be coupled with West German ratification of goodwill treaties signed last year with the Soviet Union and Poland.

title: CLASH IN CAMBODIA REPORTED BY SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 8 (AP)The South Vietnamese command reported today a new flareup of fighting across the Cambodian border and said allied ground and air forces had killed 50 North Vietnamese soldiers without suffering any losses.

description: The Administration's slightly modified tax bill went through the House like a greased pig. With about thirty Congressmen on the floor to shout aye on a voice votenot a nay was heardthe House voted to cut taxes on corporations and individuals by many billions of dollars.

title: Kosygin in Algeria Pledges Support on Arab Lands
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 7 (AP) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union said today that his nation would continue to give Arab countries all the aid they need to liberate their territory.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) President Nixon made a surprise appearance at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts last night, shortly after broadcasting an address on his economic program.

description: After all the urgency of his Aug. 15 call for national sacrifice to halt the ruinous wageprice spiral, President Nixon has outlined a program that relies heavily on the unwonted continence of labor and industry to cut the inflation rate in half by the end of next Year.

title: NICKLAUS WINS, PALMER LOSES IN BRITISH GOLF
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 7It looked like the old Arnie Palmer. There he was, 1 down and one to go on the par5, 495yard 36th hole against Bob Charles. A drive went into the right rough, a No. 3 wood bounced off a spectator and then a superb recovery wedge struck the heart of the green. Charles had missed his birdie putt. Flamboyantly, Palmer knocked his 20footer into the center of the hole to square, with the crowd in an uproar.

title: Prison Official Stricken
description: WALPOLE, Mass., Oct. 6 (AP)  Corrections Commissioner John J. Fitzpatrick collapsed tonight at Walpole State Prison and was taken to Norwood Hospital, where doctors said he was suffering from fatigue. Mr. Fitzpatrick was at the prison to discuss a work stoppage by the inmates, resulting in their being locked in their cells. Doctors said he was resting comfortably.

title: CAMBODIAN URGES DMZ FOR ANGKOR
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7Cambodia proposed in the United Nations today that the ancient ruins of Angkor, held by Communist forces ince June. 1970, be turned into a demilitarized, neutralized zone under international control to save them from destruction.

title: The Junta Hits Mr. Tasca
description: The threat by Greece's military rulers to bar United States Ambassador Henry J. Tasca from any contact with its political opponents is a striking confession of weakness and insecurity. If former Premier Caramanlis and other leaders both inside Greece and in exile were devoid of any political significance, as the regime claims, why would it bother to try to prevent Mr. Tasca and other foreign ambassadors from seeing them?

title: Sounding the Alarm on the Sahara: Fata Morgana' Bows at the Beaumont 2 Other Movies Open at Theaters Here
description: It says something about our list of priorities for problems that must be tended to (war, poverty, racial discrimination are among the things that come to my mind) that a group of adults could maintain their mannersas did a press-preview audience at Lincoln Center the other daythroughout a documentary that sounds the alarm against man's turning the Sahara Desert into a wasteland.However, Werner Herzog, the young German director of "Fata Morgana," is obviously not suggesting anything as engaged, or as engaging, as a Save-the-Sahara campaign. His film simply uses the Sahara as the background for his own vision of man's compulsion to corrupt and debase himself, as well as the world in which he lives.The vision is a doggerel nightmare that tries, too late, to deny the failed poetic aspirations of its earlier sections by employing the methods of the Cinema of the Ridiculous. In Parts I and II of the film (modestly titled "The Creation" and "Paradise"), we are treated to sometimes lovely images of an unspoiled world  sand dunes, oases, lakes  that eventually become littered wih the debris of civilization  abandoned automobiles, skeletons of ancient war planes, animal carcasses, belching oil refineries, slum villages and whatnot.On the soundtrack there are things like Mozart masses, and a spoken commentary, in German, of something that Herzog identifies as "a 16th Century holy text from Guatemala," which, when translated into English, sounds a good deal like "Hiawatha" as it might be remembered by Andy Griffith.In Part III, "The Golden Age," Herzog goes ridiculous, but with a consistently heavy touch. On the soundtrack there are soft-rock ballads by Leonard Cohen, interspersed with spoken lines such as "Unforgettable is the jump from the lighthouse," or "While you are sleeping, an apple falls from the tree into your bra."At a news conference following the preview screening of his film, Herzog refused to explain the movie on the perfectly legitimate grounds that it should speak for itself, which it certainly doesbut with a slightly forked tongue.The opening shots of the film say everything: we watch, through a zoom lens, what threatens to be an endless sequence as one jet airliner after another comes in for a landing, trailing its polluting exhaust. One, two, three planes land. By the time the sixth or seventh landsthe limits of boredom being what they arewe secretly hope that one will crash. Thus, I'm not sure that Herzog is as interested in sounding alarms as in exploiting our fascination with misery, which is less of an alarm than simply alarming."Fata Morgana," which was shown at the Vivian Beaumont Theater last night, is Herzog's third film to be screened by the New York Film Festival. His "Signs of Life" was at the 1968 festival, and "Even Dwarfs Started Small," a vivid but ponderous allegory about man out of scale with the world he inhabits, was seen last year. "Fata Morgana," which is his most personal, least interesting film, constitutes a persuasive argument for the kind of limitations put on personality by the commercial film industryunfortunately.

title: PayTV for Apartments Is Proposed
description: Introduction of payasyousee television into hotels, motels and major, housing developments with master antenna systems was seen yesterday as auguring a potential new audience for current motion pictures.

Mean while, another major New York banking organization, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, disclosed a 3.6 per cent gain in the JulySeptember quarter, trimming its ninemonth decline to 3.2 per cent.

description: SAN FRANCISCOBy almost anystandard the American prison betrays itself as a system striving toward unmitigated totalitrianism. The logic of totalitarianism defines the prison's internal processes as well as its relationship to the world without.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Nixon Administration formally accepted today the increased tax reductions for individuals, mainly lowincome workers, that the House of Representatives wrote into the tax bill.

description: ROME, Oct. 7The Chamber of Deputies completed legislative action tonight on a new tax system for Italy that had been in preparation for nine years.

title: In the Family' Opens
description: The Whitney Museum, which favored such packages as "Films by Women" in its first series, again is making a valid, collective point in its second season with "In the Family." The program of six short subjects produced by members of four different families, which opened yesterday, will continue through Wednesday.As might be surmised, the selections illustrate, if only obliquely, that blood and talent do mix occasionally with rarely boring effects. This concept is sharply evoked by "Permutations," a fascinating computer-programed animation of dot formations and electronic score by John Whitney Sr., a veteran in this highly unusual field, whose work was represented in "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "Matrix," a short previously at the museum, among other films.And in "Terminal Self," his 25-year-old son, John Whitney Jr., proves that the computer also can be used to create poetic, cloudy shapes and forms that belie their mechanical origin.On the nontechnical side, Robert Frank, the photographer-director lauded for his fine beat generation short, "Pull My Daisy," and his feature documentation of a schizophrenic, "Me and My Brother," moves a viewer with "Conversations in Vermont." As an understated search for communication with his teen-aged son and daughter in a rural, commune-like school, it evokes their past and present with genuine subdued emotion. The youngsters, like their father, emerge as adults groping for love and understanding in a complex world.As counterpoint, Barry Shapiro, a young filmmaker, is less professional, perhaps, than Mr. Frank, but just as tender and realistic in seeking a closer liaison with his father and, incidentally, mother and other relatives in "I Shapiro and Son." One may be left with the idea that you really can't go home againConnecticut, in this case  but Shapiro's documentary inquiry is honest and gives an observer a sharp insight into the not-so-simple people caught by the camera.Unlike these offerings, 29-year-old George Kuchar's "Portrait of Ramona" is an intermittently funny put-on of sex films and soap opera that generates some laughs but seems unfinished despite its nudes and frantic action. Kuchar's twin brother, Mike, who alone or with George previously turned out such locally made satires as "Sins of the Fleshapoids" and "Color Me Shameless," is represented by "Fragments," a collage of fleeting shots of male nudes and sylvan locales that are merely photographically interesting. As a group show, however, "In the Family," makes togetherness edifyingly informative and entertaining.

title: Iran Is Reported to Hold U.S. Woman Without Charge
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 7 (AP) A young American woman is reportedly being held in an Iranian prison without charge because she refuses to betray her friends to the secret police.

title: 4 DEAD, 4 INJURED IN COAST BRUSH FIRE
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 7Four men were burned to death and four others were injured tonight in a brush fire in the hills south of this resort city, the sheriff's office said.

title: Insko Drives 5 Victors At Roosevelt Raceway
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 7Del Insko captured the first four races at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, then added the nonbetting feature, the $45,350 New York Sire Stakes for 3yearolds, for a total of five victories.

title: Beaumont Backers Get a New Chance
description: Lincoln Center's repertory theater supporters were given the opportunity yesterday by the City Council Finance Committee to evolve an alternate plan to the taking over of the Beaumont Theater by the City Center of Music and Drama.

title: Menuhin, at Moscow Music Congress, Calls for Open Emigration
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7Yehudi Menuhin, the American violinist, has appealed in a speech to the International Music Congress here for free emigration of all peoples from all nations and has condemned narrow political nationalism that stifles the creative spirit.

title: Pepsico Sets Records in Net and Volume for 12 and 36 Weeks
description: Pepsico, Inc., had record sales and earnings in the 12 and 36week periods ended Sept. 4, it was reported yesterday by the maker of soft drinks, snack foods and sporting goods. The company, also engaged in the moving of household goods, mobile homes and building materials as well as in leasing and financing services, said the third quarter was the best quarter so far this year.

title: Missouri Senators and Governor Endorse Muskie Bid
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Missouris' top three Democrats endorsed Senator Edmund S. Muskie for their party's Presidential nomination today, nine months before the National Convention opens in Miami Beach.

title: Solzhenitsyn May Get Medal
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 7 (UPI)Nobel Prize officials here said today that Mr. Solzhenitsyn, winner of last year's prize for literature, may receive the medal in Mscoow.

title: Miss Vivien Stiles Is Married To Vincent R. Duffy in Jersey
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., Oct. 7In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church here today Miss Vivien de Fay Stiles, who is assistant to Andrew Heiskell, chairman of Time Inc., was married to Vincent Robert Duffy, vice president for corporate marketing and a director of Overseas National Airways in New York. The noon ceremony was performed by Msgr. Joseph R. Brestel, Vicar General of the Diocese of Paterson.

title: INQUIRY ON CRIME TOLD OF BOMBINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Congressional testimony of New York City police department detectives today linked a man suspected of having fire bombed A. & P. food stores with a crime family that had business dealings with the North American Chemical Corporation.

title: Falstaff Acquisition Of Narragansett Cleared
description: The Federal District Court in Providence, R.I., yesterday ruled that the $19.5million acqusition of the Narragansett Brewing Company by the Falstaff Brewing Corporation in 1965 did not violate antitrust laws. The Justice Department had sought to compel Falstaff to divest Itself of Narragansett, a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Dock Union Tells Members to Return
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. (AP)The West Coast longshoremen's union today ordered its 15,000 striking dock workers to return to work tomorrow in response to a Federal court order.Supporting affidavits cited the devastating effects of the walkout on the nation's economy. It is estimated the strike had cost affected states more than $1.7billion.

title: Four Dogs Are Killed in Plunge From the 15th Floor of a Hotel
description: Detectives of the West 68th Street squad were investigating yesterday the circumstances under which four dogs plunged more than a dozen stories to their death from a West Side building early Wednesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Amex Gets Black Member
description: Daniels & Bell, the first blackcontrolled member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that one of its principals, Travers Jerome Bell Jr., had been approved as an associate member of the American Stock Exchange. This marked the first time that a black had achieved such membership.

title: Pakistan Censors an ExOfficer Who Plans Election Race in East
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 7A former commander of the Pakistani Air Force announced here yesterday that his party would contest forthcoming byelections for National Assembly seats in East Pakistan, but his announcement was censored from the local press.

title: Jackson Defends Candidacy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Senator Jackson said today that his candidacy would be successful even if it should lead to establishment of a fourth party on the left.

title: CLOSER CONTROLS ON PENSIONS SEEN
