description: William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, delcared here last night that the Federal Government was likely to extend its supervision of private pension plans.

title: One of Panther 21 Admits Helping Antipolice Sniper
description: One of the original Panther 21 defendants pleaded guilty, yesterday to a charge that he had aided a sniper who fired, shots at patrolmen on Jan. 17, 1969. The charge that a sniper had fired at the police was a key element of the indictment against 13 other Panter defendants who were acquitted last May.

title: Highlights of Phase Two
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Following are highlights President Nixon's program to limit inflation to an annual rate of 2 to 3 per cent:

title: I.T.T. Unit Gets U.S. Order
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday that its ITT Defense Communications division has received on $8.1million contract from the Air Force for radar data communications equipment.

title: Some New Twists For Luxury Furs
description: Two of New York's most prestigious custom furriers, Anna Maximilian Potok and Emeric Partos, showed their glamorous collections this week.

title: DELAY IN U.S. RAISE UPHELD BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Responding to Administration pleas, the Senate voted, 51 to 32, today to uphold President Nixon's postponement of a Federal pay increase until next year.

title: U.S. Asks Reds at Paris Talks For Data on Dead Prisoners
description: PARIS, Oct. 7William J. Porter, chief United States negotiator at the Vietnam peace talks here, today asked members of the Communist delegations for information about American prisoners known to be dead in Vietnam.

title: STAR ENVOY FIRST ON BELMONT GRASS
description: A closing rush by Star Envoy enabled Lloyd Miller's 3yearold colt to take the feature event at Belmont yesterday. With Jorge Tejeira in the saddle, Star Envoy carved out the margin of a head over Jungle Cove, with Space Bid next in the field of 10 that competed in the 1 116mile turf contest.

title: 539920 Wins in Jersey
description: HIGHTSTOWN, N.J. Oct. 7 (UPI)The winning number in today's weekly staterun lottery is 539920.

title: Saigon Set to Announce Tough New Taxing Policies
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7The Government today was reported planning to announce soon a series of economic reforms intended to strengthen the South Vietnamese economy and reduce its dependence on American aid.

title: Help for the Aged
description: A voluntary, nonprofit member hospital of the United Hospital Fund took steps recently to help the aged in its areaan area in which the concentration of persons aged 65 or older is twice the national average. Many of the aged residents of the Brooklyn neighborhood are unaware of such benefits as Social Security and Medicaid.

title: Wholesale Prices Decline First Time in 10 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Wholesale Price Index, which can foreshadow trends in retail prices by a month or more, declined in September, the Labor Department reported today.

title: NIEPORTE TAKES MET. GOLF BY MOT
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 7Tom Nieporte, who gained national prestige as the first home club golf professional to win the Bob Hope Classic in 1967, won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship by one stroke today. The 41yearold Nieporte, from the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, moved into the 54hole lead this morning after a 67, that gave him a total of 210. Then in the gusty cold wind that swept the Sunningdale Country Club course this afternoon, he scored a 73 for 72hole aggregate of 283.

title: SOYBEANS GAIN; GRAINS SLUGGISH
description: The invoking by President Nixon of the provisions of the TaftHartley Act in the longshoremen's strike on the West Coast and in a grain elevator handlers' dispute in Chicago affected commodities prices on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.

title: The Edge of Confusion: Will Housewife Find Washday Answer?
description: The greatest and possibly the longestrunning soap opera of them all, appropriately enough, stars the typical housewife. The question it poses is does Ms. America care more about a dazzlingly clean wash that will set her neighbors to pouting or is she more concerned with halting the pollution of the environment?

title: Annapolis Awakens to Sailboat Show
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 7 In this quiet Chesapeake Bay community where they say that unless you're in the Navy nothing ever happens, something started happening today. The United States Sailboat Show opened for a fiveday run.

title: More Comprehensive Colleges Urged by Carnegie Commission
description: The Carnegie Commission on Higher Education, predicting an increase in college enrollment of 59 per cent by 1980, called yesterday for the establishment of 80 to 105 comprehensive, largely undergraduate colleges but said there was no need whatsoever for more researchtype universities granting the Ph.D.

title: THE POST FORESEES FISCAL PROBLEMS
description: Mrs. Dorothy Schiff, publisher of The New York Post, met earlier this week with leaders of newspaper unions and warned them of possible financial problems next year for the newspaper.

title: 2 Officers Are Named By U.S.China Group
description: The appointment of Carl F. Stover as president and Everett Case as treasurer of the National Committee on United StatesChina Relations was announced yesterday by Prof. Alexander Eckstein of the University of Michigan, the committee's chairman.

title: Gains in Productivity Essential to a Stable Economy
description: Productivity gains are not a certain cure for all the problems afflicting the American economy. But if the United States is to regain reasonable price stability and become more competitive in world trade, rising productivity is essential.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Look to Stars, Says School Chief
description: Educators and guidance counselors should use every art and science, including astrology, to know their pupils better, predict behavior and individualize instruction, Isaiah E. Robinson, the president of the city Board of Education, said yesterday.

title: Nets Release Ogden
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 7 (AP)  Bud Odgen, a 6foot6inch forward recently dropped by the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association, was released today by the New York Nets of the American Basketball Association. Odgen spent two years with the 76ers.

title: TELEVISION PLANS IRK RACING CHIEFS
description: Monticello Raceway's television contract with the Offtrack Betting Corporation brought an angry reaction yesterday from Robert A. Glasser, chairman of the State Harness Racing Commission.

title: Padres Rehire Gomez
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 7 (AP)The San Diego Padres today rehired Manager Preston Gomez and appointed Don Zimmer, a Montreal coach this season, as an aide to Gomez for the 1972 season.

title: ERVIN'S AIDES SEEK DATA ON TV DISPUTE
description: Aides of Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, said yesterday that they had informally asked National Educational Television for details of its dispute with the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: MUSKIE CRITICIZES NIXON ON DELAYS
description: PATCHOGUE, L. I., Oct. 7Senator Edmund S. Muskie criticized the. Nixon Administration tonight for what he termed the politics of postponement of solutions to problems of the economy, the environment and the war in Vietnam.

title: Bingo!
description: ALBANY, Oct. 7 (AP)Last year 23,071,432 New York State residents spent $124,999,915 in 92,568 sessions of bingo, the State Bingo Commission reported today. No matter what the economic climate may be, Ira M. Ball, chairman of the Bingo Control Commission said, bingo seems to keep rolling right along.

title: More Insurance for Same Price Due Air Travelers, State Says
description: Purchasers of airtrip insurance at all airports in New York now will be able to get about $12,000 in coverage for just 25 cents, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday. At present, 25 cents will buy about $7,500 worth.

title: HUNTER CLASS LED BY QUIET PLEASE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 Rod Jenkins, whose mounts had won 30 assorted ribbons before starting his day's work, collected four more blues today at the Philadelphia Horse Show.

title: Jobless Drop Hinted
description: ENID, Okla., Oct. 7 (AP)Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today that an announcement was imminent that there has been a decrease in unemployment nationally since President Nixon froze wages and prices. Mr. Stans, in a news conference before the President disclosed his plans for the postfreeze period, said an announcement tomorrow would show some decrease in unemploymentI don't know how much. The last national unemployment rate issued in September for August stood at 6.1 per cent.

title: CANCER BILL BACKER IN HOUSE IS BUOYED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Representative Paul Rogers of Florida, the chief sponsor of a House bill to expand research against cancer, expressed confidence today that his version would prevail over efforts to make it conform to a bill already passed by the Senate.

title: EDUCATION CHIEF CRITICIZES HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The United States Commissioner of Education, Sidney P. Marland Jr., criticized the House today for what he termed the cautious conservatism of its proposed higher education bill.

title: Yeshiva Ousts 3 Black Jews as NonOrthodox
description: Three black Jewish boys have been dropped by Yeshiva Rabbi Chaim Berlin in Brooklyn's East Flatbush section because of questions about their Orthodoxy. A committee of the religious school's board raised the questions suddenly after two years.

title: Susan Starr Shows Her Typical Vigor In Piano Program
description: Susan Starr achieved considerable fame a decade ago as a prize winner in two major international piano competitions, the Mitropoulos in New York and the Tchaikovsky in Moscow. Yet it wasn't until 1966 that the Philadelphia artist gave her first solo recital here, in Carnegie Hall, and it wasn't until Wednesday night that she played here again, also a recital in Carnegie Hall.

title: Victor Louis Asserts Soviet Will Oust Britons in Reprisal
description: LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP)  A Soviet journalist predicted today that Moscow Would expel a number of British diplomats within 48 hours in reply to the ouster of 105 Russians last month.

title: New Units to Govern Wages and Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 President Nixon has expanded on the machinery used to administer his wageprice freeze and added several elements to form a new structure to administer the controls of his postfreeze program.

title: Israel Bars 21 U.S. Black Israelites
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 7  Twentyone black Americans who wanted to join the Black Israelite community in the Negev were turned out of Israel today.

title: MEANY VIEW A KEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 Business leaders gave preliminary support tonight to President Nixon's announced plans for the next phase of his economic program, but the reaction of labor appeared uncertain.

title: Advertising:
description: The Advertising Council and SSC&B have run into a major problem in their planned campaign on behalf of American prisoners of war in Southeast Asia. They can't get the copy cleared by the television networks.

title: Fudge for Lunch
description: The Administration is demonstrating a remarkable capacity for missing the point of the school lunch program. Congress has repeatedly made clear that it wants the lowincome children of the nation to have lunches available to them, but the Department of Agriculture, looking at budgets instead of children, keeps resisting the intent of Congress. Last week the Senate voted direct the Agriculture Department to reimburse the states more generously than the department's formula announced last summer would allow. Overruling its own Appropriations Committeea rare gesture in itselfthe Senate authorized the temporary use of other departmental funds to expand the lunch program.

title: Rucker Is Eager to Show Cowboys Their Loss Is Giants' Gain
description: Sometimes, Reggie Rucker admits, he feels a little strange werking out with the Giants, who are currently plotting ways to sock it to his exteammates on the Dallas Cowboys next Monday night. Sometimes he even feels a little like a spy. But most of all he just feels good being in New York.

title: Knicks Down Lakers, 126114
description: About the only object of concern for the New York Knickerbockers at Madison Square Garden last night as they thumped the Los Angeles Lakers, 126114, in the second game of a National Basketball Association preseason doubleheader was expressed by Walt Frazier.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON PHASE 2 HOPES
description: The stock market's Phase Two Rally, carrying over from the late rise on Wednesday, rolled along in anticipation yesterday. But the recovery was strongest in the opening hour and turned relatively mild by the closing bell.

title: Pitfalls
description: WESTPORT, Conn.In purest innocence I set out to buy a book of traditional nursery rhymes for one of my granddaughters, an innocence witlessly carried over from the years when I spent many happy times reading those same nursery rhymes to my children.

title: Cost of Living Council Aide To Resign at End of Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) Arnold R. Weber, the chief fulltime policymaker of the wageprice freeze, said today that he would resign as executive director of the Cost of Living Council when the freeze expires midnight, Nov. 13.

title: Paris Seen Moving To Normalization With East Germany
description: PARIS, Oct. 7  The French Government is slowly moving toward a normalization of relations with East Germany, according to the president of the National Assembly's Foreign Affairs Committee.

title: Bank of Ireland Opens Office
description: The Bank of Ireland, largest in that country, opened a representative office here yesterday in the Seagram Building, 375 Park Ave., headed by J. Patrick O'Hara.

title: MRS. NORMAN BINGHAM
description: Mrs. Ethel Prescott Stetson Bingham, widow of Norman W. Bingham, former president of the Boston Bar Association, died Wednesday in the Sweetbrook Nursing Home in Williamstown, Mass. She was 92 years old and had lived in West Newton, Mass.

title: Fischer Draws With Petrosian; Score in Match Now 1 Each
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 7Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union drew the third game of their match in 34 moves tonight at the Teatro San Martin here.

title: Nixon Reads 4 Letters Supporting the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  President Nixon departed from the text of his economic speech to the nation tonight to read from four letters he said were among thousands he had received from people who supported his wageprice freeze.

title: Illegal Alien Reported As Gardener for Nixon
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 (UPI) A Mexican who entered the country illegally got a job as a gardener for President Nixon, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE OFF FROM '70 LEVEL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Oct. 2 was below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Bayh Cancels Florida Trip
description: WASFIINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, has canceled a political trip to Florida, saying that his wife, Marvella, has entered a hospital here for emergency major surgery,

title: 800 Seoul Students Protest
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7 About 800 students of Korea University here clashed with riot policemen today during a brief street demonstration protesting a predawn raid by soldiers on their school campus on Tuesday. The students charged that some 40 soldiers stormed into the school at 1:30 A.M. and took away five students.

title: Biggie Munn Suffers Stroke
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 7 (UPI)  Clarence (Biggie) Munn, athletic director of Michigan State, suffered a stroke today and was hospitalized in critical condition. The 63yearold former coach was discovered sitting in his car in a parking lot outside Jenison Fieldhouse.

title: Agnew Blames Convicts
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 7  Vice President Agnew said this afternoon that in his opinion the violence at Attica had been caused by the convicts, without question.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)  The White House said tonight that the President quoted from letters from James L. Griffith of Wantagh, N.Y.; Mrs. Robert J. Fuxa of Pampa, Tex.; William F. Speers of Klamath Falls, OM., and Virginia Jones of Woodbury, N.J.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Today is the 54th birthday of Danny Murtaugh, Pittsburgh's merry managerial imp. This entitles him to blow out the conflagration of candles on his birthday cake and make a wish. Such wishes are supposed to be kept secret, but everyone knows what Danny's wish will be. It will be that his Pirates beat the Orioles in the World Series that begins in Baltimore on the morrow.

title: Sovereignty and SALT
description: If Henry Kissinger and the President he advises were committed to guarding the sovereign independence of this nation at all costs, nothing could be more conducive to the stabilizing of international relations at this time than Strategic Arms Limitations Talks with the Soviet Union.

title: Surgery Slated for Laker
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 (UPI)  Keith Erickson will be lost to the Los Angeles Lakers from four to six weeks because of surgery on his right knee; the National Basketball Association club said today. Erickson will be operated on Oct. 14, to remove a cyst from a tendon.

title: Postal Service Names Aide
description: WASHINGTON, (Oct 7 (AP) Maj. Gen. Robert H. McCutcheon, retired Air Force officer, has been appointed Assistant Postmaster General for Administration, the Postal Service announced today. He is 53

title: ACCOUNTANT GUILTY IN $750,000 FRAUD
description: A certified public accountant was convicted last night of helping his son carry out a scheme that used chauffeured limousines, expensive suites, lavish entertainment and a private jet plane to create an aura of affluence for a fraudulent investment operation.

title: TEXTILES ACTION ANGERS KOREANS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 7President Nixon is making a great mistake by trying to make South Korea a victim of next year's American election campaign, a South Korean industry leader asserted today, in reaction to a United States move to curb sharply its textile imports.

title: Approval Indicated For Steel Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (Reuters)Treasury Secretary John B. Connally indicated to the Senate Finance Committee today that both he and the Administration had no objection to the Aug. 16 merger of the National Steel Corporation and the Granite City Steel Corporation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Border Incidents Stall Vorster's Bid for Talks
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 7Diplomats here say that incidents in the dense bush of the remote Caprivi Strip have set back efforts of the South African Government to get into a dialogue with black African states.

title: Nixon Praises Rep. Fulton; Funeral Set for Monday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)President Nixon today called Representative James G. Fulton of Pennsylvania a great civicminded man who will be especially remembered for his unfailing support of our space program.

title: Mysteries of the East Off Central Park
description: A hotel busboy opened the door of the Elizabethan Room a crack and satisfied himself that the 73 guests were comfortableshoeless, reclining on their backs on the floor like scattered kindling, and listening to a light drumbeat that punctuated the hum of the airconditioning.

title: Mrs. Leatrice Pendray, 66, Dies; Early Researcher on Rocketry
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 7 (UPI)Mrs. Leatrice M. Pendray, an early rocket experimenter, a syndicated columnist and a publicrelations executive, died today at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. She was 66 years old.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARIS  Secretary Rogers has devised a subtle formula to solve the issue of Chinese admission to the United Nations in a way that Should eventually prove acceptable to both Chinas and most other governments.

title: 10 Members Are Added To Productivity Panel
description: President Nixon named 10 new members yesterday to the expanded National Cornmission on Productivity, a group he organized with 23 members in June, 1970. Its function is to suggest ways to improve industry's efficiency by increasing the output of workers and, in so doing, help in the fight against inflation.

title: Hughes Gets Missile Contract
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company has received a $32.4million addition to a previously awarded Navy contract for Phoenix air  toair missiles, it was announced yesterday.

title: American Delegation at Synod of Catholic Bishops Says the Church Must Confront Racism and War
description: ROME, Oct. 7The American delegation to the Synod of Roman Catholic Bishops issued a statement today listing racism and the ongoing armaments race among the powerful nations of the world as major problems for the church.

title: Theater: McNally's Tommy Flowers
description: There is much that is likable, even lovable about Where Has Tommy Flowers Gone?, which opened last night at the Eastside Playhouse. But the play seems to have gone with Tommy Flowers, and the audience is left with a collection of sensitively attuned revue sketches, some of them amusing and some quietly touching.

title: LEADER AT ATTICA FACES TRIAL HERE
description: Herbert X. Blyden, who emerged as a leader of rebelling inmates in both the Attica Correctional Facility last month and the Tombs in Manhattan a year ago, will be transferred from Attica to the Tombs within the next few days, City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath said yesterday.

title: Soldiers Shoot Gunman
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 7 (Reuters)British solders tonight shot a gunman on a roof in the mixed Roman CatholicProtestant Springfield Road district of Belfast.

title: Proxmire Homes Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, introduced today a bill to alow the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration to insure prefabricated homes on the same basis as mobile homes.

title: Pollution Drive Leader
description: Man in the News

title: Yen Revaluation: The Debate ls How, Not If
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7Despite recurring rumors that the yen will soon be revalued, Japan's senior business leader said today that it was impossible to predict when, how or by how much the parity of the yen will be increased.

title: Democratic Reformers and Old Guard Split Over Filling '72 Convention Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7A, major internal contest broke out among Democrats today over the selection of a temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for next year's National Convention.

title: Boothe Arranges Financing
description: The Boothe Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had completed arrangements for a $52million unsecured term credit with 14 banks headed by the Bank of America.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Books of The Times
description: A few years before he died, I met Dylan Thomas on the corner of Seventh Avenue and Bleecker Street. We were both on our way to the Cherry Lane Theater, where he was to give a reading of his poems. He was with Oscar Williams, who introduced us, and timidly, because I was awed by Thomas, I asked him why he never read any of his earlier works. I named my three favorites: If my head hurt a hair's foot, Light breaks where no sun shines and After the funeral. He pondered this for a moment, then said: You know, I think I will. During the reading, even he seemed unusually moved, and you might almost say there wasn't a dry eye in the house. To each of us in the audience it seemed as if Thomas had arrived in the nick of time, bringing us a message we badly needed. He was like a downpour after a long drought; we were parched with the poetry of our time.

title: J.D.L. SUING U. S. ON WIRETAPPING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7  In an unusual civil suit, 16 officers and associates of the Jewish Defense League charged the Department of Justice today with illegal wiretapping and asked for a minimum of $732,800 in damages.

title: Congressman's Death Halts Action on Women's Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) House action on a proposed constitutional amendment designed to guarantee women equal rights with men was postponed today because of the death of a Congressman.

title: State Committee Is Named To Propose Penal Changes
description: A 15member state committee assigned the task of recommending improvements in the state's penal system was named yesterday by Governor Rockefeller and the legislative leaders of both parties.

title: Luna 19 Still in Orbit
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7The Soviet Union announced today that its latest mooncraft, Luna 19, continued to circle the moon, but it did not disclose the craft's objectives.

title: 17,626 LANDLORDS ACCUSED OF LYING
description: Almost half the landlords in the city applying for increases in rentcontrolled apartments have certified falsely that there are no violations in their buildings, according to inspectors who checked on them.

title: Patriots' Polyturf Sounds Softer, So Jets Will Retain Cleats
description: The foot (as in football) suddenly is undergoing closer scrutiny by the New York Jets as an outgrowth of their winning effort against the Dolphins in Miami last Sunday.

title: John Kroese Sr., Financier And Owner of Race Horses
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Oct. 7.John S. Kroese Sr., financier, and racehorse owner, died yesterday at the Manor Nursing Home. He would have been 82 years old tomorrow.

title: Jury Opposes Deadly Force to Quell Prison Riots
description: The Queens grand jury, in a report yesterday on last year's prison rebellion in Long Island City and Kew Garden's, opposed the use of deadly force in putting down such outbreaks, even where there are hostages, except when lives are taken or threatened.

title: Northern California Begins Sending Water to South
description: GRAPEVINE, Calif., Oct. 7 Water began moving today over the Tehachapi mountain range that separates frequently flooded northern California from arid southern California and the state's controversial multibilliondollar water project passed a milestone.

title: Red Smith and Anderson Join Daley As Sports Columnists for The Times
description: Red Smith and Dave Anderson will join Arthur Daley as regular sports columnists for The New York Times, A. M. Rosenthal, managing editor, announced yesterday.

title: Bridge: Making 3 NoTrump Contract Is Just a Matter of Position
description: An episode that is surely unique in the history of the game occurred a week ago Thursday on the final deal of the men's pair championship at the New YorkNew Jersey Regionals at Swan Lake, N.Y.

title: Notes on People
description: At his inauguration as the I 3th president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner said one of his prime aims would be to reconcile humanists and technologists there.

title: F.C.C. UPHOLDS CITY ON CABLE TV RULE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7The Federal Communications Commission upheld today New York City's plans for the local regulation of cable television. Henceforth, the F.C.C. said, cable companies will not be allowed to use leased telephone lines as a means of avoiding the city's franchising authority over the construction of cable systems.

title: Details of the President's Program for the Second Phase of WagePrice Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7Following is the text of an explanation of President Nixon's program for the second phase of wageprice controls, issued tonight by the White House:

title: MOSCOW AND HANOI SIGN NEW AID PACTS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP)The Soviet Union has signed new military and economic aid agreements with North Vietnam, Tass announced tonight.

title: A Policy of Persuasion
description: News Analysis

title: Nuptials in Jersey For Miss Davanzo
description: ROSELAND, N. J., Oct. 7Miss Rosemary Bette Davanzo was married here today to Noel Taylor, president of Taylor Travel Tours of New York. Msgr. Edward Fleming, assisted by the Rev. Mark Confroy, performed the ceremony in the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: Harvey Chalmers 2d Dead; Industrialist and Novelist
description: AMSTERDAM, N. Y., Oct. 7 (AP)Harvey Chalmers 2d, industrialist and historical novelist, died last evening, apparently of a heart attack, while fishing near here. He was 81 years old.

title: Joseph Francis Klein Marries Mrs. Tourney
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 7Mrs. Eileen Cole Tourney of Glen Cove, widow of William H. Tourney, was married here this evening to Joseph Francis Klein, a widower, of Flushing, Queens. The Rev. William Penny, Vice Canon of the Long Island Episcopal Diocese, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral of the Incarnation.

title: Ireland Ends Her Support For U.S. on China in U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 7Ireland signaled today that she would no longer support the American effort to save Nationalist China's seat in the United Nations.

title: Suez Stalemate
description: Although he did not close the door to further discussion, Egyptian Foreign Minister Riad's statement to the United Nations this week did nothing to encourage Secretary of State Rogers' hopes for promoting an interim agreement between Egypt and Israel to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN REPORTS RISE IN NET
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Inc., a leading publicly owned investment concern, announced yesterday that it had earnings of $5.04million, or 66 cents a share, in the nine months ended Sept. 30, up sharply from the yearearlier $1.4million, or 19 cents a share.

title: Commodity Price Index Unchanged From WeekAgo
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials remained unchanged from 106.8 last week.

title: Italian Prince Weds Commoner in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran (UPI)Prince Victor Emanuel of Savoy, 34yearold son of the last King of Italy, today married Marina Doria, 36, Swiss biscuit heiress and a former world water  skiing champion. They had been engaged for 11 years.

title: CITY IS CRITICIZED AS A SLUM OWNER
description: The Legal Aid Society and Queens Legal Services have complained to Washington that the city has failed to provide heat, hot water and other vital services in slum tenements that it owns.

title: A 3Day Holiday Due For Many in the City
description: This weekend will be threeday holiday for many New Yorkers as a result of a Federal law enacted more than two years ago. Columbus Day, formerly celebrated on Oct. 12, was shifted to the second Monday in Octoberthis coming Monday.

title: United Inns Offering
description: United Inns, Inc., announced yesterday at Memphis the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of 366,258 shares of common stock, of which 150,000 shares will be sold by the company and the balance by certain stockholders. United Inns operates motor inns under Holiday Inns licenses in a number of states.

title: Chicago Observes 100th Anniversary Of Fire that Destroyed Most of City
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 7Chicagoans take an enormous pride in having the biggestthe biggest hotel in the world, the biggest apartment house in America, the country's biggest exhibition hall. And tomorrow they are even proudly marking the 100th anniversary of a disasterthe Great Chicago Firethe biggest and most destructive conflagration in America's history.

title: City Officials Report Substantial Progress in Plans to Save Yankee Stadium
description: The city's plan to buy and renovate Yankee Stadium and spruce up the Bronx neighborhood around it has been substantially completed. The Lindsay administration is trying to convince the City Council that the proposal will earn, not cost, money.

title: Paintings by Mondrian Shown at Guggenheim
description: In the history of modern art, the Dutch painter Piet Mondrian (18721944) occupies a very special place. Though hardly alone in initiating the turn toward a purely abstract art, Mondrian carried this radical tendency to its most exacting realization. He did so, moreover, at a time when the highly specialized means he employed the reduction of pictorial structure to right angles and primary colorsseemed to many followers of modern painting little more than willful eccentricity.

title: Books of The Times
description: KENNEDY JUSTICE. By Victor S. Navasky. 482 pages. Atheneum, $10.

title: Long Scores Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (UPI)  Senator Russell B. Long, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today that Mrs. Banuelos should not be entitled to put her signature on every dollar bill as Treasurer of the United States if she hired illegal aliens.

title: Soviet Fleet Sails Before Pact To Protect Whales Is Ratified
description: TOKYO, Oct. 7Three Soviet whaling fleets sailed for the Antarctic Ocean this week, just in time to thwart for another season a 21year effort by conservationists to protect threatened whale species by using international observers,

title: Shell to Centralize Units
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 7 Reuters)The Shell Oil Company announced today that it will centralize almost all of its major research activities at Houston, its new headquarters city.

title: COLGATE ENTERS TALKS ON KENDALL
description: Merger News

title: McNally to Open Series for Orioles Tomorrow Against Ellis of Pirates
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 7Dock Ellis flew into Baltimore with the rest of the Pittsburgh Pirates today and, unlike his last trip to San Francisco, all he changed was his room.

title: Rangers Top Bruins in Final TuneUp
description: BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP)Jim Neilson and Bruce MacGregor scored goals 33 seconds apart early in the first period tonight and the New York Rangers went on to a 53 exhibition game victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: Advertising: Detroit Agency Opens N.Y. Doors
description: Burton Sohigian, Inc., which claims to be the fastest growing agency in Detroit (and maybe in the whole Midwest), this morning opens the doors of its first New York office.

title: Many Top Executives Approve of Phase 2 Plans
description: Many of the nation's leading business executives voiced broad approval last night for Phase 2 of the Administration's economic program, but there was some dissatisfaction, mainly over the uncertainties left by the President's speech.

title: WALSTON DRAWS PENALTIES BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday in Washington that it had charged Walston & Co., one of the nation's largest brokerae houses, with violations of the registration and antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.

title: Jewish Group Opens $30Million Campaign
description: With pledges of more than $4million, the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York started its campaign last night for $30million to support 130 socialservice and medical institutions.

title: CHICANO LEADERS UPSET OVER RAID
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7Many MexicanAmerican leaders were deeply troubled today about the controversy surrounding Mrs. Romana A. Banuelos, the local business woman President Nixon has nominated to be Treasurer of the United States.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Pay Increase Delay
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) Following is the rollcall vote by which the Senate defeated today a resolution to override President Nixon's order postponing a Federal pay raise for six months:

title: Sir Humphrey de Trafford, British RaceHorse Owner
description: BOYSTON, England, Oct. 7 (AP)Sir Humphrey de Trafford, a British racehorse owner whose horse, Parthia, won the 1959 Epsom Derby, died yesterday at the age of 79. He had been ill for some months.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Festival:
description: The ads say that the time is just right for an out and out thriller like this, and I guess that you are supposed to think that a good old kind of movie has none too soon come around again. But The French Connection, which opened yesterday at Loew's State 2 and Loew's Orpheum, is in fact a very good new kind of movie, and that in spite of its being composed of such ancient material as cops and crooks, with thrills and chases, and lots of shoot 'em up.

title: Growth of Money Slows
description: The rate of expansion in the nation's money supply has continued to slow markedly in the last few weeks, the regular weekly report from the Federal Reserve System showed yesterday.

title: Bond Prices Are Steady;
description: The credit markets, waiting to hear President Nixon outline Phase Two of his antiinflation effort, held their ground yesterday. Bond prices were little changed and trading activity slackened.

title: Bondholder Request Is Turned Down
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed yesterday it had rejected a request for dismemberment of the 1,500mile bankrupt Boston & Maine Corporation sought last summer by the Group of Institutional Bondholders of the railroad.

title: More Than Greek Clichs
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

title: Union Pacific Lists Its Amtrak Cost
description: The Union Pacific Corporation disclosed yesterday that it will show an extraordinary charge of $65million in its re port for the September quarter to reflect the cost of its railroad subsidiary's turning over its passenger service to the Governmentowned Amtrak.

title: FROEHLING PLAYS CUP MATCH TODAY
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct 7Ilie Nastase was certain Clark Graebner would play one of the two singles matches for the United States in the Davis Cup challenge round tomorrow.

title: SOVIET POET PLANS READINGS IN U.S.
description: Andrei A. Voznesensky, one of the Soviet Union's foremost poets and an outspoken critic of his Government's restrictions on intellectual freedom, is scheduled to arrive here Oct. 17 for a poetryreading tour of the United States.

title: U.S. Death Toll in War Is Put at 21 for Week
description: SAIGON, Oct. 7 (AP)Twentyone Americans were killed in combat in IndoChina last week, eight fewer than the previous week, the United States command reported today.

title: Britain Resisting Wage Curbs Despite High Inflation
description: LONDON, Oct. 7Although Britain has the highest rate of price inflation among industrialized countries, its Conservative party government is resisting calls for a formal policy on incomes to break the wageprice spiral.

title: Charlotte Reid Quits House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) Representative Charlotte T. Reid, Republican of Illinois, resigned from the House today to become a member of the Federal Communications Commission. The resignation left the House with five vacancies, four of them from Republican districts.

title: SALOMON IS JOINING LAPIN IN A VENTURE
description: Two wellknown names in finance, Salomon Brothers, the New Yorkbased investmentbanking firm, and Raymond H. Lapin, former chairman and president of the Federal National Mortgage Association, yesterday announced plans to form a new mortgagebanking company.

title: New York Uncertain About Rent Controls
description: New York City and state housing officials and real estate men were left confused last night by President Nixon's speech on wage and price controls.

title: RAPID ATOMIC GAINS BY CHINA REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8A highlevel Defense Department researcher said today that China had established a rate of nuclear research and development as good as and possibly better than those of the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Critics of Open Admissions Rebutted
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  A paper raising critical questions about college open admissions programs was assailed here today in a long statement by Dr. Robert J. Kibbee, the new Chancellor of City University, where such a program has just entered its second year.

title: Miss Mendoza Is Bride Of Quentin Munier Here
description: The marriage of Miss Marianne Mendoza to Quentin Munier took place in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More here last evening. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. John Calhoun, was followed by a reception, dinner and dance at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Walsh Defends Loan Program 2 Hours to Council
description: Albert A. Walsh, scheduled to he questioned yesterday by a City Council committee about the Municipal Loan Program, spoke for more than two hours in its defense, and was told to come back next Thursday for questioning.

title: Home Mortgage Rate Cut By State Mutual Savings
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 8 (UPI) State Mutual Savings & Loan Association today reduced its prime lending rate on home mortgages to 7 from 7 per cent.

title: A Sushi Maker Who's Thriving In What May Be a Dying Art
description: TOKYOEven in those rare moments when Yosuke Imada is relaxing, his gestures betray the importance of his hands. Like a surgeon awaiting the gloves, or a pianist before the curtain, he motions with the shoulder and elbow, not with the wrist. His fingers remain curled. They are not squandered on animating conversation. They are too valuable for that.

title: Music: A New Carmen
description: It was Bizet's Carmen, recognizably so, at the State Theater on Thursday night. The New York City Opera put a new production on the boards, and Julius Rudel, who conducted, took a look at the original score. He opened some cuts, and restored a tiny bit of the original dialogue. In all, there were only about five minutes of change. So it was a recognizable Carmen.

title: REACTOR REPORT TERMED FAULTY
description: An organization of scientists charged the Atomic Energy Commission yesterday with preparing a superficial, misleading and extremely inadequate statement concerning the expected impact on the environment from a planned breeder reactor demonstration plant.

title: Stock Exchanges Open For Business Monday
description: It will be business as usual for the stock market and one or two of the commodity exchanges, on MondayColumbus Day this year by act of Congressand a threeday weekend for the city's banks, schoolchildren, postmen and the public libraries.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities. The auction was held today because of the Columbus Day holiday next Monday.

title: 2 in Memphis Runoff
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 8 (AP)Councilman Wyeth Chandler and Judge Kenneth Turner of the Juvenile Court will be candidates in a runoff election Nov. 4 for Mayor of Memphis, according to unofficial returns in yesterday's contest. Mr. Chandler had been endorsed by the retiring Mayor, Henry Loeb.

title: Israelis Upset by Direction of Mideast Negotiations
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 8A sense of foreboding and futility appears to be spreading through the Israeli Government as officials monitor the intensifying diplomatic moves in search of an IsraeliEgyptian compromise to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: JOHN TOM ASKO DIES; OFFICIAL OF A.A.U., 64
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 8 John Tomasko, wellknown Amateur Athletic Union track and field official, died, today of a heart attack while attending the national A.A.U. convention here. He was 64 years old and lived at 926 Bloomfield Avenue, Glen Ridge, N. J.

title: MRS. M. H. EISENHART
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 8  Mrs. Ela Bausch Eisenhart, wife of M. Herbert Eisenhart, retired president of the Bausch & Lomb Optical Company, died yesterday at the age of 81.

title: TV: Report on F.B.I. Raises Questions
description: Last night Channel 13 offered viewers a special report on F.B.I. undercover agents that the Public Broadcasting Service deleted from last Wednesday's edition of N.E.T.'s The Great American Dream Machine.

title: WEBSTER CHESTER, BIOLOGY PROFESSOR
description: WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 8Prof. Webster Chester, chairman of the biology department of Colby College from 1903 until 1948, died in his home here yesterday. He was 94 years old.

title: Question About Lin
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 9The news that Mao Tsetung received Emperor Haile Selassie yesterday was announced officially early today by Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, in a dispatch from Peking.

title: Gilberto Gil Plays And Sings Program Evocative of Brazil
description: Among the real pleasures of regular concertgoing are those nights when you hear completely unheralded performers who have all the qualifications for major stardom. Gilberto Gil, working this week (through tomorrow night) at St. Clement's Theater of Latin America, is hardly unknown in his native Brazil, but this is his first appearance in New York.

title: Sudanese Says Major Powers Black Out News of Nation's War
description: A Sudanese refugee told the 30th annual convention of the Congress of Racial Equality yesterday that a conspiracy of silence had prevented dissemination of information on the 16year civil war in the Sudan between blacks of the south and Arabs of the north.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: STOCKS DECLINE AS TRADING DIPS
description: The stock market took a look, yesterday at Phase Two, and prices turned down amid somewhat murky conditions.

title: Trains Halted for Weekend
description: Bus service will be substituted for regular train service on the Waterbury branch of the Penn Central's New Haven line this weekend to allow for repairs on the Waterbury Bridge. The Army Corps of Engineers will be doing the repair work, a railroad spokesman said, adding that only a small number of passengers will be affected today and tomorrow because of light weekend travel.

title: The Greatest Article I Read in My Whole Life
description: Richard Nixon's Vice President, Spiro Agnew, writing about Attica under his byline in The New York Times newspaper the other day, said: To compare the loss of life by those who violate society's law with the loss of life of those whose job it is to uphold itrepresents not simply an assault on human sensibility but an insult to reason.

title: THOMAS FRASER
description: Thomas Fraser, a partner in the FraserHarrington Real Estate Service, the Bronx, died Tuesday in an automobile accident near Pittsburgh. He was 80 years old and lived at 3512 Cambridge Avenue, Riversdale, the Bronx.

title: Nixon Said to Have Called Off Flight Over Strip Mines in April
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Coal industry spokesmen said here today that President Nixon, who visited West Virginia today, had canceled plans for a more extensive visit to the state in April.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS REGISTERS A DECLINE
description: DETROIT, Oct. 8 (AP)Domestic auto production fell slightly this week from last, with General Motors accounting for the 3,000unit decline.

title: High School Almost Deserted After Disturbances
description: Only 50 of the 2,800 students at Charles Evans Hughes High School showed up for classes yesterday following disturbances that began there Thursday and that resulted in the shooting of two youths.

title: Iona Routs St. Peter's, 480
description: MOUNT VERNON, Oct. 8Iona College's club football team opened its homecoming weekend with a 480 rout of St. Peter's College tonight. The Gaels scored the first seven times they had the ball and ran up a total offense of 497 yards. They held St. Peter's to minus 5 yards rushing and 16 yards passing.

title: Nixon Tried to Satisfy Diverse Groups
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Faced with contrary pressures from special interest groups for a Phase Two wageprice program tailored to differing desires, President Nixon is seeking to resolve the conflicts by giving all sides a little something to cheer about.

title: KENYA'S CURRENCY IS DEVALUED BY 3%
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 8Kenya's currency was devalued tonight by 3 per cent. On Monday, when the new rate goes into effect, the United States dollar will be worth 7.14 Kenyan shilling's compared with the previous rate of 6.9.

title: 6 Seized in Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 8 (UPI)Customs agents arrested six persons when they came to pick up a suitcase filled with $29million worth of pure heroin, a Customs official said today. Two of the suspects were held under $1million bond each.

title: ARTIST IS CALLED A DRUG SMUGGLER
description: A selfstlyed artist was arrested by customs agents here yesterday after the frames of his four oil paintings were allegedly found to contain heroin and cocaine valued in excess of $7million.

title: 5 ARE ARRESTED IN STOCK THEFTS
description: A former fight manager, a business promoter and three others were arrested here yesterday on charges of conspiring to sell stolen securities valued at $1million.

title: KNICK STRING ENDED BY LAKERS, 115104
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 8The largest crowd to watch a basketball game in this state 114,500, saw the Los Angeles Lakers snap the Knicks' threegame preseason streak, 115104, tonight in the West Virginia University Coliseum.

title: RULING REAFFIRMED ON ATTICA INQUIRY
description: A Federal appeals court reaffirmed yesterday its earlier refusal to order a halt to the state's interrogation of prisoners at the Attica Correctional Facility.

title: Hirohito Is Met by Dutch Hostility on Tour
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 8Emperor Hirohito was the target of protest today on his arrival in the Netherlands for the most controversial phase of his European goodwill tour.

title: New Center for I.T.T. Unit
description: I.T.T. World Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, displayed yesterday a new communications center at 67 Broad Street that electronically acts as its own troubleshooter, traffic controller and maintenance systern.

title: SMITH GIVES U.S. DAVIS CUP LEAD
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 8Darkness delayed Frank Froehling's finest tennis hour today and gave Rumania a second wind in its Davis Cup challenge round match against the United States.

title: Lerner and Lane Bryant Had Gains in September
description: The Lerner Stores Corporation and Lane Bryant, Inc., two leading retail chains, reported yesterday sales in September were up 8 per cent from the 1970 month. Lerner's sales in September rose 8.2 per cent to $30,287,155, from $27,984,970, while its eightmonth volume rose 9.1 per cent to $230,609,181, from $211,410,972.

title: John F. Keenan, 77, Dead; Retired Family Court Aide
description: BAYVILLE, L. I., Oct. 8John F. Keenan, director of administration of the Family and Children's Court in New York at his retirement in 1954, died yesterday in Glen Cove Community Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 3 Oak Shore Drive.

title: Thousands Here Awaiting Decision on Status of Deferred Raises After Nov. 13
description: Pay increases anticipated by hundreds of thousands of workers in the metropolitan area have already been held up by the wage freeze or may be limited by President Nixon's new economic controls.

title: SOVIETHANOI TIES APPEAR BOLSTERED
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 8President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union left Hanoi by air today, ending a fiveday visit that appears to have further consolidated SovietNorth Vietnamese ties.

title: Belfast Catholic Area Flooded As Saboteurs Blast Reservoir
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct 8 (Reuters)  Saboteurs, acting a day after household use of water in Belfast had been restricted to night hours because of the drought, blew up a pumping station at a city reservoir today, sending a million gallons of water into the streets.

title: Claims Capitol Hill Was Kept in Dark
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills called yesterday for increased cooperation and communication between the Administration and both Congress and the international trading partners of the United States.

title: Peking Separates the Issues
description: In denying that Dr. Henry Kissinger will discuss the United Nations debate on China during his second visit to Peking later this month, the White House tacitly confirms the existence of an agreement to disagree about the U.N. issue. Whatever the nature of that understanding, it seems clear that Peking all along has been determined not to let the U.N. disagreement interfere with President Nixon's projected visit and the attempt to improve bilateral relations.

title: 2 ARGENTINE UNITS OPPOSE PRESIDENT
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 8 Two army garrisons south of Buenos Aires revolted against President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse of Argentina today and he ordered loyal military forces to Move against them.

title: Jobs Data: Shift in Presentation
description: News Analysis

title: AMEX STOCKS OFF IN LOWER VOLUME
description: Strong on the opening, stock prices on the American Stock Exchange dropped yesterday in moderate trading. At the close the index was at 25.67, down 0.07 from the previous day's level.

title: Antiques: Marinot Glass
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is showing off the serious side of the Art Deco style in a new installation that opened this week.

title: Art Review
description: The current exhibition of Jean Arp at the Sidney Janis Gallery, 6 West 57th Street, is persuasive evidence that the art of Arp did not suffer decline in his later years. Most of the works on view, primarily bronze and stone sculptures executed in the last twenty years of Arp's long and productive career, sustain the same richness of invention and freshness of vision that characterize his earlier creations and, indeed, his entire personality.

title: Brush Fire Fatal to Four Abates Near Santa Barbara
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 8 (AP)Subsiding winds and a 1,400man firefighting team slowed the advance today of California's worst brush fire of the year, which has taken four lives and charred more than 5,000 acres.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Finding That Prostitution Is No Longer a Victimless Crime
description: There are indications that, contrary to widespread belief, prostitution does not fully fall within the victimless crime category, the Police Department has found during its threemonth crackdown on prostitution in the midtown area.

title: Accused Soldier to Be Freed
description: FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 8 (AP) An Army private formerly accused of rioting and attempting to burn down the Fort Dix stockade will be discharged from the service this month, according to an Army spokesman. The soldier, Pvt. Thomas Catlow, one of six who faced a courtmartial in 1969 on the arson and riot charges, surrendered to authorities in New York City earlier this week after being absentwithoutleave for two years. He will be given an undesriable discharge.

title: $400 a Week Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Editorial and commercial employes of The Washington Post have rejected a $400aweek top salary contract offer for experienced personnel.

title: LIPPIZAN STALLIONS APPEAR AT GARDEN
description: The Wonderful World of Horses, with the Royal Lipizzan Stallions, returned for its second annual appearance at Madison Square Garden last night and one can only regret that it will he here for only six performances.

title: U.S. IS STUDYING RENT LAW HERE
description: Federal officials were reported yesterday to be considering the possibility of allowing New York City's revised rent control law to operate during the second phase of President Nixon's price controls.

title: Judge in Louisiana Exempts Teachers From Pay Freeze
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 8A Federal district judge ruled here today that President Nixon's wageprice freeze did not apply to the teachers of two large Louisiana school districts.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8And now it begins again, still the most glamorous protracted sport event in the American spectrum, the World Series. Because it will last at least five days and perhaps nine, because it has been happening annually since 1903, because the path that led two of 24 teams to this confrontation began eight months ago back in Florida, and because the nature of the game encourages one to focus on individuals more than on teams, this competition will, get an amount and intensity of attention unmatched by younger championships.

title: A. G. MATHEWS, AIDE IN DUN & BRADSTREET
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Oct. 8 Arthur G. Mathews, who retired as manager of the municipal service department of Dun & Bradstreet, the credit rating firm, in 1965, died here yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived at 64 Sagamore Road.

title: Drugs Found to Unmask Cancer Virus
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8  A highly effective way of unmasking hidden cancer viruses in living cells has been discovered by scientists at the National Institutes of Health.

title: Miss Sentman Bride of T. F. Richardson
description: Miss Joyce Lynne Sentman and Thomas Fitch Richardson were married last evening at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Norman D. Stanton. The bride is an assistant cashier of the First National City Bank, of which her husband is an assistant vice president.

title: AGNEW SCORES MILLS ON REVENUE SHARING
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 8Vice President Agnew today sharply criticized Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, for refusing to hold immediate committee hearings on the Nixon Administration's revenuesharing plans.

title: It Takes a Spry Pedestrian To Survive on Queens Blvd.
description: The young mother, her child clutched in her arms, darted into Queens Boulevard. She crossed the service road and then raced across three more lanes of eastbound traffic.

title: PRICES OF LUMBER AND SILVER DROP
description: Disappointment with President Nixon's speech on phase 2 of his economic program sent traders in lumber and silver futures on a selling rampage yesterday, driving prices of those commodities down considerably.

title: JetsPatriots Contest Listed for Channel 2
description: Tomorrow's game between the Jets and the New England Patriots will be available on TV in the New York area on Channel 2 at 1 P.M., not Channel 7 as announced by the Jets on Wednesday.

title: Ontario Town in Throes of Urban Renewal
description: The Talk of Kitchener

title: ITALIAN LEAGUE CHARGES INSULT
description: The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League, contending it was barred from participation in Mondy's Columbus Day Parade, will conduct a brief wreathlaying ceremony at the statue of Christopher Columbus in Columbus Circle, Monday at 9 A.M.

title: Overtight Squeeze on Trade
description: The mild optimism stirred at last week's monetary conference by indications that the United States was finally getting ready to negotiate an end to the world currency and trade crisis is beginning to dissipate.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: BRIGHTON, EnglandSurvivors of the 1964 Republican convention in San Francisco would have had a feeling of dj vu at the Labor party conference these last few days. Once again a great political party was coming under control of an extremist faction convinced that it alone had the true faith.

title: GIELEN IN DEBUT AT PHILHARMONIC
description: Michael Gielen made his American debut Thursday night, conducting the New York Philharmonic, and he made it the hard way. There was no Beethoven, Brahms, Tchaikovsky, Strauss or Ravel on which to coast into the favor of the audience. Instead there was a 40minute Mozart SerenadeNo. 10 in B flat and a masterpiece, to be surebut one restricted to the sound of 13 wind instruments.

title: INCREASE FORECAST IN THE COTTON CROP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) The Agriculture Department estimated today that the 1971 cotton crop will be 10.6 million on the basis of Oct. 1 conditions.

title: More Business Leaders Back Phase 2 Plans, but Some Question Lack of Details
description: Business and Government leaders continued yesterday to voice their approval of President Nixon's economic program, although some expressed disappointment that more details had not been provided by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally.

title: RISE IN HOMICIDES REPORTED IN CITY
description: The Police Department reported yesterday that there were 143 homicides ill the city in August, an increase of 43 per cent over the 100 in the same month of 1970.

title: Writing Prizes Announced By University of Missouri
description: The University of Missouri's School of Journalism and School of Business and Public Administration announced yesterday the winners of the seventh annual newspaper and magazine writing competition, sponsored by the Independent Natural Gas Association of America.

title: Buckley Says U.S. Reaps Seeds Of Lawlessness Sown in 1960's
description: Senator James L. Buckley declared last night that the United States was beginning to reap in its prisons the seeds of lawlessness that were planted elsewhere in the last six or eight years.

title: AIRLIFT OF REFUGEES TO PAKISTAN URGED
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 8The Governor of East Pakistan suggested in an interview today that international relief agencies organize a vast airlift to transport Pakistani refugees in India back to East Pakistan.

title: Burglar Alarm Company Here Charged With Defrauding Poor
description: District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx and Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson announced yesterday the indictment of the president of a Manhattan burglar alarm company and his corporation on charges of defrauding consumers.

title: Dr. Ramon Villeda Morales Dies; Former President of Honduras
description: Dr. Ramn Villeda Morales, a former president of Honduras and head of his country's delegation to the current session of the United Nations General Assembly, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Bellevue Hospital. He was 62 years old.

title: EXPORT BENEFIT. SEEN BY CONNALLY
description: Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally said yesterday that he expected, over the next several months, the removal of a number of trade barriers against United States exports.

title: A Clothing Maker Is Invading New Field
description: Rosenau Brothers, Inc., generally considered the world's largest producer of children's dresses, has gone into the manufacturing of adult clothes for the first time in its 56year history.

title: Film Union Accuses Studio Of Attempted Cinemacide
description: Local 52, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators yesterday accused five major film companies in New York of wanting to murder feature moviemaking in New York and to charge the union with the crime.

title: Delicate Shortage: No Bathroom Tissue
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 8  In Honolulu the issue is tissue. And you don't ask for the salt and pepper. You ask for salt and paper.

title: 54,000 to See Series Opener at Baltimore Today
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8Baseball prepared to raise the curtain tomorrow on its final act of the 1971 season, the 68th World Series, with the Pittsburgh Pirates trying to upstage the favored Baltimore Orioles.

title: Opposition Presses Trudeau For Wage and Price Curbs
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 8Some opposition leaders pressed the Government today to follow President Nixon's lead and impose wage and price controls in Canada.

title: Evading the Transit Issue
description: The proposal of city officials led by Controller Beanie to save the 30cent subway fare by borrowing from the projected transportation bond issue is, as Governor Rockefeller says, no plan at all. It certainly deserves the curt rejection it received at the hands of the Governor, constituting as it does a total evasion of the fare issue, and one of dubious legality at that. It represents the latest in a series of efforts on the part of many the city's Democratic leaders to escape any direct responsibility for devising a viable if politically unpalatable method of increasing transit income sufficiently to prevent a disastrous fare increase within the next year.

title: DR. MORRIS WORTON
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 8Dr. Morris Worton, a former general practitioner in the Bronx, died yesterday in Aurora Nursing Home in Rye. He was 84 years old and lived at 83 Fenimore Road.

title: Kosygin Pledges Algerian Aid; Shuns Militant. Mideast Stance
description: ALGIERS, Oct. 8  Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin promised the Algerian Government today to increase its already considerable Soviet aid but declined to join it in a belligerent stance on the Middle East.

title: Employment Up 325,000; Jobless Rate Is Unchanged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Unemployment remained essentially unchanged in September, but employment showed a substantial rise, particularly in the key manufacturing sector of the economy, the Labor Department reported today.

title: KAISER ALUMINUM LISTS DROP IN NET
description: Earnings of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation fell in the third quarter this year to $2,030,000, or 6 cents a share, from $7,506,000, or 35 cents a share, in the similar three months last year, it was reported yesterday from the Oakland, Calif., headquarters.

title: New Police Chaplain
description: The Rev Edward B. Beckles was appointed Protestant chaplain of the Police Department yesterday by Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: Muskie Decries Tax Plan
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Oct. 8 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, said tonight President Nixon's proposed tax cut for corporations followed the trickle down theory of economic growth: If enough wealthy people buy limousines, there will be more jobs for chauffeurs. His remarks were made at a Providence Democratic City Committee fundraising dinner.

title: Celia Cruz Excels at Chateau Madrid
description: The singers and the songs heard at the Chateau Madrid, 48th Street at Lexington Avenue, tend to follow more or less standard patterns. The singers are the stalwarts of the LatinAmerican concert and nightclub circuit. Their songs have Latin musical inflections and are almost invariably sung in Spanish.

title: Laird Voices Happiness
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, voicing happiness over Sergeant Sexton's release, said today: We remain concerned about the hundreds of other of our military personnel held in Southeast Asia.

title: Issue of Astrology Brings a Demand That Robinson Quit
description: A member of the City Council called yesterday for the resignation of Isaiah E. Robinson, the president of the Board of Education, for advocating that schools use astrology as one means of predicting pupil behavior and improving classroom relationships.

title: Teacher Dismissals Barred
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 8 (AP)United States District Court Judge Noel P. Fox issed a preliminary injunction today forbidding Kalamazoo's school board to dismiss 103 teachers and 36 library assistants. The judge also ordered the board to find the money to retain the 139 school employes, who were dismissed effective next Monday after voters defeated a proposal to raise taxes.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Edward N. Cole, the president of the General Motors Corporation, was granted a patent this week for the company's latest version of the air bag, which is designed to inflate and protect car occupants in a collision. The device described in Patent 3,610, 657 actually consists of two bags. The larger one receives the impact of the passenger's torso, and quickly deflates so as to avoid excessive rebound. The principal feature of the invention is the small inner bag. This is held near the bottom of the larger one and remains inflated for some time against the occupant's legs to keep him in a normal seated position.

title: 2 Landmarks at Albany To Be Put Up at Auction
description: ALBANY, Oct. 9 (UPI)Union Station and the old Journal newspaper building, two landmarks in downtown Albany, will be put on the auction block Nov. 8, the state Office of General Services announced today.

title: PRESIDENT'S VISIT PRODUCES RECORD
description: ELKINS, W. Va., Oct. 8President Nixon, an insatiable collector of milestones, political records and other statistical paraphernalia, achieved another goal today by becoming the first President to visit all 50 states.

title: Taiwan Warns U.N. Peking Is Peril to It
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 8  Nationalist China's Foreign Minister said in the General Assembly today that the Chinese Communists were seeking to destroy the United Nations and that therefore it was sad to reflect that some members wanted to admit Peking as a replacement for his Government.

title: RAPOPORT HORSE HAS CLOSE CALL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 Marvin Van Rapoport's Spindletop Showdown had a close call, but managed to keep his season's record clean by winning the regular conformation hunter championship today at the Philadelphia horse show.

title: Trial Date Set for Oct. 18 For Two Soledad Brothers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP)The two surviving Soledad Brothers today were ordered to stand trial Oct. 18 on murder charges stemming from the killing of a Soledad Prison guard in 1970.

title: Tax Cut Passage Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, told President Nixon today the tax cut bill would pass the Senate, probably in November.

title: Freeze Is Seen Imperiling City Transit
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame charged yesterday that the socalled Lindsay  Ronan plan to hold down the New York City transit fare was a hoax and that if it was adopted the fare has to go up.

title: McClendon Stops Malave in 4th Round at Forum
description: With a sudden, powerful combination of punches near the close of the round, Adolphus (Doc) McClendon of Paterson, N. J., scored a fourthround knockout over. Edwin (ChuChu) Malave of Greenwich Village last night in the feature of three 10round bouts at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden.

title: Missile Test Is Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)  A Sprint missile launched and controlled by radar successfully intercepted a Minutemantype vehicle yesterday in a test of equipment to be used for the Safeguard antiballistic missile system, the Defense Department announced today.

title: Utterances on Hope Draw 800 to Church Expecting Only 100
description: A theological conference on hope and the future of man so overtaxed the seating capacity of a lecture hall at Riverside Church yesterday that speakers and audience were hastily moved out of the hall into the huge nave of the Gothic edifice at Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

title: Replay It Main, Sam
description: YORK; Pa.Twenty autumns have passed since Bobby Thomson's shot heard round the world. In an age of manufactured heroes and image makers, it is good to think, of Bobby Thomson and his prodigious clout two decades ago. 1951 was the year of Joseph McCarthy, of Mao. Tsetung, of Douglas MacArthur. But, it was also the year of Bobby Thomson, belter of the most famous home run in the history of baseball.

title: Lecture on Dollar Draws A Big Crowd in Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8A group of Muscovites, evidently uneasy about the possible impact of the dollar crisis on their lives, have been assured in a public lecture that the Soviet Union is effectively insulated against financial difficulties in the West and would suffer no adverse effect.

title: U.S. Data Say Service Costs Lead Inflation Parade
description: Figures compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show that if President Nixon's economic stabilization program is to work, it will have to have a major impact on the prices of services, which have been rising faster than commodity prices and leading the inflationary trend.

title: Nicklaus and Player Reach Piccadilly Golf Final
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 8  The defending champion, Jack Nicklaus, meets an archrival, Gary Player, who has won it three times, in the eighth final of the Piccadilly world matchplay championship tomorrow over 36 holes, a test both consider the most demanding in golf.

title: BETHLEHEM PLANS TO CUT MOO JOBS
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 8 (AP)A union official quoted a Bethlehem Steel Corporation official today as having said 5,100 jobs would be cut from the concern's nearby Lackawanna mill.

title: ARTISTRY OF BREAM HEARD IN TULLY HALL
description: The sophisticated artistry of Julian Bream, his incredibly lightfingered dexterity on both guitar and lute, the immediate bond of communication he establishes with his audience, have been noted time and again since his American debut in 1958. It need only be said, therefore, that all the elements were in their accustomed good order for the English virtuoso's soldout recital at Tully Hall Thursday night.

title: Alan Aida Joins Box Step
description: Alan Aida has been signed to star in The Box Stop, a new comedy by Murray Schisgal, opening on Broadway Feb. 17. Martin Fried will direct. Richard Seader and Allan Jack Lewis are producers of the comedy, described as a satiric portrait of the modern urban man trying to get somewhere.

title: They're Playing War in Dallas
description: Every Oklahoma football fan wants to see every second of the war that is the OklahomaTexas game in the Cotton Bowl today. That stadium holds only 75,000a mere handful of the Texans and Sooners who consider their game a crusade.

title: Kodak Displays a Model Of Super8 Videoplayer
description: The Eastman Kodak Company demonstrated in Montreal yesterday what it described as a feasibility model of a cartridgeloading super8 film videoplayer for showing color and sound motion pictures over a standard television receiver. The company said the demonstration was not to be taken as a newproduct announcement but it has been known that Kodak has been seeking to develop such a system in an effort to increase sales of homemovie equipment and film.

title: FRESH ENEMY UNIT IN A BORDER CLASH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)Fighting broke out again today along the CamobodianSouth Vietnamese border. South Vietnamese infantrymen clashed with North Vietnamese regulars near Route 22 just south of United States Fire Base Pace, the area where the Saigon troops engaged the enemy Thursday.

title: Bridge: Takeout Double Opens Door For LongShot Squeeze Play
description: Contracts that look hopeless can sometimes be salvaged by a combination of skill and luck. On the diagramed deal from the Regional Open Pair Championship at Swan Lake, N. Y., last week, a few declarers took advantage of a remote chance to bring home a fiveheart contract.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Oct. 5.

title: Nixon Discusses Textiles
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) President Nixon conferred for an hour today with international economic advisers on efforts to negotiate restraints on textile exports to the United States by Japan and other Asian nations.

title: POWER CRISIS TIED TO LEGAL DELAYS
description: The State Public Service Commission, in the first of a new series of three reports on electric power planning, said yesterday that the present power crisis was attributable largely to construction and legal delays that have set back actual operation of plants planned four or five years ago.

title: HENRI PELL JUNOD, AN INDUSTRIALIST
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 8Henri Pell Junod, former executive vice president and vice chairman of Pickands Mather & Co., Inc., ore, pig iron and coke concern now part of Diamond Shamrock Corporation, died Wednesday of viral pneumonia in Lakeside Hospital. He was 70, years old.

title: Studebaker Seeks Susquehanna Corp.
description: Merger News

title: E. Albert Eckart Sr., 69, Dies; ExPresident of Sapolin Paints
description: E. Albert Eckart Sr., chairman of the finance committee and former president of Sapolin Paints, Inc., died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: VISTA GROUP URGES NIXON BE DUMPED
description: DENVER, Oct. 8About 400 members and former members of Volunteers In Service To America closed a threeday conference today with a unanimous recommendation that President Nixon be dumped. The group, called the National VISTA Alliance, also proposed that it seek an affiliation with organized labor.

title: Excerpts From Connally News Conference on the PostFreeze Economic Plan
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally's news conference in Washington yesterday on President Nixon's postfreeze economic policy, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Hart Measure Would Outlaw Private Handgun Ownership
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (UPI) Senator Philip A. Hart introduced today a bill that would outlaw private ownership of pistols after giving citizens 180 days to sell their weapons to the Government for a fair price.

title: RANGERS LAUNCH SEASON TONIGHT
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 8  Undefeated in their final six preseason games and carrying a winning streak of three, the New York Rangers will be aiming to break a losing tradition tomorrow night against the Canadiens at the Forum in the National Hockey League opener for both teams.

title: SAVOIR TRIUMPHS IN KENTUCKY TROT
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 8 Savoir who finished his juvenile season as a colt but started the 1971 campaign as a gelding, captured the 75th Kentucky Futurity today in straight heats. Showing his hooves to six other 3yearold trotters, Savoir toured the famed Red Mile, the world's fastest standardbred oval, in 1:58 1/5 and 1:58 2/5 and won $34,878.24 from gross purse of $63,415.

title: Arrives in Rabat
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 8Premier Kosygin received a cordial but restrained welcome in Rabat this morning at the start of a threeday visit.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTTERY WINNINGS SUBJECT OF INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, Oct. 8 (AP)The executive director of the New Jersey lottery yesterday confirmed that the state was investigating possible irregularities in the handing out of prize money.

title: Prexy by Court Order
description: In ordering the reinstatement of Dr. Theodore Powell as president of Kingsborough Community College, State Supreme Court Justice Francis J. Bloustein has in effect superseded the normal administrative authority of university trusteeship.

title: Executive Changes
description: The. Avco Corporation announced yesterday the election of Richard W. Yantis as executive vice president of Western operations.
