In this newly created pesition, Mr. Yantis has parent company responsibility for the operations of Avco units headquartered primarily in California. These companies include Avco Community Developers, inc., Avco Financial Services, Inc., Avco Savings and Loan. Association, and Carte Blanche Corporation.

title: Local Clubs to Refund Price Increases
description: President Nixon's economic game plan yesterday sent at least one ticket manager to an early shower.

title: Emblem Is Chosen For Inflation Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8The Commerce Department produced today a new antiinflation poster developed for display in stores. It was designed at the request of the Office of Emergency Preparedness and approved by the Cost of Living Council.

title: Muskie May Back Reform Bloc In a Key Preconvention Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, the frontrunner for the Democratic Presidential nomination, was reported ready tonight to throw his weight behind the reform element in a major intraparty dispute.

title: It Only Happens to Others' Bows
description: The theory that life imitates art is ironically reversed by Nadine Trintignant, the writer-director of "It Only Happens to Others," the French drama that had its premiere yesterday at the Paris Theater. In exposing a young couple's sudden tragedy and their ensuing, numbing grief, Mrs. Trintignant may not have entirely avoided the sudsiness of soap opera but she has largely succeeded in artistically dissecting a frightening subject with genuine understanding.This is not coincidental. A child of Mrs. Trintignant and her actor-husband, Jean-Louis, actually died suddenly when he was filming "Z" several years ago. The drama of "It Only Happens to Others" was, therefore, generated by horrible truth and it is as real as macabre fact, even if its emotional effects are only occasionally powerful.Mrs. Trintignant's often oblique approachvignettes of a remembered past inter-cut with the stark presentdiffuses matters. Despite the English subtitles, one wonders at the introductory scene, which shows an unshaven Marcello Mastroianni and a vaguely distraught but beautiful Catherine Deneuve distractedly making small talk and love in a strange, plush apartment. Only in disjointed subsequent scenes is it revealed that this is something of an anticlimax; that they aren't weird lovers; that they had been a happy, well-to-do husband and wife whose infant daughter's quick, unexpected passing has left them listless toward life, family and friends.But Mrs. Trintignant does capture precise, perceptive moments of mood and nuance. Sudden death in a hospital emergency room is made truly incomprehensible and shocking as they inarticulately grope for reasons and comfort. And vignettes of their child, alive and playful intrude with poignant effect to enhance their despair, despite the solicitude of family and friends.In their abrupt escape from urban self-imprisonment to recapture the life they once had, the director also has fashioned several sequences of quiet, sylvan beauty. Flocks of sheep, a provincial wedding and country children are striking in the film's pastel colors and also seem to indicate poetically a final release from the couple's grief.Since Mr. Mastroianni and Miss Deneuve are almost constantly before the camera, they may leave the impression of being involved in a marathon Actors Studio exercise. But they are thorough professionals who project obvious sincerity and feeling into really demanding roles. They're abetted by natural, if brief performances by a small supporting cast.As a distaff director and therefore a rare type, Mrs. Trintignant proves to be the film's top professional and an excellent vote-getter for Women's Lib. Like Proust, who insisted that "It is grief that develops the powers of the mind," she has produced a bittersweet drama out of grief that may be imperfect but is intellectually adult and sometimes, like life itself, touching.

title: CHARLES D. BAKER JR.
description: NEWBURYPORT, Mass., Oct. 8 (AP)Charles D. Baker Jr., father of Charles D. Baker of Needham, Deputy Under Secretary of Transportation, died last night at the age of 81.

title: MET FIDELIO LED BY HANS WALLAT
description: For many an opera in the repertory, you can make do With a conductor who keeps time well and gets along? with the singers: for Fidelio, that most symphonic of operas, the requirements become harder to meet. Hans Wallat, who made his Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as conductor of the Beethoven work, gave few indications that he was ready for such an assignment.

title: Art: Tapestries and a Zoo by Calder
description: Not having checked up on Old Faithful lately, I am unable to say whether it is still operating on schedule. But no matter. Interest in that great natural wonder has subsided since the emergence of another, Alexander Calder, who can be depended upon to erupt just as regularly and to put on an even better show. Currently he is putting on two, one at the Whitney Museum and one at the Penis Galleries. The first is a collection of 20 tapestries and the second a sort of zoo in which you will recognize such old friends as cows and encounter species as yet unnamed. Both shows indicate that the mysterious sources of Calder's inventive energy are still aboil.

title: U.S. Negro Catholics Present Grievances at Vatican Meeting
description: ROME, Oct. 8A delegation of American black Roman Catholics, campaigning for a greater Negro voice in church affairs, had a 90minute meeting today with Archbishop Giovanni Benelli, the Vatican's Deputy Secretary of State.

title: Portraits by a Black Artist of the 1800's
description: The exhibition of portraits by the American painter Joshua Johnston that opened this week at the Peridot Gallery, 820 Madison Avenue at 68th Street, is an event of considerable historical as well as artistic interest. Johnston, who is believed to have died about 1825, practiced his profession in Baltimore during the last decade of the 18th century and the first quarter of the 19th. He was a highly accomplished craftsman who worked in the established style of his period a primitive, folk style that was capable of sharp characterization and beautiful decorative touches.

title: In Midst of the City, A Succah Is Home For Jewish Family
description: Since last Sunday, Mrs. Elinor Friedman and her two children have been eating, studying, entertaining and resting in a wooden but they built on the cement backyard of their building, amid the apartment houses on East 86th Street off First Avenue.

title: MISS WRIGHT IS SEEN IN AN ARPINO BALLET
description: Reflection's is one of those chatty little ballets that Gerald Arpino seems able to spin off with consummate ease. They entertain the eye but don't tax the mind, and offer good dancers the opportunity to display their skill in congenial enchainments. The City Center Joffrey Ballet offered the work for the first time this season Thursday evening.

title: THREE ARE INDICTED IN TEXAS STOCK CASE
description: DALLAS, Oct. 8 (AP)Criminal indictments alleging embezzlement from the pension fund of National Bankers Life Insurance Company were returned today against two former company presidentsJohn Osorio and Sam E. Stockand a former executive vice president, Donald S. Akins.

title: HARRY DOEHLA
description: Harry Doehla, board chairman of Doehla Greeting Cards, Inc., 350 Fifth Avenue, and a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in his sleep. He wag 71 years old and lived at the Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South, and had a summer place in Roslyn, L. I.

title: Books of The Times
description: A FACTIOUS PEOPLE. Politics and Society in Colonial New York. By Patricia U. Bonomi. 342 pages. Columbia. $10.

title: Grand Union Stores Still Sell Detergent Tied to Crime Ring
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 8 (UM) Grand Union Company officials said today that the supermarket chain was still buying most of its lowsuds detergent from a New Jersey company despite magazine articles linking the producer with organized crime.

title: Florida Power Net Gains
description: The Florida Power Corporation reported yesterday gains in net income and revenues for the first nine months of this year. The report placed operating revenues at $131,959,992 for the nine months ended Sept. 30. This compared with $118,984,195 a year earlier. Net income rose to $24,014,138 from $23,726,923 in the like 1970 period.

title: Nuclear Blast Set Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (Reuters)The United States set off today a lowyield underground nuclear explosion at its test site in Nevada, the Atomic Energy Commission announced here. The blast was of less than 20 kilotons.

title: Damaging File Dropped From Col. Herbert's Record
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 The Army has thrown out a damaging efficiency report that was added to the file of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged atrocities by American troops in South Vietnam. The action, announced today by Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke at the Pentagon, clears the way for Colonel Herbert to stay in the military. Had the Army not elected to clear the colonel's record of charges of having no ambition, integrity, loyalty or will for selfimprovement and of having a terrible appearance, he would have been forced to retire from military service effective March 1, 1972, Mr. Froehlke said. The efficiency report, a periodic evaluation of officers' performance, was filed by Col. J. Ross Franklin, who had been, accused by Colonel Herbert of, derelietion of duty by covering up the alleged atrocities.

title: NEWISSUES PRICES SHOW SMALL GAINS
description: Prices of new issuesstocks of companies that never previously had a public marketclimbed early this week, then retreated and finished with only small net gains.

title: Wage Policy Statement By Presidential Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Following is policy statement No. 28 issued by President Nixon's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Television: That's the Ticket
description: We need to develop a whole new system in our communications. Take as an, example the field of radio. There has been a startling collapse of classical music in the last year. The reason paradoxically is the economic success of FM radio. As long as it played fine music it held little attraction for advertisers, but by scrapping the classics for what one manager called a really good format of schmaltzy instrumentals, the radio stations increased the audience and solved their economic problem.

title: Court Bids Pennsylvania Provide School for All Retarded Children
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8A special three  judge Federal panel ordered Pennsylvania today to provide a free public education to all retarded children in the state.

title: Utility Files Offerings
description: Directors of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., authorized yesterday the filing of registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Public Service Commission for the issuance and sale of 1 million shares of common stock by negotiated sale and $12million of first mortgage bonds by competitive bidding. The offerings are expected to be made late in November.

title: SOVIET IS OUSTING FOUR BRITISH AIDES IN REPRISAL MOVE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 8The Soviet Union tonight ordered the ouster of four British diplomats and one businessman and revoked the entry visas of three other businessmen in retaliation for Britain's mass expulsion two weeks ago of 105 Soviet representatives on espionage.

title: Vietcong Release G.I. Held for 2 Years
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)United States sergeant listed as missing in action was released by the Vietcong today after more than two years' captivity. He walked barefoot for eight hours through jungles to safety and reported that he had seen other American prisoners during the two years.

title: ReadingTest Hoax Gives School High Official Rank
description: A Brooklyn school that figured last spring in an admitted hoax to produce unbelievably high pupil scores on the citywide reading test has now been officially ranked as the bestachieving school in its district on the basis of those questionable scores.

title: Rogers, After Meeting With Egyptian, Calls Interim Mideast Accord Possible
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers, after a new round of peacemaking talks with Egypt, expressed his belief yesterday that an interim agreement in the Middle East is possible.

title: Jets May Start Crane, Rest Baker for 2 Games
description: Despite the decision by Ralph Baker to keep playing with a fractured wrist bone, Paul Crane loomed yesterday as the left linebacker for the New York Jets in tomorrow's game with the New England Patriots.

title: Chiang Said to Play a Less Active Role
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 8 After over 40 years as leader of Nationalist China, President Chiang Kaishek appears to be playing a greatly reduced role in the Government and has reportedly turned over most administrative responsibilities to his son, Deputy Premier Chiang Chingkuo.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Manufacturers Hanover Shows 5.6% Profit Drop
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation reported yesterday a 5.6 per cent decline in thirdquarter profits from banking operations, but a 20.4 per cent gain including the effects of securities transactions.

title: RAIL SHOP UNIONS ARE ON A PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 Shoperaft unions representing 90,000 railroad workers reached agreement today on a new contract with the nation's railroads. The pact will last through the summer of 1973.

title: OTB's Computers Fail For 3d Straight Friday
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation's primary computer system broke down again yesterday for the third Friday in a row, forcing five shops to close and 16 others to revert to a manual ticketselling procedure.

title: Sports Moves Over for Fashion Show
description: For over 50 years P.A.L.'s been keeping kids out trouble. Now we're in trouble.

title: LABOR WITHHOLDING ENDORSEMENT OF NEW NIXON ECONOMIC PROGRAM; SILENT ON APPEAL FROM CONNALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8Organized labor, expressing suspicion that it had been misled by the Nixon Administration, drew back today from an agreement that it made at a private briefing yesterday to support the President's new economic program.

title: Israeli Aide Bars Asylum for Jewish Criminals
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 8  The Israeli Interior Minister, Yosef Burg, said today that Jewish criminals from abroad could not expect to evade justice by invoking their rights as Jews for haven in Israel.

title: Bruder of Brazil Captures World Finn Class Title Sail
description: TORONTO, Oct. 8 (Canadian Press)  Joerg Bruder of Brazil won his second consecutive Finn Class world sailing championship today by a narrow margin from Carl Van Duyne of Annapolis, Md.

title: Market Place: A Broker Backs New Rate Plan
description: Sam Skurnick is not your runofthemill broker. Thoughtful and a prolific letter writer, the Hardy & Co. representative took a degree in mathematics at Brooklyn College in 1939. His minor was physics.

title: DEPOSITS MOUNTING AT MINORITY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) Deposits in the nation's minoritycontrolled banks climbed by almost 40 per cent during the 12 months ended Sept. 30, a high Treasury official said today.

title: Basketball Is Just a Hobby for Giants' Lakes Now
description: In the spot where the personnel questionaire asks for hobbies, Roland Lakes, the New York Giants' 6foot4inch, 268pound defensive tackle, lists tennis and pro basketball  and there's a good reason why the latter isn't his vocation.

title: Jeannette Offer Extended
description: JEANNETTE, Pa., Oct. 8 (UPI)The Jeannette Corporation has announced extension of its exchange offer to holders of its 7 per cent preferred stock until 3:30 P.M., Nov. 12. The company had offered, as of July 12, to issue 3.75 shares of common stock in exchange for each share of preferred.

title: RIVA RIDGE CHOICE IN $196,150 RACE
description: The richest race in New York State, the Champagne Stakes, has attracted a field of eight for its 100th running at Belmont Park today. With that number going, the onemile test for 2yearolds will have a gross value of $196,150, the winner earning $117,690.

title: South Africa Expects U.S. to Raise Gold Price Soon
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Oct. 8Hollard Street, the financial center of this metalrich country, is fairly confident that the United States dollar will soon be devalued agal?? gold, and the street's mood r3 wile of muted buoyancy.

title: Mrs. Holzer Married
description: Mrs. Thais Kluge Holzer, widow of Eric K. Holzer, and Henry P. C. Keuls, a widower, were married yesterday morning in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. William Gunther. The bride's first husband was president of the American Union Transport Company. Mr. Keuls is a business consultant and inventor.

title: Rebels Vow to Resist

title: LAKELAND NAMED BEST AT HATBORO

title: Pollution Notices Served
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) The Environmental Protection Agency served notice today on two Wisconsin towns and a paper mill, giving them 180 days to start abating water pollution. Notices were served on the towns of Superior and Hurley and the Superior Fiber Products Company.

description: The Kennecott Copper Corporation, a major United States copper producer, has quietly circulated to Government officials a 93page statement charging Chile with conducting a farreaching propaganda campaign to set the stage for her expropriation of the company's Chilean mine without compensation.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Ronald Reagan of California took off aboard a White House 707 jet for a 16day, fivenation tour of the Orient. With him were his wife, Nancy, their 13yearold son, Skipper, 14 aides and some of their wives.

title: Having Lost the Series on Paper, Pirates Are Set to Square Matters on Field
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 8  The Pittsburgh Pirates wondered today why they even bothered showing up for the World Series.

title: MRS. OWEN BREWSTER
description: DEXTER, Me., Oct. 8Mrs. Dorothy F. Brewster, widow of Senator Owen Brewster, died in her home here yesterday. She was 82 years old.

title: PENN CENTRAL SUED ON CITY LAND SALE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 8 (AP) The Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia has filed two suits to block the sale of the Penn Central Railroad's real estate holdings in midtown New York.

title: Parisians Use Boats in Subway Strike
description: PARIS, Oct. 8The French Government turned to the River Seine today to alleviate the effects of a subway strike in its fourth day of crippling traffic jams. The Government pressed into service a small fleet of seven excursion boats the Bateaux Mouchesto ferry passengers through the city. Each boat carries about 100 people.

description: The future of the city's largest, still undeveloped land mass is at stake in the struggle to create a South Richmond development authority on Staten Island. Difficult as the effort is, there are hopeful signs.

title: Cornell Medical Names Doctor to Master Chair
description: Dr. Edward H. Ahrens Jr., an expert on atherosclerosis, has been named to the newly endowed Hilda Altschul Master Professorship in Med icine at Cornell University Medical College. The chair is named for the late wife of Dr. Arthur M. Master, who devised the Master 2step test for heart function.

description: The state's Department of Mental Hygiene abandoned plans this week to open a halfway house for mental patients in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

description: BUFFALO, Oct. 8  Trying out a potential Presidential campaign theme, Mayor Lindsay portrayed himself today as a populist champion of the street people.

description: The city's Parks Department announced yesterday that Central Park roads would be closed to vehicular traffic to permit bicycle riding on Monday, Columbus Day, as well as on Veterans Day, Oct. 25, and Election Day, Nov. 2.

description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (AP)The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's sixthlargest producer, disclosed today that it would report a net loss in the third quarter of this year. Detailed results will be released next week, a spokesman said.

description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the telephone company's time bureau.

description: WOODBURY, N.J., Oct. 8 Mrs. Virginia Jones, a 42yearold widow who lives in Woodbury, had intended to watch President Nixon's economic address, but her boyfriend, George Krajewski, had other plans.

title: Film Festival: Romantic:'4 Nights of Dreamer' Bows at Beaumont
description: In the two years since "Une Femme Douce" played at the Seventh New York Film Festival, there have been three commercial openings of films by Robert Bresson, accompanied perhaps by a growing public appreciation of the very special cinematic vocabulary of this great and austere French master.In "Four Nights of a Dreamer," which played last night in the Vivian Beaumont Theater as part of the present film festival, the Bresson vocabulary remains intact, but in the service of a different and more worldly subject matter.Consider a scene at the beginning of "Four Nights of a Dreamer" in which the young hero, Jacques (Guillaume des Forets), takes an outing in the country. All we see in Jacques thumbing a ride out from Paris, doing two straight-faced somersaults in a field of flowers, and, at night, stepping out of the car that has returned him to the city. The point is not that Jacques doesn't have a good time, but that the strict economy of gesture that conditions the Bresson universe requires no larger notation for this moment.When a greater expansiveness is required, it will be supplied, but in recent Bresson films it has been carefully reserved for those fleeting indications of spiritual transcendence that have seemed his special interest in the cinema.In "Four Nights of a Dreamer," it is more openly supplied, but it is no less special. The story, adapted from Dostoyevsky's "White Nights," concerns a solitary man, a romantic dreamer, who one night befriends a distraught young girl and for the next three nights meets her to tell about himself and listen to her story of what may be unrequited love.On the last night the girl encounters her lost lover, and goes off with him  leaving the dreamer, who has fallen hopelessly in love, with only a memory for another dream.Bresson has moved the story from Petersburg to Paris, from the 1840's to the 1970's. He has enlarged its scope, andby making his hero an artist for whom dreams beget realities  he has provided something of a happy ending.But although the dreams translate to art, their theme is love, and "Four Nights of a Dreamer" is very much a movie about the condition of being in love. The intense covert eroticism of the earlier Bresson (in all the films except "A Man Escaped", 1956, and "The Trial of Joan of Arc," 1961) is here overt and even lyrically sustained.The effect on the film's quality is inescapable  not only in a superb purple passage in which the girl (Isabel Weingarten, another of Bresson's hauntingly beautiful heroines) examines her naked body, but in every private embrace and public encounter, in the sights and sounds that fill the city seemingly made for love.Jacques becomes a slave to his passion. He carries next to his heart a tape recorder that in his own voice repeats the girl's name, Marthe, as if that were his heart's beating. But he has always been a slave to love, and even before Marthe, he has walked entranced through a Paris that is defined by its young girls' glances.Jacques among the girls of Paris is a sequence that in its balletic purity directly recalls the great theft sequences of "Pickpocket," (1959), also set in Paris and also, in a sense, a study of an artist transformed by a woman's love.But the new sequence is also very funny  not an achievement one usually associates with Bressonand, in general, the theme of love has released not only the director's graciousness but also his wit, so that whole scenes together have an emotional complexity to match their deep, refreshing cinematic purity.I doubt that "Four Nights of a Dreamer" is Bresson's greatest movie, but it may well be his loveliest. Time and again, it is shockingly beautiful, and I can think of nothing in recent films so ravishing as his strange romantic vision of the city, the river, the softly lighted tourist boats in the night.

title: Travel Notes: On Autumn Foliage, Winter Olympics, Tours for Women
description: NATURE seems to have decided to cooperate with the revised holiday calendar. By arriving a little late in Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine this year, fall managed to postpone the customary lateSeptember turning of the leaves, and if predictions of official spotters in those states hold true the peax period for viewing this year's foliage spectacular will continue throughout this week and well into next. Such thoughtful rearranging of nature's habits enabled many travelers to plan leafpeeking trips for the long Columbus Day weekend, which winds up tomorrow and results from the shift of the holiday from Oct. 12 to the in October.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: LOS ANGELES  William R. Tincher, chairman and president of the Purex Corporation, believes in the principle of management by exception: decentralize management and deal only with the problem areas.

title: STARS AID DRIVE TO SAVE A HOTEL
description: A weeklong campaign to save the 70yearold Ansonia Hotel from demolition was capped yesterday afternoon with a program of entertainment on West 73d Street that attracted people from throughout the city.

title: Local
description: Tilden, obviously up for the game, stopped Lafayette's 13game winning streak yesterday in a Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League game, 113. The last time Lafayette lost was in 1969. The opponent? Tilden.

title: CHICO HAMILTON TAKES JAZZ LEAD
description: For the last 16 years, Chico Hamilton's jazz groups have been in the vanguard of the jazz movement of the moment, whether it involved the subtle directions of his quintets of the 1950's in which cello, guitar and flute were blended, or the slashing, aggressive combos of the 1960's, which brought to light such innovative jazz personalities as Charles Lloyd and Arnie Lawrence on saxophone and Gabor Szabo and Larry Coryell on guitar. Mr. Hamilton now has a new groupa quartet called Chico Hamilton and The Playersthat is following in this same forwardlooking&tradition.

title: Miss Carol L. Greenblatt Is Affianced
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 9Mr. and Mrs. David Greenblatt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Lynn Greenblatt, to Michael Bruce Cagner, son of Mr. arid Mrs. Nathan Cagner of New York. A winter wedding is planned.

title: ORIOLES' 3 HOMERS DEFEAT PIRATES, 53, IN OPENER;
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9The Baltimore Orioles, picking up where they left off, knocked out Dock Ellis inside three innings today and scored a 53 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the opening game of the 68th World Series.

title: Some Crosstown Bases To Co to 41st St. Depot
description: Starting tomorrow, every other M3 (49th50th Street) crosstown bus will be rerouted to begin or end its run at the Port Authority bus terminal, 41st Street and Eighth Avenue, an weekdays from 7 A.M. to 11 P.M.

title: A Popular Setting for Philanthropy The Store Fashion Show
description: The champagne glasses tinkle, the blackuniformed waiters circulate with finger foods and the beautiful people mill gracefully, quirking an eyebrow in delighted glances of recognition or touching cheeks with fashionable little kisses.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS STRESS ECONOMICS
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9The black delegates to next year's Democratic National Convention will, in the end, support the Democratic Presidential candidate who has a specific plan for black economic development, the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson says.

title: Get Ready, Get Set, Park!
description: The voice on the phone was very polite. Good morning, sir. Are you the owner of an automobile, license number XK7041?

title: EssexUnion
description: Two major Essex County powers, East Orange and Bloomfield, suffered upsets in intersectional contests yesterday.

title: Venereal Disease Increasing Among High School Students Here
description: The vaunted sexual sophistication of the modern teenager is a myth, according to health officials who are struggling to suppress an epidemic of venereal disease.

title: Music
description: IN 1948, when Metronome magazine ran a historical, if premature, obituary on 52d Street, it noted: Even today, when you leave a musician and say, See you on The Street tonight, he doesn't have to ask you which street you mean. For that matter, in 1948 and for a score of years before then, neither did the average cabdriver. If you flagged a taxi in New York and asked to be taken to The Street, you would be driven, without giving a number or avenue, to 52d between Fifth and Sixth Avenues.

title: Connecticut
description: Stamford and New Canaan raised their records to 40 and Stamford Catholic pulled the upset of the season in a 24.13 victory over Roger Ludlowe of Fairfield yesterday.

title: Jackson Making a Strong Plea For Jewish Funds and Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9In the offices of a Zionist organizad tion here is a file cabinet containing the records on questions of importance to Israel of every member of Congress, as well as other Government officials.

title: TV News:
description: The ad appeared on the TV pages of the city's newspapers all week long. No flowers, it says: He's a straight shooter who believes that news is too vital to be fooled with. And once you start diluting the facts to make them more palatable, their meaning gets muddled. Jim figures there's room in the news for humor all right but only when it's genuine. That way, the laughter you hear won't be hollow.

title: RESEARCH EXTENDED ON A SPACE SHUTTLE
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 9 (UPI)  The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has delayed the development of its planned space shuttle for six months to give aerospace companies more time to study various ideas of what it should look like.

title: Filion Wins 4 at Freehold; Afton Rooster Takes Pace
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 9Herve Filion won four races at Freehold Raceway today, including the $10,000 Washington Pace with Afton Rooster.

title: Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: OnceFamed Road Lies Forgotten by Most
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.Christian Ernst pointed to the path in his tiny front garden here where hundreds of cars paused daily more than 30 years ago to pay the tolls of the Vanderbilt Long Island Motor Parkway.

title: Uptown Concerts at McMillin Begin With Stravinsky Works
description: Given Manhattan's already bountiful supply of concerts, one might think that the last thing needed was yet another new series. But one called Uptown Concerts began at Columbia University's McMillin Theater Friday night and attracted an audience of good size for a program of Stravinsky works.

title: TopRanked Nebraska Trounces Missouri, 360;
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 9 (UPI)  Jeff Kinney pounded over for two touchdowns in the second quarter today as Nebraska pushed Missouri around en route to a 360 victory before a sellout crowd of 61,200.

title: Goodby Cottage, Goodby Summer
description: IT'S that time of year when families fortunate enough to own summer cottages wonder when they should close up for the winter. We rented the place we own from midAugust through Labor Day, so were confined to the city during the last long hot (lays. We vowed then that we'd keep the house open this year until late fall. We pictured ourselves taking walks along the deserted beaches to gather shells and marvel at the clear light of autumn.

title: EDUCATOR LOSES PUERTO RICO POST
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 9Jaime Benitez, a wellknown figure in national and international educational circles, was dismissed yesterday as president of the University of Puerto Rico.

title: Recordings
description: HEIFETZ was 70 this year. Heifetz, the ultracool dazzler who seemed effortlessly to sweep us through the great violin literature with an lan bordering on the cocky, began his seventh decade last Februray 2. In his prime, a period which must have lasted almost 60 years, Heifetz was the paragon of violinists. A white hot temperament burned just beneath an icy control. What it was at all possible to do on or with the violin, Jascha Heifetz could do, and do without being vulgar. To see the shortish man with the sad and sombre face plant his feet just so on stage and sail into a concert, never seeming to budge from the spot, never going into showmanlike gyrations and meanwhile stroking magic from the violin with his bow, was a thrill incomparable during his long rule over the concert stage. He kept them coming back, sitting on the edges of their seats, and buying his records almost from the time of his Carnegie Hall debut, in 1917, to today. The concerts have all but stopped, but the recordings go on.

title: Federal Drive on Pornography Is Stepped Up, but Cities Appear More Lenient
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 9Recent Supreme Court decisions upholding the constitutionality of Federal obscenity laws plus the encouragement of the Justice Department have produced an upsurge in Federal prosecutions of pornographic books and movies.

title: Asian Studies to Be Stressed At New Center at St. John's
description: An increasing American interest in Asian affairs is being reflected on the campus of St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, where ground was broken recently for the Dr. Sun Yatsen Memorial Hall, a $1million structure that will house the university's center of Asian Studies.

title: Reader's Report
description: As the story opens, our heroine is a homely mixedup girl. After an auto accident and plastic surgery, she turns into a beautiful mixedup girl. What is the author trying to tell us? I'm not entirely sure, but she does a vivid job of it, full of bright gag humor. Plain Jane Falconer is a clever interior designer awash in trauma. Her new face puts her in possession of a code of hollow values that conflict with the soapopera ideals for which she admittedly longs. Can one of the Beautiful People find true happiness with the man she loved before she was beautiful? Don't ask me.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE NIXON Administration has now drafted a basic blueprint for controlling inflation in Phase Two of its economic stabilization program that bears promise of a reasonable measure of success, if it attracts the broad cooperation and support from all segments society that the President has sought.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: No Open House Today
description: It was inadvertently reported in last Sunday's issue that an open house would be held today at the Queensborough Community College. The open house was held last week.

title: Environment
description: It was, said Michael Hess, chief of the civil division in the United States Attorney's office in New York, one of the most successful enforcement proceedings brought by the Government in the history of environmental law. Last December, the Government filed a civil complaint against General Motors Corporation, charging that for years its North Tarrytown plant had been pouring oil, greases, noxious salts, toxic metals and other pollutants into the Hudson River. Last week, Mr. Hess appeared in Federal District Court in New York to report that no further action in the proceedings to be necessary.

title: Preps
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 9Sid Evans's running and Brandon Trotter's passing helped Deerfield Academy to a 320 victory over Vermont Academy today. It was the second straight triumph for Deerfield.

title: Reader's Report
description: This is the second of Jack Ansell's parables on the susceptibility of Jewish husbands to Southern shihses. The focus is again Mannerville, La., which is to the author what Jefferson, Miss., was to Faulkner  a place where traditions collide with multiple damages. In Mannerville, a young Reform rabbi named Jacob Weiss meets Jo Ellen (Jelly) Johnson, age 19, a Baptist clergyman's daughter dedicated to living up to her nickname. For Jelly, Weiss leaves his wife and his New Orleans rabbinate and becomes a piano player in a Bourbon Street saloon. The story thereafter hinges on his inability to escape from his past, and on Jelly's attempt to hers.

title: DRUG USE LINKED TO HEART ATTACK
description: SEATTLE. Oct. 9A 23yearold woman is recuperating here from a heart attack that her doctors said they strongly suspected had resulted from an overdose of speed, or amphetamines, which she had injected into her veins.

title: Michael Frawley, 69, Dies; ExPresident of B.T. Babbitt
description: CHATHAM TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 9Michael P. Frawley, president of B. T. Babbitt, the cleanser concern, from 1960 to 1964, died Thursday of a heart ailment at his home here. His age was 69.

title: Stamps
description: AN old English ballad and a nativity scene dating to about 1510 will be utilized for designs for two United States 8cent Christmas stamps to be released at Washington on Nov. 10, and elsewhere in the country on the following day. Both stamps will be multicolored and produced by gravure on the Andreotti press at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing, Washington.

title: Japanese Go to the Hustings Here
description: The other day in Chicago, John D. Gray, the chairman of HartSchaffner & Marx, told a blueribbon panel of Japanese executives to stop acting as a defeated nation.

title: Free School in Maine Town Weathers 2 Years
description: ROBBINSTON, Me., Oct. 9 It is not often that a state commissioner of education will take time out to speak at a ceremony honoring the establishment of a school that is only two years old, that is housed in part of an abandoned sardine factory and that has only 31 students, from kindergarten to the eighth grade, and five teachers.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: PITT'S BIG FINISH TOPS NAVY, 3635
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (UPI) Dave Havern, the smallest man on the field, threw a 6yard touchdown pass to Leslie Block with 27 seconds remaining today to give Pitt a 3635 victory over Navy.

title: COMPANY DROPPED IN MEDICAID FRAUD
description: An ambulette transportation company and its two principal officers hive been suspended from the city's Medicaid program, Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin announced yesterday. He said evidence had been found indicating the company submitted bills for transporting people who were dead or already in a hospital.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: KNOXVILLE, Oct. 9 (AP)George Hunt kicked a 20yard field goal today to help Tennessee to a 106 college football victory over Georgia Tech.

title: Golden Egg Overdone
description: As the parimutuel merrygoround whirls faster and faster, the battle for the horseplayers' dollar grows fiercer.

title: If You Gave Mickey Mouse $400Million, fere's How He'd Spend
description: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla.My first glimpse of Walt Disney Worldthe gigantic city of fun that opened its gates to the public here last weekendwas of the delicate spires and turrets of a fanciful medieval castle reaching over the treetops a couple of miles away like beckoning fingers. It was a tantalizing sight. Yet I confess to having harbored a subversive thought as I stepped aboard the snazzy aluminum monorail that would whisk me from the parking lot to the Magic Kingdomthe amusement park at the center of this hotel and resort complex here in central Florida. It's going to be a long day, I told myself, and I wonder just how much of this Mickey Mouse I'll be able to take.

title: The Saturday Night Special And Other Hardware
description: WASHINGTON. GUN buffs who favor unfettered ownership of firearms consider Mayor Lindsay to be something of a crank because he accuses the Federal Government of total permissiveness regarding gun traffic nationally. He's just sore, they say, because this year he has had to attend the funerals of eight New York policemen who were killed with handguns, most of them bought outside the city. But after all, that's only eight out of 31,500 men on the force.

title: Preps
description: WEST ISLIP, L. I., Oct. 9Rich Unterstein, a defensive tackle, recovered a fumbled lateral in the end zone in the first period today and St. John the Baptist went on to beat Holy Trinity, 140, in a Long Island Division Catholic High School Football League game.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: S.P.C.A. Gets Part of Bequest
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., Oct. 9 (UPI)  The San Francisco Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals has been awarded $700,000 from a $6million bequest by George Whitten, an animal lover. Superior Judge James T. O'Keefe Jr. ended nearly two years of litigation yesterday by declaring that the S.P.C.A. could receive the sum. There were 151 claimants for the $6million. The judge said the executors would decide how to divide the rest.

title: Women without men, except to kill for fun and survival
description: From the start, French novelist Monique Wittig has had powerful champions. In her collection of essays, The Writing on the Wall, Mary McCarthy devoted an entire chapter to Miss Wittig's first novel, The Opoponax. Lt was, she wrote, the book I've argued for  and about most this year. . . . The novel was also hailed by Marguerite Duras. Alain RobbeGrillet described it as one of the most interesting and exciting ventures in contemporary literature. It was awarded the 1964 Prix Mdicis. At the time it was written, the author was only 28.

title: SOVIET MOON CAR ENDS ITS TRAVELS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9The Soviet Union announced today that remotecontrolled moon rover, the Lunokhod 1, had ceased function after a lifetime of 10 months, which far exceeded initial expectations.

title: Bug bombs in Williamsburg
description: Morris Renek's third novel begins with this sentence: When you're a nobody, violence gives you  at last! a sense of accomplishment. Two pages later, we find the proposition is to be tested:

title: James Goldman Becomes Fiance Of Miss Kreeger
description: Miss Elizabeth Rose Kreeger, who is in her final year at the New York University School of Medicine, plans to be married next month to James E. Goldman, who is studying there for medical and Ph.D. degrees.

title: Arizona State's Long Runs Rout Colorado State, 420
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Oct. 9 (UPI)  Long runs by Ben Malone and Monroe Eley today helped Arizona State overwhelm Colorado State University, 420, In a Western Athletic Conference game. Malone dashed for 55 and 87 yards and Eley for 73 and 43. However neither of them scored.

title: Music
description: LAST August the executive council of Lincoln Center decided it wanted a coordinator and developer of the center's communityrelations programs. John Mazzola, the center's managing director, listed the qualifications needed by whoever should fill the post: He should be knowledgeable in the arts, have an awareness of community needs, be respected by minorityand majoritygroups, know how to organize. Mazzola mulled over the list for a while and then said with a certain amount of wonder, You know, the man is right here.

title: BRITISH SEE CHILL IN TIES TO SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9British diplomats foresaw a serious chill for several months in relations with the Soviet Union, described as being at their lowest point in more than a decade following Soviet retaliation for Britain's expulsions of Russian diplomats and commercial representatives.

title: FACTS SHOW PIRATES FALTER ON MOUND
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9Pittsburgh's World Series pitching was right on schedule today: not very effective. In 18 previous World Series games, in 1925, 1927 and 1960, Pirate pitchers had allowed an average of 5.7 runs and 10.4 hits a game. Today's totals were five runs and 10 hits.

title: Kansas Triumphs, 3913
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 9 (UPI)A sophomore quarterback, David Jaynes, earned himself a starting jobby riffling three touchdown passes in spearheading Kansas to a 3913 rout of Kansas State before a Kansas homecoming crowd of 51,617, the largest to watch a sporting event in the state's history.

title: Republicans Challenged In Three East End Towns
description: The Republicans are being challenged from both the right and the left in what are traditionally safe G.O.P. areas in the races for town offices in the ruralresort Towns of Southampton, East Hampton and Shelter Island.

title: KNICKS WIN, 112100 FROM A.B.A. COLONELS
description: LOUISVILLE, Oct. 9The New York Knickerbockers closed out their preseason schedule tonight by beating the Kentucky Colonels, 112100, before 12,238 at Freedom Hall.

Sheffield United Bows, 32, and Drops From Soccer Lead

title: 2 WYOMING PASSES DOWN ARIZONA, 143
