description: EASTON, Pa., Oct. 9 (AP)Unbeaten Delaware took a tighter grip on the Lambert Cup by overwhelming Lafayette, 490 today before 11,000 fans at Fisher Field.

title: Walking to Wisdom
description: Ars longa, vita brevis. Even at my age of 85, I continue to learn every day. I wish that while still possessing the knowledge and wisdom acquired during these many years (which seem so few to me now), I might be a young physician again, hoping to enjoy life even more than I have enjoyed my present life now drawing to a close. In lieu of that I shall, like so many other senior counselors of every age, set down some thoughts, based on a long and full experience as a physician, which may, I hope, be useful to the restoration of health and happiness which this world needs so much.

title: FORDHAM IS ROUTED BY ITHACA, 39 TO 6
description: Ithaca College, on the quarterbacking of Doug Campbell rolled to a 396 triumph over Fordham University yesterday at the Rose Hill campus.

title: Miss Savage Plans Bridal
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 9Mr. and Mrs. John Richard Savage have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elspeth Virginia Savage, to David White Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelly Campbell of Brookmont, Md.

title: The Gallic mind deciphered for New Yorkers
description: For nearly five decades, one of the major pleasures in leafing through the glossy pages of The New Yorker, aside from the effervescent cartoons, an occasional plum by S. J. Perelman and the squabblepolemics of Edmund Wilson and Volodya Nabokov, has been the elegantly informative Letter From Paris, succinctly signed: Genet (with a circumflex and lending the name distinction before Jean came along). In that period Janet Flanner has been deciphering the Gallic mind and the Parisian way of life to informed New Yorkeroriented Americans in a precise, aristocratic prose that manages to catch in its fine web the glories and vagalife.

title: Driver Shoots 3 in Motorcycle Club, Then Flees
description: Three members of a Queens motorcycle club were shot last night by a motorist they confronted' after he nearly ran down a woman in Ozone Park, according to the police.

title: Dance: Pittsburgh Ballet in New Home
Tad Clawson Weds Miss Stillson
description: MENDHAM TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 9Miss Virginia Gail Stillson and Tad Robert Clawson were married here this afternoon in the Brookside Community Church by the Rev. Donald Norton MacKenzie, a Congregational minister.

title: LAKELAND TAKES 3D BEST IN WEEK
description: BRYN MAWR Pa., Oct. 9James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., is a firm believer in lucky omens. Yesterday, when his Lakeland terrier, Ch. Special Edition, was named best in show at the Hatboro Dog Clubs event, he wore a green suit, green hat and green tie.

title: Marie L. Brenner Prospective Bride
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 9The engagement of Miss Marie Long Brenner to Marvin Earle Lesser, has been announced by her parents, Milton Conrad Brenner, president and chief executive officer of SoloServe Company, Inc., a departmentstore chain here and Mrs. Brenner. Mr. Lesser is a son of S. K. Lesser, an optometrist, and Mrs. Lesser of Fort Worth.

title: Jerome Grant Fiance Of Patricia Seligman
description: Miss Patricia Anne Seligman plans to be married Dec. 11 at the Plaza to Jerome D. Grant, who is with the New York law firm of Shea, Gould, Climenko & Kramer.

title: Robert Chiger to Wed Beth Jakubovitz
description: The engagement of Miss Beth Susan Jakubovitz to Robert Chiger, son of Rabbi Morris Chiger and Mrs. Chiger of the Bronx, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome R. Jakubovitz of the Bronx and Long Beach, L. I.

title: Wide SovietHanoi Accord Initiated by Podgorny Visit
description: HONG KONG, Sunday, Oct. 10North Vietnam and the Soviet Union have set up a joint committee that will work out details of longterm economic, trade, cultural, scientific and technological relations between the two countries.

title: New Medal Features Pandora
description: PANDORA, the creation of Greek mythology, provided the artists inspiration for the medallion to be released this month by The Society of Medalists. The specimen will be the 84th in the series, issued twice yearly, by the Society. The Pandora piece is the work of Elbert Weinberg, Boston sculptor, who was one of the prize winners in a nationwide design competition sponsored by The Medalists in 1970.

title: Licensed Hitchhikers?
description: HITCHHIKERS are a damn nuisance, grumbled a New York State highway patrolman one recent weekend. But then he added, Of course, you just can't get rid of them. He seemed to be voicing a view commonly held these days.

title: Tufts Downs Norwich, 44221
description: NORTHFIELD, Vt., Oct. 9 (AP)Tufts capitalized on four miscues in the first half and scored on two long runs in the second to heat Norwich, 4422, today.

title: A Woman's Place Is in the Oven
description: ONE of the most valuable qualities of television is its ability to keep us in touch with the past. Tune in any time and there, in the form of countless old movies, the American past, unadorned and without comment, unwinds before our eyes. The movies of the past 40 years provide a history of what this country was thinking, feeling, valuing, admiring and condemning at any given time. The message may not be at all what was intended, since time has a way of distilling intentions until only actualities remain. But intended or not, the message is there and it is ours if we sit back and bear with the commercial interruptions.

title: The Nation
description: Gentlemen, history awaits you, Simeon Gofer, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, said in introducing the three tall men seated around him on the dais at the 27th annual dinner of New York's Liberal party. History might have been too grand a wordalthough Edmund S. Muskie, George McGovern and John V. Lindsay smiled when it was said. What awaits them right now are hundreds of similar hotel dinners as they struggle through the longest preconvention campaign in the history of American Presidential politics.

title: Nuptials for Molly Morck
description: GLEN ROCK, N.J., Oct. 9 Miss Molly Ann Morck, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Roland A. Morck, was married in the Glen Rock Community Church this afternoon to Wayne Thompson Bonhag, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vincent Bonhag. The Rev. Verne Dethmers performed the Dutch Reformed ceremony.

title: News of the Rialto
description: DO you yearn for the days when musicals were mostly fun and you came out of the theater humming love songs instead of dolefully ruminating upon the inadequacies of human relationships? Did you have a good time at such musicals as Guys and Dolls, How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying (it won a Pulitzer), Can Can and Silk Stockings, all of which it just happens Abe Burrows wrote or directed or both and Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin produced?

title: Closed and open
description: Houses have changed drastically since pioneer days when windows were purposely small and dwellings were designed to protect their owners from hard New England winters. In this yearround house in East Hampton (where examples of those earlier homes still exist) the architect, David Specter, balanced two opposing interests: on the one hand, sheltered comfort; on the other, a maximum exposure to the seasons changing spectacle outdoors. He varied ceiling heights, employed skylights and slanted windows, contrasting the sense of openness with more enclosed areas where the family could relax in snug surroundings. Windows frame the views and, on the exterior, enliven the boxlike design. Designer Dolores Engel chose natural textures and neutral colors to lend warmth to the inviting rooms.

title: Preps
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Oct. 9Locust Valley Friends rolled to a 200 lead at the half enroute to a 260 victory over visiting Trinity today.

title: Ala, to dent in Englan
description: IT was fall a year ago, I had five and a half months to get away from It all on vacation, and my objective was to find a cozy place to settle In for a leisurely, winter sabbatical in the English countryside.

title: Where the Sluggers Meet the Fans
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.I can't wait to see the bat that Babe Ruth used, the first visitor in line for the morning tour of the Hillerich & Bradsby plant here announced.

title: U.S. Mayors Visit a Polish University but Fail to Learn Much
description: WROCLAW, Poland, Oct. 9A group of visiting American mayors sought today, with limited success, to learn how Poland solves her problems of university education.

title: Miss Anneke Knoppers Is Fiancee
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 9Dr. Antonie T. Knoppers, president of Merck & Co., Inc., manufacturing chemists in Rahway, and Mrs. Knoppers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anneke Cornelie Knoppers, to R. Craig Woodward. He is the son of Dr. Theodore E. Woodward, professor of medicine at the University of Maryland Medical School, and Mrs. Woodward of Baltimore. The wedding is planned for Dec. 11.

title: Cognac Sales Up 20% In 1970, French Report
description: PARIS, Oct. 9World sales of cognac increased by 20 per cent last year according to a report by the industry this week.

title: Wash.Jeff Wins, 3530
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 9 (UPI)  Unbeaten Washington and Jefferson outlasted John Carroll, 3530, today in an offensive duel featuring four touchdowns by W. and J.'s highscoring running back, Rich Pocock.

title: Photography
description: COMPACT rangefinder version of Yashica's Electro35 has recently been introduced. Called the Electro35CC, It comes with a wide angle 35mm lens and the same type of automatic electronic shutter with an infinite range of speeds from eight seconds to 1/250th of a second. A CdS sensor in the lens barrel automatically presets the lens aperture (from f/1.8 to f/16) and the shutter speed to match the light available so that all the user need do is focus and press the shutter release button. The 35CC also has an exposure symbol that lights up in the viewfinder with a red signal for and yellow one for a slow shutter speed (indicating a tripod is needed or that the aperture ring should be turned to a wideropening). Priced at under $130, the Yashica35CC is less than 4 inches wide.

title: Agriculture Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Harry S. McAlpin, a career Government lawyer, was named this week as the Agriculture Department's first Negro hearing examiner. Mr. McAlpin, 65 years old, has been an examiner for the Social Security Administration since 1968.

title: SOVIET EXPLOITS UNDERSEA ORES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9  The Soviet Union says it is making important gains in the exploitation of subsea mineral resources, with a commercial tindredging operation under way off the north coast of Siberia.

title: West Coast Longshoremen Obey Writ, Return to Job
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (AP)Longshoremen returned to work at West Coast ports today under court order and slowly began the huge task of unloading carib from nearly 250 ships that have been sitting idle for up to 100 days during the dock strike.

title: Wisconsin U. Becomes Third Largest in Nation
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 9 (AP)Gov. Patrick J. Lucey has signed a bill making the University of Wisconsin the third largest institution of higher education in the United States.

title: Namath to Start Drills, Hopes to Play Oct. 31
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Oct. 9  Improvement in the nerve damage that has affected Joe Namath's left foot will permit the Jets'; quarterback to begin light workouts next week for the first time since he required knee surgery two months ago.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Businessmen traditionally have held a dual attitude toward making their voices heard in matters involving the Federal Government.

title: Miss Italiano Has Wedding
description: EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass., Oct. 9Miss Theresa Marie Italiano and Richard Joseph Murphy were married here at noon today. The Rev. Robert J. Coonan performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Ohio Liquor Control Board Is Facing a Price Dilemma
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 9 (UPI)Ohio's Liquor Control Board faces a dilemma in a confrontation with the Federal Cost of Living Council.

title: L.I. Biologists Puzzled By Fish Kill Mystery
description: The fish kills that plagued the North Shore last summer destroyed thousands of mer destroyed thousands of menhaden, and scientists say that there seems to he little that can be done to prevent recurrences because the exact cause remains unknown.

title: Marriage Planned By Beverly Gottlieb
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 9Mr. and Mrs. Murray Gottlieb have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Gottlieb, to Jonathan A. Schnitzer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jeshaia Schnitzer of Montclair.

title: Peggy Jones, Army Officer Wed in Jersey
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 9Miss Margaret Boone Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenyon Blackwell Jones of Upper Montclair and Chilmark, Mass., and Lieut. Carl William Desch Jr., U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Desch of Garden City., L.I., were married here this afternoon by the Rev. James O. Gilliom of the Union Congregational Church.

title: Pitch n Putt Rates Cut By City for the Elderly
description: The Parks Department has announced a reduction of fees from $1.50 to $1, beginning Oct. 1, for elderly people who use its two pitch n put golf courses in Queens.

title: 2 Big Banks From City Expanding To Suffolk
description: To tap the lucrative market of Suffolk County, Chase Manhattan and First National City Banks are heading eastward. But they're entering the county through the back door, establishing new subsidiaries rather than opening additional branches to meet the requirements of a new state law.

title: Miss Gail Sadler Gillies Bride In Fairfield of Henry B. Smith
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 9 Miss Gail Sadler Gillies and Henry Beale Smith were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Stanley Lyons Houston performed the ceremony in the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church.

title: POLISH TEACHERS TO GET INCREASES
description: WARSAW, Oct. 9Poland's 400,000 teachers and college faculty members will be the first professional group to receive a major wage increase since Edward Gierek became the Communist party leader after the economic riots last December.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: EXPERTS DIVIDED ON SPECIAL PRISON
description: New York state's plan to establish a maximummaximum security prison for 500 to 600 hardened and dangerous offenders in the aftermath of the Attica revolt has generated little unqualified support from penologists and prison officials around the country.

title: Art
description: THE air of relaxed and confident old age that pervades the exhibition of 61 prints by the 80yearold American painter, Mark Tobey, now on view at the Whitney Museum, is one of the more ingratiating features of the show. The work covers the past ten years and ranges through a variety of graphic techniques  lithography, intaglio, aquatint  moving readily in style and subject matter from pure abstraction to delicate figure studies. It represents a minor and less doctrinaire aspect of Tobey's art than his more famous paintings paintings which ordinarily invite a good deal of philosophical explanationand in this respect, the Whitney show makes the work seem more accessible than is often the case.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Sylvia Plath playing Pygmalion to her own Galatea
description: Though this book, as Elizabeth Hardwick remarked recently, is by no means Sylvia Plath's best, it forms a chapter of her poetic life. In these poems, written between 1960 and late 1961 and antedating Ariel, the poet plays Pygmalion to her own Galatea, willing herself into shape, struggling against the inherited outlines of her predecessors. There are very grotesque stages along the way, as in some larval metamorphosis: the roaringram disguise of Dylan Thomas; babbling exclamatory whispersinthepottingshed after the manner of Theodore Roethke; duets between heaven and earth in Stevensian orchestration; and many plaintive familial brutalities learned from Lowell. What exhausting costumes these were, and how heavy, and how distasteful to Sylvia Plath's soul we can only judge from her persistent attempts to shed these skins, and finally, in Ariel and some later poems, to transcend them. Meanwhile, here, she rages about in these disguises like some rebellious adolescent dressed by her mother in unsuitable clothes.

title: For Whom the Festival Tolls?
description: IN terms of the lunatic variety of new and old films presented regularly by its commercial theaters and such noncommercial establishments as the Museum of Modern Art. Anthology Film Archives and the Whitney Museum. New York is probably the richest movie city in the world, not even surpassed by Paris, which has the extraordinary Cinemathque Francaise. This fact, paradoxically, puts a terrible burden on the annual New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center, the 9th edition of which is nine days old as you read this, but only two days old as I write, which relieves me of the burden of attempting at this point, to predict whether it will be an artistic success or a flop.

title: Daughter for Spitzes
description: A daughter was born to Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Spitz of San Francisco on Sept. 23 at the Children's Hospital in San Francisco. Mrs. Spitz is the former Miss Harriet J. Widmann, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Marcis Widmann of Riverdale, the Bronx. The child has been named Jenni Elaine.

title: The Hemisphere
description: WASHINGTON  A week after President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile acted to expropriate Americanowned copper assets without compensation, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Henry Kissinger, the White House national security adviser, finally managed to find time for separate meetings last Monday and Thursday with Chile's Foreign Minister. Washington's delay in holding discussions underlines the critical differences in the way in which both countries are treating the problem.

title: M. B. Cagner Fiance Of Carol Greenblatt
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Oct. 9Mr. and Mrs. David Greenblatt have announced, the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Lynn Greenblatt, to Michael Bruce Cagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Cagner of New York. A winter wedding is planned.

title: U.S. TIGHTENS RULE ON FREE WITCHES
description: A new Federal regulation will cut off free lunches for 350,000 of the 390,000 city school children now getting these lunches, the head of the program said yesterday.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES FELLOW DEMOCRATS
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 9 CAP) Senator Henry M. Jackson, describing himself as a liberal but not a damn fool, says the other Democratic Presidential hopefuls are leaving the American public behind by deemphasizing national security and law and order.

title: U.S. WANTS TO SEE BOOK BY DR. LEARY
description: The State Department has asked a literary agent here to submit to security officials a manuscript by Dr. Timothy Leary perporting to disclose how the protagonist of the drug culture obtained a passport, to flee the United States after escaping from a California prison.

title: Gettysburg 4213 Winner
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 9 (UPI)Norm Hall ran for two touchdowns and rushed for 195 yards today to rally Gettysburg to a 4213 triumph over Albright.

title: City Is Studying Incentive Relief Plans
description: Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said last night that the city administration was still engaged in intensive study of two proposed state relief demonstration projects which have drawn bitter protests from welfare agencies.

title: P.S. 41 Parents Seek to Restore 5 Teachers and Continue Programs by Recruiting 150 More Pupils
description: At a time when overcrowding in most public schools is endangering the quality of instruction, the parents of Public School 41 in Greenwich Village are seeking to preserve what they consider their school's excellent instruction by advertising for 150 more pupils.

title: N.F.L. Game Films a Hit in Europe
description: PARIS, Oct. 9  The thing I miss most about living in Europe is football, Tom Bell once said, and because he said it to Pete Rozelle, there is football in Europe.

title: Francine Lapan Wed
description: The marriage of Miss Francine Jane Lapan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Lapan of the Bronx, to Charles Henry Columbus, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Columbus of Yonkers, took place here yesterday at the 55th Street Synagogue. Rabbi Reuven Siegel performed the ceremony in the presence of the immediate families.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: 7 Police Slain in September, Raising Year's Total to 87
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP)Seven policemen were killed in the line of duty in September, raising to 87 the number of county and state law enforcement officers slain in the first nine months of this year, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has announced.

title: Groping for Standards
description: President Nixon and Secretary of the Treasury Connally have now presented their design of the apparatus to administer Phase Two of the economic stabilization program. They have set as their goal slowing inflation to an annual rate of 2 to 3 per cent by the end 1972. But they have fudged the crucial question what principles and standards will be required to reach that objective.

title: Series Rumor Mill: Banks to Succeed Durocher in 1972
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 9One of the ancillary functions of every World Series gathering is the production of rumors. Some of those getting widest circulation here are:

title: Hobart Stays Unbeaten
description: CLINTON, N. Y., Oct. 9 (AP) Undefeated Hobart rallied on a 73yard kickoff return by Don Aleksicwitcz to take the lead from Hamilton and go on to 2820 victory today. The triumph was Hobart's third.

title: Bergen
description: Ridgewood's sixgame winning streak ended yesterday in a surprising 442 loss to previously nonwinning Paramus, but Passaic Valley remained unbeaten with a 226 victory over Bergenfield.

title: RUSSIANS ALERTED ON HOUSING RUSES
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 9It all began at the Jubilee Restaurant when a waitress named Masha asked a waitress named Glasha to introduce her to the builder with the monogrammed briefcase who dined every evening on caviar and fine cognac and left a 3ruble tip.

title: No Homecoming Queen
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Oct. 9 (AP) The Student Senate at North Carolina State University has voted, 32 to 24, not to provide funds for a homecoming queen contest this football season. Gus Gusler, president of the Student Senate, said, The homecoming queen tradition has been dying for the past several years and there is now very little interest among students or alumni.

title: Nassau North
description: The Blue Dragons of Levittown Division and the Green Dragons of Westbury met in Nassau North Shore Division III game yesterday and the Green Dragons were the ones breathing fire. Westbury won, 100, in la rugged match that saw Division suffer a defeat for only the second time in three seasons.

title: ATHENS RULES OUT PRESSURE BY U.S.
description: ATHENS, Oct. 9Greece's militarybacked regime suggested today it had no objection to discussing domestic problems with Vice President Agnew, but it ruled out all forms of pressure for speeding the restoration of Greek democracy, suspended since 1967.

title: Child Abuse Panel Gives Report in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)  The Governor's Committee on Child Abuse has reported that more than 7,200 cases of child abuse and severe neglect occur each year in Massachusetts, and that only about 200 of them are reported to the state.

title: St. John's Club Eleven Sinks Duquesne, 3512
description: St. John's routed Duquesne. 3512, in a meeting of two of the East's top club football teams yesterday with a homecoming day crowd of 2.500 looking on at St. John's Jamaica campus field.

title: Growing Up Catholic In MidCentury America
description: GROWING up Catholic in midcentury America was both absurd and marvelous. Absurd, because as I look back from a distance of 20 years, I see a world of changeless truth, simple moral choices and nodding assent that seems as distant from contemporary reality as the age when crossbreasted Crusaders whacked heathen skulls in the name of Jesus Christ. It was a time when priests went to Wednesdaynight bingo instead of to peace marches, nuns wore their skirts to the floor and nobody disagreed with the Pope. Rock and jazz were for bars, not churches, ecumenism was treason and as for priests who wanted to marryGod forbid!

title: Moore, Oregon Tailback, Eager to Face Washington
description: Robert Earl Moore, an allAmerica with a bundle of offensive records at Oregon, wants to spend New Year's Day in the Rose Bowl and then have a shot at pro football.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To The EDITOR:

title: $100Million Ford Grant To Aid Minority Education
description: The Ford Foundation announced yesterday a sixyear, $100million program to improve the quality of a limited number of predominantly Negro private colleges and to provide various minority students with individual study awards at most types of institutions.

title: MANHATTAN WINS IN CREW RACING
description: Manhattan College defeated Atlantic Community today by three lengths in the featured eightoared shell event of the Columbus Day New York Rowing Association regatta on the Orchard Beach Lagoon.

title: Maureen Downey To Marry Feb. 19
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 9  Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Murray Downey of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maureen Elizabeth Downey, to Robert J. McLaughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McLaughlin of Tarrytown. The wedding is planned for Feb. 19.

title: BingharnJackson Grand Juror Says the Prosecutor's Tactics Divided Panel
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 9Resentment against indictments for conspiracy and against a District Attorney's tactics deeply divided the Marin County grand jury and almost prevented the return of a true bill in the Stephen BinghamGeorge Jackson case, a member of the grand jury said here this week.

title: Hertz Sells RentaBikes
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) The Hertz RentaBike business is going out of business, but just for the winter. After a threemonth experiment by the car rental agency in renting 25 bicycles, Bruce Poole, manager of a Hertz office here, said this week that the company sold the bikes because we didn't want the expense of storing them over the winter.

title: Linda Lichten Engaged
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 9 Mr. and Mrs. Burton Lichten have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Robin Lichten, to Edwin Bruce Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Arthur Watson of Beverly Hills, Calif. The future bride is an assitant director of the Greer Gallery in New York. Her fianc is the assistant to the president of Zachary & Front, New York public relations firm.

title: Democrats in Islip Encouraged by G.O.P. Split
description: ISLIP, L. I.A split in the Republican party accompaled by wholesale firings has enlivened the Islip township election campaign and has led the Democrats to appear to be more optimistic than they are normally entitled to be.

title: An Attica Graduate Tells His Story
description: FORGET about that bull zipthree or zipfive or seven year business, the blondhaired young man in charge of D.V.R., Attica's state and federallyfunded vocational rehabilitation programotherwise known as Eblock told me across the desk during my interview for a job assignment there, As an inmate with a bad back, wearing the therapeutic brace I had come in with through Reception, I had a shot at being assigned to this most enlightened project, a segment of the State Correctional Facility (euphemism for Maximum Security Prison), perhaps as an instructor in English, which had once been my profession on the outside.

title: For Young Readers
description: I have always noticed that whenever an exceptionally truthful book is published for children, people declare that it is not for children at all. What they seem to be saying is that truth is the property of adults. Let children be children, and don't burden them with sordid reality. They will have to face life soon enough. Et cetera. Thus I must warn parents, teachers and librarians that A Wild Thing is written with all the depth and perplexity of an adult novel. Its 15yearold heroine experiences a sexual awakening, and there are several scenes of sexual intercourse. The book's ending is harsh and the entire tenor of the work is uncompromising. But A Wild Thing is also an extraordinary work of art.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The imposition of a 10 per cent import surcharge and the proposal to enact an investment tax credit limited to investments in Americanmade equipment are protectionist devices that violate the spirit, if not the letter, of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which we have long supported.

title: Miss von Bergen Wed
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J., Oct. 9 In the First Reformed Church here this morning Miss Susan Anne von Bergen and William John O'Connor, June graduates of Hope College in Holland, Mich., were married by the Rev. E. William Gertner. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Fritz von Bergen of Upper Montclair and Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Connor of New York and Shokan, N.Y.

title: Riva Ridge ($4.80) Wins by 7 Lengths
description: Although he had never raced that far before, Riva Ridge of the Meadow Stable had no trouble with the mile distance in the $195,150 Champagne Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Music
description: IT is unfortunate that the Metropolitan Opera's longawaited revival of Carl Maria von Weber's Der Freischtitzlast heard there in 1929  did not come off more successfully. The production is singularly unimaginative, resembling the efforts of a provincial opera house in Germany. Rudolf Heinrich, who was responsible for the direction, sets and costumes, moved his stage forces in a positively antediluvian fashion. Supers were shuttled around the stage in an artificial fashion. Peasants had to walk in a stifflegged manner; by their walk shall ye know them. Agathe and Aennchen were confined to spaces the size of a dovecote, in a set (crosssection of a room) that was all the rage of 35 years ago.

title: Yale Counts on Pfiel's Aerials To Triumph Over Brown, 1710
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9In its Ivy League opener today Yale discovered a quarterback, Don Pfeil, and gained a 1710 victory over Brown.

title: Springfield Misplays Help Quantico Marines Win, 238
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 9  The Quantico Marines capitalized on three offensive errors and defeated Springfield College, 238, today.

title: L.S.U. Routs Florida
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 9 (AP)Louisiana State's defense stopped Florida in the clutches as the Tigers began defense of their Southeastern Conference title with a 487 victory tonight before 67,055 fans.

title: The World
description: BRIGHTON, England  At the Labor party conference here last week, a leftwing delegate rearmed Royden Harrison, a profolsor at Warwick University, was called on to speak during the Common Market debate. He began by remarking that in his many years as a delegate this was the first time he had ever risen to support a position taken by the party executive.

title: Preps
description: Poly Prep registered its first victory over Horace Mann in five years, 3522, yesterday and extended its winning streak to eight in the process at Poly Prep Field.

title: Legal Prostitution Favored
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 9 (UPI) Councilwoman Maude Shapiro said this week that she favored legalized prostitution to help combat crime. She said she favored a law requiring the licensing of all prostitutes, which would include mandatory, health checkups.

title: Israeli Institute Gets Gift
description: The American Society for TechnionIsrael Institute of Technology announced last night that it had received a $1million gift for use by scholars, in various disciplines at the Technion in Haifa, Israel. Jacob Watler Ullman, president of they Society, with headquarters at 271 Madison Avenue, said the gift had conic from Leo Harvey of Los Angeles, trustee of the Lena P. Harvey Foundation.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Architecture
description: I DON'T know if critics are allowed to be ambivalent. We're supposed to have the answers. I am about to express some personal feelings and guarded opinions about the work and theory of Venturi and Rauch that are in large part favorable, due to my conditioning as an architectural historian.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Settling Suez With Sadat
description: Secretary of State Rogers is trying to combine diplomacy and the art of a master illusionist in the intensive, highly publicized efforts he is making to get Egypt and Israel negotiating on an interim Suez agreement.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: New York's Haitians: Working, Waiting, Watching BB Doc
description: Sitting in a coffee shop at Broadway and 98th Street, almost at the dead center of Manhattan's Haitian community, the young man spoke in a rapid, urgent, angry whisper. But what are you going to write about us? Your American press is so eager to come into our community and find out what doll we stick a needle intothings like that. They are interested only in the folkloric aspects. But they never ask the most important question: Why are these people here? You must ask this because, I assure you, you will not find 10 Haitians who stay because they love New York. If they could go home tomorrow, they would all be on the same boat.

title: U.S. Pair Wins Skating
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 9 (AP)Jane Parkey and Richard Horne of the United States won the gold medal for the pairs dance event for the second straight year in the world roller skating championships tonight with 22 points.

title: Brooklyn Recovers A Great Discoverer
description: A white marble statue of Christopher Columbus, which was misplaced or ignored in its first half century here and overlooked and vandalized for the next four decades, has finally been granted a place of prominence in the Brooklyn Civic Center.

title: WALL STREET
description: Can an economist draw a crowd? He can if his name is Pierre Rinfret, the economist most journalists like to describe as flamboyant.

Persian treat
description: When Iranians and their guests feast in Teheran's tent city this month to celebrate the 2,500th anniversary of the Persian Empire's founding, French cuisine will dominate the royal banquets. Likely to be ignored curiously, will be one of Iran's traditional, and favorite, dishes  khoreshe. It is a stew or sauce usually based on lamb or chicken, with vegetables and/or fruits. When served with Persianstyle rice, it is called chelo khoreshe. Mrs. Fraydun Manocherian of Scarsdale. N. Y., the wife of an Iranian, learned from her motherinlaw these recipes for authentic Iranian dishes.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: It is difficult to understand why visitors to the Munich Tourist Office have to pay for the simplest city map or a calendar of the week's events. We were considering a day's trip from Munich to Berchtesgaden and when we asked for a brochure, that, too, was offered at a price. Are tourists helping to pay the printing costs of Munich's advertising for the Olympics, or what? Americans might be well advised to obtain their information from the German National Tourist Office in New York City where the staff has a reputation for being cooperative and supplying the most detailed informationgratis.

title: E. M. Forster's posthumous novelmore important to the man than to literature
description: With the deaths in recent years of T. S. Eliot, Bertrand Russell and Igor Stravinsky, the world appears nearly to have been picked clean of giants. Of figures of comparable achievement, only Pablo Picasso, soon to be a nonagenarian, still walks the earth. Although Edward Morgan Forster's genius was not so pronouncedly obvious as that of any of these men, it is likely that his death, in June of last year, stirred feelings of a more personal, and hence more profound, kind. Which is as it should be, for no other writer so stressed the overriding importance of personal relationsstressed them so seductively, in fact, that in reading him one felt one had entered into a personal relationship of sorts with Forster himself. Perhaps this has to do, too, with the fact that Forster was the last novelist to tell one, godlike and with enormous artistic success, what to think of his characters; and so in reading his novels one felt the presence of an author who spoke directly to oneself.

title: Productions of a master in a minor art
description: Wilfrid Sheed presents a problem to anyone proposing to review one of his books more or less in good faith. My drugstore editions of his novels are crusted over with reviewers' enthusiastic ravings, the kind that suggest a limited education or backstage payola; but Sheed himself has sardonic words for such goingson in Max Jamison, his novel about the perils of reviewing, and in The Politics of Reviewing, the lead essay in his new collection of criticism of books, films and plays. And I'm somehow supposed to review this book of reviews, by a brilliant reviewer who knows all the tricks and openly despises most of them, in a publication whose editor, John Leonard, has supplied Sheed's book with an exuberant Foreword in which he suggests that he wishes Sheed could write all the reviews for The Times Book Review. One feels pretty threatened even before geginning.

title: the traveler's world
description: REASON and common sense finally prevailed in the halls of the Department of Transportation a couple of days after last week's column, the second in this threepart inquiry into the air bag controversy, had been printed and distributed beyond recall. The D.O.T., in response to urgent pleas from automobile manufacturers, scientists and objective observers who claimed the bag could not be made safely ready by the original Aug. 15, 1973, deadline, reversed itself and delayed compulsory installation of them on all new automobiles sold in the United States for two additional years. They will be necessary on all new cars sold here after Aug. 15, 1975, the beginning of the 1976 automobile model year.

title: Baby, It's Cold Up There
description: THE Eskimos are coming. Or, rather, the Eskimos are staying put and we are going to themwe being the everadventurous Martin Ransohoff and a crew of stalwart, longjohned moviemakers. Producer Ransohoff has purchased rights to White Dawn, James Houston's recent novel about three whalers who were shipwrecked in 1896 and had to come to terms with the Eskimos, their culture and their climate. The film, to be shot in both English and the Eskimo language, will get under way next spring on icecold Baffin Island900 miles from the North Pole, where the reallife events that inspired Houston's novel took place.

title: A treasury of his unpublished songs
description: COLE PORTER wrote Gay Divorce 39 years ago. In it, a young man named Fred Astaire, who smiled out of the side of his face and who practiced weightlessness before most of our astronauts could toddle, played the part of Guy. In a voice as appealing as it was limited, he sang a song that seemed to use an uncommon number of B's (Bnatural seven chords and Bflat seven chords, if you want to be technical about it) which has been identified with him ever since. The song was called Night and Day. It had critics. But who cares now; who remembers that E. Montillion Woolley (Monty Woolley to you) thought it was awful. When Hollywood got around to Gay Divorce in 1934 and called it The Gay Divorcee, Night and Day was in it and Mr. Astaire sang it to Ginger Rogers. So was another song destined to become a standard, The Continental, by Herb Magidson and Con Conrad. Miss Rogers and Mr. Astaire danced to it in an interminable production number which I have now seen 17 times.

title: The 20year history of a sensibility
description: At the end of the second huge volume of Leslie Fiedler's Collected Essays is Chutzpah and Pudeur, a very good and very characteristic piece about two impulses that Fiedler sees lying behind a great many works of art. On the one hand, the chutzpah of I sing or I am Walt Whitman, the brazen impulse, oral and loud; on the other, the pudeur of Let me restrain or I must qualify, the impulse of hiding, anal and cultivated. The essay is characteristic of Fiedler because it ranges widely and easily in its learning and presumptions, and because it seeks new ways to tell old truths. It is good because it finds these ways, as perhaps this shows:

title: Gary Player Beats Nicklaus for Title
description: WENTWORTH, England, Oct. 9Gary Player has won the Piccadilly world matchplay golf championship for the fourth time. The 35yearold South African, trailing by two holes in midmorning and by one hole at lunch, shot a dazzling 32 going out In the afternoon to take the title away from Jack Nicklaus, 5 and 4.

title: Nancy Williams to Be Bride Dec. 18
description: ROOSEVELT, L. I Oct. 9  Announcement hag been made by Mr. and Mrs Otto Walter Williams of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Anita Williams, to James Lewis Henderson, son of Mrs. Robert J. Wagner of Montclair, N. J., and the late Vernel Henderson.

title: Cyclists Wheel Into Bridgehampton Next Week
description: About Motor Sports

title: Police Utilizing a Computer Timer to Catch Speeders
description: Motorists on the nation's highways are discovering that it isn't enough any more to keep an eye out for policemen in their rearview mirroror look for police radar antennae along the roadto avoid a speeding ticket.

description: To the Editor:

title: Millions of Chevrolet Owners To Get U. S. Warning on Safety
description: DETROIT, Oct. 9The Federal Government is about to issue a warning to millions of owners of Chevrolet automobilesa warning about a potential defect that could throw their cars out of control.

title: Navajos Get Radio Station
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission granted yesterday the application of the Ramah Navajo School Board for a new educational FM radio station at Ramah, N. M.

title: Me Too Politics in Long Beach
description: LONG BEACH, L. J.  In the rough and  tumble of Long Beach politics, all the parties are running on the same platform.

title: KENT PINS 2112 LOSS ON TRINITYPAWLING
description: KENT, Conn., Oct. 9Kent scored its second victory of the season today, stopping Trinity Pawling, 2112. Scott Perry starred for the victors with two touchdowns.

title: Article 14  No Title
description: SUFFIELD, Conn., Oct. 9 Taft broke a 66 tie in the final period today when one Sweet caught a 45yard scoring pass from Jim Stone and defeated Suffield, 146. Sweet also scored on a 35yard touchdown run in the third period.

title: Black Nominee Acceptable
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 9 (AP)Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. of California, who seeks to wrest the Republican Presidential nomination from President Nixon in 1972, said today he would be willing to run with a Negro running mate. He spoke to a crowd in the town square.

title: ExAide in Massachusetts To Get $84,000 in Back Pay
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP) Former State Representative John A. Davis of Marblehead, indicted seven years ago on charges of conspiracy to violate the state conflictofinterest law but never prosecuted, has been notified that he is entitled to more than $84,000 in back pay.

title: Trinity Defeats R.P.I., 2319 On Aerial in Final Period
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 9Trinity, after losing a 16point firsthalf lead, swept to its second consecutive victory, defeating Renssalear Polytechnic Institute, 2319, today.

title: OKLAHOMA UPSETS TEXAS;
description: DALLAS, Oct. 9The speed of Oklahoma's Greg Pruitt, who scored three times and ran for 214 yards, offset the brute strength of Texas today incarrying the Sooners to a 4827 victory over the Longhorns.

title: What It Means To Be A Homosexual (Continued)
description: BREWSTER, N. Y.

title: J.E. Durant to Wed Cheryl E. Shockley
description: NORTH BABYLON, L. I., Oct. 9Alonzo Hilton Shockley Jr., director of state and Federal programs for the Freeport public schools, and Mrs. Shockley have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cheryl Emmelyn Shockley, to James Evans Durant, an admissions counselor at the Agricultural and Technical College, State University of New York at Farmingdale. He is the son of Mrs. James Durant of Garden City Park and the late Mr. Durant.

title: ARGENTINE UNITS GIVE UP QUIETLY
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9The rebel officers of two Argentine Army garrisons, who tried to start a revolt against the ruling military regime yesterday afternoon, surrendered quietly early this morning to loyal troops without the firing of a shot.

title: Pamela A. Martens Married to Captain
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 9The marriage of Miss Pamela Anne Martens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Martens, to Capt. Martin Ruffer Gilmartin, U.S.M.C.R., took place in St. Jude's Roman Catholic Church here today The bridegroom is on of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Gilmartin of Southampton, L. I.

title: The World
description: CALCUTTA  When the Bengalis of East Pakistan began crossing the border into India six months ago in flight from civil war, they were greeted by the Bengalis of India with sympathy and tolerance despite the disruptions created by the refugee flood. But life is a survival affair in this corner of the world and magnanimity a luxury that few can afford for long.

title: Prospects Good For a Marshland Park at Udalls Cove
description: Walls Cove, a speck of marshy green on the crowded border between Queens and Nassau Counties, is quiet this fall. Its tall marsh grasses and schools of fingerlings darting about the shallows are disturbed only by the occasional shrill whistle of a Long Island Railroad train as it rumbles into nearby Little Neck station.

title: M'LEE'S TIME BEST IN ROSSCOUNTRY
description: Kevin McLee of Hamilton High, Elmsford, who suffered from mononucleosis in August, posted the fastest clocking yesterday after a thrilling stretch dual in the New York University interscholastic crosscountry run at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: POST VANQUISHES CORTLAND, 4513
description: GRGENVALE, L. L, Oct. 9Gary Wichard completed 17 of 20 passes today for 251 yards in leading C. W. Post to a 4513 football victory over Cortland State. It was Post's third triumph in four outings. Cortland is t and 3.

title: BERME PRESSES SAVEFARE PLAN
description: Charging that Governor Rockefeller had been misinformed, City Controller Abraham D. Beame renewed yesterday the city's campaign to save the 30cent transit fare with a larger infusion of money from the proposed transportation bond issue than state officials are willing to commit.

title: Preps
description: MOUNT HERMON, Mass., Oct. 9Gary Livesey threw two ttouchdown passes today to pace Tabor to a 14.6 victory over Mount Hermon.

title: Art
description: WRITING in Partisan Review in March, 1938, George L. K. Morris addressed the following remarks to his fellow members of the Amercan Abstract Artists group: The derogatory charges of European imitation that you will have to face present a purely modern and journalistic brand of criticism. In no other period was the artist expected to appear, fullyarmed, as by spontaneous combustion. Can it be imagined that Raphael was derided for imitating Perugino? Diirer, Rubens, or Poussin for incorporating the art of Italy into their own? On the contrary, it is natural and beneficial that you should assimilate at the start whatever implements are available. However, there is no need for you to make these answers to the charge at all. Your exhibition walls resound with a native clarity and color sense that speak strong of America. The rest will follow if there is enthusiasm and patience.

title: Computers Enter Medicine
description: A woman in her mid50's gets up in the morning. Her first task: cough strenuously into a plastic tube filled with blue liquid. She mails the tube in a special cylindrical container to a laboratory in nearby New Hyde Park, L.I. By return mail comes the diagnosis: No lung cancer. Her respiratory problems must come from another source. Cost of the test: $15.

title: Beame Says City Lost Millions In Relief Tenant Rent Deposits
description: Landlords of welfare families in the city kept $4.5million in forfeited security deposits during 1970, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Every Sunday The New York Times includes a separate section, 1A, on Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. It contains news and features of interest in these areas and appears in copies distributed in Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Rockland
description: Nyack ran out of secondhalf miracles and absorbed its initial Rockland County football setback yesterday by losing to Tappan Zee for the first time in 11 years, 220. North Rockland moved into sole possession of first place by romping to a 480 victory over Suffern.

title: The Last Word: Malcolm de Chazal
description: A few years ago I discovered the perfect book. It could be read from back to front, opened at all points with enjoyment, read over and over, read slowly or quickly; one page, or part of one page, was as satisfying as the whole; it could be argued with, and win or lose, the outcome was delightful; someone who had not learned anything new in a week could find an insight for life.

title: World
description: WASHINGTONAt 10 o'clock Tuesday morning, Press Sectetary Ronald L. Ziegler, wearing that Iknowsomethingyoudon't look he sports when standing on the edge of an important announcement, and Henry A. Kissinger, radiating sobriety, appeared in the White House press room. Urgent telephone calls had gone out an hour or so before to summon reporters, and a good crowd was on hand when Mr. Ziegler stepped forth with a onesentence statement constituting the next installment in that marathon news story known as the China saga.

title: Hirohito Is Booed and Jeered in Amsterdam
description: AMSTERDAM, Oct. 9Small crowds booed and jeered Emperor Hirohito at each stop today as he toured Amsterdam on his unofficial visit to the Netherlands.

title: A Dinner, a Talk, A Walk With Forster
description: In 1949 the American Academy and National Institute of Arts and Letters prevailed upon E.M. Forster to deliver its annual Blashfield Address. That became the famous essay entitled Art for Art's Sake, which is a declaration of the artist's tendency to be an outsider in the society to which he was born, and of the unsoundness of many of the structures of our culture because they weren't built properly in the first place. Myself I would sooner be a swimming rat than a sinking shipat all events I can look around a little longerand I remember how one of us, a rat with particularly bright eyes named Shelley, squeaked out Poets are the unacknowledged legislators of the world before he vanished into the waters of the Mediterranean. Uttered to us in his highly educated, edgy but courteous tone of voice, it thrilled our audience.

title: Mrs. Jane M. Shaw Plans to Remarry
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mrs. Jane Morris Shaw of Carron, Morayshire, Scotland, widow of John W. Shaw, to Alan StewartClarke of Edinburgh, Scotland.

title: Nixon Proclaims Lunch Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (UPI) President Nixon today signed a proclamation designating the week starting tomorrow as National School Lunch Week.

title: Reagan Arrives in Taipei
description: TAIPEI, Oct. 9 (Reuters)Gov. Ronald Reagan of California arrived today on a 16day trip through five Asian countries. He will represent President Nixon at the National Day celebration tomorrow.

title: Susan Ritchie, Richard A. Clark Marry in Jersey
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 9 Miss Susan Celine Ritchie and Richard Andrew Clark were married here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederic S. Fox, recording secretary of Princeton University, assisted by the Rev. E. Rugby Auer of Trinity.

title: Kingman Douglass, a Financier And Intelligence Official, Dies
description: Kingman Douglass, financier and former assistant director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died Friday of a heart ailment in Roosevelt Hospital. His age was 75.

title: Navy Turns a Recruit Into an Instant Wonder
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 9 (AP)William J. Chalstrom of Spirit Lake, Iowa, became an officer and a gentleman in an instant.

title: Jennifer Bergin, Costumer, Bride In Yale Chapel
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 9Miss Jennifer Mandeville Tergin and Peter Hubbell von Mayrhauser, 1970 graduates of Northwestern University, were married here this afternoon in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Chapel at Yale University.

title: I.R.S. Will Take Over the Monitoring of Phase Two
description: The friendly financial experts who check tax returns and hand out refunds, assessments and penalties have been catapulted into a key role in the economymanning the front line in the war on inflation.

title: PLAYGROUND USES SCRAP MATERIALS
description: Tony DiDominico and Stacey Purtz, each about 12 years old, take turns climbing the pile of tires next to the utility pole and grabbing the pulley for a ride along the rope that stretches from the top of the pole to the top of a dirt pile at the other end of the lot.

title: Groton Routs St. George's 348
description: GROTON, Mass., Oct. 9 Bill Larkin passed for three touchdowns today as Groton overwhelmed St. George's, 348. It was the second straight victory for Groton. Two of Larkin's touchdown passes were to Preston Moore.

title: Florence Bars Hilton Hotel
description: FLORENCE, Italy, Oct. 9 (AP) The Florence Planning Commission has unanimously rejected a plan for construction of a Hilton International hotel on a hill dominating the city. The commission ruled yesterday that the $6.4million project would spoil the landscape.

title: LORD SORENSEN, 80, EXLABOR M.P., DIES
description: LONDON, Oct. 9Lord Sorensen, a former Labor Member of Parliament, whose resignation to take up a life of peerage precipitated a famous byelection, died last night. His age was 80.

title: Mrs. Turnbull Wed in Jersey
description: NEW VERNON, N. J., Oct. 9Mrs. Marjorie Hanson Turnbull and Arthur Brentano, former chairman of the board and president of Brentano's, Inc., the New York booksellers, were married here yesterday afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. Ross Greer, rector of St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in South Orange, at the home of family friends, Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Dickson.

title: Truck and $200,000 in Furs Hijacked in RushHour Tieup
description: A rushhour hijacking of a truck containing $200,000 worth of furs was carried off so adroitly amid bumpertobumper traffic in Queens that the police were still without significant clues yesterday.

title: JAMES H. GERMAIN
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J. Oct. 9  James Howard Germain, a vice president since 1955 of Johnsen & Higgins, international insurance brokers, died Thursday it Mountainside Hospital. He was 65 years did and lived at 21 Bellegrove Drive.

title: Movies
description: THE show is Dinner at Eleven and the star is Gloria Swanson. The 72  year  old actress, surely the world's most glittering grandmother, is sitting it front of a tray piled high with ??er beloved natural foods, in her green and yellow French provincial living room off Fifth Avenue. But even a health foods feast isn't enough to cheer her up tonight.

title: BYRON BY THOMSON SET FOR NEXT SPRING
description: Virgil Thomson's Lord Byron, an opera based on the life of the poet, will be given its premiere next spring by the Juilliard American Opera Center. The work has a libretto by Jack Larson, a California poet.

title: Jay H. Rossbach Jr. to Marry Mrs. Linda Johnson on Nov. 27
description: Mrs. Linda Moffett Johnson and Jay H. Rossbach Jr., a vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, have set Nov. 27 as the date for their wedding.

title: EARLY EDUCATION ON RISE IN NATION
description: An estimated 40 per cent of the country's 10.6 million children age 3 to 5 are enrolled in a formal educational program of some kind this fall, according to a study to be published by the United States Office of Education.

title: California First in Veterans
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 (UPI)California has 3,075,000 veterans of the armed forces military service, the highest of any state. The total is an increase from 2,992,000 a year ago, according to the Veterans Administration regional office.

title: Bud Palmer and Ruby Keeler To Attend Women's Golf Fete
description: The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association is planning an interesting program for those members who plan to attend the annual meeeing, scheduled for the Princeton Club on Nov. 11 at 10:30 A.M.

title: Gran Sport Wins at Miami
description: MIAMI, Oct. 9 (AP)Calderl Race Course, which canceled today's $7,500 added Tequesta Handicap when only five horses were entered, ended up with a fivehorse feature race anyway as Gran Sport won the $5,000 Sumterville Purse.

title: Miss Shelton Fiancee Of Bruce Houghtaling
description: MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Oct. 9Miss Susan M. Shelton and Bruce H. Houghtaling plan to be married. Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Shelton have announced the engagement of their daughter to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle H. Houghtaling Jr. of Walden and Cragsmoor, N. Y.

title: Penguins Top Flyers, 32
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (AP)A 35foot shot by Darryl Edestrand midway through the final period broke a 22 tie and provided the Pittsburgh Penguins with a 32 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers in the season opener for both teams tonight.

title: Jackson Sets Deadline
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Oct. 9 (UPI)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, says he will make a decision by Dec. 21 on whether to seek the Democratic nomination for President.

description: THREE internationally known numismatists will deliver lectures at the educational forum to be held during the seventh annual Grand Central Coin Convention in the McAlpin Hotel Nov. 47, it was announced last week by Morris Bram, general chairman.

title: The Porter Style
description: Some of the most successful composers of both light and serious music have tended to rely on certain chord progressions, certain rhythms, approaches and kinds of phrasing that give their works a distinctiveness. But Cole Porter seems endlessly flexible in his approach to chords, melody, rhythm and lyrics. How easy it would have been for him to become committed to the beguine; his Begin the Beguine started a craze for that tempo. But although Porter used the tempo again when it suited him, it never became his trademark. He is not The Beguine King. He simply shunned formula writing and moved in and out of musical idioms with effortless grace.

title: Dartmouth Defeats Penn, 19 to 3, Breaking a 33 Tie in the Second Half
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 9Finding themselves in a 33 halftime stalemate with stubborn Pennsylvania football team, two Dartmouth quarterbacks took matters into their own legs today by running for two touchdowns and a 193 victory before 17,600 spectators at Memorial Field.

Her husband is a director of United States Foreign Securities Corporation. The child, the couple's third, is named Andrew Drexel.

description: DUDLEY, Mass., Oct. 9 (AP) A hardhitting Jersey City State team knocked Nichols from the unbeaten ranks today. 316.

title: How Much Broker Stock Will the Public Swallow
description: Five leading member firms of the New York Stock Exchange have gone public in the last 18 months and, conditions permitting, many more will try to tap the public capital markets in the months to come.

title: Orioles 32 in 2d Game
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 9 (AP) The oddsmakers rated the Baltimore Orioles today a 31 favorite to win the World Series and a 32 choice to take the second game tomorrow.

description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Steelers activated today an injured guard, Bruce Van Dyke. He will start tomorrow against the Browns in Cleveland. Van Dyke missed the last two games because of a pulled hamstring muscle.

title: BLACK DEMOCRATS BACK HUGHES BID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 9Black members of the Democratic National Committee began today an effort to persuade a black woman. Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris, to drop out of the contest for temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the Democratic National Convention next year.

description: Reb, Sam and Jack were in town recently to talk about mutual funds, insurance, houses, mortgages and land.

title: Preps
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 9Lawrenceville won its first game of the season today by trouncing Williamson Trade, 407.

title: Preps
description: A touchdown by Steve Joffe with 41 seconds to play yesterday gave Riverdale an 1812 victory over McBurney School at Riverdale. It was the third straight triumph for Riverdale and McBurney's first loss in 10 games over a twoyear span.

title: Beth Gottlieb Fiancee Of Peter Rabinowitz
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Oct. 9Dr. and Mrs. Manuel Gottlieb have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth Linda Gottlieb, to Peter Alan Rabinowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Rabinowitz of Chestnut Hill, Mass. A December wedding is planned.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Education
description: A year ago, Dr. Harvey B. Scribner came to New York City from Vermont to take charge of the nation's largest school system. As the new chancellor, he assumed a post that had been turned down by more than a dozen candidates, including a former Attorney General and a United States Representative to the United Nations. And he arrived just as the system was undergoing a drastic reshuffling of powers with the introduction of decentralization.

title: SMETONA'S PIANISM FRESH, UNAFFECTED
description: Perhaps the most appealing aspect of Antanas Smetona's pianism is its utter modesty. This quality was very much in evidence at his Tully Hall recital Friday night, along with a tidy technique and a ripe, if not exactly prismatic, tonal richness.

title: Editor of Quill Named
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (UPI) The Quill, a monthly magazine published by Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journalism society, has named a new editor. Charles F. Long, 33 years old, succeeds Clarence O. Schlaver, who left to become editor of the American Press.

title: Miss Margot Hartmann Betrothed
description: ROSLYN HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 9The engagement of Miss Margot Keating Hartmann to Klaus Otto Haberich, son of Dr. and Mrs. J. Matthias Haberich of Dlisseldorf, Germany, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank William Hartmann of Roslyn Harbor and Ste. Agathe, Quebec. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Criminals At Large
description: If it's escape reading you're after, cuddle up with FOR THE PRESIDENT'S EYES ONLY by Richard Sale (Simon & Schuster, $7.95). It's altogether unbelievable, and altogether a lot of fun. The hero, a heman part American Indian, is an electronic genius, a man of action, infinitely resourceful, infinitely attractive to women. The guy can do everything but knit.

title: Abraham Lincoln
description: In these three admirably edited source books, Herbert Mitgang offers his readers a kind of timemachine to transport them back into the political and cultural environment of the Civil War years, with espedal emphasis upon the central national figure, Abraham Lincoln. Though the headcount of Civil War books published since 1861 passed the sixty  thousand mark several years ago, there is ample room for the present volumes since each summarizes the period as seen by contemporary observers and none has been easily accessible to the general reader.

title: BIRD MIGRATIONS TRACED BY RADAR
description: Scientists from the Woods Hole (Mass.) Oceanographic Institution are experimenting for the first time with radar off the Atlantic Coast to track birds during their autumn migrations.

title: A SECOND CHANCE AT COLLEGE GIVEN
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 7 More than 4,000 men and women aged 17 to, 50 are getting a second chance at college at four cooperative college centers on Long Island and four upstate counties  all part of the State University system.

title: RIVAL CHINA AIDES COEXIST IN VIENNA
description: VIENNA, Oct. 9This is one of the few capitals where Chinese Nationalist and Chinese Communist diplomats coexist. In fact, they eat in the same Chinese restaurant though in opposite corners, ignoring each other.

title: How the President Hopes to Keep the Lid On
description: The inflation control mechanism President Nixon announced last week is not radically different in structure from those that regulated wages and prices in World War II and the Korean War.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Kept Promises
description: Now come ripeness and maturity, the fulfillment of promises. It must have been at this season that man first discovered the potentialities of a ripe grape, for grape juice and apple cider have begun to potentiate, even as the maple trees come to their glory.

title: HISTORY EXHIBIT A BRONX EVENT
description: Robert Abrams, Bronx borough president, is fond of pointing out that his borough has more people than 15 states, numerous countries, and the cities of Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Schenectady, Syracuse, Utica and Yonkers combined.

title: Medicine
description: Dr. B. F. Skinner's pigeons have come home to roost. You can find them, metaphorically speaking, in mental hospitals, prisons, reformatories, schools for the retarded and schools for ordinary students. In effect, the same psychology of behavior  modificationthroughrewards used by the Harvard psychologist to train pigeons now curbs violence in mental patients, toilet trains severely retarded and hells normal children to read.

title: Rochester's Early Scores Overcome Union by 2113
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 9Bill Hammond took a 45yard touchdown pass on the second play of the game today and interceptions set up two other early touchdowns as unbeaten Rochester downed Union, 2113.

title: Chess
description: IT is a basic tenet of every chess critic's faith that match play vastly different, in all manner of subtle ways, from tournament play. It is also, to judge by what he has said in recent interviews, a basic tenet of Bobby Fischer's, although his recent results do a good deal to belie it. It is too obvious a fact to be an article of faith that if one simply wins every game one cannot lose, no matter what the form of competition.

description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Preps
description: ASHBURNHAM, Mass., Oct. 9Milbraham & Munson scored in every period today to trounce visiting Cushing Academy, 386. Steve Desmarias scored 14 points and passed for three conversions to help the home team to a 20 record. Cushing has an 02 mark.

title: Miss Tweedy Engaged
description: SHOREHAM, L. I., Oct. 9 Mr. Edwin S. Tweedy has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Lillian Elizabeth Tweedy, to Edward Daniel Higgins of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y. Miss Tweedy, daughter also of the late Mrs. Lillian E. Tweedy, is an alumna of the College of Mount St. Vincent. She is in her final year at the Columbia University School of Nursing.

title: The Russians Have a Williamsburg, Too
description: NOVGOROD, U.S.S.R.This ancient city once built mostly of wood might be called the Russian Williamsburg, for like Williamsburg it is of historic importance and is undergoing systematic restoration. But Novgorod is much older than Williamsburg. Founded in A.D. 862, Novgorod was the stronghold of the first Russian state.

title: AUSTRALIA FIGHTS TO SAVE CROCODILE
description: DARWIN, Australia  The barramundi, a giant perch that is prized by sportsmen for its fighting qualities and by gourmets for its delicate flavor, has been disappearing from northern Australian rivers, and scientists say civil wars in the Congo and Nigeria are to blame.

title: Terriers' Day at Penllyn Show
description: News of Dogs

title: Religion
description: ROME  No one who has ever tried to negotiate the traffic of Rome is surprised to learn that when an Italian wants to get a driver's license, the law requires him to spend more time studying theory than operating a car. Last week, the third Synod of Bishops began serious deliberations on the crisis in the priesthood in the Roman Catholic Church. Like an Italian with a learner's permit, the delegates were clearly having trouble moving from the theoretical to the practical.

title: Denise Y. Goldman Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Goldman of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter; Miss Denise Yvette Goldman, to David Bennett Spivak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Spivak of Brightwaters, L. I. The wedding is planned for Feb. 5.

title: The Nation
description: New York State's proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue has itself become an uncertain engine pulling carloads of political controversy. And, although it may still think it can, think it can, think it can, there developed increasing doubt last week that it would win approval at the polls on Nov. 2.

title: Child to Hackenbergs
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 9A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. John Hackenberg on Wednesday in Phelps Memorial Hospital in Tarrytown. Mrs. Hackenberg is the former Miss Jane Small, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Small of Franklin, Mich. The child, the couple's second, has been named Amy. Mr. Hackenberg is with the school and college department of The New York Times.

title: Headliners
description: For All Humanity

title: Margaret Hooker Bride Of Robin Lee Taliaferro
description: St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was the setsing, here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Margaret. Cartwright Hooker, daughter of Mrs. Edward Gordon Hooker of New York and the late Mr. Hooker, to Robin Lee Taliaferro, son of Charles Champe Taliaferro of Oyster Bay, L. I., and. Hobe Sound, Fla., and Mrs. Henry Stillman Taylor of Centre Island, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Raymond C. Finn.

title: Portland, Me., Club to Vote On Admission of Democrats
description: PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 9 (AP)After 85 years as a bastion of rockribbed Maine Republicanism, the Portland Club may lower the bars to Democrats.

title: N.Y. Tech Eleven Defeats Brooklyn College, 12 to 10
description: OLD WESTBURY, LJ., Oct. 9 Tony Di Prosperio, a second string quarterback, threw a 75yard pass today to Richie Lapp with six minutes remaining in the game to give New York Tech a 1210 victory over Brooklyn College.

title: STATE FILES SUIT OVER LAB CHARGES
description: In the first court action under a 1970 law to protect the public from exorbitant charges for laboratory tests, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has brought suit against a New Jersey concern that does thousands of clinical laboratory tests each year for patients throughout the metropolitan area.

title: Guatemalan Students Begin Strike as Protest Against Violence and to Press Regime to Lift State of Siege
description: GUATEMALA, Oct. 9Thousands of Guatemalan students are protesting the continuing high level of violence in the country and demanding the end of the state of siege, which has been in effect for 11 months. Similar demands nave been made by intellectuals, journalists and a group of clergymen.

title: Vietminh Veterans Recall the War Against the French
description: TUYHOA, South Vietnam, Oct. 8Many men of Phuyen province, famous for its guerrilla fighters in the, nineyear war against the French, are silent now. Many do not even speak to their children of the war that they helped win.

title: Election Is Announced
description: ATHENS, Oct. 9 (Reuters)The Armybacked Government announced today that elections would be held on Nov. 28 to select a 75member consultative committee to advise it on legislation.

title: The Music of Time marches on
description: Here comes Nicholas Jenkins back from the war. He's not shellshocked or turned on to existentialism or gone to any extreme. Not that you thought he would be. He's just there, as always, very sensitive, very discriminating and very well placed to observe the antics of the English under the Austerity Program. What does Jenkins do? Well, he is conducting The Music of Time, still. This is the tenth movement of the oratorio, and you will pardon Nick if the tempo flags once in a way, as he would put it.

title: CLEMSON UPSETS DUKE ON KICK, 30
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 9 (UPI) Eddie Seigler kicked a 39yard field goal with 10 seconds left in the third quarter today as Clemson upset Duke, 30, in the 25th annual Oyster Bowl. It was the Tigers' first victory of the season.

title: National Notes
description: Wetbacks

title: Preps
description: SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., Oct. 9Lee Carlson, a junior fullback, scored two firsthalf touchdowns to highlight Westminster's 160 victory over St. Mark's today.

title: The Colonel's Vindication
description: Dismissal by the Army of a damaging efficiency report against Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert removes the threat of that officer's forced retirement from a lifetime of dedicated service. It should also clear the way for his return to the command positions and the promotion to which his previous combat performance entitled him.

title: Ulbricht Up for Reelection
description: BERLIN, Oct. 9 (AP)Walter Ulbricht, the former East German Communist party leader, again is a candidate for the national Parliament in balloting Nov. 14. Now 78 and ailing, Mr. Ulbricht was replaced as party first secretary in May by Erich Honecker.

title: Plymouth Gets First Victory
description: PLYMOUTH, N. H., Oct. 9 (AP)Plymouth State team recorded its first varsity football victory today by downing Western Connecticut, 3927. This is Plymouth's second season, it didn't win last season.

title: Reader's Report
description: Bitter as aloes, hollow as a gourd, so wry it makes your lips puckerthis latterday spy story is all style and no substance. Well, so little substance that the undercover hero, a chap named Jon, doesn't know what business he's in. Espionage, presumably.

title: Mary D. Crittenden Wed to Howard Lewis Aller 3d
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 9 Miss Mary Diantha Crittenden was married here this afternoon to Howard Lewis Aller 3d at the summer home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Aller Jr. of New York. The Rev. Dr. Charles Ranson, pastor of the United Church of Christ Congregational in Salisbury, performed the ceremony.

title: Lowenstein Tells State A.D.A. A 4th Party Would Be Foolish
description: Allard K. Lowenstein, national chairman of Americans for Democratic Action, declared yesterday that It would be very foolish for dissident Democrats to form a fourth party at a time when the Democrats had an excellent chance of electing a President committed to peace and social reform.

title: Wichita Hotel to Be Sold
description: WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 9 (AP) The 16story Allis Hotel in downtown Wichita, closed more than a year ago by its owner, Gotham Hotels, Ltd., of New York, will be sold at an auction here on Oct. 28. Whoever buys the hotel will b liable for a $1.1million mortgage held by the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Continue planting.... Plant house plant seed indoors for winter growing.... Choose some bulbs to pot up for forcing indoors in early February.

title: Caught in the middle, between art and commerce
description: This novel is about a man who cis trying to be honest about having been dishonest. Years ago, we were startled and dismayed by The Hucksters, dismayed because its picture of the advertising business revealed how easily our sturdiest citizens could be duped by the latest progeny of Barnum. Daniel Stern now reveals what happens to those who do the duping.

title: BOSTON U. TRIUMPHS OVER UMASS, 4721
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9 (AP)An alert Boston University team scored twice on pass interceptions and once each on a kickoff return and a punt return and downed Massachusetts, 4721, today.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: A Guard Dies, Raising The Attica Toll to 43
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 9 (AP)  The death toll from the Attica prison riot rose to 43 today with the death of guard who had been held hostage and was found wounded after the police regained control of the prison.

title: Employes of Jersey City Now Balk at Political Tithes
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 9  For most of the year, rice pudding is just a wholesome, oldfashioned dessert. But with the special mayoral election less than a month off, rice pudding now means only one thing at City Hall: It is the local political euphemism for the annual 3 per cent payroll kickback to the oldline Democratic organization.

title: LEHIGH CONQUERS RUTGERS BY 3514
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 9 (UPI)Jack Rizzo scored three touchdowns and Don Dioro added two today in leading Lehigh to a 3514 victory over Rutgers.

title: Miss Mabrey Will Be Wed
description: BOSTON, Oct. 9Dr. and Mrs. Elhridge Mabrey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Mabrey to Sgt. Jeffrey Scott Taylor, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Floyd Taylor of Rockford, Ill.

title: Vladimir Ustinov, 64, Dies; Former Moscow Official
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 5Vladimir I. Ustinov, a former Communist party official who briefly achieved prominence under Nikita S. Khrushchev, died here yesterday. He was 64 years old.

title: Miss Storrs Bride Of Medical Student
description: FRANCONIA, N. H., Oct. 9  Miss Virginia Farewell Storrs and Yoshiharu Akabane, who met three years ago when he was head tennis counsellor and she was on the tennis staff at Tamarack Tennis Camp, were married today on a mill overlooking the camp. The Rev. Clinton Blake of Franconia performed the Protestant ceremony.

title: Preps
description: BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 9 John Kimmel scored on a pass from Dave Harding with four seconds remaining in the game today to give visiting Newark Academy a 1414 tie with Blair Academy.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: JACOB J. LEIBSON, WRITER, 88, DEAD
description: Jacob J. Leibson, a writer and English teacher here, died Friday at Halcott Center, N. Y., where he lived. His age was 88.

title: Colleen Pelleriti Wed to Captain
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Oct. 9 Miss Colleen Mary Pelleriti was married here this afternoon to Capt. Carl P. Parlatore of the Air Force, who flew 230 combat missions in Vietnam as a jetfighter pilot. Msgr. George M. Claric performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in a military service in the chapel at Homestead Air Force Base, where the bridegroom is stationed.

title: With the Big O and the Big K, Everything Looks O.K. Again for Milwaukee
