description: RAPID CITY, S. D., Oct. 10 (AP)The lone survivor of a helicopter crash that killed six Air Force men was reported in good condition today, Capt. David Walker of the Ellsworth Air Force Base information office, said that Capt. Norman G. Schuessler, 26 years old, of Dallas, the pilot, was doing fine and still in good condition after the crash yesterday near the air base.

title: Nancy Bass Bride Of Arthur Lutzke
description: Miss Nancy An Bass, associate editor of The Journal of Practical Nursing, was married here at noon yesterday to Arthur S. Lutzke, a securities analyst with Cowen & Co. Cantor Robert Abelson performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: Pope and Synod Fast For Pakistani Refugees
description: ROME, Oct. 10Pope Paul VI led delegates to the Synod of Bishops today in a day of prayer and fasting on behalf of the refugees of East Paidstan.

title: U.S. Clinches Davis Cup, 3 to 1
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 10 The Davis Cup challenge round ended today the way it began 71 years ago, with a United States victory.

title: BRANDT MAN WINS IN BREME EASILY
description: BONN, Oct. 10  The Social Democrats won an impressive victory today in the Bremen election, giving Chancellor Willy Brandt's ruling party its first real triumph in a state contest since he took power in Bonn two years ago.

title: Film Fete: Hint of Brecht
description: Karl is a handsome, young peacetime soldier whose soul might once have been that of a poet, but it's now inert. It rests on its own dead center in a world whose values and relationships are without meaning. Karl would prefer to avoid all contacts, but he hasn't the Interest to resist when they are forced on him, as they are by Berta, the pretty serving maid who dreams of romantic love and comes to settle for the bleakest approximation.

title: WOMAN FOUND DEAD OF KNIFING IN QUEENS
description: A 37yearold Queens woman was stabbed to death in her parents' empty apartment in Forest Hills during the weekend, the police reported yesterday.

title: The Word of Chou Enlai
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.It is impossible to conceive of Chou Enlai reversing all of his Government's longstanding explicitopposition against any form of dual representation in the United Nations, yet that is precisely what Secretary Rogers continues to see as a distinct possibility.

title: Unbeaten Redskins Down Oilers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10With the defensive unit making the big plays, the Washington Redskins beat the Houston Oilers 22 to 13 today to remain the only undefeated team in the National Football League.

title: Married Priests Seek an Active Role in Church
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 10It looked like a fraternity reunion and in a way It was, because the people who held a dinner party at a Roman Catholic Church here last night were priests who had married.

title: Texas Boy's Suicide in Jail Is Similar to His Father's
description: CONROE, Tex., Oct. 10 (AP) A 14yearold boy who was jailed for truancy has hanged himself in the same jail where his father committed suicide, in the same way, 10 years ago.

title: KOREA G.I.'S FACE A DULL, SAFE LIFE
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 10 For many of the 36,000 American soldiers serving in South Korea, life is made up of equal parts of tedium over being in Korea and relief over not being in Vietnam.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: MEET COOKIE. The year's most unlikely heroine. 56.95 at your bookstore.Advt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TO FESTIVAL MARKED BY JEWS
description: Simhath Torah  the most Joyous event in the Hebrew calendar will be observed today and tomorrow.

title: Phones Link Paris to China
description: PARTS (AP)A direct radiotelephone circuit from Paris to Shanghai has been opened, communication officials announced. Previously calls between the two cities passed through Bern, Switzerland.

title: Oklahoma Tagged As Super Eleven by Royal, Coach of Trounced Texas Team
description: Greg Pruitt and his Oklahoma mates had the most remarkable individual and team rushing performances among many last Saturday  a day when the college theme from coast to coast was emphasis on old fashioned basic running behind powerful line blocking.

title: MRS. JEANETTE JENA
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 10Mrs. Jeanette Einstein Jena, art critic of The Pittsburgh PostGazette for 35 years, died today in West Penn Hospital. Mrs. Jena, who retired two years ago, was 75 years old.

title: U.S. Says Counterfeit Bills Are Turning Up in Jersey
description: NEWARK, Oct. 10 (AP)The United States Secret Service said today that counterfeit bills were being found in New Jersey at a rate of about $6,000 a week.

title: KOSYGIN, IN RABAT, STRESSES DANGER IN MIDEAST CRISIS
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 10Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew back to Moscow today after warning here that the Middle East situation was tense and can degenerate into conflict despite the goodwill of Egypt.

title: Miss Scharf Wed to R. A. Raymond
description: HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., Oct. 10The Seawane Club was the setting here this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Judith Ann Scharf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Scharf of Hewlett, to Dr. Richard Alan Raymond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mack Raymond, of West Chester, Pa. Rabbi David Benedict of Temple Israel in Lawrence performed the ceremony.

title: SATELLITES SPOT A SOVIET BUILDUP FOR ATOMIC ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Satellite photos of the Soviet Union have uncovered evidence of a substantial buildup of more and better strategic nuclear weapons.

title: City Assesses Real Estate at 57%, Against 98% 20 Years Ago but Taxes Still Rise
description: The average real estate owner's property in New York City is being assessed at only 57 per cent of its full value, reflecting a steady drop from 98 per cent 20 years ago, 78 per cent a decade ago, and 63 per cent even five years ago.

title: RANGERS TRIUMPH OVER BRUINS, 41
description: BOSTON, Oct, 10The New York Rangers, who found a mixture or pleasure and regret in last night's 44 tie at Montreal in their National Hockey League opener, enjoyed undiluted happiness tonight as they thumped the Boston Bruins, 41, before a capacity crowd of 14,995 at Boston Garden.

title: U.S. Agency Financing Sterilizations
description: OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Oct. 10A Federal agency is providing money to sterilize men and women who voluntarily decide not to conceive any more children.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Slobodin Has Nuptials
description: Miss Donna Gail Slobodin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alex Slobodin of Englewood Cliffs, N. J., was married here last evening to Joel Uydess, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Uydess of Far Rockaway, Queens. Rabbi Charles Agin performed the ceremony at the St. RegisSheraton.

title: PeerGroup Counseling Service Is Offered to Students at N.Y.U.
description: It was 2 A.M. when a New York University coed dashed into one of the school's counseling services. Her boyfriend had taken an overdose of drugs and was unconscious in her dormitory room.

title: Evidence Grows That Byrd Will Get High Court Seat,
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10Evidence mounted today that President Nixon's first choice fdr nomination to the Supreme Court is Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, and that if his name is submitted to the Senate for confirmation it will sail through with ease.

title: Youths Urge Road Reform
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 10 (AP)A national youth conference today urged widespread highway safety reforms, including better built automobiles, tougher controls on driver testing and a legal drinking age of 18. A resolution was drafted during a fourday conference sponsored by YOUTHS, a group formed last November by Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe to advise on ways to involve the young in highway safety.

title: Gleason Fails to Confront Gulf Dock Worker Locals
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Oct. 10 (UPI)  Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, failed to appear today for an expected confrontation with recalcitrant West Gulf dock workers.

title: Girl, 18, Is a Market Maker and Key Trader
description: WASHINGTONHer customary greeting on the telephone goes: This is Wendie. I want quote on ...

title: Democrats, Urging Easier Voter Registration, See Party Gain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10While publicly proclaiming voter registration to be a nonpartisan cause, Congressional Democrats privately see a potential windfall for their party in the estimated 50 million persons who might be converted from Election Day dropouts to voters.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Spiking the U. N.
description: NORTH LOUNGE BAR, U.N. HeadquartersThe cozy, cliquish bar of the United Nations north delegates'; lounge is considered by connoisseurs to be the best bar in the world One wit has named it the Seventh Committee of the General Assembly. It is a setting in which many a calculated indiscretion has been transmitted Into the ready ears of the correspondents who professionally frequent the area. It is an honored tradition of the house.

title: TIMES GETS A WRIT TO BAR SLOWDOWN
description: The New York Times obtained a temporary restraining order last night against members of the New York Stereotypers Union Local 1 who delayed printing of the newspaper for a second day by holding two chapel meetings to discuss grievances involving union jurisdiction and work opportunities.

title: Born to Win':Czech Film on Addict Shown in Festival
description: It had been called "Scraping Bottom." But a few months ago the title was changed to "Born to Win," and that was the name under which Ivan Passer's new movie played Saturday night in the New York Film Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. Except for the pleasure it must bring to connoisseurs of the movie business, the title change doesn't much matter; as a slice from the life of a middle-aged New York junkie, "Born to Win" is, of course, a study in losing.Ivan Passer is a Czechoslovak director, friend and collaboration of Milos Forman, whose first feature, "Intimate Lighting," seemed to some of us the happiest, though least well known, product of the Czechoslovak film renaissance in the nineteen-sixties. "Born to Win" is only Passer's second movie, and it is a dreadful disappointment  but not without its reasons, and not, I think, without some honor.The reasons stem from Passer's trying to make a New York movie, when New York isn't his subject, and from his trying, against all odds and all wisdom, to make what means to be in part a madcap comedy about heroin addiction. The honor really has the same sources: the understanding of a need for a sense of place and a sense of style, which keep the film from being a total waste, even when it is going totally wrong.George Segal plays the junkie. Paula Prentiss plays his wife, also a junkie and currently a prostitute, who enters the picture only a couple of times and only long enough to say she's sorry. And Karen Black plays, the girl who picks Segal up one night while he is stealing her car. Friendly, unattached, with a terrific duplex apartment and no visible means of support, she seems the most gratuitous aspect in a movie that is in no way strong on logic.I think that Segal himself is meant to hold things together  by a degree of personal charisma that in this instance he lacks and by his story, which is supposed to be at once a compound of tragic destiny and comic misadventure. But the destiny is both too theatrically phony and too predictably conventional, and the comedy  though in a few cases genuinely funny  is too mechanical for its function. And the view of the addict's life style as desperate but somehow admirable in its canny desperation  which I believe is the movie's intention  falls in a maze of stock devices and hazy motivations.It didn't seem possible, in the scene where Segal's pal, Billy Dynamite (Jay Fletcher), takes the film's obligatory shot of bad stuff and dies, and the audience can guess everything about the sequence at least five minutes in advance because it is by now the oldest clich of the junkie movie, that a sensibility as fine as Passer's could be involved in it. But Passer's sensibility is involved, and effectively deadened, and I hope just for a time, because he has done and can do beautiful work.

title: A Harpsichord Recital by May Attracts Many Young Listeners
description: At his last solo appearance here in 1969, Michael May operated on the theory that, keyboard recitals need not be predictable, conventional or dull. Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, a full house of predominantly young, unanimously enthusiastic listeners enjoyed further proof of Mr. May's refreshing musical pudding.

title: Reggie McNamara Dead at 83; Noted Bicycle Racer of the 20's.
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., Oct. 10Reggie (Iron Man) McNamara, the professional bicycle rider who was the idol of the sixday race fans in the nineteentwenties, died last night in the Essex County Geriatric Center. His age was 83.

title: DR. CLYDE DONNELL, MEDICAL LEADER, 80
description: DURHAM, N. C., Oct. 10Dr. Clyde Donnell, a leader in providing continuing medical education for Negro physicians in North and South Carolina and Virginia, died today in Duke University Medical Center. He was 80 years old.

title: PHILIPPE HERIAT, 73, NOVELIST AND CRITIC
description: PARIS, Oct. 10 (UPI)Philippe Hriat, novelist, critic and playwright, died today at the age of 73.

title: More Vietnam G.I.'s Taken Oat of Combat
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 10 (UPI)  President Nixon's withdrawal program decreased United States fighting farces here by almost 2,000 men today as infantry and armored cavalry units were ordered to start packing.

title: OLIVER D. COLVIN, LED CARGOCAIRE
description: Oliver Dyer Colvin, developer of marine airdrying equipment, died Friday In the New England Medical Center in BosHe was 72 years old and lived In Hampton, N. H.

title: Marguerite Lozier Dead; French Resistance Figure
description: LYONS, France, Oct. 10 (Reuters) Marguerite Lozier, a heroine of the French Resistance during World War II, died here today. Her age was 74.

title: Eleven Passengers to Nowhere Are Put Ashore
description: The ocean liner Atlantis interrupted a fourday Cruise to Nowhere yesterday and sailed back into the Lower Bay to put aboard a tugboat 11 passengers because of their alleged unruly behavior at sea.

title: Divorce Found Twice as Likely Among Those Marrying Young
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The Census Bureau released statistical evidence today that mother knows best: people who marry young are twice as likely to be divorced as are somewhat older couples.

title: Small Business
description: Dr. Ferdinand P. Aleu, a neuropathologist, has interrupted his medical career to try his hand in business. The move, measured in terms of financial return, has been a success. In less than four years, Dr. Aleu has built Puig of Barcelona, Inc., a perfume distributing company, into a compact, prof itable operation and he has had a lot of fun while doing it. His initial investment was about $2,000. Puig distributes a line of perfumes and soap for women, and cologne for men which are made in Spain and France by Puig, S. A. of Barcelona, in the bestknown department and special stores in the country.

title: 3 Killed and 33 Hurt as Bus And Car Collide in Missouri
description: MARSHFIELD, Mo., Oct. 10 (AP)Three persons were killed and 33 injured early today when a Greyhound bus collided with a station wagon on Interstate 44, careened down an embankment and overturned.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 10 (AP)The Los Angeles Kings scored a pair of goals within a threeminute span late in the third period to beat the Vancouver Canucks, 43, in a National Hockey League game today.

title: Impact of Surcharge Found Slight So Far
description: Kurt Orban, a leading importer of steel products, has seen new orders shrink to about 25 per cent of normal volume since President Nixon imposed the 10 per cent surcharge on foreign goods.

title: GIANTS' OFFENSE TO TEST COWBOYS
description: Some people have said that the razzlerdazzie sets out of the I formation that the New York Giants plan to use against the Dallas Cowboys tonight, (Channel 7, 9 P.M) in the Cotten Bowl just look complicated. Basically, they are very simple, the skeptics observe.

title: U.S. Funds to Finance Polish Pulaski Memorial
description: WARKA, Poland, Oct. 10Plans to build an American memorial to this town's most famous son, Casimir Pulaski, were disclosed here yesterday during celebrations of the 192d anniversary of the death of the hero of the American Revolution.

title: Documentary on Occupation of France
description: A documentary that runs four-and-a-half hours (not including an intermission) should tire even the hardiest history or movie buff but, aside from its possible anatomical effects, "Le Chagrin et la Piti," which was unreeled last night at the New York Film Festival, makes a suprisingly educational and fascinating experience despite its inordinate length. As a studiously dispassionate but incisive inquiry into what both lowly and leading French citizens felt and did during the German attack on France in World War II and during the occupation, it soberly spotlights historyimpressively human, not pedantic, levels.It should be noted that it is largely the result of the work of Marcel Ophuls, the son of the late French director. Max Ophuls, and Andr Harris, both reporters for French Government-sponsored TV who were dismissed after the strike and student riots in 1968. Their film was completed last year with the help of Swiss and German Government television and it since has been seen in several Parisian theaters (but not on French TV) and bought for showing on Swiss, German, Dutch, Belgian, Hungarian and Swedish TV screens.The producers also use 1939-through-1945 French and German newsreel footage of, among others, Hitler and of Vichy's Pierre Laval and Marshal Henri-Philippe Ptain, as well as fairly recent interviews with such involved V.I.P.'s as Lord Avon (Anthony Eden), Pierre Mendes-France and Jacques Duclos, leader of the Communist party.These serve as counterpoint to their discusion with members of the Resistance, victims of both Nazis and the French Liberation groups, Rightists and middle-of-the-roaders to spotlight glaringly a somber chapter of history dimmed by the passage of a quarter of a century.They have, in short, concentrated their investigations on the industrial city of Clermont-Ferrand as exemplary (it is implied) of what most Frenchmen and invaders did then and how they feel about it now. And, with the aid of English voice-overs, which literally translate the French and German dialogue, its points, implied and otherwise, are made naturally and convincingly.This viewer was especially impressed by the honesty of Marcel Verdier, the local pharmacist (who wasn't quite certain he was a bourgeois); Louis and Alexis Grave, two ex-Maquis farmers who good-naturedly continue to hate the Nazis who sent them to a concentration camp; with Mendes-France's low-keyed memories of escape from a Nazi jail in his youth to fight with the Free French and with Capt. Helmuth Tausend's bland evaluation of his role as a garrison commander.Some of the important personages do stick in memory, too, such as the witty, cynical, late commander of the Resistance, Emanuel de la Vigier; Anthony Eden, and Count Ren de Chambrun, who, in legal style, defends his father-in-law, Pierre Laval. But they suffer by comparison with the straightforward accounts of the likes of Emile Caubaudon, Clermont-Ferrand's Resistance chief; the Rightist Christian de la Maziere, who fought with an S.S. regiment of Frenchmen, and even with the aging, unbilled hairdresser who was jailed as a collaborator.One must agree with Anthony Eden, who notes that it is not right for the English, who were not invaded, to judge people who were. But this lengthy, complex but entirely lucid insight into the minds of the occupied and the occupiers does give one the ability to judge from the participants' own views. "Le Chagrin et la Piti" filled the more than 1,000 seats of the Vivian Beaumont last night, which indicates, if obliquely, that this special "nonentertainment" film might have a wider audience than this special one.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 10A British expert on Vietnam, a confirmed hawk, was talking about Northern Ireland. The trouble there, he said, was the weakness of the British Army's intelligence: If they had a list of 2,000 terrorists. and got them behind bars, all would be well.

title: PENN CENTRAL ACTS ON MEETING AND BIDS
description: Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company said yesterday that they would proceed Friday noon with the opening of bids for the rail road's interest in 22 realty parcels in midtown Manhattan, but that they were extending the deadline for submitting bids for two other parcelsthe WaldorfAstoria Hotel and the Pan Am Building. No new date was announced.

title: MAYOR ADDRESSES LEGAL OFFICERS
description: Mayor Lindsay told 400 chief legal officers for municipalities across the country yesterday that it was their duty, a lawyers to prod the courts, protest the failure of correction systems and ensure that justice is administered fairly and speedily.

title: Magnafax Gets Accessories
description: The Magnavox Company announced yesterday three new accessories for its Magnafax facsimile machines that the company contends will make the equipment competitive with the Teletype, The equipment is, composed of a broadcaster, a poller and an automatic dialing unit. The broadcaster enables a Magnafax unit to transmit copy simultaneously to a number of satellite stations. The automatic dialer and poller permit a central station to poll up to 20 preselected telephone numbers automatically to send or receive copy.

title: Dow Chemical Plans Plant
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it will construct a new ABS plastic resin plant in Allyn's, Point, Conn., and expand its ABS production facilities at Midland, Mich. The combined expansion will add 80 million pounds to Dow's ABS (which stands for acrylonitrile, butadine and styrene) capacity. The material finds wide applications in the automotive, refrigeration, recreation and packaging fields.

title: Advertising: Train and Bus Travel Pushed
description: Since the overall theme of the morning in the Ted Bates conference room seemed to be ground transportation it was fitting that a pair of big wheelsRobert E. Jacoby, president, and Irving Senn, creative chieftainshould be in attendance along with several vital cogs.

title: PESIDENT SEEKS COIIRT TO WINDLE CONTROLS CASES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11President Nixon is planning to ask Congress to create a Temporary Emergency Court of Appeals to hear cases arising from his new system of wage and price controls, high Administration sources disclosed today.

title: Moderation Wins in MidEurope
description: The cause of moderate, democratic Socialism seems be flourishing in central Europe. Elections last weekend gave absolute majorities to Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Socialist party in Austria's lower house and to Chancellor Willy Brandt's Social Democrats in the Bremen state election in West Germany.

title: Knicks to Open Against Pistons
description: Because Bill Bradley is still sidelined by tendonitis in his right knee, Jerry Lucas will open at forward tonieit for the New York Knicks against the Detroit Pistons in their opening game of the National Basketball Association season at Madison Square Garden.

title: Gen. Chesty Puller Dies; Most Decorated Marine
description: HAMPTON, Va., Oct. 11 (AP) Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Puller, the most decorated member of the Marine Corps, died tonight after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MUNICIPAL VOTING DELAYED IN ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 11The Italian Government announced today the postponement until next March of the limited local elections that had been scheduled for Nov. 28. The Government said it was doing so for practical and organizational reasons.

title: ALBERT TURNER
description: Albert Turner, an independent men's clothing manufacturer here for half a century who retired last year as president of Albert Turner & Co., died yesterday in the Hospital Ifor Special Surgery. He was 79 years old and lived at 1100 Park Avenue.

title: Mobil Gives $250,000 to Aid New Children's TV Series
description: The Mobile Oil Corporation has made a grant of $250.000 to the Children's Television Workshop to help underwrite its new weekday television, The Electric Company, aimed at teaching basic reading skills to children between the ages of 7 and 10. The series begins Oct. 25 on more than 200 noncommercial, stations of the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: PANAMA'S LEADER WARNS ON CANAL
description: PANAMA, Oct. 11  GenOmar Torrijos Herrera, the National Guard commander who rules Panama, told a cheering crowd of about 200,000 supporters today that the time might soon come for one generation to offer its lives to recover sovereignty over the United Statescontrolled Canal Zone.

title: U.S. WARNIN6 U.N. ON TAIWAN OUSTER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11  A spokesman for George Bush, the American representative, said today that he shared the concern voiced by group of Senators over the impact that the expulsion of Nationalist China from the United Nations would have on United States public opinion.

title: Watchdog for Consumers
description: For more than two years the Administration and Congress have shuffled back and forth inconclusively on the setting up of an independent Consumer Protection Agency. In 1969, President Nixon recommended a consumer unit within the Justice Department. Seeking more visibility and independence for the unit, the Senate approved a bill establishing a fully independent consumer agency, but the bill died last year in the House Rules Committee.

title: Paper Links Smothers to Deal With Contractor He Promoted
description: Shortly after he left the United States Senate in January, 1969, George A. Smathers paid $20,000 for $435,000 worth of stock in Aerodex, Inc., a Florida defense contractor whose interests he had promoted in the Senate, the Long Island newspaper Newsday said in a copyrighted article yesterday.

title: 100 ATTEND SERVICE IN HONOR OF NEVINS
description: A memorial service was held yesterday for Allan Nevins, the historian, who died last March 5 at the age of 80, at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus.

title: Parade In Newark
description: NEWARK, Oct. 11 (UPI)More than 100,000 persons packed Bloomfield Avenue in the heart of this city's heavily Italian North Ward today for the Columbus Day parade.

title: Land Disputes Thwarting Green Revolution in India
description: PACHAMPETTAI, IndiaThis tiny South Indian village on the banks of Cauverl River is typical of the lush ricegrowing countryside, where efforts to bring in the Green Revolution have been hamstrung.

title: City's Razing of Housing to Put Up Office Buildings Called Insanity
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman assailed the city's building pattern yesterday as absolute insanity. He said it permitted the destruction of sound and essential housing to make room for surplus office buildings.

title: About Pro Football
description: Are pro football quarterbacks becoming like baseball starting pitchers, meaning subject to relief? In Sunday's games 10 failed to finish, two because of injuries. Roman Gabriel went out with a concussion as the Rams inexplicably upset the 49ers with Jerry Rhome, who monica, who pulled a hamstring muscle. completed only two passes. The Raiders beat Denver easily after Ken Stabler replaced Daryle La monica, who pulled a hamstring muscle.

title: G.E. IS CLOSING CIRCUITRY PLANT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would close its integratedcircuitproducts department at Syracuse, N. Y. The action, while unexpected at this time, continues a trend within the electroniccomponents industry.

title: SCRIBNER OFFERS NEW SCHOOL PLAN
description: The development of a new system of comprehensive highschool education in which students would use more of the resources of the city's nonschool world has been proposed by Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner.

title: MEDIATOR ENTERS TELEPHONE STRIKE
description: A Federal mediator, Alfred Addeo, officially entered the threemonthold strike against the New York Telephone Company by locals of the Communications Workers of America yesterday, but with little visible effect on the stalemated negotiations.

title: F. A. A. to Let Jet industry Help Rewrite Noise Rules
description: MIAMI, Oct. 11The Federal Aviation Administration has decided to withdraw a controversial proposed Federal standard for measuring airport noise and will allow representatives of the air transport industry to help rewrite it.

title: YONKERS SALE NETS RECORD $1,086,300
description: YONKERS, Oct. 11With 154 standardbreds, including 106 yearlings, bringing an aggregate of $1,086,300 for an average of $7,054; and with more than 5,000 persona sauntering in and out of the auction building at Yonkers Raceway, three oneday Old Glory Sale records were shattered today.

title: Wagner Elected Director
description: Robert F. Wagner, former Mayor of New York City, has been elected a director of Scanfax Systems Corporation, Los Angeles. The company produces educational cassettes.

title: REVOLT DAMAGES MENTAL HOSPITAL
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 11 (AP)A revolt by seven inmates that caused damage estimated at $30,000 or more to a maximumsecurity center for the criminally insane occurred during a search for smuggled liquor, authorities disclosed today.

title: Mt. Sinai Gets $2Million
description: Two gifts of more than $1million each for the Mount Sinai Medical Center School of Medicine were announced yesterday by Gustave L. Levy, chairman of the hospitals board of directors. Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ames donated more than $1million to establish the Dr. Herman G. Halpern ambulatory care unit, which will house outpatient clinics. A $1million gift from Mrs. Henry L. Moses, president of the Henry and Lucy Moses Fund, Inc., will be used for a cardiopulmonary center.

title: ANDREW HAIRE JR., YACHTSMAN, 61, DIES
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 11  Andrew J. Haire Jr., a yachtsman and former executive of Haire Publications in New York, died last night in North Shore Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Quogue and formerly in Manhasset.

title: How a Couple, With Help, Found Some Answers
description: Looking back on it now, Pete and Barbara recognize that their problems began before their marriage six years ago. Both were products of unhappy homes.

title: Nine Ballet Dancers Die In Argentine Plane Crash
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 Norma Fontenia and Jose Neglia, Argentine ballet stars, and seven other dancers were killed last night when a small chartered aircraft carrying them on the start of a tour of the provinces crashed into the River Plate minutes after takeoff from the Aeroparque downtown airport.

title: U.S. PRIESTS' VIEW IS GIVEN TO SYNOD
description: ROME, Oct. 11John Cardinal Krol of Philadelphia reported to the Synod of Bishops here today that a majority of American Roman Catholic priests favored a change in church law to permit priests to marry but said that the American hierarchy continued to oppose such a move.

title: LABOR CHIEFS HERE WARY ON PHASE 2
description: Labor leaders in this area were generally unhappy yesterday about President Nixon's latest moves to control wages, and they expressed particular concern about any step that would limit pay increases scheduled in the future under existing contracts.

title: Deceit Takes Matchmaker
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 11 Deceit gained a romantic photofinish victory in the $100,000 Matchmaker Stakes today, earning $30,000 for Windfields Farm and a date with Tom Rolfe.

title: Market Place:
description: Thirdquarter mutual fund results are out about a week now, and the drumbeaters are already at work telling the world what a marvelous year they're having.

title: Tel Aviv to Build a Reinhardt Theater
description: A new theater to celebrate the work of Max Reinhardt, the legendary AustrianJewish stage director, will be built in Tel Aviv as part of its cultural center, it was announced yesterday.

title: Giantism
description: WASHINGTONIf we ever want to make any progress in the Pentagon, somebody is going to have to reduce the number of offices, the number of generals and admirals and senior civilians, because every time one of those jobs is set up, each one of them gets a large staff. Each staff has to make work, so pretty soon the energy of the entire enterprise is taken up in doing, undoing, redoing, and satisfying everybody higher up and soon all productive work stops.

title: NATIONS PRESSED TO AID DESERTERS
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 A campaign on behalf of American servicemen who desert because of their opposition to the war in Indochina was launched here today by 200 prominent men and women from 17 countries.

title: U.N. Reports a Cartographic Controversy
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11Ever so discreetly, the United Nations has reported cartograhpic controversy involving a border dispute between Brunei and Sarawak.tions this week: How do you make Couve smile? Mention Schumann. How do you get Schumann to be serious? Mention Couve.

title: Buffalo Hunt 1971: Routine Disposal of Unwanted Game
description: HOUSEROCK, Ariz., Oct. 11  Mrs. Luann Vaughn, hunter No. 77, sat down on a dry ridge, of dirt, made herself comfortable, and her husband, Mike, handed her the rifle.

title: Tarlton Fleming Parsons, Retired Textile Executive
description: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 11Tarlton Fleming Parsons, who retired in 1956 as executive sales manager of Rosemary Sales Company in New York, a textile concern later acquired by J. P. Stevens & Co., died Saturday in Castle Point (N.Y.) Veterans Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at Voorhis Point.

title: COLLEGE TO BASE TUITION ON INCOME
description: Beloit College, a private, liberal arts school in Wisconsin, announced yesterday the adoption of a graduated tuition fee based on family income.

title: Galbraith Praises Nixon For Improving Economy
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist and author, has given President Nixon high praise for ending what he termed American selfimperialism and improving the economy.

title: Books of The Times
description: It Is ironic that Casanova's memoirs are popularly known chiefly for their sexual content, because he is the least pornographic of writers. In contrast to the characters of so many contemporary authors, he is so completely satisfied during his en. counters that he feels no desire to talk about them afterward. In the 12 volumes of his Life, there is hardly a single mention of a sexual part, or an explicit description of lovemaking. In this most concrete of contexts, Ile is at his most abstract, speaking only of charms, fires, happiness and bliss. Often it is like parsing a difficult. Latin sentence to discover exactly what happened.

title: Paris Metro Strike Extended
description: PARIS, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Drivers on the Paris Metro today ignored mounting public hostility and voted to extend their strike into its second week. Trade union officials said the decision was taken unanimously at a mass meeting attended by more than half the 2,000 drivers who began the shutdown last Tuesday.

title: RUTH LAREDO PLAYS IN A SCRIABIN CYCLE
description: Scriabin created a wild, ecstatic, visionary world in his 10 piano sonatas, and this hallucinatory music is, not surprisingly, coming back into favor nowadays, 100 years after the composer's birth.

title: Struggle for Democratic Credentials Post Is Tight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris, the candidate of the Democratic party's traditionalists, held a tenuous lead tonight in an Increasingly acrimonious fight for the job of temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee at the 1972 national convention.

title: Kennedy Asks Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, called today for an immediate investigation of refusal of several American soldiers to go on a patrol in South Vietnam. Any refusal by American soldiers to engage in combat is a cause of extremely serious concern, Senator Kennedy said.

title: Heath Voices Determination To End Violence in Ulster
description: LONDON, Oct. 11Prime Minister Heath expressed determination tonight to end the guerrilla campaign of violence in Northern Ireland and insure that everyone there has the same opportunities of life as we have in this country.

title: Shift in Crime Patterns Producing More Fences
description: Something golden glittered In the young man's palm as he sidled along 42d Street.

title: In the Footsteps of Cyrus?
description: Iranians are justifiably proud of an unusually rich national heritage dating back to the first Persian Empire established by Cyrus the Great roughly 2,500 years ago. Modern Iranians also have reason to celebrate the nation's accomplishments under the white revolution introduced by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi eight years ago. These include extensive land reform, the rapid spread of education and an impressive rate of industrial expansion.

title: Army Says Some G.I.'s Balked Briefly at Patrol
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11A United States Army spokesman said today that several American soldiers defending an allied fire base near the Cambodian border northwest of here balked for a time on Saturday night at going out on patrol.

title: Film Festival: Fascinated by Horror
description: Peter Watkins' Punishment Park is a movie of such blunt, wrongheaded sincerity that you're likely to sit through the first 10 hysterical minutes of it before realizing that it is, essentially, the wishfulfilling dream of a masochist.

title: Soviet Writer Says Peace In Vietnam Appears in Sight
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP)The Soviet journalist Victor Louis said in The London Evening News today that a negotiated end to the Vietnam war appears to be in sight.

title: RUMANIA VICTOR IN LAST SINGLES
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 11 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania completed a fourset victory over Frank Froehling 3d today in the meaningless final match of the Davis Cup challenge round.

title: Seoul Students Fight Polices
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 11 (AP)More than 7,500 students at six universities battled riot policemen today during a demonstration protesting alleged government corruption and a raid last week on Korea UniverSity by the army. At least 20 policemen and students were reported, most of them by stones and bricks.

title: George I. Hessen, 69, Dies; United Nations Interpreter
description: George I. Hessen, a retired United Nations interpreter from English and French into Russian, died on Friday in Roosevelt Hdspitai. He was 69 years old and lived at 132 West 82nd Street.

title: New Northern Electric Unit
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 11 (UPI)The Northern Electric Company, Ltd., Canada's largest manufacturer of telecommunications systems and equipment announced today formation of a United States subsidiary, Northern Telecom, Inc. The new unit has headquarters in Boston and will oversee sales and distribution operations in the United States.

title: First National Bank of Chicago Lifts Net
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the holdingcompany parert of the First National Bank of Chicago, the nation's 10th largest, reported yesterday a 9.6 per cent earnings gain from operations in the third quarter.

title: Lawmaker Would End Holiday Parking Rules
description: Angered over ticketing of cars parked near the Ocean Parkway Jewish Center, 550 Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn, Councilman Howard Golden, Democrat of Brooklyn, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation suspending all parking regulations on major Jewish and. Christian holy days and state and Federal holidays.

title: Group Urges Limited Role For Stewart as a Jetport
description: Government authorities should limit eventual growth of Stewart Airport to 100,000 airline flights a year to protect nearby residents from excessive jet noise, a planning group said yesterday.

title: Freeze Saves a Relicthe 5Cent Phone Call in Rural Jersey Town
description: VERNON TOWNSHIP, N.J. President Nixon may not be able to keep the New York subway fare from going up, and it is probably too late to bring back the 5cent cigar, but if he does nothing else the President will at least be remembered here as the man who kept the nickel telephone call alive.

title: Towns Near Santa Barbara Saved From Brush Fires
description: SUMMERLAND, Calif., Oct. 11 (CPOPacific Coast communities threatened by a brush fire were declared safe today, and weary firefighters attacked the blaze on a new front, setting backfires on remote interior ridges with incendiary deyices dropped from hellCopters.

title: N.B.C. Drops to 3d in Latest Nielsen TV Ratings
description: The National Broadcasting Company dropped from second to third place yesterday in the third weekly Nielsen program popularity ratings.

title: Newton Trial Starts Today
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 11 (UPI)For the third time in four years, Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, goes on trial tomorrow on charges of killing a policeman during predawn shootout. Newton, 29 years old, returned from Communist China last weekend for the start of his trial on charges of Voluntary manslaughter.

title: Swiss to Recognize Hanoi
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (UNI)  A communiqu on Swiss recognition of North Vietnam on the ambassadorial level was silmultaneously made public in Hanpi and Bern today. The No Vietnamese press agency reported.

title: Peter Rindskopt, 29, Dead; Atlanta Olvil Right Lawyer
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 11  Peter Eric Rindskopf a civil rights lawyer was drowned Saturday when a rural roadway in Rabun County collapsed beneath his jeep and he was catapulted into a nearby stream. He was 29 years old.

title: Superstar a Hit Before Opening
description: When Jesus Christ Super. star opens tonight at the Mark Hellinger, it will probably be the most presold musical in Broadway history. There are already indications before the reviews are published  that it may be the most profitable.

title: Gravel Acts on Amchitka
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 11 (UPI)Senator Mike Gravel, Democrat of Alaska, said today that he would demand that the White House release two environmental impact studies on the proposed underground nuclear test scheduled to take place this month at Amchitka Island.

title: Nippon Seeks U.S. Concern For Joint Jetliner Venture
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The Nippon manufacturing Company said today that it would shortly begin preliminary negotiations with three major American aircraft makers for a proposed, joint development to make Japan's first mediumrange jet airliner.

title: CHICANOS OPPOSED TO MRS. BANUELOS
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 11 (Reuters)A conference of six MexicanAmerican organizations has asked President Nixon to withdraw his nomination of Mrs. Romana Banuelos for the post of Treasurer of the United States.

title: 7 Seized as Tenant Protest Ties Up Traffic on 8th Ave.
description: Seven persons were arrested and traffic on Eighth Avenue at 21st Street was blocked for an hour yesterday afternoon as 50. tenants demonstrated against what they called the city's retreat from a promise to provide them with lowinterest loans to buy and renovate their buildings at 222 and 224 West 21st Street.

title: No Rest on Columbus Day
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) President Nixon met today with Aldo Moro, Italy's Minlister of Foreign Affairs, and jokingly observed that Columbus Day is a holiday except for the President, Foreign Ministers and the press. Mr. Moro, who is attending the United Nations General Assembly sessions, replied that politics knows no rest or holidays. The remarks occurred when Mr. Nixon invited photographers into the Oval Office, where the two conferred.

title: Chomsky Gets Subpoena
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (UPI)Prof. Noam A. Chomsky of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology said today that he had been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles investigating the leaking of the Pentagon papers to the press.

title: Mores Change, Marriage Counselors Say, but Not the Problems
description: Despite swiftly changing lifestyles, marital problems today are much the same as they were a decade and a generation ago. And marriage counselors say they have never been so busy.

title: A Few Jeers Mar the Friendly Reception as Hirohito Arrives in Bonn
description: BONN, Oct. 11Emperor Hirohito of Japan started a threeday state visit to West Germany here today among generally friendly crowds.

title: JEAN PIERSON
description: Jean Pierson, associate beauty editor of Vogue, magazine, died Sunday in New York Hospital. Her home was at 21 Bethune Street.

title: British Inquiry Urged
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP)Two British lawmakers called on the Government today to investigate allegations that hospital patients dying of cancer were being used as human guinea pigs in medical experiments.

title: Football TV Case in Court
description: TULSA, Okla., Oct. 11 (AP)The right of the National Collegiate Athletic Association to limit football telecasts will be tested in court tomorrow. Dr. Paid Sharp, president of the University of Oklahoma, and Torn Hanson, representing the N.C.A.A., have been subpoenaed to appear before District Court Judge Robert Simms.

title: Namath, Determined to Play This Year, Will Drill Today
description: Despite the New York Jets' disastrous start, Joe Namath is determined to return at quarterback as soon as possible.

title: CITY TO USE FORCE IN A PRISON RIOT
description: Since the end of disturbances an four of its correctional facilities last year, the city has hada policy that calls for mediate entry of correction officers into prisons to quell disturbances and to retake hostages or areas occupied by rebellious inmates.

title: Canadian Declines Comment
description: KINGSTON, Ont., (Reuters) Oct. 11Finance Minister Edgar J. Benson declined comment today on a published report that the United States had given Canadian authorities a list of demands that must be met before the United States would lift the 10 per cent surcharge on Canadian imports.

title: Stage: Joining the Odyssey of the Liquid Theater
description: New York and Los Angeles, those twin cities of the plain and fancy, have something new in common. It is called the James Joyce Memorial Liquid Theater, and last night it openedor started publicly flowingin the unlikely but happily apt precincts of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. What would Frank Lloyd Wright have thought? Come to that, what would James Joyce have thought?

title: P.O.W. Is Freed by U.S. In Return for G.I. Release
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11A North Vietnamese lieutenant was released today as part of a oneforone prisoner exchange initiated by the enemy, United States officials said.

title: TEXAS GROUP SEEKS UNITIZATION OIL LAW
description: DALLAS, Oct. 11 (AP)The Texas MidContinent Oil and Gas Association said today that an impending energy crisis called for a fieldwide unitization law in Texas:

title: JapanU.S. Talks to Reopen
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Oct. 12 (AP)The Japanese Cabinet decided today to reopen Governmentlevel textile negotiations with the United States. Officials said details on time and place have not yet been decided. The talks are expected to be held in Tokyo, with hopes of reaching agreement by Oct. 15.

title: Credit Markets: Bond Prices Change Little in Dull Session
description: The corporate and taxexempt bond markets, partly closed for Columbus Day, twiddled their thumbs yesterday. Few prices changed and trading activity was almost at a standstill.

title: NINA SIMONE GETS WARM RECEPTION
description: Nina Simone, who has been up and been down, been in and been out during the last 12 years of her career, is apparently in once again and more strongly than ever. An audience that filled Philharmonic Hall on Sunday evening greeted her with cheers when she stepped on the stage and showered her with adulation all through her relatively brief program.

title: 7,000 Jews in Moscow Mark Simhath Torah
description: Moscow, Oct. 11About 7,000 Jews, the majority of them young people, danced the hora and sang Hebrew songs outside the Central Synagogue tonight to commemorate Simhath Torah, the joyous holiday celebrating the giving of the Ten Commandments to Moses.

title: A.B.C.TV Adds Bill Russell
description: Bill Russell, the retired basketball star, will do the commentary on the American Broadcasting Company's accounts of the National Basketball Association's game of the week.

title: Widow Says Reawakening of Interest In Work Can Inspire Negro Children
description: Mr. Johnson is more alive than you could ever believe, James Weldon Johnson's 85yearold widow observed the other day, while speaking about the current centennial birthday celebration of her husband.

title: Bethlehem to Sell Land
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 11 (UPI)  The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced plans today to sell about 1,400 acres of land at its site in Pinoile Points, near Richmond, Calif. Bethlehem retains additional acreage at the site on San Pablo Bay, and will continue galvanizing and other fabricating operations there.

title: JAPAN IS PLANNING TO DOUBLE OUTLAY FOR U.S WEAPONS
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11The minister in charge of Japanese defense said today that the Government of Premier Eisaku Sato was prepared to double its purchases of military equipment from the United States to help reduce the deficit in the American balance of payments with Japan.

title: 2 CARRIERS MAY GO TO NAVAL RESERVES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Navy may turn some aircraft carriers over to the naval reserves.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korean Pact Expected
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 11 (Reuters)South Korea is expected to reach a governmental agreement for curbing its noncotton textile exports to the United States by the United Statesset deadline of Friday, Commerce and Industry Minister NakSun Lee said today.

title: Music: Spanish Style
description: No one understands the evocative power of Spanish music, least of all Spaniards, though they play it as no one else can. If you examine that mystical statement it will evaporate in the dry air of logic; but never mind, when you get the chance to hear Spanish musicians play Spanish music, take it. You'll seldom lose.

title: Caltex Oil Investment Set
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 11 (Reuters)The Caltex Oil Company will invest an additional $60million in Indonesia to speed its production target of 1 million barrels of oil a day, the Antara News Agency reported today. Caltex officials put present daily production at 724,000 barrels.

title: Musical Iphigenia Due
description: A new musical adaptation of Euripides's Iphigenia in Aulis will be presented next month at Martinson Hall in the New York Shakespeare Festival Publie Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, it was announced yesterday by Joseph Papp, festival producer and founder. Entitled The Wedding of Iphigenia Plus Iphigenia in Concert; the show has been adapted and directed by Doug Dyer. Peter Link has provided the music.

title: STOCKS OFF A BIT; VOLUME AT A LOW
description: The stock market registered a modest decline yesterday as trading volume, slowed by the observance of Columbus Day, fell to its lowest level in more than a year.

title: New York Antiques Fair Opens; Paintings More in Abundance
description: Perhaps no antiques show in New York has had as many paintings as the New York Antiques Fair, which opened yesterday in the 69th Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and 26th Street.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11If only they had waited fifty years to invent the private eye. . . .

title: Tent. City. Awaits Celebration: Shah's Greatest Show
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Oct. 11 The water buffalo and camel have rehearsed for a week. The European waiters have taught their Iranian assistants how to pour wine without spilling it. The freshly planted yellow and white daisies survived their flight from Paris. The tent city here in the desert is almost ready for what Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, the Shahanshah of Iran, has called the greatest show the world has ever seen.

title: 65 Arrests Made
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 (AP) Arrests growing out of last weekend's unsuccessful uprising against President Lanusse reached 65 today. A former President, a brigadier general and a Roman Catholic priest were among those detained.

title: 4 Americans Advance
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Four Americans triumphed today, three of them in straight sets, in an international tennis tournament. Jeff Borowiak of Los Angeles had the toughest match before eliminating Terry Ryan of South Africa, 76, 67, 62. The other United States victories were Charles Pasarell of San Juan, P.R., Bob Lutz of Los Angeles and Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: GAY HEAD, Mass.A gray mist was on the water and dawn was 20 minutes away when Maurice Montgomery of Watertown, Mass., and I arrived at the West Basin for a day of striped bass fishing along Martha's Vineyard's North Shore.

title: 5 in Georgia Family Die As Blast Levels Home
description: CARTERSVILLE, Ga., Oct. 11 (UPI)Five members of a Georgia family were killed today in an explosion at their rural home, and authorities learned that a new gas heater was installed only a few days ago.

title: Cowboys Beat Giants, 2013, on 2 Scoring Passes
description: DALLAS, Oct. 11For 41 mniutes tonight, the New York Giants flirted with a major upset, but finally had to settle for merely a noble effort in losing to the Dallas Cowboys, 2013.

title: LICHSTEIN LEADS NATIONAL BOWLING
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 11If firstround scoring was any indication, lefthanders are going to have their way as the $85,000 national championship of the Professional Bowlers As sociation unfolds this week at Paramus Bowling.

title: ExConvict Denied Seat By Milwaukee Council
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 11 (UPI)  The Milwaukee attorney's offide ruled today that Jimmie G. Davison, convicted in 1959 of rape, cannot legally. serve as an alderman. The Common council, which had voted last week to seat Davison, decided unanimously to honor the city attorney's opinion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Nixon's, Revenge
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11In the closing hours of the 1970 campaign, Richard Nixon climbed on the foot of his car in San Jose, Calif., and gave back to a hostile crowd of radical youths the peace sign which they regard as peculiarly their own. He received the answering roar of boos and catcalls he had hoped to elicit.

title: Japanese Increase Investment in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, Oct. 11Japanese consumer goods, television sets, radios, water pumps and diesel engines, some of the goods that have flooded the South Vietnamese market because of American  supported import laws, are beginning to be produced by Japanese manufacturers herethe latest sign of their growing economic interest in Vietnam.

title: Berliner Flees to the East
description: BERLIN, Oct. 11 (AP)West Berlin policeman reported another crossing of the Berlin Wall todaythis one from west to east. They said Herbert Proll, 29 years old, who was under arrest for suspected burglary, Pled from his police escort near the Heinrichstrasse crossing point and sprinted for the East German control building, still wearing handcuffs. They later saw East German border officials dead Proll away.

title: Medical, Center in Cincinnati Defends WholeBody Radiation in Cancer Care
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 11  Officials of the University of Cincinnati's Medical Center said today that a center program of applying wholebody or partialbody atomic radiation to terminal cancer patients a technique that is relatively rare  fins had, some posytive results.

title: U.S. Reported to List Conditions To Canada for Lifting Surcharge
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) The Nixon Administration has established a list of demands that Canada must meet before the United States will lift its 10 per cent import surcharge against Canadian goods, The Chicago Tribune reported today.

title: N.Y.U. Library Delayed as Cost Soars
description: Several years ago New York University drew up plans to build a new general library omits Washington Square campus, and to publish a biography of the building's leading private benefactor, Elmer Holmes Bobst. Both projects are running two years behind schedule.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Six years ago John William Warner suffered a broken back when a horse threw him. He was in a cast from his shoulders to his knees for seven months and doctors said he would never ride again.

title: Brimmer Urges Overhaul Of Foreign Credit Curbs
description: Andrew F. Brimmer, who administers the Federal Reserve's voluntary foreign credit restraints, called yesterday for a complete overhaul of the program.

title: Airline Agree on 4% Rise In Fares for South Pacific
description: MIAMI, Oct. 11 (AP)A 4 per cent increase in airline ticket prices for firstclass and economy fare travelers in the South Pacific, effective April 1, 1972, was announced today by the International Air Transport Association.

title: EMW Ventures Expands In $27.5Million Stock Sale
description: EMW Ventures, Inc., a venturecapital affiliate of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Co., Inc., has increased its equity capital to $41.5million through a private placement of common stock by Salomon Brothers, Lionel Pincus, president of Warburg  Pincus, announced yesterday.

title: U.S.Japan Steel Pact Proposed
description: TORONTO, Oct. 11Yoshihiro Inayama, chairman of Japan's Iron and Steel Federation, said today that he had proposed to the United States a threeyear extension of Japan's voluntary steelexport restraints with a reduced growth factor.

title: How to Undermine the Court
description: If President Nixon and Attorney General Mitchell deliberately set out to destroy the prestige and authority of the Supreme Court of the United States, they could hardly pick a more likely course than that which they now seem to be following.

title: EVERS SUPPORTS MUSKIE ON BLACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) Charles Evers, independent black candidate for Governor of Mississippi, said today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie told the truth when he said that a black could not be elected Vice President next year.

title: Congress Fight Likely on Housing Bill Giving Controls to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 An intense fight is shaping up in Congress on legislation that would make basic changes in Federal housing programs, including shifting controls to the local level while encouraging dispersal of more subsidized units.

title: TV Review
description: If it's Monkeys, Apes, and Man, this must be National Geographic. It is. The society's series, produced in association with Wolper Productions, returns tonight at 7:30 on the Columbia Broadcasting System for its seventh season on television.

title: Bronx District Attorney's Office Gets Bug Detection Equipment
description: Electronic equipment to detect hidden recording devices has been purchased by the office of the Bronx District Attorney, following the discovery last summer of what was first believed to be a hidden bug.

title: Japaneso Decision Today
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters)Japan will decide tomorrow whether to enter into negotiations with the United States on a Governmentlevel pact restricting textile exports to the American market, Mr. Tanaka said, tonight.

title: U.S. Inspectors Upset About Inability to Find Botulin Cause in Campbell Soup
description: Federal food inspectors are disturbed that, after seven weeks of intensive investigation, they have been unable to find anything wrong in the Campbell Soup Company plant that produced and sold soup containing lethal botulin toxin.

title: MRS. MARION S. PARKER
description: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Oct. 11 Mrs. Marion Stevens Parker, who had been active in local music and little theater groups, died yesterday here. She was 83 years old and lived in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: CHESTER CONKLIN, SILENT FILM STAR
description: HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 11 (UPI) Chester Conklin, a pioneer movie comedian in the slapstick era bf tworeel silents, died today at the age of 83.

title: RYAN BLAMES STATE FOR CITY FARE CRISIS
description: Representative William F. Ryan, Democrat of New York City, charged yesterday that the state had planned to impose a 50cent fare on New Yorkers all along.

title: Two Subjects for Centennial: Dreiser and Johnson
description: In this, the centennial year of Theodore Dreiser's birth, the poor boy from Terre Haute, Ind., continues to hold a central place in international literary esteem, if not in the affections of his fellow Hoosiers.

title: Memorex Disc Unit Works With an I.B.M. Computer
description: The Memorex Corporation announced, yesterday a new disc memory drive that can be plugged into International Business Machines Corporation computers. The device, called the 3670, was described by Memorex as a replacement for I.B.M. 3330 disc drive.

title: Seasonings Unit Formed
description: The National Starch and Chemical Corporation has formed Seasonings, Inc. as a wholly owned subsidiary in the food flavorings industry. The new unit incorporates the operations of the food products division of Universal Oil Products acquired earlier this month.

title: Saudi Arabian Line To Get $13Million In Eximbank Loan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (Reuter)The United States ExportImport Bank will lend $13;428,000 to Saudi Arabian Airlines to finance 36 per cent of the cost, of five Boeing 737 aircraft, with spare engines and parts, it was announced today.

title: LTV Unit Gets Contract
description: DALLAS, Oct. 11 (Reuters) LTV Aerospace Corporation said today it has received a $10.3million Army contract for fiscal 1,972 procurement of long leadtime items for the Lance missile system.

title: SADAT IN MOSON FOR TALKS ON AID
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11 President Anwar elSadat of Egypt arrived today for talks with Soviet leaders at a delicate moment in Middle Eastern diplomacy and at a time of apparently increasing strain between Moscow and Cairo.

title: JOHN HANEMAN JR., AN AD EXECUTIVE, 48
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 41 John T. Haneman Jr., a senior vice president, director and member of the executive committee of Albert FrankGuenther law, Inc., New York advertising and public relations concern, died today of cancer in Huntington Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived here.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEF IN TEXAS QUITTING
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 11 (AP)Dr. Elmer Baum, chairman of the executive committee of the Texas Democratic party, said today that he was resigning his political post.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Orioles Pout Pirates, 113, And Take 20 Series Lead
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11The Baltimore Orioles crushed the Pittsburgh Pirates, 113, today and took a twogame grip on the 68th World Series. They did it with 14 hitsall singlesand seven walks off six pitchers used by the National League champions. That was enough to make Jim Palmer a winner for the Orioles, though he tired after eight innings, in which he allowed seven hits, eight walks and struck out 10 batters.

title: Wrong Road to Equality
description: It is highly improbable that many black Americans support the contention of Roy Innis that black nationalism is the road to true equality. The director of the Congress of Racial Equality is nevertheless within the bounds of American precedent in turning down assimilation and integration as the only acceptable way life. Many other ethnic and religious groups have in the past opted for selfimposed separateness.

title: Merger News
description: The General Instrument Corporation agreed yesterday to sell the 10 CATV systems operated by its Jerrold subsidiary for $30million to the National Transvideo Corporation, a subsidiary of Sammons Enterprises, a privately owned Dallas concern. The transaction involves cable TV systems serving about 100,000 subscribers in Illinois, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Texas, Virginia, Kansas and Kentucky.

title: Verna Rainbow Victor In $48,637 Sire Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 11 Verna Rainbow and Nevele Freight, the Stanley Dancer Stable entry, finished one, two in the $48,637, onemile New York Sire Stakes Pace for 2yearold fillies at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

title: 1,000 Sailors Said to Ask Ban on Carrier's Sailing
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Oct. 11 (AP)A group of 11 American servicemen said today that 1,000 crewmen from the aircraft carrier Coral Sea had petitioned Congress to keep their ship from sailing to another combat mission off Vietnam.

title: Great Western Omits Payout
description: The Great Western United Corporation announced yesterday that the 90  cent current annual cash dividend on the common stock has been eliminated. William M. White, chairman and president, said, Conservation of cash in part through elimination of the common cash dividend will further enable us to manage our growth businesses.

title: FUTURES TRADING LACKS DIRECTION
description: Several commodity exchanges were closed yesterday and those that were open witnessed desultory trading.

title: DANIEL TAYLOR. DIES; A DESIGNER OF MAPS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11 Daniel M. Taylor, designer and publisher of maps widely used in schools in the New York Metropolitan area, died yesterday at Greenwich. Hospital. He lived at 23 Maple Avenue.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: In light holiday trading, prices on the American Stock Exchange tended to be lower yesterday, although the index close unchanged from Friday's level at 25.67. Stocks that showed price declines totaled 465, outnumbering advancing issues, which totaled 372, and unchanged issues, which amounted to 268.

title: CAROLINA SHOOTINGS KILL MAN, HURT GIRL
description: JACKSON, S. C., Oct. 11 (AP) An assailant's bullet that apparently was fired at the city police chief today as he was directing traffic ripped into a school bus nearby and wounded a 12yearold girl, the Aiken County Sheriff's Department said.

title: 4 Black Separatists Freed, Leader Is Held for Inquiry
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 11 (AP)Imari Obadele, a black separatist leader, went to a Hinds County jail cell in lieu of $50,000 bond today after four of his Republic of New Africa followers won conditional freedom to await grand jury action on charges of slaying a city policeman.

title: ExHumphrey Aide in Race
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 11 (UPI)Ronald F. Stinnett, former assistant to Senator Humphrey, announced today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for the seat now held by Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee.

title: Etter, Notre Dame Back, Undergoes Knee Surgery
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 11 (UPI)Bill Etter of Spokane, a Notre Dame quarterback, was believed to be out for the season after he underwent knee surgery today for an injury sustained Saturday against Miami of Florida.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 The sun shone brightly today. So did the Orioles. But the Pittsburgh Pirates still seemed fogged in by yesterday's bad weather and had little sense of direction as they groped their way up blind alleys and found nothing but humiliation. The Baltimores poleaxed the Pittsburghers, 11 to 3.

title: News Analysis
description: The country preacher magnetism of the Rev. Jesse Louis Jackson that attracted 800,000 of the bestknown and least known citizens to the 3d anearlier this month has left several questions unanswered in that kaleidoscope of sights, sounds and hunmanity. It seems likely that, before Mr. Jackson's Operation Breadbasket produces its 4th annual celebration of black life styles next September, some of the questions will be answered.

title: William Costello, Musician; Voice of Popeye in Films
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 11 (UPI)  William A. Costello, who for 25 years was the gravelly screen voice of Popeye the Sailor Man of cartoon fame, died here Saturday. His age was 73.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Meet Cookie. The year's most unlikely heroine; $6.96 al your bookstoreAdvl.

title: Sergei Konenkov Is Dead at 97; Soviet Sculptor Worked in U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 11  Sergei Konenkov, one of the oldest Soviet sculptors, died here last Saturday at the age of 97.

title: Orioles 92 to Take Series
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct 11 (UPI)Baltimore is now a 9to2 favorite to win the World Series over the Pittsburgh Pirates and 1310 to take the third game.

title: Nixon Health Plan Is Called Unrealistic
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 11The Nixon Administration's proposal to reduce medical costs and extend the benefits of modern medicine to more people through Health Maintenance Organizations was challenged here today as unrealistic, financially unviable, unresponsive to the consumer and doomed to failure.

title: MISSISSIPPI WHITE CLEARED IN KILLING
description: WEST POINT, Miss., Oct. 11 (AP)Seth Stanley, a white factory worker, was found not guilty today of the murder of John Thomas, Negro civil rights worker.

title: Tarrell Raises Streak, 140
description: Touchdtwns by Ken De George, a fullback, in the final period enabled undefeated Monsignor Farrell to extend its streak of 23 games as Brooklyn Tech lost, 14.0, yesterday at Oakwood, Staten Island. Farrell has won its last 12 games.

title: RICHARD C. GLOCAU
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 11Richard C. Glogau, senior vice president of Engelhard Minerals & Chemicals Corporation, died Saturday at his home here, 18 Woods Way. He was 55 years old.

title: Company Is Replaced
description: SAIGON, Tuesday, Oct 12 (AP)A United States infantry company in which five men balked at going out on a night ambush patrol was removed today from Fire Base Pace.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Numbered Account Wins;
description: Numbered Account virtually clinched the 2yearold filly championship yesterday at Belmont Park when she won the $135,875 Frizette. Ogden Phipps's formidable campaigner, a Kentucky  bred daughter of Buckpasser and Intriguing, scampered to a sevenlength triumph in the onemile test, in which she was opposed by only three others.

title: Nigeria to Resume Ties
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 11 (AP) The Nigerian Government said today that it would exchange ambassadors with the Ivory Coast, Zambia and Tanzaniathe three African countries with which it severed diplomatic relations over the Biafran war. Nigeria broke relations with the three countries when they recognized the secessionist state of Biafra in 1968. Biafra surrendered in January, 1970.

title: ItalianAmerican League Holds Its Own Columbus Day Ceremony
description: Spurned by the organizers of New York's Columbus Day festivities, 50 members of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League had their own wreathlaying ceremony yesterday morning at Columbus Circle.

title: Court Rules Execution Is Not Cruel Punishment
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 11 (AP) A sentence of death by electrocution is not cruel and unusual punishment and thus is constitutional, the Vir ginia Supreme Court ruled today.

title: National City Bank Urges Floating Currency Values
description: The First National City Bank, the nation's largest bank internationally, called yesterday for an orderly system of floating exchange rates as the best way out of the present international financial crisis.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HONOLULU, Oct. 11 (UPI)Nine, sailors who missed the carrier Constellation's departure from San Diego in protest against its return to Vietnam waters have been found guilty of three charges and sentenced to 30 days in corrective custody, the Navy announced today. The nine, who were arrested by Federal officials and flown to the ship, were tried before the Constellation's captain, J. D. Ward, at sea Saturday.

title: Construction Loan Set
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 11 (UPI)  First Mortgage Investors, Inc., has announced it has arranged a $12million construction loan for a 17story office building in downtown San Francisco to the Education Facilities Leasing Corporation, the prospective builder.

title: U.S. Adviser Quits Vietnam to Show His Disgust
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11A 26yearold Foreign Service officer, who spent 13 months in Vietnam as a refugee expert, quit his Job and left South, Vietnam last week without notice. He said his action was intended to show disgust with the United States role and policies in Vietnam.

title: 6 OWNERS RESIGN AS OTB ADVISERS
description: Charging Howard Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, with bad faith, six harness horse owners resigned yesterday from OTB's advisory board to protest OTB's decision to televise races this winter and possibly next summer from Monticello Raceway in the Catskills.

title: Digital Corp. Expanding
description: MAYNARD, Mass., Oct. 11 (Reuters) The Digital Equipment Corporation said today it plans a 260,000squarefoot addition to double the size of its manufacturing and assembly plant in Westminster, Mass. The space will be used for expansion of the present manufacturing facilities for the new DEC System 10 largescale computers.

title: Strong Action Backed in Poll
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The Opinion Research Corporation reported today that 59 per cent of the general public, and 49 per cent of union families, believe that the Government should take strong action against unions that refuse to cooperate with President Nixon's economic program.

title: Chilean Aide Rules Against Payments To 2 U.S. Concerns
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11Chile's Controller General ruled today that two of the three large United States copper companies with interests in Chile should receive no compensation for nationalization of their properties.

title: Soviet Aid Indispensable
description: CAIRO, Oct. 11Soviet antiaircraftmissile, experts and interceptor pilots are considered indispensable to protect Egyptian industry, transport and other vital targets from Israeli air superiority in the event of another outbreak of war.

title: MRS. SCHOALES DIES; AN EXECUTIVE OF PM
description: SCARBOROUGH  ON HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 11Mrs. Virginia Vanderlip Schoales, who was assistant publisher of the former New York newspaper PM and the wife of Dudley N. Schoales, a partner in Morgan Stanley & Co., died at their home on the family estate here yesterday. She was 62 years old.

title: McGovern Would Oppose Byrd; Rules Out a Racist for Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11Senator George McGovern backed quickly away today from his warm words of yesterday about Senator Robert C. Byrd's suitability for the Supreme Court.

title: U.S. Businessmen in Asia To Meet Cabinet Officers
description: TOKYO, Oct. 11A group of about 10 American businessmen who work in Asia is scheduled to meet in Washington next week with Cabinet officers and other senior officials of the Nixon Administration to discuss Administration economic policies that affect American business in this area.

title: Earnings Rise 26% At Allied Chemical
description: Operating results of the Allied Chemical Corporation rose 26 per cent in the third quarter continuing the recovery trend of the half year except for basic and agricultural chemicals. Operating earnings for the first nine months rose 43 per cent over the 1970 period, the report disclosed yesterday.

title: State Reports Drop to 17.4% in NoShows for Relief Check
description: A reduction in the number of employable welfare recipients who failed to pick up their checks at state employment offices was shown yesterday in data from the State Labor Department.

title: TIMES TO ASK LOSS BE PAID BY UNION
description: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday that it intended recover from New York Stereotypers Union Local 1 damages suffered by the company as a result of work stoppages by its stereotypers last Saturday and Sunday nights.

title: Envoy Backs Bangla Desh
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 (Reuters)  Pakistanis Ambassador to Argentina, Abdul Momin, quit his post here today to support the Bangla Desh independence movement in East Pakistan. Before flying to London with his wife and three children, the Ambassador said he planned to spread the movement's cause.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Youths, Denied 25c By Medical Student, Shoot Him in Back
description: A 21yearold Sinai Hospital medical student was shot in the back and seriously wounded last night when he refused to give a gang of six high school and junior high school students a quarter they demanded.

title: Sanguillen Finds Orioles Don't Quit While Ahead
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 Manny Sanguillen, Pittsburgh's rugged catcher, received today a double dose of one of the ingredients that make the Baltimore Orioles the champions they are.

title: Play on Zionism Founder
description: The Man Behind the Legend, a play by Yaacov Orland, based on the diaries and autobiography of Theodor Herzl, founder of modern Zionism, will have its New York premiere Oct. 24 at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street. Martin Bard will play Dr. Herzl. The play will tour the United States after the local premiere.

title: Advertising:
description: As the keynote speaker at the Western convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, Edward M. Thiele, association chairman and vice chairman of Leo Burnett, got started by, defining for his Coronado, Calif., audience what irresponsible consumerism is.

title: Councilman Asks Special Bike Lanes Not Just Deadly Signs
description: Charging that the Lindsay bikeway program is a deadly hoax on our citizens which will result in death and injuries, Eldon R. Clingan, the City Council minority leader, said yesterday he would introduce a bill to create a citywide network of traffic lanes reserved only for bicycles.

title: ExWilson Aide Appointed
description: LONDON, Oct. 11Michael Palliser, a former private secretary to Harold Wilson, was appointed today to head the British delegation to the European Economic Community. Mr. Palliser, 49 years old, as British minister in Paris, played a role in the successful diplomatic effort to end France's veto of British membership in the community.

title: HEARINGS TO OPEN ON MARKET TODAY
