description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission will begin public hearings tomorrow to determine ways to create a strong central market system hi the securities industry, William J. Casey, S.E.C, chainnan, Said today.

title: Disguising Exercise With the Word Ballt
description: Among the lost dreams of a wellrounded housewife is there a vision of a younger, slimmer self floating en pointe across a ballet stage? Apparently.

title: A Housing Victory Heartens South Africa's Chinese
description: JOHANNESBURG, Oct. 11The Wongs have won the right to live in a white neighborhood here, and South Africa's small Chinese community is hoping for a new attitude toward them.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the telephone company's time bureau.

title: Landlords Say Expenses Increase Despite Freeze
description: Landlords here say they are finding many, of their major costs rising despite the Federal wageprice freeze.

title: 2 Youths Saved in Hudson
description: The crew of a police launch rescued two students from the Stevens Institute of Technology of Hoboken, N. J., when a gust of wind overturned their 16foot sailboat in the Hudson River at 87th Street at 1:45 P.M. yesterday. The students, Douglas Burner, 17 years old, of Wilton, Conn., and William Monsees, 18, of 163 Stewart Terrace, Totowah, N. J., were not injured.

title: Raphael's Lorenzo to Be Shown
description: A portrait of Lorenzo de Medici, Duke of Urbino, which has been authenticated by four experts as a work by Raphael, will be put on public display in the near future, tits discoverer, Ira Spanierman, said yesterday. No date for the exhibition has yet been set, however.

title: SAIGON SAYS TROOPS CLASH AGAIN AT BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct, 11 (AP)Fighting on both sides of the Cambodian border continued today but on a diminished scale, South Vietnamese spokesman said.

title: Bridge: Good Judgment Is Required In Timing an Attacking Lead
description: Against a suit contract, the tendency is to make a passive opening lead that will not help the declarer. Picking the right moment to make an attacking lead that may give away a trick is not easy and requires good judgment. It is sometimes right to attack if the opponents reach five clubs or five diamonds: The fact that they have avoided three notrump may indicate that they are exposed in one suit, and the defenders had better cash some winners before discards are possible.

title: Rudolf Wittkower, Art Expert Who Taught at Columbia, Dies
description: Rudolf Wittkower, art historian and Avalon Foundation Professor Emeritus in the humanities at Columbia University, died apparently of a heart attack yesterday noon at the Men's Faculty Club. He was 70 years old and lived at 25 Claremont Avenue.

title: C. R. BERG,
description: RIDDEWOOD; N. S. Oct. 11,  C. D. Berg, managing direew for of the New York Produce Exchange, died Saturday at his home, 444 Colonial Road, after a brief illness. His age was 51 was 51.

title: Women's Rights Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, and the ranking Republican on the committee, Representative William M. McCulloch of Ohio, circulated a letter today to all members of the House urging them to reject a proposed constitutional amendment that would give women equal rights, or to accept qualifying language that would keep women from being drafted. The House is scheduled to vote on the amendment tomorrow.

title: Piedmont and Union Agree
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 11 (UPI) Piedmont Airlines and the Machinists and Aerospace Workers Union reached, a tentative agreement early today on a new contract.

title: Civil Liberties Unit Flunks Legislature On Voting Record
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union issued yesterday the first of what are planned as annual ratings of the state's legislators, and declared the Legislature as a whole a civil liberties disgrace.

title: 2 LIBERALS GET ARGENTINE POSTS
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 President Alejandro Agustin Lanusse moved his Cabinet slightly leftward today by naming two liberals to replace the conservative Ministers of Justice and Finance.

title: Sex Bias Charged at Penn
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (UPI) A group of 350 women at the University of Pennsylvania said today that they had filed a complaint with the State Human Relations Commission charging the school with bias in admissions, hiring, promotion, salary and personnel benefit practices. The group, known as Women for Equal Opportunity, represents students, faculty, clerical and custodial employes.

title: Notes on People
description: The installation of Derek C. Bok as the 25th president of Harvard University, the nation's oldest, was a subdued affair compared with similar ceremonies.

title: MAN DIES AS CAR PLUNGES IN RIVER
description: One man was killed and three other persons injured last night when a car speeding from the police went through an expressway railing and plunged into the Bronx River.

title: Anniversaries
description: BERENSONFannie and Jack. Happy 60th Wedding Anniversary. Daughter, Judith, grandchildren, Bruce, Steven, Robert, Lob Beth Mann.

title: Banks Here Were Closed To Observe Columbus Day
description: Banks in New York were closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day. The Commodity Exchange was also closed for the day, along with other exchanges trading in coffee, sugar, cocoa, cotton, wool and orange juice. Canadian markets were closed for Thanksgiving.

title: STILL POINT DANCED BY JOFFREY BALLET
description: The slight charm of Todd Bolender's The Still Point is that it is a story of boy meets girl outside of any particular time and yet applicable to a variey of places and persons. The City Center Jeffrey Ballet presented it Sunday for the first time this season with Pamela Johnson and Dennis Wayne as the lead couple.

title: Views on Changes Sought From Exchange Members
description: The New York Stock Exchange, which last month asked its listed companies for their views on the proposed reorganization of the exchange, made the same request of its members yesterday.

title: Mills Says House Gives President Sufficient Help
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 11 (AP)  The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Wilbur D. Mills, of Arkansas, said today that the House had given President Nixon even better economic tools than he requested and that leadership was now the key to turning the tide against inflation.

title: U.S. Is Advised to Devalue With 20% Gold Price Rise
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 11 (AP)A French vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation says that the United States could devalue the dollar by raising the price of gold 20 per cent without helping the goldproducing nations of South Africa or the Soviet Union.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: DR. FRANKLIN HANGER
description: Dr. Franklin M. Hanger, professor emeritus of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died Sunday in his home in Staunton, Va. He was 77 years old.

title: Hepatitis at Bowling Green
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Oct. 11 (UPI)The Bowling Green State University athletic department announced today that one of its football players had contracted infectious hepatitis and said all varsity and freshmen players and coaches have been inoculated as a preventive measure. Officials said all practices and games would continue as scheduled. Bowling Green will play at Kent State Saturday.

title: Mayors in Connecticut Oppose Plan to Change School Financing
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., Oct. 11 (AP)The Connecticut Conference of Mayors said today that a recommendation to change way towns finance school the towns finance school construction would mean more lessburden on many Connecticut taxpayers.

title: U.S. HELD UP LETTER BY P.O.W. TWO YEARS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP)Army and Congressional sources are trying to iletermine why a letter that a recently released prisoner of war wrote to his family more than two years ago while a captive was not delivered until a week ago.

title: A Man Is Defined by His Longings
description: NOTRE DAME, Ind.The violent man arms himself, calculates how he will respond to assaults or degrees of aggression or insult, practices for each conceivable extreme situation, rehearses for the exceptional. For the same reason, we are a violent country, even apart from the war in Vietnam and even if our entire nuclear crop forever lies fallow.

title: Dollar Is Mixed in Trading in Europe
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (UPI)The dollar turned in a mixed performance today in European currency markets as the Columbus Day holiday in the United States slowed trading activity. It fell to a new low in Japan.

title: EDWIN PILLING DIES; AN AD SALESMAN, 49
description: FAIR LAWN, N. J., Oct. 11 Edwin Piling, a national advertising salesman for The New York Times since 1962, drowned early yesterday, apparently after falling into the Hudson River from his cabin cruiser off Englewood Cliffs. He was 49 years old and lived at 10.12 Plymouth Drive.

title: College Sports Notes
description: The Texas Longhorns are licking their wounds after the trouncing they suffered at the hands of Oklahoma Saturday. Oklahoma's powerful offense and defense increased the Texas injury list considerably so that there are now nine starters out of action. Coach Darrell Royal's Longhorns will go against Arkansas this week with their thirdstring quarterback as the prob able starter. That's going so far down the list that Royal yesterday had trouble remembering how to spell the name of this quarterbackBob Reviere.

title: AGNEW IN TURKEY; CALLS ON PREMIER
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 11Vice President Agnew arrived here today to start a 12day tour that is to include visits to Iran and Greece.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Yonkers Track Joins Independent Protective Organization
description: Yonkers Raceway, which has had problems in the past barring notorious figures from its betting windows, has joined 31 other tracks in Harness Tracks Security, an independent protective organization.

title: City Acts to Let Homosexuals Meet and Work in Cabarets
description: A relaxation of regulations governing cabarets, dance halls and foodcatering establishments to allow them to be frequented by homosexuals has been proposed by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs.

title: Group of Scientists Urges Shift In A.E.C. Safety Role
description: BOSTON, Oct. 11 (AP)  A group of Bostonbased scientists has called for the removal of the Atomic Energy Commission as the regulating agency of safety standards for nuclear power plants.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Britain Charges Aide With Espionage in Sudan
description: LONDON, Oct. 11A 39yearold official in the British Foreign Office was charged today with having commited espionage while serving in the British Embassy in the Sudan.

title: PAYNE GIVES RECITAL ON THE HARPSICHORD
description: Joseph Payne's harpsichord recital at Tully Hall Sunday night duplicated the essentials, if not the particulars, of his previous appearance here two years ago. Once again, a Bach English Suite and a generous group of Couperin's Pieces de Clavecin shared the focus of the first half of the program; a long sequence of Scarlatti Sonatas ended the evening.

title: Common Market Calls for Erasing U.S. Trade Curbs
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 11 (Reuters) The president of the European Common Market commission, called for the removal of protectionist United States trade measures, coupled with an international currency realignment by the end of the year.

title: Tiger Cats 363 Victors
description: HAMILTON, Ontario, Oct. 11 (AP)  Tommy Joe Coffey scored 14 points today, leading the Hamilton Tiger Cats to a 36.3 Canadian Football League victory over British Columbia.

title: BRITISH EXPECT DROP IN CAPITAL SPENDING
description: LONDON, Oct. 11 (UPI) Capital spending by British industry still is on a downtrend, the Department of Trade and Industry said today. But the agency said it expected an upturn in 1972. Spending by the shipping industry still was strong, it added.

title: Columbus Unveiled on L.I.
description: HUNTINGTON, L. L, Oct. 11  The controversial statue of Christopher Columbus was unveiled today by its sponsor while his chief opponent, Huntington Supervisor Jerome Ambro, marched in the nearby Columbus Day parade.

title: Romney to Forbid Home Loan Kickbacks
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 11George Romney, the Secretary of the Housing and Urban Development, said here today that his department planned to forbid kickbacks by mortgage lenders to those who bring Government mortgage loan requests to them.

title: FOOTBALL DEATH CAUSES DISPUTE
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C. Oct. 11  The death of a member of the North Carolina football team last month is causing more tumult in this campus community than a housing crisis or next Saturday's game against unbeaten Notre Dame.

title: 17th Admiral of the Ocean Sea, at Anchor in Plaza, Assesses Famed Ancestor
description: Cristobal Colon, the Duke of Veraqua, the Marques of Jamaica, the Admiral of the Ocean Sea, discovered New York City yesterday.

title: Coed Dorm Its Foes Are Fewer
description: The trend toward coed living on campus is winning increasing acceptance among the American people, a Gallup Poll released yesterday shows.

title: RANGERS TACKLE DEFUSED BRUINS
description: Having tied one game and won another in admirable style on the road in the first weekend of play, the Rangers open their home season tonight against the surprisingly defused Boston Bruins.

title: JOHNSTOWN AIDES GUILTY IN TV BRIBE
description: The Mayor and a former Councilman of Johnstown, Pa., pleaded guilty to a briberyconspiracy charge in Federal Court here yesterday as Irving B. Kahn went on trial on charges of bribing Johnstown officials to obtain a cable television franchise for the Teleprompter Corporation.

title: '67 Mustang Owner Awarded $400,000 For Explosion Burns
description: A driver who suffered severe burns in an explosion of his 1967 Mustang was awarded $400,000 yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.

title: 4 ARE SUBPOENAED IN ELLSBERG INQUIRY
description: BOSTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)Four associates of Dr. Daniel Elisberg have been subpoenaed to testify before a Federal grand jury in Boston tomorrow and Thursday on the leaking of the Pentagon papers.

title: COLGATE IN OFFER FOR KENDALL CO.
description: The ColgatePalmolive Company last night put in a $333million bid to acquire the Kendall Company, upping the ante on the $305.5million offer made Sept. 8 by Textron, Inc., for the Bostonbased ethical drug, textile and hygiene products producer.

title: Putting on MakeupDespite Blindness
description: In the darkness, who would answer for the color of a rose?

title: BLOOD CLOT LINKAGE TO PILL SUPPORTED
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 Further research by scientists at Johns Hopkins University has supported earlier findings that women who take oral contraceptives have a greater risk of developing blood clots than women who do not take the pill.

title: September Retail Sales Rose 0.5%
description: Retail sales last month came to a seasonally adjusted total of $33.78billion, an increase of 0.5 per cent compared to August, and 9.5 per cent over the level of sales in September, 1970.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12You haven't seen the real Pirates yet. So spake Danny Murtaugh with dogged persistence as his Pittsburghers were maltreated by the Baltimore Orioles in the first two games of the World Series.

title: Korean Protests Spread
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 12 (AP)  Student protest against alleged Government corruption and compulsory military training spread today to two pro vincial cities  Kwangju and Pusandespite a Government threat to draft demonstrators into the armed forces. In Seoul, where the protests began two weeks ago, more than 5,000 students battled riot policemen.

title: Story of a Pointless Shooting in Harlem
description: Although he is an Orthodox Jew, Steven Schleifer put away his yarmulke as he skirted Harlem Monday evening, for fear it might spur violence. His brother had been beaten by a youth who had spied his Jewish skullcap and shouted, Jew, you better get out of my city.

title: Bayh Quits Race
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Senator Birch Bayh, his wife stricken, by cancer, withdrew today from competition for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination to be at her side.

title: Defense Satisfies Cornell Coach
description: Jack Musick expressed satisfaction with Cornell's fine defensive efforts in beating a strong Princeton team on the slippery PolyTurf of Schoellkopf Field last Saturday.

title: Sonics Down Braves, 12390
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 12 (UPI) Spencer Haywood scored 29 points and Dick Snyder sank 24 tonight as the Seattle SuperSonics whipped the Buffalo Braves, 12390, in the National Basketball Association season opener for both teams.

title: PRAVDA REPORTS ON NIXON'S PLANS
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12The Soviet press, including tomorrow's edition. of Pravda, the Communist party newspaper, reported the official announcement of Mr. Nixon's projected visit to Moscow without any commentary pr embellishment. Pravda carried the announcement, as is customary for such news, in the lower righthand corner of the front page.

title: WITNESS SAYS COHN AIDED 5TH AVE. COACH
description: The first defense witness at Roy M. Cohn's trial yesterday on conspiracy and other charges depicted him as a benefactor of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, which he is accused of bilking.

title: RECORD CORN CROP FORECAST FOR 1971
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)The Agriculture Department estimated today the 1971 corn crop at a record 5,399,670,000 bushels, 31 per cent more than forecasts in September.

title: AIDE ASKS STUDY IN PLAYER DEATH
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Oct. 12  Additional investigation should be made into the circumstances surrounding the death of a varsity football player at the University of North Carolina last month, the chief medical examiner for the state said today.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION DOWN 2.9% IN WEEK
description: Production of steel last week declined to 1,756,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was down 2.9 per cent from the preceding week's 1,809,000 tons.

title: WAR CHALLENGE REFUSED BY COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Supreme Court laid to rest today any lingering thoughts that it might declare the Vietnam war unconstitutional.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: MEET COOKIE. The year's most unlikely heroine. $8.95 at your bookstore.Advt.

title: New City Bus Line to Port Authority Terminal a Hit
description: The Transit Authority has a new hit on its, hands: a bus route from the midtown Port Authority bus terminal to Rockefeller Center and the East Side.

title: Fischer and Petrosian Play a Draw
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 12  A draw In 20 moves was the result tonight of the fourth game of the match betweem the United States chess ace, Bobby Fischer, and a former world chess champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, in the Teatro San Martin here.

title: ETTORE FRAIOLI
description: MT. VERNON, N.Y., Oct. 12 (AP)  Ettore Fraioli, former city editor of the Mount Vernon Daily Argus, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 71 years old.

title: ASHE, LUTZ, RIESSEN WIN AT COLOGNE NET
description: COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 12 (Ap) Arthur Ashe, Bob Lutz and Marty Riessen advanced today to the quarterfinals of a World Championship Tennis tournament.

title: Justices Refuse to Halt Questioning Of Attica Prisoners by State Aides
description: The United States Supreme Court refused yesterday to order a halt to the state's interrogation of prisoners at the, Attica Correctional Facility. Justice William O. Douglas dissented in a 6to1 decision.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: New York City has survived another summer without a major power crisis. This may have the effect of lulling us into a false sense of security.

title: Bridge Bleecker St. Club Opens Today On an AroundtheClock Basis
description: Many bridgeplayers are devotees of other intellectual games such as chess, backgammon, Scrabble and go, but club facilities are seldom provided for more than one of these activities. Perhaps this is because one tends to become dominant, and drives out the minority interests. A notable example of this is the Boston Chess Club, which abandoned the board games many years ago in favor of bridge.

title: Japan Growth to Drop
description: TOKYO, Oct. 12 (Reuters) Japan's real economic growth in the current financial year will be nearly cut in half mainly because of President Nixon's new economic policies, a cabinet spokesman said today.

title: Teachers Plan Court Test of WagePrice Freeze
description: The United Federation of Teachers said yesterday that it would bring suit this week in Federal Court in Brooklyn challenging the legality of current Federal wageprice controls and seeking to recover $15million in wages lost by city school employes during the freeze.

title: Surtax End Asked
description: DETROIT, Oct. 12 Fred J. Borch, board chairman of the General Electric Company, said today that the United States should seek an agreement with major trading nations that would put an end to all import surtaxes and export subsidies.

title: Executive Changes
description: The First National City Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of W. James Tozer, Jr., 30 years old, as a senior vice president with administrative responsibility for six major Citicorp subsidiaries. The financial services corporation also announced that James F. Jaffrey, senior vice president, has been named financial officer for supervising the financel requirements of the same subsidiaries.

title: F.B.I. Starts Crackdown On Staten Island Gambling
description: The arrest of a gambling suspect, a search of seven other persons and the seizure of extensive gambling records involving multimilliondollar bets an baseball games and horse races signaled a crackdown yesterday on organized crime on Staten Island.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES IN TOKEN ADVANCE
description: Stock prices made only a token advance yesterday, despite the apparent removal of a stumbling block to the economic recovery.

title: MARGARET R. CADWELL
description: Mrs. Margaret Roulston Cadwell, a photographer's model for the John Robert Powers Agency in the heyday of the longstemmed American beauties, died yesterday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N.Y. She was 60 years old and liVed in Orient Point Apartments, Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Charter Protesting BankMerger Curb
description: The Charter New York Corporation, the $6.7billion bank holding company that owns the Irving Trust Company here, challenged yesterday the recent crackdown by the State Superintendent of Banks, William T. Dentzer Jr., on bank mergers in the state.

title: Losers Praise Fastball, Control
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles praised Steve Blass after losing to the Pirates righthander today and declined to offer excuses.

title: French Student, 24, Slain in a Mugging, Honored in Service
description: Memorial services for Jean Crez, a 24yearold exchange student from France, were held yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital, where he died last week from injuries sustained during a mugging in July. Services also were held in Ecully, a small town near Lyons, France, where he was born.

title: The Dollar Overhang
description: Under the goldexchange standard, which broke down two months ago, the United States had what seemed like a wonderful deal: it could cover whatever foreign debts it incurred by issuing I.O.U.'s in the form of paper dollars without limit, since the dollar was held as a reserve currency by other countries. But foreign governments grew increasingly unhappy about automatically financing whatever deficits the United States ranespecially when those deficits soared to an annual rate in excess of $20billion during the first half of 1971. The foreign creditors wanted the United States to hand over some goldbut knew that it could not possibly take care of all its debts.

title: COURT RULES CATENA MUST STAY IN PRISON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) Gerardo Catena, who was sent to prison 19 months ago for refusing to cooperate in a New Jersey crime investigation, must remain there even though his contempt conviction has been upset, the Supreme Court ruled today by 5 to 1. Justice William O. Douglas was the dissenter.

title: Greece Issues New Press Law; Foreign Newsmen Are Covered
description: ATHENS, Oct. 12The Government today published a law applying to local and foreign journalists working here that carries penalties ranging from light fines to a lifelong ouster from journalism.

title: RankXerox Signs Credit
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  RankXerox, Ltd., said it had signed a $25million, eightyear credit arranged by the Orion Termbank. This is the first time the company has used centralized financing, the company said.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Uruguay: Perils of Division
description: A coalition dominated by Marxist parties came to power in Chile last year with only 36.3 per cent of the popular votebecause the country's democratic forces were divided. Now another South American country with a deeplyrooted democratic tradition, tiny Uruguay, may be on its way down the same road.

title: BRISKER OF A.B.A. ARRESTED IN FIGHT
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 (UPI) John Brisker, a star with the Pittsburgh Condors, was arrested during the World Series today and the police said two of three arresting officers who subdued him were hospitalized.

title: Sin of Head Counts
description: WARRENTON, Va.Is demography a mortal sin? I say it is, although a distinction must be made which may let off some of its practitioners with the sort of venial blemish that can be cleaned up in purgatory. I mean it is possible for a man to be more or less innocently fascinated with his charts and statistics on birth and death rates and migration trends, even with (predictably wrong) projections of population explosions and deplosions. But this kind of demographer is an odd bird; he is outnumbered by far by colleagues who wish the fascinating statistics to be transposed into a judgment about the rightness or wrongness of making new people. This generality of demographers, I am afraid, will have to burn.

title: Theater: Giraudoux's The Enchanted
description: The Workshop of the Players Art (W.P.A.) is one of an increasing number of off Off Broadway companies that have achieved, over a number of seasons, a certain stability and a sure professionalism. At the W.P.A. one can expect a reliably good evening of theater.

title: Israeli Musicians in Yuval Trio Impressive in Debut at Hunter
description: The Yuval Trio, which made its New York debut at Hunter College Playhouse Monday night, put one of music's most durable clichs to the test. It is accepted wisdom among the cognoscenti (which means it is less than wisdom to accept it uncritically) that orchestra men rarely make the best chambermusic players. So it was interesting to learn that the Yuval's violinist, Uri Pianka, is concertmaster of the Israel Philharmonic, and the cellist, Simca Heled, also is a section leader in that orchestra.

title: Agreement Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) President Nixon said today that the United States will move against Japan and other textileexporting nations if no agreement is reached or significant progress made by Friday toward limiting exports.

title: MRS. JOHN J. FLYNN
description: BRIGHTWATERS, L. I., Oct. 12Mrs. Katherine Cummings Flynn, who with her husband, John J. Flynn, operated Flynn's Hotel on Fire Island, died today in Bay Shore Hospital after an illness of six months. She was 85 years old and lived at 162 East Concourse.

title: I.B.M. Profits Up
description: The International Business Machines Corporation showed a small profit in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the giant computer manufacturer reported yesterday.

title: Four More Food Dispensers Accused Under Health Code
description: Continuing the crackdown on foodprocessing establishments with serious Health Code violations, Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase made public yesterday the names of four new alleged violators.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert Ardrey [OpEd Sept. 27, 28] claims that most animal species have genetic mechanisms that limit the size of their populations and cites man and lemmings as the major exceptions to this rule. He predicts that man, like the lemming, will soon have to resort to such painful expedients as suicide and dropping dead.

title: Eckert Memorial Friday
description: A memorial service for Dr. Wallace J. Eckert, a former professor of celestial mechanics at Columbia University, will be held in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus on Friday at 2 P.M. Dr. Eckert, who was noted for his work in using electronic computers in tracking the moon's course, died at the age of 69 on Aug. 24.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco  The spindrift of the cold war is the human spray blown hither and thither by ideological gusts. This is typified by dissidents who flee Communist lands in search of freedom, by draft dodgers seeking to escape the U.S. armed forces abroad, by American black revolutionists in foreign havens and by defectors from rival diplomatic or espionage establishments who for different reasons abandon their native lands.

title: Market Place: Mutual Funds Yearly Return
description: If you, are an investor looking for a yardstick to measure the results of your mutual fund, you might keep this in mind:

title: Soviet to Increase Military Aid to Arabs
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 12President Nikolai V. Podgorny, pledging vigorous efforts by the Soviet Union toward a political settlement in the Middle East, warned today that in the meantime Moscow would further strengthen Arab military forces.

title: Joyful Jews in Brooklyn Celebrate Simhath Torah
description: Jews danced in the streets of Brooklyn until the early morning hours yesterday in numbers that the police estimated at the multiplied thousands.

title: New Virgin Islands Hotel
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V. I., Oct. 12 (UPI)Ground was broken here today for a $12million hotel that will give the United States Virgin Islands their first major convention facilities. The Frenchmen's Reef Hotel, to be built by American Motor Inns, will have an 800seat auditorium, and will be the largest hotel in the territory. The 300room facility is to be completed in 1973.

title: Penney Antidumping Case Denied HighCourt Review
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)The Supreme Court refused to review a ruling requiring the J. C. Penney Company to seek relief in the customs court rather than the United States District Court for what it claims were procedural violations by the Treasury Department in an antidumping case.

title: Vatican Synod Developing Consensus On a Married and Celibate Priesthood
description: ROME, Oct. 12After 10 days of intensive debate, the World Synod of Bishops is developing a consensus that the Roman Catholic church should reverse centuries of tradition and establish a married as well as a celibate clergy in the West.

title: Statements on Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12Following are a summary statement on the respective roles of the Cost of Living Council, the Pay Board and the Price Commission as released by the White House and delivered to labor leaders this morning by Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson and a statement read at a news conference later by George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations:

title: Davis Aides in Britain
description: LONDON, Oct. 12 (AP)Mrs. Fanya Jordan and two associates, on a European tour to rally support for her sister, Miss Angela Davis, was detained for questioning today at London's Heathrow Airport but later permitted to enter Britain. Miss Davis is awaiting trial in California on murder, kidnapping and conspiracy charges.

title: Anaconda Faces Loss
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Anaconda Copper Company faces the loss of $247million in insurance coverage because it allowed premium payments to the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to lapse in 1969.

title: Maryland. Board Votes To Buy Landmark Hotel
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 12The threat of demolition of the 100year  old Queen City Hotel in Cumberland, Md., was reduced today when the Maryland Board of Public Works approved the expenditure of $75,000 to buy the building.

title: Westinghouse Earnings Sorge by 50.9%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation realized a 50.9 per cent increase in thirdquarter profit and a 24.1 per cent rise in the first nine months of 1971, setting records for the periods along with sales, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, reported yesterday from Pittsburgh headquarters.

title: Rev. William S. Maloney 4th, Rector of Church in Bronx
description: The Rev. William S. Maloney 4th, rector since 1961 of the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd of Matilda Avenue at 238th Street in the Bronx, died Monday while on a visit to Pittsfield, Mass., with his family. It was his 39th birthday.

title: Advertising:
description: Early last year the Bic Pen Corporation, which had been a client of Ted Bates since it started turning out its ball points in 1958, became the first client of Kurtz Kambanis Symon. Now it's moving along.

title: Foss Hopes 4 Marathons Will Bring Music Lovers to Brooklyn
description: Lukas Foss hopes to lure New Yorkers to Brooklyn this season with a fresh idea in musical programing, the longplaying concert.

title: Orioles 75 to Win Tonight
description: STATELINE, Nev., Oct. 12 (UPI)Baltimore was listed as a7.5 favorite by Harrah's Tahoe racebook to beat Pittsburgh tomorrow night in the fourth game of the World Series.

title: Morgan Guaranty to Form San Francisco Subsidiary
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced yesterday its intention to form a new subsidiary in San Francisco to be known as the Morgan Guaranty International Bank of San Francisco. The bank's move is part of a pattern among American banks to form international subsidiaries in various cities around the country.

title: Potential Risks as Well as Values Seen in Genetic Screening
description: WARRENTON, Va., Oct. 12  Genetic screening of population groups is potentially valuable, but also presents potential risks of personal injustice, some specialists suggested here today.

title: Film Fete: 'In the Name of the Father':Scene Is Italian Boys' School Run by Priests Another Individualistic Movie by Bellochio
description: There is a sequence about halfway through Marco Bellocchio's "In the Name of the Father" during which a group of upper-form Italian prep school boys prepare for their nightly recreation hour. Dressed in dark uniforms, they solemnly climb a long, dim staircase. And while the priests who are their masters gaze sadly down at them from windows and niches, like paintings framed in centuries of patient grief, each boy approaches a carved portrait bust of the school's honored founder and spits at it as hard as he canuntil spittle drips from its noble aquiline nose.To catch all the spirit of Bellocchio's film one needs to see it all. But this sequence, with its intricate interweaving of beauty and disgust, its deeply elegiac sense of satire, its gorgeously ceremonial invocation of what it most despises, will do for starts. There is a sense in which the entire movie is an elaborate put-on; its most private moments, theatrically staged demonstrations; and that sense typifies the kind of movie that this director, with three highly individualistic films now to his credit, seems committed to making.Like his "Fists in the Pocket" (1966) and the popular "China Is Near" (1967), Bellocchio's present film deals with the younger members of a relatively closed society from which the crying need and the ultimate impossibilityis escape. In this case the social unit is a miserable boys' school for rich unteachables run by priests, like a medieval fortress in the midst of a modern city. The movie follows the academic year from the school's opening (a vicious son being deposited by his vile dad) through Christmas recess to the end of the spring term. But its structure is not so much temporal as spatial, or perhaps, spiritualand "In the Name of the Father" maligns several kinds of father at various removes and at many levels of authority.One student (Yves Beneyton) leads a revolt, ostensibly in the name of science and progress, and he uses the school playin a brilliant and terrifying and most improbable conceitas a means of mass persuasion. But he is himself a demagogue, a rational madman, a Frankenstein recruiting monsters  and he is no less evil, though somewhat more potent, than the school's vice rector (Renato Scarpa), who is his only serious adversary.The film thus represents a closed system, in which the lines and the actors may change but the horror remains. "In the Name of the Father" is a work of extraordinary boldness and fantastic invention. But its dramatic limitations are such that the boldness declines into bravado and the invention mostly extends variations on a monotonous theme.However, I can think of a dozen sequences together where the film takes magnificent life, and if any movie could be no more than the sum of its beauties, "In the Name of the Father" would take the prize simply on quantity. With its students locked in their cells each night, its priests in helpless disarray, its kitchen hands in sullen discontent, a mad dog roaming its corridors and a meek assistant master scrawling obscene graffiti on the dining hall wallsBellocchio's prep school is not quite the perfect image of the prison of our lives. But it is at times an impressive distorting mirror; and at times, a most intensely lyrical freak show."In the Name of the Father" played last night in the New York Film Festival at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

title: PAULINE S. JAFFA
description: Pauline S. Jaffa, who retired in 1957 as executive head of the margin department of E.F. Hutton & Co., investment bankers and stockbrokers, died Monday in Syosset (L.I.) General Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived with a niece, Mrs. Evelyn Levy, at 24 Greentree Circle, Westbury, L.I.

title: P.&G. and Western Electric Fill Posts
description: Topmanagement changes were announced yesterday by two of the nation's largest manufacturing corporations, the Procter & Gamble Company and the Western Electric Company, Inc.

title: PUBLIC TVRADIO SPURS A DEBATE
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting and White House aides continue at odds on the longrange financing of noncommercial television and radio.

title: Notes on People
description: Leon E. Panetta, who quit as President Nixon's special adviser on civil rights and took a similar position on Mayor Lindsay's staff last year, resigned yesterday to return to private law practice in California.

title: FOE SAID TO SHELL 11 ALLIED POSITIONS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (AP)  Enemy gunners reportedly shelled 11 bases today along the Cambodian border 60 to 90 miles northwest of Saigon. The allies countered with artillery and air strikes.

title: California Bank Sets Plan
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (Reuters)The Bank of California said today that directors approved a plan to form a onebank holding company to be known as Bancla Inc.

title: Hirohito Views Lorelei Rock In Sentimental Trip on Rhine
description: BONN, Oct. 12Emperor Hirohito, like many another visitor to the romantic Rhine, paid a call today at the fabled Lorelei rock that rises 500 feet straight up from the river's right bank.

title: Governor Says Bond Defeat Would Bring 45c Fare or New Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Governor Rockefeller said today that defeat by the voters of his $2.5billion transportation bond issue would mean that New York City would have to raise the transit fare to 45 cents or impose new local taxes of more than $200million to keep the fare at 30 cents.

title: Nets Beat Squires, 118109, In Final Preseason Game
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 12  The New York Nets concluded their preseason schedule tonight by defeating the Virginia Squires, 118109, giving the New Yorkers a 62 wonlost record. For the Squires, last season's American Basketball Association Eastern Division champions, it was the third defeat against five victories.

title: 76ERS SINK BULLS IN 114100 GAME
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP)  Philadelphia's onetwo punchArchie Clark and Hal Greerproduced 57 points tonight to lead the 76ers to a 114100 victory over the Chicago Bulls in their National Basketball Association season opener.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO WARN ISRAEL ON U.N. VOTE
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 12 (AP) A Tel Aviv newspaper reported today that the United States Government has warned Israel that her failure to support Nationalist China in the United Nations could result in an Arab attempt to have Israel expelled from the world body.

title: Teamwork for Stability?
description: The agreement of George Meany and other leaders organized labor to participate in President Nixon's machinery for curbing the wageprice spiral is a needed contribution to the national interest. It would be vastly more reassuring, however, if it were not accompanied by a defeatist statement from Mr. Meany on the possibility achieving the President's stated goal of a 2 to 3 per cent inflation rate by the end of next year.

title: JET MUFFLERS STIR DISPUTE AT PARLEY
description: MIAMI, Oct. 12The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board and officials of airports in four big cities clashed today over whether the Government should order United States airlines to put mufflers on hundreds of their jets at a possible cost of $1billion.

title: Pirates Win, 51, Trail Orioles by Game
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 Steve Blass pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates back from the brink today by stopping the Baltimore Orioles on three hits, 51, for Pittsburgh's first victory of the 68th World Series.

title: Kennedy Urges the U.S. To Explore Cuban Ties
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, urged tonight that the United States explore reestablishing diplomatic relations with Cuba. He blamed the Nixon Administration for allowing United States relationships with Latin America to decline.

title: LOAN FAVORITISM CITED BY POSTEL
description: Councilman Robert I. Postel charged yesterday that major borrower from the city's Municipal Loan Program had obtained approval of loans after having pressure brought to bear by an aide to Mayor Lindsay.

title: ENTIRE C5A FLEET GROUNDED BY U.S.
Better Health Care Urged
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12 (UPI)  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said tonight that 40 million Americans do not get decent health care because they cannot afford it or are isolated and the Nixon Administration lacks the strong and compassionate leadership to solve the problem. Mr. Jackson spoke at the 99th annual meeting of the American Public Health Association.

title: Drug Dependency of Servicemen In Vietnam Is Said to Level Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  The rate of drug dependency oblong servicemen in Vietnam seems to have reached a plateau at 5.1 per cent, Dr. Jerome K. Jaffe, the President's director of antidrug programs, said today.

title: SILVER FUTURES LOSE THEIR GLOSS
description: Liquidation, short selling and stoploss orders sent silver futures prices down charply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange here. The result was that prices hit new lifeofcontract and fouryear lows.

title: Architect of Postwar Policy, Acheson Advocated Containment of the Soviet Union
description: One of the principal molders of the American posture in the postwar world, Dean Gooder ham Acheson, an urbanely elegant, sharpminded and even] sharpertongued lawyer, helped to create what he called half a world, a free half through containment of the Soviet Union by American Military power and political alliances.

title: JERSEY PLANT ASKED FOR GAS CONVERSION
description: The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and the Consolidated Natural Gas Company announced yesterday the filing of an application with the Federal Power Commission requesting authority to construct and operate a plant in northern New Jersey to gasify 110,000 barrels a day of liquid hydrocarbons to yield approximately 500 million feet a day of pipeline quality gas.

title: Nimeiry Is Sworn in Sudan As First Elected President
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 12 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry took the oath of office today as the first elected President of the Sudan at a rally in Khartoum today, the Sudanese radio reported. He continues to hold the Premiership.

title: First Party of Iran's 2,500Year Celebration
description: SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 12  The Shah of Iran borrowed a palace tonight for the first party of the Persian Empire's 2,500th anniversary celebration.

title: LETTER FROM P.O.W. JUDGED PROPAGANDA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12A letter from an American serviceman that proved he was alive took two years in reaching his parents because somebody made the assessment that it was a propaganda leaflet, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: About Motor Sports
description: Mario Andretti signed up yesterday to drive for Parnelli Jones. The agreement ends some fanciful rumors that have been buzzing the racing community for several months, rumors that had been intensified since last Friday, when Andretti finally parted company with Andy Granatelli's STP racing team. After surviving two of hiS worst seasons ever, Andretti thus joins the most successful team on the United States Auto Club's championship circuit.

title: A Blunt Labor Leader
description: George Meany, the stocky, blunt president of the A.F.L.C.I.O. detailed a few weeks ago labor's conditions for cooperating with President Nixon's Phase Two economic controls. He said that the federation would go along with an autonomous wage board but would not buyany camouflaged plan that attempted to use labor and management as window  dressingwhile the real power of decision remained in the Justice Department or the Cost of Living Council.

title: Government by Force
description: EAST LANSING, Mich.  For more than a generation the major U.S. political thrust in Vietnam has been to develop stability. Despite our professions, of faith in representative government and democratic processes, we rarely have been at ease with vigorous and independent leaders among our junior allies or with legislative bodies such as the Vietnamese National Assembly when they show vitality and independence of judgment. The events that culminated in the South Vietnamese election Oct. 3 underscore that conclusion.

title: OLD GLORY AVERAGE BREAKS 1969 NARK
description: YONKERS, Oct. 12  The 11th annual Old Glory Sale ended today with 187 standardbreds, including 118 yearlings, being sold for $415,900, an average of $2,224. Including yesterday's figures, 341 head were sold for an aggregate of $1,502,000.

title: Austerity Budget Is Studied in Suffolk
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Oct. 12 The Suffolk County Legislature began consideration today of the county's proposed budget of $298,142,531 for 1972.

title: Joint Chiefs Said to Devise Costly Cambodia War Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Joint Chiefs of Staff are said to have designed a costly program of pacification and other unconventional warfare for Cambodia to protect South Vietnam's western flank as Americans continue their withdrawal from Indochina.

title: Nixon's Announcement : 3d Surprise in 3 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 President Nixon's announcement of his plan to go to Moscow in May constituted his third major revelation within three months and reinforced the growing impression here that he enjoys the dramatic, surprise announcetnent every bit as much as did his predecessor, Lyndon B. Johnson.

title: Israelis Seek Suez Accord
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 12The Israeli Government tonight voted to go along with the search for an agreement with Egypt to open the blocked Suez Canal for international shipping but rejected points advanced by Secretary of State William P. Rogers as a basis for an agreement.

title: A Look at World Of Mrs. Roosevelt
description: HYDE PARK, N. Y., Oct. 12 The private world of Anna Eleanor Roosevelt (18841962) was opened today to the professionally curious world of scholars and researchers at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library here.

title: Martin Harris Dead at 63; Was Early Photojournalist
description: Martin Harris, an early photojournalist, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived at 412 West End Avenue.

title: Tear Gas and Hoses Used To Quell Jail Riot on Coast
description: FRENCH CAMP, Calif., Oct. 12 (UPI) About 75 prisoners at the San Joaquin County Jail rioted for the second straight day today, throwing metal trays, burning mattresses, and showering broken glass down on county officials.

title: Sir Cyril Lodowic Burt Dead; Educational Psychologist, 88
description: LONDON, Oct. 12Sir Cyril Lodowic Burt, one of Britain's leading educational psychologist and a pioneer in the study of juvenile delinquency, died here on Sunday. He was 88 years old.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS BABY LENORE PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Supreme Court today dismissed a bid to overturn the controversial Baby Lenore case brought by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino of Brooklyn and Florida.

title: Namath Throws
description: The sun shone bright over Shea Stadium yesterday as Joe Namath engaged in his first workout in two months, but the immediate prospects of the undermanned Jets were bleak.

title: Thomas More Storke Is Dead; Editor Attached Birch Society
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 12Thomas More Storke, editor, publisher and Pulitzer Prize winner, died today at his home here at the age of 94. He suffered a massive stroke yesterday.

title: Poor Tactics on Taiwan
description: In a crude and clumsy attempt to put pressure on members of the United Nations, Senator Buckley of New York, allegedly speaking for twenty other Senators as well, has done serious damage to existing prospects for retaining U.N. membership for the Chinese Nationalist Government on Taiwan. Nor did United States Ambassador George Bush help that cause when, in effect, he none too subtly echoed Mr. Buckley's implied threat that the expulsion of Taiwan might result in lessened American contributions to the U.N.

title: WILSON ACCUSES HEATH IN SPY CASE
description: LONDON, Oct. 12A simmering dispute about the Soviet spy affair burst out tonight in angry partisan charges.

title: Theater: Christ's Passion Transported to the Stage in Guise of Serious Pop
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To negotiate at knifepoint is unthinkable, we are told. When have authorities ever negotiated on prison conditions without violence or threat of violence? How else can prisoners work for reform of penal institutions which even the Vice President admits are not perfect nor beyond criticism?

title: Decline in Maternal Death Rate Linked to Liberalized Abortion
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 12  The maternal death rate in New York City has been cut by more than half since the liberalization of the state's abortion law 15 months ago, It was reported here today.

title: $6,000 Stolen From Bank
description: A welldressed young man walked off with $6,000 from branch of the Underwriters Bank and Trust Company yesterday after handing a note to a teller demanding that much in $20 bills. The branch is at Broadway and 54th Street. The police said the man had kept one hand in his pocket as if he had a gun an dfled on foot after receiving the money.

title: Copter Kills 3 on Ground
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 12 (UPI) A helicopter carrying a twoton transmission tower crashed and burned near here yesterday, killing three men on the ground and injuring the pilot and a crew member. Killed were Ray Webber, 47 years old, Ronald A. Hayes, 27, and Duff Adolf Schmitt.

title: A Century Old, Women's College at Cambridge Ponders Future
description: CAMBRIDGE, EnglandAlong Sidgwick Avenue, the cars crammed with luggage line up each morning atthe entrance of Newnham College. The young women step nervously onto the graveled courtyard and walk into the school.

title: Deputy Ministers to Meet On World Money Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) Deputy finance ministers of the major nonCommunist nations will meet in Paris next week to begin work on resolving the international monetary deadlock, Government officials said today.

title: MERRILL PROFIT ROSE IN QUARTER
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the nation's largest investment concern, reported yesterday that its earnings in this year's third quarter rose 16 per cent on a 35 per cent increase in gross revenues.

title: New Play By Denker Scheduled
description: The Headhunters, a new play by Henry Denker, starring George Grizzard in the role of a Russian playwright who has been released from a prison camp, will be produced on Broadway by Lester Goldsmith in January.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN BOND MARKETS
description: The bond market, encouraged by the news that labor would serve on the Nixon Administration's new Pay Board, staged a fairly strong rally yesterday afternoon.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE COMPACT EDITION OF THE OXFORD ENGLISH DICTIONARY, Complete Text Reproduced Micrographically. 4,116 pages. Oxford at the Clarendon Press. Two Vols. boxed, with magnifying glass. $75.

title: Winning Ironic Way: Blass Loses Notes on Orioles, Robertson Misses Sign
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12If the Pirates were embarrassed by their lopsided secondgame loss to the Orioles, what should they feel when one of their few reliable pitchers leaves important pitching notes in Baltimore and one of their best hitters misses a sign in a potentially crucial situation?

title: GIANTS ARE LUCKY SOME, OF THE TIME
description: In the long, staid history of the New York football Giants, there has never been a year so filled with zany occurrences as this one, and Monday night's 2013 loss in Dallas fit the weird pattern perfectly.

title: Two Jewish Organizations Are Critical of Superstar
description: The American Jewish Committee and the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith expressed concern yesterday that Jesus Christ Superstar might adversely affect ChristianJewish relations.

title: Nixon's Second Summit
description: The announcement by President Nixon, yesterday that he will visit Moscow next May for intensive negotiations on a broad range of issues indicates that he has won the gamble he took last summer when he disclosed his planned visit to Peking. That step raised the risk of an angry reaction by Moscow to what it might interpret as a ChineseAmerican coalition directed against the Soviet Union. However, the U.S.S.R. has been playing it cool, as witness the recent fourpower agreement on Berlin, the indications of progress at the Helsinki SALT negotiations and now Moscow's receptivity to Mr. Nixon's projected trip.

title: Equal Rights Amendment Passed by House, 35423
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The House of Representatives passed today, 354 to 23, a constitutional amendment prohibiting discrimination based on sex.

title: DEMOCRATIC BILLS ON VOTE OPPOSED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The Republican National Chairman, Senator Robert Dole of Kansas, came out strongly today against a group of Democratic bills designed to register tens of millions of Americans so they can vote in the 1972 election.

title: Guilty Verdict Reported
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 12Indian Government sources said today that the Pakistani military tribunal that tried Sheik Mujib for treason had found him guilty and recommended the death penalty.

title: 5 YOUTHS SEIZED IN IND AT 14TH ST.
description: Transit policemen arrested five youths they said were armed with a pistol, a spear and chains in a subway station yesterday near Charles Evans Hughes High School.

title: C.B.S. Will Show 5 Specials Recreating History
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System will, televise this season Appointment With Destiny, five onehour dramatic specials that recreate a particular moment in history at the sites of their enactment, and a onehour tribute to John Ford, the film director. The latter work will be titled The American West of John Ford,

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Affairs
$2,049 Belmont Double a Windfall for OTB
description: A 961 shot named Sea Step threw the Offtrack Betting Corporation into momentary panic yesterday by completing a $2,049.60 daily double at Belmont Park.

title: Malraux to Go to India
description: PARIS, Oct. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)  Former Culture Minister Andr Malraux, a declared supporter of East Pakistan's independence movement, will travel to India next month, it was learned today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 12 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong, the Wimbledon champion, made an impressive return to competitive tennis after a month's absence by routing Corinne Molesworth of Britain, 6.2, 61, in the second round of a Dewar Cup indoor tournament tonight. In a firstround match Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., beat Helen Kelly of Scotland, 61, 61.

title: JERSEY JUDGE BARS PENALTY OF DEATH
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12 (AP) A state judge today declared New Jersey's 78yearold capital punishment law unconstitutional.

title: DEMOCRATS BACK MRS. HARRIS, 93
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  The Democratic National Committee's executive committee voted 9 to 3 today to recommend the selection of Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris as temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the party's 1972 convention.

title: Quarterly Earnings Drop Sharply at Franklin New York and Dip at Marine Midland Banks
description: The Franklin New York Corporation suffered a 50.9 per cent decline in thirdquarter earnings before securities transactions, reflecting a huge increase in provision for loan losses. The Brooklynbased bank holding company operates mainly on Long Island.

title: Home Rule Bill for Capital Again Passed by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)  For the seventh time since 1952, the Senate voted today to give the citizens of the District of Columbia the right to elect their own city officials.

title: Police and Fire Departments Ask $5Million for Joint Alarm Setup
description: The Fire and Police Departments asked for $5million yesterday to install Jointly 3,000 street voicealarm boxes for calling either department in an emergency.

title: Developer Says Protests Won't Stop His Plans for Luxury Block
description: A realestate developer who in 1968 started quietly buying up the block bounded by Second and Third Avenues and 52d and 53d Streets says that the bitter opposition from much of the neighborhood will not stop his plans to build ldxury apartment towers and townhouses.

title: S.E.C. Is. Sustained
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)The Supreme Court refused today to review a Securities and Exchange Commission ruling that abolished customerdirected commissionsplitting among brokers trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: INVITED BY SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 President Nixon disclosed today that he would go to Moscow next May for a meeting with Soviet leaders.

title: Watson Convicted Of Tate Murders; Faces Sanity Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 12 (AP) Charles (Tex) Watson, who testified that he shot or stabbed six of the TateLaBianca slaying victims on orders from Charles M. Manson, was convicted today of seven counts of firstdegree murder and one of conspiracy to commit murder.

title: 12 Theater Groups In City Are Given Endowment Grants
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced 28 grants totaling $392,000 to professional experimental theaters and workshop groups under its fiscal 1972 Theater Program. Twelve of the recipients were New York City groups.

title: Curt Flood Case Put Off
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP)  The Supreme Court put off decision today on whether it would hear the antitrust suit against organized baseball brought by Curt Flood, former star center fielder of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: RCA Registers Loss;
description: The corporate carnage wreaked by the RCA Corporation's twodecadelong attempt to become a major factor in the computer business made itself apparent on the company's balance sheet yesterday. Robert W. Sarnoff, company chairman, announced a $231.1million loss for the third quarter of 1971 and a loss of $187.8million for the first nine months of the year.

title: Guerrilla Stepup Seen
description: CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 11 Under heavy security, several special freight trains carrying military supplies now arrive here every day. The arms are reported to be for the Bengali guerrillas who are fighting for East Pakistan's independence and who seem to be preparing to step up their activities against the Pakistani army.

title: Soutar,With 1,802, Takes First Place In Jersey Bowling
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 12 (AP) Dave Soutar of Gilroy, Catif., who won this tournament 10 years ago, took first place tonight as the second round was completed in the $85,000 national championship of the Professional Bowlers Association.

title: Advertising:
description: While others are just talking about it, Time Inc., is about to do itrun a campaign in support of advertising. It will run in all four of its magazines.

title: U. S. ENVOY ENDS MISSION IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 12 Edward M. Korry ended a fouryear tour of duty as United States Ambassador to Chile today at a time when relations between the two countries are at a low ebb.

title: Medina Offers to Testify At Colonel's CourtMartial
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 12 Capt. Ernest L. Medina, the Army officer who was acquitted last month on all charges arising from the Mylai slayings, arrived here today to offer his help to Col. Oran K. Henderson, his former brigade commander.

title: Art Curator Has 30,000 Friends
description: Olga Raggio, new chairman of the Metropolitan Museum's Department of Western European Arts, has some 30,000 objects in her charge and is on familiarnot to say personal  terms with most of them.

title: Ransom Frees U.S. Convoy From Vietnamese Crowd
description: DANANG, South Vietnam Oct. 12 (UPI)An American truck convoy with 14 soldiers aboard was captured and held for ransom for nearly eight hours near here today by an angry crowd of disabled South Vietnamese war veterans.

title: 44 Seized in Drug Raids
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 12 (UPI)  Authorities from Ohio and Kentuvky arrested 44 persons Ma series of drug raids today and confiscated more than $100,000 worth of drugs. The series of raids resulted in confiscation of various hallucinogenics, speed pills and barbiturates, the police said.

title: Summary of Actions Taken by the Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: NAVY TALKS BEGUN BY U.S. AND SOVIET
Expropriation Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Supreme Court agreed today to examine the State Department's role in Federal Court challenges to expropriation of United States property by foreign nations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Let's not be too hasty to reject Isaiah Robinson's suggestion that astrology might be useful in pupil placement [news story Oct. 8] or to urge his removal as head of the Board of Education for having the courage to admit publicly an heterodox belief.

title: Employers Criticize Pension Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12The debate over Government regulation of private pensions was rekindled here today as employers testified thattheir companies could not afford the reforms called for by a bill pending before the Senate Subcommittee on Labor.

title: Reagan to Visit Saigon
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 12 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan of California will fly to Saigon tomorrow to meet with President Nguyen Van Thieu at the request of the White House, an aide said today.

title: Grain Elevator Blast, Kills 4
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (Reuters) Four workmen died today when an explosion caused by grain dust igniting tore through the top floor of a 120foothigh grain elevator on Chicago's South Side. The dead were identified as Esteban Chavez, 46; Leroy Siebert, 62, and Robert Gonzales Jr., 23, all of Chicago, and Anthony Michauka Jr. 25, of Hammond, Ind.

title: C. J. HAGGERTY, 77, LABOR CHIEF, DIES
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 12 (AP)  Cornelius J. Haggerty, a prominent labor leader who served for 11 years as president of the Building and Construction Trades Department of the A.F.L.C.I.O. in Washington, died last Sunday of cancer. He was 77 years old.

title: Nixon to Honor Graham
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI)  President Nixon will fly to Charlotte, N. C., Friday to pay tribute to Billy Graham, the evangelist, a friend and spiritual adviser, the White House announced today. Mr. Nixon will speak during Billy Graham Day ceremonies at the Charlotte Coliseum and return to Washington that night, the White House said.

title: Proposal Heard by S. E. C. For TwoTiered Market
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Some noted students of the securities markets outlined today the steps they believe should be takenmany of them radical stepsto enable the securities markets of the future to handle both individuals orders and large blocks of stock more efficiently and fairly.

title: Aid for Retarded Children
description: The ruling by a threejudge Federal court in Philadelphia that the State of Pennsylvania must provide free public education to all retarded children constitutes a historic step in an area that has suffered from public and professional neglect. Similar court tests will inevitably be instituted elsewhere unless school systems across the country move toward voluntary compliance with what will surely become the universal legal requirement.

title: Celeste Holm Leaves Show
description: Celeste Holm has withdrawn from the musical version of Truman Capote's The Grass Harp because of changes in the concept of her role, it was announced yesterday by Theater 1972, the producers, She has been replaced by Karen Morrow.

title: Knicks Lose Opener Here, 9184
description: The Knicks began their 26th season in the National Basketball Association last night with one of their worst games.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BOISE, Idaho, Oct. 12 (UPI) Prisoners in the Ada County jail set fire to mattresses tonight, causing at least six men to be overcome by smoke, one of them critically. The motive was not known.

title: Royals Defeat Hawks
description: ONCINNATI, Oct, 12 (UPI) Torn Van Arsdale reeled off 34 points and Nate Archibald added 27 as they led the Cincinnati Roya!s to a 127113 homeopener victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to The Times curiously arranged spectrum, for the President to visit China is good and for the Vice President to visit Greece is bad and embraces the colonels. [Editorial Oct. 1.]

title: Nixon Trip: DiplomaticPolitical Gain Seen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 President Nixon is the third postwar President to schedule a visit to the Soviet Union and he expects to be the first to make it.

title: PRESIDENT PLANS TO ACT NEXT WEEK ON COURT CHOICES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  President Nixon, said today he would announce next week his selections to fill the two vacancies on the Supreme Court, and he did not rule out the possibility that one of the nominees would be a woman.

title: Eleonora Anchorena Wed in Greenwich
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 12  Miss Eleonora Nazar Anchorena of Buenos Aires was married here this afternoon to V. Peter Mortensen, a landowner in Argentina and former vice president of the International Basic Economy Corporation (IBEC) in Buenos Aires. Justice of the Peace Francis X, McGinty performed the civil ceremony at the Town Hall.

title: Supreme Court Refuses to Hear Jersey Appeal in Smith's Case
description: NEWARK, Oct. 12 The United States Supreme Court told New Jersey authorities in effect today to free Edgar H. Smith Jr. unless they brought him to trial again within 60 days for a murder Smith confessed to 14 years ago in Bergen County.

title: Yahya to Call Assembly
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 12  President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan said tonight that a National Assembly would be convened Dec. 27, following byelections to fill the seats vacated after the army moved to crush the East Pakistani autonomy movement, and that he would cede power to a new central government soon afterward.

title: Serious Implications
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (Reuters)  The State Department spokesman, Charles W. Bray 3d, said today that Chile's decision that no compensation should be paid for the expropriated mining properties of two American companies obviously has serious implications for the principle and fact of just compensation. But he declined to spell out the implications.

title: Fighting Alcoholism
description: Alcoholism is not just a problem confined to the Bowery; it is a chronic disease suffered by more than 300,000 New Yorkers, according to a recent study. The study also disclosed that alcoholism was the fifth leading cause of death in the city, claiming four times as many lives as narcotics.

title: Dean Acheson Dies on His Farm at 78
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12  Dean Acheson, Secretary of State under President Harry S. Truman who exercised a deep, if not always visible, influence on United States foreign policy for more than 20 years, died at 6, o'clock tonight at his farm home in Sandy Spring, Md.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the telephone company's time bureau.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS CITY JURY SYSTEM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (UPI) The Supreme Court today rejected a challenge to the New York County grand jury selection system. The contention was that the system unconstitutionally discriminated against the poor, nonwhites and the young.

title: Amex Stocks Advance Slightly As Pace of Trading Steps Up
description: The American Stock Exchange managed to make slight advance yesterday in steppedup trading.

title: BRITISH TO BLAST 50 BORDER ROADS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 12  The British Army plans to blow up 50 roads between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic an an attempt to stop the traffic in explosives by the Irish RepUblican Army, according to informed sources.

title: An Expression of Sorrow
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 12 (AP)A spokesman for the United States command said that the money paid the South Vietnamese veterans near Danang today was an expression of sorrow and not compensation.

title: U.S. URGED TO BAR RENT RISES HERE
description: Thirtysix Democratic legislators yesterday urged Federal pricefreeze authorities to prohibit the city from putting into effect a longplanned system of computerdetermined rent increases designed to encourage better maintenance of rentcontrolled housing.

title: Naples the Calcutta of Europe, Seeks Rebirth
description: NAPLES, ItalyWhen the Mediterranean naval headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was evicted by Malta's new Labor Government and joined allied staff offices and bases in the Naples area recently, Communist party strategists in Rome thought that big antiAmerican demonstrations were in order.

title: PAY UNIT DEFINED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 Organized labor pledged its support today for President Nixon's program to fight inflation after the current 90day wageprice freeze expires.

title: WESTBURY TO GIVE BETTORS A NIGHT
description: WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 12 The advice to harness racing fans planning to attend tomorrow night's 1971 penultimate program at Roosevelt Raceway is to show up early and be prepared to stay late. It will be fan appreciation night, with eight prizes to be given away. Mayor Pat Buffalino pf Westbury will conduct the draw in the winner's circle following the ninth race.

title: Manes Challenges AfterHours Fees For Use of Schools
description: Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes yesterday challenged the contention of the Board of Education that it had to raise its $3 fee for afterhours use of school facilities to $80.

title: City Relief List Up 10,560 Despite Get Tough Policy
description: Despite new state. gettough welfare laws, relief rolls here shot up in August, adding 10,560 more clients after four months of virtually, leveling off, the city's Department of Social Services reported yesterday.

title: HIGH COURT LETS HIRING PLAN STAND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 The Supreme Court rejected today a challenge to the constitutionality of the Nixon Administration's Philadelphia Plan, which requires building contractors on federally financed jobs to meet certain percentage goals in employing nonwhite workers.

title: Blues Down, Sabres, 41, As 4 Players Get Goals
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 12 (UPI) Gary Sabourin, Perry Crisp, Noel Picard and Bill Sutherland scored St. Louis goals tonight to give the Blues a 41 National Hockey League triumph over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Funds Urged for Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (AP) A bill introduced today by Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, calls for Federal funds to keep schools open after regular school hours and during the summer vacation months for recreational, educational, community and social services.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Visitors to Quebec provincial parks are given a litter bag with a number as they enter. On leaving, they give the full bag to a park official.

title: Prison Meets Strike Threat
description: THOMASTON, Me., Oct. 12 (UPI)All 330 prisoners at Maine State Prison were locked in their cells today when inmates who work in the kitchen threatened to strike unless a supervisor was transferred. Miss Ward E. Murphy, Maine Corrections Commissioner, said, This morning when the kitchen staff elected not to go to work it was felt necessary to put in a security situation at the institution.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: After a series of muggings, pocketbook snatchings, automobile breakins and thefts, acts of malicious mischief, And the threatened takeover of our housing grounds by drug addicts and suspect characters, the bomb scare on the morning of Sept. 29, at Harlem Hospital, was too much.

title: Knick Fans Chant for Defense But Offense Is Needed More
description: The crowd chanted, Defense, Defense, but what the Knicks needed more last night against the Detroit Pistons was offense.

title: Where the Heart Calls
description: MOSCOWIt is with deep feeling that I address you tonight for I stand here not only as a musician but as a Russian Jew, as one whose parents were born in this land, for which they both retain a deep attachment.

title: Visiting French Legislator Troubled by Arkansas Race Problems
description: JONESBORO, Ark., Oct. 11 Pierre Lelong's first day in the United States began with a poem recited at breakfast by Miss Lily Peter, the 78yearold poet laureate of Arkansas. It ended 17 nonstop hours later at the club of a dog race track with another new friend telling him why her children were driven 100 miles daily to and from school.

title: Army Plans to Remove All Post Slot Machines
description: WASHINGTON, Oct.13 (AP)  Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke announced tonight that all slot machines would be removed from every Army post and base around the world next July. He called the machines a corruptive influence.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Music: Cherubini Work Attracts a Large Audience
description: Performances of largescale Cherubini works are not to be run across very often, and so a large audience took advantage of the Clarion Concerts program at Tully Hall on Tuesday night. Newell Jenkins and his forces were heard in Cherubini's Missa Solemnis in D minor. In the audience were distinguished musicologists, many of whom cheerfully admitted that the score was a complete novelty to them.

title: InLaw Refuses to Testify
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 13 (AP) Spencer Marks, the brotherinlaw of Daniel Ellsberg invoked the Fifth Amendment and refused to testify today before a grand jury investigating the leak of the Pentagon Papers, his lawyer said.

title: $5MILLION GIVEN TO COLUMBIA U.
description: Julian Clarence Levi, a Columbia College graduate of the class of 96, bequeathed $5million to the university, Dr. William McGill, president, announced yesterday.

title: Valdes to Fight Abner Here
description: A 10  round middleweight fight between Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia and Perry (Lil') Abner of Philadelphia will take place next Tuesday at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: J.H.S. 263 IS CLOSED BY PARENT PROTEST
description: A protest by parents against removal of the principal forced the closing yesterday of Junior High School 263 in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

title: Michael Mahonec Is Dead; Led Builders' Supply Firm
description: Michael Mahonec, founder and president of Manhattan Builders Supply Corporation, died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown, N. Y. He lived at Castle Heights Avenue in Tarrytown.

title: 2 Senators Back Bistate Pact To Prevent Thefts at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI) Senators from New York and New Jersey urged a Senate subcommittee today to approve a compact between the two states to prevent airport thefts.

title: Shoot Out':Peck and Dawn Lyn Cast in Hathaway Film
description: It seems a lot to expect a little 7-year-old girl with just another movie and a TV series behind her to hold together a whole feature film full of inept adults, but that is what somebody must have expected of Dawn Lyn in "Shoot Out," given the story, the director, and the rest of the cast. Actually, Miss Lyn is not yet quite up to shaping such a movie, though she tries hard enough, and even succeeds in bringing some life to her role as Gregory Peck's illegitimate daughtera part that could well prove the ultimate trial of the Stanislavsky method.The film was directed by Henry Hathaway, who has provided pleasures enough in the past and from whom, given the appearance of Miss Lyn in her little smock and broad-brimmed hat, we might have expected a certain present ambition  along the lines, say, of a "Daughter of 'True Grit.'"
