But "Shoot Out" is no more than another variation of the eternal tale of the Westerner (Gregory Peck) released from prison who seeks revenge on the pal who betrayed him but is himself pursued by a hired gang of maniacal killers until a showdown in which everybody gets his except Mr. Peck, who unaccountably gets marriage and a family. Pat Quinn (Alice's Restaurant," etc.) plays marriage, and she is no match for Miss Lyn, who plays family.Since this is the kind of movie that everybody walks through, so to speak, it seems reasonable to consider styles of walking; especially Gregory Peck's style, which is by deficiency the best testimonial of the mature art of John Wayne that I have seen in recent movies. I had not thought it possible with such economy to say so much about so little. But if you want an image for the Decline of the West, you might do worse than the past president of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts, and Sciences on his solitary way up the main street of Weed City, between the bank and the local saloon.

title: Bill Would Increase HomeLoan Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Chairman Preston Martin of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board asked the Senate Housing Subcommittee today to approve a bill designed to make more funds available for home mortgages.

title: 'Superstar': The Cheers and Jeers Build
description: Religious opinion continued to be divided sharply yesterday over the merits of the rock opera Jesus Christ Superstar, but the secondnight audience at the Mark Hellinger Theater appeared unconcerned about the theological constroversy and gave the cast a standing ovation at its conclusion.

title: METS CONCERNED ABOUT THIRD BASE
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  Not concerned with World Series activities but hoping they would be again in the future, the top field management of the New York Mets engaged in some frank discussions today. Bob Scheffing, general manager, and Gil Hodges, field manager, made the following observations:

title: Police Sergeants Union Seeks to Bar Hearings by Knapp Group
description: The Sergeants Benevolent Association filed suit in State Supreme Court here yesterday to bar the Knapp Commission, which is investigating police corruption, from opening public hearings next Monday.

title: Conspiracy Charge Against Roy Cohn Dismissed
Italy Cuts Bank Rate
description: ROME, Oct. 13The Bank of Italy reduced the discount rate tonight to 4 per cent from 5 per cent. The interest rate on secured loans from the central bankthe socalled Lombard ratewas cut to 4 per cent from 5.

title: 5 PRINTING CONCERNS FORM CONDOMINIUM
description: Five printing concerns have banded together to form what is believed to be the first industrial condominium in the United States to acquire an 11story building at 535 West 45th Street with the help of state and Federal agencies.

title: Nuclear Power Plant Set
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (ReutersThe Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company said today it planned to build a $632million nuclear power plant in Perry, Ohio. The company said construction is expected to begin in the mid1970's with completion scheduled for late 1970's or the early 1980's.

title: Alabama College Closes After 5 Days of Protests
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Oct. 13 (AP)Alabama A. & M. University closed its doors today after five days of demonstrations and boycotts. There was no indication when classes would resume.

title: Customers Ride an Escalator Through a Chinese Dragon's Mouth
description: What with Presidential trips and Persian anniversary festivities, there's no doubt that the mysterious East is moving closer to us. For the next two weeks, it will be as near as Fifth Avenue and 38th Street, where Lord & Taylor is presenting its Far East Odyssey, a storewidegarnering of fashions and home furnishings from the markets east of Suez. A shopper entering the store is greeted with the smell of incense and the wail of recorded sitar music. Embroidered tents and parasols hang from the ceiling, and escalator riders from the fourth to the fifth floors find themselves entering the mouth of a Chinese dragon and being wafted up through its body and out from the tail.

title: Hazard Pay Authorized by U.S. For Teachers in Slum Schools
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The Federal Government today authorized hazard pay for teachers in schools in slum areas.

title: Books of The Times
description: During a rap session with some revolutionists in their apartment, John Stickney discovered that he was hearing three different records playing at once. Yeah, his host said, the walls are paperthin . . . I wish just once we could get together behind one album. It's that way, the author finds, with their revolution too. There are so many different drummers all playing at once that people.are having trouble finding the beat. Anarchists, Marxists, Jesus Freaks, Hare Krishnas, White Panthers; Women's Liberationiststhere's a psychedelic supermarket of ideologies and many of the young are wandering confusedly up and down the aisles, trying to find something that will nourish their indefinable hunger.

title: British Petroleum Rights Available to Holders Today
description: The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., said yesterday that terms on a rights offering to stockholders to raise more than $306million will beCome effective in London and New York today.

title: King in New York, Chaplin's 81st Film, Will Be Shown Here
description: Charles Chaplin's 81st picture, A King in New York, which has never been shown in the United States, has been acquired for release here by Oliver A. Unger, president of Leisure Media, hic., in association with Classic Festival Corporation.

title: Carson's Son on Probation
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 13 (AP)Richard W. Carson, 19 years old, son of Johnny Carson, the television performer, has been placed on unsupervised probation for two years for possession of marijuana. He and Gary M. Golden 21, of Levittown, N. Y., both memhers of the Navy, pleaded no contest to the charges yesterday in Superior Court before Judge Anthony A. Giannini.

title: Night of Dark Shadows' Arrives
description: Movie and video addicts may recall that last year's schlock vampire crowd of "House of Dark Shadows," including Joan Bennett, Jonathan Frid and Grayson Hall, sprang full grown, if not adult, onto local screens from television's "Dark Shadows" serial. But "Night of Dark Shadows," which fell on neighborhood theaters yesterday, is illustration that the pseudosinister can be a bore, even without vampires.Miss Bennett and Mr. Frid aren't around this time, even if Miss Hall is, to attempt to chill the customers. And a good thing, too, since the script devised by Sam Hall depends a good deal on visual effects that aren't particularly effective to spin a yarn about a young couple's enslavement to the tortured but lively ghosts that haunt a country mansion they've inherited.Dan Curtis, the producer-director, who's shepherded his harried flock from TV to "House of Dark Shadows" and to the present, moody adventure, hasn't given his cast much to work with that is either fascinating or believable.David Selby and Kate Jackson, as the young, abstract artist and his bride who's acquired Collinwood, seem much too hip to become the victims of Lara Parker, the sexy blonde in diaphanous shifts who'd been deep enough in hanky panky to be hanged as a witch in 1810 and is dedicated to keeping this bad work up.Mr. Selby's sudden affliction of nightmares reviving his ancestors' morbid past generated by this amorous wraith are as unconvincing as Miss Hall's weird activities. As the estate's gaunt, glacial housekeeper, she's certain that she is an early resident who's been reborn to rid Collinwood of its new owners and keep its ghosts and traditions intact.And John Karlen and Nancy Barrett, as the couple's married friends, try to be helpful but aren't.The attraction of this dour adventure is Lyndhurst, the Gothic revival mansion and estate, once Jay Gould's, at Tarrytown where the film was shot. Its many period rooms, paintings and objects d'art are richly eye-filling. The somber story shot there, however, is strictly for the low-rent district.

title: ExMayor of Johnstown Tells Of Teleprompter's Bribe Offer
description: Kenneth O. Tompkins, who pleaded guilty to a briberyconspiracy charge on Tuesday when he resigned as Mayor of Johnstown, Pa., testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he and two other Johnstown officials had been bribed by Irving B. Kahn for the Teleprompter Corporation.

title: Bronx Rabbi and 3 Indicted in FaithHealing Case
description: A 68yearold Orthodox rabbi and three of his relatives were indicted in the Bronx yesterday on charges that they took money for cabalastic faithhealing rituals that never took place.

title: House Unit Approves Law Backing Foreign Tax Credits
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (Reuters)  The House Ways and Means Committee today approved legislation to allow United States sudsidiaries operating abroad to apply foreign tax credits against their United States tax liability on income derived from mining and mineral operations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: You report the statement by the presidents of the five borough chapters of the State Society of Professional Engineers that New York City faces ecological disaster if electric demands continue their present increases with unchanged policies by governmental agencies and the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: House Gets Seat Belt Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  A bill introduced in the House today by Representative Don Brotsman, Republican of Colorado, would make seat belts mandatory for passengers in school buses. The bill would also order the Department of Transportation to set up criteria for safe seat construction for the buses. It would authorize Federal aid to help local schools comply with the proposed law.

title: Bonn Bank Rate Reduced;
description: BONN, Oct. 13  West Germany's central bank decided today to lower its discount rate to 4 per cent from 5 per cent. To take effect tomorrow, the action is aimed chiefly at easing the mounting pressure on exporting industries.

title: Allegheny Corp. Assets Up
description: Net assets of the Alleghany Corporation as of Sept. 30 were $161million equal to $18.23 common share, up from $123.2million, or $14.02 a share, on the same date a year earlier. The holding company had net income before security transactions of $3.6million, or 40 cents a share, in the first time months this year. This compared with $1.2million, or 14 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  A memorial service for Mr. Acheson, who died yesterday at the age of 78, will be conducted at 2 P.M. Friday at Washington Cathedral.

title: SOVIET TEAM TAKES MODERN PENT ATHLON
description: SAN ANTONIO, Oct. 13 (AP) The Soviet Union won the individual and team world modern pentathlon titles today. Hungary the defending champion, took second place in both categories as the United States team finished third.

title: C. Stafford Smythe Dies at 50; President of the Maple Leafs
description: TORONTO, Oct. 13 (AP)C. Stafford Smythe, president of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, died today in Wellesley Hospital. He was 50 years old.

title: Some Call Her UnfeminineBut They Haven't Seen Her Cook
Horrors of East Pakistan Turning Hope Into Despair
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Oct. 10 The horror of life in East Pakistan shows every sign of becoming permanently institutionalized, and most if not all the foreigners who came hoping to help are on the verge of despair.

title: City Block: Some Take a Job Loss Harder Than Others
description: Nicholas J. Capozzoli, who delivers the mail on West 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue, says that about 25 people on the block are now getting unemployment checks. He says that they are nearly all young and unmarired, and that this baffles him. When I was their age, Mr. Capozzoli says, I couldn't have imagined myself not working.

title: German Negotiators End Up Day in East Berlin Theater
description: BERLIN, Oct. 13East and West German negotiators ended a day of talks about access to Berlin with a visit to the Berliner Ensemble Theater in East Berlin. They saw BertoIt Brecht's Arturo Ui, a play satirizing the rise of Hitler.

title: Wittkower Memorial Today
description: A memorial service for Rudolf Wittkower, art historian and Avalon Foundation professor emeritus at Columbia University, will be held today at noon at St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia campus. Professor Wittkower died on Monday at the age of 70.

title: Doubling of G.N.P. Seen
description: Total output in the American economy, propelled by a massive increase in Government and investment spending, will more than double in the decade of the seventies to more than $2,000billion, Chase Econometric Associates predicted yesterday.

title: KayserRoth Says Nixon Move Lifted Sales of Apparel
description: The KayserRoth Corporation, one of the country's largest apparel manufacturers, has had a pickup in its business since President Nixon announced his new economic program on Aug. 15, Chester H. Roth, chairman, said after the annual meeting here yesterday.

title: Beaumont Takeover Now Seems Doomed
description: Richard M. Clurman, City Center chairman, conceded yesterday that the plan to remodel the Beaumont Theater under City Center ownership is all but dead.

title: ROGERS REPROVES CHILE ON SEIZURES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Secretary of State William P. Rogers sharply reproved Chile today for what he termed serious departure from accepted standards of international law.

title: SCHAYES DISMISSED AFTER OPENING LOSS
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Buffalo Braves of the National Basketball Association surprisingly dismissed Coach Dolph Schayes tonight, one day after the 197172 season opened.

title: House Panel Backs Wage Floor For Maids and Other Domestics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  A House committee voted today to guarantee an estimated 1.4 million maids and other domestic workers a minimum wage of at least $1.80 an hour next January and $2 an hour a year later.

title: Brooklyn Academy To Sever Its Link With Parent Body
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music will become an independent cultural institution operated by a private nonprofit body, the St. Felix Street Corporation, instead of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, the 113yearold academy's parent organization since 1936.

title: Cancer Politics
description: The effort of Representative Paul G. Rogers to win Congressional approval for a sensible approach to cancer research has apparently produced panic among the proponents of a rival measure that was passed by the Senate. Such panic is the only explanation for the highpowered advertising campaign launched by the American Cancer Society in support of the Senate measure.

title: A Look at City Planning On the Community Level
description: Isn't it time we get buses to go all the way through to Wall Street? a member of Community Planning Board 14 in the Riverdale section of the Bronx asked his colleagues at their monthly meeting.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: GENEVA, Oct. 13  Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan, the United Nations, High Commissioner for Refugees, said today that he and his top aides would make personal calls on government officials in an attempt to inspire a new international effort on behalf of the East Pakistani refugees in India.

title: HENDERSON JURY TOED OF HIS OFFER
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 13 The jury in the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson learned today that the officer once offered, in the Interest of strengthening the American people's confidence in its Army, to take the blame for any coverup of mass slayings of civilians at Mylai, South Vietnam.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest. World Series scores by dialing 6371212, the telephone company's time bureau.

title: Indians Decide Lipon Will Not Be Retained
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 13 (UPI)  The Cleveland Indians, coming off their second worst season in history, said tonight that the interim manager, Johnny Lipon, would not be rehired. The club lost 102 games and finiShed last in the American League East.

title: House Tax Panel Eases Rule on Foundation Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The House Ways and Means Committee, in a step that would benefit foundations controlled by the Pew oil and Kellogg cereal families, among others, voted today to loosen a provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1969 applying to foundations.

title: L. I. SOUND REJECTED AS SITE. FOR JETPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (UPI)  A Federal Transportation Department official disclosed today that Long Island Sound had been rejected as a possible site for a proposed floating jetport.

title: Eastman Kodak Net Up;
description: The Eastman Kodak Company's sales and earnings were the highest in its history in the 12 weeks and 36 weeks periods ended Sept. 5, according to report yesterday from its Rochester, N.Y., headquarters.

title: Consumer Bill Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) The House argued at length today over whether to strengthen or weaken a bill that would create a Federal consumer protection agency but put off voting until tomorrow.

title: Ali Fight on Radio
description: The Nov. 17 heavyweight bout between Muhammad Ali and Buster Mathis will be broadcast from the Houston Astrodome by the Mutual Broadcasting System, officials said here yesterday. Television coverage will be limited to theaters and cable systems.

title: CHASE PROFIT UP 7.2% IN QUARTER
description: The spotty third  quarter earnings performance of New York City's major banks continued in evidence yesterday as the Chase Manhattan Corporation reported a 7.2 per cent gain from operations and the Charter New York Corporation reported a 13.5 per cent decline.

title: COUNTER TRADERS ELECT PRESIDENT
description: The National Security Traders Association, an organization of 5,000 overthecounter brokers and dealers, announced yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla., that James G. Mundy has been elected president to succeed Morton N. Weiss.

title: ELLSBERG INQUIRY PRESSED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 13A Federal grand jury here inevstigating how the Pentagon papers reached the press was reported today to be moving closer to returning indictments.

title: CONFLICTING VIEWS SNAG SALE OF HOTEL
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 13  The fate of the 100yearold Queen City Hotel in Cumberland, Md., remained uncertain today as different spokesmen for the owner presented conflicting views on the sale of the building, which has been ordered demolished by the Cumberland City Council.

title: Elms Wins and Raises Lead In. World Snipe Class Sail
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 13 (AP)Earl Elms of San. Diego, the defending world champion, increased his lead today in the 25th Snipe Class sailing world championships by winning the third race in the scheduled sevenrace series.

title: Potential High Court Nominees
description: KnoWn as a strong law and order advocate with most of her legal background in criminal prosecution . . . Appointed to first judgeship seven months ago by President Nixon and now serves on the Superior Court of the District of Columbia . . . Had worked with the Kerner Commission on Riots and Civil Disorders . . . Later worked with the committee seeking to implement commission's recommendations . . . The 39yearold judge had been a Justice Department aide, where she helped draft the District of Columbia crime bill with its no knock search and preventive detention provisions . . . Recently argued for clearing court calendars of all criminal cases by calling a moratorium on civil cases . . . First sworn in as Assistant United States Attorney in September, 1957 . . . Prior to that she had clerked for Judge Burnita Shelton Mathews of United States District Court . . . The daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius F. Bacon of Watertown, S. D. . .Attended Vassar College, majoring in economics . . . Graduated in 1953 and went on to Harvard Law School . . . Lives in Washington.

title: OCCIDENTAL RULING REVERSED BY COURT
description: The United States Court of Appeals here yesterday reversed a lower court decision that would have required the Occidental Petroleum Company to give up $23.5million of profits and interest allegedly obtained in violation of the Securities Exchange Act.

title: Clarence B. Newman, 50, Of Newsday News Staff
description: Clarence B. Newman, a member of the editorial staff of Newsday, died of a rifle wound in his apartment in Manhattan on Tuesday evening. He was 50 years old and lived at 70 La Salle Street.

title: Loose Judging Standards Assailed
description: The dogshow world was roundly criticized by Kurt Unkelbach yesterday at the Dog Fanciers Club luncheon in the McAlpin Hotel.

title: Effort to Get U N. Presence in Pakistan Deadlocked
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13  Efforts to get representatives of the United Nations stationed along the tense border between East Pakistan and India remained deadlocked today, despite three months of intensive private negotiations within and outside the world organization.

title: Notes on People
description: Prince Rahim, an 8pound son and heir, was born to Aga Khan IV, the Harvard graduate who is spiritual leader of 15 million Ismaili Moslems in Asia and Africa, and his wife, the Begum Aga Khan.

title: Credentials Chairman Patricia Roberts Harris
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Patricia Roberts Harris chose the law as a career because she saw it as the last refuge of the generalist. That decision has taken her from the staff of the Department of Justice to the ambassadorship to Luxembourg to the Law School of Howard University, with way stations at the United Nations and the boards of several prestigious corporalions. Today she rode out a struggle between the Democratic regulars and the party's reformers to become temporary chairman of the important Credentials Committee for the 1972 Democratic National Convention.

title: POLLUTION LINKED TO PHYSICAL ILLS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct, 13  When the pollution in New York City air increases to levels commonly reached many times a year healthy people are much more likely to feel sick and even to get sick, according to findings presented here today.

title: Campaign Headquarters Of Yonkers Mayor Riddled
description: YONKERS, Oct. 13The campaign headquarters of Mayor Alfred Del Bello was riddled by gunfire late lagt night or early this morning, the police reported. No one was in, the onestory building at 310 Yonkers Avenue, when the shooting occurred sometime after 9 P.M., when the office was closed.

title: President of B'nai B'rith Calls for New BlackJewish Coalition
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13  The head of B'nal B'rith called tonight for rebuilding the shattered relationship between the black and the Jewish communities and reviving the liberal coalition that succeeded the civil rights campaigns of decade ago.

title: Rights Amendment Faces Delay In Busy Senate Till 72 Session
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13The constitutional amendment prohibiting sex discrimination that sailed through the House yesterday will not be considered by the Senate until sometime next year.

title: Budgets of State and City Tied to PayPrice Curbs
description: To city and state budget officials, wages and fringe benefits have emerged as the most critical components of President Nixon's planned economic controls.

title: Ball to Be Enshrined
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (AP)The first ball pitched in the first World Series baseball game played at night will have a special pedestal in baseball's museum. Luke Walker, a lefthander for the Pittsburgh Piraes threw it. It was a strike to Paul Blair.

title: Market Place: Delay Is Decried On Oil Pipeline
description: It's not widely known outside of trade circles, but some experts are now saying that Prudhoe Bay crude oil may not reach American markets until 1977 or 1978. That's the pitch, for instance, from Oil Statistics Bulletins, Babson Park, Mass., a widely read trade publication.

title: STOKOWSKI LEADS BRAHMS' FOURTH
description: Leopold Stokowski has always put his personal stamp on the music he makes. It is part of the fascination he holds for listeners, and since he has a kind of genius he makes his idiosyncrasies enjoyable even when they seem wrong. He has never changed.

title: Waitress, Salesman Win Million Each in Jersey
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 13 (AP) A waitress and a soap salesman were millionaire winners today in the second doubledrawing of the state lottery.

title: DELAY IN BUILDING OF SCHOOLS ASSAILED
description: The chairman of the City Council committee charged with watching the progress of capital construction projects said yesterday that school construction was proceeding with the rapidity of a snail.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: DETROIT, Oct. 13 (UPI) General Motors today asked owners of 1,600 Chevrolet and GMC light trucks built early in the 1972 model year to return them to dealers for inspection and possible adjustment of a spring shackle stop.

title: Lichstein, for Pin Money, Throws Left, Signs Right
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 13 With Larry Lichstein, one of the leaders in the $85,000 Professional Bowlers' Association national championship currently under way at Paramus Bowl, the left hand doesn't just wash the right hand  It has provided a handy income for it.

title: Planners Approve a Hudson Convention Center
description: The first steps toward municipal approval of two major tourist attractions  a cityawned and refurbished Yankee Stadium and a new convention center on the Hudson shorewere taken yesterday.

title: C.B.S. Earnings Rise 17%
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., had record sales and the second highest earnings in the third quarter, its best quarter this year, the report disclosed yesterday. While ninemonth sales also reached a peak, earnings were down 8 per cent from last year reflecting the severely depressed first quarter because of the mandated loss of cigarette advertising.

title: PHONE UNION SEEKS TO BUY NETWORK ADS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  The Communications Workers of America has asked the Federal Communications Commission to force radio and television broadcasters to accept advertisements from anions during labor disputes if they also air company ads.

title: Film Fete: Reich Collage
description: Dusan Makavejev's new Yugoslav film, WR  Mysteries of the Organism, is an occasionally comic and brilliant collage movie that leaves me cold, yet filled with a certain admiration for its adventuresomeness, even when that adventuresomeness appears to be the result of Makavejev and his editor's making do, as best they can, with the material at band.

title: Nixon Acts to Strengthen Aid to Minority Business
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 President Nixon acted today to strengthen the Administration's program to aid businesses operated by members of minority groups.

title: U.S. ShortTerm Drawings Set a Record
description: The Federal Reserve System disclosed yesterday that it drew a record $3.6billion on shortterm, international credit lines in the first eight months of this year.

title: Ideals vs. Interests
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The conflict that has been fought this week at the meeting of the Democratic National Committee over the choice of a key committee chairman for the 1972 convention is basically a struggle over the kind of party the Democrats are going to become.

title: Doris Doree, Dramatic Soprano Who Sang With the Met, Dead
description: Doris Doree, a dramatic soprano who had sung with the Metropolitan, City Center and Covent Garden Operas, died in Beth Israel Hospital, apparently of a heart ailment, on Tuesday. She was 62 years old and lived at 166 West 72d Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Marcos Is First Guest at Iran Fete
description: SHIRAZ, Iran, Oct. 13For a while today it looked as if the Chinese Communists, who recently established diplomatic relations with Iran, would be the first guests at the Shah of Iran's tent city extravaganza.

title: Mrs. Kathleen Hoyt Dead; Operated East Side Shop
description: Mrs. Kathleen MacGuire Hoyt, who ran Kathleen Inc., an East Side fashion shop, until her retirement a few years ago, died yesterday at her home, 50 East 73d Street. She was 87 years old.

title: State Suspends Three for Falsifying Ownership of Horses
description: The New York State Racing Commission yesterday suspended the licenses of Ralph Wilson, George Poole and Johnny Campo for 30 days for misrepresentation of ownership of thoroughbred horses. Wilson is an owner of horses and Poole and Campo are trainers. At the same time the board ordered Frank Caldwell, currently under indefinite suspension, to appear at a hearing on Oct. 29 to show cause why his license as an owner should not be revoked.

title: F.A.A. to Require Mufflers on 2 and 3Engine Jets
description: MIAMI, Oct. 13The Federal Aviation Administrator, John H. Shaffer, said today that his agency would issue an order soon requiring airlines to install noisesuppression devices on all their 1,100 two and threeengine jets. It would be the first time the Government has ordered the Muffling of jets built in the prejumbo period.

title: Month of Antiwar Rallies Begins Throughout the Country
description: Homebound workers mingled With several thousand demonstrators at a Vietnam Moratorium Day labor rally held yesterday on Seventh Aveiue between 36th and 37th Streets.

title: FABRIC DEVELOPED TO RESIST FLAMES
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation has developed and is selling a new line of fireresistant fabrics for commercial and industrial uses, the company announced yesterday. The line consists of four fabrics made of the Carborundum Company's Kynol fiber and blends of Kynol and Nomex, a nylon flameresistant fiber made by E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., Inc.

title: STOCKS DECLINE AS TRADING DIPS
description: The stock market faltered yesterday in the face of confusion and uncertainty over Phase Two of the nation's economic policy.

title: Races Battle Over Confederate Flag
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Oct. 13Negro and white students fought today at Dixie Hollins High School as a furor continued over the use of the Confederate battle flag as the school's banner.

title: Hill & Knowlton Fills Several Key Positions
description: Advertising:

title: Article 5  No Title
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 13 (UPI)Results in the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today:

title: Police Desk Lieutenants Getting Greater Responsibilities in New Role Here
description: The desk lieutenant, a fixture in precinct houses throughout the city for more than 75 years, will be replaced by a patrolman under a system now being implemented by the Police Department.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: President Nixon's China trip, the floating dollar and the imposition of a border tax on imports have inspired a lot of criticism from people who fear we have dealt too harshly with our ally, Japan. Critics say we have unwisely set Japan adrift, destabilized her internal politics so consistent since World War II, and given China an upper hand in its dealing with Japan. These critics foresee with distaste bordering on terror Japanese rearmament of conventional weapons and reassertion of Japanese leadership in Asia. Critics conclude that none of these developments are in U.S. interests.

title: Davis, Starting for Jets, Is Not Afraid to Throw
description: Before practice Weeb Ewbank walked up to Bob Davis.

title: PROGRESS REPORTED IN TAXI TALKS HERE
description: Loyal and dissident factions of the Taxi Drivers Union clashed noisily at Manhattan Center on West 34th Street last night, but the session was far milder than the last general meeting on April 14, which broke up in rioting.

title: Phoebe Ephron, Comedy Writer, Dies
description: Mrs. Phoebe Wolkind Ephron, who with her hushand Henry Ephron had been successful Broadway and Hollywood writer since 1943, died yesterday after a long illness at their home, 176 East 71st Street. She was 57 years old,

title: Bruins Find Extra Time on Ice Pays Off
description: We didn't come here to lose, said Tom Johnson, the Boston Bruins coach, after last night's emphatic 6 1 triumph over a Ranger team that had lost only two home games last season.

title: Wild Gas Well Ignited
description: DUNCAN, Okla., Oct. 13 (UPI) A blownout gas well whose fumes had driven 150 families from their homes was deliberately ignited today,, sending a 300foot trail of fire spurting into the sky. Putting a match to it eliminates any chances of a gas buildup or an explosion, said a spokesman for the Duncan County Sheriff's Department.

title: A.T.& T. FORECASTS RECORD SPENDING
description: A record capital spending program in 1972 and soaring revenues from data transmission for the rest of the decade were forecast yesterday by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Civic Group Buys Landmark on S.I.
description: A. Staten Island landmark dating from 1871, the former village hall in the community of New Brighton, was purchased at a city auction by a community group yesterday for its headquarters.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: Bondsman's Aide Is Held in Forgery Of Court Documents
description: A bondsman's aide was arraigned yesterday in the Bronx on forgery and grand larceny charges stemming from an alleged attempt last week to have a prisoner freed from the Bronx House of Detention with the use of forged court documents.

title: Pact Runs Into 1973
description: GENEVA, Oct. 13  Japan has ended her yearlong holdout against renewal of a threeyear pact regulating international trade in cotton textiles, it was announced here today.

title: SOLDIER IN ULSTER SHOT BLASTING ROAD
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 13A British soldier was wounded by sniper fire from across the border today as troops began blowing up secondary roads between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic.

title: PRESIDENT ASKS BAR UNIT TO CHECK 6 FOR HIGH COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Nixon Administration has sent the names of six persons, including two women, to be investigated by the American Bar Association as potential nominees to the two vacant seats on the Supreme Court.

title: Daniel Ridder Marries Mrs. Frani Ackerman
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., Oct. 13  Mrs. Frani Cooper Ackerman, formerly of Purchase, N. Y., was married at home here this afternoon to Daniel H. Ridder, editorpublisher of The Long Beach Independent and Press Telegram and a vice president of Ridder Publications. The private ceremony was performed by Superior Court Judge Roy J. Brown of Los Angeles County.

title: Personal Finance
description: Ten months ago Massachusetts became the first state to enact a nofault auto insurance law, and already it is talking of reducing insurance rates next year.

title: 55th St. Tenants See Halt to Eviction
description: The fate of 70 apartment tenants at 101 West 55th Street hangs on a decision, expected within a few days, that may also mark a shift in city policy toward the demolition of housing in Manhattan to make way for office buildings.

title: GIANTS PLOTTING A MOBILE ATTACK
description: Alex Webster, the football Giants' coach, seemed ready to concede yesterday that the shortest route to the goal line was not always the surest as he prepared his squad for Sunday's game with the Baltimore Colts at Yankee Stadium.

title: Hecklers of Lindsay at Cornell Focus on Jail Conditions Here
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 13  Mayor Lindsay yielded the microphone to hecklers last night before a turbulent audience of 2,300 Cornell University students who focused their questions on conditions in the city's prisons.

title: Stars Top Rockets, 135121, With FourthQuarter Surge
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 13 (AP)The Utah Stars broke open a close game early in the fourth quarter tonight and opened the 197172 American Basketball Association season with a 135121 victory over the Denver Rockets. Utah was led by Glen Combs, a guard, who scored 36 points,

title: Wood, Field and Stream.
description: Critics and advocates of a proposed 400home development project in the town of Rockland, N. Y., will, have an opportunity to air their views at a public hearing set for next Thursday at 11 A.M. at the Fire Hall in Livingston Manor.

title: Thompson Promotes Officer
description: Those Madison Avenue prophets who have bqen saying Stever Aubrey is the man to watch at the J. Walter Thompson Company, can really chuckle it up this morning.

title: Top City Aides Curbed on Outside Work
Canada's Exports Grow
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 13 (Canadian Press)  Canadian exports to the United States rose in September to $1.02billion, Statistics Canada reported today, showing a greater rate of increase after President Nixon's new import duties than before it.

title: SOYBEANS PRICES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Increased interest abroad in United States  produced soybeans attracted speculative activity in futures of that commodity on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, sending prices up sharply. Late profit taking, however, trimmed some of the gains.

title: Cambodians Report Victory
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 13 (AP)The Cambodian high command today reported the capture of Pnomsantuk,. a 600foot hill 75 miles north of the capital, where a 20,000man task force has been stalled for about two weeks in its drive to clear Route 6. The hill is one of three dominating the road to the provincial capital of Kompong Thom about five miles farther north.

title: Sadat and Soviet Agree on Steps to Strengthen Egypt
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 13Soviet and Egyptian leaders announced agreement tonight on new measures aimed at further strengthening the military might of Egypt.

title: Rollins, ExReporter, Named Editor by Harlem Weekly
description: The appointment of Bryan T. Rollins, a 33yearold urban affairs consultant and former newspaper reporter, as executive editor of The New York Amsterdam News was announced yesterday by Clarence B. Jones, editor and publisher of the Harlem based weeklyn newspaper. He succeeds Jesse Walker, who is retiring after 15 years with the paper.

title: H.R. A. HEAD SCORED ON RELIEF JOB AID
description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger criticized the city's Human Resources Administration yesterday for minimizing the significance and numbers of likely removals of relief recipients from welfare rolls under the state's new workrelief law.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13Here is a partial list of reasons Congress cannot do anything:

title: Emperor's Feast: Made in U.S.A.
description: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 13Although no one expected the Emperor of Japan to arrive here today with Alaska on $5 a Day tucked under his arm, he apparently decided not to break the tourist's golden rule, of When in Rome, do as the Romans do.

title: 2 NEWSMEN BACK AGNEW'S ATTACKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) Two Nebraska newspaper executives said today that Vice President Agnew has sometimes been right in his attacks on the press.

title: Laird Warns of Soviet Missile BuildUp Far Exceeding His Earlier Estimates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird expressed concern today over what he said was a continuing Soviet buildup of landbased and seabased missiles. This buildup, already far outdistancing the estimates he offered Congress seven months ago.

title: Curtis Is Plastered For Giants but Only On Right Forearm
description: Mike Curtis and the rest of the Baltimore Colts will come jogging into Yankee Stadium on Sunday to play the Giants. They were here three years ago and won, 260, putting Fran Tarkenton out of the Arne in the fourth quarter because of frustration rather than injury. The cast of Colts has changed by about a third but two key positions remain the same, Earl Morrall at quarterback and Curtis at middle linebacker.

title: Harmony the Dish at Democratic Lunch
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The Democratic Congressional delegation from New York had lunch todaytogether.

title: Reagan to Convey to Thieu Congratulations From Nixon
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 13 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan of California said here, today that he would extend President Nixon's congratulations to President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam on his election victory.

title: Punishment By Dollar
description: Letters to the Editor

title: CLEMENTE'S FOUL BORDERLINE CASE
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct, 13Although no one ever can say for sure, it's at least possible that a controversial drive hit by Roberto Clemente in a Pittsburgh rally in the tliird inning of tonight's World Series game could have left Three Rivers Stadium as a fair ball but wound up officially foul.

title: Rebuilding the Stock Market
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has opened hearings on a complex set of issues that boil down one: What is to be the structure of the securities industry in the United States?

title: Per Astra Ad Aspera?
description: Teachers through the ages have, when confronted by pupils obstinate refusal to absorb the proferred wisdom, turned eyes heavenward in a mute call for supernatural guidance. Perhaps it is just such exasperation that has impelled Isaiah E. Robinson, president of the city's Board of Education, to seek aid and comfort in astrology when he ponders the urban school scene.

title: Kison and May, Pirates' Heroes, Close in Age and Plans
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13  Bruce Kison and Milt May, the 21yearold heroes of Pittsburgh's victory over Baltimore in the World Series tonight, were born 5 months apart in 1950. Now they will be married 7 weeks apart in 1971.

title: YIELDS ON BONDS CONTINUE TO FALL
description: Interest rates continued their pronounced drive toward lower levels yesterday.

title: AlbertoCulver Items Going to New Agency
Knoll Opens Own Retail Outlet
description: That maker of fine modern furnishings, Knoll International, has at last made it possible for shoppers to view its complete line and buy what they will. Until yesterday, when Knoll opened a shop on the third floor at Georg Jensen, it wasn't always easy.

title: Saar Chamber Orchestra Lives Up to Reputation
description: The power of the internationally distributed recording in making musical reputations would be hard to exaggerate. One of the famous examples from recent years, the Chamber Orchestra of the Saar Radio, performed at Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night, with Antonio Janigro conducting. The Saar group, which is on its second American tour, became one of the busiest recording orchestras in the world under the late Karl Ristenpart at a time when many another excellent ensemble was pricing itself out of the studios.

title: Profits and Wages
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Julius Sedhnayr Weds Mrs. Jane Kerr
description: The marriage of Mrs. Jane Richard Kerr, a literary agent for children's books, to Julius Hamilton Sedimayr, group vice president at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., took place here yesterday. Criminal Court Judge Frederick L. Strong performed the ceremony at Mr. and Mrs. G. Bruce Leib's home.

title: Ez Painter Corp. Agrees to Sell Off Brush Operation
description: The Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday that the Ez Painter Corporation of Milwaukee had agreed to an F.T.C. antitrust order to sell off certain of its paintbrush and roller operations. Ez Painter has agreed to divest itself within a year of the Corporate name and certain trade accounts of the American Brush Corporation, which makes roller,s used for the application of paints. In addition Ez Painter is required to divest itself of King Paint Roller, Inc., Detroit, a maker of paint rollers that is an affiliate of Masterset Brushes, Inc., acquired by Ez Painter in 1970.

title: Chile Deplores Pressure
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 13 (UPI)Foreign Minister Almeyda accused Mr. Rogers today of exercising veiled pressure against Chile because of her refusal to pay for the copper properties.

title: Two Quit Education Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  President Nixon accepted, yesterday the resignations of Judith Williams of Coventry, Conn., and Oliver C. Carmichael Jr. of South Bend, Ind., from the National Advisory Council on Education Professions Devel, opment.

title: TORIES ENDORSE STAND ON MARKET
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 13 The Conservative party conference overwhelmingly endorsed today the Government's commitment to bring Britain into the European Economic Community.

title: U.S. Checking Con Ed 5% Rate Rise
description: The temporary 5 per cent increase in Consolidated Edison's electricity rates for commercial and residential customers, granted June 15, is one of five cases under investigation for possible rollback under President Nixon's wage, price and rent freeze program.

title: Car Makers Give F.T.C. Data to Back Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 The General Motors Corporation, responding to the Federal Trade., Commission's demand for documentation of advertising claims, has listed an automatic choke and body by Fisher among the Chevrolet Chevelle's 109 advantages.

title: VOLKSWAGEN SETS NEW RISE IN PRICES
description: BASIN HARBOR, Vt., Oct. 13 Volkswagen, the largest seller of foreign cars in the United States, announced today a 6.8 per cent price increase for most of its 1972 models, giving Detroit a price edge in Its battle with the import.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BELGRADE, Oct. 13 (Reuters) The Yugoslav press tonight welcomed President Nixon's announced visit to Moscow as contributing to the lessening of world tension, but added there is nothing very sensational in the news.

title: Red Cross Talks Lag in Korea, but All Is Harmony
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, Oct. 13Clinking their beer glasses in a farewell toast, South Korean and North Korean negotiators smilingly agreed to try again next Wednesday after failing today to set a date for the opening of fullscale talks on the humanitarian problems left by the war that ended 18 years ago.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES $250MILLION LIMIT ON CAMBODIAN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted today to impose a $250million ceiling on military and economic aid to the Cambodian Government in the current fiscal year.

title: U.S. Warns Opel Owners Of a Defect in Windshields
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP)  The Department of Transportation today urged the owners of more than 100,000 Germanbuilt Opel automobiles to return their vehicles to General Motors Corporation dealers as soon as possible for windshield cementing.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Victor Comptometer Corporation announced yesterday the election of A. C. Buehler Jr. as chairman. He succeeds his late father, A. C. Buehler. In another executive change, Alvin F. Bakewell, vice chairman in charge of international operations and research, has retired. He will continue as director. George W. May, in addition to his current duties as president and chief operating officer, will assume the duties formerly held by Mr. Bakewell.

title: CHAMBER SEEKING DOCTOR MEMBERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  The United States Chamber of Commerce is soliciting new memberships from doctors to help combat what it describes as welfarism and the passage of national health insurance.

title: U.S. Aide Rejects Buckley View on U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13An Administration spokesman rejected today Senator James L. Buckley's proposal that Congress cut back United States financing of the United Nations if Nationalist China is expelled from the international organization.

title: Enemy Demolition Squad Destroys Two U.S. Copters
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 14 (AP)A small band of enemy demolition men slipped into an allied base eight miles northeast of Saigon early yesterday, blew up two helicopters and heavily damaged three others.

title: ALEC REEVES DIES; INVENTOR WAS 69
description: LONDON, Oct. 13Alec Harley Reeves, an electronics scientist and inventor, credited with the development of pulsecode modulation, died of cancer today. He was 69 years old.

title: 8 EastWest Nations to Set Up Center on Technology Problems
description: Scientific representatives of eight nations in the East and West have agreed to set up an international institute to foens some of the world's best brains on the complex problems arising from modern technology,

title: Coast re Contained
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 13 (AP)A brush fire that killed four firemen and blackened about 14,200 acres of valuable watershed was declared fully contained today. Officials said it could be completely controlled by tomorrow.

title: U.S. Will Seek Contempt Action Against Defiant Dock Locals
To Orioles, It's 2Outof3 Series Now
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 Well, said Brooks Robinson, it's now two out of three, right?

title: Alfred Faces Hobart Saturday In a Big Battle of Little Powers
description: College football upstate has been as crisp and attractive as one of those wonderful autumn days in the Finger Lakes region. There have been many shades of success, from the power of Syracuse and the allwinning record of Cornell to the surprising achievements of little and unbeaten Alfred and Hobart. Colgate, Rochester, Ithaca, Union and St. Lawrence have sparkling teams and individuals like Cornell's Ed Marinaro and Ithaca's quarterback, Doug Campbell, brighten the scene.

title: DR. FINN J. LARSEN, 55, EXDEFENSE OFFICIAL
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 13 Dr. Finn J. Larsen, Assistant Secretary of the Army for Research and Development from 1961 to 1963 and principal deputy director of defense research and engineering for the Department of Defense from 1966 to 1969, died Monday night of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

title: More Than Merely Present
description: I would place you among the greatest Secretaries of State this country has had, Harry S. Truman wrote to Dean Acheson as they prepared to leave office 1953. We are still too close to the events of that period to evaluate Mr. Truman's characteristically exuberant assessment. What is clear is that Mr. Acheson, not only as Secretary of State but during six wartime and postwar years as Assistant and Under Secretary, played highly creative and often decisive role in the shaping and administration of American foreign policy.

title: Steelers Practice on Field Before Series Night Game
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers managed a workout at Three Rivers Stadium today despite the fact that the allpurpose field is being used for the World Series.

title: NADER CALLS PACT BONANZA TO I.B.M.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, charged today that the United States Postal Service was about to grant the International Business Machines Corporation a massive anticompetitive boondoggle in contracts to develop an automated lettersorting system.

title: Russia's Goals in the Mideast
description: WASHINGTONThis piece begins, like the sermons of my youth, with a text. It is taken from testimony given last March and April before Senator Jackson's Subcommittee on National Security and International Operations by two eminent authorities, the first on the Middle East by Bernard Lewis, the second by Robert Conquest on the Soviet Union:

title: $2MILLION FRAUD UNCOVERED HERE
description: The police arrested two men yesterday they said had bilked credit card companies, department stores and airlines of more than $2million by using stolen traveler's checks, fake credit cards and bad checks.

title: AGNEW, IN TURKEY, SUPPORTS REFORM
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 13 Vice President Agnew ended his twoday official visit to Turkey today after giving strong support to the militarybacked Turkish Government in its efforts to make deep social reforms.

title: Talks Stir Japanese
description: TOKYO, Oct. 13 (AP)  The Japanese textile industry said today it will oppose the Government's decision to negotiate a textile agreement with the United States.

title: ACHESON IS MOURNED IN TRUMAN TRIBUTE
description: INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 13 (UPI)  Former President Harry S. Truman, profoundly distressed by the death of Dean Acheson, his Secretary of State from 1949 to 1953, today described him as a friend of all mankind.

title: Auto Racing and the Market Place
description: Sports of The Times

title: FRANK G. QUINN
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Oct. 13Frank G. Quinn, a member of the board of directors of the Quinn and Boden Company, book manufacturing concern in Rahway, died yesterday at nursing home in Scotch Plains. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: British Exports at Record
description: LONDON, Oct. 13British exports were at a new high last month and September merchandise trade was in substantial surplus for the sixth straight month, the Department of Trade and Industry reported today.

title: MRS. HARRIS WINS DEMOCRATIC POST Reformers Defeated, 7231, as Hughes Loses Bid for Key Convention Job
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris, a black lawyer, was elected today as temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the 1972 Democratic National Convention in an overwhelming victory for the party regulars.

title: Insiders Stockholdings
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: LEGAL ABORTIONS CLIMB IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, Oct. 13A large increase in the number of legal abortions, accompanied by a striking advance In abortion safety, was reported today by Britain's chief medical officer in his annual review, On the State of Public Health.

title: U.S. Backs Its China. Stand With Soft and Hard Sell
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 13With the China debate scheduled to open on Monday, the United States is applying the full weight of its diplomacy and prestige in scores of foreign capitals for its policy of dual Chinese representation in the. United Nations.

title: Add Alchemy to Studies
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Sergeant Freed by Foe Reunited With Parents
description: AURORA, Colo., Oct. 13 (AP)S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr., Who walked to freedom Friday near the CambodiaSouth Vietnam border after having been a prisoner of war for two years, was reunited with his parents today.

title: Alternatives Asked By G.O.P. to Plan On Fund Sharing
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) 6Republicans are inviting alternatives to President Nixon's revenuesharing plan, now locked in committee, thus keeping alive the possibility of some help this year for hardpressed local governments.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF IN ACTIVE TRADING
description: Most prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday in active trading.

title: Russian Astronaut Reports Manned Flight Is Planned
description: VIENNA, Oct. 13 (AP)The Soviet astronaut Pavel Popovich says that despite the landing disaster of the Soyuz 11 spaceship last June the Soviet Government is planning another manned space flight next year and will put a second Lunokhod craft on the moon.

title: Layer, Emerson Triumph; Rosewall Wins at Cologne
description: COLOGNE, Germany, Oct. 13 (AP)Rod Laver and Roy Emerson of Australia reached the quarter finals of the World Championship Tennis Professional tournament here today.

title: CHURCH SUPPORTS FAIRNESS RULES
description: The executive council of the United Church of Christ rejected yesterday any weakening of the fairness doctrine of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Jesuits Name Director
description: The Rev. Andrew C. Varga, a former general assistant of the Society of Jesus (Jesuit), has been named director of the John Lalarge Institute, a conference center in the America House at 106 West 56th Street.

title: Refunds on Rent Expected For Thousands Under Law
EAST GERMANS HAIL NIXON TRIP TO SOVIET
description: BERLIN, Oct. 13  President Nixon's announcement of his forthcoming visit to Moscow was hailed in East Germany today as a move that foils the plans of Peking's leaders to use their latest flirtation with Washington for, the establishment of antiSoviet bloc.

title: CONGRESS TO GET PLAN FOR A VOICE ON CONTROL POSTS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13An effort will be made in Congress to require Senate confirmation for President Nixon's wage and price regulators.

title: Bankruptcy at the U.N.
description: The threat to slash American financial support for the United Nations if the General Assembly votes to expel the Chinese Nationalistsa threat that originated among Congressional conservatives led by Senator Buckley New Yorkis like an anvil tossed at a drowning man.

title: In Seattle Superman Is No. 24
description: The Seattle SuperSonics are promoting their own version of SupermanSpencer Haywood.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 13  John Lynch, the Irish Prime Minister, announced that he had formally protested to Britain about the blowing up of secondary roads between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic. He said that the action was a retrograde step that would aggravate a deteriorating situation.

title: City Skating Rinks Pat Price Rise in Freezer
description: The freeze  President Nixon's price freeze, that is has hit the city's ice skating rinks, prompting the Parks Department to roll back its new rates for adults at general skating sessions.

title: Pirates Beat Orioles, 43, And Even Series at 2All
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13In the first night game in the 68year history of the World Series, the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 43, this evening and deadlocked the Series at two games apiece.

title: Sales of New Cars Rose in 10Day Period
description: New car sales rose in the first 10 days of October but variety of influences made the results considerably less of an economic indicator that is usually the case.

title: Bridge: New Pair Will Help Britain In Bid for the European Title
description: The bridge prestige of Great Britain, at a low ebb in recent years, may be on the rise again. For many years the British relied on veterans who had learned the game before World War II, but they have now found a young team with the necessary blend of talent and experience to make an effective bid for the European title.

title: PLANNERS DEPLORE CHARGE BY A RABBI
Korea: Getting It All Together
description: The first official dialogue between the two countries of North and South Korea since 1954 is now occurring. The Red Cross Societies of both countries are discussing the question of families separated by the political division of Korea at the 38th parallel.

title: Human Cells in Test Use Genetic Matter Native to Bacteria
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 13  Scientists here have described experiments in which human cells, growing in laboratory flasks, took up and used genetic material native to bacteria.

title: Chess: Soltis and Schonhaus Share Handicap Tourney Laurels
description: A handicap tournament, ranging from the odds of pawn and move to a rook, was held at the Marshall Chess Club in a threeround Swiss system. The current club champion, Andrew Soltis, and Stephen Schonhaus tied for first place with 3.0 each.

title: Inflow at Savings Banks Up Sharply in September
description: The nation's mutual savings banks registered an estimated $125million net deposit inflowtional Association of Mutual during September, the largest for the month since a $142 million gain in 1964, the NaSavings Banks reported yesterday.

title: Bank Loan Interest Dipped in August, But Only Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) Interest rates charged by the nation's commercial banks dropped slightly in the two weeks following the wageprice freeze announcement, a Federal Reserve report disclosed today.

title: Shop Talk
description: The traditional antagonism between China and Japan brings a certain irony to the fact that the first fashions to reach New York from the People's Republic of China are at Takashimaya, the Jap anese department store at 509 Fifth Avenue, be tween 42d and 43d Streets. While clothes are shipped directly from Shanghai, they come from all over China, according to James Chen, who, with his wife, Suzie, heads up Taka shimaya's import division. Although the collection is in its infancy, it is expected to grow with each passing week, Mr. Chen reports, adding that he has applied for a visa and hopes to make a trip to China in the near future.

title: The Second Messenger
description: Dr. Earl W. Sutherland Jr. of Vanderbilt University, winner of the Nobel Prize in Physiology and Medicine, is known to biomedical scientists as one of the scientific giants of the mid20th century, one of the few biolo gists whose work is fully comparable in importance to that of the contemporary founders of the better publicized field of molecular biology.

title: Fortress America?
description: Meeting with a group of businessmen, Secretary of the Treasury Connally said that he was struck by a basic lack of confidence a basic spirit of gloom that the United States was on the verge of going protectionist economically and becoming a Fortress America?. He urged his audience to repress such gloomy thoughts and give the President their unashamed and unabashed support to rise above partisanship, just as, said Mr. Connally, Mr. Nixon is doing.

title: Agency Declares Fuel Oil Is Subject to Price Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Office of Emergency Pre paredness issued a statement today affirming that fuel oil prices are subject to the same guidelines published by the Cost of Living Council under the President's wagepricerent freeze order as other products.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: U.S. War Dead at 8 in Week Fewest Since 65
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 (UPI)  The United States command announced to day that eight Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week, the fewest for a week in more than six years.

title: CITY HOSPITAL UNIT VOTES JOB ATTRITION
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, presi dent of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yes terday that the board of direc tors, after a meeting called to find ways to cope with a $30 million budget deficit, had voted to begin selective attrition of all vacated jobs within the agency.

title: 7 Dead in NATO Games
description: MANCHING, West Germany, Oct. 14 (AP)Seven persons have been killed in accidents involving the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Reforger III maneuvers since the exer cise, near the Czechoslovak frontier, began Monday. The dead were three American sol diers, two West German sol diers and two West German civilians. The exercise ends to morrow.

title: Residents Flee Blaze in Stanhope Hotel
description: Coughing and retching, soot blackened residents of the state ly Stanhope Hotel on Fifth Avenue at 81st Street fled to the street yesterday morning as acrid black smoke from a basement fire filled the build ing.

title: Nixon's Own Expert Criticizes Cutbacks In School Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Nixon Administration was sharply rebuked today by House, committee and by its own leading authority on hun ger for seeking to eliminate fed erally subsidized school lunches for possibly 1.5 million needy children.

title: Municipal Loan Foes in Confrontation
description: Councilman Robert I. Postel and the man whose resigna tion he has been demanding Albert A. Walsh, head of the Housing and Development Ad ministration confronted each other in public for the first time yesterday.

title: Barclays Cuts Key. Rates To Raise Loan Demand
description: LONDON, Oct. 14Barclays Bank, Britain's largest, ushered in a new era of rate competi tion in this country today by cutting the interest payable on both loans and deposits by 0.5 per cent. The moves pegged the Barclays prime rate (known here as bluechip rate) at 5.5 per cent.

title: TV: Jude the Obscure Serial Shown on Channel
description: Thomas Hardy's Jude the Obscure is a major novel. The British Broadcasting, Cor poration's relatively faithful dramatization of Jude the Obscure is minor television.

title: Fortune Society Scores Plan for TopSecurity Prison
description: As a task force examined New York's penitentiaries to se lect a site for the maximum maximum state security prison for hardened and dangerous offenders, Fortune Society of ficers charged yesterday that such a facility would constitute a denial of prisoners rights to due procesg of the law.

title: Subway Motormen End Strike in Paris After Chaban's Plea
description: PARIS, Oct. 14 (Reuters)  A strike by Paris subway mo tormen that paralyzed the cap ital for nine days collapsed to day under gathering pressure from the Government, an exas perated public and the motor men's own unions.

title: FAMULA'S 63 LEADS CLUB PROS BY TWO
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 14 (AP)Eddie Famula of Short Hills, N. J., gained a two stroke lead in the first round of the $100,000 National Pro fessional Golfers Association club pro championship today with a sevenunderpar 63.

title: Wood, Field and Strearn
description: Warren Page, the execu tive vice president of the National Shooting Sporti Foundation, has given mid dleaged hunters cause for small, rejoicing.

title: Advertising:
description: When Jack Cantwell, who had been president of two agencies that belonged to somebody else, opened his own place in March, 1970, he decided the best way to get his foot In a prospective client's door was to present hint with a new product. Not just the product alone but one that had been named and packaged and one with an advertising campaign and marketing plan already pre pared.

title: 2 Offices Here Lead AntiInflation Drive
description: The front line in the war against inflation here is a long, groundfloor room with 20 tele phone, cubicles at 120 Church Street in Manhattan and a sec tion of the first floor with a row of eight desks at 35 Tillery Street, Brooklyn.

title: The Talk of Susquehanna
description: SUSQUEHANNA, Pa., The men sit at the bar in the dim light of the American Legion post here and quietly sip whisky. A few peel open thin strips of paper they have purchased from the bar tender for a dime each and look for concealed lucky numbers that pay off as much as $5.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco  Every now and then the world's statesmen, benefiting from the jet age, seek to embellish diplomacy with motion. We have entered another season of official tourism. Even this ministate's cover sign Prince is on tour. One is reminded of the legend that President Eisen hower ordered his roving Secretary of State: Foster, don't just do something, stand there.

title: Continental Can Net Off;
description: The Continental Can Compa ny and the American Can Com pany, the two leaders in the metal container and packaging field, had higher sales in the third quarter and nine months this year, according to their reports issued yesterday.

title: DI GIUSEPPE SINGS HIS FIRST DEVEREUX
description: Robert, Earl of Essex, must have been a more engaging scoundrel in life than Doni zetti's Roberto Devereux makes him. In the opera, which the New York City Opera per formed for the first time this season on Wednesday night, he spends most of his time on stage being browbeaten by Queen Elizabeth or repenting his behindthethrone fling with a fellow courtier's wife. But Enrico di Giuseppe, taking the role for the first time, made a good stab at interesting one in a weak character who is sur rounded by strong, fascinating women with tireless voices.

title: Bubba Worries Giants Harper
description: The right ankle that Charley Harper hiirt hopping from a, cafeteria window during the fire scare at the New York Giants training camp at C. W. Post College this summer still bothers him a bit But he's hoping he doesn't have to think too much about it this week because he has other worries.

title: 3 HELD IN PROTEST AGAINST GOVERNOR
description: Three persons were arrested last night when portions of a crowd that had protested the presentation of a humanitarian award to Governor Rockefeller splashed paint on and broke windows in several office build ings along the Avenue of the Americas.

title: Senators Forsaking Senate for the Stump Well Ahead of the 1972 Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The lure of the 1972 Demo cratic Presidential nomination has produced a wave of tru ancy in the Senate five months before the formal competition of the primaries gets under way.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Rangers List Ticket Sale
description: The New York Rangers will put a limited number of tickets on sale today for games with Pittsburgh, Oct. 24; Detroit, Oct. 27, and Los Angeles, Nov. 10. The tickets can be pur chased at the Felt Forum box office at Madison Square Gar den Center and Ticketron.

title: Vatican Synod Shifts Discussion To Promotion of World Justice
description: ROME, Oct. 14Delegates to the. International Synod of Ro man Catholic bishops began to day to shift the focus of their deliberations from the crisis in the priesthood to What they could do to promote world justice.

title: ROCKETS TOPPLED BY 76ERS 10594
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) Billy Cunningham scored 41 points, Including 13 in the foalth quarter, to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 10594 victory over Houston tonight in the Rockets National Basket ball Association debut in Texas.

title: New Accounting for Leases Is Opposed
description: A broad spectrum of American business involved with leasing went on record yesterday as opposing highly explosive proposals to change the rules by which the accounting profession deals with leasing transac tions.

title: Book Fair in Frankfurt Is Responding to Trends
description: FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 14The Frankfurt book fair, which opened its doors today for the 23d time in the postwar era, seems to be running to trends more than ever as far as topics of in ternational interest are con cerned.

title: Oil Company Fined for Spill
description: RICHMOND, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)The Standard Oil Com pany of California was fined $1,000 in Municipal Court to day for a 10gallon oil spill in San Francisco Bay.

title: 885924 Wins in Jersey:
description: VINELAND, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP)  The winning number in this week's New Jersey, lot tery was 885924.

title: Lisbon Tells of Angola Toll
description: LISBON, Oct. 14 (AP)Gov ernment troops killed 191 guer rillas and wounded 69 more in skirmishes in the Portuguese African territory of Angola in September, a communique said today. Fourteen Portuguese sol diers died in action during the same period, the communique added.

title: Artichoke Hearts Are Baked in Pie
description: In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

title: Floridians Down Memphis With Big 4th Period, 103.99
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 14 (AP)The Floridians broke away in the fourth quarter to capture a 10399 victory from the Mem phis Pros in the American Bas ketball Association opener to night.

title: Camera Obscura
description: The list of six men and women whose names were published yesterday as leading candidates for the two vacant seats on the Supreme Court suggests once again that Mr. Nixon is trifling with the prestige and authority of the nation's highest tribunal. The utter lack of dis tinction of at least four of the six candidateshowever worthy they may be as individual citizensreveals a continuing failure of the President to reach for accept able standards of appointment to this pinnacle of the American judiciary.

title: BRITISH AMBUSHED Al ULSTER BORDER
description: BELFAST, Oct. 14A squad of British soldiers was am bushed early today by Irish Republican Army guerrillas on an unmarked section of the border between the Irish Re public and Northern Ireland. The soldiers and guerrillas ex changed fire for two hours be fore British armored car rein forcements scattered the at tackers.

title: 2 Gunmen Assassinate ExEast Pakistan Chief
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 14Abdul Monem Khan, for mer Governor of East Paki stan, died today in the Dacca Medical College Hospital of gunshot wounds inflicted by two men who visited his home in Dacca, the East Paki stani capital, last night. The assailants, after talking with him for some time, suddenly fired and escaped. They left a grenade in his house.

title: GREEK REGIME FOE APPEALS TO AGNEW
description: ATHENS, Oct. 14Demetrios Papaspyrou, president of the last Parliament before the 1967 military coup, called today for an end to what he termed United States intervention in favor of the dictatorial regime in Greece.

title: Matket Place Usual Wisdom Defied by Fund
description: Here's a small fund with little bits of money all over the placejust $6million but invested in 100 stocksthat has managed to do quite well.

title: Germ War Center Will Be Converted Into a Cancer Lab
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 President Nixon, who has made the fight against cancer major point in his domestic program, will go to Fort Detrick, Md., Monday to an nounce the conversion of the Army biological warfare re search center there to a cancer recearch center.

title: B'NAI B'RITH SEES. CRISIS IN FAMILY
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14The nation's largest. Jewish organi zation moved today to cope with problems of the Jewish poor, drug use among youth and other social ills that threaten, the stability of the Jewish family.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The recent forecast of the 1972 G.N.P. by the National Association of Business Economists sounds like an other Alice in Wonderland look at the future. I believe that it will be impossible for the G.N.P. to reach $1,143 billion in 1972 ($782 billion in 1958 dollars) for one single, reason: There will not be enough energy to allow the U. S. to reach that level by 1972.

title: Miss Goolagong Gains Final
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 14 (UPI)Evonne Goolagong of Australia defeated Jackie Fay ter of Britain today to reach the final of the Dewar Cup in door tennis tournament. The scores were 6.4, 46, 62. Vir ginia Wade of Britain and Francoise Durr of France are scheduled to meet in a semi final tomorrow.

title: Patrolman Indicted Here In Beating of a Prisoner
description: A 26yearold Manhattan patrolman has been indicted for allegedly beating a former Jor danian policeman in a prisoner van and then dumping him into the street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times on Sept. 27 carried an article on alleged abuses in the Medic aid program that involved prescrip tions for orthopedic shoes. Two years ago, the Podiatry Society of the State of New York submitted a detailed plan to the city designed to prevent: exactly these abuses.

title: 181,821 Abortions Perform
description: During the first year of New York State's liberalized abor tion law, 181,821 abortions were performed statewide, the Department of Health an nounced yesterday in its of ficial report for the period from July 1, 1970 to June 30, 1971.

title: Film Examines Right to Life Of a Mentally Retarded Infant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The question of whether a mentally retarded infant should be al lowed to die of a correctable physical defect was raised in a filmed discussion here today.

title: Syria Says Israeli Planes Violated Airspace and Fled
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 (AP)A Syrian Army spokes man said today that Israeli warplanes had penetrated Syrian airspace.

title: JOHN G. HODGES
description: John G. Hodges, a jazz pian ist, died at his home, apparently of a heart attack, on Tuesday. He was 56 years old and lived at 205 West 80th Street.

title: 2 Jersey Leaders Drop Script And Remain Silent on Mashie
description: TRENTON, Oct. 14Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine had counted on having New Jersey's two leading Democrats publicly committed this evening to his candidacy for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination. But it didn't work out that way. Earlier this month Missouri's Democratic Governor, Warren E. Hearnes, and its two Demo cratic Senators, Stuart Syming, ton and Thomas F. Eagleton, made early endorsements of Senator Muskie's Presidential candidacy.

title: CHINA REDS FIRM ON TAIWAN STAND
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 14The Chinese Communists today re jected the view that the Soviet Union's three seats in the Unit ed Nations creates a precedent for keeping the Chinese Na tionalist Government on Tai wan in the world organization.

title: HOUSE APPROVES A FEDERAL AGENCY TO AID CONSUMERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  The House passed by a 344to 44 vote today a bill to create an independent Federal agency with authority to advocate and defend consumer interests, particularly in regulatory pro ceedings before other Federal agencies.

title: DR. CLAUDE BECK, HEART SPECIALIST
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 14  Dr. Claude S. Beck, the surgeon who originated an operation for coronary occlusion, died to day in a nursing home after suffering a stroke last year. He was 76 years old and lived in East Cleveland.

title: SAAB GAINS DISCOUNT ON AUTO INSURANCE
description: The Allstate Insurance Com pany announced yesterday that a Swedishbuilt automobile, the 1972 Saab 99 E, had become the first car to qualify for the corn pany's new 15 per cent bumper discount on collision insurance. The auto sells for $3,807.

title: A Senator's Immunity
description: AMHERST, Mass.The Nixon Ad ministration is at it again. First it tried to intimidate the television net works. In vain. Next it attempted, for the first time in our history, to silence the press by the threat of prior cen sorship. Again in vain. Now the Jus tice Department has launched an attack on the constitutional privileges of a coordinate branch of the Gov ernmentthe Congress of the United States and, by implication, every legis lature in the United States.

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.2 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 107.0 from 106.8 last week.

title: Pound Circulation Increases 8.31Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended yesterday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: NoBail Prisoner Release lnvestigated
description: Police and judicial officials isaid yesterday that they in tended to look into the release without bail of a number of prisoners who were arraigned Tuesday and Wednesday night in Bronx Criminal Court.

title: 6 Indicted in Jersey in Theft on Docks
description: NEWARK, Oct. 14  Six men were indicted today by Federal grand jury on charges of stealing copper and liquor from New York piers in 1968.

title: 63 Million, a Record, Saw Series Night Game
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14The first night game in World Series history was seen on 21 million sets, National Broadcasting Company offi cials estimated today on the basis of preliminary reports.

title: 2 ESPOSITO GOALS HELP BRUINS WIN
