description: BOSTON, Oct. 14 (UPI)Phil Esposito; the National Hockey League's defending scoring king, tallied two goals and had three assists while Wayne Cashman, a line mate, added two goals tonight as the Boston Bruins downed the Buffalo Sabres, 62.

title: JEROME ROSE GIVES HIS ANNUAL RECITAL
description: Jerome Rose, who is becom ing an annual piano recitalist here, loves and believes in the traditional composers, and he is not afraid to program their less familiar works. On Wednes day night in Tully Hall, he played Schubert's Sonata in A minor (Op. 42), Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op. 10, No. 3) and Schumann's Kreisleriana.

title: MiddleIncome Wage Earners Are Found to Need Legal Aid
description: The middleincome wage earner is being deprived of adequate legal representation because he is too poor to af ford private legal fees and too well off to qualify for free legal aid, according to testi mony by legal experts at hearing conducted by State At torney General Louis J. Lef kowitz yesterday.

title: HENDERSON JURY HEARS GENVKOSTER
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 14  Brig. Gen. Samuel W. Kos ter, who was demoted and cen sured by the Army an connec tion with the events at Mylai 4, testified today that his sub ordinates had never told him mass slaying of civilians occurred during the attack on the South Vietnamese hamlet.

title: Rhodesia Sees Hand Bolstered by U.S Senate Move on Chrome
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Oct. 14The vote last week by the United States Senate to permit the importation of Rhodesian chrome despite a United Na tions embargo is felt here to have strengthened the hand of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith in the present delicate stage of his contacts with the British Gov ernment.

title: Prices of Stocks Tumble In WideRanging Retreat
description: A jittery stock market took a severe pasting yesterday as prices fell to their lowest level since the Friday before the famous Nixon rally on Aug. 16.

title: Merger News
description: Wells Fargo & Co., parent company of the $7billion Wells Fargo Bank, announced yester day a major modification in its plan to acquire the $1billion First Western Bank and Trust Company from World Airways, Inc., for $95million in cash and notes. Richard P. Cooley, president and chief executive of Wells Fargo, stated that we will divest First Western's 41 northern [Califor nia] branches to a buyer or buyers acceptable to the regulatory authorities.

title: It Was Enough to Make a Man Cry  Briles Did
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14 Nelson Briles cried today. I've never done that before, but I couldn't help it, said Briles, an amateur acting huff who wasn't acting when he responded with tears to a spontaneous ear  shattering and heartthrobbing standing ovation as he came to bat in the eighth inning.

title: Abortion Group to March
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) The Women's National Abor tion Action Coalition announced plans today for a march on the Capitol Nov. 20 to support demands for the repeal of all antiabortion laws.

title: 4TH VIOLENT NIGHT BESETS PATERSON
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 14 Marauding bands of Puerto Rican youths hurled fire bombs and stones at stores, automo biles and police vehicles to night in the fourth consecutive night of violence in the Spanish speaking community of this North Jersey industrial city.

title: LABOR SETTING UP PRICE WATCHDOG
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., announcnd plans today for the creation of labor watchdog units around the country to monitor prices dur ing the second phase of Presi dent Nixon's economic stabiliz ation program.

title: WILLIAM H. TRIPP, YACHT DESIGNER
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 14Wil liam H. Tripp, a yacht designer and marine engineer, died yes terday in Yale Memorial Hospi tal of injuries sustained in an automobile accident in North Haven Tuesday evening. He was 52 years old and lived in Harbor Acres, Port Washing ton, L. I.

title: Samuel Spewack,72 CoAuthor Of Broadway Comedies, Is Dead
description: Samuel Spewack, coauthor with his wife, Bella, of a long string of comedies for Broad way and films; including the hit musical Kiss Me, Kate, died yesterday of blood cancer at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Mrs. Rosenstiel Fined $500 On AttemptedPerjury Plea
description: Susan Rosenstiel, estranged wife of Lewis Rosenstiel, former chairman of Schenley Indus tries, pleaded guilty to at tempted thirddegree perjury yesterday in Manhattan Crim inal Court and was fined $500.

title: Notes on People
description: Lyndon B. Johnson, making a surprise appearance at re dedication ceremonies for the Dwight, D. Eisenhower Museum in Abilene, Kan., eulogized the late President as a towering figure in our American national past.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES ILLEGAL ALIENS BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) The House Education and Labor Commitee approved legis lation today that would fine or jail employers for knowingly hiring illegal aliens.

title: Physiologist at Vanderbilt Wins A Nobel for Hormone Research
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14Dr. Earl W. Sutherland Jr., a pro fessor of physiology at Vander bilt University, was awarded the 1971 Nobel Prize in Physi ology or Medicine today for his work in unraveling the secrets of how hormones work.

title: Retail Sales Up in Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 The Department of Commerce reported today that depart ment store sales for the latest week ended Oct. 9 was an esti mated $791million, an increase of 7 per cent above the $736 million sales for the corre sponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the latest, week were an estimated $7,721,000,000, an increase of 10 per cent above the $7,005, 000,000 sales for the same week last year.

title: Bridge:Declarer Must Make the Most Of Chance to Land Contract
description: Players sometimes lose their heads when faced by a bad trump break. A contract that appeared simple has sud denly become difficult, and they fail to make the most of their chances. This was the situation on the diagramed deal, played recently at the New YorkNew Jersey Re gional Championships.

title: Democrats at It Again
description: Nearly eighty years ago, Thomas B. Reed, the Repub lican czar of the House of Representatives, called his Democratic opponents a hopeless assortment of dis cordant differences. This week's row over the chair manship of the Credentials Committee for their next national convention shows that whether or not the Demo crats quite live up to that description, they are still there trying.

title: MARTIN MODIFIES MARKETTIE VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  William McChesney Martin Jr. indicated today that he had changed his mind, somewhat, about the essential structure of the more integrated securities markets of the future.

title: TEXAS RANGER KILLS MOBSTER OF 1930'S
description: FORT WORTH, Oct. 14 (AP) Ted Walters, a gangster once compared to his contempora ries Bonnie and Clyde, was shot to death today by a Texas Ranger.

title: For Elderly, Phase 2 Is Glint of Hope
description: President Nixon's Phase Two economic plan seems like a good idea to Louis Kanter, eight years into his retirement and increasingly buffeted by in flation.

title: LEGISLATOR HURT IN RELIEF PROTEST
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 14About 500 welfare recipients protest ing announced cuts in their monthly allotments swarmed through the corridors of the State Capitol for several hours today.

title: Harlem Photographer's View Shrinks
description: The world of James Van DerZee, which was once as large as all Harlem and as comfortable as the 12room brownstone in which he lived on Lenox Avenue, has Shrunk to one room.

title: Pregnant Teacher Upheld In Fight on Required Leave
description: Jack M. Sable, State Commis sioner of Human Rights, has ruled that a pregnant school teacher may continue working as long as she is medically certified as able to manage her duties.

title: EXKENNEDY AIDE CALLED BY INQUIRY
description: BOSTON, Oct. 14  A for mer legislative assistant to Senator Edward M. Kennedy) has been subpoenaed to appear here before the Federal grand jury investigating how the Pentagon papers reached the press.

title: Nets Open the Season Tonight And Barry Is Feeling No Pain
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 14Rick Barry, his collar length blond hair unmussed, raced up and down the court, cut for the basket and fought for rebounds today and the hurt look of the past few sea sons was absent from his face. It was the Nets final workout before their American Basket ball Association opener at Is land Garden tomorrow night against the Pitsburgh Condors.

title: The Conquest of Cancer
description: HOUSTONThe medical and scien tific community is sharply divided over proposed legislation seeking the con quest of cancer. There is no dispute about the need for new legislation to secure a much greater and more con certed mobilization of scientific per sonnel, research centers, strategy and money for a bolder assault against can cer. Both sides agree this is necessary. The controversy is based on the meth od to attain these goals.

title: Price Panel to Get Many Early Pleas By Key Industries
description: A number of industries, trapped between higher labor costs and frozen price levels, are likely to be camping on the doorstep of the Presi dential Price Commission when it begins considering applications for price in creases, probably next month.

title: Janet Baker Shows Mastery in Song
description: To Janet Baker's large and worshiping audience, Wednes day night in Philharmonic Hall, she could do no wrong; and, indeed, there was very little that she did do wrong. Miss Baker, as we all know by now, is the most charm ing and musical of recitalists. The British mezzo  soprano sings with unfailing taste, backed up by plenty of voice. Any concert of hers is a treat.

title: Davis Takes Lead In Semifinal Round Of $85,000 Bowling
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP)Dave Davis, a 29year old lefthander, took the lead tonight as the matchgame semifinals began in the $85,000 national championship of the Professional Bowlers Associa tion.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: In the 15 previous seasons of the Ivy League's round robin football competition, Brown is the only team that has never come away from a Dartmouth game as the winner.

title: RAIL TON FROM OFF FROM 70 WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week end ed Oct. 9 was considerably be low the volume in the corre sponding 1970 week. Inter city truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Pirates Beat Orioles, 40, and Gain 32 Lead in Series
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14Nel son Briles pitched the Pitts burgh Pirates to their third straight victory over the Balti more Orioles today with a stun ning twohitter that put the Pirates one game away from winning the 68th World Series.

title: NO. DECISION MADE ON PIER MEDIATOR
description: A Federal Mediation and Con. dilation Service spokesman said yesterday that no decision had been made yet on it, mediator for an International Longshore men's Association work stop page that has kept virtually all Atlantic and Gulf Coastports shut down for the last 14 days.

title: Rogers Stand Spurs Chile Unity Drive
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 14 The statement by Secretary of State William P. ogers yester day warning Chile against na tionalization of United States companies interest in large copper mines without compen sation touched off a national unity campaign here today.

title: Merck Income at Record
description: Merck & Co., Inc., reported yesterday record earnings and sales for the third quarter and nine months.

title: A STERN PROGRAM BY GRETE SULTAN
description: Grete Sultan, a pianist who plays what she likes and pays little heed to repertory fads or popular taste, came to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night with a program that was stern to say the least. It consisted of Schubert's Impromptu in F mi nor (Op. 142) and Moment Mu sical No. 6, Schoenberg's Kla viersttick (Op. 33A), Wolpe's Form for Piano (1959) and Bee thoven's 33 Variations on a Waltz by Diabelli (Op. 120).

title: CITY HELD CLOSE TO ITS DEBT LIMIT
description: The city is dangerously close to its statutory debt limit and may have to curtail $332million in construction projects, Con troller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

title: TEXTILE PARLEY OPENS IN TOKYO
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14 (Reuters) Japan and the United States opened Governmental negotia tions here today on an agree ment regulating Japanese tex itile exports to the American market.

title: BankAmerica Profit Rose 7.6% in the Third Quarter
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest banking institution, yesterday reported that earnings before securities transactions increased 7.6 per cent in the third quarter this year from the comparable period a year ago.

title: 5 Rockefeller Brothers Gather as Sister Opens a VestPocket. Park
description: Five Rockefeller brothers assembled on East 51st Street yesterday afternoon to watch their older Sister, Mrs. Jean Mauze, open a 6,360squarefoot vestpocket park.

title: Seoul to Sign Pact
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 14 CommerceIndustry Minister Lee Nak Sun announced today that a textiles quota agreement between the United States and South Korea would be initialed here tomorrow.

title: Stage: Yanni's Friends and Relations
description: Eugene Yanni's double bill at the Provincetown Play house called Friends and Relations, which opened last night, is brief but hard ly to the point. There are two dialogues, two sketchy sketches, that do not so much expose characters as traduce them. They are both quests for eccentricity rather than truth and they pose little more to the spectator than anecdotes of oddity.

title: F.D.A. Sets New Standards For Prescription Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct: 14 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration has set new safety and effectiveness standar& for fixedcombination prescription drugs, which make up: about 40. per cent of the kinds fie quently sold:

title: NIXON COURT LIST MAY BE ENLARGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14A high Government source said today that it was quite possi ble one orj two more names might be referred to the Amer icon Bar Association before President Nixon named his two nominees to the Supreme Court next week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 14 (AP) An Israeli military spokesman said today there had been no contact between Israeli and Syrian warplanes above the ceasefire line separating the two countries. He declined to say whether Israeli planes had crossed the line.

title: Pakistan Said to Have Received North Korean Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Sipsah, an 8,000ton Pakistani ship, has recently unloaded crates of North Korean small arms and ammunition at Ka rachi, well informed sources re ported here today.

title: TaxExempt Yields Drop;
description: Interest rates on taxexempt state and city bonds yesterday reached their lowest levels in more than two and a half years.

title: Passenger With a Licensed Gun Shoots 2 Assailants in Subway
description: A Yonkers businessman pulled out his pistol and wounded two men who held him up with a carving knife yesterday on an IRT subway train entering the Astor Place station.We've got twothirds of our force working at night, one transit detective said, so now the robbers work in the day time, and they pick on people who are old or alone.

title: About Pro Football
description: The Giants and Jets play at home on the same afternoon five times this season, begin ning Sunday. What's left of the Jets goes against Buffalo as favorites while Baltimore is a heavy choice over the Giants. On television, Chan nel 4 will show New England at Miami at 1 P.M., if there is no World Series game, and Cleve land at Cincinnati at 4 if there is baseball. On Chan nel 2 it will be Minnesota at Green Bay at 4. Here is a preview of all Na tional Football League games, with wonlosttied records in parentheses:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To save tax dollars, our branch li braries are now operating on reduced schedules. Undoubtedly, an amount at least equal to that saved will be spent on independent research reports, ad visory services and consultants fees. Wouldn't we be wise to keep our li braries open, fully staffed, suggesting to our city managers that they use these facilities to inform themselves directly on subjects which demand their attention? I think so.

title: Porter Sees Nixon Visits Disturbing Vietnam Reds
description: PARIS, Oct. 14William J. Porter, the United States Am bassador to the Paris peace talks, suggested today that the Vietnamese Communists were bothered by the forthcoming visits of President Nixon to Peking and Moscow.

title: Bernstein on Podium
description: Leonard Bernstein will con duct the opening concerts in the New York Philharmonic's 49th season of Young People's Concerts, which will begin Nov. 13. Mr. Bernstein will appear again on Dec. 18, and the series will be completed with Dean Dixon conducting on March 18 and Michael Tilson Thomas on April 12.

title: Rangers a Solid Club, Bolstered By Fairbairn's Return to Form
description: It was inevitable. Mrs. Mir lam Ellman, a longtime Ranger) watcher from Kings Point, L. watched her team go down to a 61 defeat to Boston Wednes day night and asked the old question, What's wrong with the Rangers?

title: Fischer, Petrosian Draw in 5th Game; Tied at 2 Each
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14  Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union drew after 38 moves of the fifth game of theirs match here today.

title: The Muse of Tragedy Is Still Waiting
description: WASHINGTONI looked for her again this year, and there she was, still waiting. A lifesize bronze statue, a lonely figure in the lofty expanse of the State Department's entrance hall in Washington. An inscription, on a small board propped against the hem of her metal skirts, informs the curi ous that she is Melpomene, the muse of tragedy, and that she was presented to the United States, on behalf of the Greek Government, in 1865, by Greek Ambassador Alexander Matsas. Also that she was placed there temporarily, until a better location could be found.

title: E.E.C. Wants a List
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (Reu ters)A senior official of the Common Market said today that it stands ready to discuss a reciprocal reduction of trade barriers with the United States.

title: 2 HERE CONVICTED OF HAVING BOMBS
description: A jury in Criminal Court here yesterday convicted two young men charged with possessing homemade bombs with intent to injure.

title: Sharp Battle Near Krek
description: SAIGON, Friday, Oct. 15. (AP) A South Vietnamese armored task force reportedly clashed with North Vietnamese troops yesterday in a brief but savage battle northwest of here just inside Cambodia.

title: INFLUENZA SHOTS HELD INEFFECTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14A Federal scientist charged to day that the flu shots that have been taken by millions of Americans annually are in effective and that the Govern mental agency that regulates these vaccines has refused to act against them.

title: The Day the O's Came Up With Nothing but O's in a World Series
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14  There Isn't much a baseball team can say after it has been held to two hits, and that's exactly what the Balti more Orioles had to say to day: not much.

title: Sports of The Times
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 14One day last winter Nelson Briles dropped in on Bing Devine, the St. Louis Cardinals general manager, to talk contract terms for 1971. It was the proper procedure, because Briles was pitching for the Car dinals and Bing was the man who controlled the purse strings. The phone rang and Bing excused himself to take the call in the next room.

title: Trotter, Racing Secretary, Is Dismissed by N.Y.R.A.
description: Thomas E. (Tommy) Trotter, racing secretary and handi capper for the New York Racing Association, affirmed yesterday that he had been dis missed from his position by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board of trustees of the organization.

title: Next Time She'll Do Away With Furniture
description: The next time around Jody Brad shaw, Bloomingdale's modernfurniture buyer, intends to build a house that requires no furniture.

title: MGM SETS MOVE IN LEISURE FIELD
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14In a dual action here today, Metro GoldwynMayer, Inc., announced the election of a new chair man of the board and a major diversification into the leisure field with the construction of a fleet of luxury cruise liners and a large resort hotel in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Neighbors of West Side Squatters Argue at Hearing
description: Neighbors of the West Side block that was occupied by 35 families of squatters squabbled before the Board of Estimate yesterday over the ad visability of putting a public housing project there.

title: Morris Bernstein, Who Set Up Beth Israel Institute, Dies at 88
description: Morris J. Bernstein, a philan thropist who endowed the in stitute of that name, at Beth Israel Medical Center that pi oneored in the methadone treatment for heroin addicts, died yesterday in the medical center. He was 88 years old and lived at 19 East 88th Street.

title: Penn Central Trustees to See ManhattanRealty Bids Today.
description: At noon today, John F. Har ding, clerk of the Federal Dis trict Court In Philadelphia, will open bids in the Penn Central Railroad's board room in Phil adelphia for what could be the biggest real estate deal in re cent history  22 parcels of property and buildings in mid town Manhattan, north of Grand Central Terminal.

title: Books of The Times
description: JAPAN'S IMPERIAL CONSPIRACY. By David Bergamini. 1,239 pages. Morrow. $14.95.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am at a loss to understand how your editorial concept of Confiscation in Chile [Oct. 2] differs greatly from what our own businessmen call down right confiscation right here at home in such diverse areas as:

title: MONETARY RESERVES OF BIG NATIONS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (Reu ters)The International Mone tary Fund reported today that total reserves of the 14 major nonCommunist nations rose to a record of $83,601,000,000 at the end of August from $65, 746,000,000 at the end of 1970.

title: Pirates 95 to Take Series
description: Las Vegas oddsilakerra last night established the Pittsburgh Pirates as 9.5 favorites to win the World Series. Baltimore is rated a 32 favorite in Satur day's game if Jim Palmer is the Oriole pitcher and Bob Moose the Pittsburgh starter.

title: Screen: Stember's '7254':Forum Offers Diffuse Saga of Young Man
description: The Film Forum rates credit for lending a helping hand to another aspiring, if unsung, moviemaker, by giving theatrical exposure to John Stember's first film, "7254," which will run at that intimate showcase for generally noncommercial fare today through Sunday. But good deeds and intentions aside, Mr. Stember, who is a fashion photographer, gives us a good deal less than meets the eye or the ear in this ill-defined and disconnected saga of a modern young man's angst in a world rent by wars and other dissensions.Mr. Stember, who produced and directed from his story and for his own company, SHA Productions, apparently was uncertain about just how he would project the problems endured by his vaguely limned but highly distraught hero.What we're exposed to is a series of vignettes photographed in color against mostly local backgrounds that give the impression of having been tossed in merely to indicate progressive anxieties.The anxieties appear to have basis in awesome facts. We see televised scenes indicating Hitler's holocausts, and others, up to and including Vietnam. Vietnam is what appears to have set off our troubled pettish hero, Alan Midgette. In disjointed scenes, he is oddly unresponsive to the pleas of his nude, beautiful but callow wife (Phoebe McAdams) to come to bed; to his loquacious, divorced mother (Ruth Ford) and her saccharine adoration, and to a vague, older friend (Paul Gallan), who, at one point, chases him desperately as he rows down a sylvan stream.Unfortunately, Mr. Midgette, a lank-haired, slightly delicate blond type sporting a flowing white scarf, is given to long, moody silences and few words that convey coherency or depth. In a reflective sequence shot for no real reason on a windswept beach through waving weeds, his Vietnam observations include, "Those are real babies crying, this war is a crime against nature."The dialogue, done in an ad lib, Andy Warhol technique, is not a crime against nature but it does little to put the principals in sharp focus. Nor does it do much for the meaning of the climax, which has our tortured Alan fleeing inexplicably from everyone at an airport.The title, "7254," a program note says, is the "Kodak designation for color negative film." Well, it wasn't used especially positively this time.

title: Regis Debray Talks to President Allende
description: These are excerpts from an interview with President Allende of Chile by Debray, a French Marxist. The full text appears in The Chilean Revo lutions Conversations with Allende.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Political and Security Com mittee 10:30 A.M. and P.M.

title: Teamster Chief Adamant
description: CHICAGO, Oct 14 (Reuters) The president of the team sters union, Frank E. Fitzsim mons, said today that he would not countenance any attempt to hold back pay hikes already negotiated by his union after expiration of the wageprice freeze.

title: Dock Union in Los Angeles Votes to Return to Work
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 (UPI)The longshoremen's un ion in the Long BeachLos Angeles port complex voted to day to return to work under an arbitrators ruling and in face of a Federal court order.

title: August Inventories Of Business Gained
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) The nation's business inventories, spurred by large buying by retailers, increased $675million in August, more than twice the July rise, the Commerce Department said to day.

title: Executive Changes
description: Ralph Weissman, for merly merchandise man ager of the women's readytowear apparel di vision of Gimbels New York area stores, has been named vice presi dent and general mer chandise manager of all soft goods divisions. He succeeds Paul A. Sala mane, who was recently named president of Gim bels New, York. Terry Kasoff has been appoint ed merchandise manager of all women's readyto wear apparel for the up stairs operations of Gim bels New York, in addi tion to continuing as merchandise manager of all women's sportswear and junior apparel. Mr. Weissman, who has spent his entire business career with Gimbels, joined the company in 1947 follow ing four years of service in the United States Navy. After holding various posts in the apparel divisions, he was successively store manager of Gimbels stores in Paramus, N.J., and Westchester County. He assumed his most recent post in 1963. Mr. Kasoff joined Gimbels as buyer of misses raincoats and casual coats in 1961 and held various other buyer posts until he became associate merchandise manager for sportswear in 1968. In 1969, ho was named a merchandise manager.

title: Sutherland's Work Opened New Field
description: Fifteen years ago Dr. Earl W. Sutherland Jr., who yester day won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine, discov ered cyclic AMP, a remarkable substance that appears to be present in minute quantities in every living cell. Only in recent years, however, have scientists begun to see the discovery as one of the major advances in man's understanding of life.

title: Sudan Names a Cabinet, Retaining Most Ministers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 (UPI)Maj. Gen. Gaafar al Nimeiry, the Sudan's first elected President, announced 26man Cabinet today and es tablished a oneparty system for his country.

title: U.S. Aides Oppose A Major Expansion In the Youth Corps
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  Members of the Senate Interior and Insular Affairs Committee sharply questioned today Ad ministration officials who op pose a major expansion of the Youth Conservation Corps.

title: House Unit Votes $2 Pay Minimum in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14A bill to increase the minimum wage to $2 an hour next Jan uary for some 35 million work ers was cleared by a House committee today and headed, toward a certain fight in thel House itself.

title: Journalism School to Honor Times, C.B.S., Mrs. Brown
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (UPI) The New York Times, the Columbia Broadcasting System and Helen Gurley Brown have been named to receive the annual Distinguished Achievement Awards of the University of Southern California School of Journalism.

title: Leonard M. Gold Marries Lois F. Meyer
description: Miss Lois Fredrica Meyer was married here yesterday evening to Leonard Marshall Gold. Rabbi Louis C. Gerstein performed the ceremony at the Carlyle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Just before I leave for England and home I. must say thank you for the greatest experience in my lifemy first trip to your city. I left England in the belief that New Yorkers have no time for the minor courtesies and pleasantries of life. What nonsense:.

title: Secret Satellite Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 14 (UPI)A secret satellite atop a Thor Burner 2A combination rocket was launched today from this coastal aerospace center. No other details were released by the Air Force.

title: Fund Leaders Reject Bid For SocialPolicy Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14Leaders of the mutual fund industry largely rejected today a proposal that they estab lish rules requiring mutual funds to take into account the social policies of corporations in which they invest share holders money.

title: Advertising:
description: Clinton E. Frank, Inc., Chi cago, made its first public stock offering yesterday, 150,000 shares at $15.50 a share. All shares came from 64 stockholders in the com pany. The new issue was completely sold, closing at $16.50 bid.

title: MRS. HARRIS VOWS TO FIGHT MISTRUST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  Mrs. Patricia Roberts Harris, elected yesterday as temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the 1972 Demo cratic National Convention, promised today to combat the continuing lack of trust among Democrats manifested in the fight over her selection.

title: Judy Heldman Is. Defeated In Dewar Cup 2d Round
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 14 (AP)Virginia Wade of Britain defeated Judy Heldman of New York, 64, 63, in to day's second round of the Dewar Cup tennis series.

title: Peru Oil Exploration Set
description: The Peruvian Governmental oil company, Petroperu, said yesterday at Lima, that the Tenneco Oil Company and tho Union Oil Company of Cali fornia plan to explore and de velop petroleum reserves in a 1 million hectare area of that country's northeastern jungle. The two companies reportedly have signed a 35year contract with Petroperu

title: 12thHour Drive Is Made For a Chicago Landmark
description: CHICAGOAnother vir tually hopeless campaign to preserve the Old Stock Ex change, one of the more famous examples of the Chi cago school of architecture, got under way here this week.

title: EYE INJURY IMPERILS BING'S PRO CAREER
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 14 (A)Dave Bing, star of the Detroit Pistons, has been hos pitalized for surgery to repair a detached retina in his right eye and his future as a pro fessional basketball player may be in jeopardy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The five hopeful faces in The Times of Oct. 6 seeking to succeed U Thant as Secretary General of the United Nations form an impressive array. All would appear qualified but the choice of any one of them will reflect the insidious EastWest, DevelopedDevel oping, etc., politics and infighting which will plague any choice.

title: Horsemen See Bonanza For Bookies in TV Plan
description: Monticello Raceway's televi sion contract with the Offtrack Betting Corporation was called everything from outrageous to monstrous yesterday during an emotional fourhour hearing be fore the State Harness Racing Commission.

title: Bus Terminal Habitues Get Own Coffeehouse
description: Mrs. Bertha Moore is 80 years old and lives alone in a $35amonth room on Tenth Avenue. About the only pastime she used to be able to afford was a trip to the Port Authority Bus Terminal waiting room to watch the world go by.

title: Dining at the Plaza After Its Face Lift
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and &Icor (four triangles to none).

title: Stars, Canadiens Tie, 11
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 14 (UPI)  Minnesota's Tom Reid scored on a penalty shot in the third period tonight to enable the Minnesota North Stars to gain a 11 tie with the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Kemp Malone, Chaucer Expert, At Johns Hopkins, Dies at 82
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) Dr. Kemp Malone, an authority on Chaucer and professor of English literature at Johns Hop kins University for 30 years, died yesterday at his country home in Eastport, Me., at the age of 82.

title: FRANKIE LAINE TIES OLD TO NEW
description: Can it really be 25 years, a quarter of a century, since Frankie Laine lifted himself from obscurity by singing That's My Desire in his tight, clipped, staccato phrases? For a fact, it is, and it is 20 years since he solidified that break through by opening up those staccato phrases to an exuber ant shout on Mule Train and Cry of the Wild Goose.

title: CANADIANS MOVE TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 14The Ca nadian Government announced tonight a program of increased Government spending of $375 million and temporary reduc tions in personal income taxes and the corporation tax to spur the lagging economy.

title: NEW SUEZ MOVES EXPECTED IN CAIRO
description: CAIRO, Oct. 14A stepup in diplomatic efforts toward a reopening of the Suez Canal was foreseen by diplomats here today following President Anwar elSadat's consultations in Moscow.

title: Rogers Voices Confidence on China Vote at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 14  Secretary of State William P: Rogers and other Administration officials today stressed their confidence that the campaign to save National ist China's seat the United Nations would succeed.

title: Hirohito, Home, Urges New Effort for Friendship
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14Immediate ly after his return home today, Emperor Hirohito told his people: I feel deeply that further efforts will be needed to achieve international friend ship and world peace.

title: PAN AM PLANNING FURTHER CUTBACKS
description: Pan American World Air ways, which in the last two years has cut back its payroll to about 37,000 from a peak of 41,000, is about to announce further cutbacks in its staff.

title: A Persian Night of Kings, Queens, Sheiks, Sultans and Diamonds
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Oct. 14 The Shah of Iran estab lished himself tonight as one of the world's great party givers. For sheer grandeur, his gala in a silk tent will be hard for any nation to sur pass.

title: New Hope for Black Colleges
description: The sixyear, $100million Ford Foundation program to improve the quality of ten private Negro colleges cannot solve the staggering problems of the nation's predominantly black campuses; but it does symbolize a new realism in dealing with an institutional disaster area. If the plan succeeds, a few frontrunners in that pitifully neglected sector of higher education could emerge into the integrated academic mainstream.

title: Lutz, Borowiak Are Victors, Asher Bows in Pro Tennis
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Oct. 14 (AP)Bob Lutz and Jeff Borowiak of Los Angeles scored upset victories today and Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., wasbeaten in sec ondround singles matches at the world professional tennis tournament.

title: Bayh Assistant Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) A key member of Senator Birch Bayh's staff, Robert Keefe, has resigned now that the Indiana Democat has de cided not to seek the Presi dential nomination. Mr. Keefe, 37 years old, had been the Senator's administrative As sistant since 1963.

title: ROGERS INDICATES U.S. MAY INCREASE ISRAELI ARMS AID
description: Secretary of State William P. Rogers deplored yesterday the new Soviet pledge to strengthen Egypt's military arsenal and said that the United States would have to carefully reconsider its mili tary commitments to Israel as a result.

title: Kissinger to Begin Trip To Peking on Saturday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP)  Henry A. Kissinger, the White House foreign policy expert, will leave for Peking on Saturday to make arrangements for President Nixon's journey to China.

title: EFFECTS OF MILK ON BLACKS NOTED
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 14 A Baltimore research team has found that more than half of black schoolchildren may be Unable to digest milk properly, raising serious questions about the usefulness of school milk programs to help raise the nu tritional status of blacks.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange registered their big gest loss in more than two months yesterday as the trading pace slowed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times editorial [Oct. 5] on Representative Richard H. Poff's deci sion to withdraw his name from con sideration as a Supreme Court nominee again brings to light the South's dilemma in having its citizens face rejection time and again for high national office.

title: BILLS COACH SEES AN UPTURN AHEAD Club Too Good to Go On Losing, Johnson Says
description: The Buffalo Bills, losers In their four league games this season, are too good a team to keep on losing, their coach, Harvey Johnson, said by phone from Buffalo yesterday.

title: Men in the News
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 14 Earl Wilbur Sutherland Jr., a gregarious and easygoing professor at Nashville's Van derbilt University, has known for several years that he was under consideration for a Nobel Prize. Nobody gave him inside information. He just knew that the experiments he has been conducting over the last 25 years have led scientists to one of the most promising new areas of research to be opened in many years. His name had been mentioned in the speculations preceding previous Nobel awards.

title: Albert M. Deichler Jr., 75, City Midday Club Manager
description: OCEAN CITY, N. J., Oct. 14 Albert M. Deichler Jr., who retired in 1964 after 40 years with the City Midday Club in New York, the last 22 as man ager, died yesterday in Shore Memorial Hospital, Somers Point. He was 75 years old and lived at 2000 Simpson Avenue.

title: Slaying Suspect Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted Vincent Hall, 28 years old, of Washington, D. C., yesterday on murder, robbery and other charges in the fatal shooting of Charles Butler, a bank guard, last May 3 in the $18,722 robbery of the Banker's Trust Company branch at 896 DeKalb Avenue, in Brooklyn.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES $844MILLION CUT FROM AID REQUEST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tentatively cut nearly $850million today from the Administration's $3.3bil lion foreign aid request.

title: Bell Tolls in Europe for Traditional Way of Teaching
description: LONDON, Oct. 14  In East London's Prior Weston Elemen tary School, the children are taught in mixedage groups, wandering freely in and out of rooms and calling teachers by their first names.

title: Teleprompter Witness Asserts He Took Bribe, Rejected One
description: A key witness testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he took a bribe from Irv ing B. Kahn, head of the Tele prompter Corporation, but re jected a higher offer from some one else.

title: CITYREPORT CITES LOSS OF HOUSING
description: More than onefifth of the office construction in midtown Manhattan between 1963 and 1971 required the demolition of housing, and more than one fourth of that now in the plan ning stage would do the same, according to a report by the City Planning Commission.

title: Guerrillas Said to Curb Relief
description: GENEVA, Oct. 4 (Reuters) East, Pakistani guerrillas have been frustrating efforts to dis tribute United Nations relief supplies throughout East Paki stan, Assistant Secretary Gen eral Paul Marc Henri said here today.

title: Five Get 10Year Sentences In West Virginia Vote Fraud
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 14 (AP)Five highranking Lo gan County Democrats were each sentenced today to 10 years in a Federal penitentiary for vote fraud conspiracy in their county's 1970 Democratic primary election.

title: Growth of Money Slows
description: The rate of growth in the nation's money supply has slowed to a crawl in recent weeks, the Federal Reserve Sys tem reported yesterday.

title: Environment Exhibits Mark Park Art Show
description: A fourday art show, with exhibits to illustrate how man helpfully and harmfully affects his environment, opened yesterday at Battery Park under the auspices of the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administra tion.

title: Four Nations Bitter
description: TOKYO, Oct. 14The Jap anese, Taiwanese, South Ko reans and the people of Hong Kong are together going to contribute to the campaign funds which President Nixon hopes will get him reelected next November.

title: Army to Release 65,000 by Next June 30 to Reduce Forces to 892,060
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14The Army announced today that it would release about 65,000 of ficers and enlisted men from active duty by June 30 to com ply with a Congressional order to cut its manpower to 892, 000 for the fiscal year 1972, the lowest level in 11 years.

title: Silver Futures Continue to Advance
description: After moving in a narrow range during the bulk of the trading, prices of silver futures closed higher again for the sec ond day on the Commodity Ex change here.

title: 40 Indictments Expected As Result of Knapp Data
description: At least 40 indictments involving city policemen are expected to be returned, beginning next month, by grand juries acting on information supplied by the Knapp Commission. The commission, headed by Whitman Knapp, a Wall Street lawyer, has been investigating allegations of police corruption in the city and is scheduled to begin hearings Monday.

title: Books of The Times
description: CHANCE AND NECESSITY. An Essay on the Natural Philosophy of Modern Biology By Jacques Monod. Translated from the French by Austryn Wainhouse. 198 pages. Knopf. $6.95.

title: Share Increase Is Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) The Marriott Corporation said today it has proposed to share holders that its authorized common stock be increased to 45 million from 30 million shares.

title: Publisher Sued by Author Of The Sensuous Woman
description: Joan Garrity, author of the best seller The Sensuous Wo man, sued Lyle Stuart, Inc., the book's publisher, yesterday for damages totaling more than $3million.

title: Stand Reaffirmed by Britain
description: BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 14 The Home Secretary, Reginald Maudling, reaffirmed in strong terms today the Government's commitment to keep Northern Ireland a part of Britain.

title: Crowds, Wagering Rise as 71 Curtain Falls at Westbury
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 14 Clearing the way for tomorrow night's start of a 53progfena season's finale at Yonkers Race way, Roosevelt Raceway closed its doors for 1971 tonight with 19,917 fans wagerhig $2,0624 120.

title: Traffic Increases
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation yesterday reported gains in revenues and earnings for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30. The company said the gains were attributable to traffic growth over the past 12 months.

title: More Problems Beset Ewbank
description: As if Weeb Ewbank didn't have enough trouble patching together the New York Jets for tomorrow's Shea Stadium open er, with the Buffalo Bills, two personal problems developed yesterday. He received a jury duty notice and a parkingtick et reminder.

title: Skil Sues Black & Decker In Civil Antitrust Action
description: The Skil Corporation yester day filed a civil antitrust suit in Federal District Court against the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company. Both concerns make portable power tools.

title: Market Place: Buying Antiques As Investmnets
description: Let's say you've had it with Wall Street and you're looking for a new, possibly safer place to put your money. Ask Sigmund Roth schild what to do and he may tell you to start haunting the suburban antique shops.

title: Education Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) President Nixon today pro claimed next week as Amer ican Education Week and called on fellow citizens to say some nice things about the nation's teachers to mark the event. I urge all my fellow Americans, he wrote, to make known dur ing this week their apprecia tion for the truly heroic efforts of our teachers and all our education professionals upon whose humane skills so much of our greatness as a people depends.

title: Pearl Primus Is Honored For Contribution to Culture
description: Pearl Primus, dancer, chore ographer and anthropologist, has been selected to receive the 1971 National Culture Through the Arts Award by the New York State Federation of Foreign Language Teachers.

title: Water Vapor Reported Found on Moon
description: Two scientists at Rice Uni versity said yesterday that geysers of water vapor had been detected erupting through cracks in the surface of the moon, providing the first evi dence that pools of water may lie beneath the otherwise dry and barren lunar landscape.

title: Bridge:Declarer's, Ability a Factor To Weigh in Penalty Double
description: Sizing up your opponents is an important part of the game. If you are considering a penalty double, consider the capacity of the declarer: will be get the most out of the dummy? Remember that the double will warn the de clarer to expect bad distribu tion.

title: 11 Boeing Planes Ordered
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15 (Reuters) All Nippon Airways said today that it had ordered 11 planes from the Boeing Company for delivery in the first half of 1972. The order is made up of eight 727200's and three 737's. The airline said it would bor row from the ExportImport Bank in Washington and pri vate United States banks, in cluding First National City, to finance the purchases.

title: Burger May Pick Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) President Nixon is consider ing asking Chief Justice Warren E. Burger to select a Federal threejudge panel to hear ap peals of wage and price board decisions in the postfreeze period, Congressional sources said today.

title: 78 Senators Ask Phantom Jets for Israel
description: WASHINGTON. Oct. 15 More than threequarters of the Senate joined in sponsoring a resolution today calling upon the Administration to resume the shipment of F4 Phantom fighterbombers to Israel with out further delay.

title: Wright Club Is Linked to Board Building
description: A building that was to have been leased by the city as headquarters for the controver sial District School Board 23 has been linked to the political club run by the board's chair man, Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright.

title: DOC PROTHRO DEAD; MANAGED PHILLIES
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 15 (UPI) James Thompson (Doc) Prothro, former manager of the Phila delphia Phillies and father of Tommy Prothro, coach of the Los Angeles Rams, died here last night. He was 78 years old.

title: Football Transactions
description: NEW YORKJunior Coffey, running hack, ??? on injured list.

title: Horsemen Propose Statewide OTB Unit
description: Rating groups have devel oped what they regard as a workable substitute for pres ent inadequate off track bet ting legielation, Jacques Wimpf heimer, the president of the Thoroughbred. Owners and Breeders Association, said last night.

title: 250 Calls to Channel 13 Protest Nudity in Movie
description: Channel 13 received more than 250 telephone calls Thurs day night protesting a film sequence showing closeups of a woman's breasts and human buttocks. The film sequence was part of what a station spokesman called a happen ing on Free Time, Chan nel 13's regular series.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I read on your Oct. 9 front page the announcement that the Commerce De partment has produced a new infla tion poster developed for display in stores as a weapon in the fight to control our cost of living.

title: The Urban Jungle
description: A businessman, responding to a holdup in broad day light, draws a pistol and fends off his attackers. Such an improbable incident smacks of the Wild West. Unfor tunately, the appalling episode was played out not a frontier town on a movie set but in the heart of what ought to be a civilized metropolis, and in the subway. It is added testimony that New York is degenerating into an urban jungle, and this devastating fact alone renders credible so implausible a shootout.

title: U.S. Wins Its 2d Court Case On Compliance With Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) The Federal Government said today that it had won its sec ond court case to gain compli ance with President Nixon's antiinflation program. The case involved a Portland, Ore., land lord who was ordered to stop charging increased rents.

title: ExSlave Said to Be 130 Is Dead in Mississippi
description: COLUMBIA, Miss., Oct. 15 (AP)A onetime slave, who helped bury the dead during the Civil War's siege of Vicksburg and estimated his age at 130, died today in a hospital here.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW PRICE RISE
description: On the promise of, a better export picture, grain and soy bean futures prices bounded up ward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Video Tape Copying Improved
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. believes it holds the key to mass production of tape for video cassettes. These devices, which are just being introduced, are expected to al low home view ers to supple ment regular channels and pro gram television to their own taste. The technology of Patent 3,613,102, which the company received this week, is described as duplicating magnetic video tapes 10 times as fast, less expensive ly and with better quality than conventional electronic methods. The copying proc ess was invented by Walter W. Gilbert, George R. Nacci and the late Nelson B. Daly in the central research de partment at Wilmington, Del.

title: Davis's 218 Average Earns Top Spot for Bowling Finals
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Oct. 15 (AP) Dave Davis of Miami main tained his lead tonight in his bid to win the $85,000 Profes sional Bowlers Association na tional championship for a record third time.

title: WELFARE CLIENTS GET AID OF COURT
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 15In the second day of protests at the State Capitol against scheduled cuts in welfare payments, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill stayed away from his office today because, his aides said, he efared that his presence might have pro voked an incident.

title: HECKSCHER ASKS FOR $94MILLION
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music leaks enough to present a water ballet. Wear and tear by one million patrons in the last 10 months necessitates in terior repairs in Carnegie Hall. The City Center's plumbing is bad and plaster falls on the performers. Lincoln Center says its cityowned plaza is a disgrace and should be re paired.

title: College Test Fees Raised; Government Investigating
description: The fee for the college board examinations that two million high school students will take in the new academic year has been rasied, and the increase is being investigated by the Federal Government to deter mine if it violates the Presi dent's wageprice freeze.

title: Henry Bullock, 75, Holder Of 29 Trapshooting Titles
description: VINELAND, N. J., Oct. 15 (AP)  Henry Bullock, a na tionally known trapshooter who won numerous competitive events in the sport, died Wednesday. He was 75 years old and lived in Milmay.

title: 4,650 Pulled Out of Combat
description: SAIGON, Oct. 15 (Reuters) The United States command today announced that 4,650 men had been withdrawn from combat. The cutback is the big gest since a reduction of 6,000 was announced last July 1. The current strength is just below 210,000 men.

title: The Toxic Americans
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y.According to Alexander Pope, the proper study of mankind is manand it looks like we're getting around to that these days in the pollution business. Significant concentrations of mercury are found in many freshwater fish, in predator type ocean fish, and now in this coun try significant (but not yet toxic) con centrations of mercury have been found in man the consumer. So mer cury Joins DDT metabolites on the list of toxic substances rising in man.

title: Trudeau Is Confident on the Economy
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 15Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the Government had embarked, on its program of employment incentives and tax cuts as a mark of confi dence in Canada's prospects for prosperity.

title: Furs  From Blazer to Cape
description: THE COLD WEATHER isn't far off and it's time to start thinking of furs. There are sheltering furs to warm and shield both the tender and the rugged female from winter chills. And there are sophisticated ones to glamorize an active night life and the holidays ahead. And more than ever this year there is a large selection of sporty, prac tical styles to wear day in and day out. This sea son, the styles vary from the timeless classics (high on fashion's score card)reefers; wrapped polo coats, and neat blazers on to sweeping capes of every conceivable length. Jackets loom as the red hot news, particularly the waistlength ones. And obviously on the increase is the influence of the Orient in sleek, sophisticated designs.

title: GULFSTREAM GETS PRIME RACE DATES
description: MIAMI, Oct. 15The Florida State Supreme Court literally turned the Florida horse racing picture upside down when it ruled today, in a 61 decision, that Gulfstream Park should have the lucrative middle racing dates this winter.

title: Mayor of Paterson Acts to Assist Puerto Ricans
description: PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 15 In a move to restore calm to the Puerto Rican community here, Mayor Arthur Dwyer of fered today to appoint a Spanishspeaking aide to his staff, to find more jobs for members of minority groups in municipal government and to keep abreast of those groups needs and aspirations.

title: Kennedy and Bayh Assail Nixon's Way of Filling Court Vacancies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  Two liberal Senate Demo crats attacked today President Nixon's way of going about filling Supreme Court vacan cies, with one calling it an in sult to the Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times recently published a letter by Dr. Basil L. Photos in which he sought to justify the Greek ter ritorial claim on the socalled North ern Epirus, or southern Albania. He tried to argue that the population of the territory in question is predomi nantly Greek, and he used as one of his arguments a secret population census by Mussolini in 1939, which showed 212,000 GreciOrthodox liv ing in the area under discussion.

title: STOCKS STUMBLE; VOLUMESTAYSLOW
description: Stock prices stumbled lower yesterday as Wall treet fun damentalists worried about the economy and chart readers worried about the gap.

title: TIMES COMPLETES MEMPHIS TV DEAL
description: The New York Times Com pany announced yesterday that it had completed the acquisi tion of Cowles Broadcasting Service, Inc., from Cowles Communications, Inc. Cowles Broadcasting Service is the licensee of a Memphis televi sion station, WRECTV.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15If the Baltimore Orioles had their backs to the wall today, they also had a chalked sign on the wall in their locker room, and it said: Remem ber the Mets. It took a year. Now we can do it in two days here.

title: IRANIAN CONSULATE ON COAST BLASTED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (UPI)An explosion heavily damaged the Iranian consulate here late last night. The police said that the type of explosive used had not been identified.

title: Stage: Sleuth Still Fun
description: Who cares whether the butler did it the second time around? It is a cruel test to see a mystery play twice almost tantamount to asking a kamikaze pilot to audition. Anthony Shaffer's Sleuth, which is just approaching its second year at the Music Box Theater survived the unfair test triumphantly.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times reports on Nixon's Phase Two, particularly the Oct. 8 news analysis by Max Frankel, bring to mind a concept from the Middle Ages: that of a just price, which was the price an artisan or seller was morally entitled to. Perhaps what we are evolving in this country is a parallel morality applicable to pricewage determination, based on community consensus, and expressed in terms fitting for a dynamic society: namely the concept of a just increase in price, or in wage rate.

title: MINNESOTA OPERA BEGINS STRONGLY
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 15As one of the most progressive ensembles in this country, the Center Opera of Minnesota has developed a reputation far be yond this city, where it was formed. That reputation was in creased when it was able to take some of its productions to other cities, including Nevi York, last summer. Anything does now has national interest.

title: WILL RASNER DEAD; AIDE OF BONN PARTY
description: BONN, Oct. 15Will Rasner, longtime parliamentary whip of the Opposition Christian Democratic party, died in a hospital here today. He was 51 years old.

title: Flights Into Kennedy Halted by Fog
description: Kennedy Airport was closed to incoming flights last night because of fog that caused, the diversion of planes to Montreal, Boston, Hartford, Philadelphia, Newark and La Guardia Airport.

title: Edward Neumann, Served With Prudential Insurance
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15  Edward M. Neumann, who retired as senior vice president and actu ary of the Prudential Insurance Company of Newark in 1956, died Wednesday in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital. He had un dergone openheart surgery.

title: BRAIN CHANGE TIED TO FOOD ADDITIVE
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 15An Israeli research team has found that a common food preserva tive, sodium nitrite, can pro duce seemingly permanent epi lepticlike changes in the brain activity of rats that regularly consume it in their diets.

title: HOLDING PLAN IS OUT FOR BURLINGTON LINE
description: Directors of Burlington Northern, Inc., said yesterday they have reviewed findings of a study authorized last July to determine the advisability of forming a holding company and have decided against taking such action.

title: 18 Seized at West Point Given Date to Leave U.S.
description: Eighteen LatinAmerican al fens seized at the United States Military Academy yesterday were given until Nov. 25 to leave the country voluntarily.

title: Men and Words in Prison
description: My first big surprise when I became president of International P.E.N. in 1965 was learning the number of writers in prisons in the free world. From time to time in my fouryear term, the East bloc ran just about neck and neck with the West. No sooner did a writer get sprung in one country than another was jailed some where else. The one slender ray of hope has been the defensiveness of regimes to the charge of jailing intel lectuals. By notifying the world of a writer's imprisonment, P.E.N., Amnesty International and the Authors League occasionally have saved lives of artists and writers who would otherwise have been destroyed, unnoticed and un remarked.

title: RAYMOND L. M'CANN.
description: FRANKLIN, N. J., Oct. 15 Raymond L. McCann, retired board chairman of the New Jersey Zinc Company, died yesterday in Franklin Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 16 Main Street.

title: 200 Tombs Inmates Are Treated to Classical Music
description: In the 11thfloor audito rium at the Tombs, the very room in which last year's riot of city prisoners began, two 22yearold musicians per formed a program of music by Brahms, Ravel and Ernst Bloch for some 200 inmates Thursday night.

title: RUDOLPH S.RAUCH, 79, INDUSTRIALIST, DIES
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 15 Rudolph S. Rauch, retired Phila delphia industrialist, died Wednesday night in Bryn Mawr Hospital after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in nearby Bryn Mawr.

title: Alexander's Welcomed at Roosevelt Field
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 15In 1967, Alexander's, Inc., opened a 320,000 squarefoot store opposite the Green Acres Shopping Center in Valley Stream, L. I., and was greeted by the owners of the center with a metal fence separating the new store from the center. The fence still remains.

title: Gunmen in Belfast Kill Two Policemen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 15Two policemen were killed by machinegun fire on a busy shopping street in down town Belfast this afternoon.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: John Cary in his letter published on Oct. 6 takes issue with those of us who were critical of the U.N. Sub commission on Prevention of Dis crimination and Protection of Minor ities for failing in August to consider whether there was a consistent pat tern of violations of human rights in East Pakistan, from whatever source.

title: AIDE TO MITCHELL QUITS OVER LINK TO TEXAS BANKER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15Will R. Wilson, the chief enforcer of Federal criminal laws, resigned tonight, saying he sought to spare embarrassment to the Nixon Administration because of his association with a Texas stock manipulator.

title: A BOMB BLAST RIPS BUILDING AT M.I.T
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 15 (Reuters)A bomb exploded early today in a Massachusetts Institute of Technology build ing housing the Goverment funded Center for International Studies.

title: Stars Beat Chaps, 116106
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 15 (AP)  The Utah Stars, down 7 points midway in the final quarter, outscored the Dallas Chaparrals in the final minutes tonight to capture a 116106 victory.

title: Investors Capital Trust Freezes Shares in Funds
description: GENEVA, Oct. 15Investors Capital Trust, an offshore mutual fund group that is mov ing its base of operations from Geneva to Monte Carlo, an nounced today that it had, suspended the sale and redemp tion of shares in its three prin cipal fundsthe Dollar Fund, the Fund of New York and the Real Estate Stock Fund.

title: Big Game in the Mild West
description: Champions of hunting are naturally given to expound ing on the alleged attributes of their pastimethe skill involved, the danger, the moment of truth, man against the lords of the jungle and other such bits and pieces of primitive mystique. But what is to be said for shooting a ranch buffalo herded fifty feet past one's waiting rifle barrel by an obliging zoo keeper, or his equivalent?

title: Jauits Offers a Loan Plan for Medical Students
description: Senator Jacob K. davits pro posed yesterday that the edu cation of medical students be totally supported on the basis of a loan against services by the Federal and state govern ments.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I regret that in the obituary for Walter C. Baker which appeared in The Times Sept. 26 circumstances did not permit the mention of Mr. Baker's long association with and generous and effective support of the Metra politan Museum of Art. Mr. Baker vas an exceptionally active trustee of the museum from 1948 as well as beinig a vice president of the museum from 1960 to 1971. He was also a collector of great discrimination and built tip a truly remarkable collection of clat sical antiquities and old master draw ings. His subtle connoisseurship In these two areas made him an invalti able member of the acquisitions com mittee.

title: NETS OVERCOME CONDORS, 115107
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 15The New York Nets have grown up. In overhauling the Pittsburgh. Condors, 115 107, tonight in their season opener at the Island Garden, they brought a, new image to the American Basketball As sociationdefense.

title: Robber, 27, Gets 20 Years
description: A 27yearold man who was convicted last Aug. 5 of taking part in the $25,000 holdup of a Bay Shore, L. I., bank last Dec. 21 was sentenced yester day to serve 20 years in prison and a fine of $15,000. The sen tence was imposed by Chief Judge Jacob Mishler in Federal Court in Brooklyn on Charles Lucchetti of West Islip, L. I. An assistant United States At torney, Emanuel Moore, had described Lucchetti as a sol dier in organized crime.

title: Sales Advance 8%
description: The Crown Zellerbach Cor poration reported gains in sales and earnings yesterday for the first time this year, with third quarter net income up 19 per cent and sales 8 per cent ahead of the period last year. C. R. Dahl, president said profit for the first nine months continued to lag behind the 1970 level.

title: LONG DISPUTE OVER
description: TOKYO, Oct. 15Negotiators for Japan and the United States initialed an agreement tonight to limit the flow of Japanese textiles to the American market.

title: JOE SULLIVAN DEAD; A JAZZ PIANIST, 61
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 (UPI)  Joe Sullivan, a jazz pianist who had played in the orchestras of Benny Goodman, Red Nichols and Bob Crosby, died Wednesday at San Fran cisco General Hospital. He was 61 years old.

title: CITYENFORCEMENT OF PRICES SOUGHT
description: Consumer Affairs Commis sioner Bess Myerson has direct ed her department's lawyers to determine whether the city can make violations of the Federal price freeze a violation of city consumer protection law punishable by a fine or im prisonment.

title: An Appraisal
description: The following article was written by Robert M. Solow, professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: Woman Believed Fire Victim Found to Have Died in Stabbing
description: The death of a pregnant 22 yearold housewife whose body was found Thursday after a tire in her Brooklyn apartment was listed as a homicide yes terday when an autopsy snowed she had been stabbed repeatedly.

title: Landmark Pharmacy Finally Closes Doors
description: Gilbert's Pharmacy, a small triangularshaped shop that opened on the corner of Grand and Henry Streets in 1884 and became as much of a landmark to the Lower East Side as the Henry Street Settlement around the corner, closed its doors to the public yesterday.

title: Yale's Freshman Eleven Routs Columbia by 270
description: Yale's freshman football team totaled 356 yards yesterday in defeating Columbia, 270, at Baker Field.

title: Tenant's Group Charts Fight Against City Rent Control Law
description: Tenant groups are organizing a campaign aimed at heading off any move by Federal offi cials to allow the city's rent control lawwith its attendant rent increasesto remain in effect during Phase Two of President Nixon's wage and price controls.

title: Brother Joseph of Manhattan College 64, Dead
description: Brother Brendan Joseph Brennan, director of admissions at Manhattan College from 1951 to 1967, died yesterday in his quarters at the college in. Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 64 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: According to her Sept. 21 letter, Mrs. Ann Rotenberg is under the mis guided impression that to be over 65 means to be a poor doctor and to be under 65 means to be a good one.

title: POLICE END WET ON STUDY LEAVES
description: The Police Department dis closed last night that it had re Taxed its oneyear limit on leaves, of absence for members to attend college and would now grant indefinite leaves, with the requirements of the prospective student supersed ing the staffing needs of the department.

title: Yonkers Man Gets 10 Years On LoanSharking Charge
description: John Tortora, a 38yearold Yonkers man who was Con victed on 16 counts of loan sharking last August, was sen tenced in Federal Court here yesterday to 10 years in prison.

title: Whites Undercut Norfolk Busing
description: NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 11A court,ordered plan to achieve racial balance in Norfolk's pub lic schools through largescale, crosstown busing of pupils has apparently been frustrated by what has been called Forres ter's Law.

title: Grand Jury Begins Hearing Testimony On Loan Program
description: District Attorney Frank S. Hogan has begun presenting evidence to a New York Coun ty grand jury on alleged crimes committed in connection with the Municipal Loan Program.

title: Palmer. Leads French Golf With 66
description: SAINTNOMLABRETECHE, France, Oct. 15Arnold Palmer, who remembers his every shot after a mind of golf, didn't have to tax his memory too much today at the Lancome Trophy invitation tourney here near Paris.

title: Bulls Beat Bullets, 10682
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) Bob Love scored 9 straight points early in the first quarter to spark the Chicago Bulls to a 10682 victor yover the Balti more Bullets tonight for their first triumph of the season.

title: Pirates Bank on Moose to End It Today
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 15Using a different starting pitcher for the sixth time in a row, the Pittsburgh Pirates will try to end the World Series by beat ing the Baltimore Orioles to morrow at 1 P.M.

title: MURPHY REMOVES DETECTIVE CHIEF PENDING INQUIRY
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy last night removed Albert A. Seedman as chief of detectives after receiving in formation from the Knapp Commission that he and three guests had received a free $83 meal from the New York Hilton Hotel.

title: Antiques: Cow Creamers
description: Cow creamers are the sort of small objects that offer many collectors just the right challenge.

title: COFFEY IS PLACED ON INJURED. LIST
description: Junior Coffey, an injury plagued, 6foot1inch, 215 pound running back, was Put on the injured reserve list by the New York Giants yesterday and, most likely, will Missthe remainder of the season.

title: Man in the News
description: A 70yearold economist was sound asleep in his greenshuttered, yellowed clapboard house in Cam bridge, Mass., yesterday morning at 6:15 when the telephone awakened him.

title: U. S. Businessmen Seeking invitations To Fait in: Canton
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 15 Thousands of businessmen from more than 30 countries, but apparently not including the United States, have entered China in the last few days for the opening today of the monthlong fall session of the semiannual Canton trade fair.

title: Ocean Hill School Board Told to Answer Charges
description: School Chancellor. Harvey B. Scribner, acting on an appeal brought by a coalition of Ocean HillBrownsville parent and copmunity groups, ordered the Community School Board of District 23 yesterday to respond to charges of illegalities and improprieties in the conduct of district affairs.

title: NEWISSUE MARKET IS MIXED FOR WEEK
description: The newissue market turned mixed this week as this seg ment of overthecounter ac tivity resisted the sharp down ward pressure experienced by the stock exchanges. Trading was light to moderate.

title: Reagan Meets: Thieu in Saigon And Defends OneMan Race
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15  Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, on a threehour vis it to South Vietnam today, de livered a messagd from Presi dent Nixon congratulating President Nguyen Van Thieu on his reelection.

title: Cornell Is Host to Harvard Today
description: Ed Marinero and his Cornell blockers are working better together this season than they did in the two previous, years. Yet they relish the opportunity to needle one another as Marinaro zeroes in on the premier rushing record in college football.

title: Gloom Pervades American Mining Congress as Executives Ponder Shrinking Markets
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 15 Weak minerals prices, foreign expropriations, sluggish mar kets, dwindling profit margins, rising costs of pollution abate ment, and an unfriendly legis lative atmosphere cast a pall over the American Mining Con gress, which closed a fourday convention and equipment show here yesterday.

title: Tax Aide Chosen to Head Enforcement of Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Edward F. Preston, Assistant Commissioner of Internal Rev enue for Administration, has been selected as the top en forcement officer for the sec ond phase of President Nixon's domestic economic program.

title: Strife Marks Yonkers Opening
description: YONKERS, Oct. 15Yonkers Raceway reopened this evening following a morning, afternoon and night of travail that must have tried the patience of near ly everyone connected with the harness racing track.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Time was when gambling was illegal in New York State because it was pub licly considered immoral. Governors crusaded against it and garnered many votes. Boys playing craps on the street were scattered by the cop and ca sinos for the rich were raided.

title: Overtime Cutback Causes Slight Drop In Car Production
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) Auto production in the United States dropped slightly because of a cutback in overtime work this week, the trade paper Automotive News reported yes terday.

title: CHANTILLY TAKES HARRISBURG PRIZE
description: HARRISBURG Pa., Oct 15  Sindy Paul's Chantilly had a close call but captured her 20th championship in, 24 Starts this year when, she was sent, to the top in the small pony compe tition at the opening session of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show tonight.

title: Mrs. Larkin, With a 163, Wins Senior Golf Crown
description: HAWORTH, N. J. Oct. 15 Mrs. Vincent de Paul Larkin, Nassau, won the 21st annual Women's Metropolitan, Golf As sociation senior championship today at the White Beeches Golf and Country, Club.

title: Cohn Is cquitted of All Charges in Bus Line Case
description: Roy M. Cohn was acquitted of all charges against him yes terday at the end of his fourth trial in Federal Court here.

title: Laser Is Stirring Imagination of Weapons Scientists
description: DENVERLasers, whose in tense spears of light have fired the imaginations of miltary weapons men for the last dec ade, are now finding increasing practical applicatons n defense technology.

title: Muskie, on a Tour of Newark, Is Shown Scars of 1967 Riots
description: NEWARK, Oct. 15  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson took Sena tor Edmund S. Muskie through parts of this city this morning, showing the Maine Democrat some of the urban scars that still persist from the riots that left 26 dead here in 1967.

title: 2 Big Bond Sales Planned; Treasury Sells Note Issue
description: In an unusual performance for a Friday, the money and capital markets bustled with activity yesterday as the Treas ury sold a $2billion note issue and California and Ford an nounced large bond sales.

title: NIXON AIDE SEES WAGEPRICE RISES PERMITTED SOON
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 15 A high official of the Nixon Administration indicated today that the Government expected to permit a large number of wage and price increases to take effect right after the end of the current freeze of prices and wages on Nov. 13.

title: Bradley Expected to Return To Knicks LineUp Tonight
description: Bill Bradley is expected to return to the, starting lineup tonight against the Los Angeles Lakers at Madison Square Garden as the New York Knicks attempt to atone for the sour game they played and lost to the Detroit Pistons in their season opener earlier this week.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Soviet Union returned its orbiting space laboratory, Sal yut, to earth last Sunday after nearly six months of space flight, Tass, the Soviet press agency, announced tonight. Tass said the unmanned Salyut entered the dense layers of the atmosphere over a preset area of the Pacific Ocean and ceased its existence.

title: The Talk of Auroville
description: AUROVILLE, India  We've found peace here, said Daniel Roucher, a 26 yearold compositor from France, sitting crosslegged on a mattress.

title: Safe Place':Work by Henry Jaglom Stars Tuesday Weld
description: "Tomorrow," says Susan (Tuesday Weld), who is sometimes called Noah, "is where the past is."Miss Weld, a lovely young woman with large, sad eyes and a few barely discernible freckles, is enchanting to watcha mysterious mixture of childlike grace and aggressive erotisicmbut when she opens Susan's mouth, what comes out sounds like an amalgam of Chinese fortune cookie and Sir James M. Barrie.Susan, as a child, used to fly, which, she tells us, always amused her brother. As an adult in today's New York City, she finds it impossible to cope, but not, you realize, just because she has to get around on buses and subways. Susan is simply too fine and pure and vulnerable for the world that encircles her. When she isn't escaping into fantasies inhabited by a kindly old park bench magician (played by Orson Welles with an uncertain Myron Cohen accent), she may worry over the telephone company's substitution of numbers for exchanges with such names as Gramercy, Plaza and Algonquin.Like Susan, Henry Jaglom's first feature film is a beautiful drag."A Safe Place," which was shown at the New York Film Festival last night, is the time-fractured story of Susan's journey to that undiscovered country from whose bourn no tourist returns, at least, not without a very special visa. Because Jaglom has chosen to use time, in his word, emotionallythrough constant cutting between present and past and futurethe narrative pretends to be a lot more complex than the rather superficial case history of a suicide it really is.Jaglom, who also wrote the original screenplay, looks like a young director attempting to walk without ever having learned to crawl, which is too bad because there are indications that he might crawl with a good deal of style. In fits and starts, "A Safe Place" is almost as moving as it wants to be, as when Jack Nicholson, an old lover out of Susan's past (who may or may not be her brother), (drops in at 4 A.M. to chat and make love, much to the comic impatience of a present lover.Jaglom, however, never lets a scene go by without splicing ing in fragments of memories of the past and fantasies of the future. The effect is not to construct a higher emotional reality, but to upstage any reality by attention-grabbing tricks. The director is, nevertheless, consistent, since this is the structural equivalent to his habit of photographing characters around and through foreground objects that tend to obscure ordinary sightlines.If "A Safe Place" reveals anything, it reveals the director's apparent adoration of his star, whom he studies in every possible light and color combination, and in every possible camera setup, often orchestrated with fine, corny songs out of the 1940's and 1950's on the order of Charles Trenet's "La Mer" and "Vous Qui Passe Sans Me Voir." Tuesday Weld in a tight close-up, accompanied by Trenet on the soundtrack, is not exactly a higher cinematic truth, but I can think of less stimulating combinations.Orson Welles has some terrible moments reading his fortune-cookies lines, but it's nice to see him alive and well, even if it's in Central Park trying, unsuccessfully, to make a bored llama disappear.
