All of the major performances are, in fact, attractive, limited only by the material. These include Nicholson, as well as two newcomers, Gwen Welles, who has a long odd, funny monologue about New York City mashers (which has no place in the movie except that it is odd and funny) and Philip Proctor, who plays Susan's square suitor with the sort of puzzled eyes and half smile that I associate with Nicholson, who may be setting the acting style for the 1970's.The film wil have its commercial opening here Oct. 29 at the new Columbia II Theater.

title: Dr. Henry J. Barrow, 79; Led Bronx Medical. Group

Ross Franklin, had been ac cused by a fellow officer of dereliction of duty by failing to report alleged war crimes by merican and allied service men two years ago.

The Dean, a British subject; is charged with sup porting terrorist activities aimed at the violent overthroW of the South African Government.

title: NORMAN STEENROD, EXPERT ON TOPOLOGY
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 15 Dr. Norman E. Steenrod, Henry Burchard Fine Professor of Mathematics at Princeton Uni versity and an expert in topology, a branch of applied mathematics, died yesterday at Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 61 years old and lived at 167 Hartley Avenue.

title: Banking Profits Rise
description: The First Pennsylvania Cor poration, the parent company of the First Pennsylvania Bank ing and Trust Company, Phila delphia's largest bank, reported yesterday operating earnings for the third quarter of $8.5 million, or 71 cents a share, up 11 per cent from the $7.7 million, or 64 cents, earned in 1970.

title: U.S. is Now Listed to Speak First Day of China Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15The United States, origi nally listed as the ninth speak er in the China debate opening Monday, moved up today to the third spot, immediately behind Albania and Algeria  the principal advocates of expel ling the Chinese Nationalists. The United States delegate, George Bush, is now in position to address the Assembly on the opening day of the debate.

title: Texas Oil Output Slated in November Shows Dip Again
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 15A rise in foreign stocks of crude oil was listed today by Texas Railroad Commission chairman Byron Tunnell as a reason for another cut in Texas oil pro duction, ordered to take effect Nov. 1.

title: Queens to Get Art
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which has added art to the Bronx County Courthouse, will hang some of its paintings, etch ings and prints in the Queens Borough Hall. Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes said yesterday that Thomas P. F. Hoving, head of the museum, agreed to this after meeting with him and touring the hall.

title: People of China: A Glimpse at Their Everyday Life, at Work and at Play
description: These views of mainland China and its people are such as might be glimpsed by any visitor, perhaps Henry A. Kissinger, the White House security adviser, who leaves for Peking today, if he should stroll the byways of city and countryside away from official functions and organized dem onstrations. During a recent tour, Marc Riboud, French photographer, found these ordinary Chinese at work, on streets and country roads, romancing and having fun.

title: Man Stabbed Going To 42d St, Station; Suspect, 19, Is Shot
description: The Transit Authority calls it Stairwell M11. It is on the southwest corner of 43d Street and Eighth Avenue, and in the postmidnight hours it may be the most deserted flight of stairs leading into the busy 42d Street IND subway station.

title: Art: Two Uses of the Shaped Canvas
description: The shaped canvas has as sumed a great many forms in the painting of the last dec ade. Abstractionists have cre ated shapes especially de signed to convey the con creteness of the painting as a physical object in itself, and thus diminish our sense of the picture space as an il lusionistic image of some thing beyond the boundaries of the actual painting. Neo dadaists and pop artists have devised irregular shapes as a function of their own special iconography. Minimalists have used the shaped can vas to create hybrid forms of pictorial sculpture. And so wt. The use has varied, but the device itself is now firm ly established.

title: Upon Accepts Tigers Post
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) The Detroit Tigers hired Johnny Lipton, the former elevelatid Indians manager, today to man age their Toledo farm cltrb. Lip ton succeeds Mike Roarke as manager of the International League team.

title: Coed Sues Vassar; Blames Marijuana For Flunking Out

description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15One of the most mo mentous issues to come before the United Nationsthe repre sentation of Chinamay be de cided by a single rollcall vote. Or it may take some 20 votes.

description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15 The Soviet Union said today that a Major program of urban ex pansion was under way in a northern city that was recently identified as a nuclearsub marine center in a Washington dispatch on a reported build up of Soviet strategic weapons.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15 (AP)The United States command announced today that an unarmed American plane was fired Upon from the ground yesterday while on a recon naissance mission over North Vietnam 95 miles north of the demilitarized zone.

title: Merger News
description: A battle for control of N. V. Rubberfabrick Vredestein, a large Netherlands tire and rubber maker, ended yesterday with a settlement in which the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will sell its shares in Vredestein to the B. F. Good rich Company for an undis closed amount. The conflict began in April, 1970, when Goodyear announced a tender offer for Vredestein's shares and B. F. Goodrich countered by increasing its investment in the Netherlands concern. Good rich has long had an interest in a subsidiary of Vredestein. As a result, t:.e two American companies control most of Vredestein's capital stock but, after litigation, neither h s been able to exercise voting control.

title: LunchHour Special: Serenade By Youthful Bulgarian Chorus
description: There was an unscheduled lunchhour special yesterday at the 7 Arts Coffee Shop on Am sterdam Avenue: It was the Bulgarian Children's Chorus, 40 youthful voices accompanying the veal cutlet and tomato sauce.

title: House Rules Unit Bars Vote On Desegregation Measure

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) Hyman Kaitz, a career civil servant, was appointed today to head the new Office of Cur rent Employment Analysis Critics said that the move was White House spurning of Harold Goldstein, the man who had handled the Administra tion's unemployment reports.

description: TOKYO, Oct. 15The Japa nese have a proverb, Nama byoho wa okizu no moto, which means Crude tactics cause great injuries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As conveyed in C. Gerald Fraser's Oct. 8 news story on Roy Innis and the CORE convention, Mr. Innis ideas and concepts in the field of race are a briar patch of confusion. One has to assume that his observations, diag noses and prescriptions are put forth seriously, although in this era of the pervasive puton, one can never be sure. Comment on them is an ines capable duty, since failure to do so might enlarge the ranks of the gulli ble who reason that, if a statement is not, publicly refuted, it must be true.

description: The Supreme Court has removed any lingering doubt that the Government has a constitutional right to prohibit all strikes by public employes.

title: The Common Denominator
description: A Senate Foreign Relations Committee vote to limit economic and military assistance to Cambodia to $250 million and to put a ceiling of 200 on the number of American civilian and military personnel assigned to that country represents a timid attempt to prevent Cambodia from going the way of Vietnamtoo timid, in our view. Like the $350million limit on spending in Laos already voted by the full Senate, the proposed Cambodian restriction is too generous to check effec tively a deepening United States involvement in what formerly, were fringe areas of the Indochina conflict.

description: WONDERLAND. By Joyce Carol Oates. 512 pages. Vanguard. $7.95.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)  Senator George Mc Govern today suggested series of monthly debates to give candidates for the Democratic Presidential nom ination more public ex posure.

title: U.S. Tells Chile Seizures Could Endanger Aid to Needy Countries
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15  United States officials called on Chile today either to honor her international obligations or risk what they termed the ripple effect of mounting United States resistance to helping underdeveloped coun tries.

title: New Statement On the Freeze
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 Following is Policy State ment No 29 issued by the President's Cost of Living Council on the latest rulings relative to the 90day freeze on wages and prices:

title: Russian AvantGarde Art Exhibited
description: It is not difficult to think of the Russian Revolution in art as a direct outgrowth of the political revolution of 1917. The political revolu tym essentially constituted, however, the official recog nition, consolidation and even glorifh.ation of the revolu tionary spirit in art that had been part of the esthetic consciousness in Russia for several years before the polit ical upheaval.

title: Abel Gance's Movie on Napoleon
description: Abel Gance's "Bonaparte and the Revolution," which, to the credit of the New York Film Festival, played Thursday night in the Vivian Beaumont Theater, is a new movie that goes back more than 40 years. It began as one part of a six-part study of Napoleon, had its premier at the Paris Opera in 1927, but was scarcely seen after that except in mutilated and much diminished versions. Gance himself has accused Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer of buying the film and then virtually suppressing it, so that its expensive wide-screen, three-camera technique (a precursor to Cinerama) should not endanger the profits of an industry that already felt itself threatened by the coming of sound.The other five parts of "Napoleon" were never made, but in the nineteen-thirties, Gance prepared a sound version, valuable at the very least for preserving the voice of Antonin Artaud, who played Marat. The current film draws upon both versions, though it uses a screen of conventional size, rearranges material, adds some new footage, including a fine introduction by Gance at 82, adds music (Beethoven's 5th Symphony; the original score was by Arthur Honegger) and provides the silent action with some voice-over narration and much dialogue. The post-synchronizing of the dialogue, credited to Claude Pessis, is spectacularly successful, and it may rank with Polyvision and the triptych screen (and color and, on a lost reel, 3-D) among the technical marvels of this all but legendary movie.Gance himself is now part of the legend. He is as old as the art he serves, a master unknown to most audiences, and his romantic study of a personal history has become his own history, wonderfully vindicated in a work that, like the man, could scarcely ever have seemed much younger. For all its four and one-half hours, its multitude of effects, its elaborate visual rhetoric, its willingness to make every point more than once, "Bonaparte and the Revolution" moves with a vitality that any film made yesterday might envy and that almost none can equal.The movie deals with Napoleon through his young manhood, roughly from the beginnings of his military career through his marriage to Josephine de Beauharnais (Gina Manes) and the Italian campaign of 1796. But considerable attention is given to the Revolution, to the meetings of the Convention and to the Reign of Terror, and the film's most remarkable portraits surely are those of Marat (Artaud), Danton (Alexandre Koubitsky), Saint-Just (Gance himself) and above all an almost expressionless and coldly terrifying Robespierre (Van Daele).The actual relation of Bonaparte to the Revolution is often tenuous, though in making that relation Gance achieves some of his most startling effects. Napoleon is seen on the one hand as destined to spread the spirit of the Revolution over the lands he is to conquer, and on the other, as embodying a principle of disciplined will that seems exactly counter to the actual spirit of the Revolution as the film unflatteringly presents it.But for all his magnificent scope, Gance is more interesting with personal stories than with national destiny, and his Napoleon (Albert Dieudonne) is a figure of subtle and, in context, rather surprising complexity. Thus the great purple passages in "Bonaparte and the Revolution"  for example, the famous intercutting between Napoleon in an open boat, the tricolor for his sail, tempest-tossed in his 1792 escape from Corsica; and the tempestuous Convention, photographed as if by a wave-borne camera  seem grand, but not as grand as the rich and sophisticated interplay of light and shadow, dream and reality, character and event, in the technically less imposing courtship and marriage of Napoleon and Josephine.However, there is no point at which "Bonaparte and the Revolution" is less than a wonderful old movie and a marvelous new one. And in this excellently titled version I hope it remains permanently available for American audiences.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES NEW CANCER BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15A House subcommittee on public health and environment has unanimously approved a cancer research bill that differs sub stantially from one passed by the Senate last spring and lacks one provision considered important by the White House.

title: Harvard Economist Wins Nobel Prize
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 15Prof. Simon Kuznets, the 70yearold American economist and statis tician who developed the con cept of using the gross national product as a measure of a na tion's economic growth, won the Alfred Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science to day.

title: Palisades Park: Hopes Receding
description: FORT LEE, N. J.They won't be coming to the amusement park here next year to ride the roller coaster or get cool in the waves of the poolunless someone comes up with $1million in rent.

title: Ford Lists Rises in Prices For Several 1972 Models
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP)The Ford Motor Company an nounced today federally ap proved price increases on sev eral 1972 models to reflect equipment change on domestic models and the 6.5 per cent surcharge on imported cars and parts.

title: Safety Unit Issues Alert For 8 Million Chevrolets
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15The De partment of Transportation to day warned owners of about eight million 19651969 Chev roletproduced automobiles that there is a potential risk in driving their cars.

title: Customs Inspectors Credit Union Short $500,000
description: The Custom Inspectors Fed eral Credit Union is missing at least $500,000, and a warrant has been issued for the arrest of one of its managers.

title: Miss Fromhold Wed To Timothy Driscoll
description: HAVERTOWN, Pa., Oct. 15 In St. Denis Roman Cath olic Church here this eve ning Miss Patricia Fromhold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred B. Fromhold of Ard more, was married to Timo thy Warren Driscoll, son of Arthur Driscoll of Morris Plains, N. J., and the late Mrs. Driscoll. The Rev. Joseph A. Ward performed the ceremony.

title: Neighbors Go Visiting in Iran's Tent City
description: PERSEPOLIS, Iran, Oct. 15 While nobody in the imperial encampment has troubled his neighbor for a cup of sugar, there's a smalltown atmos phere to the Shah of Iran's luxurious tent city, even though all the residents are either kings, grand dukes, princes, sultans, sheiks or heads of state.

title: FLORA AUSTIN BORG, JERSEY NEWSWOMAN
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Oct. 15 Mrs. Flora Austin Borg, a vice president and a director of The Bergen Evening Record Corporation, publisher of The Record, died yesterday in Hackensack Hospital after a brief illness. She was 62 years old and lived at 655 Summit Avenue.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 15It is only two or three years since the British were using heroic measures to keep the value of the pound up. Now they ars doing their best to hold it down. To ward off eager buyers of pounds, officials are talking gloomily about sterling's prospects and have even put up barriers against the phenomenon for which they used to yearn, foreign money entering Britain.

title: Music: On Hiroshima
description: Now comes another Hiro shima piece of musicLuigi Nono's Sul ponte di Hiro shima (canti di vita e d'amore)to join Pender ecki's famous threnody on the unhappy city. It was played Thursday night by the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Michael Gielen.

title: Properly Labeled Detergents Are Backed as Safe
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15The director of the Food and Drug Administration's Product Safety Bureau said today that any laundry detergent on the mar ket, properly labeled would be acceptable for use in house holds.

title: MAJOR CONCERNS SETTING LAYOFFS
description: The Western Electric Com pany, the Caterpillar Tractor Company and the RCA Corpo ration added yesterday some 2,150 workers to the ranks of the unemployed.

title: Howard A. Austin Dies at 55; ExSenior Aide at Prudential
description: Howard A. Austin, former senior vice president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died of cancer Thursday at Doctors Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived at 1158 Fifth Avenue and Point o Woods, L. I.

title: Washington Hails Accord As Curb on Protectionism
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 The Nixon Administration to day viewed the textile agree ment reached in Tokyo as re moving a major irritant in United StatesJapanese rela Lions and preventing a protec tionist sentiment from taking hold in this country.

title: President and Graham Switch Roles in Day for Evangelist
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 15 President Nixon flew here this afternoon to honor a personal friend and the nation's most widely known evangelist on Billy Graham Day  and be fore the ceremonies had ended the President and the preacher had seemingly reversed roles.

title: RONAN OPTIMISTIC ON 30CENT FARE
description: Top city officials and Dr. Wilr Liam J. Ronan expressed op timism about saving the 30cent transit fare after meeting for three hours yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel.

title: SAM SNEAD CARDS 65 TO LEAD BY 3 0N 132
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 15 (AP) Fiftynineyearold Sam Snead shot a fiveunderpar 65 today for a 36hole total of 132 and a threestroke lead in the $100,000 National Professional Golfers Association club pro championship.

title: Luna 19 to Remain in Orbit And Will Not Land on Moon
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15The So viet Union indicated today that its latest mooncraft, Luna 19, in orbit around the moon since Oct. 3, would continue to circle the moon and not land.

title: HOUSTON DOWNS VILLANOVA, 429
description: HOUSTON, Oct 15 (UPI) Gary Mullins, the quarterback, scored the first two times he carried the ball and completed his first, pass, for a touchdown tonight to lead the University of Houston to a 429 victory over Villanova.

title: NIXON ASKED TO DROP SCHOOL LUNCH CURBS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15A bipartisan group of 59 Senators urged President Nixon today to overturn what they called un lawful and arbitrary new limi tations on subsidized school lunches for needy children.

title: WILLIAM F. HALL, 87, OF HALLMARK CARDS
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. Oct. 15 William Finch Hall, retired vice president and treasurer of Hallmark Cards, Inc., and brother of Joyce C. Hall, the founder, died yesterday after brief illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Erhard Opposes Retaliation By Europe on Surcharge
description: Ludwig Erhard, former chan cellor of West Germany, said here yesterday he hoped that European nations would not retaliate against the 10 per cent United States import sur charge because it would lead to the disintegration of inter national commerce.

title: F. C.C. OVERRULES 2 GIANT CARRIERS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) The Federal Communications Commission today authorized Interdata Communications, Inc., to construct a microwave com moncarrier service transmitting data, voice, and other special ized communications between New York City and Washing ton, D. C.

title: PACTS WELCOMED BY INDUSTRY HERE
description: Textile manufacturers here, while commending President Nixon's success in bringing about import quotas for non cotton textiles, were somewhat reserved in comments yesterday about the agreements reached with Japan and other textile exporters of the Far East.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DECLINE FURTHER
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday in light trading.

title: Executive Changes
description: Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the Pres ident's Council of Economic Advisers during the administration of Presidents Kennedy and John son, has been elected a director of Shelter Corpo ration of America, Inc. Mr. Heller is presently re gents professor of economics at the University of Minnesota. The company also elected Henry T. McKnight of Minneapolis a director.

title: Medina Leaves Army; Feels Like a Civilian
description: FORT McPHERSON, Oct. 15 (AP)  Capt. Ernest L. Medina, who was acquitted of charges in connection with the killing of South Viet namese civilians in 1968 at Mylai, was given an honor able discharge from the Army today.

title: Harlem's History Through a Camera
description: As James Van DerZee's camera saw Harlem from the teens through the 1940's, it was a pretty nifty place to live. Crime, dope and poverty Were scarcely visible, pro test and militancy were po lite, the streets were clean and, above all, bourgeois as piration prevailed.

title: CANADA INCREASES HER TRADE SURPLUS
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 15 (Canadian Press)Canada had a commod ity trade surplus of exports over imports amounting to $184 million in September, bringing the cumulative surplus for the year to $1.81billion, Statistics Canada reported to day. The figures were down only slightly from a September surplus of $189.3million last year, when theninemonth to tal ran to $1.96billion.

title: Notes on People
description: It wasn't quite Persepolis, but Mayor Lindsay did enter tain an unusual number of foreign dignitaries at City Hall yesterday. Two of the guests came bearing gifts, and two received fourinch gold keys to the city in re turn. But most were treated only to coffee and cake in the Mayor's office. The gold key recipients were Peter Malben Studd, Lord Mayor of Lon don, and Lieut. Cmdr. Cristo bal Colon, a descendant of Christopher Columbus. The Commander gave the Mayor a copy of a letter sent to Spain by Columbus after he discovered the New World. The other visitors were re cently appointed Consuls General: David Rivlin of Is rael, who gave the Mayor a pictorial history of the Bible; Adolfo Martin Gamero of Spain; John Ford of Britain; Inguan Kim of South Korea; Najmul Sagib Khan of Paki stan; Luis Leigue of Bolivia and, from Iran, Moshen Gou darzi, whose absence from his country's 2,500th birth day party was unexplained.

title: Lakers Rout Pistons, 132103
description: DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) The Los Angeles Lakers made Bill Sharman's debut as coach a winning one as they surged to a 132103 victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: ORTHODOX LEADER HITS IMMORALITY
description: A leading Orthodox rabbi who said he could no longer remain silent in the face of growing immorality that threatened to destroy tradi tional family life assailed the entertainment industry yester day.

title: Weekend at Camp David
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI)  President Nixon arrived at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., from Charlotte at 6:14 P.M. and then flew by helicopter to Camp David, Md., to spend the weekend.

title: WARRIORS DEFEAT CELTICS BY 9775
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP)Jeff Mullins scored 28 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 9775 victory over the Boston Celtics tonight in a National Basketball Association season opener for both teams.

title: Holdups a Way of Life to IRT Clerk
description: How do I get to the GG train? the harassedlooking man asked.

title: Rescuing Elaborate Objets From the Ravages of Time
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I.  Six years ago Mrs. Anita Flack bert, rummaging around an antiques store here, found a battered, 19thcentury French credence. It was in laid with tortoise shell and bronze scrollwork, in imita tion of the style to which Andre Charles Boulle, Louis XIV's favorite cabinetmaker, lent his name, and Mrs. Flackbert saw in that worn piece of furniture a chance to make something as beauti ful as it once was.boiling glue, a special formu la she concocted after all other adhesives had failed. But, you must have pa tience and a great deal of imagination. It all comes from an appreciation for Boulle's beauty, and the fact, too, that It could perhaps never be made again.

title: ANNIE L. POWERS
description: Annie L. Powers, who had been a teacher at Public School 147, Broadway and Henry Street, for more than 50 years, died yesterday at the Hudson View Nursing Home in Yonkers. She was 86 years old.

title: Shadow Brook Captures Gwathmey Steeplechase by 5 Lengths at Beth ont
description: The task of carrying 163 pounds over the steeplechase Course of three miles was hardly a difficult one for Stephen Clark's Shadow Brook at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: SQUIRES SUBDUE COUGARS, 118114
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Oct. 15 (AP)  The Virginia Squires, sparked by Charlie Scott, rallied to defeat the Carolina Cougars, 118114, in the American Bas ketball Association season opener for both teams tonight.

title: Ethnic Leaders Attempt a Coalition
description: Bayard Rustin, the black leader, had a homemade Italian meal served on paper plates in Mrs. Mary Sansone's finished basement in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Thursday night.

title: KOSYGIN PRAISES PRESIDENT ON TRIP
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 15Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, asserting that SovietAmerican coopera tion is essential for world peace, today welcomed Presi dent Nixon's forthcoming visit to Moscow and said that other countries need not fear that the two nations were ganging up to dictate their will to all the others.

title: Ice Rink Closed for Repair
description: The Lasker Memorial ice skating rink in Central Park will be closed for repairs start ing Monday for about three weeks. The Parks Administra tion said water had seeped under concrete slabs. It also announced that the indoor rink in Flushing MeadowsCorona Park in Queens would open Oct. 23.

title: Textile Agreement
description: The agreement bludgeoned out of the Japanese and other Asian synthetic textile and wool exporters yester day represents a victory on the part of President Nixon and the Southern textile industry, but at a cost to American longrange international political and economic interests that has yet to be fully calculated.

title: The New Economic Monarchy
description: WASHINGTON  There are myriad inequities in the executive's interpre tation of the Economic Stabilization Act of 1970. Decisions are handed down from that branch of Government comparable to those of eighteenthcen tury kings. The resemblance is more striking in that the crown ruled invari ably in the favor of the great mer chants and other wealthy businessmen.

title: Oil Quotas Attacked
description: BOSTON, Oct. 15 (AP)  A twoday United States Senate subcommittee hearing on the mandatory oilimportquota system concluded today with calls for a consumer revolt and elimination of the quota.

title: Movies
description: IT was a restless night I lay awake pondering life's crucial questions. If man stops his sneeze half way through, Is he entitled to the full blessing? Did Presi dent Millard Fillmore really install the first bathtub in the White House? Does Raquel Welch jog for her health? Things like that. But I couldn't get back to sleep.

title: Art
description: T HE National Endowment for the Arts has taken over the Cor coran Gallery in Washington un til November 14 with an exhibi tion called Wilderness and the pre sentation of a project by which the Government of the United States will enlighten the nation from sea to polluted sea with a mobile art museum. If you can't quite absorb that sentence, don't worry. The whole business is very com plicated.

title: For Young Readers
description: But for its fairy tale para phernalia, Alone in the Wild Forest could well pass as an apocryphal book of the Old Testament. It is spare, severe, oddly humorless. It celebrates the justice of a very angry and uncompromising God. The mechanisms of retribution ex tend backwards and forwards: past lives, after lives are reck oned. Each character drags be hind him, as one might a gan grenous trail, the mass of sins accumulated in previous incar nations. Singer teaches an austere lesson; moments of fan tasy and magic do little to mitigate this austerity. There is, doubtless, a good deal of truth in the lesson, but it makes for an unpalatable sort of children's book.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I have been thinking over your article on the hard pressed private club (Sept. 26). To me, it's an alarming situation. Not because of the pressure on my clubs, or anyone else's, but because of the ominous implications for our liberty.

title: Miss Weinberg, William Hesse Plan Marriage
description: Miss Eileen Spinoza Wein berg, a junior at Finch Col lege, and William Blass Hesse, who is in his second year at Brooklyn Law School, plan to be married.

title: The Last Word: H. Bustos Domecq on the New Architecture
description: Oddly enough, the term functional architecture, which people in the profession hardly use anymore without a certain pious smile, has not lost its hold over the public at large hopes of clarifying the concept, the present essay shall with minimum of broad strokes sketch a compact survey of the major architectural trends of the day.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 As a student of Irish history, Danny Murtaugh was familiar with the saga of Finn MacCool slaying the goblin to free the Halls of Tara for the kings of Ireland. He also knew that MacCool did it with an enchanted spear. Just as Danny made ready to slay his Baltimore goblin today to win the World Series, he discov ered that he didn't have an enchanted spear.

title: 2d Gift for Stonehill College
description: NORTH EASTON, Mass., Oct, 16 (AP)Stonehill College has received its second $100,000 gift in the last several days, the Rev. Ernest J. Bartell, its president, announced Wednes day. The gift came from Richard J. Potvin, a Brockton civic lead er and member of the college's board of advisors. The college was presented with $100,000 a week ago by Mrs. Julia Goulart Of New Bedford.

title: SURCHARGE PERILS U.S.SWISS ACCORD
description: GENEVA, Oct. 16The 10 per cent American surcharge on imports is threatening to delay conclusion of a treaty under which Switzerland would help the United States track down money hidden in Swiss banks by agents of organized crime, a high Foreign Ministry, official said this week.

title: KICKBACK INQUIRY IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 16A grand jury investigation of al leged payroll kickbacks of 3 per cent from Jersey City and Hud son County employes to the oldline Democratic organiza tion is being conducted by the County Prosecutor, Geoffrey Gaulkin, a Republican.

title: News of Dogs
description: This is the time of the year in this area that gun dogs take over. Two big threeday events end today and another pair is scheduled for next weekend.

title: Delaware Routs Rutgers, 487, Scoring 21 of Its Points in the Opening Period
description: NEWARK, Del., Oct. 16 (AP) The University of Delaware scored 21 points in the first period and coasted to a 487 victory over Rutgers today.

title: The Battle of the Books
description: On its face it was strictly a bookman's squabblehot copy fpr literati, Yawnsville for com mon men. The country's first citizen of letters, Edmund Wil son, had conceived the idea of a new edition of major Ameri can writers modeled on the Pleiade editions in Francea project to insure that hence forth all books by our classic authors would be inexpensively available for purchase every where. (Most of the writing was out of print.) Moral sup port for the idea came from a number of writers and pub lishers, and in 1962 the search for funds was carried to foun dations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Norman Rosten writes in The Times (letter Oct. 4) that foreign policy ad viser Walt Rostow has been con demned by history, and ought to have the decency to be silent.

title: Local
description: Lafayette and Canarsie bat tled to a 1414 tie in a P.S.A.L. game at Lafayette Field yester day. Joe Caserta, who ran 50 yards for the Frenchies first touchdown, gained 105 in seven carries. Rod Palmer scored the Canarsie touch downs.

title: 2 Grandchildren Born For Eglevsky, Dancer
description: A daughter was born on Sept. 28 to Lieut. Andre Eglevsky Jr., U.S.N., Medical Corps, and Mrs. Eglevsky in the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. L The child, whose mother is the former Doris Gaythwaite of Brook ville, L. I., has been named Doris Cristyn Luba. She is the first grandchild of Andre Eglevsky, the dancer, and Mrs. Eglevsky of Massape qua, L. I.

title: Bridge Been feeling liverish lately?
description: CIRCUMSTANCES sometimes con spire to place a bridge expert in a context of classical tragedy. In the International Team semifinal play off match in New York last month, Peter Weichsel of New York found himself reluctantly playing the role of Prometheus. That ancient immor tal, it will be recalled, used his sharp wits to outwit Zeus, who took brutal revenge by chaining him to a rock where an equally immortal eagle pecked constantly at his liver.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Spiro Anagnostopoulos ar rived yesterday in Athens on his first visit to the land of his forefathers and was greeted like a king. The en tire Greek Government, led by Premier George Papadop oulos, and thousands of Athenians turned out at the airport for the welcoming ceremony.

title: SIX IN COURT RACE NOT CHECKED YET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Justice Department sources confirmed today that the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation had not yet checked out the six potential nominees whose names were submitted by the Nixon Administration to the American Bar Association last week.

title: A.I.C. Downs Bates, 373
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass, Oct. 16 (AP)Bruce Laird ran for 246 yards and Dave Creighton threw two touchdown passes today as American Interna tional defeated Bates 373. It was Bates 18th consecutive defeat dating back to 1969.

title: DARTMOUTH BEATS BROWN TEAM, 107
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 16 Unbeaten Dartmouth, a two touchdown favorite, cracked Brown's stubborn defense in the first period, then settled for a 10.7 Ivy League football victory in a defensive battle today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The Red Baron was a bit perplexed when he read that he had withdrawn from the International Air Transport Association (Travel Notes, Oct. 3). He read the paragraph a couple of times just to be sure and then quickly checked his wallet for his membership card, thinking he may have lost it. No, there it was. So, all of us at Luft hansa were relieved, because we like the idea of I.A.T.A. very much, especially for all the services it provides. Some times, however, as in any or ganization, I.A.T.A. members disagree. Right now, we disagreebut only about air fares, not about anything else.

title: Art
description: T HE leap into abstrac tion that occurred in European painting around the year 1913 the exact date and the little matter of who was first are still in disputewas an event of enormous artistic conse quence. Whether the imme diate point of departure was Expressionism, as in the case of Kandinsky, or Cubism, as in the case of Mondrian, the established pictorial means was suddenly relieved of the obligation to make any ex plicit reference to an imme diately recognizable subject matter. Implicit references persisted, to be sure, but the whole notion of what a painting represented un derwent a radical change. Thenceforth, the socalled content of painting could no longer be determined sole ly on the basis of what the artist put down on the sur face of his picture.

title: Coins
description: NEW YORK'S fall coin auction season lends promise of being the best in many years, with one of this country's richest private collections be ing offered in the first two sales. Two of this city's ma jor companies, Stack's and Schulman Coin and Mint, Inc., have teamed to dispose of the Nate S. Shapero and Nate S. and Ruth B. Shapero Foun dation numismatic items. This famous collection represents decades of collecting in the United States, as well as in many foreign countries.

title: 2 MICHIGAN LEADERS SUE ON SCHOOL TAX
description: LANSING, Mich., Oct. 16 State Attorney General Frank J. Kelley and Gov. William G. Milliken have filed suit against three wealthy suburban Detroit school districts in an effort to have the state system of public school financing through local property taxes declared uncon stitutional.

title: Shall we dance?
description: Quick, Fred Astaire! Choose your partner and start dancing, for you're right back in fashion. Your pleated pants, your pulleddown sweaters, that insouciant airthey are all a part of one of the newest eveningfashion looks. Those casually worn jackets now are in satin or taffeta, and the sweaters glitter by night. And the pleated pants? Well, they were made for dancing It's a great look, Fredespecially on the ladies. That Astaire sweater is now done up in glittering black. Here it's pulled over an appleembroidered white satin shirt, velvet pleated pants. Patti Cappalli for Addenda. Shirt, $28; sweater, $24; pants, $38. Seventh floor, Saks Fifth. All jewelry is,. by Yves Saint Laurent. A red satin blazer (near right) goes over a whitetie crepe de chine shirt, pleated black satin pants. All by Valentino. The blazer, $210; shirt, $70 pants, $90. All from the Valentino Boutique, 801 Madi son Avenue. Shoes, Silvia of Fiorentina.

title: Condors Beat Rockets, 140136
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 (AP) The Pittsburgh Condors out scored the Denver Rockets, 117, in the second overtime period to take a 140136 victory

title: Letter to the Editor 10  No Title
description: To the Editor: McGuaneif my own reac tion is typical  must have tested a good many of your readers.

title: EMBANK ASSURED OF RETURN IN 72
description: Philip H Iselin, the president of the New York Jets, dis closed yesterday that Weeb Ewbank can do whatever he wants next season  con tinue as both general manager and coach, or remain as gene ral manager while retiring as coach with the expiration of his threeyear contract.

title: N.Y.U. 10 Soccer Victor
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 16A goal by Joe Fink in the first period carried unde feated New York University to a 10 soccer victory, its fifth over Montclair State today.

title: A Lovely Last Picture Show
description: IT is the autumn of 1951 a Saturday night in Anarene, Tex and SOO Crawford (Timothy Bottoms), the cocaptain of the high sehool foot ball team, and Charlene Duggs, (Sharon Taggart) sit in the last row of the Royal Theater necking, without a great deal of enthusiasm, and watching Father, of the Bride, one of Louis B. Mayer's less stern conceptions of what America would be if it had any sense. Sonny, you understand, accepts the difference be tween the reality of Charlene, who Is a mess, and the fantasy of Elizabeth. Taylor, who, to understate the case, isn't (or, at least, she wasn't).

title: Brigadier Gerard, 12, Takes Champion Stakes
description: NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 16 (AP)Unbeaten Brigadier Gerard, the British owned 12 favorite beat Rarity by a short head in heavy rain today to win the 1mile champion Stakes today. The winner earned $60,669 for his owner, Mrs. J. K. Bishop.

title: The World
description: BRIGBITON, England.  Even if the signs and the slo, gaps were removed, no one would have any trouble in stantly disthiguishing the an ntial conferences of Britain's two major patties That was clear in the ball and the hotel lobbies last week, as the Tories followed Laboi.to this seaside resort;

title: Preps
description: EXETER, N. H., Oct. 16 Exeter won its third straight game this season routing Mount Hermon, 230, today. Mike Burke, the Exeter quarterback threw touchdown passes to Jim Curry for 20 and 22 yards, and kicked a field goal and 2 extra points.

title: Group Admits Killings
description: LONDON, Oct. 16A group calling itself the Irish Repub lican Movement claimed respon sibility today for the killing of two Belfast policemen yes terday.

title: The Nation
description: WASIFIRVGTON  When the issue of supplying military and economic aid to Cambodia was first before Congress last year, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, with obvious reference to the Vietnam involvement, gave assurances that we have no intention of slipping into the mistakes of the past. Last week the question of whether the United States was going down the same slippery slope in Cambodia was revived by the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee as It set a $250million limit on United States spending in Cambodia in the current fis cal year.

title: 2dPeriod Rally Turns Tide
description: TORONTO, Oct. 16The New York Rangers, evidently with out reverence for history, dumped the Maple Leafs, 53, tonight as the Toronto hockey club began its 40th season in Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: THUBTOND IMAGE SEEN AS CHANGING
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 16  The development of what some see as a new image for Senator Strom Thurmond is attracting widespread Interest and causing mixed reatcions among Negroes in South Carolina.

title: Two Williamsburg Remembrances
description: As often as I have written about the old neighborhood I never seem to ex haust the subject. I began my sojourn in Paradise in the first year of my life, at 662 Driggs Avenue, Brooklyn, and remained there until 1899, when the family moved to the Bushwick section and my life began all over again, seemed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As most serious visitors to Taiwan realize after a very brief stay, the exNanking officials of Chiang Kai shek and their fumy are running that island wellnigh as if they were a foreign occupying power. After all those years, and with all the American bounty that is theirs to channel, they still have not been able to generate any genuine native support. Worse, they probably haven't even been in terested in creating it.

title: L. I. BottomFishing Skipper Still Sailing Smoothly at 74
description: FREEPORT, L. I.  Capt. Lou De Blasio, the last of the bottomfishing skippers on the Freeport waterfront, says he is slowing down but no body believes him.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: FLEECING THE LAMBS. By Christopher Elias. 246 pages. Henry Regnery Com pany. $6.95.

title: Trains in Amtrak, Although Still Scarce, Have Become Clean and More Punctual
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 After five months of Amtrak management, passenger trains in America are cleaner, more gracious and mbre consistently on time than they have been in a decade.

title: LAFAYETTE HALTS PENN TEAM, 1715
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 (AP) Lafayette utilized a solid ground game and voided turn overs today to upset Penn, 1715, for its first victory over the Quakers since 1923.

title: Reader's Report
description: The setting of this novel by the daughter of Louis Brom field is a vast Ohio estancia that resembles Bromfield's Mal abar Farm, on which Mrs. Geld was raised. When a ra pacious politician wants to commercialize the Sutter's Val ley property after the death of its illustrious owner, Thomas Barr, he is resisted by Barr's daughter and her husband, who are in love with farming for its own sake. Unfortunately, their good intentions are not enough to capture the reader, for A Timeless Place is a motionless novel, slack in nar rative propulsion and low in vital signs.

title: Nassau's 4H Program Is Largest in Country
description: MINEOLA, L. I.In Nas sau County, where land can cost more than $50,000 or $100,000 an aere, there aren't many spots where a 4H club member can try his hand at tilling the soil.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Recently four of us saw Cliff Gorman in Lenny. His performance surpassed those of greats going back over 30 years In our theater going experience. The audience gave him a standing ovation, which he so rightly deserved for, this tourdeforce per formance.

title: Reagan Calls on Park
description: SEOUL South Korea, Oct. 15 (AP)  Gov. Ronald Reagan of California visited President Park Chung Hee today to deliver a personal message from Presi dent Nixon. Governor Reagan said the message assured Mr. Park that the United States had no intention of abandoning its commitments to its allies dur ing President Nixon's forthcom ing talks in Peking.

title: Prime Rate Nears Demise
description: The banking industry ap pears to be moving toward the first fundamental change since 1934 in the way in which it prices its basic prod uctthe business loan.

title: Summit
description: WASHINGTONThe Presiden tial road to Russia is paved with good intentions. The Roosevelt mission to Yalta in World War II left a trail of suspicion and bit terness. The Eisenhower journey in 1960 collapsed with the U2 spy plane crisis. A Kennedy junket in 1964 was aborted by assassi nation. A Johnson trip in 1968 was ruined by the Soviet inva sion of Czechoslovakia. Knowing this, President Nixon has mapped his approach more carefully than any predecessor. He has timed it to follow an even more spec tacular journey to Peking and to coincide with what should be a springtime of EastWest accom modation. He could have gone sooner but he was able to ar range a moment that promises to yield the maximum diplomatic and political advantage.

title: En Garde, Pessimists! Enter Rn Dubos
description: EN GARDE, pessimists! Rene Dubos, who has dueled to the death a myriad of killers in visible to the naked eye, sees clearly the threats to the environmentyet remains an optimist. Having lived al most all but one of the years to date of the disillusioning 20th century, he still believes that man is a noble work. Even the warning of his friend and early hero, Lewis Mumford, that human beings are rapidly falling vic tims to a megatechnic civilization run amuck, cannot shake his faith in the future.

title: White expatriates and black mimics
description: I have always believed that a writ er writes one book all his life: wheth er consciously so or not, his work is of a piece. For this reason the writer is entitled to present as the provi sional entity between two covers, which is what any single book is, any combination of writing that he sees as that entity. V.S. Naipaul's group ing together of a short novel, two stories and two fragments of a travel diary is not a collection of occa sional pieces but an entity; and approach it as contiguous with personal vision that blazed forth in his magnificent novel A House For Mr. Biswas a few years ago.

title: BOSTON IS OPENING COURT ON HOUSING
description: BOSTON, Oct. 16 Housing officials here are Counting on a novel court system to help halt the deterioration of the city's housing brought abotft largely by a failure of the traditional court Systeth, to enforce housing codes.

title: Announcements 5000
description: Announcements 5000

title: Refugees in World Rise
description: In the last six years, the total number of refugees in the world has more than doubled, climbing from 7,900,309 in 1964 to 17,318,320 in 1970, Church World Service reports, accord ing to The Associated Press.

title: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 3  No Title

title: Lees of Central Connecticut Takes CrossCountry Run
description: Bob Lees led a procession of six teammates across the finish line as Central Connecticut State completely dominated crosscountry rivals Iona, City College and Fairleigh Dickin son of Madison yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

title: Movies
description: I F you want to get a good inter view out of d, Andy Warhol had instructed the reporter, buy fifth of good Scotch and set it in front of him. Warhol was speaking of Emile de Antonio, the documentary film maker, whose opinionated documentary on President Nixon called Millhouse: A White Comedy is breaking all attend ance records at the Upper West Side's New Yorker and has even moved over to the East Side's chic Plaza Theater to accommodate the overflow.

title: Mrs. Cleaver Back in the U.S.; Plans a National Speaking Tour
description: Mrs. Eldridge Cleaver, wife of the Black, Panther leader and author, returned to New York yesterday with their two children, after a flight from Zurich, Switzerland.

title: Caribbean Airline Fares To Be Unchanged in 1972
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (AP)Airline ticket prices in the Caribbean area will remain unchanged next year, while longhaul fares to and from South America will increase slightly, the Interna tional Air Transport Association announced this week.

title: MANY INEQUITIES ARE UNDER STUDY
description: The International Offshore Rule, the formula used to rate yachts of different size and design so that they can race equitably with one another, will be amended, it was an nounced by Olin Stephens dur ing the meeting of the Offshore Rating Council.

title: About Motor Sports
description: Bill Scott of McLean, Va., and Tom Reddy of Bronx ville, N. Y., will compete today for the national cham pionship for professional drivers of Formula Super Vee cars. The occasion is the closing, event of the summerlong, coasttocoast series for singleseat, open wheel racing cars based on Volks wagen compo nents, machines that are capable of 155 miles an hour on the straights. The race will be run 33 laps over the 1.9mile, Laguna Seca road course at Monterey, Calif., as a prelude to the ninth CanAm race of the season.

title: Eleanor And Franklin
description: The dimensions of both the great ness and deficiencies of Eleanor Roosevelt and her marriage to Frank lin D. Roosevelt appear with sensi tivity and vividness in Joseph Lash's monumental biography. Nothing so fresh and intimate has appeared since Robert Sherwood's Roosevelt and Hopkins. Lash quotes in abundant, revealing detail from Mrs. Roosevelt's papers, to which the family gave him full access. Yet despite his handi caps as the family's authorized biog rapher, and as one of Mrs. Roose velt's admirers and confidants, he writes with rare candor and judg ment.

title: Fordham Varsity Defeated By Seton Hall Club, 76
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 16Seton Hall University's club football team upset the Fordham University varsity, 76, today. It was the Pirates third victory in four games and the Rams third loss in four attempts.

title: Sesame Street Getting High Marks
description: Little Stevie Boyer knelt to say his prayers the other even ing and began reciting the al phabet. His surprised father, Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, chancellor of the State University of New York, asked the 5yearold boy where he had learned his letters.

title: Foreign Notes
description: With the China debate scheduled to open in the United Nations tomorrow, United States officials con ducted a strong campaign of arm twisting last week in an effort to line up support for its twoChina position. Some diplomats with sore arms complained privately of blackmail.

title: Frenzied Motion in Jewish Life Is Criticized by Two Leaders
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 Two major personalities in Jew ish communal lifeone a se cular leader, the other a force in religious thoughthave cri ticized what they called the failure of the Jewish commu nity to think through the nettling problems that con fronted it.

title: PassaicHudson
description: Bruce Basile, Hackensack's quarterback, put on another offensive shdw yesterday to pace a 278 victory over Pas saic Valley in a battle of un beaten Northern New Jersey Interscholastic League powers.

title: Preps
description: KENT, Conn., Oct. 16Scott Perry scored twice on runs to day and Kent remained unde feated, beating Suffield, 180. Kent is now 30 and Suf field 11.

title: U.S. Quits Base, Fear Moves In
description: LANDING ZONE DOTTIE, South Vietnam, Oct. 15The Americans are gone from here now. Watching the last of them leave a few days ago, wrecking and burning what they did not take out in a convoy, the vil lagers of Binhlien both cursed them and felt sad. They are still angry because of what was de stroyed in four days of fires and what the huge bulldozers smashed and plowed under. But they are uneasy because, as one old farmer said:

title: Et Al.
description: A fine collection of pieces of literary criticism and history by a Harvard professor. Berth off's range is wide; he is no stick in the mud, nor is he a swinger. He discusses every thing from Emerson to Armies of the Night and Malcolm X's autobiography. He loves Ed mund Wilson. The jacket is festooned with high, just praise from John Updike.

title: Feasibly
description: To the Editor: Your featured review by Thomas McGuane of the new John Hawkes book The Blood Oranges celebrated its launch ing with the following headline, a pickup from McGuane's re marks:

title: Supplies of Vital Phosphorous Found in Peril in Ecology Study
description: An ecological study made for presentation to the United Na tions Conference on the Human Environment in Stockholm next year has determined that the world's known potential supply of phosphorous, a nonrenew able resource essential to life,1 could be exhausted by the end of the next century.

title: Pull Is Named Best in Maryland Show
description: WEST FRIENDSHIP, Md., Oct. 16A 6yearold puli was the choice of Mrs. Augustus Riggs 4th as best in show at the Catonsville Kennel Club's 26th annual event on the Howard County Fair, grounds today.

title: Westchester
description: Pleasantville stayed unde feated, untied and unscored upon yesterday in running the school's winning streak to 13 games with a 280 victory over previously undefeated Alexander Hamilton of Elmsford. The Westchester Interschc ??? Con ference Northern Division game was played at Pleasantville.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16In a time of social upheaval such as the United States has been experiencing in the last halfdozen years, it is the pro tagonists of change, the revolution aries  genuine and makebelieve who dominate the discussion of public affairs. But even stronger if less visi ble is the widespread desire of Ameri cans to return to their common roots as one people, to rediscover old guide lines and reassert old values.

title: Ithaca Tops Wilkes, 4128
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 16 (AP) The passing of Doug Camp bell rallied Ithaca from a 140 deficit to a 4128 victory over Wilkes today. The victory was Ithaca's fourth in five games.

title: A JapaneseAmerican Is at the Helm in San Jose
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 16 The Mayor's office here is dec orated with the standard props: an American flag, a California flag, a picture of the new City Hall. On one wall is a framed scroll with Japanese writing on it.

title: Kissinger Party Flying to Peking; Is Due W ednesday
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP)  Henry A. Kissinger left Washington for Peking today to work out plans for President Nixon's trip to mainland China. His plane left Andrews Air Force Base at noon.

title: Local
description: Jim Butler's running and the passing combination of Pat Fal lacaro to Steve Glassman led unbeaten Lincoln to a 2612 Public Schools Athletic League victory yesterday over Poly Prep at Lincoln Field. It was the fourth triumph for the Abes and Poly's first loss in four contests.

title: Columbia Wins on Gamble For 2 Points at End, 1514
description: Home rooters in the crowd of 18,530 at Baker Field yesterday would have been justified in nicknaming Colum bia's gridiron Cardiac Plains as the Lions beat Yale in a heartstopper, 1514.

title: GroomIn for Dog Owners
description: Michael Willen will give demonstration on grooming at the Elks Club, Great Neck, L. I., at 11 A.M. today.

title: Amherst 146 Victory Ends Rochester Streak at 12
description: ROCHESTER, Oct. 16Am herst used two firstquarter touchdowns and a strong de fense today to score a 146 vic tory over the University of Rochester, ending Rochester's 12game winning streak.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Mr. Nixon's opportunity to appoint a Supreme Court Justice after the res ignation of Justice Fortas elicited from the President a statement to the effect that the Jewish seat was a thing of the past. Although it seemed a states manlike and realistic approach at the time the illusion was soon shattered by the Haynsworth and Carswell fias coes, and was finally settled by the approval of Mr. Blackmun.

title: An Elite Brain Factory
description: PITTSBURGH  People tell me the air is bad in Pittsburgh, said Richard M. Cyert, staring absentminded ly at a spot in his balding beige office carpet. But, add ed the dean of the Graduate School of Industrial Adminis tration at CarnegieMellon University, I'm one of those people who tends to be im pervious to his environment.

title: W.M. Jeffords 3d Weds Miss Perry A. Crouse
description: WAYNE, Pa., Opt. 16  Miss Perry Aldrich Crouse and Walter Morrison Jeffords 3d were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Fred erick A. Breuninger in St. Davids Episcopal Church.

title: Ann Clute Is Married
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Oct. 16Miss Ann Stratford Clute daughter of Warren W. Clute Jr., and Boyd Rich ard Obenshain of Albuquer que, N. M., son of Mrs. Marie Obenshain of Hempstead, L. I., and Boyd H. Obenshain of Hamburg, N. Y., were mar ried here this afternoon at the Clute home by the Rev. Clark N. McKinney, a Pres byterian minister.

title: The L. B. J. Library: The Life and Times Of Lyndon Johnson in Eight Full Stories
description: AUSTIN, Tex.It's all here with the bark off, Lyndon Johnson told blueribbon crowd at the dedica tion of the L.B.J. Library here last May, nodding back toward the $18 million structure and implying that therein reposed the real lowdown on himself and his muchdiscussed place in history. Like much else about the former President, that proposition is debatable. Indeed, after ambling through the library's museum and viewing all sorts of exhibits ranging from letters to Johnson from Bobby Kennedy and the Smothers Brothers to a display that has Hello Lyndon issuing from hidden tape recorder, yet finding barely any mention of the war in Vietnam, began to suspect that quite a bit of bark was still in place.Standing at the bottom of the mag nificent travertine stairway leading from the ground (first) floor to the Great Hall (second floor), the visitor can see the outside rows of stacks behind fivestory glass wall. Only the ground floor, the Great Hall and a portion of the top (eighth) floor, which contains a replica of the Oval Office of the White House, are open to the public. What remains are the stacks.

title: After Years Of Effort, U.S. Court Opens on L.I.
description: WESTBURY, L. I.Jurors ride a, bus back and forth between here and Brooklyn, the courtroom audience sits in rented folding chairs, and there is no clerk yet in the clerk's office, but the Unit ed States District Court for the Eastern District of New York is now in session on the top floor of an office building next door to Roose velt Raceway.

title: Curry Tops. Bridgewater
description: BRIDGEWATER, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP)Curry College wrapped up the New England Small Col lege Conference football cham pionship today in a 130 vic tory over Bridgewater State.

title: Lorraine Hovey Rowan Is Engaged
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 16 Miss Lorraine, Hovey Row an, a Junior at George Washington University, and Charles Eustis Bohlen Jr., who is in his second year at Yale Law Sc'hool, plan to be married during their Christ mas vacation. His father is the former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, the Philip pines and France.

title: Pirates 3dBase Coach Foils Girl Friday's Act
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16  Frank Oceak, Pittsburgh's thirdbase coach, was late get ting to third base for the Pi rates sixth inning today and the Baltimore fans booed him for it.

title: Science
description: The view from the entrance of the, cave was awesome. Mas sive glaciers filled the valleys of the mountainsthe Pyrenees to the south. Across the tree less plains one could see vast herds of woolly rhinoceroses and archaic horses. There were scatterings, as well, of archaic cattle, caribou and deer.

title: ARCHIE DEFEATS ARCHIE
description: In Norman Lear's reply to Laura Z. Hobson, As I Read How Laura Saw Archie  on this page last week, a sen tence was inadvertently omitted from one paragraph. The paragraph should have read:

title: MIDDLEBURY ROUTS HAMILTON, 61 TO 18
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Oct. 16 Middlebury College defeated Hamilton 61.18, as Peter Mac key, a sophomore quarterback, put on a splendid aerial display.

title: OKLAHOMA STATE DOWNS MISSOURI
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., Oct. 16 (UPI)Brent Blackman, a soph omore quarterback, pitched touchdown passes of 31 and 20 yards and bootlegged 6 yards for another, all within the first 10 minutes of the third period, to lead Oklahoma State to a 3716 Big Eight victory over Missouri today.

title: JOHN C. HEROENHAN
description: NORTH CASTLE, N. Y., Oct. 16John C. Hergenhan, this Westchester County commu nity's first fulltime policeman and its first chief of police, died last night in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 4 Wago Avenue, Armonk. He had retired in 1969.

title: Hofstra Beats Wayne, 10.7; Hoehn Catches 15 Passes
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16With Rusty Hoehn setting a school record of 15 receptions in one game, Hofstra University held on for a 107 victory today over Wayne State University.

title: Queens Carnegie Hall Marks 11th Year
description: The Colden Center of Queens College is marking Its 11th anniversary with the reputation of having be come the borough's Carnegie Hall.

title: Cavaliers Improved
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 16 (AP)The Cleveland Cavaliers, who lost their first 15 games last season, won in their second start to night, defeating the Buffalo Braves, 9389.

title: Wallace to Name Students
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 16 (UPI)Gov. George C. Wallace says he will appoint students to nonvoting positions on boards of trustees at Alabama colleges and universities. Meeting with about 100 student government officers, he said Wednesday he would sign an executive order establishing the ex officio posi tions for students on the boards.

title: Local
description: Monroe won its first game of the season yesterday by de fatting Stuyvesant, 2820, at Randalls Island. Monroe was paced by its quarterback, Dave Washington, who threw for two touchdowns, including one to Mark, his twin brother.

title: Local
description: Ricky Dingle, Evander's guarterback, ran for three touch downs and totaled 22 points yesterday as his team routed Flushing, 448. Evander is now 301. Flushing has not won in four games.

title: Ex Officer, a War Protester, Now Helps G.I.'s as Lawyer
description: CAMBRIDGE, England Oct. 12Three months after Thomas S. Culver was found guilty of taking part in an antiwar pro test in London, the former Air Force legal officer site in his small home on Hamberstone Road advising dissident Ameri can servicemen and quietly shaping his future.

title: Talks, Classes, Shows
description: THERE will be a Flower Photography Workshop at the New York Bo tanical Garden on Sat urday and Oct. 30. Don Langer, the instructor, will start classes promptly at 10 A.M. Students are asked to bring their, camera, film, closeup attachment, flash unit and extension cord, The sessions will be held in the tropical conservatory and will last for two hours plus informal shooting and chat ting after the noon hour. Registration $25 Advance payment should be made by Wednesday to the Education Department, New York Bo tanical Garden, Brenx, N.Y. 10458.

title: Kiss and Run Is First
description: SALEM, N. H., Oct. 16 (AP) Kiss and Run scored a con vincing victory today in the $15,000 Governor's Handicap at Rockingham Park.

title: Football Malpractice
description: Earlier this week, a for mer football player at the University of North Carolina released a statement that chronicled the lack of con cern by coaches and train ers toward injuries the play er said he had received dur ing his time with the team.

title: Some Anonymous Attackers Are Now Condemned by Soviet
Gretel and Gretel II Are Offered for Sale
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 16 (AP)Sir Frank Packer, Aus tralian newspaper publisher, has advertised his three 12 meter yachts for sale.

title: Nipponese egoism, psychic skulduggeries, Italian mythmaking
description: This is a collection of five uneasy pieces. In each one the reader is given an intriguing situation, a series of neatly planted clues and a generous number of plot twists, the kind of thing that Bennett Cerf has lovingly referred to as shenan igans. His taste for shenani gans must be shared by a great many readers: Miss du Maurier has been a household word for more than 30 years, and the most famous Re becca in the world today is not from Sunnybrook Farm or the Book of Genesis but from a lonely old English mansion called Manderley.

title: The Quiet
description: A few chilly nights can bring quiet to the darkness now, the first night quiet since April. The katydids and the tree crickets, which made the darkness hum and quiver only a few weeks ago, have pretty well run their course. The pulse of their lives heath too slowly to set them stridulating. The quiet is almost palpable. You can hear the whisper of the leaves brushing against each other.

title: Trainers Here Are Uncertain About Florida Plans
description: Are you going to Flor ida?

title: Letters
description: In the next to last para graph of Amos Elon's cover story on the Black Panthers of Israel, he concedes that in Israel the problem is above all social, not necessarily eth nic and certainly not racial. And therein lies the real story that Elon and The Times should have had on the cover of the magazine.

title: NEW SUEZ MOVES WEIGHED BY U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 16The United States is ex ploring way to intensify its eightmonthold effort to nego tiate an interim peace agree ment in the Middle East, includ ing the possibility of holding a new round of indirect talks be tween Egypt and Israel.

title: Music
description: T HERE have been con ductors who have worked at both the Metropolitan Opera and the New York City opera at different times in their ca reersErich Leinsdorf, Joseph KOsenstock, Thomas Schip pers, for example. The first one to have been engaged by the two, companies simul taneously, is Christopher Keene. Not only that, being pit 24, he became, the sec oltl youngest conductor to hem been engaged by the Mit. (The youngest was the 23,.earkild W.alter Damrosch, back in 18854

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The radioactive wastes, resulting from the manufac ture of nuclear weapons, stored in tanks buried in Richland, Wash., are not the only ones of The Seven Wonders of the Polluted World. A problem of poten tially greater magnitude is the disposition and storage of radioactive waste of atomic power plants. Meanwhile, there are little data about the effects of highly radioactive materials on the leakage in tegrity of the devices and spaces designed for them; and the ability of manmade structures to withstand the stresses of historyerosion, war, earthquake, etc.also does not give much reason for optimism. Has anyone taken a look at the Parthenon lately? The time has come to consider anew the potential ities of nonpolluting solar energy. ALAN H. GREEN

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: The day that Mel Allen was fired ended the Golden Era for the Yankees. Being a woman my interest in baseball was on the lukewarm side until Mel Allen made me feel that he reserved the seat next to him just for me. He also made me feel that no matter how many dumb questions I asked, he wanted to answer them all. He became my friend jai though I never met him) still miss him.

title: $1.4MILLION IN GIFTS FOR NEGRO COLLEGE
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 16 Gifts totaling $1,462,000 for Benedict College have been an nounced by Dr. Benjamin F. Pay ton, president of the traditional ly black institution.

title: Shah Visits Father's Tomb As Celebration Near End
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 16 (Reuters) The Shah of Iran laid a wreath at the black mabrle tomb of his father, Roza Shah Pahlevi, founder of the Pahlevi dynasty in 1925, today as the lavish celebra tions of the 2,500th annivers ary of the Persian Empire drew near an end.

title: Suffolk
description: Greenport, making a bid for a perfect season, picked up its fourth straight shutout yes terday at the expense of Comsewogue, 300. Coach Dor rie Jackson's Oystermen scored in every period.

title: 2 SLAIN IN CLASHES IN ULSTER CITIES
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, Oct. 17 (AP)  A civilian gunman was reported killed and two senior police officers were shot in East Bel fast gun battles early today.

title: Preps
description: ASHBURNHAM, Mass., Oct. 16Consistent yardage on the ground by Dan Klarsch, junior, helped Cushing Aca demy down Thayer Academy, 3413 today. Klarsch gained 156 yards rushing. Vfn Maxson passed for 14 points and ran for 8 as Cushing won for the first time in three games.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTHI AVE.
description: The script of the Seventh Avenue success story is fairly repetitious: place a competent man and an idea together and you have a moneymaking business and that is how the script reads for Rain or Shine, Inc., an important source of women's and misses rainwear.

title: The Apple Orchards in Suffolk County
description: K D. (Link) Wells, the Suf folk County cooperative ex tension agent, said that the apple crop brought orchard owners in the county about $250,000 a year.

title: TV Proxy Protests a Harbor Plan
description: No one could recall any thing like it happening be fore. A Brooklyn group, pro testing plans for a waterfront redevelopment, brought along its own television tape to show to the City Planning Commission on the ground that some of the neighbors could not make the trip to City Hall and so had sent their message recorded.

title: Jobless Veteran Held in Slaying Of Flatbush Woman by Stabbing
description: An unemployed Vietnam war veteran suspected of murdering a 22yearold Brooklyn house wife who was stabbed 90 times and then burned was arrested late Friday night, the police an nounced yesterday.

title: 42 Soviet Agents Reported Exposed In Spying on NATO
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 16Belgian press reports said today that Anatoly Tchibotarev, a 38year old member of the Soviet trade mission here who disappeared from his home two weeks ago, had exposed a Soviet spy net work that had been eavesdrop ping on telephone conversations at headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty organization here and at Supreme Headquar ters Allied Powers Europe in nearby Mons.

title: SEEMAN'S ACTION AN ISOLATED ONE, POLICE HEAD SAYS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he suspended Albert A. Seed man as chief of detectives three days before the start of police corruption hearings because the chief may have been indiscreet or used bad judgment.

title: Princeton Routs Colgate, 3512, for First Victory of Year
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 16 Princeton University's football team, its emotions fueled by three straight losses this sea son, exploded this afternoon in Palmer Stadium to score a de cisive 35.12 victory over a strong Colgate eleven.

title: MANHATTAN CREWS WIN OWN REGATTA
description: Manhattan College won three of four events in its homecom ing week regatta today on the Orchard Beach Lagoon rowing course.

title: Some Solid Refreshment For Motorists In Vermont
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.On the theory that man should feed his soul as well as his stomach at road side rest areas, Vermont has placed massive pieces of concrete or marble sculpture in every major rest area along Interstate 89 and Interstate 91. Foliage pilgrims thus have extra reason to pause these roadside sites this fall.

title: Greek Rites On L.I. Today
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I.Bone relics of two Eastern Ortho dox saints, St. George and St. Panteleimon, are to be enshrined permanently in the altar of St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church today in a colorful ceremony consecrat ing the church.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARIS  One of the shrewdest French diplomats I know predicted eight months ago: If the United States and China can find a means of rapprochement we will see the way open up to a solution of the problem of Indochina, and other countries, including the Soviet Union, will have to subscribe to it.

title: Eric Sivirxa Have a Son
description: A son was born on Sept. 30 to Mr. and Mrs. Eric Sivin of Forest Hills, Queens, in University Hospital here. The child has been named Philip Matthew. The child's father, a lawyer, is with the New York firm of Jacobs Persinger & Parker.

title: NEBRASKA VICTOR OVER KANSAS, 550
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 16 (AP) Unbeaten Nebraska's top ranked football team smashed Kansas today, 550, in a Big Eight Conference clash before 68,331, the largest crowd in Memorial Stadium history.

title: Doughty's Three Touchdowns Lead Michigan to 356 Trouncing of Illinois
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 16 (UPI)Glenn Doughty scored one touchdown on a pass and two on runs today as Michigan trounced Illinois, 356.

title: Ships Grope for Mayor's Cup
description: ABOARD THE SCHOONER MATTHEW W., Oct. 16The annual Mayor's Cup Race for schooners is run in mid October because it is usually the season of the briskest winds in New York Harbor, the kind of weather that these seacruising vessels thrive on.

title: U.S. CHINA TRADE IS STILL BLOCKED
description: President Nixon's effort to open trade between the United States and mainland China has so far not resulted in a single direct commercial transaction.

title: Fresh Air Ousts Fog After Flight Delays And 5 Road Deaths
description: A stagnant air mass that blanketed the metropolitan area since Friday, trapping pollu tion in the air causing a thick fog that closed airports inter mittently, was steadily lifting yesterday, the National Wea ther Service reported.

title: Humphrey Now Welcome at Colleges
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 16  Friendly students had tipped off Senator Hubert H. Hum phrey's aides that militants would disrupt his speech this week, but they did not know exactly how.

title: Jane Elizabeth Carey Wed to Thomas A. Haswell
description: Miss Jane Eizabeth Carey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Carey of New York and San Juan, Puerto Rico, was married here yes terday morning to Thomas Alan Haswell, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Glen Haswell of Mannford, Olda.

title: Clemson Tops Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 16 (UPI) Clemson scored three touch downs in the third quarter to day to rout Virginia, 3215. The Tigers put on drives of 79, 80 and 75 yards after spotting the Cavaliers a 73 halftime lead.

title: Lelia Leith Griswold Planning May Wedding to John Lamb Jr.
description: MONKTON, Md., Oct. 16 Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Howell Griswold 3d have announced the engagement, of their daughter, Miss Lelia Leith Griswold, to John Gra vette Lamb Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lamb of Cleveland. A May wedding is planned.

title: CALIFORNIA WINS ON LATE FIELD GOAL
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 16 (UPI)Ray Wesching kicked a 20yard field goal with 1:06 re maining to give California a 12423 victory over Washington State today.

title: Go On and Relax, You May Get Kissed
description: THE James Joyce Memorial Liquid Theater more simply known as The Liquid Theater and currently ensconced at the Guggenheim Museuim is the only participatory the atrical event I have ever attended at which I got an elbow smack in the eye end a Kiss to make up for it. The kiss is the difference.

title: WISCONSIN'S KICK: BEATS MICH, STATE
description: MADISON, Wis., Oct. 16 (UPI)Roger Jaeger kicked a 30yard field goal with 5:12 left in the game to give Wis consin a 3128 Big Ten upset victory over Michigan State today.

title: Announcements 5000
description: Announcements 5000

title: Northeastern Romps, 3416
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP)  Northeastern Univer sity's football coach, Joe Zabil ski, earned his 100th career victory today when the Huskies beat Springfield College, 3,116. Northeastern got 21 points in the second quarter, led by a twotouchdown performance by the quarterback, Al Mello.

title: Forthcoming Book on World War II Spies Draws Inquiry From the British
description: One recent crisp fall morn ing a lean, youngish man with an Oxford accent walked into the offices of the David McKay Co., a publishing house at Third Avenue and 47th Street, and asked to see the company's, president, Kennett L. Rawson.

title: F and M Routs Dickinson
description: CARLISLE, Pa., Oct. 16 (AP)  Franklin and Marshall took first place in the Middle Atlan tic Conference (Southern Divi sion) today by roling to a 340 victory over previously unbeat en Dickinson.

title: It's called zampino
description: One of the most interesting dishes of the Italian kitchen is a sausagelike oddment called zampino, It is made of pork and is widely admired (and served) not only by Italian chefs but French as well. Although zampinoa stuffed pig's legis not a common supermarket item, it is available in this country (suppliers in the city are listed at the end of the recipe). Like most pork dishes, zampino goes well with beans such as those described in the recipe on this page.

title: France Wins in Field Hockey
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 16 (AP)France defeated Kenya, 10, and the Netherlands and Spain drew, 0.0, in the second round of the first World Field Hockey Cup today.

title: A wooden baton and an iron rod
description: Lawrence Welk and his Cham pagne Music Makers play familiar tunes on television on Saturday nights. During this hour there is some smoke that gets in your eyes, some of her laughter across a crowd ed room and some of the second wind supposed to blow as the days dwindle down. Even the corn is cribbed.

title: Run the Gantlet, $3.80, Takes Rich Man o War
description: Unaccustomed as he has been to the mile and a halfhe had never run that distance before the Rokeby Stable's Run the Gantlet won the $112,000 Man o War at Belmont Park yester day. With a crowd of 35,082 backing him into favoritism, Run the Gantlet, who paid $3.80, took the lead at the stretch turn to score by 2 lengths over the Calumet Farm's Gleaming, with the Clai borne Farm's Practicante next in the field of eight.

title: Brookhaven Lab Celebrates 25th Birthday
description: UPTON, L.I.The Brook haven National Laboratory celebrated its 25th birthday last week, still the largest laboratory in the nation dedi cated to basic research on the peaceful uses of atomic energy but uncertain as to its future.

title: QUENTIN F. O'CONNELL
