description: AMAGANSE1T, L. I., Oct. 16 Quentin F. O'Connell, execu tive vice president of Nadal & Lansing, general contractors, o 654 Madison Avenue, New York, died today, apparently of a heart ailment, at the home of a sister. He was 70 years old and lived at 221 East 66th Street, New York.

title: Penguins Triumph, 2 to 1
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Oct. 16 (UPI)Two third period goals, 56 seconds apart, by Tim Horton rallied the Pitts burgh Penguins to a 21 victory over the Vancouver Canucks to night.

title: 14 Task Forces to Study City Services
description: A total of 14 task forces will be named soon by the new state commission to investigate and analyze the city's governmental structure and to determine how well the city provides those specific services which are criti cal to maintaining the vitality of city life.

title: Rumania, in a Huff, Quits the Book Fair in Frankfurt
description: BONN, Oct. 16The Ruma nian Government has with drawn its large display from the international Frankfurt Book Fair in protest against the pub lication in West Germany of a prison novel by a young Bucha rest author.

title: Manchester United Is 10 Victor Over Derby in Soccer
description: LONDON, Oct. 16, Reuters The brilliance of George Best enabled Manchester United to gain a 3point lead today in the English Football League First Division.

title: LINDSAY, IN INDIANA, ASSAILS NIXON POLICY
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., Oct. 16Campaigning for mayoral candidates across this Presiden tial primary state, Mayor Lind say charged today that the Nixon Administration was pursuing a cities be damned policy.

title: 76ERS TOP HAWKS FOR THIRD IN ROW
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (AP)Luke Jackson's two free throws with 43 seconds remaining lifted the Philadelphia 76ers to a 104402, National Basketball Association victory over Atlanta tonight.

title: It's Cider Time On Long Island
description: EAST NORTHPORT, L. I. Sometime this week, just in time for Halloween sales, the cider presses at Richter's Orchard will begin squeezing golden juice from this year's crop of apples.

title: L.S.U. TURNS BACK KENTUCKY BID,1713
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 16 (AP) Louisiana State, ranked 12th and the heavy favorite, had all it could handle as it posted 1713 Southeastern Conference victory over Kentucky tonight.

title: Artist Tries for Sound on Canvas
description: Buffs of Indian music are most familiar with the el dritch whines and insistent twangs of the sitar, the table and the shahnai. But do they have an idea of what the sounds and rhythms of these instruments would look like translated into painting?, Ameena Ahuja, a part Indian who has loved Indian music since her childhood in Delhi, has attempted to explain the Indian ragas or melodies as a visual experience on can vas and the results of her efforts are on exhibition at the LesnickKuhlik Gallery at 23 East 67th Street.

title: MOORE'S PLUNGE WINS FOR OREGON
description: EUGENE, Ore., Oct. 16 (UPI)  Bobby Moore plunged over from the 1 late in the fourth quarter today to give Oregon a 2321 Pacific8 victory over Washington and kept alive the Webfoots hopes for the Rose Bowl.

title: Hume Improvement
description: A NEW singlecontrol lav atory faucet that is made almost com pletely of plastic, and that comes in a choice of pastel colors is now avail ableand it sells for con siderably less than compar able allmetal single control lavatory faucets. Molded of Celcon acetal copolymer, the faucet comes in pastel blue, avocado, white, harvest gold and sand (the company claims it is the first ever offered in any but metallic finishes). It also offers the homeowner a unique ad vantage in that the color can be changed to suit changes in the rest of the color scheme by simply removing four screws that hold the hous ing on, then replacing with a different color housing or shell. This requires no dis connecting of the plumbing.

title: Nixons at Camp David
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Oct. 16 (UPI)  President and Mrs. Nixon relaxed today at the Presidential retreat with two guests, C. G. Rebozo and Ho bart Lewis, board chairman of The Reader's Digest. Both men are longtime family friends. Mr. Nixon watched the World Series game on television.

title: A Glorious Finale
description: WHITESBORO, N.Y., Oct. 16 Ch. Fanfare Ringmaster, owned by Theresa Lazzaro and Patricia Laurans of Kent, Conn., who will be 5 years old in nine days, was retired from the dog show ring on a high note today. The Doberman pinscher was named best in a field of 857 dogs at the 46th fixture of the Cen tral New York Kennel Club on the grounds of the Hidden Val ley Golf Club. It was Ring master's second top award. On the way he won his seventh group. He also has been best at five specialties.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NORTH CHARLESTOWN, N. H.In the mistshrouded hour before dawn, it was so quiet we could hear other duck hunters talking and set ting out their decoys 500 yards away on the Vermont side of the Connecticut River.

title: REVSON, HUME LEAD QUALIFIERS
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 16 Peter Revson and Denis Mime, who have comfortably domi nated this season's CanAm, qualified today for the first two starting positions in tomor row's running of the Monterey Castrol CanAm. Revson won the polo position with a quail Eying record for the Laguna Seca road course, 116.366 miles an hour.

title: Et Al.
description: A sobering survey of Latin American economic progress or lack of it, by an old South American hand who has been a correspondent for Time, Life and Reuters, MacEoin's mes sage emerges from talks mostly with antiEstablishment South Americans. Its import is clear, insistent and repetitious: the continent's vaunted development in the sixties was a flop, the poverty gap between the Third World and the richest nations (Communist and non Communist) is widening, and the United States in league with local oligarchs holds South America in objective imperialist thrall, The more industrialization, the more in debt to the North American banks and conglomerates the continent becomes. The mood Mr. MacEoin senses is revolu tionary: nothing less than a restructuring of society and greater participation of the masses in economic gain will change it. This is good report ing of things that are, or should be, well known by now.

title: The False God of Growth
description: DITCHLEY PARK, England  Let me begin by asserting two proposi tions. If you do not agree with them, read on, for I shall try to show that they are true.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Did everything glamorous and sophisticated and life canbebeautiful really hap pen in the nineteentwenties? In retrospect it did. And it was then that the American fashion industry began to be aware of its potential and recognized the importance of advertising through the medi um of the then influential slick publications.

title: Reader's Report
description: In this engaging novel, Jo seph Pillitteri shifts from the medical scene he explored in his first book to professional footballworlds that are not so fair apart, when you con sider the spectrum of bodily injury available to the athlete. Alex Lincoln, secondstring quarterback with the Normandy Hawks, is on the active injured list, meaning that he plays with a surgicallyspliced knee, thus adding incessant pain to the residue of his in securities. These include his brother the obstetrician, who needs money; hi., father, who needs his help; a new wife and a troubleprone 16yearold stepson. (His 13  year  old boy by a previous marriage has problems, too.) All thisand shuffling in his mind the reper toire of Hawk plays  keeps Lincoln's nervous stomach con tinually on the boil.

title: SPAR Heads Reserves
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I.A Great Neck teacher who has never been to sea has be come the first woman offi cer to be designated as com manding officer of a Coast Guard Reserve unit.

title: Foundation Offers Hope To Children Near Death
description: Sixteen years ago, Frank J. Ficarra had a butcher shop in Brooklyn. Across the street was a fish store owned by Joseph Caltabiano. They were both merchants and both of Italian descent, but it was something much more per sonal that drew then togeth er. Their children had thal assemia major, more com monly known as Cooley's Anemia.

title: Sartre Accuses the A talk with Sartre
description: GERASSI: In a few days, part one of your massive work on Flaubert will be published. Yet you have often told me in recent times that the only viable activity for the intellectual to day is the political tract. Is that not a contradiction? And would you ex plain what you mean by viable activity?

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  National School Lunch Week was marked here last week, and the formali ties were scrupulously observed. The President issued the usual proclamation. An elaborate dis play of child nutrition photo graphs went up in the Agricul ture, Department lobby.

title: Writer Defends New American Revolt
description: The French literary lion JeanFrancois Revel met a group of American intellectuals here Friday night and told them that the United States was not going to the dogs.

title: Pros Top Squires, 9493
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 16 (AP)  Bobby Warren sank a jump shot with 52 seconds remaining to give the Memphis Pros a 9493 victory tonight over the Vir ginia Squires.

title: Notre Dame Downs No. Carolina, 160
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 16 Undefeated Notre Dame, seek ing more offensive punch to take the team to another bowl game, turned to a new quarter back today as the Fighting Irish downed North Carolina, 160, before the usual capacity crowd of 59,075.

title: Dance: A Giant Stride Forward by National Ballet
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 The National Ballet of Wash ington, now in its first season at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, has taken a giant stride forward with its new production of that most elaborate of the fullevening Tchaikovsky tz.lassiO, The Sleeping BeautY.

title: Jingo Django
description: Not so much a fiction as a string ing together of events, ideas, charac terizations and stylistic devices in imitation of a fiction, Sid Fleisch man's Jingo Django is slickly pro duced, ultimately inadequate.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Now that man has turned Earth into a mound of swill, where will be flee after he louses up the moon?

title: Things can go terribly wrong
description: If the title suggests a hand out from Brussels, forget it. Walter Laqueur's Europe is a long way East of the Six, which is basically a comfortable los ers club of World War II. His homeland is the European heartland, that meeting ground of Slav and German and Jew which produced so rich a cul ture and so disastrous a har vest. He was born in Breslau, then a town in eastern (Wei mar) Germany; it is now Wro claw, in western Poland.

title: Britain Drops Charges
description: LONDON, Oct. 16  Fears that attempts might be nade to kill or kidnap Oleg Lyalin, the Soviet K.G.B. defector to Britain, led to the dropping of drunken driving charges against him, the Attorney General's of fice said today.

title: Stamps
description: A N 8cent blueonwhite stamp will be embossed on white envelopes to mark the White House Conference on Aging to be held in Washington starting Nov. 28. The 6 inchenvelope commemorat ing the conference will be issued on Nov. 15 from Washington.

title: Preps
description: Effective passing by Joe Feliciano, a junior quarterback, led Fieldston to a 2822 victory over Woodmere today.

title: RucheII Magee Wins Move To Reopen 1963 Conviction
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 16 (UPI)  Ruchell Magee, the San Quentin convict charged along with Angela Davis in the Marin County shootout of 1970, won a court motion yesterday to re open his 1963 conviction that sent him to prison. Magee, 32 years old, has been trying to re open the case for the last eight years by sending petitions to the courts.

title: The World
description: PANAMA CITYWhat nation on earth would bear the humiliation of seeing a foreign flag planted in its very heart? Gen. Omar Tor rijos, the Panamanian strong man, addressed the question to a cheering crowd here Monday. What nation would allow a foreign governor on its territory?

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: The article, Job Testing Comes Under Fire (Sept. 19) was unfair to the business community in that an article so superficial serves only to heighten whatever confusion already exists on the subject of nondiscriminatory employ ment practices.

title: Two Men of Art on a Man of History
description: In death as before, Charles of Lorraine continues to fasci nate and trouble the French. It is doubtless far too soon to view the de Gaulle phenome non in full historic perspective, but the urge to do so has in spired a new stream of mem oirs and essays, at least two of which are remarkable works of literature.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Charles Marowitz and The London Scene are al most too much. DOr years now (it seems like centuries) capering cockroaches of the ilk of Richard Neville, Jim Anderson and Felix Dennis, the editors of Oz, have been flinging their little bags of offal in the face of society; trumpeting their selfassert ed right to be as obnoxious, exhibitionistic or destructive as they please.

title: Freeze on Prices Is More of a Thaw to Many Shoppers
description: Food prices have risen ap preciably despite the Nixon Ad ministration's wage  price freeze, according to scores of Shoppers interviewed here yes terday.

title: Crossing the Tracks to Hopper's World
description: T HE blank concrete walls and steel con structions of modern industry, midsummer streets with the acid green of closecut lawns, the dusty Fords and gilded movies all the sweltering, tawdry life of the American small town, and behind all, the sad deso lation of our suburban land scape. He derives daily stim ulus from these, that others flee from or pass with indif ference.

title: CAMBODIAN BORDER IS RAIDED BY 8.52's
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 16 (AP)American B52 bomb ers were said to have mounted one of the heaviest raids of the war along the Cambodian South Vietnamese border today in a renewed effort to smother the threeweek enemy offensive at the frontier.

title: Preps
description: LAKEVILLE, Conn., Oct. 16 Hotchkiss led, 240, before TrinityPawling got any points today and held on for a 2414 victory. Hotchkiss won its sec ond straight and TrinityPawl ing lost its second game.

title: An Unsettled People
description: Very good it is to discover, in the dull realm of American history writing nowadays, a scholar of intellect and imagi nation. Rowland Berthoff has turned out a study in social history, ably written, that may succeed in reinvigorating the whole disciplinelong sur rendered to liberal sloganizing, pots and pans history, and a boring sameness of opinions which has come to oppress even the masters of our dom inant historical school.

title: Purdue Victor, 2120
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 16 (UPI)Purdue stormed back in the last two minutes and scored on Darryl Stingley's 14 yard touchdown dash today to pull out a 2120 squeaker over its Big Ten foe, Northwestern.

title: Hewitt, Miss Goolagong Win Dewar Net Finals
description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 16 (AP)Bob Hewitt of South Africa defeated Gerald Battrick of England, 76, 63 to win the first of the Dewar Cup indoor tennis tourna ments today.

title: I, a Grown Man, Hit in the Head with
description: NOT long after we were married, my wife and I stood toe to toe in the kitchen, exchanging verbal punches that were as devasta ting and as painful as any thrown in a championship heavyweight match. Each accusation, each emotional blow found its mark, and we both reeled from the awesome destructive power of the truths we hurled. Then suddenly, he cause there were no adequate words left to express her hurt, frustration and anger, my, wife did what now seems to be the only sensible and rational thing she could have done. She picked up a frozen veal chop recently left out on the table to defrost, and hurled it at me, striking me just above the right eye.

title: Wild roar Is the Toughest Game in Tuscany
description: POPULONIA, ItalyIn the fall near ly every man in Tuscany goes hunting, some popping off into the hills on Vespas with guns slung over their backs, others in three wheeled trucks with a pack of dogs in the truckbed. The Italian gunner appar ently bangs away at anything that hops or flies, which may account for the small grasshopper population. To the dis gust of your British shootin squire, he Will attract larks with little whirling mirrors, and he will think it only logical to loose off at sitting birds. But there is larger game than hares and larks in these lovely mountains of central Italy, and there is something more to be said for the Italian gunner.

title: the traveler's world
description: LET us try this morning to seed and settle the clouds of confusion that have been whipped up over the proposed reduced air fares be tween the United States and Europe effective Feb. 1. It is time to post road signs through the airfare debate be cause at 10 o'clock Tuesday morning, Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada and chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee's Subcommittee on Aviation, will gavel open three days of hearings on his bill to give the Civil Aeronautics Board authority to ap prove/disapprove and thus set air fares on international routes to and from the United States.

title: Foreign Notes
description: SAIGONNobody's hopes were up here last week be cause of the release by the Communists of S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr. and the recipro cal release of a North Viet namese prisoner. The general assumption was that it was a localized decision, not stem ming from any basic change of heart by Hanoi.

title: AROUND THE
description: Rescue impatiens, begonias, lantanas, coleus, iresine, alternanthera, etc., from frost but taking cuttings promptly. Root them in water, vermiculite or sand and peat for potting and growing as winter house plants. Do not fertilize shrubs, evergreens, rosebushes or trees now. These plants are settling for winter. Continue bulb, shrub, trek planting.

title: Countering Rising Mail Costs
description: In Richmond, the Virginia Electric and Power Company is delivering monthly bills to its 90,000 customers by hand and plans to expand this service to other urban areas in the state by the middle of next month.

title: The Nation
description: The high command of or ganized labor decided last week that it would give a whirl to President Nixon's machinery for policing wages after the freeze. But there is a widespread sus picion that the union chiefs will quit the newly established Pay Board the first time a key de cision goes against them.

title: Rosemary? She's Andre's Baby Now
description: MIA FARROW has no guru now. But she still medi tates, even though she doesn't meditate much as she did right after she and Frank Si natra broke up in 1967 and she came under the influence of Maharishi, Mahesh Yogi. That took lot of thought.

title: 96, He Renews Car License
description: SANFORD, N. C., Oct. 16 (UPI)J. Ed Butler, a 96year old retired farmer, has renewed his driver's license for four more years. I didn't have bit of trouble getting my license renewed, he said. He has been driving for 65 years.

title: Cigarette Country
description: When the pukka politicianbusi nessman is offered a choice between corporate profits and public health, he'll go for the cash almost every time. The British did it last century when they used the army to keep the China opium traffic open. The United States Government and the tobacco industrialists have worked together for most of the past 50 years to promote cigarettes. Their collusion was not carried out in ig norance of the consequences. For 200 years the cancer  producing qualities of tobacco have been recog nized, and for at least 30 years the special dangers of cigarettes have been widely acknowledged. So what Susan Wagner has produced in Cigarette Country is a fascinating and fastpaced murder story without the mystery. We know who the vil lains are before we begin reading.

title: Experimental Express Lane to Speed ueens Bus Riders to Midtown Tunnel
description: A special morning rushhour express lane for Manhattan bound buses will be set up on the eastbound side of the Long Island Expressway during the last week of this month, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: The Rights Of Americans
description: To the Editor: As editor of The Rights of Americans: What They Are What They Should Be, may say that the contributors are grateful for your generous review?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The real problem about such places as Far Hills IFar Hills, at 50, Sees a Chal lenge on Zoning, Oct. 3] is not that they have 10acre or 50acre zoning. The prob lem is that the taxes do not reflect the values.

title: Peter M. Coy Weds Josephine Merck
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Oct. 16 The marriage of Miss Josephine Amy Merck to Peter McAdoo Coy, a first year law student at the Uni versity of Virginia, took place in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frederick Buech ner, uncle of the bride, as sisted by the Rev. John T. Morrow of St. Luke's.

title: Photography
description: HOW can a major Amer ican photographer re main unknown for close to 50 years? This is the question posed by the career of Edward S. Cur tis, a large selection of whose work is on view at the Morgan Library through Nov. 6. The answer seems to lie in the circumstances of Cur tis's work and its publication.

title: COLONELS SCORE OVER NETS 10798
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 16 (AP)  Artis Gilmore scored 29 points and Dan Issel 26 as the Kentucky Colonels opened their American Basketball As sociation season tonight with a 10798 victory over the New York Nets.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: My only regret about the excellent Seven Wonders of the Polluted World (Travel section, Sept. 26) is that you did not accompany the Saul Lambert drawing of a full garbage can floating in space with the prophetic poem by A. Kulik published 18 years ago in The New York Times Magazine. I have that poem in my faded collection; one verse reads:

title: Medicine
description: Few pieces of Federal legisla tion have started out with loftier aim and more glittering promise than Title XIX of the Social Security Amendments of 1965, which encouraged the states to establish Medicaid pro grams: Within this decade, no American would be denied high quality, comprehensive medical care because of an inability to pay for at.

title: Mrs. Buckley Has Child
description: A daughter was born on Sept. 18 in Mount Sinai Hos pital to Mr. and Mrs. William H. Buckley. The child was named Cristina Parke. Mrs. Buckley is the former Miss Linda Parsons Taylor, daugh ter of Lieut: Col. William Ehlers Taylor, U.S.A., retired, of Riverside, Calif., and Mrs. Angela Taylor, of New York. Mr. Buckley iS an art director.

title: Cyril Lewis's Long island
description: EAST WILLISTON, L. I.  The train to East Williston pierces the cluttered, indus trial center of Long Island as straight as an arrow. Through Queens Village, New Hyde Park and Mineola, the cars pass a chain of factories and warehouses, interrupted only by an occasional con crete parking lot.

title: For HomeFurnishings, Recovery Is in Sight
description: The $50  billion  a  year home furnishings industry, second to the automobile business as the country's largest distributor of con sumer goods, is collectively holding its breath thesedays.

title: Griffin Is Riverside Victor As Calm Curtails Sailing
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 16 A very light southerly breeze died, an dthere were no finish ers within the time limit today in the four classes that sailed on Long Island Sound off Riv erside Yacht Club.

title: Miss Duhamel Wed To David J. Ford
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 Miss GhislainePascale Du hamel and David James Ford were married here today in the North United Methodist Church by the Rev. Howard W. Buckley.

title: Miss Walker Wed to Craig Stapleton
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 16St. John's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Dorothy Bush Walker,. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Walker Of Farm ington, to Craig Roberts Stapleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin F. Stapleton of Englewood, Colo.

title: Dance
description: T HE City Center Joffrey Ballet is back in town for its annual fall sea son. The program in cludes new productions by Alvin Ailey, Margo Sapping ton (a former member of the Joffrey troupe previously bestknown for her nude pas de deux in Oh! Calcutta!) and Gerald Arpino. Later I will talk about the first of the Ailey pieces, a new pro duction of his Feast of Ashes, and the other new works. Now might be the oc casion to discuss the critical reception of the Joffrey Bal let in London. It was un expectedly mixed.

title: NOV 22, 1908: President Kennedy, Vice President Johnson and Gov. John Counnlly of texas arrive in Dallas
description: The New York Times begins publi cation of excerpts from Lyndon Baines Johnson's memoirs of his Presidency, to be published in book form by Holt, Rinehart & Winston on Nov. 7 under the title The Vantage Point: Perspec tives of the Presidency, 19631969.

title: Jermain Duncan to Be Bride of David Graham Nov.
description: Miss Jermain Duncan of New York and David Russell. Graham of Wiekenburg, Ariz., will be married here on Nov. 7.

title: Letters
description: Amos Elon's article, The Black Panthers of Israel (Sept. 12), was very well done, and appeared at a most cru cial time in the annals of this storyin point of fact, the problem of the Sephardim in Israel is by no means a new phenomenon.

title: Education
description: Many of the country's in stitutions of higher learning, because of rising costs and declining support, are caught in a financial squeeze. But the black colleges, experts generally agree, are in the tightest bind of all. Most of the black colleges entered the present economic recession without endowments as a cushion and with few wealthy alumni. The overwhelming majority of their students are children of poverty and thus cannot be counted on to pay increased tuition, if they can afford any tuition at all.

title: The Divided Queens Delegation
description: WASHINGTONAre you kidding? A member of Con gress from New York snorted the other day when asked about unity in the Congress ional delegation from Queens.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: PETER BROOK'S Or ghast prellnit nid grei star mun Margaret Croyden ladpaster aqueltor obroony durwilist hentbacken a casino. Nonproster, yarman holt dreenyeny carbolt Mart at/Sade.

title: A. Chilean family chronicle
description: IN a residential section called Pro videncia, on a street of pastel houses, each with double doors, metal grilles over the windows and locked gates, a family of three gen erations is sitting down to dinner.

title: WICHARD PACES POST TO A 43.7 TRIUMPH
description: GREENVALE, L.I., Oct. 16 C. W. Post put on an awesome offensive show, rolling up 530 yards before a Homecoming Day crowd of 3,200, to rout Gettysburg, 437. The victory was the fourth in a row for the Pioneers, whose only loss was to Lehigh on opening day.

title: WAGNER DEFEATS ALBRIGHT, 2714
description: READING, Pa., Oct. 16Jake Ellis's recordbreaking perform ance powered Wagner College to a 2714 victory over Albright today before a Homecoming Day crowd of 3,500 at Albright Stadium.

title: Jersey City St. Eleven Wins
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP) Jersey City State defeated Newark State, 44.0, in a Gar den State Conference game to day. Jerry Lavelle scored two touchdowns for the winners.

title: Court
description: WASHINGTONIn his long and arduous search for candi dates to fill two vacancies on the Supreme Court, President Nixon has offered the nation his ver sion of the dream justicea Republican from a Southern or Border state who has a lawand order judicial outlook, a known distaste for racial desegregation and is neither too young nor too old.

title: RADICALS IN TOKYO STREETS,
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16With their massed banners flying, about 1,500 radical students and workers trotted chanting through the streets of down town Tokyo tonight to start what is expected to be a month of mass demonstrations and violence.

title: $100,000 Bowling Open To Be Rolled at Garden
description: The richest edition of the United States open bowling tournament will be run at the Madison Square Garden Bowling Center Jan. 2 to 8, it was announced yesterday.

title: Television
description: W HETHER right or wrong, the decision was, awkwardly handled. In timing and overall handling, it even appeared to be dumb. That is what remains puzzling about the Public Broadcasting Serv ice's lastminute deletion of a Special Report from the Oct. 6 edition of The Great American Dream Machine.

title: Adelphi Triumphs, 288, On Albany State Fumbles
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Oct. 16 (AP)Adelphi's football team turned a pair of fumbles into firstperiod touchdowns today and defeated Albany State, 288. It was the Panthers first victory of the season.

title: The Style Was Always Bravura
description: In a city of gray and anonymous men, Dean Acheson stood out like a noble monument from another and more vivid era. Tall, elegantly dressed, haughtily mustached, swift of mind and phrase, trenchant in his analysis, flashing in his wit, imperturbable if sometimes con descending in his urbanity, irresistible in his charm, lofty in his scorn,'he brought the nation's capital a personal bravura that will be terribly missed. After his death last week at 78, some would add that, in the last decade or so of his life, his views on foreign policy also stood out like monuments of another age. While this is true enough, it must be reinem bered that the age which produced these views was historic in its deeds and con sequences, and that the views them selves, however bleak they came to seem in a different time, were in their own time an intelligent and imaginative re sponse to bittet realities.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: ORGANIZED. LABOR pledged its support of Phase Two of the President's economic program. Leading indus tries appeared ready to plea for relief before the Presi dential Price Commission.

title: DREXEL TROUNCED BY LEHIGH, 4820
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 16 Lehigh scored four times in the first quarter today to turn back Drexel, 4820. The victory was the Engineers fifth of the foot ball season against one loss.

title: Lloyd Merrill Weds Chandra Carr
description: Miss Chandra Dennison Carr was married yesterday afternoon to Lloyd Neal Merrill, counsel to the minor ity leader of the City Coun cil. The Rev. Robeirt C. Hun sicker performed the Epis copal ceremony in St. Paul's Chapel of Trinity Parish.

title: First Ship Since Strike Reaches Hawaiian Port
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (UPI)The first ship from a Pacific port since the suspen sion of the West Coast dock strike reached Hawaiian wa ters today, carrying food and other items in short supply.

title: DEMOCRATIC GAIN FOUND BY GALLUP
description: For the first time in 30 years of polling on the subject, the Gallup Poll has found that more business and professional per sons are more apt to be Demb crats than Republicans.

title: Oklahoma Trounces Colorado by 4517
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 16 Greg Pruitt flashed by Colo rado on touchdown scampers of 66 and 12 yards today and Jack Mildren hurled two long scoring bombs as secondranked Oklahoma's thunderbolt Wish boneT offense blitzed Colo rado, 4517, in a collision of two Big Eight gridiron powers.

title: Swim Coaches Selected
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. Oct. 16 (AP)Sherm Chavoor of the Arden Hills Swim Club will coach the United States wom en's swimming team in the 1972 Olympics. Peter Daland of the University of Southern Califor nia will coach the American men swimmers.

title: Tampa Routs Drake, 362
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 16 (AP)Tampa rolled up 414 yards today to defeat Drake, 362. Drake, which had won four games in a row, had minus 32 yards rushing.

title: Orioles 75 to Win Series
description: The Baltimore Orioles are 75 favorites to beat the Pitts: burgh Pirates today and win the World Seriies, according to oddsmakers in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SEOUL DEBATE SET ON STUDENT UNREST
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 16 The Government's use of the army in subduing student un rest became a major political issue today as the opposition New Demodratic party de manded the immediate removal of soldiers from schools. An emergency session of the Na tional Assembly was called for tomorrow to discuss the issue.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Stonehenge, the collection of 72 giant stones weighing up to 30 tons apiece, has stood on Salisbury Plain 60 miles southwest of London for perhaps as long as 4,000 years. In that time it has withstood the vandalism of Roman legions, Saxon armies and 19thcentury curiosity seekers. But in recent years, vandals have caused damage costing thousands of dollars.

title: Interfleet Match Postponed
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 16 The start of the annual inter fleet team match between Marblehead (Mass.) and West ern Long Island Sound Inter national Class skippers was postponed today because of a lack of wind off Larchmont Yacht Club. The series was reduced to as many races as can be saild tomorrow.

title: Et Al.
description: A disappointing biography of the Vulgar Supreme of Amer ican pop music, the ever young, ever lovin Elvis Presley, by a contributing editor of Rolling Stone. There should have been more than the endless details of contracts, appearances and moneymaking, but there ain't. Lots on the business wizardry of manager Col. Tom Parker, who made Elvis and himself rich as rajahs. This is really no more than a star biography; not a shred of interpretation of Elvis's music, choreography, popularity, mystique. Elvis is king, but why you'd never know from this book.

title: TITO VISITS INDIA 5TH TIME SINCE 54
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 16 (Reu ters)President Tito of Yugo slavia arrived here today for an official visit of several days, during which he will discuss international problems with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and the IndianSoviet treaty signed In August.

title: Illegal Aliens Pose EverDeepening Crisis
description: They come on the commer cial jet from Bogota, nervous and silent among the tourists, and they come stuffed three together in the trunk of a Mex icali smuggler's sedan. They come hunted ragged through the scorched Texas brush coun try, alert for rattlesnakes, and they come pushing their lug gage before them in the air conditioned reception center at the Kennedy International Air port.

title: Kissinger in Hawaii
description: HILO, Hawaii, Oct. 16 (UPI) Henery A. Kissinger, on his way to Peking, arrived here late today on the first leg of his trip. Mr. Kissinger did not talk with newsmen or issue any statement.

title: Billiards Matches Thursday
description: Willie Mosconi will face Steve Marino of Brooklyn in a dou bleheader pocket billiard match next Thursday at Rack EmUp Billiards, 10214 Jamaica Ave nue, Richmond Hill, Queens. Following the matches, which are scheduled for 4:30 P.M. and 7 P.M., Mosconi, a 15time world champion, will give a trickshot demonstration.

title: Six Asian Nations Accept Bids to World Cup Golf
description: Six Asian nations have ac cepted invitations to compete in the 19th World Cup golf tournament Nov.10 through 14 in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: New Investigative Report Forced Wilson to Quit as Mitchell Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The Nixon Administration abruptly forced the resignation yester day of Will R. Wilson, its chief enforcer of criminal laws, af ter it received a potentially em barrassing investigative report further implicating him with a Texas stock manipulator, quali fied sources said today.

title: Pirates Dispute Plate Umpire's Decision on Walk to Frank Robinson in 10th
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16Lousy damn umpire.

title: Conventional on the rise, different at top
description: The presumption of innocence whether in criminal trials or politics has never really caught on in this country. H. L. Mencken observed generation ago that a criminal de fendant is generally presumed guilty, a presumption that rises to the level of a certainty if he is acquitted. HoweverMencken's theory goes if he is lucky enough to be convicted, a presumption immediately attaches that the conviction was unjust or dishonest, probably both.

title: S. MISSISSIPPI BOWS TO OLE MISS, 20 TO 6
description: OXFORD, Miss., Oct. 16 (AP) Kenny Lyons ran 46 yards for one touchdown and turned early breaks into two more scores with key passes as Mis sissippi defeated Southern Mississippi, 206, today.

title: Connally Says U.S. Can Wait for Reform of World Currencies
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16  Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally indicated to day that the United States felt it had the time to allow agree ment on international currency reform to wait until other na tions came around more to the American view of what was needed.

title: Lewitzky in Dance Debut Here at 56
description: Most in the audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Friday night had never seen Bella Lewitzky dance. But it was a large audience sprin kled with dance names, and it was obvious that Miss Lewitzky's drawing power and reputation as one of the country's finest modern danc ers were as strong as ever.

title: Karen A. Waltz Is Wed
description: QUONSET POINT, R. Oct. 16  The marriage of Miss Karen Ann Waltz to Robert Franklin Browne, both of New York, took place here this afternoon in the Dixie Kiefer Memorial Chapel. The Rev. Frederick Gardner, a Baptist minister of West erly, performed the ceremony assisted by Capt. Robert Jones, Chaplain Corps, U.S.N. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Waltz of Westerly. Her husband's par ents are Mr. and Mrs. Henry Browne of Oklahoma City.

title: From a Prison Comes Fine Workmanship
description: THOMASTON, Me.  Thousands of tourists pass through this picturepost, card New England village (population; 3,000) each year, pausing to admire the mighty shade trees, now turned russet and gold, that line Main Street, the gracious white clapboard houses with their green shutters, or to catch the strains of organ music drifting from the 130yearold. St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Back in the nineteenthir ties, industryhungry states in the South, notably Mississip pi, undertook to finance in dustrial expansion via public bond issues. As early as 1936 Mississippi's Gov. Hugh White unwrapped what he termed a BAWI program (balance agriculture with industry).

title: Letters to the Editor
description: With so many landlords now pushing for coops and so many tenants trapped in unfamiliar situations, shouldn't the city set up a special office to advise and guide tenants concerning this complex end bewildering trend?

title: YORKERS SETTLES 2D LABOR DISPUTE
description: YONKERS, Oct. 16 Labor pains continued to harass har ness racing at Yonkers Race way, but as was the case the previous night, when the re opening was presented on schedule, today's trouble was settled in time to permit the second night's action.

title: PITCHER IS CALLED FINEST IN SERIES
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16Why, did Manager Earl Weaver, con founding almost every amateur strategist in America, let Jim Palmer bat in the fifth and seventh innings with his team behind, and then use a pinch hitter for him In the ninth in ning when the score was tied?

title: Feudal Ruler Wins 4th
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16 (AP)Feudal Ruler registered his fourth straight victory today at Calder Race Course.

title: WATERFRONT UNIT CITES CRIME DRIVE
description: The executive director and the former secretary of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor disagreed sharply yesterday about the extent of the commission's efforts against organized crime and its suc cess or failure in solving dock thefts.

title: Deborah Clark Bride of Editor
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 16Miss Deborah Hale Clark, who is descended from Thomas Truxtun, commodore of the frigate Constellation, was married here this afternoon to James Oliver Robbins, whose ancestor, Lewis Mor ris, was a signer of the Declaration of Independence.

title: How much will the sweeper charge and who will pay him?
description: (There Ain't No Such Thing as a Free Lunch). The Economic Strategy for Environmental Crisis. By Edwin G. Dolan. 128 pp. New York: Mit, Rinehart & Winston. Paper, $3.50.The world, we are being told, is going to hell in a shopping basket. Every trip to the supermarket speeds us toward the apocalypse; every gain in prosperity takes its toll in pollution. The useful and uplifting things around which industrial man has built his lifedetergents, Mus tangs, the Sunday New York Times turn out to choke his lakes, clog his lungs and overflow his vacant lots. The harsh lesson is that eco logical sanity may require an end to economic growth.

title: Holy Cross Wins, 2814
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 16 (AP)Joe Wilson ran 51, 1 and 57 yards for touchdowns today as he led Holy Cross to a 2814 victory over Boston University.

title: TransAtlantic Airlines To Try Again on Fares
description: International airlines ap pear to be moving toward a compromise agreement that may avert a threatened price war over transAtlantic air fares after Feb. 1.

title: Five of Cycle Club Ambushed in Car In Stratford, Conn.
description: STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 car containing five mem bers of the Huns, a Bridgeport motorcycle club, was sand wiched by two other cars on Route 1 and then shot up early today in what the Stratford police said was a wellplanned ambush.

title: Miss. Cecily Mary Piderit Married
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Child Jesus in Richmond Hill, Queens, was the setting yesterday at noon for the wedding of Miss Cecily Mary Piderit and Albert Joseph Brancaccio.

title: Pirates Attract the SecondGuessers
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16Most people were interested in find ing out about two particular moves the Pirates made today. Both came in the top of the 10th inning, when the Pirates had a good chance to score be fore the Orioles did.

title: Headmaster Is Honored By Football Foundation
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct 16 (UPI)Dr. Frank Learoyd Boyden, 92yearold headmaster emeritus a't Deer field Academy in Massachu setts, has been named to re ceive the National Football Foundation's Distinguished American Award.

title: LAND SALE PROFIT LINKED TO NIXON
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16  Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, said in a series concluded this week that President Nixon made about $180,000 profit in vesting in a Biscayne Bay, Fla., island and was the only mem ber of the land syndicate known to have made a profit.

title: About Pro Football
description: A Federal grand jury in Cleveland has been taking testimony for almost a year now in an effort to deter mine whether the constitu tional rights of the athletes are compromised in their dealings with pro football's owners. The grand jury was inspired by accusations of Bernie Parrish, a former Cleve land cornerback, whose new hook, They Call It a Game (Dial Press), has the establishment in a froth.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The abundance of traveler complaints voiced in letters and articles concerning French discourtesies toward American tourists moved the French Government and tour ist industry to change the situation. While not spec tacular, there has been some improvement. Furthermore, hotel gauging need not be a fact of life, as one reader wrote (Travel section, Sept. 26). Following a European tour last summer, I and other members of a group received refunds for hotel accommoda tions that fell short of a travel agency's elaborately brochured promises. How did that happen? We complained en masse.

title: Reader's Report
description: The word from Beau Harbor is negative, very negative. A palatial vacation compound on the shores of Lake Tahoe, it is directly in the path of a hurricane of anomie. All of the things you hear about on the David Susskind show are socked right into the solar plexus of the Baileys of Bal boa and Beau Harbor. Young Sara, a victim of drug abuse. Son Richie, an Army deserter to Canada. Son David, a cas ualty of the Berkeley riots. Plus idyllic Beau Harbor itself, caught in a crossrip of environ mentalists and developers. Plus acute tax and credit problems. Plus plain and fancy adultery.

title: Elizabeth Waltz, James Luce 3d Plan Marriage
description: EVERETT, Wash., Oct. 16 Miss Elizabeth Ann Waltz and James Oliver Luce 3d, whose father is board chair man and chief executive of ficer of the Consolidated Edi son Company of New York, plan to benlarried.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Nobody writes better of con voluted espionage than the pseudonymous Adam Hall, whose most recent novel along that line is THE WARSAW DOCUMENT (Doubleday, $5.95). Hall's style is interesting. He writes in a clear, direct manner, but his plotting is anything but that. Things are left unsaid and sometimes unexplained. Strands wiggle here and there, leading to a knotted mess that becomes un tied by some kind of presti digitation. The story is an elab orate chess game: check, sacri fice, discovered check, gambit material, predetermined open ing moves.

title: MRS. WILLIS GRADISON
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 16MrsJ Dorothy Benas Gradison, mother of Mayor Willis D. Gradison Jr. and the wife of former Vice Mayor Willis D. Gradison, died here yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: In reading Andrew M. Gree ley's article For a Black Vice President in 1972 (Sept. 19), I was particularly interested in learning that such a candi date must be a rather special kind of black man. Like other political analysts, Mr. Greeley is apparently able to set aside racial and ethnic qualifica tions, but he still considers sex a bona fide occupational qualification for higher office.

title: LIMONGELLO WINS TITLE IN BOWLING
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Oct. 16 Mike Limongello, a 27yearold bachelor from North Babylon, L. I., rallied today to win the Professional Bowlers Associa tion national championship at Paramus Bowl.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: Bullets Rout Warriors, 10893
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 (UPI) Earl Monroe and John Tresvant combined for 50 points while Fred Carter pulled down 15 re bounds as the Baltimore Bullets recorded a 10893 victory over the Golden State Warriors to night.

title: Great Mystery Captures Laurel Dash and Returns $13
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 16Great Mystery got his revenge today when he took the lead at the head of the stretch and went on to win the $23,400 Capitol Handicap by 1 lengths be fore a crowd of 13,102 at Laurel Race Course.

title: Amsterdam News Gains in Community
description: In the four months since group of black investors took over the ownership and opera tion.of The New York Amster dam News, there have been dramatic changes in format, dis tribution and editorial content. These factors have combined to increase the net paid weekly circulation from 80,000 in June to 98,000 at present, according to Clarence B. Jones, editor and publisher. With the exception of Muhammad Speaks, The Am sterdam News has long enjoyed a circulation larger than any of the other 175odd black com munitybased weeklies in the country.

title: News of the. Rialto
description: IT was One Of those rare days on Broadway last season. There they Weretheater, owners producers and managers, along with chieftains from the various labor and creative unions sitting together in harmony at the ??? table in Sardi's Belasco Room They exuded a sense of Satisfaction as they celebrated the conclusion of months of palaver Land the birth what they called thelimited gross contract.

title: Hawks Edge Stars, 32
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 17 (UPI)Stan Mikita scored the tying and decisive goals tonight to keep the Chicago Black Hawks undefeated with a 32 victory over the Minne sota North Stars.

title: Route II, Intrepid Tie at Harrisburg For Jump Laurels
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 Joe Fargis, one of the rookie United States Equestrian Team riders, and Moffat Dunlap, an experienced 30yearold were involved in an unusual tie to night in the first international jumping event of the Pennsyl vania National horse show.

title: W. VA. OUTSCORES E. CAROLINA 4421
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Oct. 16 (UPI)Pete Wood, a full back, scored three touchdowns and Brian Chiles, his relief man, tallied twice, as West Virginia capitalized on East Carolina's offensive mistakes today and defeated the Pirates, 4421.

title: Polo Finale at Bethpage
description: The final polo match of the Long Island Industrial Recrea tional Association season will take place at 3:30 this after noon, when Bethpage meets the Westbury team at Bethpage State Park.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The action of the Senate on Sept. 23 in voting 46 to 36 to allow chrome ore imports from Rhodesia, contrary to the 1968 economic sanction of the U.N. Security Council, is a terrible setback for the forces of human dignity. [Editorial Oct. 10.] It speaks of our concern for business interests and profits, rather than our concern for oppressed people. Senator Byrd's contention about dependence on Rus sia for chrome ore is a straw man, in view of the size of our stockpile, and ignores the larger threat to our se curity and to the world coming from the repression of blacks by whites in Rhodesia, in Attica, or anywhere.

title: V. S. Naipaul, Man Without A Society
description: LONDON. He seems to be in the throes of continuing identity crisis, painfully examining each marker of position, uncertain most of all about his own place. In conversation he switches continuously from first person I to second person you to third per son one all to indicate him self, V. (for Vidiadhar) S. (for Sura jprasad) Naipaul, authorparty of the first, second and third parts.

title: ARMS RACE OVER IN A GEORGIA AREA
description: SPARTA, Ga.Four elderly white men, sitting in front of a fire engine along the part of Route 15 where Sparta's threeblock shopping district is called Broad Street, talked un hurriedly about the timber trucks that passed by now and then.

title: Gardens
description: A HOUSE may have a variety of exposures, depending upon its relation to the compass. The planting of each exposure will vary with the amount of sunlight in winter and in summer and, the prevailing winds of each sea son. The accompanying photos illustrate how a particular property problem was solved for a north and south wall of a house.

title: NIGERIA CALLED FIT FOR LEADING ROLE
description: Dr. Elliot P. Skinner, former Ambassador to Upper Volta, has declared that Nigeria has largely recovered from its civil war and is new ready to play an important leader ship role in Africa. He added that Africans still needed to decolonize themselves, not ing that while black African countries were politically in dependent, the economies of Africa are still in expatriate hands.

title: CAMPAIGN OPENS IN EL SALVADOR
description: SAN SALVADOR, Oct. 15 The main candidates have been chosen and campaigning has begun for the presidential elec tions in February in El Salva dor, where the incumbent National Conciliation party, backed by the army, is being challenged by a coalition head ed by Christian Democrats.

title: 43 Alleged Gambling Places Raided in 5 Jersey Counties
description: NEWARK, Oct. 16A strike force of 171 law enforcement officials raised 43 alleged gam bling places in five New Jersey counties today.

title: Stamps,
description: TWOTHIRDS of the new Scott Standard Postage Stamp Catalogue is now at stamp stores. As re ported here weeks ago, Scott is revising its catalogue for mat with the justissued 1972 (128th) edition of the Stand ard, going to three volumes instead of two, with each volume to contain approxi mately 800 pages. Each will sell for $8.

title: MANAGING IS OUT, SAYS F. ROBINSON
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16 (AP) Frank Robinson of the Balti more Orioles said today he no longer wants to be a major league manager, but he added there was a chance he would change his mind.

title: Let Me Fall Before I Fly
description: Under a rosebush in a garden is a circus, elaborate and exquisite, with tiny liontamers, acrobats, bare back riders, clowns, even a fat lady two inches tall. All this exists for one child alone (a boy, actually, but the author refers to him only as

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The Martin Report makes numerous recommendations that, if enacted in their en tirety, will strengthen the in tegrity of our financial mar kets and promote the public interest. To reach these con clusions, one must understand the real issues with which it attempts to deal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Point of View article Grants to Home Buyers Needed to Spur Housing [Oct. 3] recalls what hap pened in New York City af ter World War 1. The city offered a 10year abatement on the tax on the land but not the house. At the end of the period a largo volume of taxes were returned to the city.

title: CITY'S FIRST BANK FOR SPERM OPENS
description: New York's first commercial humansperm bank, announced several weeks ago, opened offi cially Friday with semen sam ples from 18 men frozen in stainless steel tank and the phone already ringing with prospective clients.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: It is surprising that current discussions of the interna tional financial system, its crisis and need for reform do not revive some of the Bret ton Woods ideas of J. M. Keynes. Their implementation might avoid the kind of eco nomic disaster some fear. What were his central Ideas?

title: Gulfstream, With Choice Winter Dates, Wooing New York Horses
description: MIAMI, Oct. 16James Donn Jr., president of Gulfstream Park, is in New York this weekend on a novel mission. For the first time he is seeking out New York horsemen to race at Gulfstream. For the first time in Florida racing history, Donn's race track will be run ning the coveted midseason racing dates this winter.

title: Suit Against Time Inc. Lost By Man Labeled a Mobster
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 (AP)The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Cir cuit has ruled against Joseph Cerrito in his $7million libel suit against Time Inc.

title: Bergen
description: Undefeated Leonia, leading the National Division of the Bergen County Scholastic League with a 30 wonlost rec ord, mounted a powerful ground attack yesterday to defeat its neighborhood rival, Palisades Park, 380, for its fourth vic tory.

title: The only battle anyone w
description: Vietnam is beginning to be History rather than News. Perhaps future his torians, like author Don Oberdorfer, will describe the recent and current conflict there as the Second Indo china War, finding its causes as murkily dynastic as we now regard the Wars of the Spanish Succession. The Gulf of Tonkin affair already starts to seem as obscure and distant as the Agadir Crisis of two genera tions ago, and those famous victo ries at Khesanh and the Ashau Val ley become as dimly irrelevant as the Battle of Ratisbon or the storm ing of Pietermaritzburg.

title: Helen Martin Bond Is Engaged To Walter Taylor Reveley 3d
description: LYNCHBURG, Va., Oct. 16 Mr. and Mrs. G. Everett Bond have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Helen Martin Bond, to Walter Taylor Reveley 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. W. Taylor Reveley of Hampden Sydney, Va.

title: Fines Listed for Cabbiesi Who Fail to Start Meters
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the city's Taxi Commission, yesterday listed stiffer penal ties for taxi drivers who fail to activate their meters when passengers enter their cabs.

title: Growth Is Issue in Riverhead
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I.  Ex pansion of this largely agri cultural town seems to be shaping up as the major is sue in the race for Super visor.

title: Et Al.
description: As books on foreign peoples go, the Irish win the quantity prize. Perhaps there's a big audience for them, perhaps writers know a setpiece when they see one, perhaps the tax laws are inviting. Anyhow, here is another by veteran his torian Richard O'Connor (who has the name for it, although he also wrote The German Americans)., It's a good guide to the people, with endless ad vice on Irish hospitality, Irish drinking, Irish blarney. It's the kind of book that leads light headed reviewers to say, Sure and it's a darlin placeonly that would be paddywhackery (a puton of superIrishness practiced by some of the natives and the Irish Tourist Bureau). The book finds the author in a garrulous, enter taining mood with a strong personal involvement in his subject.

title: 119104 Setback 2d in Row
description: Life these days in the Na tional Basketball Association is not the romantic, winning ad venture that it used to be for the Knickerbockers. To the surprise and distaste of the players, their coach and most of 19,296 fans at Madison Square Garden last night, the Knicks were routed by the Los Angeles Lakers, 119104.

title: An OldTime Cider Mill to Visit
description: CLINTON, N. Y.Harold Went worth is making cider at his cider mill again this fallthe same way his fathqr made cider before him and his father's father before that. On st treelined side street in this upstate village the sount of ancient but well maintained machinery comes through the wide open doors of the Clinton Cider Mill for a few weeks every fall as apples from the nearby countryside gre squeezed to give up the traditional drink of American harvest time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The U.S. should either take a firm stand in favor of keeping Taiwan in the U.N. or desist from halfhearted dithering which only serves to em: barrass our allies. If we threatened to cut off appropriations for the U.N., that organization would have to heed our view or face bankruptcy (we pay over 30 per cent of the budget).

title: Miss Maguire Becomes Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 16In St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here today, Miss Patricia Amanda Ma guire was married to Parker Kalloch Murray by the Rev. Thomas P. Guinan, who also performed the nuptial mass.

title: Photography
description: A. NEW model Nikon, the F2, has recently been introduced by Ehren reich PhotoOptical In dustries, Inc., distributor of Nikon cameras and equip ment in this country. De signed so that most of the existing lenses and other ac cessories currently available for use with the Nikon F can also be used with the F2, the new model is designed to increase ease of handling with a hinged back that does not have to be removed to load the camera. It also has a new shutter that offers a range of speeds from 1/2000 of a second to a full 10 sec onds, and it provides a choice of six different, instantly in terchangeable viewfinders an eye level finder, two dif ferent meter/finders, a waist level finder, a 6X focusing finder and a throughthelens action finder.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: PHILADELPHIA  Railroad bankruptcy lawyers, a flour ishing breed in the nineteen thirties, when more than three dozen United States carriers were in the throes of reorganization, had dwin dled to a scarce species by the time the Penn Central came along to challenge their skill.

title: DUKE SETS BACK N. C. STATE, 4113
description: DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 16 (UPI) Ernie Jackson scored two touchdowns today to spark Duke in a 4113 victory over North Carolina State.

title: Local
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 16 Joe Gaffney completed scor ing passes of 55 and 53 yards to lead Brooklyn Prep to a 226 victory over Long Island Lutheran today. Alan Ding felder picked off one of Gaf fney's aerials and returned it 72 yards for the Lutheran score.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Wilson Carey McWilliams ap pears to have read Washing ton Plans an Aggressive War hastily at best. Otherwise, he could not have written that we proposed trials for those re sponsible for the Vietnam war.

title: 2 in Suffolk On Ballot Against Aspland
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I.Suf folk County's growing traf fic in hard drugs has been a leading chief issue raised by two young lawyers running against District Attorney George J. Aspland.

title: Miss Higgins Is Betrothed
description: DULUTH, Minn., Oct 16 The engagement of Miss Eliz abeth Butler Higgins to Lieut. LeRoy Lewis Little, 3d., U.S. A.F., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Raymond J. Higgins, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Little of Pittsburgh.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: The reason that all the young people understood One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest and felt no need to ask questions is that they recog nized Nurse Ratched as the system, the disturbed patients as disenfranchised citizens and Randle Patrick McMur phy as an involved militant who tried to correct a wrong ful practice against human beings.

title: Rizzo and Rival Debate in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA. Oct 16 Former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo held his temper and his lead this week at a critical juncture in the Philadel phia mayoralty campaign.

title: LI Official Asks More Hotlines For Youths
description: MANHASSET, L. T.Mich ael J. Tully Jr., North Hemp stead Town supervisor, has called on local governments throughout the United States to assist in the establishment or area hotlines to offer distressed youths a new safety conduit.

title: Mitchel Field Plan Decried
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I. Under a merciless assault by bulldozers, steamrollers and other huge yellow pieces of earthmoving equipment, the vast acreage of Mitchel Field is beginning to resemble some distant planet.

title: Mary Elizabeth Switzer Dies; Retired Official of H. E. W., 71
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Miss Mary Elizabeth Switzer, who retired in February, 1970, as administrator of the Social and Rehabilitation Service of the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare, died this morning in George Washington Hospital. She was 71 years old.

title: Women Calling for Better Jobs
description: COMMACK, L. I.For the halfmillion women in Long Island's millionmember labor force, work offers a mixed blessing.

title: Airgentine Nationalism
description: BUENOS AIRES  After battling a rising tide of na tionalism for more than a year, the foreign business community in Argentina be lieves it now sees firm land. Whether foreign businessmen can reach the shore is anoth er matter, however.

title: Lesley Schwab, Edward Forman Married on L. I.
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Oct. 16  Miss Lesley Bliss Schwab, daughter of Mrs. William Rogers Deering of Laurel Hollow, Syosset, and of Herman C. Schwab of Oyster Bay, was married here today to Edward Joseph For man, son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Forman of Rock ville Centre.

title: RoyalsCeltics Game Postponed: Wet Court
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 16 (UPI) The scheduled National Basketball Association game between the Cincinnati Roy als and Boston Celtics tonight was postponed because of a wet floor. No new date was announced.

title: A KNOCK OR A POKE FOR A HIT
description: I wish J. Anthony Lukas (How Mel Allen Started a Lifelong Love Affair, Sept. 12) had listened to more pres entday baseball broadcasters before criticizing Frank Mes sers blandness or Phil Rizzu to's uneasy relationship with the English language. Per haps these men are not so vivid as the ones Mr. Lukas recalls from his youth, but think they are probably the best today.

title: Square Generation, Blum Up, Takes Mermaid Stakes by Neck at Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY Oct. 16 (AP)The Cisley Stable's Square Generation won the 24th running of the $30,275 Merniaid Stakes at Atlantic City by a neck over Dresden Doll today.

title: Drivers Reporting Loose Engine Mounts
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16Miss Manette Charney was about to Iturn off Northern Boulevard in Manhasset, L. I., last Monday when her 1967 Chevrolet sud denly lurched forward and then began to accelerate back ward into the crowded high way.

title: NEM ALFA GTV SCORES ON COAST
description: MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 16 Driving with superb skill and a touch of luck, Horst Kwech of Valley Stream, L. I., won for ALFA Romeo today the Trans American Championship for sports sedans with engines of less than 2.5 liters.

title: Chinese to Play in Canada
description: NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario (AP)A badminton team from Communist China will arrive Nov. 12 for a series of exhibi tion games against top Cana dian players.

title: U.S. Ship Rescues 7 Seamen
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 16 (Reu ters) The American Astro naut, a container ship, today rescued seven injured seamen from the mouldering hull of the British freighter Precious Pearl in the South China Sea.

title: The Cup of Horrors
description: LONDONIn the near future, The European Foot ball Union, otherwise known as Eufa, will have to pass judgment on the refusal of Ajax of Amsterdam, holder of the European Cup, to go to Montevideo, Uruguay, to contest the intercontinental soccer championship against Nacional, winner of the South American Cup.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 10The poli ticians and editorial Writers have been telling us recently, how much Dean Acheson Will be missed in Washing ton, but they haven't told us Why. The reason he will be missed is that he told Presidents what he honestly thought about the realities of power in the world andnot what they wanted to hear.

title: Cambodian Decree Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 16 (Reuters)The Cambodian Government decided today to abolish the National Assembly and rule by decree, authorita tive sources reported.

title: A New EgyptianSyrian Unity Agreement Indicates Libya Is Out of Step With Her Two Federation Allies
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16  The Libyan regime, headed by Col. Muam mar elQaddafi, seems to have fallen out of step with its two allies in the sixweekold Fed eration of Arab Republics.

title: Sending Hamlet Up the Flagpole BOB
description: DEAR JERRY: JUST got back from the affiliates meeting in the Bahamas. Remem bered I promised to get back to you by the first and must apologize for the delay. However, as I am sure you are aware, the television business is pretty much up in the air over the commer cial and critical success of The Six Wives of Henry the Eighth. It has all the networks, including ours, go ing through a complete re appraisal of our programing, which is my reason for writ ing to you.

title: Gardens
description: PLANS are now avail able for an indoor plant growing device designed by Cornell University. Though primarily designed for use in school rooms, the plans can be adapted for plant growing in the home, office or elsewhere.

title: A brave book in the new mode of the old
description: For more than a decade poets have been dismantling the old traditions. They have experimented with surreal images and new subject matters. They have burrowed deep into their per sonal anguish, and deeper into the calamities of American public life. It seemed that some new and per manent shape had arisen in American letters in the work of poets as dif ferent as Allen Ginsberg, John Ash bery, W. S. Merwin, Gary Snyder. But experiments and moral anguish are exhausting. The recent nostalgia that everyone is talking about, for the graceful, private, paranoid and white years of the fifties, has not left poetry untouched. Lately voices have been heardJames Merrill, Rich ard Howard, Daryl Hinemaking a claim again for rhyme and iambic pentameter; for poems about traveling in Italy; for lengthy elegant phrases, raising life out of the crude realities into a saraband of sunlit forms and airy monologues.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: MUCH of the heavy overcast that darkened pros pects for Phase Two of the Administration's economicstabilization program lifted last week, but some formidable clouds of uncertainty re mained. That's the principal reason for the very diver gent reactions of the financial markets since President Nixon disclosed the broad outlines for the next part his inflationcontrol blueprint 10 days ago.

title: SABRES ROUTED BY CANADIENS, 93
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 16 (UPI) Yvan Cournoyer, Marc Tardif and Henri Richard scored two goals each tonight as the Mont real Canadiens routed the Buf falo Sabres, 93.

title: TOLEDO NEEDS RALLY TO WIN 29TH IN ROW
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Oct. 16 (UPI) Toledo trailed Western Mich igan, 217, in the third quarter today but staged a comeback on the passing of its record setting quarterback, Chuck Ealey, and won 3524, extend ing the longest winning streak in college football to 29 games.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The current antagonism of organ ized labor toward the N.E.P. may mark a significant change in its strategy for improving the welfare of the working man.

title: Young Wins Walk Crown; Colorado Is Team Victor
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) Larry Young, bronze medalist in the 1968 Olympic Games, continued his preparations for the 1972 Olympics with a vic tory today in the senior na tional 40kilometer walk.

title: The World
description: MOSCOWSoviet rela tions with Egypt have rarely been as smooth as imagined in the West. This has been one of the primary lessons of the serialized memoirs of the Nasser era now being pub lished by one of the late Gamal Abdel Nasser's closest cronies, newspaper editor Mohammed Hassanein Heikal.

title: An elder statesman remembers
description: At 85at last almost com pletely withdrawn from public life  David BenGurion now spends most of his time speak ing to Israeli youngsters about the past and future (the present, he often remarks, does not in terest him), and editing his di aries which are said to be ex tensive. In the past five years he has published three major works of reminiscence and per sonalized history. The present English volume  the Hebrew original appeared in 1969  is the second of these.

title: PALMER, WITH 131, KEEPS PARIS LEAD
description: SAINTNOMLABRETECHE, France, Oct. 16Arnold Palmer shot a sevenunderpar 65 today over this 6,947yard suburban Paris course for a 36hole 131 and a threestroke lead over Gary Player in the Lancome Trophy tournament. For the six other golfers in this $28,000 in vitation tournament, there is little point in showing up for tomorrow's final round.

title: Nassau North
description: Jericho hurdled a major road block on its journey to the top of North Shore Division III when it handed Westbury its first defeat of the season yes terday, 3522. The victory left Jericho at the top of the divi sion with a 30 record.

title: Case in Maryland
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Oct. 16A local prosecutor who termed a pending arson charge against Brown a fabrication is scheduled to be tried Mon day for contempt of court.

title: Lindsay Backs Murphy
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 16 Mayor Lindsay, on a Political tour of Indiana today, was questioned by reporters about the action by Commissioner Murphy, against Chief Seedman.

title: TEXAS TROUNCED BY ARKANSAS, 317
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 16 (UPI)Arkansas quarterback, Joe Ferguson, riddled Texas's defense with three touchdown passes and ran for fourth score today in a 317 victory over 10thranked Texas that moved the Razorbacks into first place in the Southwest Conference.

title: Youth Shot by Detroit Police Awarded $400,000 by Court
description: DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP)  Ulysses Lawson, 20 years old, whose left leg was amputated after a policeman wounded him in the Detroit riots in 1967, has been awarded $400,000 dam ages by a special Circuit Court mediation panel.

title: Reader's Report
description: Frank Yerby, a specialist in the flamboyant costume novel, turns here to the ancient West African kingdom of Dahomey and devotes to it a wellagi tated mixture of romantic bra vura and historical fact. The latter comes from scholars and travelers who have been fasci nated by Dahomey's intricate culture. The former is Mr. Yer by's special patent. Thus, a young village chief named Ny asanu adheres to the ideas of romantic love, fair play and similar sidelines of the roman tic Yerby hero. At the same time, his rise and fall illus trates the customs and folk ways of his country: the rites of manhood and marriage; the feudal system; war.

title: WALLACE AROUSES FEARS IN FLORIDA
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Oct. 16 The spectre of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama possibly winning 70 or more of Florida's 131 delegates to the 1972 Demo cratic National Convention has many Florida Democrats clam oring for an overhaul of the state's new Presidential pri mary law.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: The description of two new theaters in The Times recent ly mentions only stairs and escalators as ways of reach ing the auditoriums. Does this mean that persons with phys ical disabilities due to birth defects, paralysis, amputa tion or stroke will not be able to attend these theaters? Philharmonic Hall is already difficult or Impossible for some disabled persons and a recent visit to the Ziegfeld Theater suggests that the ap parent lack of elevators there may make it out of bounds also.

title: CORNELL SUBDUES HARVARD BY 2116
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 16 Cornell proved it had some football aces to go along with Ed Marinaro today. A come back team, the Ithacaws rallied after Harvard had a 10.0 lead in the first quarter and defeat ed their Ivy League foe from Cambridge by 2116 today.

title: Preps
description: ANDOVER, Mass., Oct. 16 Andover ran its winning streak to 15 games, three this season, by edging Lawrenceville, 148, today. It was the third loss in four, games for Lawrenceville.

title: Preps
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 16Riverdale, led by the of fense of Ron Corinaldi and the defense of Mark Tramo, easily, won its fourth straight game today as it topped Stony Brook, 326. Corinaldi scored 16 points and gained 82 yards rushing. Tramo, a sophomore lineback er, led his team with 11 tackles.

title: Local
description: Woody Brown's 80yard kick off return in the fourthquarter gave Wingate a 127 upset vic tory over Tilden at Tilden Field yesterday.

title: Local
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 16 Dennis Vattaglino scored two touchdowns on runs today to mark Xavier's 156 victory over Eastern Military Academy. Xavier and Eastern are both 21 after their first Metropoli tan Football League game.

title: Et Al.
description: A philosophical examination of the tendency to escape from freedom in contemporary society. Pfaff discusses such burdens of modern man as alienation, anomie, loss of community and sees in them a fear of freedom, a flight into irrationality, a seeking of choiceless security. He asks for radical liberalism, which, through the state, will make the reforms necessary to easing social tensions. For the indi vidual, he advises freedom, although he knows that places a man in bleak loneli ness and in danger of con fusion from infinite choice. Intelligently argued, aphoristi cally written, but a not entirely effective rearguard action in behalf of traditional liberalism.

title: Morocco Acts to End Grievances That Led to Attempted Coup
description: RABAT, Morocco, Oct. 13 Morocco is carrying on a vig orous reform program, placing emphasis on weeding out cor ruption in the public adminis tration, following the abortive coup d'etat against King Hassan II in July.

title: NEWSMAN IN PRAGUE IMPRISONED AS SPY
description: VIENNA, Oct. 16 (UPI)A Czech newspaperman has been sentenced to 10 years imprison ment on charges of spying for the United States Embassy in Prague, the Czechoslovak press agency saki day:

title: U.S. JEWS TO FIGHT POVERTY IN ISRAEL
description: VIENNA, Oct. 16A multi milliondollar American Jewish aid program to fight poverty in Israel was announced here this week by Louis D. Horo witz, a high official of the American Jewish Joint Distri bution Committee.

title: Less Is Moleinwnmies van der Rohe Less Is a BoreRohe, at Venturi
description: ROBERT VENTURI'S favorite place to visit is Las Vegas. He doesn't go there to gamble, and he doesn't like to drink or go to nightclubs. What he likes about Las Vegas is its architecture.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Letters to the Editor

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In Anthony Ripley's Oct. 12 report age Buffalo Hunt 1971: Routine Dis posal of Unwanted Game, one senses why we are making so little progress toward a more pacific world. We are treated by example of the sovereign state of Arizona to a system which supports the needs of socalled sports men to destroy living creatures.

title: DEERFIELD DEFEATS CHESHIRE, 56 TO 7
description: DEERFIELD, Mass., Oct. 16 Deerfield Academy rolled up 42 points in the first half be fore easing off in running its record to 30 with a 566 vic tory over Cheshire Academy today. A total of seven players scored a minimum of 6 points each for Deerfield.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MARION, Mass., Oct. 16 Tabor rallied in the second half today to defeat Choate, 2114. Brian Donnelly caught a fourth quarter scoring pass from quar terback Gary Livesay for Tabor's winning points.

title: It's Already Spring on Seventh Avenue, and the Chinese Influence Is Strong
description: It will be a while before bosky breezes blow and crocuses appear, but to the fashion world it is already spring. The rites are being performed in Seventh Avenue showrooms and in an occasional hotel ballroom as designers unveil next season's wares to store buyers.

title: PARLEY DISCUSSES LIFEDEATH ETHICS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 16A panel representing health, law and religion concluded today that society lacked the rules and guidelines it needed to deal with the new powers over life and death that society now, holds.

title: Stamps
description: CHARLES DE GAULLE, symbol of French resistance in World War II and later President of France died about one year ago, on Nov. 9, 1970. Although in his will be expressed a desire that no honors be extended to him after his death, and he was buried in the small town of ColombeylesDeuxEglises, where he had lived after his retirement in 1969, France will now issue four commemorative stamps in his memory, divided by a label bearing the Cross of Lorraine.

title: MET'S BEQUEST
description: With reference to the arti cle, The New Man at the Met (Sept. 12), Jane P. Boutwell states that Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s be quest of $5million to theMet ropolitan Opera was a sign of approval of the Rockefeller family to Goeran Gentele's appointment as new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Susanne Carr Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Carr of Wagga Wagga, Australia, have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Susanne Gai Carr, to John Akin, Howell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howell of Potters villa, N. J. Mr. Howell was graduated from the North wood School in Lake Placid, N. Y., and from Babson In stitute of Business Adminis tration in Massachusetts. His marriage was terminated by divorce:

title: PENN STATE DRUBS SYRACUSE, 31 T00
