description: SYRACUSE, Oct. 16Penn State's undefeated Nittany Lions reached out a big paw for the Lambert Trophy today and just about put the silver token into their trophy case with an unusually easy 310 victory over Syracuse.

title: Two Williamsburg Remembrances
description: I've been working recently on a more or less autobiographical article, describ ing, among other remembrances, my ar rival in Hollywood from Brooklyn 35 years ago, and I wrote that one of the first things that struck me when I ar rived was the sight of the Los Angeles streets that I had seen so many times in the backgrounds of the old tworeel comedies.

title: Body Found in New Jersey Identified as That of Sailor
description: UNION TOWNSHIP, N. J., Oct. 16 (AP)  The body of shot and casterated man that was found in woods in this Ocean County community Oct. 2 was identified today as that of Navy Yeoman 3d Cl. John A. Reinisch, 23 years old, of Granite Springs, N. Y. The state police said Mr. Reinisch had last been seen hitchhiking in his hometown on Sept. 26. He was headed for his ship in Newport, R. I.

title: IOWA STATE TOPS KAN. STATE, 240
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 16 (AP)Dean Carlson threw to Ike Harris for two long touch downs and riddled Kansas State's pass defense for 235 yards today in pacing Iowa State to a 240 victory.

title: Child to the Schachters
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schach ter on Oct. 4 in the Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Schachter is the former Miss Hindy Lauer of New York. The child is named Amanda Cath leen. Her father teaches at the Brooklyn Technical High School.

title: South Korea's Reaction SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 16Le Nak Sun, South Korea's
description: Commerce  Industry Minister, said today of South Korea's agreement with the United States on limiting annual ex ports of manmade fibers, We are not satisfied, although our agreement is not unfavorable compared with those signed by other countries.

title: TO OUR READERS
description: Every Sunday The New York Times includes a sep arate section, 1A, on Brooklyn, Queens and Long Island. It contains news and features of interest these areas and appears in copies distributed Brooklyn, Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Blues Rout Red Wings, 92
description: ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (UPI) Wayne Connelly scored two goals tonight to lead the St. Louis Blues to a 92 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: MUSKIE SUFFERS SETBACK. IN PARTY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine appears to have suffered a political setback this week when he intervened unsuccess fully in a contest for the chair manship of the Credentials Committee at the 1972 Demo cratic National convention.

title: STUDENTS GETTING WARNING ON JOBS
description: College career counselors are telling students in this third year of job shortages for col lege graduates to beware the first job, according to leaders in the counseling field.

title: UNDEFEATED ALFRED BEATS HOBART, 2821
description: GENEVA, N. Y., Oct. 16 (AP) Three touchdowns in the fourth quarter carried unbeaten Alfred University to a 2821 vic tory over Hobart College today. It was the Saxons fifth victory and the Statesmen's first defeat after three triumphs.

title: Passion for Truth
description: Professor Emeritus Simon S. Kuznets of Harvard,.the second American to receive the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, was the leading figure in developing the national income amounts through which countries throughout the world measure changes in economic activity and the distribution of income.

title: Land ho!
description: The Alaskan land claims bill got a boost toward pas sage earlier this year when several of the major oil companies plus the consor tium organized to build the proposed Prudhoe BayVal dez pipeline put their con siderable lobbying muscle behind a claims settlement. The industry was concerned that unless the issue was decided, the natives might be able to get a court in junction halting construc tion of the line, which would cross land claimed by the natives. The pros pect of lengthy litigation was enough to get an in fluential segment of the oil industry behind a settle ment. The industry appar ently has not urged any particular settlement for mula, but instead has urged Congressmen to get on with the job of making that determination them selves.

title: FOUNDATION. CITES 9 FOR AIDING RETARDED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Nine persons whose work has helped deal with the problem of mental retardation were named recipi ents today of 1971 Kennedy International Awards totaling $120,000.

title: TurbinePowered Boat Goes on View
description: The first gas turbinepow ered production sport fish erman will go on public dis play today at Yacht Haven, Stamford, Conn. The 48foot fiberglass Pacemaker craft is powered by two of Ford Motor Company's, new marine turbine engines.

title: Housing Debated in Oyster Bay
description: Lowcost housing and tax reform are the major issues involved in the fourway race in Oyster Bay for Town Supervisor and for four of the six Seats on the Town Council.

title: It's Not How You Play The Game, But What Pill You Take
description: DRUG usage is quickly becoming as common among athletes as the wearing of white sweat socks. Tom Ecker, a former college track coach who has written six books on sports, believes it's a great rarity today for someone to achieve athletic success who doesn't take drugs. My own experience as an athlete, coach and journalist would tend to corroborate Ecker's claim.

title: Hong Kong Predicts the Textile Pact Will Bring Heavy Losses
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 16Gov ernment officials and textile in terests reacted today with re sentment and predictions of great economic damage from the agreement that Hong Kong representatives concluded yes terday in Washington, limiting growth of the colony's noncot ton textile exports for a five year period to 7.5 per cent year.

title: Rap Brown W ounded Here In Shootout After Holdup
description: H. Rap Brown, the fugitive black militant leader, and two policemen were shot early yes terday morning in a gun battle following the armed robbery of a West Side bar.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  EQUITY (1) the quality of being fair or impartial; fairness; impar tiality; the equity of Salomon. The Random House Dic tionary definition of equity is as good a description as any of the task will face tile Pay Board and price Commission selected by President Nixon to adminis ter the Phase Two controls of his Economic Stabilization program.

title: The Natives May Win One: The Great Alaskan RealEstate Deal
description: THE jet flight from Anchorage to Kotzebue is a twohour trip in a time machine. Shiny Boeings whisk the traveler from the sprawl ing subdivisions and shabby trailer courts, the countless usedcar lots and the budding patch of skyscrapers that mark Middle America's firmest toehold in the far north. They plunk him down amid the litter and ram shackle dwellings of a weather beaten village perched precariously on a sand spit jutting into frigid Kotzebue Sound. The trip spans the chasm between a quintessentially American city in the making, where the inhabitants live much like Amer icans elsewhere, and a community about twice as old as New York (having been continuously inhabited for at least 600 years), where the people still live on the animals of land and sea and only gradually are shedding traditions rooted in the Stone Age.

title: StoneAge Tribe in Philippines Is Imperiled
description: To the growing list of en dangered speciesalligators, bald eagles, whooping cranes and the likeis now added a primitive tribe of man, the StoneAge Tasadays of the rain forests on the island of Mindanao in the Philippines.

title: Capt. Eliahu BenDror, 70, Palestine Military Figure
description: Capt. Ellahu BenDior, noted military figure in Pales tine and in Israel's war of in dependence, died in Israel on Thursday after undergoing surgery. He was 70 years old.

title: SNEAD, WITH A 206, LEADS IN CLUB GOLF
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 16 (AP)  Complaining about his putting, Sam Snead slipped to a 36, 3874 today but clung to a onestroke lead with a 54 hole total of 206 after the third round of the Professional Golf ers Association's $100,000 club pro championship.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Andrew Greeley includes among the benefits to be ac crued with the choice of a black Vice President the ex ample to be set for the other presumably less enlightened major powers. It should be noted that the French, who have always been less self conscious than Americans in racial matters, have long had black representation in the French Assembly and for much of the tenure of Presi dent de Gaulle had a black man from French Guiana first in succession to the presi dency.

title: Telephone Co. to Give Scores During Series
description: New York's baseball fans may get the latest World Se ries scores by dialing 637 1212, the telephone com pany's time bureau.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIIf the Vietcong had been doing this well after six months, they would have considered it remarkably good start The foreign, diplomat was talk ing about the Mukti Bahini (Liberation Forces), the Ben gali insurgents who are fighting for the indepen dence of East Pakistan, which they have named Bangle Desh (Bengal na tion).

title: In Buffalo, Anxiety Over the Mill
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y. They just couldn't  they wouldn't  ever close the mill down and move out.

title: East German Assails Peking as AntiCommunist
description: BONN; Oct. 16East Ger many's leading party ideologist, Kurt Hager, has denounced the Chinese leadership of Mao Tse tung as antiCommunist, it was learned here today.

title: Danish modern is classic
description: Scandinavian modern may have passed from American favor, but the furniture of Danish designer Hans Wegner still stands in museums around the world. In his own home on the outskirts of Copenhagen, Wegner supplies some of the pieces to the puzzle of why Danish design never quite conquered American hearis. The house is as finely modeled and detailed as his furniture. It is im posing yet calm, assured yet al most ordinary. Proportions and craftsmanship, however, set the house apart. These are subtle qualifies. But in a nation tired of gimmicks, whose youth seem more interested in domes in the wilderness than joining the rat race, one wonders whether Wegner hadn't wrestled with and resolvedsome of our con flicts years before. The brick columns reoccur inside, too, acting as supports for hanging shelves and cabinets. The cabinets are doubledsided: on this side is writing desk; on the other, storage for stereo components. This arrangement separates the rooms without disturb ing the open quality of the house. Fir planks emphasize the ceiling slope and contrast with the white brick columns. The oblong teak dining table and chairs, the chaise wrapped in furs and the arm chair show the diversity of Wegner's art.

title: Ontario Center is Formed To Aid U.S.Canada Rapport,
description: A conference center for de veloping new avenues of under standing and cooperation be tween the peoples of Canada and the United States has been established in Niagaraonthe Lake, Ontario, a historic fron tier town that was once a battleground between the two countries.

title: Memoir Terms Kennedy Role in Diem Coup a Blunder
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 Lyndon B. Johnson says in his White House memoirs that the Kennedy Administration's role in thil overthrow of President Ngo Dinh Diem was a serious blunder that caused political chaos in South Vietnam and be came a principal factor in Mr. Johnson's subsequent commit meat of ground combat forces there.

title: The ad Diary Of a anhattan Ecologist
description: IT started with reports of excessive fallout, clouds moving across the country in 1962. Strontium 90, a radioactive substance, was sifting out of the sky where we had placed it with several impressive explosions. It was settling on the grass of Wyo ming, Ohio, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, and the cows chewing their cuds were consuming dangerous levels of a cancerproducing, leuke miarelated chemical substance, and it was glowing, or so I imagined, in the milk my child was drinking three or four times a day. Sitting in the playground, a group of mothers to gether, we looked up at the sky and, like Chicken Little, we felt frightened. Garlic, said my mother, a clove or two around the neck can't hurt. I thought of walking about under neath a lead parasol, and then some lady, whose husband was a radiolo gist at a nearby hospital, said that powdered milk was kept on the shelves for months and would have been made before the cows had a chance to consume the grass beneath the current chemical rains.

title: Music
description: W HILE hovering Cas sandras were pre dicting a bloodbath to accompany the succession of Goeran Gentele to the crown of Rudolf Bing, a scheme was already afoot to divest the new general manager of half of his pow er. Author of the plan was Gentele himself, who recom mended that the Metropoli, tan Opera be granted a mu sic directorthe first in the history of the company, To get the man he wanted, Gen tele agreed to share equal artistic responsibility. Only under these terms, a virtual splitting of the kingdom, would Rafael Kubelik come to the Met. The contract was signed. Everybody was non plussed, but when the shock wore off jubilation set in, and the Voices of doom were silent.

title: HEATH SEES SIGNS OF A TRADE WAR
description: LONDON, Oct. 16Prime Minister Heath said today that drastic American economic policies had sent rough winds blowing across the world of trade and finance.

title: Egypt Indicates Soviet Pledged LongRange Assistance in Talks
description: CAIRO, Oct. 16The Egyp tian leadership implied today that President Anwar elSadat received longrange Sovietaid commitments during his talks in Moscow this week.

title: City Council of Churches Appears to Be Divided Over Relevancy
description: The Council of Churches of the City of New York has suf fered a steep decline in income over the last few years and appears to be divided over a question of relevancy.

title: Youth Admits Police Theft
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Oct. 16 (UPI)Larry R. Vande Pol, 21 years old, has pleaded guilty to stealing $5 from the conces sion stand at police head quarters. He was a frequent visitor at the headquarters as a student at Grand Valley State College and a major in police administration and public serv ices.

title: National Notes
description: The C5A is the largest air plane in the world. It weighs 700,000 pounds, requires 28 Wheels to support its bulk on the ground and four huge Gen eral Electric jet engines to lift it into the air. Last week, the United States Air Force grounded its entire fleet of 47 C5A'sand when they will fly again remains uncertain.

title: Endorsement Ban Held Factor in 2 L.I. Races
description: Democrats and Conserv atives in the neighboring Suffolk County Towns of Smithtown and Brookhaven, aided by a ban on cross party endorsements, are buoyed this year as they try to wrest control from the entrenched Republicans.

title: Letters
description: In his sketch.(The Bergdorf Goodman Story, Sept. 26), the eminent biographer Ste phen Birmingham failed to do his research thoroughly.

title: JANE BLALOCK'S 141 LEADS WACO GOLF
description: WACO, Tex., Oct. 16 (OFT Jane Blalock backed an open inground 70 with a second round 71 today to take a twostroke lead in the Ladies Professional Golfing Associa tion's $20,000 Quality First Classic.

title: Optimism of Experts Grows for JetportatSea Here
description: Five years ago, such a project would have been considered silly, Donald H. Elliott, head of the City Plan ning Commission, said last week., But now there's some optimism that it can be done.

title: Ohio State Tops Indiana
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 16 (UPI)Ohio State, its rush ing attack stifled for most of the game, used its passing game to register a 277 victory over Indiana today  its third in a row in the Big Ten.

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: J. Anthony Lukas's article brought back pleasant memo ries. There were many kids in my neighborhood, Nostrand Avenue and Kings Highway in Brooklyn, who referred to Red Barber, not as the Old Redhead, but rather as Pur ple Hairdresser. Another was so wrapped up with the old Dodgers that he was known as Harry Ebbets. I doubt that anyone remembers his real surname.

title: Reader's Report
description: The Sepoy Rebellion of 1857 has everything a bloodand thunder novelist dreams of: sus pense, violence unending, a gaudy period background. Hardly a plot is needed; the lapses of the East India Com pany provide all that is nec essary in the way of motiva tion and continuity. With such natural advantages, the pseu donymous William Clive can hardly missand he doesn't.

title: Nightlife in Havana before Castro
description: Three Trapped Tigers is a re markable book. I doubt a funnier book has been written in Spanish since Don Quixote. Granted, that is not saying much. Literature in Spanish has not been noted for its humor. Yet this, precisely, is one of the book's strongest points: it has savagely refreshed an often porten tously solemn heritage. It is also one of the most inventive novels that has come out of Latin America, and that is saying a great deal. The in ventiveness of LatinAmerican fic tion since Borges is by now (one would hope) fairly widely recog nized.

title: Miss Doyle Bride of C. P. Kirchen
description: SHERIBURNE, N. Y., Oct. 16Miss Mary Elaine Doyle, daughter of Mr., and Mrs. Harold Doyle, was married here this afternoon to Chris topher Paul Kirchen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Kirchen of Fayetteville, Ark. The Rev. Lawrence Bassney performed the ceremony in St. Malachy's Roman Catho lic Church.

title: Agnew Gets a Rousing Welcome on Arrival in Greece
description: ATHENS, Oct. 16Vice Presi dent Agnew returned to the land of his forefathers today, to the most elabbrate cere monial display the Greek capi tal has known since the military coup d'etat of April, 1967.

title: How Japanese Run a Business
description: Why is it that Japanese firms are so often seen as pricing in unfair, irration al, uneconomic ways? Japanese companies are com monly accused of dumping into world markets. Yet it is clear that it Japanese compa nies were in fact persistently dumping, they could hardly continue to exist for long periods, much less finance their very rapid and contin ued growth.

title: JASPER RUNNERS WIN AS KEOGH SETS MARK
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 16 Mike Keogh, Manhattan's soph omore crosscountry captain, set a course record today as the Jaspers won their 19th consecutive race over a three year period, defeating Provi dence, 2629. Keogh's time of 25 minutes 2.6 seconds for the 5.2mile course broke the rec ord set by William Speck by 21 seconds. Speck, a Friar senior, finished second in 25:07.

title: The Wild Children
description: The senseless shooting of a young medical student by a band of teenagers in this city the other day is the most recent example of the terrifying phenomenon of violent crimes, particularly of assault and robbery, committed by adolescents and even children. Reports, from across the country confirm the dismal trend. Ex perts agree that the situation is even worse than the statistics suggest. Violence committed by children against children usually remains unreported, unless the injuries sustained by the victims are serious.

title: Air Force Turns Back Army, 207, on Two Touchdowns in 2d Half
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Oct. 16 (AP)Joel Carlson raced 88 yards on an option play and the Air Force defense converted a blocked punt into another touchdown as the Falcons ral lied to defeat Army, 207, today.

title: Japan Across Two Oceans
description: LONDON  Hard on the heels of Emperor Hirohito's visit to Europe, a 35man delegation organized by Ja pan's chief industry and banking federation, Keidan ren, will arrive in West Ger many Sunday to begin a twoweek tour of four Com men Market countries.

title: GOLF TOUR TRIALS LED BY ZENDER'S 425
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 16 (UPI)Bob Zen der, a 28yearold stockbroker from Skokie, Ill., shot a three underpar 69 today to win the Professional Golfers Associa tion qualifying tournament with a sixround total of 425.

title: CARTIER WINS RUN IN FAST CLOCKING
description: Vince Cartier of Scotch Plains (N.J.) High School, who lost valuable time when he tripped in the hills, posted the fourth fastest schoolboy clocking ever run at Van Cortlandt Park in the 21st St. John's University interscholastic crosscountry run yesterday.

title: Janis Beckerman Wed To Michael Markman
description: Miss Janis Anna Becker man, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Beckerman of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., was married here last evening to Michael Markman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Markman of New York and Dallas. Rabbi Phillip, Schecter performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: SPEEDCAR CRASH KILLS 3 IN TEXAS
description: LEWISVILLE, Tex., Oct. 16 (AP)A television newsman and two employes of the Inter national Hot Rod Association were killed today when a car that had reached a speed of 286 miles an hour veered through a guard rail after blowing a tire.

title: Art
description: 0 N an art scene as com mercially competitive and as fraught with the politics of move ments and reputations as New York's is, prestigious museum shows of work by young and relatively unknown artists can scarcely avoid contro versy. No organizer of such a show can be unaware that he is in the position of a handi capper, as it were, for the local art sweepstakes, and that, in this city of touts, his exhibition will be viewed with mixed partisan ardor and cynicism  with the result that the quality of the works included may seem almost a minor consideration.

title: Fugitive Black Leader Had Led a Civil Rights Group
description: Hubert Geroid Brown, known] to the public as H. Rap Brown and named as a suspect in a West Side bar holdup yester day, is the controversial and longmissing former chairman of the defunct Student Non violent Coordinating Commit tee, a civil rights organiza tion.Brown received much attention subsequently because he made appeals to Negroes to take mili tant action in their fight for equality.

title: CONNECTICUT BEATS MAINE ELEVEN, 217
description: ORONO, Me., Oct. 16Con necticut maintained its football jinx over Maine by defeating the Bears, 217, today behind the quarterbacking of Bob Ro bustelli. It was Connecticut's sixth straight triumph over the Blue and White since 1965.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Kings and princes don't wear crowns to parties any more, but their wives some times do. When the Shah of Iran staged a fourand ahalf hour formal dinner last Thurs day to celebrate the 2,500th anniversary of the Persian monarchy, no fewer than 20 crowns and a dozen tiaras scintillated on the heads of royal ladies.

title: Gay Icarus Victor
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct, 16 (Reuters)Gay Icarus, the favorite, won the $75,000 Caul field Cup over a mile and half by two lengths today.

title: VA. TECH WINS, 4130, ON TWO LATE SCORES
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Oct. 16 (UPI)William and Mary fum bles set up two fourthquarter touchdowns by James Barber today as Virginia Tech recorded a 4130 victory, its first of the season.

title: Hoover, in Unusual Letter, DefendsF.B.I.Operations
description: J. Edgar Hoover has made rare defense of the Federal Bu reau of Investigation to a group of lawyers, scholars and jour nalists who will hold a confer ence on the F.B.L later this month.

title: A Geriatric Center Is Expanding
description: The Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center has an nounced contracts have been signed to erect a $23,000,000, minestory, 530bed facility in Brooklyn for longterm care of chronically ill or dis abled people.

title: The Nation
description: The Nation

title: Music
description: THE Martinson Hall in the New York Shake speare Festival Public Theater is on the third floor of the old building on Lafayette Street. It is a rather small, close room, seating about 300, though about 350 tickets were sold for the first of the Prospec tive Encounters the other Friday. The overflow was accommodated on pillows Strewn all over the floor.

title: 6 Aboard Plane Killed In a Crash in Virginia
description: HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 16 (UPI)A private execu tive plane crashed in heavy fog today while landing at Ingalls Field near Hot Springs. All six men aboard were killed, including execu tives of two companies that designed and operated the Enrico Fermi nuclear plant near Monroe, Mich.

title: WALL STREET
description: Despite some talk to the contrary, Muriel Siebbrt, the first and now only woman member of the New York Stock. Exchange, has no thoughts about selling, membership on the exchage.

title: Williams Scores Early, Often In Trouncing Bowdoin, 55.0
description: >WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Oct. 16Williams scored a touch down in the first two minutes today and went on to over whelm Bowdoin, 550.

title: Travel Notes: More Airlines File. For TransAtlantic Fare eductions
description: JUST what the trans Atlantic airfare picture will be on Feb 1 still remains anyone's guess, but the dive toward lower rates has definitely begun. Following the lead of Luft hansa, which has announced fares starting at $180 round trip (offseason package re quiring the purchase of $70 worth of ground arrange ments) between New York and any city in West Ger many, KLM Royal Dutch Air lines and Sabena, Belgian World Airlines will introduce similarly low fares (from Feb. 1) with the addition of a senior citizen discount. That fare, for persons 65 and over, will be $190 offseason, $228 in summer the same as the youth fare that will be offered to travelers aged 12 through 21. The package fare between New York and the Netherlands or Belgium will be $170 plus $70 in ground arrangements.

title: LUISA MILLER REVIVED BY MET
description: There are probably not many operagoers who have really missed Verdi's Luisa Miller following the Metropolitan Opera's temporary retirement of it at the end of 196768 sea son, but its revival Friday night was not unwelcome, and the performance it got was one to make the company proud.

title: ROAD PLAN LINKS TWO FORMER FOES
description: JAMESBURG, N.J., Oct. 16 The determination of a small band of environmentalists to preserve a 1,700acre tract of bog and sandy uplands near here as a nature park and wild life refuge now appears after eight years of effort to have gained the support of the mu nicipal officials in surrounding towns and townships.

title: CATHOLIC PANELS ON BISHOPS ASKED
description: The Canon Law Society of America has proposed a new system for the selection of Roman Catholic bishops de signed to give priests, nuns and laymen a voice in the process.

title: Friendship Can Prevail, Even for a Politician
description: Twentyfive years is a long time to know somebody and like him. I've known Jack Muratori that long, maybe longer, since both of us spent our summers growing up in Point Lookout, L. I. He was always a bit of an intellec tual. But I never let that come between us.

title: An ultramodern miracle that began at Rectigraph
description: The story of Xerox Corpora tion is Exhibit A for con temporary freeenterprise ideal ists, demonstrating that in the age of supercorporations, gov ernment regulation and admin istered prices a better mouse trap can still be a path of suc cess, nice guys in business can still finish first, etc. Of course, those things don't happen every day; and by thus pro viding the idealists with ammu ninon, Xerox has helped per petuate a possibly dangerous myth; but that's hardly Xerox's fault.

title: RomeBerlin Ties Urged
description: ROME, Oct. 16  Thirtyfive members of Italy's Parliament called today for establishment of diplomatic relations with East Germany. The members of Parliament includes figures of the dominant Christian Demo cratic party as well as Commu nists and Socialists.

title: Miss Cornbrooks Wed
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16  Miss Elaine Adel Cornbrooks, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Ivan Cornbrooks Jr. and Clarence Henry Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr., were married here this afternoon in the Second Pres byterian Church by the Rev. Dr. J. Robert Hewett.

title: Music: Pianist Includes Ragtime in Bill
description: Alan Mandel gave a pro gramfof American piano music at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday evening, That in itself is not so unusual, but the opening and closing groups were. Mr. Mandel started with four Gottschalk pieces, and this probably has not been done for generations. To top that, he ended with four rag time pieces, and that probably has never been done at a le cital by a serious artist.

title: Colts Present a Twin Threat to Giants
description: Johnny Unitas, the Baltimore quarterback, probably won't see any action against the New York Giants in Yankee Stadium today (1 P.M.) unless the Colts are either safely ahead or way behind.

title: He dealt with geniuses and knavesand kept his cool
description: He is a plodder, to use his own term, a patient and custo mary man who did not expect, but nonetheless gained, great enterprise from himself and his colleagues. In his list of qualities that make a good pilifther he ends with this one: Some educational back ground but not too much. This tells something of the man and of his occupation. Schol arship can render a person ob sessive and perhaps obtrusive; if it is expected of some au thors, it is doubtful in a pub lisher, who probably ought to hear everything for the first time. Cass Canfield's autobiog raphy describes some extraor dinary people as he knew them which is to say, without bias. He entertained, counseled and trafficked with geniuses and knaves throughout 50 years30 of them as bead of the house of Harperbut he has not lost his singular sweet ness of character lie remains a dear man.

title: Two on Norwegian Ship Die in Blaze Off England
description: PENZANCE, England, Oct, 16 (UPI)Two persons died today in a fire on the Norwegian ship Anatina in heavy seas off the southwest tip of England.

title: Chess
description: T HE United States Open Champion ship has long been regarded as the second most prestigious tour nament in the country, directly behind the U. S. (invitational) champion ship itself. From its relatively humble origins, when it was little more than a local tournament in the New York area (up until about 1950 the New York area was the only one that really counted, so New Yorkers styled their tournaments national championships as a matter of course) it has now grown into a giant: the 1971 Open, held in Ventura, California, attracted 400 players.

title: U.S. Grants Soviet Captain of Fishing Vessel Asylum
description: TOKYO, Oct. 16 (AP)A 47 yearold Russian fishing boat captain rescued in Japan's Northern Sea has been granted asylum in the United States, an American Embassy spokesman said today.

title: SCRANTON MAY GET PRICE BOARD POST IN INFLATION FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 William W. Scranton, a former Governor of Pennsylvania who was chairman of President Nixon's Commission on Campus Unrest, is being considered for membership on the panel that will set price and rent guide lines under the second phase of the Administration's program to fight inflation.

title: Recordings.
description: FEW people are more familiar with the eso teric problems of grow ing up musically absurd than those who decide to make careers as professional players of woodwind instru ments. For me, it was the clarinet, a perfectly respect able instrument, one that plays an invaluable role in most post18thcentury mu sic, and one that really hits its stride in that peculiar, but popular, musical hybrid, the symphonic concert band.

title: A Life On Film
description: Mary Astor is that rare avis, a film star with brains. I have met her twice: the first time in 1962, aboard a ship in Syd ney Harbor, like the one she took to Panama in Across the Pacific. Listening to Tchai kovsky's First Piano Concerto on closed circuit television, she said, I played that on my Australian tour in The Great Lie.  The second time we met was at Mary Astor's home, al most 10 years later, in an im mense retirement settlement called Fountain Valley south of Los Angeles. To both improb able locales, she brought the same extraordinary grace with which she illuminated scores of desolate films.

title: Alabama Tops Tennessee, 3215, First Time Since 66 for 6th Victory in Row
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 16 (AP)Alabama, led by Robin Parkhouse and a ballhawking secondary, defeated Tennessee, 3215, in the Southeastern Conference today.

title: FLY BALE DECIDES
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 16The Baltimore Orioles fought their way back into the World Series today by defeating the Pitts burgh Pirates, 32, in 10 tense innings and throwing the Series into a winnertakeall finale toinorrow.

title: Preps
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 16 Hackley fell behind early today when King School scored on a 71yard pass play off a double reverse. But the Hornets im mediately moved ahead, 86, when Steve Smith returned the ensuing kickoff 70 yards and Craig Dillon converted, and Hackley went on to a 3414 Fairchester League victory.

title: Five Stories Of Ferrara
description: Giorgio Bassani's Ferrara, like all true cities, is a myth, a state of being and of having been, and he haunts it with the nostalgic passion of the exile. His The Garden of the FinziContinis was an ambig uous vision of paradise lost. The stories in the present vol ume, first published in Italy some 15 years ago, add to the vision by enlarging upon the ambiguities.

title: North Dakota Upsets No. Dakota State, 237
description: FARGO, N. D., Oct. 16 (AF)Tony Shahbarat, a na tive of Jordan, kicked three field goals for North Dakota today in a 237 triumph over previously unbeaten North Dakota State, the No. 1 ranked smallcollege football team. State had not been beaten in 36 games.

title: Foreign Notes
description: The British and Irish Gov ernments clamped down on the outlawed Irish Republican Army last week in an effort to curtail terrorism in North ern Ireland.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on crime insur ance [Crime Insurance Hard to Get, Even in Good Areas, Sept. 261 says that burglary insurance is often available only to customers of insur ance brokers who place sub stantial other insurance with those brokers. Is that legal?

title: Court
description: Forty years ago, another Re publican President was faced with the responsibility of filling a great Supreme Court chair, the one occupied by Oliver Wen dell Holmes Jr. When President Herbert Hoover showed his list of prospective candidates to Senator William E. Borah of Idaho who was known to favor a Western Republican  Senator Borah pointed to the bottom name and said, Your list is all right, but you handed it to me upside down.

title: Nixon to Speak in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) President Nixon will address a Republican fundraising dinner in Chicago Nov. 9. The $500 aplate Salute to the Presi dent dinner is one of more than 20 being held simultane ously throughout the country. The President's address will be carried by closed circuit tele vision to other participating cities, according to William C. Croft, chairman of the dinner.

title: Lawyer to Wed Maxine Jo Roth
description: Miss Maxine Jo Roth, a so cial worker with Louise Wise Serarices, and Melvin L. Schweitzer, a lawyer with Royal], Koegel & Wells, have made plans to be married in the whiter. Miss Roth and her Ranch are New York Uni versity graduates.

title: Peking Reported in Drive to Play Key Role in Mideast and Africa
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 16China recently asked Iran and Turkeytwo nations with whom she has just established diplomatic tiesto let Chinese airliners refuel there along planned new routes from Pek ing to Albania and Rumania. It is courting the Persian Gulf states of Kuwait and Bahrain, strengthening its, new relations with Ethiopia, financing devel opment projects in Sudan, help ing to build houses in Algeria, and even quietly flirting with Israel.

title: Miss Maxine Wellborn Fiancee Of Robert H. Shaw Jr. of Navy
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16Miss Maxine Bethune Wellborn and Lieut. Comdr. Robert Harris Shaw Jr., U.S.N., will be married here Jan. 22 in St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: EssexUnion
description: Rick Crosta, Whose passing had led Union to three straight victories, turned to kicking yesterday to spark a 108 de cision over Bloomfield in Union.

title: Planners Denounce Rabbi
description: A public housing project in the neighborhood?

title: RALLY BY AUBURN DEFEATS GA. TECH
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 16 (UPI) Pat Sullivan led a rally that produced three touchdowns in the first six minutes of the final period and gave seventh ranked Auburn a 3114 victory over Georgia Tech today.

title: Rockland
description: North Rockland lost a little of its luster but not its top spot in Rockland County football yesterday. The unbeaten and untied defending league cham pions were finally scored on, but still managed a 286 victory over Pearl River.

title: Et Al.
description: By Charles B. Seib. 108 pp. Doubleday. $4.95.Washington Star managing editor Charles Seib joins the numerous company who have sought full or parttime escape from megalopolis. Seib's Wal den (his son and daughter call it Walden South) is in Rappahannock County, Va., 85 miles from Washington, on the eastern edge of the Blue Ridge. A lowkey account of his search for a secluded bit of land (33 acres); the construc tion of a simple, oneroom cabin (sans electricity or running water); a pond; ob servations on plant and animal life; the passing of the seasons. References to Thoreau are fre quent: Seib estimates that his cabin (relatively speaking) cost even less than Thoreau's; Seib's disturbed comments on Kent State and Cambodia parallel Thoreau's on John Brown. Like his cabin, Seib's book is modest and comfy; its construction possibly gave him as much satisfaction.

title: MINNESOTA RALLY TOPS IOWA, 1914
description: IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 161, (AP)Minnesota converted a late Iowa fumble into the de ciding touchdown today to escape with a 1914 Big Ten football victory over the vic toryless and mistakeprone Hawkeyes.

title: N.Y. Tech Boaters Win
description: OLD WESTBURY, Li., Oct. 16Joe Pinto registered three goals today as New York Tech's soccer team beat Ba ruch, 50.

title: Strong wit whose laughter answers and derides
description: Fortyfour years ago, Stephen Vincent Benet said of Phelps Putnam's first book, Trine,  a slow vintage, but the wine will keep. Allen Tate found in it a maturity and a distinction of style that rank him immediately with the five or six interesting poets who had appeared in the twenties. When, in 1931, The Five Sea sons was published, some re viewers thought that Putnam had the makings of an America epic poet. Others, more con servative, were troubled by unnecessary lines  repug nant because the realism was dragged in, and by certain bawdy phrases sophomoric in their obsession with physiology. But except for one or two slight pieces, Putnam published nothing more, even in magazines.

title: For Young Readers
description: That's Boris being tempesttossed across the top of this page. In a little while he's going to be a beached whale lying high and dry on the sand, losing his moisture in the hot sun. Do you think that Amos, a mote of mouse, will be able to help him then? For the answer to the first ques tion you'll have to read William Steig's picture book, AMOS AND BORIS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $4.50). I'll give you a little of Steig's story about the meeting between these two dis paratesized mammals. Years before Amos had answered the sea's call: studied navigation at night, built a snug craft, stocked it with provisions and set sail full of love for life. Unfortunately one night, pondering the enormity of the universe and the starstudded sky, Amos rolls over the side and has other things to think about: What would it be like to drown, would it feel just awful, would his soul go to heaven, would there be other mice there? That's when he meets Boris and gets a week's ride by whaleback. He comes to admire the bulk, the grandeur, the power, the purpose, the rich voice, and the abounding friendliness of the whale and Boris admires the delicacy, the quivering daintiness, the light touch, the small voice, the gemlike radiance of the mouse. In a word the reason is friendship.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: When I lived in Shiraz, I traveled on the roads de scribed so well in the 400 Mile Auto Trip Through Iran (Travel section, Sept. 26). It was always exhilarating, driv ing from Isfahan, to round a curve and find in the stark landscape the columns of the ancient city of Persepolis mute and grand. There were no signs or anything else to distract one from the view. So it was with mixed feelings that I read about the current celebrations marking the 2,500th anniversary of, the Persian monarchy (visiting dignitaries are being housed in a new Club Mediterrande at Persepolis). Tourism is good for the area, but part of an ancient civilization which stood for centuries in quiet splendor will now be part of a tourist spectacle.

title: Hyde Park: An Era Revisited
description: MY few personal recollections of the Roosevelt family are not of Franklin but of Eleanor, and even then I encountered her fleetingly and only toward the end of her life.

title: Et Al.
description: The master of the Theater of the Absurd continues in the vein of his earlier Fragments of a Journal. Diary jottings mingle with searing memories of his authoritarian father; metaphysical musings with thoughts on antiSemitism, Soviet death camps, the sham of bourgeois revolutionaries. There is an occasional light hearted fantasy played out with children who might be his own; the germ of his idea for The Rhinoceros; overall a mysti cal sense of plenitude. Subtle in form and content.

title: The Closing Circle
description: This may be the best book on ecology ever written. It is certainly the most sober, rigorous, well organized statement of what our en vironmental problems are, how we got them, and what we should do about them.

title: MARSHALL BEATEN BY DAYTON, 13 TO 0
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Oct. 16 (AP)Gary Kosins, a tail back, scored two touchdowns today to lead Dayton to a 130 victory over Marshall.

title: Nipponese egoism, psychic skulduggeries, Italian mythmaking
description: Though hardly known in the West except among specialists, Natsume Soseki (18671916) is generally regarded by his coun trymen as the major fiction writer of modern Japan. His complex psychological works, in which traditional Japanese ideals are combined with the form of the Western realistic novel, have had a profound in fluence on subsequent Japanese writers, including those most familiar to Western readers, like Tanizaki, Kawabata and Mishima. For anyone seriously interested in the development of Japanese literaturea lit erature that since 1945 has be come more available in the West than that of any other remote culture  a knowledge of Soseki's novels is essential.

title: L.I. Rail School Starts tomorrow
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.For six years Peter Berman was a commuter on the Long Is land Railroad between Wood mere and Brooklyn. He was never very fond of the hour andahalf trip and as assist ant business dean at Adelphi University's School of Busi ness Administration here, he says now, I'd never do it again.

title: Preps
description: LIVINGSTON, N. 3., Oct. 16 Unbeaten and oncetied Newark Academy got two touchdowns from John Kimmel and a pair of scoring passes from Dave Hardin today en route to a 2112 victory over Bordentown Military. It was the fourth Newark Academy suc cess.

title: Horse Show News
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 16 On the face of things, the United States and Canada should dominate the interna tional events of the three big indoor horse shows this year. The two teams will be riding against each other and Ar gentina on the fall circuit that got under way here yes terday with the Pennsylvania National at the Farm Show Arena. The im portant Washing ton International event, which fol lows the Penn National, is not an official international show, but will instead offer combined internationalopen jumper division.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: The informative article on Iran did not mention that most Iranian of disheschelo kebab. In a base of the per fect Iranian rice, flavored with sumac, you make a hole into which you pour egg yolk and butter, then cover it with strips of broiled lamb. With this goes fresh pepper chunks, slices of sweet onion and pickles. It sounds terrible but tastes quite good. The pre ferred drink with chelo kebab is dugh, a beverage of yo ghurt, water and ice. The dish is the specialty of the Firuz restaurant in Teheran.

title: 75 YEARS MARKED BY HUDSON GUILD
description: The Hudson Guild celebrated its 75th anniversary last week, and took the occasion to ana lyze and reassess its role as one of the oldest and largest neighborhood houses in the city.

title: Cuite Says U.S. Should Pay ForeignMission Protection
description: The Federal Government should provide protection around United Nations head quarters, foreign missions con sulates and trade offices in New York, the majority leader of the City Council said yes terday.

title: The Hunting Peoples
description: The date 10,000 B.C. marks an interlude, an inbetween imminent time, in the story of man. The world was roomier then, containing an estimated 10,000,000 persons. All of them, like us, were fullfledged mem bers of the Homo sapiens club. All were huntergatherers, liv ing predominantly on wild plants and wild animals. It was a kind of heyday of prehis toryman having adapted suc cessfully to environments from semideserts and savannas and tropical forests to rigorous winter regions not far from the edges of milehigh glaciers.

title: Col. Herbert Won't Press Case Against General
description: FT. McPHERSON, Ga., Oct. 16 (AP)Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert said he would not press further charges against Maj Gen. John W. Barnes, who has been cleared of covering up atrocities in Vietnam.

title: U. M. W. and Coal Company Pay $8.9Million Mine Suit Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16The United Mine Workers of Amer ica and the Consolidation Coal Company ended three years of court appeals here yesterday by turning over separate damage checks of $4,453,500 to a small nonunion Kentucky mine op erator whose business the courts have held they conspired to ruin.

title: FLORIDA IN UPSET OF FLORIDA STATE
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Oct. 16 (UPI)Richard Franco of Flori da kicked a 42yard fourth quarter field goal today as the Gators, previously without a victory, handed Florida State its first loss, 1715.

title: Sherill Holden Bride of Robert Craig Jr.
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Oct. 16Miss Sherill Ann Holden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Holden, was mar ried here this afternoon to Robert Duncan Craig Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Richard B. Andersen per formed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: HOTELS HERE DENY THEY FETE POLICE
description: Spokesmen for some leading midtown hotels denied yester day that they provided free food and lodgings to police of ficers as has been charged by, the Knapp Commission that has been investigating police cor ruption.

title: U.S. to Give $8Million For Rail Cars in Jersey
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) Senator Harrison Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, announced yes terday that the United States Urban Mass Transit Admin istration had approved a grant of $8,533,333 for new railroad passenger cars fat New Jersey.

title: Army 150Pounders Rout Princeton Eleven, 34.16
description: PRINCETON, Oct. 16Royce Richards threw three touch down passes as he guided Army's undefeated 150pound football team to a 3417 vic tory, over Princeton today.

title: Preps
description: Wheatley (L.I.) rallied in the secondhalf yesterday to defeat Dalton, 12.6, at Van Cortlandt Park. Dave Perlin scored the winning points in the fourth quarter on a 21yard pass. The victory brought Wheatley's rec ord to 31. Dalton dropped to 12.

title: Director at Bay
description: Three years ago the owner of fewer than 100 shares of stock in the Penn Central Com pany sued Howard Butcher 3d, senior partner in Butcher & Sherrerd, the Philadelphia broker age house.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16Mote tran scribed moments from the Nixon Mitchell papers:

title: Doing Business With Brezhnev
description: Apart from the 1972 election, the critical factor behind President Nixon's historic decision to be the first Ameri can President to visit Moscow, as well as Peking, appears to be a feeling that he can do business with Brezhnev. This feeling evidently is based primarily on the recent Berlin agreement and on exchanges in the strategic arms limitation talks (SALT). It reflects a sea change atmosphere in less than a year.

title: Nassau South
description: If West Hempstead's players failed to carry Mike Hintz off the field on their shoulders and Elmont did not do the same for Ed Swanson after yester day's football games, it was only because both teams were too tired.

title: Upsala Triumphs, 35.31, As Kersey Twins Excel
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 16 (AP)Mike Kersey bobbled but held onto a 45yard pass from his Identical twin brother, Mor ris, with nine seconds left, to give Upsala a 35.31 victory over Susquehanna today.

title: Upstate Power Project Brings Rising Protests
description: GILBOA, N. Y.More than 11,000 tourists from 32 states and 25 foreign countries came here last summer to climb an observation plat form covered with synthetic red carpeting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Edam: The proposed $2.5 billion Trans portation Bond Issue, which will be on the November ballot, is represented as a package balanced between mass transit and highways and between the needs of the New York metropolitan area and upstate. This is nonsense. The price of the muchneeded transit and rail improvements proposed for the metropolitan area is completion of the enormously destructive Inter state System in New York City. This would amount to about one billion dol lars in Federalstate expenditures.

title: Knicks Turn Back Cavaliers, 121120, For First Victory
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 17We were lucky to win, said Coach Red Holzman after the New York Knickerbockers edged the Cleveland Cavaliers in over time, 121120, tonight at Cleve land Arena.

title: Miss Therese Stern, Irvin Grodsky Marry
description: Miss Therese Sandra Stern was married here yesterday afternoon to Irvin Grodsky. Rabbi Judah Nadich and Can tor David J. Putterman of ficiated at the ceremony in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

title: Dr.Teresita Reyes Wed To Frederick Kuo Jr.
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 17 Dr. Teresita Reyes, daugh ter of Narciso G. Reyes, Per manent Representative of the Philippines to the United Na tions, and Mrs. Reyes, was married here this afternoon to Frederick Kuo Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kuo of Great Neck.

title: AUSCHWITZ FRIAR BEATIFIED BY POPE Vatican Honors Kolbe, Who Gave Life for Another in 41
description: ROME, Oct. 17A Polish priest who gave his life to save a fellow inmate in a Nazi concentration camp 30 years ego was beatified by the Roman Catholic Church today. The solemn and moving cere mony was attended by 1,500 to 2,000 persons who had journeyed here from Poland. Among them was the man whose life had been saved.

title: Iran's Celebrations End
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 17 (Reuters)A display of ancient Iranian gymnastics by about 1,000 athletes today brought to an end the weeklong celebra tions marking the 2,500th an niversary of the founding of the Persian empire.

title: Sabres Drop Another
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 17 (AP) Charlie Burns scored twice to night to pace the Minnesota North Stars to a 32 victory over the Buffalo Sabres. It was Buffalo's fourth straight loss after a seasonopening victory.

title: Clashed With Nixon on War
description: Dr. James Edward Allen Jr., who died Saturday in a plane crash in Arizona, served as Commissioner of Education un der President Nixon for only 18 months.

title: PETROSIAN ADJOURNS GAME WITH FISCHER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 (AP)Bobby Fischer of the United States and Tigran Petro sian of the Soviet Union played five hours and 42 moves to night before adjourning their sixth chess game in the match to determine a challenger for the world title.

title: Blass, His Eyes Weak, Needs Hand Signs but Orioles Can't See Him
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17  As with any other pitcher, when Steve Blass pitches for Pitts burgh, Manny Sanguillen, his catcher, flashes signs with his fingerone finger for a fast ball, two for a curve, three for a changeup.

title: One Thing's for Sure The Cans Contain Alcohol
description: Since August, local liquor stores have been selling pre mixed cocktails in 8ounce containers. Prepared cock tails have been sold in bottles for years in New York State, so that this new wrinkle might seem to be merely a simple adaptation of wellknown packaging tech niques.

title: A YOUNG QUARTET EXCELS IN CONCERT
description: In the two years since its debut at the Marlboro Festival, the Cleveland Quartet has stepped into the front rank of chambermusic playing, which is something like being granted a Ph.D. in your sophomore year. The young group opened a threeconcert series yester day afternoon at Hunter Col lege Playhouse with stylish readings that only the lite string quartets of the world would be likely to match.

title: Deaths
description: LANDMr. and Mrs. David Land (nee Grace Rosenblatt) happily announce the arrival of Brith and Robert's sister, Lisa Ellen on October 14th, 1971.

title: Busing Is Michigan's Biggest Political Issue
description: ROSEVILLE, Mich., Oct. 17 We just came back from vacation yesterday. They didn't say how are you. They said, Did you hear? And when Mar garet Hagen and her husband, Don, heard, they were about as angry as the hundreds of thou sands of other white suburban ites around Detroit.

title: LitterPocked Lot, A Brooklyn Stage Frame Dance Bills
description: Selecting a site in which to perform used to be one of the last things a choreographer would think of. Now it is often one of the first. Rudy Perez and Company were on a rubble strewn lot in midManhattan while Bella Lewitzky's company was on the stage of the Brook lyn Academy of Music on Satur day evening and both had chosen their locations with care.

title: Advertising:
description: Here is the latest chapter in the saga of the restuctur ing of the New York office of the J. Walter Thompson Company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On Nov. 2 we will have an oppor tunity to do something about chang ing New York State's social and eco nomic climate, namely by approving Amendment 1, the Community Devel opment Article.

title: U.N. Found Closely Split On Eve of China Debate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 17The United Nations debate on China begins on the floor of the General Assembly tomor row morning with the 131 members so evenly divided that predictions on the outcome are still impossible.

title: Wings Win First, 53
description: DETROIT, Oct. 17 (UPI)Alex Delvecchio gave Detroit a 40 lead at the start of the third period tonight, but the Red Wings weren't assured of their first victory of the season until Bill Collins scored on a break away with 10 seconds left in a 53 triumph over the St. Louis Blues.

title: L.I. Greeks Consecrate Church in Hempstead
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 17 St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church was consecrated here today in a colorful and his toric service that ended with the enshrining of relics of three Eastern Orthodox saints in the altar table.

title: Heller Suggests a Thaw Of PreFreeze Pay Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Dr. Walter W. Heller, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under Presi dents Kennedy and Johnson, said today that wage increases already written into longterm labor contracts could be un frozen without crippling Presi dent Nixon's economic stabili zation program.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17  The longer the list of pros pective Nixon appointees to the United States Supreme Court, the better the Presi dent's earlier choice, Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr., begins to look to some of the Democrats who opposed him. Senator Mike Mansfield, the Democratic floor leader, con fided to report ers this week that he had come to regret voting against Judge Haynsworth when the South Carolinian failed to win confirmation, 55 to 45, in November of 1969.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on the issue of China's seat.

title: COOKERY OFFERS GUITAR PROGRAM
description: Since Barney Josephson be gan booking established jazz pianists such as Mary Lou Wil liams, Marian McPartland and Sammy Price into his restaur ant, The Cookery, West Eighth Street at University Place, last November, one could be grate ful that there was a place in New York where these musi cians could be heard in com patible surroundings.

title: City's Problems Follow Lindsay on Campaign Trail
description: Mayor Lindsay's weekend swing through Indiana pointed up a major problem in his fledgling Presidential campaign  the Mayor can leave New York but New. York doesn't leave him.

title: Lobbyists, Certain That Congress Won't Materially Alter Nixon Tax Bill, Keep Pressure Low
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17One day last month, as the House Ways and Means Committee was considering President Nixon's tax bill, Representative Phil M. Landrum, a member of the committee, received a letter from the head of a small textile plant in his North Georgia dis trict.

title: Taipei Frees Nearly 5,000 Nonpolitical Prisoners in an Anniversary Amnesty
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 17  Nearly 5,000 prisoners were re leased last week under an am nesty granted in honor of the 60th anniversary of the found ing of the Chinese Republic.

title: Mayor Del Bello of Yonkers Is Favored to Win ReElection in FourWay Contest
description: YONKERSThe Mayor's job here is only a parttime one, with a salary of $13,000 a year. But it is being sought this year with all the energy and acri mony that has traditionally characterized politics in the state's fourth largest city.

title: PIRATES TRIUMPH OVER ORIOLES, 24; WIN WORLD SERIES
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17The Pittsburgh Pirates completed one of the most dramatic re versals in baseball history to day when they defeated the favored Baltimore Orioles, 21, and won the 68th World Series in the seventh and final game.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Deborah Josephs tragic essay, The Right to Die with Dignity [OpEd Sept. 25], points up the confusions of responsibility that exist with respect to medical care. She says, There must be a point where a patient is permitted to die. She resents not being consulted about the treatment of her brotherinlaw. However, when informed that if she would not permit treatment she would have to remove the patient from the hospital, she balks because it was the tubes and instruments to which Flip was at tached that were keeping him alive.

title: FACILITY MAY AID SUBATOMIC STUDY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17  French and Soviet officials have for mally inaugurated a gigantic nuclear research installation south of Moscow, opening new prospects in the study of sub atomic particles in conjunction with the world's biggest atom smasher, already in operation nearby.

title: 12 Firemen Who Died In 1966 Blaze Honored
description: Mayor Lindsay pinned medals of valor yesterday on the relatives of 12 firemen who died in a fire on Oct. 17, 1966.

title: CAIRO TO CONTROL TROOPS IN SYRIA
description: CAIRO, Oct. 17The Egyp tian Minister of War, Gen. Mo hammed Sadek, has been given command over the Syrian troops facing Israel so that operations can be coordinated with those of the Egyptian forces along the Suez Canal, it was disclosed here today.

title: SelfGoverning Inmates of Walla Walla Prison Find Life Easier
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., Oct. 17A strange prison social structure, perhaps the strangest in the United States, has been formed in the last year at the Washington State Penitentiary.

title: Lib in Longhorn Country
description: AUSTINIs there women's lib in Texas? Of course. The reason I know there is women's lib in Texas is because I got a call a few weeks ago from a reporter on the women's section of The Austin American. She was doing a survey of typical old maids, she said, and wanted to inter view me about whether the advent of women's lib had made any difference in the attitudes of normal people toward us old maids. For example, she asked, do people still ask why a nice girl like you never got married? Yup, they do.

title: Palmer Cards 202 For 2Shot Victory In EightMan Golf
description: SAINTNOMLABRETECHE, France, Oct. 17Arnold Palmer came in out of the rain today two strokes ahead of Gary Player and $20,000 richer:

title: SHELLING REPORTED NEAR CAMBODIA LINE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 18 (AP)North Vietnamese gunners shelled United States and South Viet namese fire bases yesterday and the allies responded with more air strikes as fighting along the South VietnamCam bodia border entered its fourth week, the Saigon command re ported.

title: Black Hawks Top Kings, 40
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 17 (UPI) Jim Pappin scored twice and Tony Esposito got his second shutout as the Chicago Black Hawks defeated the Los An geles Kings, 40, tonight for their fifth victory without a defeat.

title: Big Board Plans to Carry Corporate Bonds on C.C.S.
description: The New York Stock Ex change announced yesterday that it was planning to include corporate bonds in its Central Certificate Service, the ex change's central depository for securities.

title: ANNE M. ROBERTS, HOUSING OFFICIAL
description: Mrs. Anne Mason Roberts, deputy regional administrator of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and former director of the New York City poverty program, died in her sleep early yester day. She was 61 years old and lived at 200 West 90th Street.

title: Vance, Sanders Elects
description: Vance, Sanders & Co., Inc., the mutual fund concern, yes terday named its 54yearold executive vice president, John D. Wilson, as president effec tive Nov. 1 to succeed John A. McCandless, 65, who is retiring. Landon.T. Clay, vice president, becomes chairman ric Pierce, treasurer, will also become sen ior vice president.

title: Mrs. Judith Long Is Bride of Dentist
description: RUMSON, N. J., Oct. 17 Mrs. Judith R. Long and Dr. Mortimer M. Glasgal were married here this afternoon at Congregation B'nai Israel. Rabbi Jack Rosoff and Cantor David Myers officiated.

title: Spain Foils Prison Escape
description: ZAMORA, Spain, Oct. 17 (Reuters)Authorities at a special prison for priests today discovered a 40footlong es cape tunnel leading from a boiler room. The prison holds about 20 priests, many of whom are Basques serving prison terms for offenses connected with the Basque separatist Movement.

title: New Engelhard Officer
description: John G. Harlan Jr., 54 years old, has been appointed pres ident of the Engelhard Indus tries Division and senior vice president of the Engelhard Min erals & Chemicals Corporation.

title: Harlem Girl Is Found Slain In Yard of Former Home
description: A 10yearold East Harlem girl was found murdered yes terday morning in the backyard of a tenement on East 111th Street where she formerly lived.

title: 3 Weekend Deaths in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 17A British soldier was (shot dead in West Belfast this afternoon, the third serviceman killed by the Irish Republican Army this weekend.

title: GUAM IS NEXT STOP FOR KISSINGER PARTY
description: WAIMEA, Hawaii, Oct. 17 (UPI)  Henry A, Kissinger, President Nixon's national se lcurity adviser, spent today with a group of aides in seclu sion near this Hawaiian town making final preparations for their trip to China to discuss with officials there details of President Nixon's visit.

title: PAULINE DOMANSKI IN FIGARO DEBUT
description: The New York City Opera has a new Countess in its Marriage of Figaro produc tion. Pauline Domanski, a Juil liard graduate with recent Ger man opera experience, made her debut in the role at the Saturday afternoon perform ance.

title: Inmates Rights Restored
description: THOMASTON, Me., Oct. 17 (UPI)Most prisoners were al lowed to attend church services and talk with visitors today for the first time since a strike threat last week forced a gen eral locking up at the facility. Some prisoners were involved in a peaceful kitchen workers strike on Tuesday.

title: Families of Spanish Origin Earn More Than Blacks Do
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17In the first national comparative study of its kind, the Census Bureau has found that persons of Spanishspeaking ancestry earn significantly greater in comes than blacks, even though they have poorer educations.

title: NEW SPECULATION ON PEKING ARISES
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 17 Evidence is still lacking to sup port definitively any of the speculations about what, if any, the problem is in the top leadership in Peking.

title: 40 Are Reported Killed By Earthquake in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct.  17 (Reuters)About 40 people have been killed by an earth quake in southeast Peru, provincial authorities re ported today.

title: Stunt Pilot Killed in Crash
description: GREENVILLE, N. C., Oct. 17 (UPI)Beverly Howard, a 57 yearold stunt pilot, was killed today while performing at benefit air show before a crowd of about 2,500. The wingtip of Mr. Howard's biplane caught the top of a 60foot tree as he was doing a roll before snatch ing a ribbon extended between two poles.

title: Kosygin Arrives in Ottawa To Begin Friendship Tour
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 17Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, the first Soviet head of Government to come to Canada, tonight began an eightday visit here to pro mote closer CanadianSoviet ties.

title: Arts Abroad
description: PARIS The homes of the affluent move west. The houses of culture, on the oth er hand, move eastat least in Paris.

title: Clemente Wins a Car For Heroics in Series
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (AP)  Roberto Clemente, right fielder of the Pittsburgh Pi rates, who collected 12 hits in the seven games, was named today as the out standing player of the 1971 World Series by Sport Maga zine.

title: What Health Crisis?
description: Chairman Wilbur Mills of the House Ways and Means Committee will open hearings tomorrow on the many and varied plans on Capitol Hill for modi fying or revolutionizing this country's medical care system. Mr. Mills power is such that his conclusions could greatly influence the future of Ameri can medicine.

title: Hopes and Biotopes
description: The World Wildlife Fund has taken a step which fairly reflects the distance society has come in environmental sophistication. For a decade this useful organization has devoted itself to the saving of specifically endangered animal species. Now, on the eve of its tenth anniversary, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, the Fund's interna tional president, announces an extension of its concept to the preservation of whole habitats, of ecosystems which make possible the continued existence of these threatened animals.

title: FRAUD UNIT SET UP ON RELIEF CHECKS
description: The city's Department of So cial Services announced the creation of a new Fraud Con trol Unit yesterday to increase efforts to prevent, detect and make recoveries on frauds in volving lost and stolen welfare checks, duplicate checks and forgeries.

title: Murtaugh Weighs Decision
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (UPI) Danny Murtaugh says he will let everybody know in three or four weeks whether he's coming back to manage the Pittsburgh Pirates or not next year. The outcome of this World Series has absolutely nothing to do with my de cision, Murtaugh said.

title: BROOKLYN GUNMEN GET $400,000 CARGO
description: Four tractortrailers carrying cargo worth $400,000 were stolen out of a freight terminal in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn last night after armed intruders handcuffed the night watchman to a trailer axle. The police estimated that the tractor  trailors were worth $160,000.

title: Middle East Roulette
description: Moscow and Washington are playing Russian roulette again in the Middle East. A new Soviet pledge further strengthen the military might of Egypt and Secretary of State Rogers retaliatory promise to care fully reconsider United States military commitments to Israela promise backed by the petition of 78 members of Congressthreaten a dangerous new escalation of the arms race in the area. Such an escalation would further reduce the prospects for peace and increase the peril of a fresh outbreak of fighting that would almost inevitably involve both major powers.

title: Gallup Poll Finds Kennedy Is Choice of Young for 72
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, is the clear choice for President in 1972 among voters 18 to 21 years old, according to a Gallup Poll conducted for Newsweek magazine, United Press Inter national reported yesterday.

title: STATE HELD BIASED AGAINST WOMEN
description: The state government was accused of having an active and abiding prejudice against women for state jobs in a report yesterday by the Demo cratic minority of the State Senate Finance Committee.

title: 2 PARADES MARK AUTUMN HOLIDAYS
description: Mariachi and other Latin rhythms on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan and fifes and bugles and drums on Fourth Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brook lyn set onlooker sto dancing or marching in place along the sidelines of two parades yester day celebrating. October holi days.

title: PAKISTAN IS WARNED BY INDIANS ON WAR
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 17In dia's Defense Minister, Jagjivan Ram, warned Pakistan today that if a war was thrust on India she would not withdraw from any Pakistani territory occupied by the Indian Army.

title: Satellite Is Sent Into Orbit Trailing Solar Power Cell
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Oct. 17 (UPI)A scientific satellite with a 32 footlong solar power cell that unwound like a window shade was launched into polar orbit today atop a ThorAgena rocket.

title: Redskins Defeat Cards, 200, to Go 2 Games. Ahead in Division
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17Are the unbeaten Redskins for real? They convinced the St. Louis Cardinals today, winning their fifth straight game, 200. The fans, players and coaches re sponded as if they had just reached the Super Bowl.

title: 3 TONS OF ARMS SEIZED BY DUTCH Planeload Was Reported to Be Destined for I.R.A.
description: THE HAGUE, Oct. 17The Dutch police have seized a planeload of more than three and a half tons of Czechoslo vakmade arms that they be lieve was intended for the Irish Republican Army.

title: Harvard Names Official
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 (AP)Harvard announced to day the appointment of John P. Reardon Jr. as director of admissions to the college. He has been associate dean of admissions and financial aids since 1969, when he joined the Harvard faculty.

title: How a Net Capital Loss Cushions Tax Impact
description: The following are the sav ings that would result from the recording of a $1,000 net shortterm loss or a $2,000 net longterm loss as a de duction to the extent of $1,000 from 1971 ordinary income:

title: Politburo Clears Soviet FiveYear Plan
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 17The So viet Union's new fiveyear plan, with promises of a better deal for the consumer, cleared a major hurdle last week when the Communist party's ruling Politburo gave the long docu ment its stamp of approval.

title: B'nai B'rith Sponsors Housing For the Elderly at Seven Sites
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17  B'nai B'rith will sponsor seven lowrent housing projects for senior citizens on a nonsectar ian basis as the first step to wittki a network throughout the country.

title: Hanoi Group in Italy for Visit
description: ROME, Oct. 17A delegation of North Vietnamese trade union officials arrived here to day from Moscow for a 10day visit to Italy, the first by an official group from Hanoi. The North Vietnamese are to meet with political, social and cul tural organizations.

title: OFFICIALS IN ITALY ACCUSED OF SCANDAL
description: ROME, Oct. 17Public prose cutors have disclosed informa tion that they say links 13 high Italian Government offi cials and businessmen to two major scandals.

title: Solutions to Italy's Recession Eluding Leaders
description: MILANThe Italian public is feeling the whipsaw blades of a particularly vicious recession.

title: Catholic Clergymen to Offer Counseling on Draft Here
description: Ten clergymen from the Ro man Catholic Diocese of Brook lyn who recently completed draft counseling course at St. John's University will hold draft counseling sessions in Brooklyn and Queens begin ning today.

title: Greek Town Ready for Agnew
description: GARGALIANOT, Greece, Oct. 17The schoolchildren went on a nature walk the other day, and as they wan dered their teachers directed them to clean up the scrap paper and litter that has accumulated over the months in the forest at the edge of town.

title: ST. LOUIS POLICE WATCHED BROWN
description: The St. Louis police said yes terday that H. Rap Brown and three men seized with him here early Saturday morning after a robbery at a West Side bar were seen together in that city several weeks ago.

title: Shop Talk
description: When is a box not a box and a staircase not a stair case? When they are fool theeye pieces of jewelry de veloped especially for Car tier by Viennaborn Paul von Ringelheim. And, not content with making one trompe l'oeil box serve as a pin or cuff link or money clip, Mr. von Ringelheim sometimes has a stack of three or four, or even five, little boxes do ing the job. And the staircase? It forms a pen dant on a neck ring and the illusion of steps ready to lead up to somebody's throat is so complete that it's hard, until one touches it, to real ize that the pendant is per fectly flat.

title: YEHORAM GAON GIVES WARM SONG RECITAL
description: It was old home week at Car negie Hall Saturday night, if you were an IsraeliTel Aviv newspapers being hawked in the street and English playing second fiddle to Hebrew in the audience.

title: Pagan Weighs In With Hit After Shift From Light Bat
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 17Jose Pagan switched his strategy to day before driving in what turned out to be the decisive run against Baltimore in the World Series.

title: For Relevance, the Students at Ste John's College Turn to Galileo
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 17 The Board of Governors of St. John's College met over the weekend and decided to consider changing the school's name.

title: Dollar Eurobonds Stage Comeback As Prices Go Up
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 17With an almost bewildering display of enthusiasm, European in vestors have again embraced the long unfashionable straightdollar Eurobond, sending prices up a point and more in the highcoupon sec tors last week. This allowed a quarterpoint cut in the coupon of the latest issue of fering and, paradoxically, set marked nerves on edge.

title: POSTED SAYS CITY TRIED TO GAG Hill
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel asserted yesterday that he had been offered a job in the Lindsay administration at more than $35,000 a year if he would keep quiet about his charges of frauds in the Municipal Loan Program.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the furor now raging over the Transportation Bond Issue, up for voter approval in November, many people have lost sight of the basic fact that, if this bond issue is defeated, the result would be no new money whatsoever for mass transit construc tion in New York City.

title: Goldman, Sachs Optimistic on Stock Market Outlook
description: Goldman, Sachs & Co., centuryold investment banking firm, is one of the most im portant and influential con cerns in the Wall Street area. Robert S. Danforth, 45, is part ner in charge of the investment research department. The other day, he talked with Vartanig G. Vartan of The New York Times. Excerpts from their con versation follow:

title: Physician Marries Miss Karen Grant
description: Miss Karen Grant and Dr. John English McWhorter 4th were married here yesterday afternoon in the First Pres byterian Church by the Rev. John Macnab.

title: G.I. Chutist Electrocuted
description: Needles, Calif., Oct. 17 (UPI) High winds were blamed to day for the death of an Army Special Forces reserve sergeant electrocuted in a parachuting accident yesterday. Thomas Ir vin Parrott, 27 years old, of Manhattan Beach, Calif., took part in a jump over desert ter rain. A shift in the wind blew him into a high voltage wire, apparently killing him instant ly, said Deputy Coroner William Fancher.

title: HUGH LEACH, EXHEAD OF A RESERVE BANK
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 17 (AP) Hugh Leach, president of the Federal Reserve Bank in Rich mond from 1936 to 1961, was killed yesterday in the collision of his car and a dump truck. His age was 77.

title: Expulsion Is Perilous
description: As the General Assembly opens debate on the ques tion of China's representation in the United Nations, member governments should keep one basic fact in mind: There is only one way to preserve the opportunity for fourteen million people on Taiwan to be represented at Turtle Bay and that is by retaining a U.N. member ship, at this point in time, for the Chinese Nationalist Government.

title: Mrs. Steckler Reweds
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 17 Mrs. Rose Steckler of Hew lett, widow of Lawrence Steckler, was married here today to S. Harvey Fosner, executive vice president and general manager of Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury. Rabbi Joel Y. Zion performed the ceremony at noon in Temple Israel. After a reception at the Idlewild Hotel at Ken nedy Airport, the couple left on a monthlong wedding trip to the Far East. Mr. Fosncr's first wife died.

title: A.D.A. BOARD LEVELS ATTACK ON O'BRIEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 The national board of Ameri cans for Democratic Action to day sharply attacked Lawrence F. O'Brien, chairman of the Democratic National Commit tee, for his role in the fight last week for the chairmanship of the Credentials Committee of the 1972 Democratic Na tional Convention.

title: U.S. TV TO PRESENT WORLD SYMPHONY
description: The Public Broadcasting Service announced yesterday that it would televise a concert by the World Symphony Or chestra on Thanksgiving eve ning, Nov. 25. The 90minute program, which will be carried by Channel 13 at a time to be announced, will be conducted by Arthur Fiedler.

title: BULGARIAN YOUTHS CHARM WITH SONGS
description: It has been a long time since a group looking and sounding as fresh, natural and unspoiled as the Bulgarian Children's Chorus has come to town. It made its debut here on Friday night in Philharmonic Hall, with Hristo Nedyalkov as con ductor and Roujka Charak chieva as pianist.

title: Five Who Took Sanctuary After Jumping Ship Give Up
