description: HONOLULU, Oct. 17 (UPI) Five sailors who jumped their ships to take church sanctuary were in a Navy brig today after surrendering to the mili tary police.

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Vietnam Problem
description: Following is the second in the se ries of excerpts from the memoirs of Lyndon Baines Johnson, which will lie published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston on Nov. 7 under the title The Van tage Point: Perspectives of the Presi dency, 19631969:

title: With deep sorrow we announce the death of out friend and associate
description: WERTHEIM & CO.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 17A European fig ure who would be regarded as a great friend of the United States was talk ing the other day about transAtlantic relations. When the conversation turned to the monetary situation, the temperature rose.

title: WILLIAM TRAUTH
description: LEONIA, N. J., Oct. 17Wil liam Eldon Hart Trauth, a teacher for 30 years at Buckley School in New York, and owner and director of Wild Goose Camp for Boys, Harmony, Me., died after a heart attack Friday in Englewood (N. J.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived here.

title: Paine, Webber Makes Changes In Ranks of Top Management
description: One of tthe nation's leading brokerage houses, Paine, Web ber, Jackson & Curtis, Inc., which recently disclosed plans to sell stock to the public at some time in the future, an nounced toplevel management changes yesterday.

title: Public Hearings to Open Today On Alleged Police Corruption
description: Tapes and films of what are allegedly typical cases of police corruption are scheduled to be displayed today by the Knapp Commission when it opens two weeks of public hearings.

title: Conover, Voice of Jazz, Is Challenged as a Czar
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 Willis Conover has been de scribed as America's Jazz ambassador. He is credited with the birth and growth of jazz in Russia through his program Music, U.S.A.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: A draft convention for the prohibi tion of biological warfare was sub mitted to the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 30. Although the framers of the draft convention, the United States foremost among them, reaffirm their adherence to the prin ciples and objectives of the 1925 Geneva Protocol, and call upon all states to comply strictly with them, the effect of the draft convention is to undermine the clear prohibition of the Geneva Protocol, which bans the first use in war of asphyxiating, poi sonous or other gases, and of all anal ogous liquids, materials or devices and of bacterial methods of warfare.

title: Jets Defeat Bills on Davis's Passes, 2817;
description: With two touchdown passes by Bob Davis and two other touchdowns out of the resur rected T formation with three running backs, the New York Jets scored more points in their 2817 victory over the Buffalo Bills yesterday than they had in their four previous games this season.

title: Nixon Orders Clarification Of School Lunch Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) Responding to an appeal from 59 Senators, the White House announced today that President Nixon has ordered the Agri culture Departure to clarify a controversial set of school lunch regulations imposed earlier this fall.

title: Arkansas Liberals Divided. Over Potential Supreme Court Nominee's Role in Integration Resistance
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 17  Liberal opponents of Presi dent Nixon in Arkansas are divided over his reported con sideration of Herschel H. Fri day, a Little Rock lawyer, for appointment to the Supreme Court.

title: JUDY RANKIN TAKES PLAYOFF ON 2D HOLE
description: WACO Tex., Oct. 17 (UPI) Judy Rankin sank a tapin shot for a par on the second hole of a suddendeath golf playoff to day to defeat Jane Blalock in the Quality First Classic at the Waco Country Club.

title: PANEL WOULD GIVE STATE FISCAL RULE OVER THE SCHOOLS Special Commission Sees It as a Way to Make Public Education Equal for AU PRESENT OUTLAYS VARY Cities Spending Less Than Suburbs, and U.S. Courts Have Decried Inequity
description: A majority of a special state commission favors a plan to have the state assume responsi bility for raising and distribut ing all funds for public elemen tary and secondary schoolsa Iradical change intended to pro duce greater parity in school expenditures between poor and wealthier districts:

title: Saints Upset Cowboys, 24 to 14
description: While indecision remains as to whether Craig Morton or Roger Staubach is to be the Cowboys starting quarterback, Archie Manning, the rookie sig nalcaller for the Saints, en hanced the chances for his job by forging a 2414 upset vic tory over Dallas at New Or leans yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If the assailants of medical student Steven Schleifer (shot in the back by a gang because he refused them 25 cents) are even sentenced to jail, will they then reach the status of polit ical prisoners? If they riot while in prison, will they be apologized for by Tom Wicker, defended by Herman Badillo and celebrated by William Kunstler?

title: Sarah Bergman Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Sarah Bergman was married here yesterday after noon to Daniel Greer, first deputy commissioner to the Department, of Ports and Ter minals in the New York City Economic Development Ad ministration. Rabbi Joseph B. Soloveitchik performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz, where he was assisted by Rabbis Emanuel Gettinger and Steven Riskin.

title: JOHN P. DAKIN
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Oct. 17 (AP)Dutchess County Un dersheriff John P. Dakin died here today, after suffering a heart attack. He was 56 years old and lived in Pleasant Val ley.

title: CAUTION IS URGED IN CUTTING TAXES
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 The American Bankers Associa tion today called on Congress and by inference the Nixon Administration as well  to move slowly in reducing per sonal income taxes as part of the President's economic policy.

title: H.E.W. Aide Here Named
description: David Grossman, formerly the Federal official in charge of the Model Cities program in the New York region, has been named to head the community services office in the regional headquarters of the Depart ment of Health, Education and Welfare. Bernice L. Bernstein, H.E.W. regional director, said Mr. Grossman would be respon sible for increasing the effec tiveness of the department's programs at the community level.

title: Westbury Wins Polo Final By Beating Bethpage, 5 to 3
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 17 Westbury defeated Bethpage, 5.3, today to win the Long Is land industrial recreational championship in the final polo match of the season at Beth page State Park.

title: AMEX PLAN SEEKS A SINGLE MARKET
description: The American Stock Exchange has formulated a plan for new national stock market that would compass all of the na tion's existing stock exchanges in one vast trading system.

title: Chess:
description: The new champion of Sweden is SvenGeren Maim gren, a 28yearold student from Goteborg, who won the title in a tournament held re cently at Eskilstuna with a score of 104.

title: POLICY DECISIONS AWAITED ON BONDS
description: Bond prices scored impres sive gains last week, but some climbed so much that investors balked at accepting the lower yields they were being offered.

title: and Sewage Treatment
description: In the intense competition for debt limit funds those capital expenditures permitted to localities under the lawsewage treatment and disposal facilities regu larly lose out. The appeal of new schools, new highways and other improvements too often shunts these projects to the back of the drawing boards.

title: Stage: The Norwegian Troll Again
description: Ibsen seemsmost happily to be in favor these days'After many years of neglect, New York appears to be re evaluating the old Norwe gian troll and even finding his work unobtrusively rele vant to our times. Last night the Roundabout Theater  that mighty minitheater un derneath a Chelsea super market  opened its season with a production of The Master Builder, the first time this sixyearold com pany has tackled Ibsen.

title: ServanSchreiber Elected President of Radical Party
description: PARIS, Oct. 17  Jean Jacques ServanSchreiber, the author and politician, today was elected president of the Radical party.

title: IMPRESSIVE DEBUT BY MARILYN VONDRA
description: Marilyn Vondra made her debut at Tully Hall Sunday afternoon, her fetching talent all the more pleasurable for arriving unheralded. The so prano projects a light, sweet tone, her voice capable of con siderable dynamic emphasis, but most often used with a relaxed and graceful delicacy. Her phrasing was appropriate, she showed a gratifying aware ness of her songs poetic con tent, and she neither wandered from pitch nor produced an unlovely sound all afternoon.

title: The Disestablishment of Science: I
description: On. Feb. 2, 1939, my late friend and colleague Leo Szilard sent a letter to Prof. J. F. JoliotCurie in France in which he proposed that atomic physi cists should make a voluntary agree ment not to publish any new findings on the fission of uranium. It was a crucial time in history. The date was shortly after Munich; Hitler was riding high and was clearly determined to make war. And just at this threaten ing moment, results were published which left no doubt that the atom of uranium could be split and neutrons released in the process. Szilard con cluded that a chain reaction could be produced and warned JoliotCurie: In certain circumstances this might then lead to the construction of bombs which would be extremely dangerous in general and particularly in the hands of certain governments.

title: Pittsburgh Victory Fete Erupts Into Riot
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 (AP) Thousands of persons rioted in the downtown area to night after the Pittsburgh Pirates had won the World Series.

title: U.S. Attorneys Here Propose System to Speed Appeals
description: United States Attorneys Whitney North Seymour Jr. and Robert A. Morse of the South ern and Eastern Districts of New York respectively, an nounced yesterday that new ad ministrative procedures would be begun to cut by 30 days the time involved in Federal criminal appeals in the New York area.

title: Voznesensky Here For Poetry Tour
description: The popular and esteemed Russian poet Andrei Voz nesensky arrived here last night for a monthlong tour of American college cam puses. Though he speaks English easily, he will read his poems in Russian at 15 campuses, depending on image and intonation rath er than words to convey his sense.

title: Notre Dame, Penn State Top the List of Uncommitted Contenders for Bowls
description: The shakedown during the first half of the college foot ball season has left 11 major teams undefeated and untied and three leading bowls begin ning to develop plans around the future successes of seven of those teams.

title: REVSON IS VICTOR DESPITE PROTEST
description: MONTREAL, Calif., Oct. 17 Peter Revson won his fifth CanAm race of the season to day in a smokespewing finish that was marked by confusion, controversy and protest.

title: Relief and Shock in Belfast

The pollution unit is dioxide and dust emissions from the coalburning steam generators.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Nearly all of the city's top elected officials, all but one of whom is a Democrat, re gard with wry amusement Mayor Lindsay's crosscoun try travels to establish rap pert with Democratic offi cials.

title: Squires Wins A.A.U. Run.
description: Pete Squires of the New York Athletic Club defeated Howie Ryan, his clubmate, yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 25kilometer championship at Van Cortlandt Park. The runners were both clocked in 1 hour 27 minutes 21.8 seconds. Joe Boyle of the New York A.C. was third in 1:27.40.

title: Inflationary Ride to School
description: Termination of the $1amonth transportation passes the city formerly issued for all schoolchildren has forced the families of about 120,000 pupils in New York's public, parochial and private schools to pay the full amount of their children's daily bus and subway fares. Under the new rules, pupils who live less than specific distance from school are no longer eligible for passes. The dis tances vary according to grade level. As a result, the cost of getting these pupils to and from school has sky rocketedfrom $1 to at least $12 a month. The amount is twice that high for many youngsters who must use more than one public carrier each way.

title: RANGERS TOPPLE CANADIENS, 8 TO 4
description: On an electric night when they humbled the proud Mon treal Canadiens, the Rangers, achieved a few milestones last night as they scored an 84 vic tory.

title: Torture in Northern Ireland Is Charged
description: LONDON, Oct. 17Charges that brainwashing and third degree methods are being used against men detained in North ern Ireland aroused deep polit ical concern here tonight.

title: Mrs. Nona M'Adoo Park, Daughter of Senator, Dies
description: Mrs. Nona McAdoo Park, daughter of the late William Gibbs McAdoo, Senator from California and Secretary of the Treasury during the Wilson Ad ministration, died at her home yesterday. She lived at 447 East 57th Street.

title: The Screen: Incest Is Theme of Malle's 'Le Souffle':Lea Massari Portrays Non-French Mother Benoit Ferreux Plays 15-Year-Old Boy
description: The directorial career of Louis Malle has followed a general though by no means spectacular decline from the time 10 years ago, when he was widely regarded as a major hope of the French New Wave, to the present, when he is scarcely regarded at all. After an initial outburst of such highly individual and charmingly perverse conceits as "The Lovers" (1958) and "Zazie dans le Mtro" (1960), he has descended, through bouts of quality and commerce, to his latest film, "Le Souffle au Coeur," in which the major purpose of perversity is to charm.The point is not that "Le Souffle au Coeur" is a terrible moviethough it isn't very goodbut that it could probably have been made with as much distinction by any of those directors, all equally anonymous, who specialize in urban romantic comedy (or tragedy) of a sophistication that is supposed to be peculiarly French. "Le Souffle au Coeur" is comedy, and I guess its sophistication is a bit peculiar.Its hero is the 15-year-old son (Benoit Ferreux) of upper-middle-class parents, who is passing onto maturity and who discovers that for sexual initiation as for everything else, a mother is a boy's best friend. It is, I should say, a happy incest movie, with the addition of a somewhat nervous morality requiring a) that the boy no sooner have his mother than he must rush out to take the nearest unrelated teenage girl, thereby proving his normality, and b) that his mother's joyful experience cancel out a previous extramarital affair, so that she returns to hearth and home. A family that plays together stays together.Lea Massari is the mother, and it is important that she is beautiful, vivacious, generally affectionate, fantastically youthful  and not French. Indeed, so much is made of her warm Italian temperament that I suspect the working of a kind of national-character protectionism. Although Benoit Ferreux receives from Malle's camera the greater glamour treatment (he has sensitive good looks, but seems reserved to the point of placidity), Miss Massari is more properly the film's star. In a different kind of movie out of a different tradition I think she might have managed the major performance that ever since I first saw her (as the lost girl in "L'Avventura") she seems to have promised.Nothing in "Le Souffle au Coeur" seems very necessary but perhaps the most pleasantly gratuitous element is the time, the early 1950's. Except for references to Indochina, styles of dress and styles of jazz, Malle has kept period authenticity to a gratifying minimum. But he has indulged himself in two minor characters, the boy's older brothers (Marc Winocourt and Fabien Ferreux). Lying, cheating, stealing, drinking, wenching and insulting their elders, they are the very incarnation of 1950's juvenile delinquency. Of course they seem terribly classic and lovable. But in their genuinely outrageous vitality they are also the best reminder of the imaginitive world Louis Malle used to inhabit  and can still, when the inspiration strikes."Le Souffle au Coeur" played Saturday night at the Vivian Beaumont Theater, the last selection in the New York Film Festival. Under the title "Murmur of the Heart," it opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie.

title: Steel Inventories Approach the End Of Cutting Period
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 The end of steeel invntory cutting, was in sight last week. This had not shown up in orders, but large users were providing tar get date for the stabilizing of steeel locks. Officials of one automobile company said all excess inventory would be gone by the end of November. Jan. 1 appeared to be a more genera1 turning point for auto companies and others.

The phrase does not sug gest an appointee who is likely to be a great justice of that Court. Indeed, given the nature of the Court's work, the phrase is not very helpful in the process of selection.

title: Tokyo Giants Win Series
description: TOKYO, Oct 17 (AP)  The, Tokyo Yomiuri Giants walloped the Hankyu Braves, 61, today, capturing a record seventh Japan Series championship be fore a near capacity crowd of 43,500 at Korakuen Stadium.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Oct. 4 editorial Road to Mid east Peace rightly characterized Abba Eban's five roads to peace as an excursion into familiar byways and imaginatively stated the need for new directions when peace talks are stalled. Yet ideas which the editorial offered are no more likely to bring peace than Mr. Eban's.

title: For Community Development

As a result, New York State has been unable to mount an effective attack on urban blight; it has been handi capped in trying to unleash private investment and to meet emerging needs for middleincome housing, univer sity dormitories and a range of community facilities from daycare centers to gymnasiums.

title: Concentus Musicus Excites Enthusiasts Of Its Each Style

As with Stokowski's grand iose Bach transcriptions at the other end of the spectrum, a middle ground is evidently im possible: either you will love it or hate it and there are weighty arguments on both sides.

Shallowbrook A of Somers, Conn., will play, Ox Ridge, Shallowbrook B will meet Monroe (Conn.), and the Greenwich Pitchforks will meet West Hills (L. I.).

title: Books of The Times
description: It had to happen, and Peter De Vries was bound to be the writer to do it. The hero and first person narrator of Into Your Tent I'll Creep, one Albert Banghart, is a Lardneresque sheik from Chicago's South Side who thinks that VillaLobos is somebody's country estate and New York's port authority is a wine expert. During a slack period in his quail hunting, Banghart runs into an old highschool French teacher of his, Rose Piano by name, who on closer inspection turns out to be not so old, and single into the bargain. A friendship develops, then a marriage. But since Rose is an intellectual and liberated, and since Al is unambitious and compliant, their marriage is the kind we've all been trying to imagine lately: she goes out to work and comes back with money; he keeps house and gossips over the backyard fence. (Neighboring housewife: Tell me, how do you get your wash so white? Banghart: I use Swish, now with improved enzyme power, I never have to presoak.)

title: Accident Blocks Route 95
description: CRANSTON, R.I., Oct. 13 (AP)A truck carrying gasoline overturned on Interstate 95 today, spilling part of its 2,500gallon load. The southbound lane was closed and traffic was rerouted over side streets.

title: A Piece of America
description: With the public and most members of Congress paying no attention, the Federal Government is about to give away a piece of America. The land is some of the most rugged and picturesque and richly endowed with animals as any on this continent. If it were in Connecticut or Colorado, this handout of 50 million acres would evoke an outcry that would shake the capital.

title: Milton T. Lasher Is Dead; Lawyer, ExJersey Mayor
description: UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N. J., Oct., 18Milton T. Lasher, a lawyer and former Mayor of Edgewater, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: SENATE UNIT OPENS GRIEVANCE HEARINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Because a veteran Foreign Service officer committed suicide last April after he had been dismissed without a pension and refused a grievance hearing, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee began hearings this morning on two bills creating grievance boards for State Department employes.

title: Casey Says S.E.C. Is Near Decisions
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18William J. Casey, chairman of the Securities and Exchange. Commission, disclosed today that the commission was close to reaching a decision on a number of issues involving mutual funds, in addition to all those it is considering involving the future of the stock exchanges.

title: Peter Kihss of Times Honored by Silurians
description: Peter Kihss, a generalassignment reporter, for The New York Times, was honored last night by the Society of the Silurians, receiving a gold quill marking his continued distinguished journalistic work during more than 25 years.

title: Kosygin Attacked in Ottawa by Man Shouting Long Live Free Hungary!
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 18A min shouting Long live free Hungary! jumped on Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin's back here today as the Soviet leader and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau began a short walk across Parliament's grounds.

title: JOHN GRAHAM DIES; GEOSCIENTIST WAS 53
description: EAST HARPSWELL, Me., Oct. 19 John W. Graham, a geoscientist and educator, died in his home here Saturday. He was 53 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: For the longest, while the baseball cognoscenti held firm to the conviction that the Baltimore Orioles were the best team in baseball. They had everything in such extravagant quantities that they even looked to be an incipient dynasty in the same overwhelming pattern of the old Yankees. From now on, though, any such Oriole fanciers will have great difficulty in proving their theory.

title: U.N. CHINA DEBATE OPENS WITH TAIPEI AND THE U.S. SPLIT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18The United States and Nationalist China differed sharply in the General Assembly today on the question of. admitting Communist China to the United Nations.

title: Peruvians to Airlift Supplies To Towns Struck by Quake
description: LIMA, Peru, Oct. 18 (Reuters) Peruvian authorities organized a helicopter airlift tonight to carry drugs and supplies to survivors cut off by thousands of tons of fallen rock in an earthquakestricken valley in southeastern Peru.

title: An Aopraisal
description: TEHERAN, Oct. 18  The pageants were spectacular enough. The guest list was exceedingly itnpressive and the celebration of Persia's 2,560th anniversary was certainly one of the most brilliantly catered in history.

title: Indomitable Bette Davis in Gimmick Comedy
description: Bette Davis's motion picture career, which began about 40 years ago, has been recycled more often than the average rubber tire, often with resultslike "The Nanny" and "Anniversary"that convince you there is a definite limit to the number of times any organic resource can be profitably reclaimed.I say that quickly and ruthlessly because not recently (certainly not since "What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?") have I admired the star's wit, courage, discipline, talent and guts in quite the same degree as I did yesterday, watching her in a silly, foolishly entertaining movie that may well disappear before anyone else sees it."Bunny O'Hare," directed by Gerd Oswald, a man whose strengths have never been in comedy, is a gimmick comedy, unusual in the fact that to be told its gimmick is to know the very worst there is about the film. Everything else is an improvement.As Bunny O'Hare, the sort of little old lady who wears blue sneakers and what looks to be a man's rain hat, Miss Davis plays a member of the Silent Majority who takes to robbing banks, disguised as a hippie, with the collaboration of a real bank robber played by Ernest Borgnine. As I said, the gimmick is dreadful. Miss Davis, however, gives a performance that may be one of the funniest and most legitimate of her career, which has been spectacular for mannerisms that overwhelmed every character she's ever played, with the notable exceptions of Leslie Crosbie, Regina Giddens and Margo Channing."Bunny O'Hare" is nonsense of a quite acceptable order, filled with absurd chases and stock characters who have been conceived and played with affection, especially by Jack Cassidy as a right-wing detective who believes the bank robbers to be "radical bird lovers" (their ploy is to release canaries in the banks they rob).I also liked Reva Rose and John Astin, as Miss Davis's terrible children, for whom she turns to a life of crime; Joan Delaney, as a pretty, completely sane criminal psychologist, and, of course, Borgnine, who, like Miss Davis, refuses to notice that the comedy he's in is as broad, and full of potholes as the state of New Mexico, where the movie was shot. Class will out.Also on the bill with "Bunny O'Hare," currently at neighborhood theaters, is "The Velvet Vampire," which is almost as funny as "Bunny O'Hare," though I doubt that it means to be. It has to do with a beautiful, 125-year-old woman, the mistress of a remote ranch in the southwest who stocks her own blood bank with tourists dumb enough to spend the night. It is to be recommended only if you can see it at the New Amsterdam on 42d Street, where audiences loudly, freely and obscenely associate with the action on the screen.

title: Heath Frees Party for Market Entry Vote
description: LONDON, Oct. 18  Prime Minister Heath, in an unexpected change of tactics, freed his Conservative party followers in Parliament today to vote as they choose in the crucial decision on entry into the European Common Market.

title: Winding Down Pay Inflation
description: Perhaps the toughest problem awaiting the Pay Board that President Nixon will appoint this week is what do about wage increases due in the next two or three years under union contracts already signed. No comparable hurdle confronted the administrators of wage controls in World War II and the Korean war because longterm agreements of the kind now general in basic industries were a rarity then.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNINGS ADVANCE AT BIG CHICAGO BANK
London Sets Inquiry on Reports Ulster Suspects Were Tortured
description: LONDON, Oct. 18The British Government ordered an official inquiry tonight into charges that detained suspects in Northern Ireland were being brainwashed and tormented to give information.

title: CITY AIDE BACKS HOMOSEXUAL BILL
description: Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday that the Lindsay administration supported passage of a bill prohibiting discrimination against homosexuals, in housing and employment and that she expected Police and Fire Department officials to support the job aspect of the measure.

title: MINUTEMEN CASE IS DROPPED HERE
description: A highly publicized case in, which 16 men allegedly linked to the rightwing paramilitary Minutemen were seized and indicted five years ago has been dropped with the last remaining charges dismissed.

title: PENTAGON WATCHING SOVIET NAVAL FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 18 (Reuters)The Pentagon said today that it was watching closely Soviet naval force, possibly including missilecarrying submarines, that had assembled in the midAtlantic and could be headed toward Cuba.

title: PRINCE LAUDS U.S. ON CLEANUP WORK
description: The United States, with its unparalleled industrial technology, has brought on tremendous pollution problems, but Americans also set the world's pace in solving these problems, Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands told a banquet audience at the WaldorfAstoria last night.

title: Pots, Pans and Other Toys
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (UPI)Parents waste their money buying scientifically designed crib devices and educational toys to speed the development of their infants, according to Dr. Richard I. Feinbloom, professor of pediatrics at Harvard Medical School.

title: Factory Output Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Industrial production rose in September, following a sharp drop in August, but failed to regain the levels of the spring and summer, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: SADAT IS PURSUING RECONCILIATION AIM
description: CAIRO, Oct. 18A policy of reconciliation pursued in Egypt by President Anwar elSadat during his year in power was emphasized today by the publication of photographs of three former high officials who broke with the regime of President Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Advertising:
description: The Magazine Publishers Association maintains that the First Amendment covers the advertising as well as the editorial matter in the free press and that the Government is attempting to control the press indirectly by dictating to advertisers.

title: Police Report Smashing of 3 AutoTheft Rings
description: Twentytwo persons were arrested yesterday in wellpublicized raids on 23 garages and junkyards, as the Police Department reported breaking three stolencar rings.

title: RuralPlant Tax Cut Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  Senator James B. Pearson, Republican of Kansas, today Urged a special tax reduction for industries that build new plants in rural areas. In testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, he suggested that the proposed investment tax credit, which would permit Companies to subtract 7 per cent of the cost of new equipment from their taxes, be doubled for companies newly located in areas 25 miles from cities.

title: Record, Fund Inflow Seen For Savings and Loan Units
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 18 (Reuters)Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, predicted today that net new savings received by Savings and Loan Associations this year could more than double last year's record today.

title: A's Williams Is Manager of Year
description: Dick Williams of the Oakland Athletics, dismissed two years ago by Boston because, he said, I was too mean, was named yesterday by The Associated Press manager of the year in the American League.

title: Telly, Princess Pout Score at Big A
description: The thoroughbred activity of the New York Racing Association shifted to Aqueduct yesterday, with a gratifying turnout of 27,880 on hand. From now through the end of the local campaign, Dec. 15, the action will be at the Big A.

title: Public Voice Sought
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Mr. Kolton said today the Amex plan would modify the number of industry representatives on the board while increasing the number of public members. He did not specify how many seats were involved.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: NEW LONDON, N.H.,At times a seething wall of rain driven by a sharp easterly wind nearly obliterated our view of the far side of Pleasant Lake.

title: World Trade Center Rising In Noisy, Confusing World
DAY, ON SCORPIO, IS JUMPING VICTOR
description: HARRISBURG,Pa., Oct. 18Jim Day of Hornby, Ontario, won the coin toss, and as result Canada scored another victory in the international jumping tonight at the Pennsylvania National horse show.

title: Bonn Asks Surtax Data
description: BONN, Oct. 18  The West German Government said today that it could not react to United States Treasury Secretary John B. Connally's reported willingness for a, partial lifting of the United States import surcharge until it saw the official minutes of the Secretary's news conference last Saturday at Hot Springs, Va.

title: Lindsay Joins StateCity Talks to Save 30Cent Fare
description: City officials yesterday began what appeared to be an allout effort to reach an agreement with Governor Rockefeller on the transportation bond issue and the 30cent transit fare

title: First C.5 A Returned to Service; Proxmire Cites a New Accident
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 The Air Force announced today the return to service of the first of 47 grounded C5A transport planes.

title: Eban Unsatisfied on Jets
description: Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel has described Secretary of State William P. Rogers's promised reconsideration of Phantom jets for Israel as important but something that still does not amount to the firm decision that we believe to be urgent. Mr. Eban made his remarks Sunday night at the Stephen S. Wise Award dinner of the. American Jewish Congress at the New York Hilton hotel, where he was one of those honored.

title: AMNESTY IS ASKED FOR ALL WAR FOES
description: A group of 16 lawyers, writers and academicians has petitioned for amnesty for all those who have refused to fight in the war in Vietnam and for those who have run afoul of military law during a war which many, think is itself illegal.

title: Bond Yields Oil on New Issues But Rates on Older Ones Rise
RUSSO BALKS AGAIN ON PENTAGON DATA
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18Anthony J. Russo refused again today to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon Papers after the Justice Department objected to giving him a transcript of his testimony.

title: Air Quality Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The White House announced today Presiednt Nixon's appointment of Coleman duPont Donaldson to the I5member Air Quality Advisory Board.

title: Pittsburgh Deflates Riot Report
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 Police Superintendent Robert E. Colville today said that, despite some reports, there were no serious injuries, no violent crimes against persons and no rapes during the tumultuous celebration last night of the Pirates World Series victory.

title: 3Way Talks Deciding Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The future of President Nixon's welfare reform program is being decided behind the scenes in a series of delicate threecornered negotiations between the White House and two mutually hostile Senate power blocs.

title: Market Place: Taking a Look At Accounting
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 18The Rebecca Crown Center at Northwestern University here is like a gracefully modern castle, with its exposed concrete columns and beams and its vertical windows peeking from behind lime stone visors. The offices inside are highly functional.

title: Film:
description: Travel may be broadening but it also can be debilitating if Secret Rites, the documentary now at the Forum Theater, is any yardstick. A melange of color footage produced, directed, photographed or collected by Ramiro Arango, a Cuban living and working in Rome, it touches fleetingly, like scavenger bird, on scraps that are real but hardly of abiding interest to anyone but the morbidly curious.

title: Investigations Chief Michael Francis Armstrong
description: Several years ago, a young assistant United States attorney asked a witness who was testifying in ?? Court to give the jury a description of one of the persons involved in the case.

title: Legal Action Planned
description: TOKYO, Oct. 18 (Reuters) The Japanese textile industry said today it intended to take legal action to block last week's United StatesJapanese agreement curbing textile exports to the American market.

title: Sugarman Opposes Incentive Points in Welfare
description: The head on the city's Human Resources Administration told Federal officials and members of Congress yesterday that he opposed a staterequested welfare demonstration project that would slash welfare benefits for residents of West Harem and two upsets counties. The projects would require the welfare recipients to earn incentive points to get back to levels paid relief recipients elsewhere.

title: BURGER HAS VIRUS; GOES HOME EARLY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Chief Justice Warren E. Burger left the Supreme Court bench at noon today and returned home to treat a virus infection.

title: Bush Gives Texas Flair To China Debate at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18If George Bush looks and sometimes sounds like Eastern Establishment, there was the style of an oldfashioned Texas politicking barbeque in his performance in the General Assembly today.

title: WEST GULF PORTS TARGET OF I. L. A,
description: The executive council of the International Longshoremen's Association set up a special committee yesterday in the hope of working out an agreement that would persuade more than 30 West Gulf Coast locals to join a labor stoppage that has, kept ports from Maine to New Orleans closed since Oct. 1.

title: LOWS ANDRE TRAPP
description: AMITYVILLE, L. I., Oct. 18Louis Andre Trapp, who retired five years ago as a partner in the Trapp Press, printers and publishers in Brooklyn, died at Brunswick Hospital here today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 76 years old and lived in Massapequa. Mr. Trapp had been with the company for 45 years.

title: Nock Unhappy on Bench; Contract Hassle Blamed
description: As the Jets prepare for Sun day's visit by the Miami Dol phins, George Nock is smolder ing over his sudden disappear ance as a running back.

title: U.S. Bars Substantial Increase In Its Involvement in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The State Department affirmed today that the Administration was committed to maintaining a low profile in Cambodia and was not considering any plan that would substantially increase the American involvement there.

title: Morgan's Djinn Wins Race In MarylandVirginiaWaters
description: OXFORD, Md., Oct. 18Commodore Henry S. Morgan's Djinn won the Motorsailer Division today in the first race held in the New York Yacht ClubCruising Club of America Chesapeake Station joint cruise through Maryland Virginia waters.

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: War on Poverty and the 1964 Campaign
description: THE first full day of my Presidency was loaded with the urgencies of government in crisis. When I recall that day, I think of people: people entering my office, people leaving my office, people meeting in my office, people waiting in my reception room, a steady stream of people. They included former Presidents, Cabinet officers, leaders of Congress and staff members.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President flew to Camp Detrick, Md., where he spoke at dedication ceremonies naming the base as a new center for cancer research. He returned here in the afternoon and met with Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Robert H. Finch, a White House counselor, to discuss Mr. Finch's visit to Latin America.

title: 76ers Deal Clark to Bullets For Loughery and Carter
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP)The Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association traded Archie Clark, a guard; a secondround choice in the 1973 college draft and an undisclosed amount of cash to the Baltimore Bullets tonight for Kevin Loughery and Fred Carter,, guards.

title: Emission Tests Deferred
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI)  The Government yielded slightly to the auto manufacturers today on rules covering exhaust emissions.

title: On Buying Lovely Things That Last
description: Elaine Cannel contends there's no trick to spending money. But spending it wisely, to buy things that will wear well both in durability and in your affections, well, that's something else again.

title: ExRepresentative Says He Is Guilty Of Tax Evasion
description: ALBANY, Oct. 18Former Representative Martin B. McKneally of Newburgh pleaded guilty in Federal Court here today to one of four charges of failing to report income for tax purposes during the years 196467.

title: Focus on People
description: We can never, by the nature of our work, model our procedures on those of private industry. No matter how many machines we install, hospital care will still depend upon people. This statement by an admin istrator of a member voluntary, nonprofit hospital of the United Hospital Fund of New York sums up the quality of hospital care  its focus on people.

title: Union Protest in San Juan
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Oct. 18 (UPI)About 2,500 union members, chanting, Workers are right... give Nixon a fight, marched through San Juan today to protest the wage freeze and Puerto Rico's exemption from the proposed $2anhour minimum wage. The marchers, representing about 35 labor unions, staged brief rallies in front of the Capitol and the Governor's mansion, tying up traffic in much of old San Juan.

title: Preventive Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The United States expressed concern today over the heightened tensions and buildup of opposing forces along the IndianPakistani border.

title: Six in Queens Indicted in BogusIncinerator Case
description: Six men have been indicted in Queens on charges that they supplied bogus smokecontrol machinery to building owners seeking to meet stringent new airpollution control laws.

title: FLOAT WEIGHED FOR PRIME RATE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct, 18The First National City Bank, the largest bank in New York and secondlargest in the nation may be on the verge of announcing a floating prime rate that would move automatically with interest rates in the open market.

title: M. ARTHUR CAVALLO, RETIRED BANKER, 83
description: M. Arthur Cavallo, a retired vice president of the Bank of Manhattan, died yesterday in St. I Barnabas Hospital, the Bronx. His age was 83. He lived at 3317 84th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: J. F. K. in Retrospect
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Every day of the year under rainy skies or sunshine, ordinary Americans and visitors from overseas come by the hundreds to a hillside in Arlington to visit the grave of John F. Kennedy.

title: MERGER ACCOUNTING MAY BE CHALLENGED
description: EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 18Harvey Kapnick, chairman of Arthur Andersen & Co., hinted strongly today that the accounting firm would challenge in court two of the Accounting Principles Board's opinions on mergers.

title: CORRUPTION JURY CALLS POLICEMEN
description: NEWARK, Oct. 18A Federal grand jury is reportedly investigating charges that several New York policemen invited a New Jersey gambler to set up shop in the Bronx when a bookmaker there went broke and they lost their source of graft payments.

title: O.E.C.D. Study Used
description: PARIS, Oct. 18West Germany is prepared to accept a basic deficit in its balance of payments, while Japan is still aiming for what insiders described as a rather large surplus.

title: G.M.Head Denies Engine Mount Peril
description: DETROIT, Oct. 18Edward Cole, the president of General Motors, said today that there was no real danger in driving Chevrolet Automobiles produced from 1965 through 1969, and asserted that there should not be a recall to replace the motor mounts on the eight million cars.

title: GRANTS ARE GIVEN IN SCIENCE TEACHING
description: The National Science Foundation has announced awards totaling more than $3.1million for programs to improve the teaching of, college science, mathematics and engineering. The awards were made to 49 institutions in 25 states,. the District of Columbia and Bermuda.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Joblessness Up in Poor Urban Areas
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) The Labor Department announced today that unemployment in poverty neighborhoods rose during the summer as a result of a sharp increase in joblessness among Negroes. It also announced that it would stop reporting such statistics during 1972.

title: City Bargaining Unit Seeks To Spur Police Pact Talks
description: The Office of Collective Bargaining, in an effort to spur contract settlements, has asked the city and the police, fire and sanitation unions to appear at a hearing today and report on the issues that separate them.

title: ROCKEFELLER LEADS TRIBUTES TO ALLEN
description: ALBANY, Oct. 18 (UPI)Governor Rockefeller led state officials today in mourning the death of Dr. James E. Allen Jr., who guided New York's education system for 14 years.

title: Rap Brown, in Fair Condition, Is Moved to a $122aDay Room
description: H. Rap Brown, the black militant who was shot and captured early Saturday after more than a year as a fugitive from riot and arson charges, was moved yesterday from Roosevelt Hospital's intensivecare unit on the 11th floor to $122aday private room on the 10th floor.

title: Photographer Who Leemtied From Myself Exhibits Work
description: If one could pin Roman Vishniac between two slides of glass and examine him closely to determine his es sence, what. a bewilderment would be in store.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up at Weekly Auction
Notes on People
description: Under renewed pressure at the United Nations to accept at least a short extension of his term when it expires Dec. 31, Secretary General Thant warned that time was running short for his job to be filled and urged prompt action on a successor.

title: Champion of Education
description: James E. Allen Jr., who was killed with his wife a plane crash last weekend, saw the fundamental issues of social justice with, a clarity that sometimes made his more politically inclined colleagues in school administration slightly uneasy in his presence: Yet he was never selfrighteous or arrogant. He understood why educational officials and politicians were often driven choose the easier road; and he held the respect of even those whose course he vigorously opposed.

title: 23 POLICE RELIEVED IN DEATH IN MEMPHIS
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 18 (UPI) Police Chief Henry Lux said tonight that he had relieved 23 policemen from duty in an investigation of the apparent beating of a Negro youth over the weekend.

title: Greek Opposition Boycotts Agnew Fete
description: ATHENS, Oct. 18Greek opposition politicians boycotted a formal United States Embassy reception for Vice President Agnew tonight rather than be presented to him in the presence of Premier George Papadopoulos, head of the militarybacked regime.

title: Waiting for Johnson
description: Alex Webster and Wellington Mara might be in a situation strikingly similar to that of Vladimir and Estragon, the two leading characters in Samuel Beckett's play, Waiting for Godot.

title: U.S. Plywood Gains
description: Bolstered by increased demand for building materials and home furnishings, thirdquarter earnings of U. S. PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., rose 62.5 per cent to $14,076,000, or 40 cents a share, from $8,663,000, or 22 cents, in the 1970 period.

title: Metal Maker Off 77%
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, in line with industry results reported so far, made the poorest showing in ninemonth earnings in more than 10 years and had the lowest quarterly profit since the company first issued quarterly statements in 1956.

title: Cambodian River Craft Sunk
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 18 (AP)The Cambodian high command reported today that a Cambodian landing craft, part of a convdy of 15 vessels attempting to reach the besieged provincial capital of Kompong Thom, 80 miles northeast of Pnompenh, was sunk today by Vietcong on North Vietnamese shelling.

title: Auden: A Difference in Memories
description: LONDON, Oct. 18He sits in a cluttered room overlooking a leafy garden in North London. He speaks quickly, lighting a cigarette will a trembling hand and then crushing the butt after several puffs.

title: FISCHER IS VICTOR IN BUENOS AIRES Petrosian Loses 6th Game in Chess After 66 Moves
Sharp Fighting Breaks Out Near Cambodia Line
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 19 (AP)Sharp fighting broke out yesterday along the Cambodian border northwest of here, while to the northeast Vietcong units attacked a South Vietnamese hamlet and a military position.

title: Twice Worthy Reported Fit
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 (AP)Twice Worthy was named a likely starter for the $150,000 Washington D.C. International today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SILVER FUTURES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Some confidence seems to have returned to the silver futures market as prices rose again for the fourth straight session on the Commodity Ex change here. Before the rise started it had seemed that the bottom had fallen out of the silver futures market.

title: HAROLD E. PHELAN, CITY TRANSIT AIDE
description: Harold E. Phelan, a member of the community relations staff of the city's Transit Author ity and a past president of the Newspaper Reporters Association, died Sunday of a stroke in Kings County Hospital, on his 55th birthday. He lived in Oceanside, L. I.

title: Film:
description: People with an abiding interest in what young America is thinking today will be happy to learn that with perhaps one exception all the movies in the Whitney Museum's current TeenAge Filmmakers program are concerned with nightmare visions. The one exception is Quiet Snow, a nature study by Rob Hahn and Corey Kaup, which earns its perhaps because after several minutes of pastoral imagery it ends with about 30 seconds of mere blackness accompanied only by noise. For all I know, that may be a nightmare.

title: Early Miscarriages Found Prevalent in OperatingRoom Workers
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 18Women who work in operating rooms seem to experience more spontaneous miscarriages in early pregnancy than other female health workers, a team of Stanford University scientists has reported.

title: Amtrak Official Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The National Railroad Passenger Corporation, Amtrak, today appointed Robert S. Medvecky, 40 years old, of Weston, Conn., as its vice president  general counsel and secretary.

title: SHANISKY TRADED BY METS TO CARDS IN 8PLAYER DEAL
description: Art Shamsky, who had more memories than hits last season with the Mets, was traded yesterday to the St. Louis Cardinals in an eightman deal.

title: HouseOrders Nixon Aides Not to Cut Pupil Lunches
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The House, by a 353to0 vote, passed legislation today ordering the Administration to abandon its plan to eliminate Federal school lunch subsidies for as many as 1.5 million needy children:

title: SCHWEITZER WINS JURY'S CLEARANCE
description: A grand jury investigating a prisoner's allegations that he had bribed an aide to State Supreme Court Justice Mitchell D. Schweitzer and other officials reported yesterday that it had found no basis to indict the officials.

title: Man Accused of Killing 5 Goes on Trial in California
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. Oct. 18 (UPI)John Linley Frazier went on trial today on charges that he murdered an eye surgeon and four, other persons he said were despoiling the environment.

title: JOYCE B. BALOKOVIC, AUTHOR, YACHTSMAN
description: CAMDEN, Me., Oct. 18 Joyce Borden Balokovic, an author and yachtsman, died of cancer today at her home here. Her age was 74. She was the widow of Zlatko Balokovic, YugoslavAmerican violinist.

title: Eisenhower Theater Opens in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Tonight was Republican night at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

title: Sirignano Says He Erred In Reference to Greek Line
description: It was the Hellenic Lines, Ltd.not the Greek Linethat was once fined $5,000 for having allowed a longshore union official, Anthony Scotto, to participate in selecting a pier superintendent, William P. Strignano, executive director and counsel of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, said yesterday.

title: Acting Principal of I.S. 142 Removed a Second Time by Queens Local Board
description: The Community School Board of District 28 in Queens yesterday removed Mrs. Desiree Greenidge for the second time from her post as acting principal of Intermediate School 142.

title: Working Mother Loses Suit To Deduct ChildCare Costs
description: A woman who sued in the United States Tax Court here for the right to be allowed to deduct childcare expenses incurred because she worked has lost her case, which was based on a contention that the relevant provisions of the tax code deprived her of her Constitutional rights.

title: Increases Ruled Out For Security Deposits
description: The Internal Revenue Service said yesterday that increases in apartment security deposits were illegal during the President's wageprice freeze.

title: Orange Bowl's Artificial Turf Criticized as Wilting in the Sun
description: Is it possible for a football field to melt? Apparently it is. The synthetic surface in Miami's Orange Bowl has deteriorated to such a point that on a hot day the players slip and slide over the plastic grass. On Sunday, when the Patriots played the Dolphins, the temperature at field level was 115. Jim Plunkett, the Patriot quarterback who was tackled seven times while trying to pass, said, It was slick as ice. According to a pressbox come, a 413 victory for Miami that had an effect on the outcome, 413 victory for Miami.

title: 250,000 MOBILIZED, SYRIAN CHIEF SAYS
description: LEBANON, Oct. 18  The Syrian President, Lieut. Gen. Hafez alAssad, said today that his country has mobilized a quarter of a million soldiers on the confrontation lines with Israel, and emphasized that we are ready to throw all of our potential into the battle when the time comes.

title: F.B.I. IS CHECKING 2 ON COURT LIST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun to check the backgrounds of Herschel H. Friday of Little Rock and Judge Mildred L. Lillie of Los Angeles, two of the six persons on President Nixon's list of potential nominees for the two vacant seats on the Supreme Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vote Battle, Not Debate, Is U.N. Focus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 18Foreign Minister Chow Shukai, his voice frequently breaking in indignation, stood at the green marble lectern in the General Assembly hall for nearly an hour this afternoon, trying to tell the world why Communist China must not be allowed to replace Nationalist China in the United Nations.

title: Salvaging Families That Compulsive Gambling Nearly Destroyed
description: They're charming and devilmaycare and never worry about tomorrow, Ellie G. said without a smile to the small circle of women. The voice hardened: And they're phonies and liars and they'd mortgage the family for some action.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. to discuss question of SouthWest Africa.

title: The Disestablishment of Science: II
description: We live in a civilization in which science is no longer a profession like any Other. For now the hidden spring of power is knowledge; and more than this, power over our environment grows from discovery. Therefore, those whose profession is knowledge and discovery hold a place which is crucial in our societies: crucial in importance and hence In responsibility. This is true for everyone who follows an intellectual profession; in the sense that I have just described it, ours is an intellectual civilization, and the responsibility of the scientist is, I repeat, only a particular case of the moral responsibility which every intellectual must accept.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Metroliners Resume Speed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 (UPI)  The Penn Central Railroad's Metroliners resumed speed of 100 miles an hour today after a threeday precautionary slowdown. Speed was reduced to 80 miles an hour last Friday after a malfunction of a traction motor. The cars were inspected over the weekend, the railroad said.

title: Excerpts From Knapp Commission Tape on the East Side Brothel
description: A. What are we talking about in figuresapproximately?

title: Russ Togs Officer Resigns
description: Seymour Kaplan has resigned als vice president for sales of Russ Togs, Inc., the apparel concern, after 17 years in the post. Mr. Kaplan, who last night confirmed reports of his plans to resign, is one of two vice presidents who have left Russ Togs recently The other is JosephNathan, who was vice president in charge of fabrics.

title: Administration Acts to Cut Grain Surplus, Lift Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Nixon Administration announced today a program that could raise farm subsidies by $600million or more next year in an effort to reduce surplus production of corn and other livestock feed grains.

title: Rufus R. Rand, the Last Member Of Lafayette Escadrille, Is Dead
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 18Rufus R. Rand, the last survivling member of the Lafayette Escadrille, died Friday at the Lafayette Club. in Minnetonka Beach, a suburb of Minneapolis. He was 79 years old.

title: Muskie Lost Fight but Gains a Backer
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Senator Edmund S. Muskie's unsuccessful intervention in contest over the chairmanship of the Credentials Committee at the 1972 Democratic National Convention paid its first political dividend today.

title: SOVIET DISSIDENT PROTESTS SEARCH
description: MOSCOW, ,Oct. 18 Roy A. Medvedev, a historian who recently defied official warnings by joining in the writing of book published in the West about his brother's detention in a Soviet mental hospital, has reportedly left his job after the Soviet secret police confiscated virtually all of his private papers six days ago.

title: 43,000Job Decline Is Reported in Area By Labor Bureau
description: Employment in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area declined 43,000 from July to August, according to Herbert Bienstock, regional direcfor of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Health Services Criticize Lag in Naming Phase 2 Unit
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18  In the 10 days since the Nixon Administration announced its plan to set up a Committee on the Health Services Industry to help implement Phase Two of the wageprice freeze, no committee has been formed nor has a sense of order emerged as to what it is supposed to do.

title: New Name for High Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) The name of Representative Edward Rutchinson, Republican of Michigan, has been forwarded to the White House for consideration as a Supreme Court nominee. An aide to Mr. Hutchinson said that he had been recommended by Senator Robert P. Griffin, Representative Gerald R. Ford and other members of the Michigan Congressional delegation.

title: Amex Posts 4th Straight Loss in Slower Trading
JURY IS SELECTED IN STOCK FRAUD CASE
description: A jury was selected yesterday in Federal Court for the trial of 10 men accused of conspring to violate Federal laws in the sale and purchase of stocks.

title: Body Found in Car Trunk
description: The partially decomposed body of a man was found yesterday in the trunk of a stolen car parked in the central Bronx, the police reported. Detectives of the Bathgate Avenue Station identified the man as Malcolm Graham, 31 years old, of 665 East 181st Street, the Bronx. The police said the cause of death was undetermined pending an autopsy.

title: Cambodia's Khmer Ballet Makes U.S. Debut Tonight
description: Young women who strike poses that defy human bone structure and whose grace persuasively explains why their predecessors were once considered divine will fill the Brooklyn Academy of Music's stage tonight as the Classical Khmer Ballet from Cambodia makes its United States but.

title: Handgun Licenses Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Senator Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, Democrat of Illinois, called today for legislation to require all handgun owners to obtain a Federal license. He also advocated registration of all handguns.

title: KNAPP UNIT TELLS OF POLICE BRIBERY AS HEARINGS OPEN
description: The chief counsel of the Knapp Commission said yesterday that as a result of a yearlong investigation of the New York Police Department, the commission had concluded the department has a serious cor ruption problem that must be characterized as extensive.

title: Nixon Counts on Conversion of Military Facilities
description: FORT DETRICK, Md., Oct. 18President Nixon expressed the hope today that as the nation moved from a wartime to a peacetime era it could convert many of its military facilities to meet pressing domestic challenges.

title: 2 IN ALBANY BACK SCHOOL FUND PLAN
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 18Two key members of the State Legislature said today that they were sympathetic to the idea of the state's assuming a far greater responsibility for raising and distributing funds for public elementary and secondary schools, as a special state commission is expected to propose soon.

title: Naming of Pay and Price Panel Members Still Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Nixon. Administration's announcement of the names of members of two panels that will play key roles in the second phase of its economic stabilization program has been delayed by clearances and refusals to serve, according to Government sources.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Reduced 4,000 More
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 18 (AP)  The United States command announced today that American military strength in South Vietnam dropped another 4,000 men last week to a total of 206,000.

title: RISE IN NET POSTED BY PACIFIC LIGHTING
Bridge: Death of Bach in Bermuda Is a Major Loss for Game
description: The world of bridge lost one of its bestloved personalities when Norman Bach died Saturday in Bermuda at the age of 68. He was the founder of the present series of world championship contests for the Bermuda Bowl, which was started on his initiative in 1950. For the next two decades he was. a familiar figure at world championships, sometimes representing Bermuda in a World Olympiad, sometimes presenting the Bermuda Bowl to the winners.

title: 400 Women Try to Measure Up for Bunny Jobs
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J. Nearly 400 aspiring Bunnies hippetyhopped up to Suite 311 of the Holiday Inn here over the weekend. There were tall brunette girls and small blond ones, most with impressive meaurements.

title: LOSSES REPORTED BY PENNSY TRUSTEES
description: The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company reported yesterday a $23.2million net loss for August, which brought the net loss for the first eight months of this year to $179.2million. The net operating loss for August was $6.8,4million, and for the first eight, months it was $110,5million.

title: Depository Discussed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (Reuters)A corporation to serve as a national clearing house and depository for all securities transactions should he created as the best solution to the present operational crisis, Junius Peake of Shields & Co., told a House Commerce subcommittee today.

title: Researchers at a Symposium on Drug Abuse at Stanford University Foresee a Brave New 1984
description: STANFORD, Calif., Oct. 18Scientists today sketched a brave new 1984 beyond the wildest dreams of George Orwell and Aldous Huxley.

title: U.S. Lags in Development Of New Atomic Reactors
description: Within the next year, either Peter Mummery, head of a reactor development center in northern Scotland, will send champagne to his Soviet counterpart at Shevchenko on the Caspian Sea, or vice versa.

title: SECOND GUN DOUBTED IN ATTACK BY SIRHAN
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18Los Angeles County District Attorney Joseph P. Busch today cleared a police ballistics expert of charges that he improperly conducted ballistics tests in connection with the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy.

title: 28% RAISE ACCEPTED AT WASHINGTON POST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (UPI) Commercial an deditorial employes of The Washington Post agreed today to accept a 30month contract that would provide them with an overall pay increase of 28 per cent.

title: Public Finance Department Set Up by First Boston Corp
description: The First Boston Corporation, in a move that reflected recent growth and greater complexity of local government financing, announced yesterday the formation of a public finance, department under the direction of Ralph S. Saul, vice chairman of the firm and a former president of the ,American Stock Exchange.

title: Plans for New Emmy Telecast And Slate of Officers Listed
description: The National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences announced yesterday plans for the 197172 Emmy Awards telecast and the election of a new slate of officers.

title: U. S. Pilot Killed in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Oct. 18 (AP)The United States Embassy announced today that a United States Air Force observation plane was shot down over northern Laos today and the American pilot killed. The plane, piloted by, an Air Force officer from the air attache's office here, was searching for enemy troops along the western edge of the Plaine des Jarres.

title: Suspect Held in Slaying Of Girl, 10, in Harlem
description: A 62yearold bookbinder was arrested and charged with murder last night in the death Saturday of a 10yearold Harlem girl who found strangled in a tenement backyard.

title: Kahane Detained at Montreal
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (Canadian Press)Rabbi Meir Kahane, head of the militant Jewish Defense League, was detained by immigration officials on his arrival at Montreal International. Airport tonight, spokesman for Air Canada said.

title: Vivian Blaine to Return In Company Star Role
description: Vivian Blaine, who created the memorable role of Adelaide, the star of the Hot Box Club in Guys and Dolls, is returning to Broadway Nov. 1 in the starring role of. Joanne in Company, the Stephen Sondheim George Furth musical.

title: Man Apparently Slain Revived After Stabbing
description: A man believed to be in his late 20's was in critical condition in Polyclinic Hospital last night after apparently being stabbed in the chest in the midtown area.

title: Dr. Kenneth Marshall, Official Of Antipoverty Programs, Dies
description: Dr. Kenneth E. Marshall, project chairman for the department of environmental research and development of the American Telegraph and Telephone Company and former director and associate of antipoverty programs in Paterson, N., and of Haryou in New York ,City, drowned Saturday night in a boating accident off the World's Fair Marina. He was 46 years old.

title: Judicial Record Scored
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct 18 (UPI)Judge Lillie was overruled unanimously by the California Supreme Court in four key cases earlier this year, Harvard law professor said today.

title: Advertising:
description: Tall, chic, handsome, talented, dedicated, articulate, concerned. You could hang any or all of those descriptions on Margot Shermanas well as liberated women and you'd be right enough. But what she'd really much prefer is just advertising professional.

title: I.D.S. UNIT SUING STOCK EXCHANGE
description: Jeffcries & Co., a brokerage subsidiary of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., filed suit yesterday against the New York Stock Exchange, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and 74 Individuals, charging antitrust violations.

title: HONG KONG DENIES REPRISALS TO U.S.
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 18The Hong Kong Government will MA take any reprisals for the American imposition of severe quota limitations on the imports of Hong Kongmade woolen and synthetic textiles.

title: Warning by Mrs. Gandhi
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 18 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has declared that the military situation on the borders between India and Pakistan is quite grave.

title: THREE ECONOMISTS TAKING NEW POSTS
description: Three Wall Street financial economists are moving to new positions.

title: House Votes Ship Safety Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) A bill to let the Coast Guard run a vesseltraffic system at congested ports and set safety rules for ships using crowded waters passed the House today, 335 to 1. The bill was sent to hearings Senate, which has held hearings on a broader measure.

title: Judge in Alabama Invokes Antibusing Law first Time
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 18 (AP)  A state court judge invoked a new state law for the first time today in ordering Brimingham school authorities to admit five white students to the school of their choice rather than the one to which they had been assigned by a Federal court.

title: F.C.C. Weighs TV Bans on China Show
description: The Federal Communications Commission is expected to act in two weeks on complaints that the three television networks and nine local stations refused to sell time for an hourlong program protesting the admission of the People's. Republic of China to the United Nations.

title: U.S. GRANTS ASYLUM TO SOVIET DEFECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP The State Department announced today that Anatoly Chebotarev, a former Soviet trade mission employe in Brussels, is in the United States after having been granted political asylum.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18Here are some of the new books designed to help light the way through the coming Presidential election year:

title: Michael Bradshaw Dies; ExEditor of Toledo Blade
description: TOLEDO, Oct. 18 Michael Bradshaw, a newspaperman for 37 years in six cities, and former editor of The Blade here, was found dead Sunday in hotel room in Cambridge, Mass. He was 68 years old.

title: C. MERTON ROHRABAUGH
description: ABINGTON, Pa., Oct. 18 C. Merton Rohrabaugh, former president and board chairman of Kudner Agency, Inc., New York advertising company, died of a heart attack at a hospital here yesterday. He was 77 years old and lived in Huntingdon Valley.

title: Water on the Moon?
description: The most surprising information yet obtained about the moon has been announced by two Rice University scientists, who believe they have detected water on its surface in the form of geysers emerging from cracks caused by moonquakes. So vital are the implications of this report that confirmation (or refutation) of its conclusions is probably now the most important single item on the agenda of lunar science.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Kissinger on Way to Chinal
description: HILO, Hawaii, Oct. 18 (AP)Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser, left here this afternoon on a Presidential jet for China Mr. Kissinger is journeying to Peking to arrange for Mr. Nixon's forthcoming visit.

title: Zen Diet Assailed By A.M.A. Council As Peril to Health
description: The American Medical Association's Council on Foods and Nutrition yesterday called the Zen macrobiotic diet one of the most dangerous dietary regimens and expressed deep concern over its increasing popularity, particularly among adolescents.

title: MENTALCARE CRISIS REPORTED IN STATE
description: Charging that a crisis exists in the state's mental hospitals, representatives of parent groups and voluntary agencies in the mentalhealth field organized a campaign last night to urge remedial action.

title: Those Textile Quotas
description: The quota agreement with Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Korea on noncotton products will not seriously affect the flow of textiles and apparel from abroad in the coming months, nor will there be any significant upward surge of prices on either imports or domestic goods. An allowance of a 5 per cent increase of Japanese textile exports to the United States over the next three years and a 7 per cent increase in Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Koreaprovides a very substantial base to build up allowable quotas.

title: CANFIELD RECAPS BUSY BOOK LIFE
description: It may come as something of a surprise to learn that Cass Canfield, the urbane publisher who prodded Leon Trotsky, Eleanor Roosevelt, John F. Kennedy and Svetlana Alliluyeva into writing boolcs for him should have failed to obtain Marshal Tito's memoirs when he visited Yugoslavia shortly after World War II.

title: Murtaugh Weighs Future as Pilot
description: While the Baltimore Orioles prepared to head for Japan tomorrow, the Pittsburgh Pirates began yesterday to divide the spoils of their World Series victory and count the casualties.

title: CONNALLY TO SEE THIEU INSTALLED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18In a gesture that drew wide diplomatic attention, President Nixon has named Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally to represent him at the inauguration of the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, on Oct. 31. Mr. Connally will make other stops in Asia and perhaps elsewhere, Administration sources said tonight.

title: 54 Jersey City Clergymen Backing Jordan for Mayor
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 18The traditional ties between the Roman Catholic Church and the oldline Democratic organization were challenged here today when a group of clergymen dominated by Catholics announced their support of Dr. Paul. Jordan, the reform candidate in next month's special Mayoral election.

title: Excerpts From Statements in General Assembly on the Repiesentation of China.
An Apollo 17 Experiment Will Seek Water on Moon
description: A radiowave experiment is planned for Apollo 17 to search for the water that some scientists now believe may lie beneath the moon's surface.

title: C.A.B. HINTS AT BIAS IN A FARE FOR AGED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The Civil Aeronautics Board said today that a proposal by KLM Royal Dutch AirlineS to offer a lowcost transAtlantic fare to senior citizens had raised questions of poSsible unlawful discrimination.

title: Cleveland Electric Slates Nuclear Plant for Ohio
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company announced yesterday plans for building $632 million nuclear power plant in Perry Lake County, Ohio, some 35 miles east of Cleveland.

title: I.T.T. AND HIGBIE SET MERGER DEAL
description: The Higbie Manufacturing Company of Rochester Mich., announced last night that letter of intent had been signed with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation for the acquisition of Higbie by the diversified company in a deal valued at about $39million.

title: Those Crucial Court Vacancies
description: WASHINGTONWhat you want is favor, not justice, said Oliver Wendell Holmes to a labor leader at a White House dinner one night. But when I am on my job I don't give a damn what you or Mr. Roosevelt [his host] wants. (Referring to Theodore Roosevelt, who had appointed him to the Supreme Court).

title: U.S. CONCESSIONS TO PANAMA SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18The United States is preparing to cede to Panama substantial territory, commercial concessions and some legal jurisdiction in the 500squaremile Panama Canal Zone, according to American and Latin diplomats.

title: Dr. Allen's Body Among 10 Lifted From Mountain Slope
description: KINGMAN, Ariz., Oct. 19 (AP)The bodies of Dr. James E. Allen Jr. and nine other persons who died Saturday when a small aircraft crashed were lifted from a rugged Arizona mountain slope today and transported 80 miles to Kingman.

title: Connally to Visit 3 Nations In Asia After Thieu Inaugural
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The White House said today that Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally would visit Thailand, the Philippines and Japan and perhaps other Asian countries after he goes to Saigon to represent President Nixon at the inauguration of President Nguyen Van Thieu on Oct. 31.

title: Pardee Key to Redskin Success
description: Three times last Sunday Jack Pardee backpedaled quickly from the line of scrimmage 10 yards deep into the passing lane because he knew the pass was coming. Three times a Cardinal pass did come and three times Pardee intercepted it. I feel as good now as when I was 21 and I'm a helluva lot smarter, he said afterward. John Perry Pardee is a 35yearold line backer for the Redskins and somewhat typical of the Washington team that has won five straight games to astound the National Football League.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISAt home the United States has frozen wages and prices but abroad there is an opposite trend. President Nixon is deliberately unfreezing our overseas position. Both the American dollar and American diplomacy are afloat.

title: JUSTICES TO HEAR 111W. VOTE PLEA
description: WASHNGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the campaign manager of the late Joseph A. Yablonski should be allowed to intervene in a Government suit seeking to overturn the United Mine Workers election that Mr. Yablonski lost.

title: Senate Unit Favors Ban On Assistance to Greece
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has quietly approved a ban on military or economic aid to Greece in the current fiscal year. An escape clause permits the President to extend aid if he deems it in overriding national interest and explains his reason to Congress.

title: Gynecologist Wounded, Partner Robbed in Holdup
description: A gynecologist, was shot in the head and her partner, a general practitioner, robbed of $250 after two gunmen invaded their Brooklyn office last night, the police reported.

title: Bigger Voice in U.N. Sought by Japanese
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 19Japan's hardworking diplomats at the United Nations face difficulties and contradictions as they strive to carry out policies here commensurate with their nation's new position as one of the great industrial powers.

title: REV. JAY M. LOGAN, 57, PRESBYTERIAN AIDE
description: The Rev. Jay M. Logan, an executive of the United Presbyterian Council on Church Support, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: William Cunningham, 78; Lawyer, Tennis Devotee
description: RAHWAY, N.J., Oct. 19William Dickson Cunningham, a retired lawyer formerly with Cadwalder, Wickersham Taft of 1 Wall Street, died this morning en route to a hospital. Mr. Cunningham, who was 78 years old and lived in Rahway, had been suffering from a heart ailment.

title: Bond Prices Rally Again As Rate Cut Is Predicted
description: The bond market's October rally, interrupted Monday by the largest decline in two weeks, got going again yesterday afternoon as Government and banking leaders talked forcefully of lower interest rates.

title: State of the Economy
description: WASHINGTONNew job opportunities, expanding production, more rapidly rising real incomes and pur chasing power  these are the basic Objectives of the President's economic program. This must not be forgotten in the inevitable preoccupation with the freeze or the postfreeze structure. The real name of the game must be kept squarely in the forefront.

title: Sonics Top Royals, 101100
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 19 (AP)Dick Snyder scored 22 points to lead the Seattle SuperSonics to a 101100 triumph over the Cincinnati Royals tonight.

title: HOUSE SIDETRACKS WAR PULLOUT PLAN PASSED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19Administration forces, by a 23vote margin, succeeded today in blocking a direct vote in the House on the Vietnam war issue, thus sidetracking a troopwithdrawal amendment passed by the Senate.

title: OutofUniform Officers Take Notes on the Testimony in the Knapp Hearing Room
description: Everybody is corrupt. Having made his judgment after a brief glance into the Knapp Commission hearing on police corruption yesterday, the young man, a library clerk, said he had to hurry awayto deliver a law book.

title: DIVIDEND CUT IN HALF BY SCOTT PAPER CO.
description: The Scott Paper Company, whose earnings have been down sharply this year, yesterday cut its quarterly dividend on the common stock by 50 per cent.

title: Pressure Campaign on Bond Issue
