description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 20 (AP)The State of Mississippi is under a Federal court order not to interfere with an integration plan for the Jackson school system or to withhold funds from the district because of busing.

title: E.E.C. SETS CURBS ON INVESTMENT AID
description: LUXEMBOURG, Oct. 20 The European Economic Community today agreed on curbs on the amount of aid members can give industries that set up new plants in Common Market countries. The move is designed to stop members of the sixcountry unit from bidding against each other to attract foreign, and especially American, investment.

title: A Glossary of Terms Relating to Corruption
description: The Knapp Commission's hearings on police corruption have included testimony with a number of references unfamiliar to the general public. The following glossary defines some of them in terms presented by a witness, Patrolman William R. Phillips:

title: TITO SUPPORTS INDIA ON PAKIST ANI CRISIS
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 20President Tito of Yugoslavia ended his fourday state visit to India today after endorsing almost fully India's position on the East Pakistani crisis.

title: Manson Aide Captured After Flight From Jail
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 20 (UPI)  A Manson family member accused of attempted murder escaped from a 13thfloor jail cell today after sawing through bars and sliding down a rope of torn mattress covers. However, he was recaptured seven hours later in a house to house search in Hollywood, where he had crashed the getaway car.

title: PRICE OF IMPORTS IS STUDIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The United States said today it had started an investigation to determine whether five countries are selling large power transformers in the United States market at less than their value.

title: SILVER FUTURES FALTER AT CLOSE
description: Unable to sustain a late morning rally, induced by the  of a point reduction in the prime lending rate by most of the nation's largest banks, silver futures dropped again yesterday on the. Commodity Exchange (COMEX) here.

title: NEW YORK WILL CUT PHOSPHATE LEVELS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (UPI)  A Federal switch in attitudes over phosphate pollution is threatening the credibility of the environmental movement, New York State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation said today.

title: PRIMERATE CUT BEGUN BY BANKS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20Under heavy pressure from the Administration, the nation's major banks began today to reduce their prime lending rates to 5 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: U.S. Delays Amchitk'a Test Until Oct. 27 at the Earliest
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP)The Nixon Administration said today, that it could not detonate a five, megaton nuclear warhead under Amchitka Island before Oct 27, but it declined to disclose the exact date.

title: Boston Mayor's Aide Slain
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP)  A campaign aide to Mayor Kevin H. White was slain in his car today in an area of fashionable, shops and highpriced apartments. The victim, was John Labanara, 27 years old. The police said robbery might have been a Motive.

title: NIXON IS EXPECTED TO PICK ARKANSAN FOR SEAT ON COURT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Nixon Administration has informed John L. McClellan, Arkansas's senior Senator, that the President will nominate Herschel H. Friday of Little Rock to the Supreme Court, probably tomorrow, qualified sources reported today.

title: LABORITE DISSIDENTS KEEP POSTS IN PARTY
description: LONDON, Oct. 20  Roy Jenkins and other leading advocates within the Labor party of British membership in the Common Market will not resign their party offices in the deep party conflict over the issue.

title: Teleprompter, Kahn Guilty of Bribing 3
description: The Teleprompter Corporation and its board chairman, Irving B. Kahn, were found guilty in Federal Court here yesterday of bribing three city officials to obtain an exclusive cable television franchise in Johnstown, Pa.

title: Councilmen Express Astonishment and Anger at City's Municipal Loan Program Policy
description: Three daylong hearings into alleged abuses of the Municipal Loan Program have produced exclamations of astonishment, irritation and, at times, outrage from the Councilmen who have been listening.

title: HOUSE VOTE AIDS ALASKAN NATIVES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The House passed today a bill to settle the centuryold land claims of Alaska's native Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts by paying them $925million in cash and granting them 40 million acres. The vote was 343 to 63.

title: Monitoring Price Controls
description: Effective regulation of wages after the freeze will be hopeless in the absence of effective regulation of prices. The Administration's commendable desire to hold down the bureaucracy involved in policing price controls passes to the public a large measure of responsibility for reporting violations of ceiling prices.

title: MEMBERFIRM GROUP BACKS MARTIN PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reuters)A group representing 43 New York Stock Exchange member firms today urged support of recommendations for stockexchange reforms proposed by William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Major Canadian Banks Reduce Prime Rates
description: TORONTO, Oct. 20 (Canadian Press)Major chartered banks in Canada announced reductions in their prime rates today to 6 per cent from 6 per cent, effective Monday.

title: Militancy Grows on Pakistan's Border, but Few Believe That War Will Come
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 20Camouflaged gun positions, strident newspaper headlines and Crush India automobile stickers notwithstanding, Pakistan does not seem like a nation on the brink of war.

title: Ruling on the Demolition Of Maryland Hotel Upheld
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 (AP)A Federal appellate judge declined today to block further the demolition of the historic Queen City Station Hotel in Cumberland, Md.

title: LINDSAY BATTLES MERIT WELFARE
description: Mayor Lindsay asked yesterday for Federal rejection of what he called the state's proposed Brownie point welfare demonstration project. He charged that it would increase family instability and raise administrative costs 15 to 20 per cent for affected relief recipients.

title: Pentagon Orders Decrease in Use Of Secrecy Stamp
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Pentagon announced today that it plans to make its documents harder to classify and easier to declassify and that it would reduce the number of people empowered to classify them.

title: State Jobless Rate Up As Phone Strike Is Felt
description: The rate of unemployment in New York State rose slightly to 5.7 per cent last month, but it remained well below the July figure of 6.1 per cent  the highest in seven years.

title: Excerpts From Statements in General Assembly on the Representation of China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20Following are excerpts from today's debate in the General Assembly on the issue of Chinese representation in the United Nations:

title: Bones of Peking Man, Missing for 30 Years, May Be Recovered
description: After despairing for 30 years that an invaluable collection of 500,000yearold bones of Peking Man had been irretrievably lost in China during World War II, anthropologists now have hope that new information that has recently come to light will lead them to the fossils.

title: Nixon Expresses Satisfaction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (Reu. ters)The White House today expressed President Nixon's satisfaction at the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to Willy Brandt, the West German Chancellor.

title: Bond Denied in Slaying
description: BELLEFONTE, Pa., Oct. 20 (UPI)John Tressler, 48 years old, was ordered held without bond today in the state penitentiary at Rockview pending a hearing on Oct. 29 on charges that he killed one policeman and wounded an auxiliary officer in a feud involving his garbage dump. Mr. Tressler was arraigned before Magistrate Louise Green for the murder yesterday of Patrolman Ronald D. Seymore, 29, and for assault with intent to kill Clarence Seaward, 45, an auxiliary policeman.

title: Catlow' Pits Crenna Against Brynner
description: An elaborate and somewhat too aggressively agreeable Western, Sam Wanamaker's "Catlow," opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters. Though not without its share of death and violence, it sees the frontier as somehow producing more smiles than tears, and it is the kind of western for which I imagine them as using stock shots not of heroes falling, but of the principal characters laughing.The principal characters are Catlow (Yul Brynner) and Cowan (Richard Crenna), who sound like a comedy team but are actually a big time outlaw  Caltow  and the marshal, his best buddy, who pursues him. With everybody pretty much a protagonist, major antagonisms are pushed to one side, reserved for occasional Indians, who do most of the film's dying, and for a hired killer (Leonard Nimoy), who also dies, but whose main function is to reveal the cruel scars of an action that would otherwise be no more than happy highjinks with deadly weapons.Catlow's plan to steal a Mexican shipment of contraband gold provides the plot, and lots of local color, and a pair of Mexican-spitfire type girl friends (Jo Ann Pflug and Daliah Lavi) for Crenna and Brynner. No one of these elements really failsthough the plot and Miss Lavi get lowest gradesbut all of them together don't add to a coherent or even mildly pleasing movie.Often, for whole sequences at a time, "Catlow" looks as if it is going to be about somethingfriendship, or the meaning of property, or the discovery of happiness that seems to be the issue of so many of its more suspenseful moments. But it ends up being about nothing at all, as if it were unaware of its own ideas or the potency of its images. And so tension becomes tedium and laughter grows tired, and the screen recedes not quite out of sight, but surely out of mind.

title: Personal Finance
description: Nofault automobile insurance is available today in just one stateMassachusetts.

title: Job Losses at Grumman Send Shivers Through L.I.
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 20 The slump in the aerospace industry and the termination of the Lunar Excursion Module project have jolted the Grumman Corporation, and the jolt is still sending shudders through Long Island's economy.

title: Bridge:Aces Likely to Be Favored In Team Playoffs Tomorrow
description: The world champion Aces will no doubt start as the favorites in the international team final playoff in New Orleans starting tomorrow, but nevertheless they will be very narrow favorites. Their opponents will be a fourman group that knocked them out of the Spingold Knockout Teams in July: Lew Mathe and Don Krauss of Los Angeles, Edgar Kaplan of New York and Norman Kay of Philadelphia.

title: LUCILLE MEDWICK, POETRY EDITOR, 49
description: Lucille Medwick, associate editor of The New York Querterly, a poetry magazine, died yesterday at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer & Allied Diseases after a long illness. She was 49 years old and lived at 1000 Fenimore Road, Larchmont, N. Y.

title: NETS AND KNICKS COUNT BLESSINGS
description: The Knicks and the Nets were counting their modest blessings yesterday after Tuesday night's victories and in anticipation of their games tomorrow.

title: Union and Coal Mine Owners Halt Contract Talks Indefinitely
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Contract negotiations betweem the United. Mine Workers of America and coal mine opera tors broke off indefinitely to day, with the union accusing management Of deliberately trying to prolong the strike it the nation's bituminous coa fields.

title: Maryland Prosecutor Fined
description: ELLICOTT CITY, Md., Oct, 20 A prosecutor who said a pending arson charge against II. Rap Brown was fabricated was found guilty today of contempt of court and fined $350.

title: Gunman Is Slain in Madison Ave. Office Building
description: Policemen wearing bulletproof vests and carrying shotguns poured into a midtown office building in search of two armed holdup men during the evening rush hour yesterday.

title: Notes on Violence
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The intellectual who does all his fighting from an office is counterrevolutionary today, no matter what he writes, JeanPaul Sartre told John Gerassi, a radical American intellectual, in an interview printed in The New York Times Magazine of Oct. 17.

title: Sato Comes Under Increasing Attack Over His Foreign Policies
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20  Premier Eisaku Sato is under siege from all sides. Political attacks against him began to intensify today in the special session of Parliament called to ratify treaty with the United States under which Okinawa would be returned to Japan.

title: Tobacco Net Dips
description: American Brands, Inc., reported yesterday a 5.9 per cent increase in earnings for the third quarter and 15.3 per cent for the first nine months, of 1971, compared with yearago results, to set records for the periods. Sales exceeded $2billion, for the first time in the latest nine months.

title: Army Rests in Trial
description: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 20 (UPI)The prosecution formally rested its case today in the courtmartial of Col. Oran Ti. Henderson on charges of suppressing information on the 1968 Mylai massacre. The Army's chief prosecutor, Maj. Carroll J. Tichenor, made the announcement to Judge Peter S. Wondolowski in late afternoon.

title: Uncovered Undercoverman Changes Jobs
description: Teddy Ratnoff, a man with many aliases and a shadowy past, explained yesterday how he became a parttime agent for the Knapp Commission, the financial adviser to a brothel madam and the man who taperecorded the incriminating conversations of a policeman on the takea patrolman who has since turned star witness for the investigation of police corruption.

title: ...but a Question Mark on Berlin
description: A cloud the size of a ??, the hand of Soviet Foreign Minister Gromyko, hangs over the new Four Power accords on Berlin and the detailed annexes now being negotiated intensively by the East and West German Governments. It is a cloud that could threaten the entire Eastern policy for which Chancellor Willy Brandt has just been granted the Nobel Prize.

title: New Head of State U. Unit
description: ALBANY, Oct. 20Dr. James W. Hall has been appointed president of the State UniverSity's experimental Empire State College, it was announced today. He has been acting director of the college since it was established last July. He will receive $28,000 a year.

title: Brasilia Air Terminal Open
description: BRASILIA, Oct. 20 (UPI)Braztl's most modern airport terminal opened here today. The $27million terminal can handle two million passengers a year.

title: Advertising:
description: At a nifty buffet luncheno in her 28th floor offices with their view of Central Park, Mrs. Mary Wells Lawrence announced that Charles Moss, 33years old, is the new president of Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: KOSYGIN LOOKING TO VISIT BY NIXON
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 20Premier Alexsei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union said today that Russia was looking forward to President Nixon's visit next spring as much as Mr. Nixon was.

title: RUINS TRIUMPH OVER WINGS, 43
description: BOSTON, Oct. 20 (UPI).Bobby Orr, a defenseman, scored one goal and assisted on two others in the first 10 minutes tonight to spark the Boston Bruins to a 43 victory over the Detroit Red Wings.

title: Nobel Peace Laureate...
description: In his State of the Nation address to the Bundestag last January, Willy Brandt downgraded, with a selfeffacing Berlin proverb, the claim advanced by others that on the diplomatic front 1970 had been a German year. Then he added: All the same, we can say without complacency that in the difficult search for a lasting peace the Federal Republic of Germany has not been a sleeping partner but a driving force, and this will remain so.

title: New Amtrak Schedule Expands Metroliner Service
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The National Railroad Passenger Corporation announced today a series of timetable changes, effective November 14, that will include the expansion of Metroliner service between Washington and New York from 9 to 12 round trips daily and the first additions to the BostonNew York service in nearly two decades.

title: Market Place:
description: You remember Papert Koenig, Lois, a hotshot advertising agency of $40million in billings in 1967. It was. the first major ad agency to come to the public for money back in 1963. Things went beautifully for a while. Those 1967 billings were practically double the $21million rung up in 1963.

title: Voznesensky: A Poet Poses Questions
description: The poet is not the one to supply the answers for mankind, the Russian poet Andrei Voznesensky remarked. All he can And is pose the questions. And if the poems are complicated, why then so is life. The problem of the poet as a human being is not to become standardized, to be individual, and in this effort the poet provides the reader with the material and way of thinking to achieve it.

title: Moonlighting by the City's Accountants Curbed
description: The city's Board of Ethics, in effect, barred city accountants yesterday from preparing Federal, state or city income tax returns for private interests.

title: Group of 10 Session Ends  Delegates Remain Divided
description: PARIS, Oct. 20Specialists from the 10 richest nonCommunist countries left Paris today after a threeday meeting on the world monetary crisis. They were still so divided they could not begin serious negotiations.

title: Alston Manager of Year
description: Walt Alston of the Los Angeles Dodgers was named yesterday by the Associated Press as manager of the year in the National League.

title: Increase in Net Reserves Reported by West Germany
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 20 (Reuters)West Germany's net monetary reserve rose by less than 100 million marks to 62,300 million marks in the week ended Oct. 15, the West German Bundesbank said today.

title: INTEREST RATES ON BONDS DECLINE
description: Interest rates swept lower across a broad front again yesterdayfrom shortterm Treasury bills and commercial paper out to the longest maturity corporate bonds.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Football has been compared to war, by soldiers well as by football men, and one of the elements in this essentially valid comparison may be called the law career survival. That law, which most officers live by, can be formulated as follows: I want to do everything I can to help my side win, but I also want a clear record showing that defeat, if it comes, can't be blamed on me.

title: Texas Democratic Leaders in Disarray
description: If I win the nomination for Governor, Mr. Barnes remarked today, I'll have to move in and take the party reins in my hands. If I lose, would guess that Bentsen would take over.

title: A.E.C. SHIFTS ROLE TO PROTECT PUBLIC
description: BAT, HARBOUR, Fla., Oct. 20 Dr. James R. Schlesinger, the new Atomic Energy Commission chairman, told the nation's nuclear industry tonight that the agency's role had suddenly shifted from promoting atomic energy to protecting the public interest in nuclear affairs.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES $31BILLION AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a $3.2billion foreign aid authorization bill today. It did so after having restored $375million, or roughly half, of the cuts it had tentatively ordered in the measure last Friday.

title: Kissinger Begins Meetings
description: PEKING, Thursday, Oct. 21Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security affairs, and Premier Chou Enlai began talks yesterday on arrangements for Mr. Nixon's visit to China.

title: Pipelines Are Proposed For U.S. Postal Service
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation has submitted a commercial proposal to the United States Postal Service for delivering mail, baggage and any form of bulk material by low pressure pipeline. James B. Henderson, president, said the system would require pipeline, a pump and a. capsule container.

title: Excerpts From Testimony by Patrolman Phillips on System of Payoffs to Police
description: Following are excerpts from testimony given yesterday before the Knapp Commission, during its third day of public hearings, by Patrolman William R. Phillips of the New York City Police Department.

title: Saigon Warns Papers on Detrimental Material
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20The Government's Office of Information has issued a new directive to the press to avoid material detrimental to national security and public order.

title: Lockheed on an Upward Track
description: VAN NUYS, Calif., Oct. 20 The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation still faces a rough and in some respects an uncertain road, Daniel J. Haughton, chairman, told the annual meeting here today, but he added that we are now on an upward track.

title: FOUR SHOTS FIRED AT SOVIET MISSION
description: Four rifle shots were fired through a window of an 11thfloor room of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street last night. The police reported no injuries to the family of six, including four children, who were in the room.

title: Train Hits Chemical Truck
description: EVERETT, Mass., Oct. 20 (AP) Thirteen passengers were injured today, apparently not seriously, when a Buddliner train cut in half a trailer truck loaded with chemicals. The single unit, selfpropelled commuter train was carrying 45 persons from Ipswich to Boston.

title: MEMPHIS REPORTS. NEW RACE VIOLENCE
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 20 (UPI)New street violence erupted in Memphis tonight after the burial of a black teenager whose death resulted in the furloughing of 23 policemen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In your Oct. 6 news story the security for President Nixon's trip to China was discussed. An official is quoted as saying: It can be safer than a trip to Chicago.

title: CESAR GIRON DEAD; A FORMER MATADOR
description: MARACAY, Venezuela, Oct. 20 (UPI)Cesar Giron, one of six Venezuelan bullfighting brothers and a leading matador for 15 years, was killed last evening in a collision of his car and a truck near here. He was 38 years old.

title: Seedman Reinstated as Detective Chief
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy reinstated Albert A. Seedman as chief of detectives yesterday and said an inquiry into a free meal he and his party had eaten at a midtown hotel had found no indication that Chief Seedman is other than an honest man.

title: Kosygin Is Gled
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 20Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union, who is visiting Canada said of the award of the Nobel peace prize to Mr. Brandt: That's fine. I'm very glad. I think he deserves it.

title: Burch, Johnson Deny F.C.C. Interferes With News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Dean Burch, a Republican, who is chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, and Nicholas Johnson, his frequently dissenting colleague who is a Democrat, joined forces today in rejecting the broadcasting industry's charge that the commission interfered with news programing.

title: Brown Is Arraigned in Hospital In Robbery and Murder Attempt
description: A Criminal Court judge went to H. Rap Brown's bedside in Roosevelt Hospital yesterday to arraign him on robbery and attempted murder charges and to fix bail at $250,000.

title: Price Board Chief Chosen; Nixon Bill Disturbs Labor
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20President Nixon intends to name C. Jackson Grayson Jr., dean of the business school at Southern Methodist University, as chairman of the sevenmember Price Commission, it was disclosed today.

title: Comment by Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 State Department officials said today that Premier Lon Nol had been compelled to dissolve the National Assembly under terms of the Cambodian Constitution, which provides for only a oneyear extension of an Assembly. The last extension expired on Monday.

title: Three C5A's Cleared
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Air Force announced today that it had lifted the grounded status of three of its fleet of 47 C5A transport planes, grounded last week because of structural Irregularities. It said structural Xrays of the three planes had turned up no faults. The Air Force began grounding the planes in September when cracks were discovered in some wings. The entire fleet was grounded last week after an en gine tore loose from the wing mount of one plane.

title: PLAN TO SAVE 30CENT FARE DEVISED BY CITY AND STATE; BOND ISSUE PASSAGE IS KEY
description: City and state officials agreed yesterday on a plan to save the30cent transit fare for two years. However, they stressed that the plan, worked out in several weeks of bargaining, depended on the passage of Governor Rockefeller's $2.5billion transportation bond issue.

title: AMEX PRICES DROP AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday registered its biggest loss in almost three months in moderate trading.

title: New Engine Lifts Hope for Steam Auto
description: A research engineer at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. has invented an engine that the company says could lead to the development of a practical steam engine for automobiles.

title: Confederate Flag Ban Held Invalid in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 20Virginia's Attorney General, Andrew P. Miller, ruled today that the University of Virginia's ban on the flying of the Confederate flag at the university's football games was unconstitutional.

title: Pests Over Pesticides
description: The House will debate today an utterly inadequate bill from its Agriculture Committee supposedly controlling those chemicals that have turned out to be more pest than pesticide.

title: Sand Ridge, $6, Scores In Aqueduct Turf Race
description: George Bostwick's Sand Ridge demonstrated his versatility at Aqueduct yesterday in winning the main race on the card, a 1 116 mile test on the turf. The victory was the second in a row for the 4yearold campaigner, who previously had registered a triumph in a hurdles event.

title: Ballet: From Cambodia, the Khmer
description: The Classical Khmer Ballet of Cambodia has resplendent jeweled costumes. But not all of them were delivered in time to the Brooklyn Academy of Music Tuesday night for the company's United States debut and the opening of the academy's fiveweek AfroAsian Festival.

title: AIRLINE LOSS SEEN IF AIR FARES DROP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Government and industry representatives disagreed today on now to respond to the threatened transAtlantic air fare war in a way that would both protect consumer interests and shield airlines from what they said would be huge losses.

title: BEATING ALLEGED IN SWINDLE TRIAL
description: A key Government witness In a stock swindle conspiracy trial yesterday pointed to two of the 10 defendants and charged that they were the men who had slapped and kicked him, forcing him to give up all stock certificates in the Miamibased land investment company of which he was president.

title: Books of The Times
description: Despite T. S. Eliot's wish to have his private life remain permanently immured from public view, the walls he erected before his death in 1965 are now beginning to crack. At least two biographies are in the works (one by Bernard Bergonzi, to be brought out next year by Macmillan; the other by T. S. Matthews, which Harper & Row hopes to issue two years from now). And next month Harcourt Brace Jovanovich will publish Eliot's original, thousandline draft of The Waste Land, so that we will be able to see exactly what Eliot's mentor Ezra Pound cut out and rearranged before the poem was pub. li shed in 1922. One wonders, however, how much besides local gossip and material for graduateschool dissertations these or any other future projects will add to Robert Sencourt's T. S. Eliot: A Memoir"the first breach in Eliot's fortress of privacy, by an English literary critic who met Eliot in 1927 and remained close to him for approximately 20 years thereafter.

title: Balalaikas and TangosHow Nostalgic Can You Get?
description: Would you bet a million dollars that an extravagant Russian supper club will pay off in midtown Manhattan? Supper club? Russian? It's happening right now at 123 East 54th Street. A syndicate of investors led by Path Sapounakis, who also masterminded the Greek restaurant, Dionysus, has just opened Casino Russe.

title: CAMBODIA ORDERS EMERGENCY RULE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia; Oct. 20Premier Lon Nol declared a state of emergency today and appointed a new Government to rule by ordinance rather than by constitutional law. He said he would no longer play the game of democracy and freedom since it stood in the way of victory in wartime.

title: DR. R. W. ROBERTAZZI, ANESTHESIOLOGIST ,59
description: Dr. Raphael W. Robertazzi, chief of anesthesiology and secretary of the medical board of the Coney Island Hospital, died last Thursday while attending a medical conference in Naples, Italy. He was 59 years old and lived at 2045 East 14th Street, Brooklyn.

title: BOOKBINDERS AGREE TO A UNION MERGER
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 20Delegates of the International Brotherhood of Bookbinders voted today to merge their 70,000member union with the 60,000member Lithographers and Photoengravers International Union.

title: Vitamin C Tablets Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it had ordered the recall of 10 million Vitamin C tablets posing potential health hazards to heart and diabetic patients seeking to ward off colds., Labels on the tablets manufactured by the Lit Drug Company of Union, N.J., failed to note that the tablets contained sodium ascorbate, the F.D.A. said

title: THREATS TO 4 JEWS BY K.G.B. REPORTED
description: MOSCOW, Oct 20The Soviet secret police have threat ened criminal prosecution against four Moscow activiSts in the campaign for emigration to Israel if they do not halt their activities, but all foulrefused to do so, dissident sources reported tonight.

title: SMELL IS DOUBTFUL FOR DOLPHIN TEST
description: Although frustrated by a lingering knee injury that has prevented him from playing this season, Matt Snell indicated yesterday that the power of prestige would influence his return to the Jets next year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In their criticism of President Nixon's New Economic Policy, Messrs. Nader and Stanton of the Public Interest Research Group accuse Treasury Department officials of making deceptive statements in support of the tax proposals now before Congresseven alleging the issuance of false statements. [Letter Oct. 5.] It is, in fact, Messrs. Nader and Stanton who are engaging in deception.

title: RULING AFFECTS FUTURE OF FRAM
description: The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday that the United States Court of Appeals in Cincinnati had reversed the Federal Trade Commission's order that Bendix divest itself of the Fram Corporation, maker of a wide line of automotive filters. The court ordered the F.T.C. to restudy the matter. Bendix acquired Fram in 1967 for about $75million worth of preferred stock.

title: T.W.A. Advances
description: American Airlines, the nation's second largest domestic carrier, and Trans World Airlines, the fourth largest, yesterday reported large profits for the third quarter. Because of heavy deficits suffered earlier this year by both systems, the profits reported for the nine months were only a fraction of those of the third quarter.

title: Big Board. Weighs Letting Firms Sell Life Insurance
description: Member firms of the New York Stock Exchange would be permitted to sell life insurance for the first time under rules changes that are being considered by the exchange's board of governors.

title: 113 Plainclothes Men to Return To Uniformed Duty Here Today
description: One hundred and thirteen plainsclothes men  about quarter of those on the police forcehave been sent to the Police Academy for a refresher course before being returned to uniformed duty.

title: Zoo in Central Park Is Making Some Cages More Like Nature
description: The first changes in design of the Central Park Zoo since it was built in 1934 were announced yesterday by Park Administrator August Heckscher.

title: NEW SAIGON DRIVE IS ON IN CAMBODIA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 21 (AP)The South Vietnamese command reportedly sent a 2,500man force yesterday into an operation in eastern Cambodia where North Vietnamese troops were said to have been in retreat after a fourweek drive.

title: A Top Executive Is Named At Kings Lafayette Bank
description: John P. DeSantis has been appointed executive vice president and chief administrative officer of the Kings Lafayette Bank. He also was elected to the board of the bank and its parent, the Kings Lafayette Corporation, a onebank holding company.

title: Jail Disturbance Quelled
description: MARTINEZ, Calif., Oct. 20 (AP)A disturbance that sheriff's sergeant described as a spontaneous riot. broke out in the Contra Costa County jail last night but was quelled within two, hours with no injuries. Sheriff Sgt. Dale Sandy, acting watch commander, said the distrubance was probably linked to overcrowding at the jail.

title: U.S., SOVIET AGREE TO SHARE MARS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The space agency said today that the Soviet Union had agreed to exchange data from the American and Russian spacecraft now approaching Mars.

title: Miss Heldman Overcomes Nell Truman in Straight Sets
description: BILLINGHAM, England, Oct. 20 (AP)  Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., and Julie Heldman of Houston, reached the quarterfinals of the second Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: May I suggest that your position on the Transportation Bond Issue [editorial Sept. 28] smacks of the hog in the trough mentality. By urging its defeat on the basis of local interests, you patently ignore the needs of the rest of the eighteen million citizens of our state. Frankly, I expected better of The Times.

title: Court Defers a Ruling On Thieu's Reelection
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 20 (UPI)South Vietnam's nineman Supreme Court today postponed for 24 hours a decision on whether to overturn the Oct. 3 reelection of President Nguyen Van Thieu as unconstitutional.

title: MotherinLaw's Hearing Set
description: BOSTON, Oct, 20 (AP)The Justice Department has peti tinned Federal court to have Dr. Ellsberg's motherinlaw jailed for contempt.

title: Warning to Newsmen in Peking
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 20Foreign correspondents in Peking have been warned not to speculate about what seems to be an unusual development in the Chinese Communist Government.

title: Candice Bergen Cast as 'T. R. Baskin'
description: "T. R. Baskin" is a comedy for people with a high tolerance for whimsey, about an amiable, wise-cracking, small-town girl who seeks a full-filling life in Chicago. Apparently she's been living in a coal mine since she's surprised to discover a culture that wires its elevators with music, makes its office buildings airtight for air-conditioning, eats TV dinners and warps its men, who are either Playboy-philosophy creeps or, in one case, a soft-spoken, R. D. Lang-reading, male chauvinist pig. (After a thoroughly satisfying night of love, he slips a $20 bill into her pocket.)Things go so badly, so arbitrarily, for T. R. Baskin that, toward the end of the film, she is driven to the brink of serious introspection. "The city is pretty from a distance," she says, "like someone with bad skin."T. R. Baskin is never at a loss for words, most of which sound as if they had come straight from the notebook of a writer who spent most of time jotting down funny lines without ever worrying much about character.It thus falls to Candice Bergen, a beautiful actress who projects intelligence, humor, vulnerability and self-relianceall more or less simultaneouslyto make something credible of the mouthpiece character written for her by Peter Hyams. She is constantly on the point of succeeding when the screenplay suddenly requires her to say something like: "A fly came into my office last week, and nobody knew what it was."Such poetic conceits are enough to make me want to defend everything from air-conditioning and TV dinners to air pollution.The film, which was shot entirely on location, features some nice performances in addition to Miss Bergen's. Peter Boyle ("Joe"), has been upgraded to playing a middle-class salesman from Utica (whose sensibilities are still lower middle-class). James Caan is the man who, for reasons I never quite believed, treats T.R. as if she were a whore; and Marcia Rodd, who was so fine in "Little Murders," is funny as T.R.'s best friend at the otherwise depersonalized insurance company where she works.Somewhere deep inside "T.R. Baskin," there is, I suspect, a real, touching film crying to get out with something more than a wise-crack, but neither Hyams, nor Herbert Ross, the director, have been able to find it. The movie opened yesterday at Loew's State 1 and Loew's Tower East.

title: WPIX Giving Sunday Hour to NewChina Group
description: Station WPIX has allocated the hour of 9 to 10 on Sunday night to the Committee for New China Policy. The program in part will be designed as an answer to last Sunday's presentation entitled U.S. China Policy: Danger at the Crossroads, which was sponsored by the Committee, of One Million Against the Admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

title: Bonn Promises Cooperation
description: BONN, Oct. 20 (Reuters)West Germany will work with its Common Market partners and other countries for a return to fixed exchange rates as soon as possible, Chancellor Willy Brandt said today.

title: Queens Lawyer Convicted Of Having $900,000 in Loot
description: A Bayside, Queens, lawyer was convicted in Federal Court on Tuesday of unlawfully possessing nine stolen $100,000 Treasury bills.

title: Thant Nominates Peterson
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20  Secretary General Thant has proposed the appointment of Rudolph A. Peterson, former head of the Bank of America, to succeed Paul G. Hoffman as admiinstrator of the United Nations Development program. Approval by the General Assembly is expected and Mr. Peterson will take over his new duties on Jan. 15.

title: Aaron Enters Golf Event
description: Hank Aaron of the Atlanta Braves became the first entrant yesterday for the $30,000 American Airlines Golf Classic, set for Feb. 4 to 6 in Puerto Rico.

title: Chou Enlai: On U.S. Talks
description: PEKINGAs soon as I was told that I should not leave the hotel for too long and too often so that everybody could be able to find me, it was quite clear to me that Premier Chou Enlai was going to receive me.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President sent congratulations to Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany on his designation as the winner of the Nobel Prize for peace.

title: Home Products Up
description: The American Home Products Corporation reported yesterday record earnings and sales for the third quarter and first nine months of this year.

title: Policemen Irked by Knapp Hearings
description: On their beats and in the back rooms of their stations, policemen voiced resentment yesterday at Knapp Commission testimony charging widespread graft and bribetaking on the force.

title: Harassing Cited in Principal's Ouster
description: A factfinder has held that harassment and pressures by a small group of militant teachers, parents and community people led to the removal last year of Mrs. Miriam Precourt as principal of Junior High School 13, in East Harlem.

title: Brandt Voices Gratitude; Prize Is High Obligation
description: BONN, Oct. 20  Chancellor Willy Brandt, the father of a policy that has taken long steps toward reconciliation with Germany's wartime enemies in Eastern Europe, voiced deep emotion and great gratitude today on winning the Nobel Peace Prize.

title: Brandt Wins Nobel Prize For His Efforts for Peace
description: OSLO, Norway, Oct. 20Willy Brandt won the Nobel Peace Prize today for building bridges between East and West. The fivemember committee of the Norwegian Parliameat unanimously chose the West German Chancellor because it said, he had stretched out his hand to reconciliation between countries that have long been enemies.

title: CUBA IS ACCEPTED IN ECONOMIC BLOC
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 20Cuba has been accepted as the 95th member of an influential but loose grouping of developing countries that seek to formulate a joint strategy to protect their economic interests.

title: KOSYGIN PLEDGES TO CUBA EXPECTED
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 20Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin is expected to use his visit to Cuba later this month to reassure Premier Fidel Castro that Moscow's interest in accommodation with the United Statesand President Nixon's visit there next Maywill not be at the exIpense of its Communist allies.

title: Rachel Newport Scores At Yonkers, Pays $176.20
description: YONKERS, Oct. 20  Even among chronic gamblers, the most risky of betting ventures is to wager on 2yearold trotting fillies because of their inexperience and shortage of manners. Still, those who saw fit to put up money on Rachel Newport in tonight's $46,678.35 New York Sire Stakes found themselves well rewarded.

title: CANADIAN RIDES DOUBLE VICTORY
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 20Moffat Dunlap of Canada captured his second class in international jumping today at the Pennsylvania national horse show. Riding Grand Nouvel, he covered the tricky faultandout course with the most points, 20, in a speedy time, 54.2 seconds.

title: Soap Opera Buffs Tune In a Tour
description: Lynne Rogers is probably best known to her fans for her nice girl roles on television soap operas. Rita Lloyd, on the other hand, almost always played the meanies.

title: MILLS SAYS NIXON IS PRESSURING HIM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20Representative Wilbur D. Mills accused President Nixon today, of seeking to intimidate him; into pushing the Administration's revenue sharing program through Congress.

title: Big Utility Gains
description: The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday gains in net income for the three, nine and 12 months ended Sept. 30

title: 2d G.I. Dies of Meningitis
description: FORT ORD, Calif., Oct. 20 (UPI)A second soldier has died in the latest outbreak of meningitis at this basic training base. He is Pvt. Robert Peele, 19 years old., of Tucson, Ariz. He was inducted in September and was in his fourth week of training.

title: Clemente's Dream. A Utopian Sports City
description: Now that Roberto Clemente's hitting and fielding have helped Pittsburgh win the World Series, they could help the Pirate star realize the biggest ambition in my life,

title: Bank Robber Escapes In Chartered Airplane
description: WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio, Oct. 20 (UPI)An armed bank robber apparently made a successful escape in a chartered airplane whose pilot was unaware of the holdup, the sheriff's department reported yesterday.

title: Stocks Slump on Broad Front
description: Stock prices buckled yesterday under the weight of dispiriting news as the market suffered its sharpest decline in two months.

title: Warriors Triumph, 11598
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 20 (UPI) Cazzie Russell poured in 29 points and Jeff Mullins got 27 tonight to pace the Golden State Warriors to a 11598 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: WASHINGTON POST ANNOUNCES SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Washington Post announced today that Paul R. Ignatius had resigned as president of the morning newspaper.

title: Senate Panel Sets Apart and Expedites Tax Cuts for Individuals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20The Senate Finance Committee decided today to expedite two provisions of the pending tax bill by approving them as separate legislation.

title: FIVE ARE INDICTED IN PONTIAC BOMBING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) A Federal grand jury today indicted on conspiracy charges the former Grand Dragon of the Michigan Ku Klux Klan and four of his associates in the bombing of 10 school buses in Pontiac, Mich., last August.

title: Insiders'
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock, ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports included the following:

title: CRIME STUDY PANEL IS CREATED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) The Nixon Administration announced today the creation of a National Commission on Criminal Justice designed to devise means of reducing the crime rate in America.

title: Food, Not Promises
description: The White House statement that the President has long been committed to the achievement of a program which provides a school lunch to every needy child would be more persuasive had the Department of Agriculture not persisted in stratagems to bar needy children from the program.

title: Robert F. Lyons Stars in 'Todd Killings'
description: The astonishing thing about "The Todd Killings" is that it holds you fast, while exasperatingly missing out on three levels. As a character study of a charming, 23-year-old psychopath, the king rooster of the teeny-bopper set, the film, which opened in neighborhood theaters yesterday, has a fine performance by young Robert F. Lyons. But he is no more indicative of a dangerous void in today's contemporary youth, as the movie insists, than Jack the Ripper was of Old London.Secondly, as a suspense melodrama, the picture is absurd. As it opens, "Skipper" has murdered a girl. Two awed teen-agers help him hide the body. Weeks later he kills two more. And in between, in a small Nevada community, the police casually question him, they sit around on their haunches.Thirdly, although the color camera shrewdly sketches the small-town Americana background and a cynically seasoned group of young people, nothing really accounts for the hero or his heinous behavior.Even so, the sure brilliance of producer Barry Shear's direction and Harold E. Stine's photography, and the subtle meshing of the incidents make for an engrossing, often gripping eyeful. The picture has a dazzling potentialsimply to look at and hearthat is sustained close to the surface.Young Lyons gets firm flanking by Richard Thomas, in a slight flavoring of the Leopold-Loeb case, by Belinda Montgomery, and by two veterans, Barbara Bel Geddes and Gloria Grahame, in brief but professional stints.Finally, horror and sex are actually soft-pedaled. Failure though it may be, "The Todd Killings" is anything but dull.

title: Plan for January Welfare Vote In Senate Seems to Fall Apart
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20  A Democratic agreement to move welfare reform legislation out of the Senate Finance Committee in December and onto the floor in January appeared today to have fallen apart.

title: PARLIAMENT VOTES DANISH SURCHARGE
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Thursday, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Denmark's Social Democrat minority Government early today won a twovote victory in Parliament on its plan for a temporary 10 per cent import surcharge.

title: UNIONISTS OPPOSE CHOICE OF FRIDAY
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 20 The top three labor officials of Arkansas have attacked President Nixon's consideration of Herschel H. Friday, a Little Rock corporation lawyer, for appointment to the Supreme Court.

title: Four Features Begin Their Runs Here:Poitier Is Virgil Tibbs in 'The Organization'
description: Our reigning black superstar, Sidney Poitier, who, as detective Virgil Tibbs, has been majestically impervious to criminals and the white Establishment in "In the Heat of the Night," and "They Call Me Mr. Tibbs," retains his imperious cool in "The Organization," which opened yesterday at the Victoria, 86th Street East and other theaters. But despite his smooth restraint, this dizzying complex of a king-sized heroin heist, shootings and chases set against authentic, picturesque San Francisco backgrounds evolves largely as surface action and reaction so dear to TV's cops and robbers.Don Medford, a video veteran, naturally has directed with an eye on speed and gunplay, and his color cameras have recorded it all with eye-catching effects. James R. Webb's script, which economically and colloquially matches the pace of the action, does not, however, do much beyond indicating the nature of the characters involved.The opening sequence, in which a highly efficient gang using sophisticated equipment stealthily snatches a $4-million heroin cache from a furniture factory, is tension-packed stuff full of promise. More fireworks do go off, but these are far less imaginative and convincing as we proceed to an explosive climax in the unfinished San Francisco subway.The gang, it turns out, are not thieves exactly, but a variety of types who've been personally hurt by drugs and are out to get the internationally placed bigwigs controlling the traffic. But a murder has been committed and they expose themselves to Tibbs in order to clear themselves and to aid him in his investigation. It's all complicated, perhaps unnecessarily so, what with our hero's loyalty being divided between cops and his informers and red herrings by the dozen being tossed into the proceedings.The script, in short, is short on fuller explanations. The members of the gang are unusuala Japanese girl, a waterfront preacher, a dope pusher and the likebut they merely appear in quickly passing but hardly memorable vignettes.As noted, Sidney Poitier is unflappable and tough but he does occasionally show signs of weariness and a desire to spend more time with Barbara McNair and George and Wanda Spell, who appear briefly as his wife and children, as they did in "They Call Me Mr. Tibbs." He can't be blamed, since "The Organization" can be rough on super-city sleuths as well as movie-goers who've been through much the same melodramatics before.

title: Executive Changes
description: The appointment of Frank R. Latin as vice president and general manager of the lighting equipment division of GTE Sylvania, Inc., was announced yesterday. He succeeds John C. Avallon, who was named vice president of research and engineering Of the General Telephone and Electronics Corpora, tion and of the lighting products group.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20The Associated Press Managing Editors Association presented its first Freedom of Information Citation today, honoring The New York Times for its publication of the Pentagon papers.

title: Agnew Views Missiles, Minoan Ruins on Crete
description: HERAKLEION, Crete, Oct. 20 (AP)  Vice President Agnew, touring on the island of Crete, inspected the ancient ruins at Cnossos today, then viewed a missile base of the. North Atlantic alliance.

title: PUPIL LUNCH BILL IS SENT TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 The Senate passed today by unanimous voice, vote legislation forbidding any cuts in federally subsidized school lunches for needy children. The meas ure, approved Monday by the House, 353 to 0, now goes to the President.

He also proposed dropping the 10 per cent investment tax surcharge and the buyAmerican investment credit.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Robert Wells will resign from the Federal Communications Commission on Nov. I, the White House said today.

title: Stage: Ghetto Life of Anit Supposed
description: Black is coming to Broadway these days, and I mean real black, not just someone singing 01 Man Rivereven though that's quite a radical song if you ever listen to it. But now the black theater is moving uptown. And it is different. Scott Fitzgerald pointed out that the rich are different from us. To blacks, we whites are rich. Even to rich blacks we poor whites are rich. And different.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 (AP) Bill Cunningham and Kevin Loughery combined for 49 points and did the clutch scoring as the unbeaten Philadelphia 76ers gained their fourth victory by defeating the Seattle SuperSonic tonight, 10093.

description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 20 Dr. Robert A. Good, a leading immunologist, said today that he had been able to induce resistance to certain forms of cancer in animals by reducing the amount of protein in their diet.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bembach, which already has a London office, is going to acquire another agency over there. It is the sixyearold Gallagher Smail shop and will be acquired, the British Government willing, for a certain amount of cash and a certain amount of common stock.

description: The stock market was pounded yesterday as prices showed their heaviest losses in two months. The DowJones industrial average fell 12.78 points, bringing its setback over the last six sessions to 37.90 points.

title: Rockefeller at Rites Of Frank Simpson, Capitol Mail Chief
description: ALBANY, Oct. 20 (UPI) Governor Rockefeller flew from New York City today to attend a funeral service for Frank C. Simpson, grandson of a slave, who rose from being a shoe shine boy to mail superintendent for five Governors.

description: MONTREAL, Oct. 20 (AP) The United States Federal Home Loan Bank Board proposed new regulations today to permit Federal savings and loan associations to offer more flexible terms on home, apartment and commercial real esstate loans.

description: Ted Shawn, who led the male liberation movement in the American dance in the 1930's and won, said yesterday, on the eve of his 80th birthday, that the art of the dance had gone from destitution to brilliance in the United States in this century.
