description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20President Emilio G. M6clici has accepted an invitation of President Nixon to visit the United States beginning Dec. 7, it was announced today.

title: Colman Has a Winner to Cheer
description: Dick Colman was a quiet man in his days as Princeton's football coach, when he was the last man to use the singlewing attack exclasively. Now he's an, athletic director and a cheering partisan who sits in the stands watching Middlebury set passing records on its way to one of its best seasons. Colman moved to the Vermont college three years ago and one of his first steps there was to hire John Anderson, a Dartmouth assistant, as head football coach. Things nave been looking up ever since.

title: North Stars Win, 70
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 20 (AP)  Jude Drouin, Doug Mohns and Bill Goldsworthy sparked the Minnesota North Stars to a 70 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight as Cesare Maniago posted his 12th National Hockey League shutout.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CAIRO, Oct. 20President Tito arrived today for consultations with President Anwar elSadat on the Egyptian conflict with Israel.

title: SAMUELSON URGES YEN REVALUATION
description: TOKYO, Oct. 20 (UPI)Paul A. Samuelson, economics professor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, called on Japan today to make a 15 per cent upward yen revaluation.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PARIS, Oct. 20The Soviet Ambassador to France, Pyotr A. Abrasimov, met today with 120 French Jews with the apparent motive of forestalling hostile demonstrations during the forthcoming visit of Mr. Brezhnev.

title: U.N. COUNCIL SCORES SOUTH AFRICA ANEW
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct, 20The Security Council today strongly condemned South Africa's refusal to turn over administration of SouthWest Africa to the United Nations but stopped short of suggesting sanctions.

title: London Philharmonic Led by Haitink
description: As orchestras go, the London Philharmonic, founded by Sir Thomas Beecham in 1932, is one of the younger ones. But it always has enjoyed a high reputation, and with good reason. Some of England's best musicians play in it, and it is the kind of responsive ensemble that a conductor can mold as Ile desires.

title: DR. CHARLESHOWARD, EXDEAN OF RICKER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 Dr. Charles Worth Howard, president emeritus of Ricker College in Houlton, Me., and former dean of the American University in Cairo, died here of a heart attack on Monday. He was 72 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: President Georges Pompidou officially opened the Louvre's homage to Pablo Picasso in the area of the grand hall where the Mona Lisa used to smile.

title: Narcotics Aide Is Arrested In Traffic Bribery Case
description: A 23yearold state narcotic program counselor was arrested by the police and charged with bribery yesterday after he allegedly offered a patrolman $5 while receiving a ticket for a traffic violation hi the South Bronx, the poke said.

title: Nader Questions Legality Of Phase 2 Policy Panels
description: Declaring that the Constitution had been stretched like so much bubble gum, Ralph Nader yesterday sharply questioned the legality of President Nixon's plan for controlling wages and prices after the 90day freeze ends next month.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Republic Steel Corporation yesterday named William a. De Lancey, 55 years old, as executive vice president, the second ranking officer of the company after Willis B. Boyer, 56, president and chief executive officer. Mr. De Lancey, who had been vice president and general counsel, will fill a post that had been vacant since the appointment of Mr. Boyer to the presidencythree years ago. The new No. 2 man joined the steel company in 1952 as assistant counsel after a number of years with the prominent New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. Two years after joining Republic he became assistant generarcounsel and in 1959 general counsel. He became vice president and general counsel in 1961 and joined the board three years ago. Earlier this year he took on the general supervision of research and planning. In 1938, while at the University of Michigan, he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, the honor society. He received his law degree in 1940 from the University of Michigan Law School.

title: ' Gladiators' Is Shown at Olympia Theater
description: Peter Watkins's "The Gladiators," which opened yesterday at the Olympia Theater, concerns a contest known as the Peace Games, played regularly in the foreseeable future, directed by the world's powers, sponsored by an Italian spaghetti company and televised internationally with the purpose of syphoning off man's aggressive urges and thus preserving the peace. In a derelict Swedish factory, two groups of fighters, a Chinese team and a Western team, perform maneuvers with real arms to their own deaths  while, at a safe distance, their generals urge them on and neutral officers push the buttons on a giant machine that is supposed to program the soldiers' reactions and to determine their fates.The machine, the officers, the generals, the soldiers  all belong to something that the film identifies as "the system," something that it clearly regards as a monstrous indignity but about which it offers very little information. Somewhere along the line, a narrator points out that the games, of course, have absolutely nothing to do with keeping the peace  although he never mentions just what they do have to do with.Like most futurist fiction, "The Gladiators" is a form of satire. But unlike good futurist fiction, or good satire, it fails to distinguish between friends and enemies, or even to suggest a narrative order in which some distinction might be possible.Thus, the East does evil and the West does evil, the great powers do evil and the emerging nations do evil with them. Officers and men, the establishment and its critics, patriots and protesters, technicians and ideologues  all serve the same rotten ends, and all are dutifully paraded before the camera as if for example's sake. Only one young couple, a British soldier (Richard Friday) and a Chinese militiawoman (Pik-Sen Lin) endanger the system  by instantaneously falling in love, I think, and by running awayuntil a student radical (Jean Pierre Delamour), who doesn't know he's been programed to do it, presses the right button, and the police catch the couple and beat them to death.Although it pretends to deal in political matters, "The Gladiators" really has no politicsbut only a universal paranoia masquerading as a sense of urgency. It therefore offers no insights, and only the most commonplace ideas, and unless you are very highly suggestive it is less likely to engender anger than ennui.Minds as muddled as Peter Watkins's may have made good movies, but I doubt that they have tempted fate quite so consistently and tiresomely as Watkins has by repeatedly working in the area of his least competence. After several features ("The Gladiators," made in 1969, precedes the recent "Punishment Park"), his outrage seems by now a commodity  perhaps unsalable, but up for use in whatever anxiety pattern is conveniently at hand.

title: Bridge: Players in Tournament Here To Keep Eye on New Orleans
description: Enthusiasts in the metropolitan area will be focusing their attention on two different contests this weekend. They will be competing in the Metropolitan Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel, but will eagerly await the results from New Orleans, where a final playoff match will determine the 1972 United States team.

title: Transatlantic Gaullism
description: Prime Minister Heath's warning that Western Europe can no longer rely on the United States as it did inthe past highlights the growing distrust stimulated by recent Administration policies among most of the country's closest allies abroad.

title: Troy Demands Knapp Call 2 Who Charged City CoverUp, but Panel Rejects Idea
description: Councilman Matthew J. Troy, the Queens Democratic leader, demanded yesterday that the two policemen who had charged city officials with covering up police corruption to protect Mayor Lindsay be subpoenaed to testify before the Knapp Commission.

title: TOYOTA INCREASES PRICES ABOUT 9%
description: DETROIT Oct. 21Toyota the Japanese car maker raised prices about 9 per cent today It is the last of the major auto importers to. raise prices. The increases reflect higher production costs in Japan and the increase in the value of the yen, Toyota. said.

title: Woman, 83, Is Cleared Of Gunrunning by Irish
description: CORK, Ireland, Oct. 21 (UPI)The hunt for the passenger whose name was marked on a consignment of smuggled guns aboard the liner Queen Elizabeth 2 has ended in the parlor of an 83yearold grandmother from New York.

title: Shots at Soviet Mission Stir Bitter Debate in the U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21  The General Assembly engaged for long hours today in shouted and chaotic floor debates of rare bitterness as a result of last night's sniper attack on the New York headquarters of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: Devlin and Miss Craig Stand Out in Carmen
description: The New York City Opera has not had the best of luck in casting its new production. of Bizet's Carmen, but in the performance given Wednesday night it came up with a firstrate Escamillo (the toreador) in Michael Devlin and a good Micaela in Patricia Craig.

title: The Court Nominations
description: In nominating Lewis F. Powell Jr. of Virginia and William H. Rehnquist, an Assistant Attorney General, for the Supreme Court, Mr. Nixon put an end to the furious speculation which seemed to have been deliberately set motion. Mr. Powell admirably combines the fundamental requirements of legal and intellectual distinction with Mr. Nixon's insistence on political conservatism and Southern origin. Mr. Rehnquist, a Goldwater conservative, has a brilliant professional background but a questionable record on civil liberties.

title: Computer Study by Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) The Senate, where official records are still kept in handwritten ledgers, adopted a resolution today authorizing study of how it could switch to computers. The resolution authorizes the expenditure of $78,000 for a fourmonth study, including $45,000 in consultants fees and $11,685 for a professional computer expert.

title: Cambodia Floats Currency
description: PNOMPENH, Oct. 21 (UPI) Premier Lon Nol's Government announced today it would allow the Cambodian riel to float and find its own value. Diplomats said this amounted to devaluation of the currency.

title: The Screen
description: In spite of occasional jolting headlines, the political arenas of South America remain dimly remote to many North American minds. The Whitney Museum's new film program, a pair of color doc umentaries made in Chile by the American team of Saul Landau and Haskell Wexler, should change that, at least temporarily.

title: All 16 Aboard Die in Illinois Commuter Air Crash
description: PEORIA, Ill., Oct, 21 (AP)A commuter airliner hit a utility, line and crashed while approaching the Peoria Airport in light rain and fog today, killing all 14 passengers and the crew of two.

title: G.M. SEES SURVIVAL
description: DETROIT, Oct. 21General Motors unveiled a safety car today that its engineers said had a good chance pf eventually preventing a person from being killed or severely injured in a 100mileanhour crash into another car.

title: Saving the Fare
description: The plan agreed on by city and state officials to save the 30cent fare is a shrewdly devised but jerrybuilt structure, reflecting a maximum of political blackmail and a minimum of genuine statesmanship on the part of all concerned. Yet the 30cent fare must be saved. The politicians in Albany and at City Hall have now left New Yorkers with literally no other course but to accept a tricky solution to a monumental problem that demanded forthrightness and courage instead of evasion and financial jugglery.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I think it is shameful and unfortunate that a Governor of one of our United States should choose to compare the election of South Vietnam's President Thieu to that of George Washington. It is shameful that Governor Reagan implies that our heritage has decayed to such an extreme that he can make such. an analogy.

title: Stirling Outpoints Dane
description: COPENHAGEN, Oct. 21 (UPI) Bunny Stirling, the British Empire middleweight champion, who seeks a world title bout, posted a 10round decision over Denmark's Torn Bogs tonight.

title: Employe's Suicide With Boss's Pistol Cancels Gun Permit
description: A women's suicide, committed with a pistol that her employer owned legally for 15 years without incident was cited by a State Supreme Court justice here yesterday as he refused to overturn the revocation of the weapon's permit.

title: Japanese Suspend Talks
description: TOKYO, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Toyo Kogyo Company, a Japanese car maker, said today it would suspend its negotiations for a capital tieup with the Ford Motor Company until the end of this year because Ford wants to defer large capital investments abroad after President Nixon's dollardefending program.

title: BRITISH TO OPPOSE U.S. IN U.N. VOTING
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21Britain told the General Assembly today that she would vote against the Americansponsored resolution that seeks to keep Nationalist China a member.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Modern Museum Opens Barnett Newman Show
description: Running through only the material nearest at hand, a press release including quotes from the catalogue, I find the following words and phrases employed in describing the art of the late Barnett Newman, who is the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art that opened yesterday: purity and drama immediacy and simple splendor... cosmic.. magnificent... heroic.. grand, strong, profoundly moving...full, passionate blazonlike, tightlipped dignity... voluptuous energy. spiritual visions... philosophic enquiry on the nature of agony.

title: POTOMAC PROPERTY IS BARRED TO SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The State Department told the Soviet Embassy today that Washington would not approve Moscow's purchase of a tract of land once owned by George Washington five miles from his home at Mount Vernon.

title: SQUIRES CONQUER CHAPS BY 10399
description: RICHMOND, Oct. 21 (AP)The Virginia Squires, paced by Charlie Scotts 21 points In the second half,. rallied tonight to defeat the Dallas Chaparrals, 10399, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Allstate Life Coverage Up
description: The Allstate Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had reached the $10billion level of coverage in force, with about 45 per cent of the total in group insurance and the remainder in individual policies.

title: DANIEL J. M'CARTHY
description: NORWALK, Conn. Oct. 21Daniel J. McCarthy, a public relations executive, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital after a long illness. His age was 48 and he lived at 6 Huckleberry Drive.

title: Notes on People
description: PARIS, Oct. 21Stavros S. Niarchos, the Greek shipping magnate, married Tina Livanos, his former sisterinlaw, in a virtually secret civil ceremony today.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Denmark continues to maintain that the necessity for an allout ban on its highseas fishery for Atlantic salmon, developed in 1964 in the Davis Strait off Greenland, is not supported by scientific evidence.

title: An Impassioned and Popular Writer
description: On July 12, 1904, the little frontier town of Parral in the south of Chile registered the name of Neftalf Ricardo Reyes Basualto, the son of a crew foreman on the Chilean railroad.

title: SHORT INTEREST DROPS IN MONTH
description: Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a frequently watched technical indicator of the stockmarket outlook, fell 603,942 shares, theexchange announced yesterday.

title: Gen. Louis E. Woods Dies at 76; Marine Led Guadalcanal Units
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  Lieut. Gen. Louis E. Woods of the Marine Corps died yesterday at the age of 76. A longtime Marine aviator, he served in the corps for 34 years before retiring in July 1951.

title: Administration is Angered
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The Nixon Administration reacted with anger and concern today over the sniper attack last night against the Soviet Mission to the United States.

title: WILLIAM F. FENNELLY
description: William F. Fennelly, assistant manager of transportation at W. R. Grace & Co., died Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 2681 South Grand Avenue, Baldwin, L. I.

title: MEANY TO ACCEPT A PAY BOARD SEAT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21George Meany has agreed to accept membership on the Nixon Administration's Pay Board, a spokesman for the labor federation said today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your Oct. 11 editorial on Soviet emigration policy left out an important fact that would, have made the reason for the restrictive policy clearer.

title: CANADIAN RIDER IS SHOW VICTOR
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 21Determined to keep Canada in the lead in the international jumping at the Pennsylvania, National Horse Show, Barbara Simpson, from Calgary, sped her mare, Australis, round a gambler's choice course of 10 fences tonight and posted the top score. Australis collected 90 points in 51.2 seconds.

title: DAVID A. MUNN, 73, UNION CARBIDE AIDE
description: STAMFORD, Conn. Oct. 21  David Aloysius Munn, retired divisional sales manager specializing in plastics at Union Carbide Corporation New York City died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 1539 Shippan Avenue here.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21 The Egyptian Government's chief spokesman, Tahsin Bashir, said tonight that there was no official comment as yet on a news agency report that Cairo had agreed to formal designation of Mr. Sisco as intermediary to work out an agreement for reopening the Suez Canal.

title: A Stagnant Air Mass Afflicting City Region
description: The National Weather Service warned yesterday that a stagnant air mass over the city and nearby areas might cause smoke, dust and gases to accumulate near the ground until about 11 o'clock ,tonight.

title: Excerpts From U.N. Debate on China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21  Following are excerpts from today's debate in the General Assembly on the issue of Chinese representation in the United Nations:

title: U.S. Cardinal Urges P.O.W. Appeal by Synod
description: ROME, Oct. 21John Cardinal Carberry urged the Synod of Bishops today to appeal for humane treatment of prisoners of war.

title: Amex Stocks Drop As Volume Eases; Losses Top Gains
description: The American Stock Exchange gave it a good try yesterday to finish in the win column for the first time in seven sessions but didn't quite make it as declines outnumbered advances by a slight margin in slower trading.

title: How Not to Pacify Ulster
description: If one thing is certain in the complex tragedy of Northern Ireland it is that the abrupt withdrawal of British forces would be quickly followed by a bloodbath almost unimaginable dimensions. Yet that is exactly what Senators Kennedy of Massachusetts and Ribicoff Connecticut, along with Representative Hugh Carey New York, are demanding. Their resolutiOn urges the Nixon Administration to call for an immediate British troop pullout and for unification of Ireland.

title: EARLY VOTE ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 President Nixon nominated Lewis F. Powell Jr., a former president of the American Bar Association, and William H. Rehnquist, an Assistant Attorney General, to the Supreme Court tonight.

title: He Gave His Favorite Room to Museum
description: After 40 years in use in a Park Avenue apartment, an extraordinary Art Deco roomwithinaroom that was exetuted by master craftsmen in Paris has found a new home in the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department stores sales at $837million, up 9 per cent from the yearearlier $771million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,764,000,000, up 11 per cent from $7,009,000,000.

title: Disavowal by Administration
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Nixon Administration has quickly dissociated itself from the KennedyRibicoff resolution calling for the withdrawal of British troops from Northern Ireland.

title: U.H.F. Aida Total Care
description: Treating the entire person is essential to rehabilitation medicine, a field concerned with both physical disabilities and with giving the disabled patient the means to return to a normal life. One of the 56 voluntary nonprofit hospitale of the United Hospital Fund provides the most comprehensive and uptodate rehabilitative care available including physical occupational recreational and speech therapy and occupational counseling.

title: British Frigate in Polish Port
description: WARSAW, Oct. 21 (AP)A British warship entered the Polish port of Szczecin early today for the first postwar visit by a Western naval ship to the former German territory. Diplomatic observers said the visit by the frigate Ashanti amounted to de facto recognition of Poland's postwar western frontier.

title: ExDean Praises Rehnquist
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 21Carl B. Spaeth, former dean of the Stanford School of Law who now holds an endowed professorship at the university, said today that William H. Rehnquist, one of President Nixon's Supreme Court nominees, had been a very able student when he was at Stanford. If confirmed, Mr Spaeth said, Mr. Rehnquist would undoubtedly be a wellinformed strict constructionist who knows what is required for documentation for important decisions.

title: SURGEONS GET PLEA TO RESTUDY ETHICS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 21 (UPI)Dr. Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences, said today that natural forces that weeded out the unfit were being conquered and that, as a consequence, the nation faced the prospect of a society more prone to disease.

title: 13 KILLED, 100 HURT IN A GLASGOW BLAST
description: GLASGOW, Scotland, Oct. 21 (AP)  An explosion in busy Scottish shopping center today killed 13 persons arid injured at least 100.

title: Poll Indicates Negro on Ticket Would Be a Liability in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A Negro VicePresidential candidate would be a liability on a national ticket in 1972, the Gallup Poll reported today, but prejudice toward a Negro's running for President is at the lowest level yet recorded,

title: KOSYGIN IN MONTREAL AS 1,200 HOLD MARCH
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (UPI)Premier Alexei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union was given dinner here tonight while an estimated 1,200 demonstrators marched on the Soviet consulate lighting bOnfires, breaking at least a half dozen windows and splattering the building with paint.

title: CODE DISAVOWED ON SUBWAY NOISE
description: Dr. Robert N. Rickles, the city's Commissioner of Mr Resources, disavowed yesterday a subway, noise abatement section of the new noise control code his ,departrnent presented to the City Council last month.

title: INDICTED JUDGE ASKS A LEAVE FROM BENCH
description: At his own request, Judge Bernard Klieger yesterday was relieved of his judicial assignments pending the determination of charges against him.

title: Watson Sentenced to Death For a Part in Tate Murders
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (UPI) Charles (Tex) Watson was given the death sentence today for the TateLabianca murders. It was the same penalty given the four other members of Charles Manson's family who were tried for the seven slayings.

title: 4 Held as Members of a Burglary Ring
description: WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 21Investigators from the local office of the State Organized Crime Task Force have arrested three men and a Woman believed to be members of what the task force calls one of the most active burglary rings in the Eastern United States.

title: Excerpts From Testimony and Tape Recordings at Knapp Commission Hearing
description: Following are excerpts from testimony and tape recordings heard yesterday by the Knapp Commission during its fourth day of public hearings.

title: Peak Sales Reported
description: The Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Company, the widely diversified industrial producer, attained record sales and earnings in the third quarter and first nine months this year, Harry Heltzer, chairman, reported from St. Paul, Minn., headquarters yesterday.

title: MANDATORY TERM URGED FOR HEROIN
description: Paul Curran, chairman of the State Commission of Investigation, recommended yesterday that a mandatory minimum sentence of two to five years be imposed automatically on anyone convicted of selling one ounce of heroin.

title: Advertising:
description: September has come and gone so that means the third quarter has ended and it's time for those who have to speak up to speak up.

title: Effect of Knapp Hearing Is Felt In Numbers Game in Harlem
description: A Harlem numbers runner said yesterday that Knapp Commission hearings were beginning slowly but steadily to have an impact on his community where the numbers game flourishes, allegedly throtigh payoffs to the police.

title: LADY FLEMING,ILL, FREED FROM JAIL
description: ATHENS, Oct. 21 (Reuters)Lady Fleming was released from prison tonight after a court suspended for eight months a 16month jail sentence imposed on her for her part in a plot to free a Greek prisoner accused of trying to assassinate Premier George Papadopoulos.

title: CALIFORNIA COURT EASES TAX RUING
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 21 (UPI)The California Supreme Court, in a modification of its school financing decision Aug. 30, ruled today that the existing property tax system for supporting the public schools was still valid.

title: The Helpful Stewardesses
description: Two stewardesses in Pan American blues, caps slightly tilted, ignored the curious glances of Greenwich Village habitus and rounded up 25 giggling children in front of the Fifth Avenue Hotel on Ninth Street.

title: G.M. Decides to Skip Car Show in Coliseum
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday that it would not take part in the International Automobile Show in the New York Coliseum next spring.

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Many Fruitless Peace Bids to Hanoi
description: IN the summer of 1965 I came to the painful conclusion that an independent South Vietnam could survive only if the United States and other nations went to its aid with their own fighting forces. From then until I left the Presidency, we had three principal goals: to insure that aggression did not succeed, to make it possible for the South Vietnamese to build their country and their future in their own way and to convince Hanoi that working out peaceful settlement was to the advantage of all concerned.

title: The Witness: Policeman's Son, A Decent Lad, a Cool Grafter
description: A grayhaired man in the Audience at the Knapp ComMission hearings yesterday gazed gently at the face of William R. Phillips, who was completing three days of testimony about his career as a bribetaking policeman.

title: Spacecraft Shift Canceled
description: PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP)A final midcourse correction for Mariner 9, the United States spacecraft scheduled to orbit Mars on Nov. 13, has been deleted because the spacecraft is so precisely on course, project officials say. The correction, a short firing of Mariner's engine, had been set for Oct. 26, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology's Jet Propulsion Laboratory said yesterday.

title: DEBATE ON MARKET BEGINS IN COMMONS
description: LONDON, Oct. 21The long struggle to bring Britain into the Common Market today entered what should be its last phasedebate in the House of Commons on the terms of entry negotiated by the Conservative Government.

title: Unrest Surges in Memphis; Police Car Kills Black, 3
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 21Scattered rockthrowing and firebombing hit Memphis for the third straight night tonight, with the death of a 3yearold black boy, struck by a police car, threatening to exacerbate racial tension in this city.

title: Youth Seized in Firing at Soviet Mission
description: An 18yearold Brooklyn youth described by the police as an activist of the Jewish Defense League was seized halfblock from the Soviet Mission to the United Nations last night and charged with illegal possession of the rifle used to fire four shots through an apartment window of the mission Wednesday night.

title: Businessmen Bid U.S. Freeze Own Spending
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP)  The United StatesChamber of Commerce placed fullpage advertisements in all three Washington newspapers today under the heading Let's freeze government too.

title: H.U.D. IS CHARGED WITH RACIAL BIAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21A Federal hearing examiner has found the Department of Housing and Urban Development guilty of racial discrimination and has recommended the return of pay withheld from 106 employes who had demonstrated against alleged discriminatory practices.

title: Museum SexBias Case Is Resolved
description: After an investigation by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's office, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has signed an assurance of discontinuance that it will not engage in employment policies that discriminate against women.

title: Bombs Explode in Londonderry
description: BELFAST, Oct. 21 (UPI)s Eight bombs exploded in Londonderry tonight and youths stoned British troops who fired back with volleys of CS nausea gas, a British Army spokesman said.

title: Lou Adler Is Appointed Head of WCBS Radio
description: Marvin Friedman has been replaced as news director of WCBS AllNews Radio by Lou Adler, a reporter and documentarian for the Columbia Broadcasting System's local radio and television outlets for 12 years.

title: H.S.M. Burns, 71, ExPresident Of Shell Oil Company, Is Dead
description: H. S. M. Burns, president of the Shell Oil Company from 1647 until his retirement in 1960, died yesterday. He was 71 years old and lived at 485 Park Avenue and also in Locust Valley, L. I.

title: Lewis Franklin Powell Jr.
description: Lewis Franklin Powell Jr. could bring to the Supreme Court the Southern voice that President Nixon is looking for. But, assuming he is confirmed to the post he was named to last night, the Southern voice will have soft and reasoning inflection that traces back to his native tidewater Virginia. In manners and polish, Mr. Powell fits comfortably into the image of the antebellum South. But in the moderation of his ideas and his approach to integration, he appears to belong more to what has been called the new South.

title: Goven Ousts Hewitt, 64, 64; Miss Goolagong Advances
description: BILLINGHAM, England, Oct. 21 (AP)  Georges Goven of France, defeated topseeded Bob Hewitt of South Africa, 64, 64 today in the quarterfinals of the Dewar Cup tennis tournament.

title: MOST BOND PRICES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Most of the credit markets continued yesterday to march confidently toward higher bond prices and lower interest rates, but the taxexempt sector got out of step.

title: Nixon Ends Prior Checks With Bar on Nominations
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The Nixon Administration abruptly terminated tonight its agreement to check the judicial. qualifications of potential Supreme Court nominees with the American Bar Association before formally appointing them to the Court.

title: JOHN L. UNDERHILL, EXPOLITICAL WRITER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 John Lispenard Underhill, a former political reporter for The New York Times and later a Republican party aide died here today after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Southern Railway in Bid For the Norfolk Southern
description: The Southern Railway has approached the Norfolk Southern Railway about becoming part of its system, it was disclosed yesterday by both lines. It was emphasized in the joint announcement that the discussions had been purely exploratory and that no specific proposals for the Southern's acquisition of the Norfolk Southern had been made.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 21United States Embassy and Israeli Foreign Ministry officials said tonight they had seen no dispatches concerning a report that Egypt had agreed to Mr. Sisco as a gobetween in negotiations.

title: Synod Is Keeping Prelates on Run
description: ROME, Oct. 21The Roman Catholic Archbishop of St. Louis sat in an overstuffed chair in his quarters here and gave a lively rendition of When Irish Eyes Are Smiling on his chromatic harmonica.

title: Ruskin Tells of City Loans On Fictitious Mortgages
description: Borrowers from the Municipal Loan Program received money from the city to pay off mortgages without having to supply documentary proof that there really was a mortgage, Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin told a City Council committee yesterday.

title: Recital
description: Sonatas by Weber, Prokofdev and Scriabin have a great many notes in them. So do the pieces in Albeniz's Iberia. Putting them into place and making musical sense out of them is a prodigious technical feat, and accomplishing this was one of the impressive factors of Thomas Schumacher's recital in Tully Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Marcia Rodd in Box Step
description: Marcia Rodd has been signed to costar with Alan Alda in The Box Step, the new Murray Schisgal comedy, which Richard Seader and Allan Jack Lewis will bring to Broadway on Feb. 17, Martin Fried is directing.

title: I.A.T.A. CHIEF SEES AIRFARE ACCORD
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Knut Hammarskj old, Director General of the International Mr Transport Association, predicted today that feuding transAtlantic airlines would reach agreement on new farei next week and avert a threatened price war Feb. 1.

title: Thant Makes Appeal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 21Secretary General Thant, acting on the basis of military reports from the IndiaPakistan area of a growing threat of war, has sent personal appeals to President Yahya Khan and Premier Gandhi.

title: Mrs. Doubilet's 84 Leads Jersey Seniors by Stroke
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 21  Mrs. Henry Doubilet of Hollywood posted a 44, 4084 today for a onestroke lead in the first round of the second annual 36hole women's senior state golf championship of New Jersey at the Crestmont Country Club's 5,924yard, par74 course.

title: TORIES WIN EASILY IN ONTARIO ELECTION
description: TORONTO, Oct. 21  The Progressive Conservative party, which has governed Ontario without interruption for 28 years, rolled to an overwhelming victory tonight in an election for control of Canada's largest province.

title: U.S. AIDES EXPECT NO '71 ARMS PACT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Many qualified United States officials no longer believe that an agreement with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic arms can be reached by the end of this year. But they express optimism that one will be achieved by the middle of next year.

title: Allende Praises Poet
description: SANTIAGO. Chile, Oct. 21 (UPI)  President Allende praised the firm ideological position of Mr. Neruda today.

title: Melchionni Is Big Assist to Nets
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 21The New York Nets are in Bill Melchionni's good hands.

title: Times to Distribute Films On American College Life
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that it would distribute a series of 13 films, each portraying the environment and way of life at a different American college. The films are designed for use by guidance counselors, teachers, parents and high school students.

title: Giants Rating Goes Up, But Only Against Eagles
description: The Jets play at home on Sunday as underdogs to Miami, while the Giants will be the favorites in Philadelphia. Isn't everyone? Three games will be televised here: GiantsEagles, Channel 2 at 1 P.M., followed by Washington at Kansas City at 4 P.M. and Cincinnati at Oakland, Channel 4 at 4 P.M. The Monday night game is Baltimore at Minnesota, Channel 7 at 9 P.M. Here are previews of all the games with wonlosttied records in parentheses.

title: Ellen S. Straus to Write A Column for McCall's
description: Ellen Sulzberger Straus, founder of WMCA: Call for Action, has joined McCall's magazine as columnist and contributing editor.

title: Betty Bronson, 24 Peter Pan In Silent Film, Is Dead at 64
description: PASADENA, Calif, Oct, 21 (UPI)  Betty Bronson, who became a star at 17 when she was chosen by Sir James Barrie for the title role in the silentfilm version of his Peter Pan in 1924, died here Tuesday after a brief illness. She was 64 years old.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 21 (AP)Manuel Orantes of Spain and Ken Rosewall of Australia moved into the quarterfinals of the Spanish open tennis tournament today.

title: Museum Aide Disappointed
description: MALIBU, Calif., Oct. 21Burton Frederickson, curator of the J. Paul Getty Museum here, expressed disappointment tonight that the Titian painting would not be coming to California, but added: If the British people want it badly enough to put up that much money, they should have the right to keep it.

title: Toure's AntiImperialist Purge Terrorizing Guineans
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 14President Sokou Toure's independent Government is conducting an extensive antiimperialist purge that has sent waves of terror through this West African republic.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER ADVANCE
description: Without setting any price records soybean contracts managed to show impressive gains yesterday. Most contracts closed with 3 cents a bushel increases in active volume.

title: 7 GAMBLERS HELD ON DATA PROVIDED BYKNAPP WITNESS
description: Seven East Harlem gamblers, some of them listed as major organizedcrime figures by the Police Department, have been arrested on the basis of information provided by Patrolman William R. Phillips, the corrupt policeman who became an undercover agent of the Knapp Commission.

title: Agnew Said to Assure Greece on Arms
description: ATHENS, Oct. 21Vice President Agnew has assured his Greek hosts that President Nixon is ready to override any Congressional ban on military aid to Greece, American and Greek sources reported today,

title: Ms Isn't Sweeping the Nation The Foes of Miss/Mrs. Find
description: Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of New York, says that a profound question involving the status of women is involved.

title: Aaron Registers a 66
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 21 (AP)A pair of Georgia natives, Tommy Aaron and Hugh Royer, shot sixunderpar 66's today to share the firstround lead in the $150,000 Kaiser international open golf tournament.

title: Atkinson Doubtful for Sunday
description: Freakish injuries, particularly in workouts, are the bane of every coach, and Weeb Ewbank has had more than his share. The Jet head coach's latest headache concerns Al Atkinson, who might not be available for Sunday's game with the Miami Dolphins at Shea Stadium.

title: JERSEY STANDARD HITS PROFIT PEAK
description: Record crudeoil production and naturalgas sales as well as higher product prices contributed to record sales and earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30, the concern said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Announces Inquiry Into the HotIssue Boom
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced here yesterday that it was beginning a major inquiry into the newissue craze of the Sixties in a move to develop new disclosure policies and prevent a repetition of the largescale investor losses of that period.

title: Airman Arrested for Having Secret Data
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21M. Sgt. Walter T. Perkins, the topranking noncommissioned officer in the Defense Weapons Center's intelligence division at Tyndall Air Force Base, Fla., was charged today with improper possession and use of documents dealing with national security.

title: 2 Brothers Accused of Bilking Many in Market Studies Fraud
description: Two brothers were accused yesterday of swindling thousands of individuals by soliciting them to engage in a fraudulent market research scheme for cash rewards that were never paid.

title: First Shutout for Edwards
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 (AP) Gary Edwards, in only his seventh N.H.L. game, kicked aside 34 shots tonight as the Los Angeles Kings trounced the Philadelphia Flyers, 7.0, before 14,120 in the Spectrum.

title: Hospital Groups See Peril in Job Cuts
description: The administrators of the city's 18 public hospitals, along with organizations of doctors, nurses and other staff members of the institutions, charged yesterday that a jobattrition policy being contemplated by the Health and Hospitals Corporation would consign more patients to death.

title: Murphy Defends Honesty Of the Average Policeman
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy, in a shortwave radio address yesterday to his 31,000 men, said that there is no reason to be ashamed because one or another traitor to the uniform that you wear so proudly seeks to justify his own dishonesty by pretending that none of you is honest.

title: A Survey Finds Ethnic Studies Lacking in State
description: A survey made for a special educational commission has found that public elementary and secondary schools in the state have taken at best a token approach toward inclusion of ethnic studies in their curriculums.

title: Murray L. Handwerker, 48, A Founder of Big Daddy's
description: Murray L. Handwerker, cofounder and executive vice president of Big Daddy's Restaurants, Inc., which owns or operates five fastservice eating establishments in Brooklyn Queens and Long Island died of a heart attack yesterday in Jamaica Hosptial Queens He was 48 years old and lived to 2752 Whitman Drive Brooklyn.

title: RAIL TRAFFIC OFF; TRUCK TONNAGE UP
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Freight traffic on United States railroads during the week ended Oct. 16 was considerably below the volume in the corresponding week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period registered an increase.

title: Neruda, Chilean PoetPolitician, Wins Nobel Prize in Literature
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 21Pablo Neruda, the Chilean poet, diplomat and Communist leader was awarded the 1971 Nobel Prize for Literature today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Getting the Japanese to double their purchase of military equipment so that American balance of payments will be reduced reflects either the desperation or the immature judgment of Government officials.

title: Stage: Four Americans
description: The Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn is beginning its current season with Four Americans, a sequence of oneact plays by new American writerstwo this week and two next week. On Tuesday, plays by Michael Weller and Stephen H. Foreman opened in Chelsea's revised and improved Third Theater atop the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: CONGRESS BUOYS GRUMMAN HOPES
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., Oct. 21A HouseSenate conference committee in Washingtonitoday approved the appropriation of $801million for 48 F14 jet fighter airplanes, and the reaction at the Grumman Corporation here, where the planes will be produced, was one of overwhelming relief:

title: William Hubbs Rehnquist
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Early this week, William Hubbs Rehnquist, Assistant Attorney General, sent a memorandum to the American Bar Association defending Judge Mildred L. Lillie, who had been proposed to the association by President Nixon as a possible Supreme Court Justice. Tonight, Mr. Rehnquist, a conservative Arizonan, was himself nominated by Mr. Nixon for a seat on the Court.

title: Dartmouth Prepares to Halt Wild Harvard Offense
description: The Ivy League colleges may refer to themselves as brethren in regard to their collective approach to higher education, their stiff academic, requirements and their scholarship grants based upon student needs, but there is no love lost among them on the athletic field. This seems especially true when Dartmouth and Harvard get together far a football brouhaha.

title: U.S. WAR TOLL OF 5 LOWEST IN 6 YEARS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21 (AP)  Five Americans, were killed in combat in Vietnam last week, the lowest weekly death toll in more than six years, the United States command announced today.

title: Nevada Backs Student Vote
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 21 (AP)Nevada's Attorney General Robert List ruled today that college students might register to vote Where they attend college if they meet county residentce requirements. Mr. List said voters 18, 19 and 20 year old could establish legal residence for voting purposes separate from their parents or guardians.

title: Tarport Adios, Surprise Score Pacing Victories
description: YONKERS, Oct. 21Hugh Grant's Tarport Adios ($5.60), in 2:04 1/5, and the Jerobe Stables Surprise ($14), in 2:03 2/5, were the winners of their respective divisions in tonight's New York Sire Stakes for 2yearold pacing colts and geldings.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21  Every President since Franklin Roosevelt has known that It is bad business to pick a fight with Wilbur Mills, the influential chairman of the powerful House Ways and Means Committee, but apparently President Nixon hasn't got the message.

title: Jersey Bus Line Struck
description: Drivers and maintenance men for the Hudson Bus Transportation Company, went on strike last midnight, shutting down the line, which carries 15,000 commuters daily into New York City from northern and central New Jersey communities. It also carries 10,000 passengers daily between points in New Jersey.

title: Gains Made in Drive to Slow Construction Raises
description: DETROIT, Oct. 21  The Administration's effort to control wage increases in the construction industry appears to be succeeding, though not as quickly as some expected.

title: Prime Interest Replaced
description: The First National City Bank, the second largest bank in the United States and the largest in New York, announced yesterday it is shifting to a new, more flexible method for establishing commercial loan rates,

title: Peking Newspaper, in Unusual Move, Publishes Photos of Kissinger and Other U. S Aides
description: PEKING, Oct. 21 (Reuters) Photographs of President Nixon's special envoy, Henry A. Kissinger, and his aides appeared in the official Chinese Government newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao tonightan event to which foreign diplomats attributed considerable significance.

title: Government of Lon Nol Denies Any Intent to Rule Cambodia by a Dictatorship
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 21  The Government of Premier Lon Nol, in an exceptional formal statement, denied tonight that it intended to rule by dictatorship and was abandoning democracy.

title: Advertising:
description: Advertising's current favorite discussion topicthe fullservice agency vs. the house agency vs. independent buying servicesgot a thorough kicking around yesterday as the Conference Board's annual marketing conference went into its second day at the New York Hilton.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET BID INDIANS AVOID WAR WITH PAKISTANIS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 The United States and the Soviet Union are exerting strong diplomatic pressure on India to avoid any action that might lead to hostilities with Pakistan, American officials said here today.

title: Pan Am's Net for Quarter Rises; Small Increase in Costs a Factor
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., reported yesterday a thirdquarter net income of $25,540,000, or 64 cents share, compared with $17,344,000, or 49 cents, for the period last year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent letter to the editor, five Massachusetts Institute of Technology economists argued that profits should be controlled directly through an excessprofits tax, rather than merely indirectly through the relative levels at which wages and prices are controlled. According to them, an excessprofits tax has always been adopted along with wageprice freezes in the past... [as] an absolutely essential ingredient in an equitable policy of eliminating inflation. They suggest that economists who oppose such tax thereby callously propose that the burden of incomes restraint should bear most heavily on wage and salary workers.

title: Cranes Arrive in Texas
description: AUSTWELL, Tex., Oct. 21 (AP) Four whooping cranes have come to a wildlife refuge here, the vanguard of an annual migration from Canada that naturalists hope will include some young of the nearly extinct special. The feeding grounds here are in excellent shape, said Robert C. Brown, manager of the Aransas Wildlife Refuge. We sent 56 to Canada last spring and we're hoping we'll get 60 birds back this winter.

title: Kiernan Assails Lindsay on Hearings
description: The Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption were described yesterday by the head of the Patrolmen's Association as a move by Mayor Lindsay to attract nationwide attention.

title: Walsh Says U.S. Told the City To Trim HousingBuilding Plan
description: The city's Housing and Development Administrator, Albert Walsh, said yesterday that Federal/officials had told the city to curtail its housingconstruction program.

title: WILLIAM R. DALEY, A FINANCIER, 79
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 21  William R Daley, president of Otis & Co. a holding company and formerly a private banking firm, died today In the Cleveland Clinic after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: 2 NOMINEES GIVEN CAUTIOUS BACKING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21President Nixon's two Supreme Court appointments met with cautious approval tonight from both conservatives and liberal Senators, indicating that the nominations would be Confirmed by the Senate.

title: Market Place: Effect Examined Of Gas Shortage
description: You've heard about the naturalgas shortage, but you've never really worried about it because there's plenty of gas to fuel your furnace at home.

title: Head of Chase Unit Named
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday named Victor E. Rockh ill, xecutive vice president, as president and chief executive officer of the Chase International Investment Corporation, a foreigninvestment subsidiary. He succeeds John M. Lyons, who becomes vice chairman.

title: Herman and Howie Invite Bookies to Join the Team
description: An animated cartoon named Herman The Horse galloped into the Garment District yesterday in the first of a series of promotional efforts for the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

title: Books of The Times
description: A couple of weeks ago on the Dick Cavett show, Norman Mailer and Jose Torres, a former lightheavyweight champion, put on the gloves and went three rounds. Though Torres was holding back, of course, Mailer was impressive. For a middleaged writer, he's a pretty good boxer. He explained that he and Torres had exchanged lessons: He helped Torres by editing his book on Muhammad All and Torres taught him to box. On the evidence of Sting Like a Bee, I'd say Mailer got the better of the bargain. As a beginning writer, Torres reminds me of a mistake some young fighters make: They pick up the mannerisms of their ring idols, but without knowing how to use them. Carrying their hands low like Sugar Ray Robinson or Muhammad Ali, they get hit, because they can't slip punches like the masters. Mailer is obviously Torres's literary hero, and he has adopted Mailer's vocabulary of machismo, magic and mystification when talking about fighters. His psychologizing is rather like the clinching for which Ernie Terrell was famous: It slows up the action. Sonny Liston said of Terrell: He hug a man more than I hug my wife. Torres smothers his man in patterns, transitions, indoctrinations"as if fighters threw not punches, but metaphors or hexes at each other.

title: MARKET DECLINE HALTED BY RALLY
description: Stock prices steadied late yesterday as selling pressure eased and certain groupsnotably the glamour and airline issuesmoved higher.

title: Kenya to Hang Robbers
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 21 (Agence FrancePresse)  Kenya's Parliament tonight approved a bill for the hanging of robbers who inflict grievous bodily harm on their victims. The bill has to be approved by President Jomo Kenyatta, who yesterday said he favored the public hanging of robbers.

title: EGYPT SAID TO AGREE TO U.S. INTERMEDIARY
description: CAIRO, Oct. 21 (UPI)Authoritative sources in Cairo reported today that Egypt had accepted Washington's suggestion that Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco act as gobetween in EgyptianIsraeli negotiations for an interim agreement on reopening the Suez Canal.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President went on nationwide television to announce his nominations to fill the two vacant seats on the Supreme Court, He received diplomatic credentials from Joseph AtardKingswell of Malta, Andre Jean Coulbary of Senegal, Edmund Valencia Ibanez of Bolivia, Toma Granfil of Yugoslavia and Carlos Manuel Muniz of Argentina. He also sent a Veterans Day message to members of the armed forces.

title: As Students Age...
description: The upsurge of student activism and the radicalization of large segments of the undergraduate population since 1964 has led to considerable speculation about the future Politics of this college cohort. Opinion surveys make clear that the most recent students and graduates are much more left of center and critical than those of the forties and fifties. Will they retain their present commitments in substantial measure, and thus constitute major force for social change, as they climb the occupational hierarchies?

title: British to Keep Titian From Going to Getty Museum
description: LONDON, Oct. 21  The Government yielded to Britain's art Establishment today and agreed to contribute public funds to keep a Titian masterpiece from going to California.

title: Pentagon Merges Two Missile Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard announced today a decision to combine two proposed missile development programs to make possible earlier deployment of the missiles aboard nuclear submarines currently available.

title: Channel 13 to Resume Coverage of Hearing
description: Channel 13 did not carry yesterday morning's hearings of the Knapp Commission on police corruption and received hundreds of telephone calls in protest. Arrangements were made late yesterday to resume coverage at 10 A.M. today and, in all probability, next week's sessions.

title: Autumn's Apples for Dessert
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Transcript of the President's Announcement on Two Nominees for Supreme Court
description: Good evening.

title: AQUA BELLE POSTS 8LENGTH VICTORY
description: Contributing a closetotherail performance in the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday, the Hobeau Farm's Aqua Belle scored a smashing triumph over five rivals.

title: British Officials Are Restrained
description: LONDON, Oct. 21British officials were restrained almost to the point of silence today over Senator Kennedy's assertion in Congress that Northern Ireland was rapidly becoming Britain's Vietnam.

title: Books of The Times
description: Putting a book together from morning reviews and weekend pieces is a hazardous business. It's not hard to do, in fact there's nothing easier, but the finished product differs, sometimes startlingly, from the ingredients that went into it. The item that was bright and newsworthy in the daily review appears denatured and flat in book form. Some topics sound so trivial that the space seems wasted; others are so weighty that the space. is inadequate. Names and occasions fade, and they don't loom as sharply in the consciousness of the book buyer as they did in the mind of the man who bought the morning paper. And no matter how they are organized, the books too often suffer from a scrappiness that was absent when the pieces occupied their natural places in the column. Paul Henry Lang, who was music critic of The New York Herald Tribune from 1954 to 1963, believes he has gotten around these objections in Critic at the Opera. By eliminating the critiques of the performances from the reviews, he writes, and omitting topical references, I was left with a sizable body of writings about opera as a work of art. These deletions have certainly altered the complexion of his original articles, but they have also eliminated what many would consider the only valid reason for compiling such a volume in the first place: to reflect with an immediacy hard to duplicate the musical life of the time. By removing all references to performers, performances, untoward occurrences, musical tidbits, memorable personalities, in short by removing all references to the peaks and shallows of musical history, he has in effect destroyed the record and with it all that was quick and alive in those years. What is left is a series of disquisitions on the character and importance of a number of wellknown (and tired) operas. In spite of its title, the book is not a report of the critic at the opera, but of the scholar in his study.

Last week, the same amount and term were 99.028 and 3.94 per cent. Also 82day bills were $45million at 98.122 and 3.84 per cent. Last week, the same amount and term were 98.030 and 4.03 per cent.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21Though the names of many women candidates for the Supreme Court were publicly discussed in the last few weeks, President Nixon had only relatively, small talent pool of Women lawyers to consider in reaching his decision to nominate two menand no women to the Court.

title: INDUSTRY REJECTS MYTH OF AD COST
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21The advertising industry presented testimony by an economics professor today to challenge the popular belief that advertised products necessarily cost more than other brands.

title: Panther Held in Cincinnati
description: CINCINNATI, Oct. 21 (UPI) Earl Walter Leverette, a 26yearold fugitive identified as a Black Panther wanted for the attempted murder of a policeman in Milwaukee two years ago, was arreste dhere yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Agents took him into custody at his home in Avondale. He said he had been living here for one year under the name of Jackson.

description: TICONDEROGA, N. Y., Oct. 21  The International Paper Company dedicated its new $76million plant here today. The plant, located on the western shore of Lake Champlain, replaces an older and smaller mill that was beset by air and water pollution problems.

title: Paris Peace Delegates Accuse Each Other of Stalling Tactics
description: PARIS, Oct. 21 Against background of continued mutual recrimination the 133d weekly session of the Vietnamese peace talks failed to make any visible progress today.

title: Ulster Chief Says Kennedy Plays Politics With Lives
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct, 21  Brian Faulkner, Northern Ireland's Prime Minister; accused Senator Edward M. Kennedy today of playing American politics with the lives of the Ulster people.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I am seriously concerned about the emotional attitude of most Americans, particularly the young voters, to the pollution problems. It has some of the hysteria of the CruSades, or (as more recent parallel) of the space race.

title: Amstar Sales and Profits Set a Record for Quarter
description: The Amstar Corporation, formerly the American Sugar Company, reported record net sales and income for its first fiscal quarter ended Sept. 30 at the company's annual meeting yesterday in the Waldorf Astoria Hotel.

description: Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange during four of Wall Street's most turbulent years, disclosed yesterday that he would not seek renewal of his employment contract when it expires next July 31.

title: Theater: Pleasant Revue
description: It is of course difficult to start a notice of an Israeli musical revue on Broadway without saying: Shalom! But nothing if not original, shall pointedly desist.

title: The Burden of the Constitution
description: The men at the executive levels of justice have trampled on traditions and ideals and principles: of justice. They see the Constitution as a burden, an obstruction to he overcome, as technical barrier to be avoided when inconvenient, evaded where possible, and ignored if necessary. Pledged by oath to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution, instead they defile, dilute and debase it. Proclaiming that they will. strictly construe it, rather they constrict and destroy it Slowly, stealthily, they arrogate to themselves the powers that the Constitution meant to be shared and powers that the Constitution never meant Govern ment to have at all.

title: Comment by Neruda
description: PARIS, Oct. 21Pablo Neruda came out of his embassy office here today and gave assembled newsmen a poet's line: Poets believe in miracles and this time it has happenedit would seem.

title: Mr. Agnew in Greece
description: No one will begrudge Vice President Agnew the deep satisfaction afforded by his return to the land of his forebears in Greece's Peloponnesus. It was a poignant moment when he told citizens of Gargalianoi, which his late father left to come to the United States in 1897, that he had learned it was possible to go home again, even to a home he has only heard of but never seen before.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISOne of the most successful tactics employed by the Vietnamese Communist side to confuse U.S. opinion during peace negotiations here is the simple one of saying different things to different Americans and then blandly refusing to see contradiction in such views, much less explain them.

title: 091738 Wins Jersey Lottery
description: WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Oct. 21 (AP)  The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 091738. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400, and the last three, $40.

title: Aid for Military Widows
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) The House voted 372 to 0 today to set up an annuity plan for widows of retired military men. The bill now goes to the Senate. The plan would provide a maximum survivor annuity of 55 per cent of a person's retired pay, with the beneficiary paying 60 per cent of the cost of the annuity.

title: Chaplin, 82, Softens Criticism of U.S.
description: VEVEY, Switzerland, Oct. 21  Charlie Chaplin finds that his 20 years of absence from the United States have mellowed his once astringent attitudes toward the country that revoked his visa in 1952 and forbade his reentry unless he could prove his moral worth.

title: Shots Heard Round the World
description: The shots fired into the Soviet Mission to the United Nations Wednesday night raise to an intolerable new level of criminal violence the persisting harassment foreign missions in this city that long ago exceeded all bounds of legitimate protest. This cowardly assault on a room containing a family of six, including four children, fortunately missed any human target. But it has struck a damaging blow at the reputation and selfrespect this city and nation.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The remarks of Roy Innis, national director of CORE, reported in The. Times [Oct. 8] equating the ideology of black nationalism with race purity and the integrationist philosophy with house niggerism are nothing more than a distorted form of Jensenism coming home to roost. In addition to resurrecting the bankrupt, eugenic theories of Gobineau, Chamberlain, and Hitler's chief racial expert, Alfred Rosenberg, Mr. Innis has distorted the contours of history beyond recognition. Even those with the slightest knowledge of the AfroAmerican past know that the relationship between a man's chromatographic profile and his loyalty to black humanity exists only in the mind of Roy Innis. [Editorial Oct. 12]

title: Evans Glad to Leave Giants Back Room

description: PUTKHALI, Pakistan, Oct. 10The adults peered cautiously out of the darkness of their mud huts. But the children, who have recovered more quickly from the upset of warfare, poured out to stare and giggle and smile bashfully at the strange foreign visitors.

Don't let geography trip you up, however. The Hollywood in this instance the one in Florida and not the one in California. It situated just north of the Miami Dolphins, who are due to tangle with the New York Jets in the general area Flushing Meadow.

Powell Jr. He also said that William H. Rehrnquist, in his Justice Department post, 'has demontrated a high degree of competence and a very credible dedication to the public service.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (Reuters)The United States today recorded seismic signals that presumably were from a Soviet underground nuclear explosion, the United States Atomic En. ergy Commission said.

The 6foot4inch Riordan, lefthanded shooter, suffered a fracture of a small bone in his left wrist yesterday when he fell during a practice scrimmage at Pace College.

title: WATTS IS PIANIST WITH LONDONERS

Both Mr. Watts and Mr. Loinsdoll made smoothness, legato phrasing and elegance their overriding aims In the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 in B flat, thereby frustrating anyone for whom the B flat Brahms is the epitome of nobility and struggle in German music.

title: ROBERT N. STEVENS

Other rich countries have decided to act in similar fashion.

description: LONDON, Oct. 22 Is business boom getting under way in Britain?

description: To the Editor: Your description of the qualifications of Judge Mildred Loree Lillie [biographical sketches of Supreme Court nominees Oct. 14] illustrates perfectly the absurd sexist prejudices to which all women are persistently subjected. I refer to the last sentence; In her mid50's she still has a bathing beauty figure.

title: U.S. Troops Leave Camodian Border
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 22The last American combat units along the Cambodian border were pulled, out to'day from their fire base, which had been under daily enemy shelling for the last four weeks.

title: Pay Board Chairman George Hugo Boldt
description: When the Seattle Seven conspiracy trial opened in Tacoma, Wash., last November, United States District Judge George H. Boldt made it clear that he would tolerate Yippie departure from normal courtroom decorum so long as the trial itself was not impaired. He kept his promise, allowing the defendants to laugh, make offhand remarks, even register critiques of the courts. But when they generated a melee, he declared a mistrial on the ground that they had prejudiced the jury against them selves, and handed out a halfdozen contempt citations.

title: Jr. Wilson Newman
description: Former chief executive of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc., the credit reporting concern... Still active as the chairman of its finance committee... 61 yars old.... Earned a degree in law from New York University....Director and trustee of numerous companies, associations and schools. Director of the National Bureau of Economic Research.... Native of Clemson, S.C.... Bachelor of Science degree from Clemson College. Lives in Short Hills, N.J. Joined Dun & Bradstreet in 1931, became assistant general counsel in 1943, assistant to the president in 1944, vice president in 1946 and the president in 1952.

title: A. G. Vanderbilt a Friend indeed to a Working Girl

Graham, for many years editor of the house organ of the Equitable Life Assurance Society and the man chiefly responsible for the revival of interest in Frank Merriwill novels, died, apparently of a heart attack, while visiting friends in Forest Hills, Queens, on Thursday. He was 60 years old and his home was at 509 Old Mill Road, Spring Lake Heights, N. J.

description: LONDON, Oct. 22It is easy to use Harold Wilson as an argument for the cynical view of politics. Few politicians have switched principles so unconvincingly as the leader of the British Labor party.

Became an American citizen in 1937. Served on President Eisenhower's Council of Economic Advisers from 1953 to 1955... Was dean of the School of Business Administration at U.C.L.A. and vice president of the University of Chicago... Associates describe him as a studious man and excellent organizer... Lapp called today for a tax on utility revenues to finance intensified research and development that he said is necessary to meet an energy crisis, by the year 2000. Dr. Lapp, physicist, made his proposal in remarks for a seminar of the South Carolina Press Association, Clemson, S.C.

title: Leonard F. Woodcock Labor
description: President, of the United Automobile Workers... 60 years old ... Wellspoken but with a quick temper.. If they want war, they can have war, was his threat to Nixon Administration when wage freeze was announced. Has been as critical of inflation as any businessman Boasted that his contract with General Motors would fight inflation... Took over U.A.W. when Walter P. Reuther died in a plane crash May 9, 1970... Born in Providence, R. I.... Lived in Germany and England as a child.... Returned to the United States in 1926.
