description: ROME, Oct. 23Jozsef Cardi nal Mindszenty the Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary and spiritual leader of that country's seven million Catho lics left tonight for Vienna, where he is expected to settle.

title: Strategy of Victorious Trojans Geared to Garrison, Long Pass
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 23 While Edesel Garrison tried to tell anyone who would listen that nobody could cover him oneonone, John McKay puffed a victory cigar today and ex plained his success formula against Notre Dame.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23There are three really important questions in the China debate at the United Na tions, all of which are in danger of being lost in a torrent of Secondary arguments, parliamentary maneuvers and bilateral political pressures.

title: New Role for Beverly Sills: Not as Prima Donna but as Mother
description: To her mother, she is still Bello Silver man from Brooklyn. To her husband she is Bubbly, to her friends she is Bub bles and to her fans she is Beverly Sills, America's most famous opera singer, a prima donna at the pinnacle of a spectacular career.

title: Peter Graham Harnden Dead; Architect and Designer Was 58
description: Peter Graham Harnden, an American architect and design er, died at his home in Cada 4ques, Spain, on Oct. 15 after a long Illness. He was 58 years old.

title: Negro Schools Receive $1.6Million U.S. Grant
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has awarded grants totaling $1.6 million to 22 predominantly black colleges and universities to improve their social service educational programs.

title: Fleecing the Lambs By Christopher Elias. 246 pp. Chicago: Henry Regnery Company. $6.95. Wall Street Security Risk. By Hurd Baruch. 356 pp. Washington: Acropolis Books. $8.95. The Funny Money Game The Inside Story of a Memorable Business Debacle. By Andrew Tobias. 219 Chicago: Playboy Press. $6.95.
description: The New York Stock Exchange, for the past 180 years, has occupied a unique place in our economy. Though priding itself as the keystone of American capitalism, it has always been a monopolistic fiefdom with the powervirtually free of government interferencesto fix prices, restrict entry, make its own rules and deter mine what sort of market millions of investors will have for trading securities. The theory has been that the Exchange's members could some how pursue their private interests while regulating themselves in the public interest.

title: Music; Reich? Philharmonic? Paradiddling?
description: THE odds must have been fairly long against Steve Reich's name ever appearing on a New York Phil harmonic program, but there it is, thanks to Pierre Boulez's choice of Reich's Phase Patterns for next Friday night's Prospective Encounter concert at the Public Theater. Reich is, after all, hardly the type., He began running away from the Western music tradi tion shortly after he learned to walk, creatively speaking, and hasn't stopped. He writes pieces for such bizarre, unsymphonic ensembles as four electronic organs and maracas (Four Organs), or two slightly unsynchro nized tape recorders that do nothing but repeat the same foursyllable threenote phrase (It's Gonna Rain).

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: In the hit movie, The Graduate, one of the most memorable moments is when Dustin, Hoffman is called aside by an older man after graduating from college and told the one word that would open up new vistas of fame and fortune for him: plastics.

title: U.S. RIDERS WIN AT HORSE SHOW
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23Neal Shapiro played the part of Frank Merriwell and saved the United States Equestrian Team tonight at the windup of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

title: ACES BUILD LEAD IN BRIDGE MATCH
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23The world bridge champions, quintet of young men from Dallas, seemed well on the road to representing the United States for the third straight year when play resumed here this afternoon in the interna tional team final playoff match.

title: Et A1.
description: More about the Astor clan and the glittering world of late 19thcentury Society. The Astor Orphans (a phrase which serves as the subtitle of this book) were the grandchildren of Sam Ward (about whom Mr. Thomas wrote a separate book) eight Chanter brothers and sisters, who in 1876 inherited from their mother five million dollars and the family estate on the Hudson. Their other names were Winthrop, Stuyve sant, Livingston, Beckman, Armstrong and White; among them were a soldier, artist, novelist and politician. For de votees of in claim vita Amer ican style.

title: Reforms Are Urged To Halt Sharp Rise In Children's Crime
description: Alarming increases in crimes by children, including the growth of miniextortion rings in schools, indicate a need for major reforms in the nation's system of juvenile jus tice, according to Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: SHANKER ELECTED BY TEACHER GROUP
description: KIAIVIESHA LAKE, N. Y., Oct. 23Albert Shanker was elected president of the newly formed United Teachers of New York today and immedi ately announced a campaign to unionize all 300,000 teach ers in the state, including those serving in private schools and colleges and universities.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Duck Dance, $4, Scores By 3 Lengths in Vosburgh
Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: AFTER THE COUNTERCULTURE
description: To THE EDITOR: David French's beautiful and articulate article, After the FallWhat This Country Needs Is a Good Counter Counterculture Culture (Oct. 3), was truly enlightening. With great insight born out of an experience which know has been common to many counterand excoun terculturists, he has focused on what has gone awry: the counterculture has, by and large, substituted form for substance (Community has become the television of the counterculture..).

title: Ulrich ColsmanFreyberger Weds Susan B. Painter
description: NORFOLK, Conn., Oct. 23 Miss Susan Brown Painter, daughter of Mrs. T. Culbert son Clark 2d of Farmington and Norfolk and Charles A. Painter 3d of Laguna Beach, Calif., was married here this afternoon to Ulrich Colgman Freyberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl ColsmanFrey berger of Bonn, Germany.

title: Dara Robertson to Wed
description: WOODMERE, L. I., Oct. 23 A Dec. 23 wedding in Los Angeles is planned by Miss Dara Mae Robertson and. Dr. Frank Lloyd Annis, a psychi atrist.

title: A Critic Likes the Opera, Loathes the Production
description: THE title page of the program for Jesus Christ Superstar at the Mark Hellinger stresses that Tom O'Horgan has not only directed the production but has conceived it. It Is not an immaculate conception.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE LOCKED IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Amid cries of blackmail and rubberstamp, the House and senate have become locked in a jurisdictional battle over which body shall determine what amendments are ger mane.

title: Unity Urged for All Of Spanish Origin
Two Amendments on Ballot Neglected
description: The long controversy over the proposed $2.5billion state transportation bond issue and its effect on the 30cent transit fare here has obscured for many voters the fact that they will also be asked to vote on Nov. 2 on two amendments to the State Constitution.

title: Poetics, Not Politics'A day in class with Prof. Eugene McCarthy
description: THROUGHOUT the 1968 Presi dential campaign, students flocked to the support of Sen ator Eugene McCarthy; as a mark of their gungho enthusiasm, they even cut their hair and donned ties and shirts in an effort to be clean for Gene. Now their hair has gone to seed, they are wearing patchon patch dungarees, but they are once again on the scene with Gene. At the University of Maryland's sprawl ing campus at College Park, English 479 is currently being taught by McCarthy and Freedman and English 243 by McCarthy, Harding and Gold.

title: Sketch by an Art Student Leads To Arrest of Sex Case Suspect
description: A sketch drawn by a 17yearold art student of the face of a man who sexually as saulted her on a rooftop two years ago led yesterday to the arrest of a 27yearold Bronx bartender on charges of molest ing the student and two other teenaged girls this fall.

title: Artificial Kidney Use Poses Awesome Questions
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 23  Ernie Crowfeather a bright charm ing part American Indian with a history of personal in stability and brushes with the law died recently at the age of 29 after he refused further lifesupporting therapy.

title: Bill on Food Labeling
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) All foods would be labeled as to their vitamin, fat, calorie and protein value under a bill in troduced by Senator Richard Schweiker, Republican of Penn sylvania.

title: South Africa Voices Fears that Peking Is Being Admitted to the Councils of Its Enemies on the Continent
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct 20  The prospect of United Nations membership for Com munist China is causing a realignment among black Afri ican states and liberation move inents, Western diplomats here Say.

title: Louis XV Table Is Sold for $410,000
description: A little Louis XV table, for which six bidders fought at the ParkeBernet Galleries, was bought yesterday by Jack Linsky, a New York collector, for $410,000the second highest price ever paid for a piece of furniture. Claude Sere, a French Gov ernment expert on native furniture, bid for the table and later took it in a taxi to Mr. Linsky's home at 927 Fifth Avenue.

title: Senate Unit's Curbs Could Block Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23President Nixon's plan for sweeping reforms in the foreign aid program would be dealt a heavy blow by a littlenoticed provision in the $3.2billion authorization measure ap proved this week by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Reader's Report
description: This is a roundbyround ac count of a Congressional pri mary in upstate New York, seen through the jaded eyes of the candidate's campaign manager. Actually, the election has been programed in smokefilled rooms. Candidate A, a bright young millionaire looking for his first hurrah, is a stalking horse to outmaneuver candidate B so candidate C can win. Po litical scripts, of course, have a way of becoming unstuck, and this one is no exception.

title: Soviet Motives Assessed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Senior United States specialists here say that India and the So viet Union are quietly collabo rating to promote the political separation of East Pakistan from the central Pakistani Gov ernment and its independence under Indian protection.They report that Moscow is currently cautioning India not to recognize  prematurely the state proclaimed by the East Pakistan separatist move ment known as Bangla Desh, lest this lead to an armed clash with the Pakistani Government of President Yahya.

title: Jane Tuckerman Married to Henry E. Foley Jr.
description: SOUTH WESTPORT, Mass., Oct. 23Miss Jane Bayard Tuckerman, whose ancestors include John Alden, Miles Standish and William Brad ford of the Plymouth Colony, was married here this noon to Henry Elliott Foley Jr.

title: About That Lady Who Want to Marry The pope, and Other Innocents Abroad
description: SHE is in her 40's, and her passport picture shows her to be rather plain. But hers is a face that has launched a dozen panics among the Swiss Guards at the Vatican, where at least once a year she can be ex pected to present herself to seek the Pope's hand in marriage.

title: Morton Levya Have Son
description: REDDING, Conn., Oct. 23 A son was born on Sept. 19 in the Mount Sinai Hospi tal in New York to Mr. and Mrs. Morton P. Levy of Greentree, Redding., and New York. The child has been named Jonathan Brett.

title: Et A1.
description: The New Social Darwinism, according to Ivor Catt, is the hireandfire syndrome domi nating such sophisticated in dustries as electronics and aero space. The object: keep the help coming and going; we'll all feel better and look better. So prevalent is the practice in the U.S. that Catt (a British elec tronics man who has worked here) claims he can identify strategems to avoid being fired most add up to a kind of counterefficiency. After his U.S. stint, Catt returned to England, where he has a cottage in the country and can start planting apple trees for his grandchildren. Mr. Catt has point here, but not the wit of a Parkinson or Galbraith.

title: Financial Printing
description: One late afternoon last year a Wall Street law firm gave Ad Press, Ltd., a rush order to print the 149page basic agreement whereby Honeywell, Inc., would pur chase the computer opera tions of the General Electric Company.

title: WALL STREET
description: Harding L. Lawrence, chair man and chief executive of ficer of Braniff Airways, Inc., is one airline executive who believes the solution to his industry's troubles is largely in its own hands.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: The threatened closing on Jan. 1 of the Theater and Music Collections of the New York Public Library, because of a lack of funds, would of course be a cultural disaster. I am certain continuance could be assured by setting aside one week for fund raising in the theaters and concert halls, passing bas kets among the audience as does Actors Equity for the annual Actors Fund collec tion.

title: The king's fabric
description: The term corduroy stems from the French corde du roi, or king's cord. And this season the alwaysfavored fabric is in deed getting the royal treatment. No longer considered only a rugged outdoor ally, corduroy has acquired sophistication and elegance since the time it was the whooshsounding de rigueur cloth for schoolboys knickers. Today it appearsin fineribbed, wideribbed, sculptured, printed and velvetlike versionsin clothing which is definitely Now. Vive corduroy!

title: Chez Simenon EPALINGES, Switzerland.
description: It was a Monday in May. A fine rain had been falling since morning. It felt gentle against one's face and hands.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: I agree with your article Let the Specialist Compete (Oct. 3). I believe that com petition among market makers will provide for greater continuity and depth of markets.

title: Law
description: In the wake of the Attica prison revolt, a new phrase has entered the public consciousness: the max max prison. It surfaced in the de mands of 8,000 unionized New York prison guards, and gained prominence with the recent announcement by both Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and State Correctional Chief Russell Os wald that a maximummaximum pris on would be established in the state. It would hold 500 to 600 incorrigi bles, the hardened and dangerous offenders. Maxmax was presented as an idea whose time had come.

title: DIVORCE OPPONENTS CAMPAIGN IN ITALY
description: ROME, Oct. 23Leaders of last year's successful drive for divorce in Italy are being forced to take up arms again to de fend their victory against an organized campaign by right wing Catholics.

title: Shades of Cousteau, James Bond and Jules Verne
description: In Jules Verne's most futuris tic fantasy, his locale might have been the clear waters of the Bahamas, his vehicles a range of sleek and glistening submersibles, from torpedo shaped scooters and octagonal robots, to a ninefoot sea sled that steers with a joy stick and purrs along at 3 knots, 300 feet down.

title: Rustic Utopia, doomed in advance
description: Old Man Rittera 77yearold Vermonter, leathery, hard nosed, crotchetyhas a reputa tion for eccentricity even among his fellow eccentrics. He also has apple orchards and a de caying farmhouse, untenanted. Enter Josh, a Vietnam veteran with long hair, painful memo ries and a dream of starting a commune. The two men meet and touch across the genera tions. You a hippie? Ritter asks. There aren't any hip pies anymore, Josh replies. Gears mesh, the relentless mills start to grind, and we're off on another inspection of the mori bund American dreams of agrarianism, Utopian socialism and the life.

title: The World
description: The United States and Com munist China last week joined in mystifying the world. While American representatives and Peking's allies did battle in the United Nations, White House ad viser Henry Kissinger and Premi er Chou Enlai talked over the teacups in China's capital about plans for President Nixon's visit.

title: U.S. Court Orders Dockers to Reopen New Orleans Port
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 23 (UPI)Federal District Judge Jack M. Gordon today signed an order at the request of the Na tional Labor Relations Board that could bring at least a tem porary end to the New Orleans dock strike.

title: Look Bwana, in East Africa you carry a bicycle on the bus, eat crocodile tail and get to know the people who married the wind
description: FOR a black Guyanese like myself, or for that matter any Westerner black or whitevisiting East Africa, it is a case of leaving a country in which, to use Haw thorne's words, there is no shad ow, no antiquity, no mystery and ar riving on a continent where shadows and mysteries first secreted themselves inside the human spirit.

title: FRANKLIN INSTITUTE CITES 9 SCIENTISTS
description: Nine scientists were honored by the Franklin Institute in Philadelphia Wednesday night. Announced as winners of medal awards Were:

title: 10Mile Chase Through 2 Boroughs Ends in Arrest of Alleged HitRun Driver
description: The police engaged in a 10 mile automobile chase yester day through Queens and Brook lyn, interspersed with gunshots, before apprehending an alleged hitandrun driver.

title: Montclair Harriers Score
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 23Un beaten Montclair State College captured its first New Jersey State College Conference cross country championship since 1966 at Hudson County Park today, defeating Jersey City State, 1750. The Indians also defeated City College of New York, 1743, and increased their twoseason victory streak to 18.

title: Mailbox:
description: To the Editor:

title: Books:
description: indigestion. It cannot digest all the advanced scientific equipment available. Nor, ap parently, can the business executives charged with su pervising a company's com puter activities.

title: Et A1.
description: The author, beginning as a skeptic, took a look at people who play the market by hunch or astrology or tarot. Some are feelers, who go by intuition; some formulators, who use a system based on an occult sci ence. Both get rich. Or so the man says.

title: News of the Rialto
description: PEOPLE who loved and fought for it are likely feel a sense of vindicationnot surprisethis morning with the news that Lorraine Hansberry's The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window is to be born again on Broadway. Born again in Its shape as play but with one element addedit will have original songs by Gary Friedman, composer of the score for The Me Nobody Knows, with Ray Errol Fox assigned to do the lyrics. Be careful though, all involved warn, that it not be thought of as a musical. The songs are not going to be sung by the characters in the play. They will be rendered by four singers providing a kind of Greek choral comment to aspects of the play. We also hope that songs will help advance the action, says Friedman, who is promising music with a contemporary feeling though the time of the play, the midsixties, remains untouched. It's a sort of lyrical musical hindsight thing, a contempo rary comment, Friedman adds.

title: MERCHANTS GET BRIBE WARNING
description: Police commanders In parts of Manhattan are giving busi nessmen in their precincts let ters asserting that policemen are being paid salaries com mensurate with their duties and should not be offered bribes or gratuities.

title: Labradors Sweep Retriever Laurels In ThreeDay Test At the Long Island Retriever Field Trials It Was All Shoot, Chase and Swim, Recover and Back to Your Master on Shore
description: Few sports events are more demanding than retriever trials. The dogs are sent through water and land tests, where they are judged for their natural abilitiesintelli gence, attention, nose, cour age, perseverance styleand for skills acquired through trainingsteadiness, control, response to direction and delivery. The dogs are ex pected to re trieve any type of game under all conditions.

title: The Service Econmy
description: Most of the major nations of the West will have shifted from a predominantly indus trial to a predominantly serv ice economy by the end of the present decade, accord ing to Constance Sorrentino, an economist of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Badillo Move Decried
description: Gumersindo Martinez, a member of the city's Board of Elec tions, charged yesterday that, Representative Dadillo was damaging the pond causes of unity among the SnanHispeatz ing citizens by sponsoring the conference in Washington, which he saki left out ctitzens of Central and South American and Carihbran background.

title: RevenueSharing Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) Senator Claiborne Pell Demo crat of Rhode Island, announced today that he would start hear ings Wednesday on the Admin istration's revenuesharing pro posals for education. Senator Pell, who is chairman of the Labor and Public Welfare Com mittee's education subcommit tee, said that Elliot L. Rich ardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, would be the first witness.

title: Lutz, Orantes in Final
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct, 23 (UPI)Bob Lutz of Los An geles and Manuel Orantes of Spain gained the final of the Spanish open tennis tourna ment today.

title: That wonderful emperor who gave you Pearl Harbor
description: H. A. L. Fisher once opened his memorable history of Europe with the affirmation that history was one emergency after another. Selected readings in recent years might sug gest that AmericanAsian relations have been one damn conspiracy after another. The Pentagon Papers evoked Lyndon Johnson's conspiracy to wage war against North Vietnam; McCar thyism conjured up a conspiracy of proCommunist intellectuals and State Department officials losing China to the Chinese and/or Soviet Com munists; Pearl Harbor inspired a Roosevelt conspiracy to maneuver the nation into the European war through the backdoor of conflict with Japan; and Pearl Harbor also demonstrated a Japanese conspiracy to conquer Asia and dictate peace from the White House. With the publication of David Bergamini's Japan's Imperial Conspiracy, the history of modern Japan and the origins of the Pacific war have now been reduced to one grand conspiracy of the Japanese emperoro.

title: Deep Freeze: Try It Again
description: SOMEONE goofed! At least 30,000 covers the Navy's own estimate destined for cancella tion in Antarctica in the year ly Operation Deep Freeze program were canceled at San Francisco, and not at McMurdo or South Pole Sta tions. Now the U.S. Naval Support Force, Antarctica, is making amends. Originally, the deadline for the South Pole Deep Freeze cancels was Sept. 1. The deadline has now been revised  to Jan. 1, 1972.

title: City Lawyer Is Acquitted Of Loan Conspiracy Count
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP)A Federal District Court jury to day acquitted Max Block Jr., New York lawyer, of charges of conspiring to arrange $14 million in loans from the pen sion fund of the Journeyman Barbers Union.

title: SEOUL PULLS TROOPS OUT OF UNIVERSITIES
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 23 Army troops withdrew from six universities here today, end ing an eightday occupation of campuses to suppress protests against Government corruption and student military training.

title: NO ON BOND ISSUE IS SEEN UPSTATE
description: BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 21Assemblyman Kenneth S. Leasure, Republican of Broome County, looked at a framed let ter on the wall of his law of fice in nearby Endicott that he said was from old Nelse. The letter thanked the burly lawyer for his support of the state's 1967 transportation bond is sue.

title: Hartford Looking to Extended Freezo
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23  Con necticut state officials, grap pling with huge budget prob lems, are looking forward to extended controls in Phase Two of President Nixon's economic program as a stabilizing factor that may benefit state opera tions in the long run.

title: An economic giant, a political dwarf
description: By accident rather than de sign this book by Alfred Gros ser, the doyen of France's Ger many watchers, author of eight books on Germany, appears at a moment of supreme topicali ty. American publication coin cides with Chancellor Brandt's visit to Russia in the aftermath of the fourpower Berlin agree ment. This visit promises (or threatens, depending on one's point of view) to turn Federal Germany's hitherto low profile in world affairs into a high one.

title: Battlers Against Inflation
description: The upereep of living costs in the first full month President Nixon's freeze provides disturbing new evi dence of the difficulties inherent in the war on inflation. The boards the President has now appointed to carry on the fight against resumption of runaway inflation Phase Two of the stabilization effort will need the fullest cooperation of all Americans.

title: Arms Control in Europe..
description: A quartercentury after World War II, the most power ful armed forces ever massed in peacetime by hostile alliances remain deployed within eyesight of each other in Central Europe. Throughout the year, whenever the NATO or Warsaw Pact armies maneuver behind the 500 mile border from the Baltic to the AlpS, the forces of the other take countermeasures to assure readiness to meet a surprise attack.

title: PAKISTAN OFFERS SEIZED TV FILMS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 23  Television film confis cated from foreign news teams last March by Pakistani Army authorities has been distribu ted by the Pakistani Govern ment for use as propaganda, it has been disclosed.

title: Milton Hebald By Frank Getlein. Illustrated. 156 pp. New York: Viking Press. $12.50.
description: New York being essentially an artistic city (without vio lence there is no art, as Floren tine history reminds us), it is proper that the traveler to New York be greeted at its gates by the most public and massive kind of art available. The sea traveler is met by Bartholdi's Liberty, the airtraveler, if he flies PanAm, by Hebald's Zodiac. It is the fate of the sculptorunless he is quirky like holed Moore and attenuated Gia cometti or tarred and feath ered like Epsteinto be anon ymous to the great public, and this anonymity can prevail even in educated circles. James Joyce's Stephen Dedalus dis cussing Lessing's Laokoon, dismisses sculpture as an in ferior art without knowing much about it, and this may excuse Joyceans who, moved by the Joyce statue in the Zurich graveyard, do not know that Milton Hebald made it. But if literary men, generally speak ing, are devoted to Hebald more than any other living sculptor, it is because he has mediated wonderfully between the world of stone and metal and that of words.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: If family stability plays an im portant role in the wellbeing of our nation, it is hard to envision the Equal Rights amendment just passed by the House of Representatives as a constructive act. The bill seems not to have been discussed adequately or, maturely but rather shouted through under pressure from a relatively small band of zealots. It seems to me that the removal of legal responsibility from a man for supporting a family, giving the family a name and protect ing his daughters from the sort of influences the U.S. Army might have in store for them before marriage is likely to have some effect on the manner in which men relate to their wives and children and vice versa; those traditional ties will be weakened.

title: Agnew, in His Farewell, Hails the Greek Regime
description: ATHENS, Oct. 23  Vice President Agnew left Greece today after expressing unre served support for the Greek Government. Senior diplomats said that his support went far beyond the policy of the Nixon Administration as stated be fore Mr. Agnew's trip.

title: EVERS, ILL IN BED, PUSHES CAMPAIGN
description: JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 23Mayor Charles Evers of Fay ette, the black candidate for Governor, took to his bed with fatigue and a virus infection early this week, and con servative white Mississippians thought that might get him out of their hair.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: CLIVE Barnes's predic tion in his recent ar ticle, Somebody Loves An Albatross, that the City Center's takeover of the Beaumont and Forum Thea ters was in the bag proved to be less than accurate since the City Council's Finance ;Committee laid over the matter in order to give Beau mont supporters sufficient time to raise the funds neces sary to keep the theaters op erational.

title: ME GANDHI CALLS FOR INDIAN UNITY TO MEET DANGER'
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, on the eve of her departure on threeweek foreign tour called on the Indian people tonight to stand united and alert be cause our country is facing danger.

title: GROWTH RATE SLOWS FOR SOVIET INDUSTRY
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23The So viet rate of industrial growth slipped in the last three months while the rate of increase in labor productivity also declined below levels earlier this year, the thirdquarter report on eco nomic performance disclosed today.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Carole R. Neri Plans Marriage To Gregory L. Lembo Dec. 27
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Oct. 23Mr. and Mrs. James M. Nerl of Englewood and Palm Beach, Pia., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carole Rose Neil, to Gregory L. Lembo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Lembo of New York and Spring Lake.

title: Lady Prose
description: To the Editor: Newgate Callendar (a pen name whose coyness is apt to bring your more susceptible readers out in hives) is in need of help. His obsession with what he calls lady prose has now led him into extravagances unsuited to a reputable news paper.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: The world oil industry, which in this decade will be called on to supply as much oil as has been consumed since Colonel Drake drilled the first well in 1859, is seeking new ways to find the necessary capital.

title: Music
description: FINALLY, rock singer Cat Stevens seems established. After five years of continuous flux, of sudden suc cesses and declines, disappearances and recoveries, he has acquired a stable audience, and each of his records outsells the last. In America, one album and sev eral singles have broken through already, and his latest album, The Teaser and the Firecat, is off to the fastest start yet. This afternoon and this evening, he will sing at Philharmonic Hall at the start of his most ambitious American tour to date.

title: Foreign Notes
description: He's nearing the end of his tether. He's done more than his share. That was how the wife of a South Afri can priest, the Rev. Bernard Wrankmore, described her husband's condition last week as a fast he had undertaken to protest the Government's apartheid policies went into its third month.

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: The Tet Offensive
description: On March 31 1968 while sitting at my desk in the White House and facing the shiny eyes of the television cameras, I announced four major decisions. would not accept my party's nomina tion as candidate for another term. was stopping most; of the bombing of North Vietnam in the hope that would lead to peace. I had decided to make the expansion and modernization of South Vietnam's armed forces a goal of even higher priority. Finally, to meet existing needs, I had decided to make a small increase in the size of our own military forces in Vietnam.

title: Bridge
description: REALLY big swings in team playIN totalling more than 1,700 points are usually the result of a heavy penalty, with some unfortunate de clarer doubled and vulnerable.

title: Sports Car Club of America Seeks Club Racing Sponsors
description: It seems like only yester day that the Sports Car Club of America, a nonprofit group organized by amateur racers and other enthusiasts, was debating whether it should recognize profession alism. Since then the club has not only developed a full pro gram of professional racing, but it has also gone beyond pro fessionalism into unabashed com mercialism, com plete with a mar keting department. Now the S.C.C.A. has begun an ambi tious campaign to sell its club racing program, some times mistakenly identified as amateur competition, to sponsors.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: After reading Daniel Fried enberg's schemes for the di rection of the Jewish Mu seum, I can only wonder at the lack of visual resources at his disposal. Whereas it is commendable for him to have taken the effort to map a course, it is a negation of the vital energy and scope of a museum to devote itself sole ly to a historical mission which reads like a scholarly doctorate thesis.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I don't really see that what the artists Robert Brustein writes about in his article are doing is anything so different from, for example, J. L M. Stewart, professor of English at Oxford and biographer of Kip ling, Peacock and Joyce, who is probably better known to most of us as Michael Innes.

title: We Are Killing The Sea  Around  Us
description: SUNNY morning at Matinicus Rock, off the mouth of Penob scot Bay in Maine. The swell rolling in from the Atlantic rises and crashes on the steep incline of the jutting granite; the waves suck back, pale green and foaming, and each ripple along their lines of force is clear and sharply defined. Wherever our boat passes, the water is speckled with the tiny young of marine organ isms; they are no bigger than the point of a pin, and there are thou sands of them in every cubic yard of sea. Dolphins slip by, in herds. Glistening whales rise, take in great drafts of air, and sink beneath the surface to feed on schools of shrimp. Birds are everywhere  terns, gulls, razorbilled auks, puffins, petrels, eider ducks, guillemots, shearwaters, phalaropes. The ocean here is rich with food and motion and life. of sea. Dolphins slip by, in herds. Glistening whales rise, take in great drafts of air, and sink beneath the surface to feed on schools of shrimp. Birds are everywhere  terns, gulls, razorbilled auks, puffins, petrels, eider ducks, guillemots, shearwaters, phalaropes. The ocean here is rich with food and motion and life.

title: Miss Cushing Has Nuptials
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J. Oct. 23  Miss Pamela Hedges Cushing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lee Cushing, was married here this afternoon to Henry Mueller Hulshizer of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Hulshizer of Rumson.

title: London Denies Indictment
description: LONDON  The Ministry of Defense tonight described Mr. Seaman's allegations as a com plete fabrication. A spokesman said: Nothing of this nature has ever been carried out. Cer tainly no people have ever been sent over there with explosives. It is utterly nonsense.

title: CHILE IS AROUSED BY U.S. WARNING
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23The warning by William P. Rogers, the United States Sec retary of State, that all Amer lean aid to Chile would be cut off unless there was prompt compensation for expropriated properties has provided Presi dent Salvador Allende Gossens with a new weapon in his drive to muster wide support for his Marxist Government.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: DANIEL M. FRIEDEN BERG in Can a Jew ish Museum Live by Art Alone? made very clear that the basic problem of the museum is that it should function as a Jewish museum rather than as a museum of art under Jewish auspices. He is to be com mended for the understanding and creativity of his specific recommendations.

title: Soviet Said to Test Satellites That Hunt And Destroy Others
description: LONDON, Oct. 23 (UPI)The Soviet Union has been testing earth satellites that approach and destroy other spacecraft as authoritative publication Jane's All the World's Aircraft said this week.

title: Football's Upset of Century Took Place 50 Years Ago
Miss Oates loves to splash blood on us
description: Like Othello, who wooed Desde mona with his awful tales of the Cannibals that each other eat,/ The Anthropophagi, and men whose heads/ Do grow beneath their shoulders, Joyce Carol Oates has held the admiring attention of a dis tinguished audience with her fic tional museums of the grotesque. Three successful novelsExpensive People, A Garden of Earthly De lights, Them  have wrought mayhem, rape, madness, murdered children, murdering children, worka day murder, what have you. Her most recent before Wonderland collected all these bits and pieces of the Gothic wardrobe, capped them with a contemporary reference to the Detroit riots, and carried away the National Book Award in 1970 She deserved it.

title: Natalie Tolles, David Ketcham Marry in Jersey
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Oct. 23Miss Natalie Carleton ,Tolles and David Ross Ketcham were married here this afternoon in Christ Congregational Church by the Rev. Allan Tinker.

title: Numbered Account Takes Nonbetting, $124 , 520 Selima by 6 Lengths at Laurel
Nixons Drive to Camp David
description: THURMONT, MD. Oct. 23 (AP)The President and Mrs. Nixon were driven to by to their Camp David hideaway near here for the weekend. The Nixons, who expect to return to the White House tomorrow night or Monday morning, made the 71mile auto trip in an hour and 20 minutes.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Ada Louise Huxtable's sal lies against the Kennedy Cen ter take no account whatever of a critical truism: in apprais ing the merits or demerits of any building, its form cannot possibly be separated from the function.

title: In Swahili, it's trouble
description: When I was a schoolchild studying ancient history, it seemed to me that those in sane and bloodthirsty deeds I read about were committed by barbarians, and that, of course, people were much more civilized now. In several hun dred years, if we have not succeeded in destroying this planet, schoolchildren will be studying our times and actions and probably will think the same thing about us. Men are madare mad, were mad, and never seem to learn. Violence goes on.

title: W. AND M.127 VICTOR OVER VA. MILITARY
Memphis Is Calm as Negroes Press for Reforms
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 23Memphis became calmer last night after three straight nights of dis turbances, but many Negro leaders were devising strategy for further political pressure on the city administration to im prove relations with the black community.

title: Edward Bermant Marries Alison R. Kent
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., Oct. 23  Miss Alison Ring Kent and Edward Charles Bermant were married here this evening in Temple Sinai by Rabbis Alvan D. Rubin of Temple Israel in Clayton, Mo., and Norman Kahan of Tem ple Sinai.

title: Witchcraft In Bullet Park
description: When in 1969 John Cheever turned from the lovable Wapshots to the weird creatures who inhabit Bullet Park, most reviewers attacked or dismissed him. They were, it seems to me, dead wrong. The Wapshot books, though well made, were minor. Bullet Park, illusive, mysteriously built, was majorin fact, a magnifi cent work of fiction.

title: Sexual life in the West End of London
description: Yes, but who is Nicholas Mosley? In the end this is a fairly difficult question, but a crude beginning is easy enough: he's upperclass (alias Lord Ravensdale), has a private in come, a notorious father (Sir Os wald), a wife and four children in Hampstead; and his eighth novel is beautifully named, Natalie Natalia.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: I'm surprised John Canaday bothered to fly to Province town to take in a neighbor hood show when he feels something must be wrong with those who go to Prov incetown in the first place, Many people go there because it has good beaches. Some may go to be with other artists. But why not? Would he consider it improper in his case to ever be where there other critics?

title: Television
description: FROM, giggles to goggles to gurgles to girdles, straight on to riddles and wriggles, and back again to giggles. The trip be gins tomorrow on public tel evision's The Electric Com pany, in the first of 130 halfhour programs that the Children's Television Work shop has scheduled for week days over the next 26 weeks.

title: Et A1.
description: A program for the civil serv ice, by the chairman of the Civil Service Commission under J.F.K. and L.B.J. In view of all the public employe strikes, ac cusations of nonresponsiveness in government, the lack of cre ativity, etc., there is a need for a good popular study; and, although Mr. Macy's back ground is full and his sug gestions sound, this remains an administrator's report.

title: So his children will see him plain
description: It's intimidating to review the journal of a man who can write good novel in the time it takes fallible human to turn out a passable book review. Intimidating or not, you don't pass up the chance for a glimpse into a mind that has pro duced so much fiction in 40 years of highpressure productivity.

title: 2 Cholera Dead in Lisbon
description: LISBON, Oct. 23 (AP)Por tugal's health authorities re ported today that two persons had died in a new outbreak of cholera in Lisbon. Five are under care in hospitals here for cholera, officials said. The out break was traced to the city's outlying slums, where condi tions of hygiene are considered far below standard.

title: Mailbox:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Fleischer Trails in Rio Golf
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 23 (AP)Jaime Gonzalez, 17yearold Brazil amateur, took a fourstroke lead over Bruce Fleischer of the United States today after the third round of the Brazilian open golf tourna ment. Gonzalez shot a 2over par 73 for a 54hole total of 206. Fleischer posted a 69 for 210.

title: InjuryRiddled Jets Play Dolphins Here Today;
description: In a game that will affect, the Baltimore Colts as well as themselves in the Eastern Di vision of the American Confer ence, the New York Jets will oppose the Miami Dolphins to day at Shea Stadium. The Dol phins are 10point favorites.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: In the last four years, ac cording to statistics com piled by the International Ladies Garment Workers Un ion, imports of women's and children's wear made of cot ton, wool and manmade fibers increased 92 per cent in dollars and 105 per cent in equivalent square yards of materials needed in produc ing them.

title: CONNECTICUT VOTE FOCUSES ON CITIES
description: HARTFORD, Oct. 23It is the time of year again when politicians go into the streets shaking hands and making speeches, and this time, in 157 of Connecticut's 169 towns and cities, the prize is the Mayor's office.

title: Sanda C. Leach, F. F. Cooper Jr. Marry in Chapel
description: Miss Sande Cannon Leach, whose greatgrandfather, J. W. Cannon, founded Cannon Mills in Kannapolis, N. C., was married hero yesterday afternoon to Fowler Faine Cooper Jr., second vice presi dent of the Federal Compress and Warehouse Company of Memphis, of which his father, the late Mr. Cooper, was ex ecutive vice president.

title: Cathleen E. Moran Sets Nuptials
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., Oct. 23The engagement of Miss Cathleen Elizabeth Moran to Peter R. Vermylen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Anthony Vermylen of Saddle River, N. J., has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Moran of New Canaan. A wedding next summer is planned.

title: British Soldiers in Ulster Kill 5, Including 2 Sisters
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland Oct. 23Two sisters riding in a car were shot dead by British soldiers today.

title: Nancy Donnelly Is Bride
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 23 Miss Nancy Anne Donnelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Donnelly, was mar ried here this noon to Ed ward Joseph Neville, son of Mrs. M. Edward Neville of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Neville. The Rev. Francis Boyle performed the cere mony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is an alumna of the Elizabeth Seton School in Yonkers and Rosemont College. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Mellen, Donnelly and Fogarty. The bridegroom, is a Villanova University graduate.

title: Joan Wexler Bride of Robert Kroll
description: Miss Joan Susan Wexler, associate director of public ity at Simon & Schuster, publishers, was married yes terday to Robert David Kroll, a vice president of the Vick Chemical Company. Rabbi Jacob Reiner performed the ceremony at Congregation Ohab Zedek in Belle Harbor, Queens.

title: The inside story, or some of it, from a Secretary of the Interior; Who Owns America? By Walter J. Hickel. 328 pp. Englewood Cliffs, N. J.: PrenticeHall. $6.95.
description: Looking back on his twoyear ten ure as the Nixon Administration's Secretary of the Interior, which ended with his summary firing, Walter Hickel describes how he was yanked around by the White House and re peatedly made to act against his own best judgment.

title: A shrug to the road ahead
description: A rapid survey of the sixties, competent, inclusive, brightly writtenon the face of things, what could this be but good value?. The historian, a Rutgers professor, bends himself sen sibly at the start to demytholo gizing, praising Ike for talking rot and being resourceful, creaming Camelot for talking chic and being ineffective. He studies L.B.J. in triumph, the beginning of the desperate time in Vietnam, the emergence of the counter culture and the New Left. There's a chapter for the year of disasters, 1968 (Tet, the murders of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, the Chi cago convention), and another in defense of the author's con viction that theend of the dec ade really ended something (Epilogue: The Revolution Is Over). And there are frequent diversions from straight chron ological accounting: summaries of pop culture trends; evoca tions of the early days of the period's heroes and villains (Cesar Chavez, Ralph Nader); profiles of new institutions (Women's Lib, Hell's Angels).

title: Opium, not alcohol, is the demon
description: One property of cannabis (or hashish), certainly as interest ing as any other, is that an ob jective account of its psycho active effects and the conse quences of its prolonged use seems impossible to achieve. Judging by the reports of Bayard Taylor, Fitz Hugh Lud low, Thophile Gautier, and Charles Baudelaire, this was as true in the 19th century as it is today. Among them, Baude laire, though probably not a mythmaker by design, none theless provided more material for our own Harry Anslinger (the former Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Narcot ics) than anyone since Marco Polo with his tale of Hasan of Assassins.

title: Fresh Yankee's Streak Ended at Five as Cathy Lee Wins at Yonkers
Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Headliners
description: Poets believe in miracles and this time it has happened it would seem. This was the reaction of Pablo Neruda, the 67yearold Chilean poet, diplomat and Communist leader, when it was announced last week that he was the winner of the 1971 Nobel Prize for Literature. The citation read: For poetry that, with the action of an elemental force, brings alive a continent's destiny and dreams. Many of Mr. Neruda's poems extol Chile's mountain landscapes and defend the cause of Latin America's exploited Indians. They are clear and lyrical, infused with love and politics. The works range from the gently erotic Twenty Poems of Love to his vast General Song which became accepted as the leading epic of LatinAmerican man. This was Mr. Neruda's second such prize. His first was the Stalin Prize in 1950 for his hymns of praise to the Soviet Union.

title: His analyst knew why he had died
description: Jean Bruller, the French graphic artist, has been writing novels under the name Vercors since the 1940's  when he cofounded the underground press Editions de Minuit and wrote its first publication, The Silence of the Sea, a limpid novelette about an old man and his niece offering passive resis tance to a German officer bil leted with them. This was an immediate success.

title: Reader's Report
description: If Richard Jessup was un kind to ultramilitant youth in his last novel A Quiet Voyage Home, he is doubly mean to their elders in this one. All the bad rumors about America come true, and are laid right at the doorstep of the genera tion now phasing itself out, from moral corruption to police brutality. The present victim of society's evils is an 18yearold youth, emptied of illusions by twoyears combat service in Vietnam. (He lied about his age to enlist.) Terry Foxway comes back from the war a tabula rasa, void of all excess psychological baggage except his pragmatic conditioning for survival. The good old U.S.A. has a fine opportunity to write some nice things into Terry's personality, but everyone plays him false: his girl, his teach ers, his employers, the VIP's who admire his war record. From his parents he learns only an oppressive sense of empti ness. (It was as if they had misplaced their lives.)

title: Reader's Report
description: Burt Hirschfeld, who matric ulated in the erotic novel with such paperback tinder as Cindy on Fire, hits a smoother, more sophisticated stride with Acapulco. There is this writerdirector (tempo rarily a mess, but a nice guy at heart) searching for himself down in Mexico. Then there is this film producer doing a quickie called Love, Love. The producer is also a messbut at heart he's really a rotten guy.

title: The World
description: NEW DELHIWill they or won't they? The question pre occupies foreign diplomats here as they try to guess whether India and Pakistan are going to go to war again. The betting changes by the day. A week ago the odds were for war. This week end they were down to 5050.

title: News of the Camera World
description: NEW movie projector that accepts both Super 8 and standard 8mm movie film has recent ly been introduced by Agfa Gevaert, Inc. of Teterboro, N. S. In addition to its abili ty to change quickly from one type of film to another (the user need merely flick a small lever) this new mod el features automatic film threading and an automatic rapid rewind.

title: Travel Notes: AutoTrain to Florida Is Booked Solid Through New Year's
description: MOTORISTS contem plating use of the Auto Train between Lorton, Va. (about 20 miles south of Washington) and Sanford, Fla. (about 30 miles southwest of Daytona Beach) had best make reser vations in a hurry. According to a spokesman for the Auto Train Corporation, the serv ice, which begins Dec. 6, is al ready solidly booked through New Year's. The official was guarded about the number of reservations that have been made so far, but he was em phatic in saying that people who haven't already reserved space will have to find some other way to get to Florida this year. In fact, he added, some reservations have been received for as far in advance as 1973.

title: Antiwar Activities for Veterans Day Are Outlined in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 Members of the peace move ment outlined plans today for Veterans Day antiwar activities on Monday.

title: HEARINGS ENDED FOR ANGELA DAVIS
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Oct. 23 After 10 months of argu ments, pretrials hearings in volving Angela Davis have ended, and neither the defense not the prosecution is entirely satisfied.

title: Youth Rebellion of Sixties Waning
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Oct. 23  The great youth trip that heady, sometimes breathtaking sometimes frightening, roller coaster ride that careened through the late years of the nineteen sixties and plunged headlong into this decade is slowing down and may be al most over.

title: Miss Lynne M. Steinsieck Is Married
description: MERIDEN, N. H., Oct. 23Miss Lynne Marie Steinsieck was married here at dawn today to Joseph Pulitzer 4th, a greatgrandson of Joseph Pulitzer, who founded The St. Louis PostDispatch, owned The World in New York and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes.

title: Adelphi Bows to Cortland; Officials Gain 254 Yards
description: CORTLAND, N.Y., Oct. 23In a game marked by 254 yards in penalties on 26 infractions, Cortland State evened its won lost record at 3 and 3 by down ing Adelphi University, 238, today.

title: VOTERS LISTLESS, SWISS WOMEN SAY
description: GENEVA, Oct. 23  Switzer land's women politicians, who will make their first bid for Federal office In the parliamen tary election on Oct. 31, have found it hard to get voters to recognize their names.

title: TV Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: CERTAIN brand of fool hardiness, I realize, is required to venture a critique of a critic on his own hearth, to sally forth where many angels, theatrical or televisionary, fear to tread. But because the recent show on Channel 13 concerned with the alleged doubledeal ing of the F.B.I. had such large implications for Public Television and because John J. O'Connor, inadvertently am sure, did not seem to be fully aware of those implica tions, I felt this urge to say my say.

title: ...Toward Detente at Sea
description: The spirit of dtente has been modestly advanced by the tentative understanding reached by American and Soviet naval negotiators in Moscow last week on measures to prevent collisions and other incidents at sea.

title: UKRAINIAN PRELATE CRITICAL OF VATICAN
description: ROME, Oct. 23 (UPI)Joseph Cardinal Slipyj accused the Vatican today of preventing him from speaking out against the most grave persecution by the Soviets of 6 million Ro man Catholics in the Ukraine.

title: A Priest Says, It Doesn't Have a Soul
description: CAN Jesus survive Jesus Christ Superstar"? Sometimes it is Love Story in Jerusalem. Other times it is only The Greening of the Box Office. (Oh, wow.) But is it a seri ous work of art? And how does it deal with the Passion of Christ? Since this show is built on the Rock, we had best look under it.

title: Amtrak Plea Is Na Surprise
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Key Congression al figures are disappointed but not greatly sur prised by Amtrak's request for a $170million operating subsidy for the next two years.

title: Syracuse Amasses Most Points Since 1959 in Trouncing Holy Cross, 6321
Saigon Students Set Fire To 6 Markets and 2 Vehicles
description: SAIGON, South Vietnain Oct. 23 (UPI)Militant anti Government students, angered that market vendors refused to honor their call for a general strike today attempted to burn six food markets in Saigon.

title: Music
description: THERE already is a bit of a fuss about Jesus Christ Superstar, what with religious groups up in arms, some hailing the libretto as a new look at Je sus and the New Testament, others crying blasphemy and heresy. It was only a short time ago that Leonard Bern stein, in his Mass, took a look at religion, and that too caused much talk, though no bOdy in Washington picketed the Kennedy Center. Bern stein's view took in all reli gion, and it was his thesis that organized religion has failed. Jesus Christ Super star is more doctrinaire. It tells the story of Jesus large ly from Judas's point of view, and is full of relevancies that relate to our own day.

title: Lydia Thompson Fiancee of Charles Whitehead 2d
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 23Miss Lydia Merwin Thompson and Charles Eduardo Whitehead 2d plan to be married Dec. 18 in the chapel of the Lawrence ville School. The future bride groom and his father, E. Har lan Whitehead of Lawrence ville, N. J., are graduates of Lawrenceville and Princeton University.

title: AURELIO ATTACKS CHOICE FOR PANEL
description: Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio yesterday attacked the appointment of Edward N. Cos tikyan to head a task force for the state commission investi gating City Hall.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23  The women's liberation people, who are right about so many things, are headed in the wrong direction in their campaign to abolish Miss and Mrs. and substitute Ms as the universal title of address for women, both married and single.

title: Appeal by Soviet Group
description: LONDON, Oct. 23The Soviet Human Rights Committee has ap pealed to the World Psychiatric Association to place on the agen da of its congress in Mexico City next month the use of psychia try against political dissidents.

title: Ann Feeble Robinson Is Wed To. Justin Jason Stevenson 3d
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23Miss Ann Keeble Robinson was married here this after noon to Justin Jason Steven son 3d, a lawyer with Shear, man & Sterling in New York.

title: A visit to Peking UniversityWhat the Cultural Revolution Was All About
description: MOST earlyrising Chinese were already well into a typically hot July Peking day. On the shady, spacious campus of Peking University, a distinguished theoretical physicist, Chou Peiyuan, vice chair man of the Peking University rev olutionary committee, introduced roomful of Chinese to a visiting group of Canadian academics and professionals. Among the people here to welcome you are members of the People's Liberation Army; rep resentatives from the leading group in our newly formed party commit tee; workers from our drug factory, run for the university by the chemis try department; several Red Guards; some other studentsand, of course, several of our professors. Today we will tell you exactly what happened here between 1966 and 1971why it was necessary to shut down China's greatest university for three of We to tell you about the great revolution in education that is going on before your eyes. You will be able to see this yourselves, in visits to several classrooms, universityoperated fac tories, dormitories and libraries. After you have seen all this we will return here, to have a frank discussion about what you have seen and heard today. We will try to answer your questions as best we can. We are striving to follow Chairman Mao's instruction, Seek the truth from the facts We hope that you too will do this, and that you will help us to overcome our shortcom ings in this spirit of constructive criticism. tell you about the great revolution in education that is going on before your eyes. You will be able to see this yourselves, in visits to several classrooms, universityoperated fac tories, dormitories and libraries. After you have seen all this we will return here, to have a frank discussion about what you have seen and heard today. We will try to answer your questions as best we can. We are striving to follow Chairman Mao's instruction, Seek the truth from the facts We hope that you too will do this, and that you will help us to overcome our shortcom ings in this spirit of constructive criticism.

title: PHONE BOOK OUT IN SPANISH HERE
description: More than 200,000 copies of a Spanishlanguage telephone directory for New York City, carrying Spanish commercial and residential listings almost exclusively, are being distrib uted this week to the city's Spanishspeaking phone sub scribers.

title: Aaron Posts 68 and Cuts Casper's Lead in Kaiser Golf toTwo Shots
BOSTON CAMPAIGN USES COMPUTERS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 23Computer campaigning has been intro duced into Mayor Kevin H. White's reelection drive here and the result seems to have confused his opponent, Repre sentative Louise Day Hicks.

title: Sanitizing the Sweepstakes
description: The Reader's Digest ex pects to distribute $1,069,925 in sweepstakes awards to po tential subscribers this year or virtually as much as it did in 1970.

title: The Nation
description: Soon after Arthur K. Watson, son of the founder of Interna tional Business Machines, was appointed Ambassador to France last year, he went on a disturb ing tour with agents of the Fed eral Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs.

title: Cahill Vows Vengeance
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 23Joe Cahill, chief of the I.R.A. in Belfast, vowed vengeance today for what he described as the mur der of two women killed in Belfast by British troops,

title: HISTORIC DISTRICT IS A HARLEM ISSUE
description: Plans of the State Narcotic Control Commission to demol ish several brownstones to ex pand rehabilitation facilities along Harlem's Mount Morris Park North have brought pro tests from some community people who cite the proposed designation of the area as historic district as a reason for not tampering with the buildings.

title: U.S. Business ROUNDUP
description: HONOLULU  Hawaii, which is attracting increas ing numbers of vacationing Orientals as well as Amer ican mainlanders, would like to convince more travelers from both parts of the world to put their visits on a busi nesslike basis.

title: Williams Routs Tufts, 336, As D'Arata Gets 4 Scores
F.D.A. Warns Against Burns From Halloween Costumes
description: WASHIINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) Noting that flammable cloth ing accounts for 150,000 burns and 3,000 deaths a year, the Food and Drug Administration urged parents today to make sure their children's Halloween costumes were made of flame retardant materials.

title: Victorian valentine
description: Only the experienced eye of a designer could have seen the possibilities of this tenantfarmer cottage in Connecticut when it came up for sale. The 30by30foot cottage had been built in the Depression years on Depression budget. But designer John Maurer recognized the rarity of its rolling hillside setting and welcomed the challenge. The house was so small, he says, that there was nothing to do but approach the design tongue incheek. So, Maurer gave his cottage a Hansel and Gretel playfulness. He brightened the rooms with chintzes and prints, painted the floors bright colors and used an army of decorative devices. The approach was successful: Friends call the house a Victorian valentine.

title: Blood Refusal and Death
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 23 (UPI) A woman who refused to ac cept blood transfusions follow ing childbirth three weeks ago because of religious beliefs died today at Lakewood Hospital. Mrs. Jeffrey J. Neumann, member of Jehovah's witnesses, was supported by members of her family in her refusal to ac cept blood or blood derivatives. The sect believes it is against God's law to accept blood.

title: Medicine
description: To be beloved of a goddess is not always a fate to be desired. Tithonus, in Greek mythology, was sought after by Aurora, goddess of the Dawn, who per suaded Jupiter to make him im mortal. However, she neglected to specify that he should also remain young. Tithonus became gray. His limbs weakened until he could no longer move and the goddess shut him into his room, from which his feeble cries could be heard. Finally, tiring of this, she turned him into a grass hopper.

title: New Mexico Drivers Scored
description: ALBUQUEQUE, N. M., Oct. 23 (UPI)This city's Traffic Safety Coordinator, Tom Slaybaugh, says New Mexico drivers have the worst record in the nation. He said Thursday that the death rate per 10,000 registered ve hicles in the state is 8.7, com pared with the national average of 4.9. The death rate per 100, 000 miles traveled is 7.6 in New Mexico, he said compared with the national figure of 4.0.

title: How Chile Lives With Inflation: Sueldo Vital
description: In Chile, where inflation has averaged more than 25 per cent a year for more than 30 years, a number of inter esting expedienta have been adopted.

title: POSTEL ACCUSES A MAYORAL AIDE
description: Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday named Jerome M. Becker as the city official he said earlier had offered him a job as the city's Housing and Development Administrator in exchange for calling off his inquiry into the Municipal Loan Program scandal.

title: Television
description: THE eyes have it, all rightclear, blue, hon est. Along with that firm, open face, lightly seamed by time and, surely, good clean wind and rain, they help make Arthur Hill seem the epitome of... well, whatever's decent and right and true. The combination also made Hill the perfect choice for the role of Owen Marshall, Counselor at Law, ABC's lightly disguised at tempt to capitalize on the huge success of its resident physician, Marcus Welby, by moving him into a courtroom and changing his name, if lit tle else. Presumably, viewers who care about tonsils can also be made to care about torts in sufficient numbers to give ABC two big winners in the ratings game and a clear shot at the world of dentis try next season.

title: The Record Of Cities
description: To the Editor: Your recent issue, which pre sented diametrically opposite points of view on facing pages, was  in my opinion  in the best tradition of literary period icals. I refer to the reviews of Anthony Bailey's In the Vil lage, and The Immigrant Ex perience. The Anguish of Be coming American, edited by Thomas C. Wheeler.

title: New York Tech Wins
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 23New York Tech's unde feated club football team ran its streak to five by beating Concordia, 2120, today Bob LeVine threw two touchdown passes and scored the clincher on a 1yard run in the third period. Joe Pinto kicked all three conversions.

title: To Missilenien, Immense Power Is Routine
description: MINOT, N. D.Capt. Willis Funn of Powhatan, Va., works 60 feet underground in Launch Control Center of the Strategic Air Command. He controls 10 Minuteman3 mis siles. These have a range of 8,000 miles and are armed with three warheads of 200 kilotons each.

title: From the First 18 Years of My Life
description: THE three stories of mine that Larry Arrick has chos en to adapt and direct for the stageand that, taken together, he titles Unlikely Heroes"are among the first I ever wrote and published. As result, I am no longer on intimate, or even friendly, terms with them. This isn't to say that I find the stories without merit, or that, from the heights of my Professionalism, am about to dismiss them out of hand as juvenilia. For one thing, there are no such heights, or so it has seemed to meonly new stages in the writer's perennial appren ticeship. Each new project makes one into a beginner again, though unquestionably a different sort of beginner in the seventies than in the fifties. My point is this 14 years And five books of fiction have come and gone since these stories were everything to me, and I would be mawkish, deluded parent it I were to feel toward them in their awkward adolescence as I did in their darling infancy.

title: D. H. Lawrence And Edward Carpenter A Study in Edwardian Transition. By Emile Delavenay. Illustrated. 288 pp. New York: Taplinger Publishing Company. $15.
description: Emile Delavenay is the lead ing French interpreter of Law rence. His monumental explora tion of Lawrence's early life and literary career, D. H. Law rence: L'Homme et la Gense de Son Oeuvre: Les Amides de Formation, 18851919, is per haps the most important Law rence study Ito have appeared in any language during the last 10 years. When Lawrence left England in 1919, more Or less for good, he had written many of the works upon which his enduring fame and value are based. But his welladver tised difficulties with the Eng lish authorities during war time, the scandal of the sup pression of his great novel, The Rainbow, by magis trate's order in 1915, and the frustration of his efforts to publish an even greater novel, Women in Love, led him to look back upon Englandfrom shipboard as upon a gray coffin slowly sinking into the sea and guaranteed that this most regional and English of English novelists would choose to remain an exile from his native land for most of the 10 or 11 years left to him.

title: WILSON CLEARED BY PRO FOOTBALL
description: The National Football League declared yesterday that Ralph Wilson Jr., owner of the Buf falo Bills, was not guilty of conduct detrimental to profes sional football in the case that brought about his suspension by the New York State Racing Commission.

title: National Notes
description: Some 100,000 young Ameri cans have fled the country, re fusing to be drafted or deserting the Army. Some 500 draft re sisters are in Federal prisons; another 3,000 have served sen tences for that crime. In mili tary stockades, 5,000 are serving sentences for crimes committed in Vietnam, another 4,500 are waiting trial and thousands more have been) less than honorably discharged from the services.

title: Auto Dealers and Papers End Oregon Battle on Ads
description: PORTLAND, Or., Oct. 23A breakdown in communica tions is how both sides de scribe a contest of power here between the press and automo bile dealers.

title: YOUTHHOME PLAN FOUGHT IN BRONX
description: A pioneering, multimillion dollar program to place groups of wayward youngsters in su pervised privatehome settings as an alternative to dilapidated detention centers has run into vocal community opposition over selection of its first site.

title: The master at 90Picasso's Great  Age Seems Only  To Stir Up thee Demons Within
description: MOUGINS, like most of its neighboring villages, is perched on a hilltop in landscape reminiscent of Tuscany, studded with silvery olive trees and cypresses so dark they seem almost black. Beneath the town lies the Bay of Cannes, and behind it, to the north, the snowcapped chain of the Alps. Picasso had spent many care free vacations here in the years before the war, and in the room he occupied at the Hotel Vaste Horizon a few smears of paint that fell from his palette are still to be seen, pre served as zealously as sacred relics.

title: Post Rallies to Down Maine, 4221, as Wichard Stars
Connecticut Airport Gains in TransAtlantic Flights
description: WINDSOR LOCKS, Conn.  Surrounded by bucolic landscape dotted with tobacco farms and populated by deer, fox, pheasant, grouse and other wildlife, it hardly seems like a jumping off place for overseas flights.

title: Art
description: THE exhibition of paintings by Amadeo Modigliani (18841920), now installed at the Acquavella Galleries, 18 East 79th Street, as a benefit for the Museum of Modern Art, comes to us exactly 20 years after the museum's own large retrospective survey of the subject. So much has changed in those 20 years, so many reputations have risen and fallen, so many values have been challenged and overturned, our consciousness not only of the history of modern painting but of the nature of art itself has been treated to so many shocks, that one's first surprise now lies in finding that Modigliani is somehow still there. The truth is, he is not a painter who is much on our minds nowadays. There is nothing in his art that rattles our nerves, and nothing in it either that promises us nirvana. His art is earthly, elegant, and sociable, and nowadays that is hardly enough to lend it the requisite intellectual luster. For minds permanently bivouack ed on the esthetic barricades, he offers of problems.

title: U.S. Study Shows Wage Raises Are Due 5.8 Million Next Year
description: One of the first problems facing the new Pay Board is what to do about deferred wage increases due millions of work ers under existing contracts.

title: Stanford Formula Aids Pollution Fight
description: MENLO PARK, Calif., Oct. 23Scientists at the Stanford Research Institute here have developed a mathematical formula that they say can be used to calculate carbon monoxide concentrations in any city that wishes to know more about its air pollution.

title: Miss Thistlebottom's Hobgoblins The Careful Writer's Guide to the Taboos, Bugbears and Outmoded Rules of English Usage. By Theodore M. Bernstein. 260 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus '
description: All you editors and careful writers can now stop worry ing about: cannot help but, can't seem, contact, fey, hectic, decimate, mean time, nubile, statistic, over, refer back, momen tarily, and insignia. Theo dore Bernstein has pronounced them okay. Don't imagine, however, that you can go hog wild; Mr. Bernstein makes it clear in the prologue to his new book that he rejects the role of permissivist. Thus it behooves the cautious to read with care his modified opin ions on anyplace, balance, fix, each other, different than and way, for example. On the other hand, if you don't know what it is about these locutions that makes them top ics for discussion, count your self lucky and forget you saw them here.

title: The Changing of the Court
description: The fate of nations is determined by the capacity their institutions to adapt themselves to altered needs. Constitutional government is most seriously endangered when its procedural arteries harden so that change and reform appear impossible save by violence and revolu tion. The wisdom of the Founding Fathers has given the United States Supreme Court the power to keep the Constitution adaptable and to protect individual citi zens from the tyranny of bad laws and arrogant govern ment.

title: Public Cynicism Has Reformers In Jersey City Shunning Label
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 23Vot ers in this machinerun city tend to consider candidates as those who are on the payroll or those who are trying to get on, and for many voters, reformers fall into the latter group.

title: Books:
description: Stock market writer Ira Cobleigh has the happy fa cility of writing short books full of meat. This highpro tein offering is not quite as colorful and interesting as one of his recent books,. Happiness Is a Stock That Doubles in a Year, but it is pertinent and useful to the average investor.

title: U.S. Tells How to Buy Tree
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The Agriculture Department has available a booklet for those who like to plan ahead for Christmas tree shopping. The booklet, How to Buy Christmas Tree, is available free from the Office of Inforina tion, Department of Agricul ture, Washington, D. C., 20250.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: C. L. Sulzberger's warm support of dual representation for China in the United Nations (column Oct. 8) re veals a regrettable misunderstanding of the Taiwan problem.

title: TYPHOON LIMITS VIETNAM ACTION
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Typhoon winds reaching 140 miles an hour re stricted war action in the north today, the United States and South Vietnamese military com mands reported.

title: Newswomen Plan Dance
description: The Newspaper Women's Club of New York will hold its 1971 Front Page dinner dance at the Imperial Ballrooth of the Americana Hotel on Nov. 5. Front Page Awards for ex cellence in journalism by news women in the metropolitan area will be presented, along with two journalism scholar ships to help young newswo men complete their training.

title: Besides Games, Eagles Players Also Lose Mustaches
description: For the first time this season the New York Giants will take the field as clearcut favorites when they face the Philadelphia Eagles at 1 P.M. today in Phil adelphia's new Veterans Sta dium. The game will be tele vised in New York by Channel 2.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON Virtually all systems were go for Phase Two of President Nixon's economic stabilization program by the end of last week.

title: Central Labor Council Condemns WorkRelief Proposal for Welfare Mothers as a Threat to Unions
description: The New York City Central Labor Council has condemned a state proposal to put welfare mothers in public jobs to work off their relief grants, calling it a serious threat to the trade union movement and no gain for the women.

title: Art Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: At last, something to gladden the hearts on the role of the Jewish Museum. If it could not come alive, portray Judaism and all its ramifications within the con text of world history, then why does it carry that name? The very fact that Daniel M. Friedenberg, who is a staff member, speaks so forcefully and clearly on the role of the museum bares a situation in which there must have been wide disagreement all these years. It certainly must have been a courageous act for him to speak out within an institution that has blundered along so painfully all these years.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR: I strongly deny and object to the statements attributed to me by Martha Weinman Lear in her article, New York's Haitians: Working, Waiting, Watching Beb6 Doc (Oct. 10).

title: Persia Is a Theme At Antiques Show; Low Prices Found
description: The Persian theme, in honor of the 2,500th anniversary of the Persian Empire being ob served by Iran, is one of many reflected in the National Arts & Antiques Festival, which opened yesterday in the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 67th Street.

title: U.S. Post for C.C.N.Y. Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct, 23 (UPI) Edward W. Aponte, a Puerto Rican and acting president of a community college of the City University of New York, has been appointed to the staff of the Cabinet Committee on Op portunities for SpanishSpeak ing People.

title: Wilhelmina Murray Martin Is Married to Bruce W. Eaken Jr.
description: Miss Wilhelmina Murray Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray W. Martin of New York and Meridian, Miss., was married here yes terday afternoon to Bruce Webb Eaken Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Eaken of Pepper Pike, Ohio. The Rev. Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony in St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal Church, with the Rev. Dr. Terence J. Fin lay participating.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: Astonishingthat's the word for Nancy Milford's review of my book, The Hidden Life of Emily Dickinson. Astonishingly incompetent, I meanbut that's the luck of the draw.

title: Movies
description: As everyone knows, Peter Fonda and Dennis Hopper virtually rev olutionized the procedures of American filmmaking with Easy Rider. And yet practically everyone, as if resentful of the actors success, seemed to be waiting to tear down their followup efforts, Fonda's The Hired Hand and Hopper's The Last Movie. The truth of the matter is that these second films, in which Fonda and Hopper continue to explore the para doxes and the beauties and the contam inations of the American character, are in every way earnest, respectable, capa cious projects.

title: HUGHES SUBMITS TO NEVADA TERMS
description: CARSON CITY, Nev., Oct. 23 Howard Hughes, Nevada's biggest casino operator, tax payer and landowner, who in recent months has been at odds with state officials here, is back in their good graces.

title: Beyond Freedom And Dignity
description: There are three B. F. Skinners. The first is Skinner the experimenter, the author of The Behavior of Organ isms, for more than 30 years an explorer of how far animals and men can be pushed to change engrained habits. This Skinner has created special environments within his laboratory: the fa mous Skinner Box is a device that enables a researcher to control to tally the conditions in which a rat, rabbit or man acts; by carefully changing one element in the environ ment, from altering the temperature to rewarding only certain actions, the researcher hopes to see trans formations in longestablished pat terns of behavior. The Skinner who invented these techniques belongs to an old school of psychology, founded by Pavlov, Thorndike and others at the end of the 19th century.

title: Elizabeth Leach Married
description: MARSHFIELD NILLS, Mass., Oct. 23 Mieg Eliza beth Leach, daughter, of Mr. and Mrs. William Fullerton Leach of Marshfield Hills, was married here this after noon to Thomas Francis Welch Jr. of Sydney, Aus tralia.
