The Rev. Mahlon Gil bert performed the ceremony in the North Community Church, and the Rev. Jerome Peters, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted. The bride groom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Welch of Tenafly, N. J.

title: JERSEY OFFICIALS SEEK PAY ADVICE
description: TRENTON, Oct. 23  Statel and municipal budget officials in New Jersey are hoping Pres ident Nixon will quickly ap point the committee he is es tablishing to deal with prob lems of state and local govern ment during Phase Two of his economic stabilization program.

title: TENSIONS ON RISE IN NORTHERN IRAQ
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 23An attempt on Sept. 29 to as sassinate the Kurdish leader, Gen. Mustafa alBarzani has kept tension in northern Iraq at its highest level since the end of the Kurdish war in March last year.

title: Blasts Kills 3 in Spain
description: CASTELLON, Spain. Oct. 23 (UPI)  There workers were Ku led and five injured here last night when a reactor exploded in a chemical plant the police said.

title: Playground in Harlem Renamed For a Tennis Player and Coach
description: Althea Gibson, a Winbledon tennis champion from Harlem, returned yesterday to the ten nis courts where she started her career and helped Harlem's tennis set dedicate a play ground to her late coach, Fred erick Johnson.

title: QUALIFYING PACE IS SET BY SIFFERT
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, Oct. 23 (AP)Jo Siffert of Switzerland won the pole posi tion today for tomorrow's 40 lap race. The winner of the Austrian Grand Prix and the runner up ,in the United States Grand Prix toured the Brands Hatch circuit at 115.21 miles an hour in his BRM in gaining the top spot.

title: Et A1.
description: Apparently no one till now has taken the trouble to write a book about the 1,200 odd Amer icans (Dodge City marshals, tennis players, socialites, min ers, musicians, fugitives from justice, etc., age 17 to 69) who volunteered to serve with the dashing Teddy Roosevelt in America's musical comedy war. They served only 133 days as members of the 1st Volunteer Cavalry; 37 per cent of those who got to Cuba were casual ties; and their daring activities were capped by the taking of San Juan Hill, a rather pointless maneuver except that it ulti mately made Teddy (according to his own account) President of the United States. Compe tently told, with much original material but for military buffs only.

title: Foyt Wins at Phoenix and Takes 2d Place in USAC Final Standing
description: CASHION, Ariz., Oct. 23A. J. Foyt, a fivetime national driving champion, ended a twoyear dry spell today by win ning the Bobby Ball 150, the closing race of the season on the Marlboro Championship Trail of the United States Auto Club. The victory gave him 300 championship points, enough to lift him into second place in the final standing.

title: Skiing and Winter Sorts Preview
description: SOME cynical souls say that the best way to pick a ski area for a week end is to tack a ski atlas of the East on the living room wall, back up 10 paces, close your eyes and throw a ski pole. For those who don't have a living room large enough to allow a dis tance of 10 paces, there is an alterna tive method: Analyze who you are, what kind of skier you are, how much travel time you're willing to invest in a week end, and how much money you can spend. Then plug yourself into the ski area which best satisfies all your re quirements. The following are by way of some general hints as you pursue your analysis.

title: Daley of Times to Be Cited
description: Arthur Daley, sports colum nist for The New York Times, will be honored by the Green wich (Conn.) OldTimers Asso ciation, along with Torn Seaver, the Mets pitcher, and Carl. Lindemann Jr., vice president, sports, National Broadcasting Company television network, at a dinner Tuesday, Nov. 9.

title: S.M.U. Triumphs Over Texas Tech By 1817 Score
Charge Under Investigation
description: SANTA FF., N. M., Ocr. 23 (UPI)Attorney General David Norvell said today that Mr. Ti jerinn's charge was under inves tigation. He said he discussed the charge with Mr. Tijerina last week and had asked the state police chief, Martin Vieil, to investigate. Mr. Norvell de clined to discuss the details of the charge.

title: The Court
description: In announcing the nominations of Lewis Powell and William Rehnquist as associate jus tices of the Supreme Court, President Nixon declared hat he had based his selection on two criteria (1) their excellence as lawyers and (2) their judicial philosophy. There can be little doubt about what the President meant by the first criterion, or about the fact that his nominees met it. Both Mr. Powell and Mr. Rehnquist are welleducated and successful law.; yers who seem intellectually equipped to com pete on what Mr. Nixon characterized as the fastest track in the nation.

title: the traveler's world
description: DISCOVER America Travel Organi zations, the people who brought you the nationwide Monday holi days program, including this threeday holiday weekend for the ob servance of Veterans Day, is turning its association's attention to the fourday week. It took nearly 40 years to con vince the Federal Government and, to date, 48 of the 50 slates to buy the threeday weekend, but the fourday work week already has a foothold. About 700 companies around the nation with nearly 100,000 workers have put their time clocks on the fourday sched ule, and the idea is beginning to blos som like one whose time has nearly come.

title: Pay for Holiday Tomorrow Affected by Wage Controls
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The Government has speci fied the conditions under which workers can get Vete rans Day off with pay.

title: Iona Beats Marist, 147; Gains Total of 346 Yards
Medicine
description: Back in 1933, a powerful in dustrialist joined forces with young surgeon to provide a pro gram of medical care for work ers building an aqueduct through the isolated wastes of the South ern California desert. From that seed, planted by Henry J. Kaiser and Dr. Sidney Garfield, has de vloped the KaiserPermanente program, the largest private medical organization in the world with an enrollment of two million persons.

title: PRISON REFORMS SOUGHT ON COAST
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 23The entire California cor rectional system, from juvenile halls and county jails to San Quentin and Folsom Prisons, is under challenge in a federally financed study by a team of criminologists.

description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 23Fred Santos scored a goal at 1:30 of the second overtime period to give New York Tech a 10 victory over Hunter to day in a Metropolitan Intercolle giate Soccer Conference match.

title: VASECTOMY FAIR SUCCESS IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 23Offi cials seeking an answer to In dia's population problem are organizing vasectomy fairs in the countryside.

title: Ingrid Christina Johnsen Wed to William Barrett
description: RED BANK, N. J., Oct. 23 The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this evening for the marriage of Miss Ingrid Christina Johnsen to William Barrett of Bernardsville, son of Mr'and Mrs. W. Boyd Barrett of Ellwood City, Pa.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISIt is a sad and sordid fact that armed forces of the three. West ern nations which like to consider themselves particularly civilized have been alleged to employ torture in re cent years while combating guerrilla and urban guerrilla enemies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Itzhak Sharav's approach to vacancy decontrol [Point of View: Decontrol Law Not AntiTenant, Sept. 19] can hardly assuage the public's apprehension over the future of the housing market in New York.

description: CARRY ON

title: MISS WADE TAKES DEWAR NET FINAL
description: BILLINGHAM, England, Oct. 23 (AP)Virginia Wade of Eng land fought back from the edge of defeat to defeat Julie, Held man of Houston, 4.6, 75, 63, today in the women's final of the second of the fivetourna ment Dewar Cup indoor tennis series.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The public inquiry which has begun to reveal pervasive pattern of corruption in the New York City Police Department could uncover the same pattern in most cities and towns across the nation.

title: Norfolk School Gaining in Racial Harmony
description: NORFOLK, Va.The scene outside Matthew Fontaine Maury High School the oth er evening would have been unbelievable to many of those who watched Virginia's segregationists close the school in 1958 rather than allow a single Negro to ,en roll there.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Much of the heat in the current conflicts, be tween economists and ecologists is generated be cause we fail to explore each other's assumptions before we throw the first punch.

title: College Graduate a Maid
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Oct. 23 (UPI)Carol Roberts, 24 years old, a former doctoral candidate at Harvard University, has begun a new job as a cleaning woman for a Cambridge home.

title: WEST HILLS WINS POLO TITLE, 1413
description: DARIEN, Conn., Oct. 23Paul Rizzo scored on a penalty shot to give West Hills of Hunt ington, L. I., a 1413 victory over Monroe (Conn.) tonight in the final round of the George C. Sherman Memorial indoor 5 goal polo championship at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Ch. Special Edition Takes Top Honors in jersey
DANILO DOLCI BEGINS ANTIFASCIST DRIVE
description: ROME, Oct. 23Danilo Dolci, the social crusader, has em barked on campaign against resurgence of Fascism in Italy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: I noted with interest the small news article in The Times of Oct. IS reveal ing that India's Defense Minister, Jag jivan Ram, has warned that in the event of a war with Pakistan, India would not withdraw from any terri tory occupied by Indian troops, saying that India will not submit to world pressure in this regard.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In this international trades game, you have only so many times at bat. It seems a shame that Mr. Nixon used one of his to protect the Southern textile industry, which is one of the most antisocial industries we have, because it nourishes on low wages and autocratic work ing conditions.

title: Casals Conducts New Hymn at U.N. Today
description: Perching forward in a chair, his strong, stubby arms propped against the lectern, Pablo Casals alter nately spoke, grumphed and sang in his Spanishaccented English:

title: Penn State, on Bahr's Goal, Upsets Navy in Soccer, 2.1
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Oct. 23  Penn State scored the East's major soccer upset of the season today by defeating pre viously unbeaten Navy, 21.

title: COLD FRONT ENDING CITY'S 2DAY SMOG
description: A mass of stagnant air that hung over the city for two days, ,searing eyes and making breathing difficult, yielded yes terday to light winds and rain.

title: St. John's Sinks Manhattan In Club Football, 48 to 8
description: St.John's club football team had little trouble with Manhat tan yesterday, routing the Jaspers, 48.8, before 2,500 at the Redmen's Jamaica, Queens, campus and a television audi ence over WNYCTV.

title: Salvation Army Names Woman to a High Post
description: The Salvation Army, yes. terday, named Brigadier Shir ley J. Sipley, a 47yearold career Salvationist, as its first assistant national chief secretary.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: William Hopkins Ewan, after almost 35 years with Borden, is now executive di rector of the new National Advertising Review Board, the advertising industry's first serious, fullscale at tempt at selfregulation.

title: Silver Ike Dollars Being Mailed
description: MAILING of the Eisen hower proof dollars to the public began on Oct. 14, it was announced by Mrs. Mary Brooks Director of the Mint. These are the commemora tives made of 40 per cent silver and the release date coincided with the birth date of the late President, born at Denison, Tex., on Oct. 14, 1890.

title: Special Hotel Squad Here Is Checking Down Thieves
description: Some wear evening clothes. Some are prostitutes Who op erate in pairs. One seems to be a beautiful, highcheekboned girl, but is actually a man.

title: $250,000 in Israeli Bonds Purchased by Seton Hall U.
description: Seton Hall University, a Ro man Catholic institution, has purchased $250,000 in Israeli bonds as a demonstration of its confidence in the future of this democratic state in the Middle East.

title: Original Stylization Is Missing In City Opera's Giulio Cesare
description: The opportunity to hear Bev erly Sills sing Handel again is reason enough to welcome the New York City Opera's revival of its production of Handel's Giulio Cesare after a brief ab sence of the work from the company's repertory. The first performance was given Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Education
description: Busing innercity black children to suburban schools may still be a scary prospect in many parts of the country where whites believe it would lead to violence, in termarriage and other night mares of the affluent. But residents of these areas might look to a couple dozen towns in Connecticut where a busing program has been successful and suburban fears of black and Spanishspeak ing children were largely dis pelled years ago.

title: A Dublin Conversation: Do you support the I.R.A.? Not exactly, but you can't turn your back on it
description: DUBLIN. IF you took down everything the Irish have to say about their own country and signed it, you'd be called the greatest bigot on legs. There's this to watch out for, too. If you praise the place they'll think you're a bit soft, but if you don't, they'll look at you queerly for that. Of course, you can always take middle position, but nobody likes a moderate (overheard in a pub: Scratch an Irish moderate and you'll find granite).

title: Minkus Catalogs
description: A 12PAGE section of full color reproductions of United States postage stamp rarities is fea tured in the 1972 Minkus New American Stamp Catalog, now available at stamp stores, along with its older big brother, the Minkus World Wide Catalog for 1972, which continues as a twopart com pendium measuring about seven inches thick.

title: 2 U.S. Agencies Form Noise Abatement Office
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The Department of Transportation and the Na tional Aeronautics and Space Administration have set up a joint office of noise abate ment.

title: King Nashua, Takes Dash
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Oct. 23 (AP)King Nashua, ridden by Rudy Rincon, covered six furlongs in 1:13 today to cap ture the $2,100 feature at Finger Lakes Race Track. The winner paid $10. It was Rin con's third success of the after noon.

title: Wilkes Wins On Late Kick
description: HUNTINGDON, Pa., Oct. 23 (UPI)  A freshman, Terry Blaum, kicked a 24yard field goal with 10 seconds remaining to give Wilkes College a 30 vic tory over Juniata today.

title: Peking City Aide Heads Cultural Unit
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 23Wu Teh, who was acting mayor of Peking during the Cultural Rev olution, has emerged as the di rector of a new national agency for cultural affairs that ob samara had at first thought was headed by Chiang Ching, the wife of Mao Tsetung, the party chairman.

title: Anticipating Consumerism
description: Beating the consumer organizations to the punch is paying off for at least one grocery chain.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CLAYTON, N. Y.Speed ing up the 26foot Linda B., then immediately throttling back, James Brabant, a Clay ton fishing guide and skipper, glanced at the three lines trolling behind us and re marked, I sometimes get a muskie that way.

title: Hockey Breaks the Ice and Kosygin Smiles
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum hia, Oct. 23Premier Aleksei Kosygin of the Soviet Union scored his first popular success in Canada here last night.

title: Selling the Great Outdoors
description: For every urban dweller, huddled in his highpriced highrise apartment, yearn ing for the great outdoors, there is a recreational com munity being developed by major American corpora tion.

title: HOUSE UNIT BLAMES F.D.A. IN MAN'S DEATH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) The Food and Drug Adminis tration was recalling hadtast ing sweets when it should have been policing the removal of mislabeled poison that later took a man's life; a House Gov ernment Operations subcommit tee said today. The subcommit tee said that the F.D.A. was negligent in the death of a man and the serious illness of woman who ate the poison ac cidentally in a Washington area restaurant early this year.

title: Thefts of Bicycles Rise Sharply in City
description: Bicycle thefts have become an unhappy feature of life in the metropolitan area. In New York City, 10,000 to 12,000 losses a year are being reported to the police, and there are ad ditional thefts that are not re ported.

title: WORLD SYMPHONY PERFORMS HERE
description: Philharmonic Hall looked as if it was trying to compete with the United Nations on Friday night. Gathered on stage were representatives of 64 nations, They weren't there to play poli tics on behalf of their countries but to make music as members of the World Symphony Orches tra,

title: The Nation
description: Months of quiet maneuvering, culminating in days of frantic, closeddoor negotiating, ended last week. Mayor Lindsay and Governor Rockefeller had reached an agreement  the Mayor pledging his support for the Governor's $2.5billion transpor tation bond issue, which will be on the ballot Nov. 2, and the Governor making available enough state money to allow New York City a chance to preserve its present 30cent transit fare structure. For a change, the May or and the Governor, those old and bitter rivals, were pulling in the same direction. And the City of New York, for the first time, had committed itself to subsidize its mass transit operations with general tax revenues, accepting the notion that subways might actually be an essential city serv ice in the same league with school.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The heartless exploitation of the prisonerofwar issue by the American brass is again exposed in the case of John Sexton Jr. A letter to his family, in his own handwriting, was kept from his parents for two yearsapparently because his captors had duplicated its contents for their own propaganda purposes. And his family was not informed that he was known to be captured but only that this was a possibility; the military continued to list him as missing in action.

title: Rizzo's Election Rival Gains Support
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23Thacher Longstreth gained sup port from several quarters this week in his campaign to defeat former Police Commissioner Frank L. Rizzo for Mayor Nov. 2.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: Robert Brustein selected portions of my interview with Susan Sontag (which ap peared in Vogue on Aug. 1) to buttress his diagnosis of what he calls her cultural schizophrenia (If an Artist Wants to Be Serious and Re spected and Rich, Famous and Popular, He Is Suffering From Cultural Schizophrenia, Sept. 26).

title: The Agnews Return
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (Reu ters)Vice President and Mrs. Spiro T. Agnew arrived at An drews Air Force Base in Mary land today from Greece.

title: Daley Agrees to. End Patronage If Illinois G.O. P. Reciprocates
Reader's Report
description: I can remember when in spiration books were written by sobersides like Bruce Barton and Fulton Oursler. What a long, long way we've come!

title: Religion
description: ROMEA French prelate at the world Synod of Bishops was heard to remark to a colleague last week, If I go home with what we've got now the priests will be out to greet me with tomatoes.

title: LETTERS.
description: To the Financial Editor Perhaps you gave Thomas J. Holt Wall Street's Supt? Bear, Sept. 19) a great deal of unwarranted publicity which scared the public.

title: Troops Kill 3 in Robbery
description: NEWRY, Northern Ireland, Sunday, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Three men were shot dead by British troops in a robbery at tempt early today, an army spokesman announced.

title: Getting toned (by the Natives) in Staphorst
description: STAPHORST, the NetherlandsI must admit that I was a bit nerv ous about poking my curious American nose into the town of Staphorst since I had heard how they treated, or rather mistreated, touriststhrowing stones at them and smashing their car windows. So, for protection, I invited along two friends from home, Susan and her district attorney husband, Arnie, who happened to be in the Neth erlands at the time.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: I am not a fan of Mailer's writing (or Segal's or Son tag's, for that matter), but in my view there is no doubt that he is the best man of let ters we have. No one else re sponds with such articulate passion to the life of our time (usually you have to set tle for either passion or ar ticulateness). I remember a brief statement he made which came over the news on British television on the night of Robert Kennedy's assassi nationabout America, Chris tianity and his wife: it was equal to Whitman on Lincoln.

title: Quintuplets Born in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 23 (AP)Mrs. Hadassah Berman, 22 years old, who had been taking fer tility pills, gave birth by Cae sarean section today to quin tuplets, three girls and two boys whose weight ranged from 1 pound 8 ounces to 2 pounds 14 ounces.

title: Art Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Congratulations to Daniel M. Friedenberg for so persua sively defining the function of a Jewish museum as one that would include historical and ethnographic materials as well as works of art.

title: Hunter Mountain Is My Cup of Glogg
description: THERE are still skiers hereabout who don't know what has hap pened at Hunter Mountain in the past eight years. Hunter, which is reached by driving 102 miles up the New York State Thruway (to Exit 20), then 21 more miles on State Routes 32, 32A, and 23A, is apt to be shrugged off as one of those distinctly minor ski areas too near to be really worthwhile.

title: Adele Lee Hall And. Professor To Be Married
description: TENAFLY, N. J., Oct. 23Miss Adele Lee Hall, who is studying for a doctorate in international studies at the Claremont Graduate School in California, plans to be married on Dec. 30 to Carl Uddo Zachrisson Jr., an as sistant professor of political studies at the Claremont Graduate School and Pitzer College.

title: Skiing and Winter Sorts Preview; Europe: The Alps Are Only $210 (An Up) Away
description: AEUROPEAN ski vacation still rates four stars on the list of ad ventures American skiers dream. about. Jet speeds may have taken some of the romance out of trans Atlantic travel and an avalanche of firsthand accounts may have taken some of the mystique out of the Alps as a skiing paradise, but the moun tains of Austria, France, Italy and Switz erland still pass the ultimate test: Al most every skier who has been there wants to go back.

title: Cafe a la Cracow, Or, How to Make Friends in Poland
description: CRACOW, PolandThis is one of those rare cities where even day after day of rain won't really ruin a trip. The drizzle simply gives the traveler an excuse to stay indoors at a cafe or restaurant, sipping a drink of hot honey and wine, nibbling on almond cakes and talking with quick ly made Polish friends. Cracow, in fact, may be the most vibrant cafe city in all of Eastern Europe.

title: Cowboys in New Plush Home Today
description: The Dallas Cowboys play today for the first time in their new home, Texas Sta dium, which is pro football's most plush establishment. The Cowboy debut was de layed three times because of heavy late summer rainsthat stopped work on the parking lots.

title: 2,500 JOIN M'INTIRE AT CAPITAL RALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23The Rev. Carl McIntire called today for victory in Vietnam, cancel lation of President's Nixon an nounced trip to China and re turn of prayer to public schools at his fourth rally in a year and a half.

title: New Chief at Amherst Hails Tenure System
description: AMHERST Mass., Oct. 23 (AP)John William Ward, 48yearold professor of his tory and American studies, became the 14th president of Amherst College in inaugura tion ceremonies today.

title: Art Notes
description: IT was a whole different bag for the Metropolitan Museum, all right. For all of last week, one of its picture galleries was trans formed into a Dream House a dark, cavelike sound en vironment, enhanced by cal ligraphic slide projections. Visitors shucked their shoes to enter, sprawled on carpet strips and heardfor hours at a clipa form of music that to many ears would make monotony sound scin tillating: a continuous, wall towall drone mildly embel lished by voices and instru ments.

title: Sports of The Times
description: This is not a shill. It's too late for that, because the two selection committees for the Cy Young awards already have cast ballots. The accountants tabulating them have been held incommunicado and under heavy guard in that there can be no pre mature leaks in security. But the time has almost arrived for Jack Lang, the demon secretary of the Baseball Writers Associa tion, to extend his hand in the manner of an Oscar presenter and say, The envelope, please.

title: Ski Deals: Midweek Packages, Bunks, Tours and Air Fares
description: THE dream of ski area operators and lodge keepersaside from having heavy snow.. storms at regular intervalsIs to find their parking lots full of cars in midweek. They want you there Monday through Friday; and that is why the midweek ski pack age remains the best buy in snow country. This season, though, two other factors bear watching by the budget conscious: the Government's price freeze, which should re sult in keeping down lift and lodge prices; and the flurry over air fares, which is likely to trim rates to the Rockies as well as across the Atlan tic to the Alps.

title: Skiing and Winter Sorts Preview; Why Ski Turing? Well, Instead Of Meeting People e Meet Elk
description: ONE Saturday last winter, while most of my skiing friends were at their usual haunts waiting in lift lines, paying exorbitantly for being hauled up a mountain, skiing downhill more or less in chisters and occasion ally even elbowing each other in the ribs, where was I? Where. was I indeed!

title: Education
description: Few concepts in public school education have gained as wide currency, and aroused as much emotion, as equality of opportunity. While the emphasis has been On racial questions, the is sueso often enmeshed with questions of how to educate children of varying abilities and backgrounds and what tb regard as successalso has involved economics.

title: World
description: MONTREAL  Premier Aleksei Kosygin is a travel ing man, and he probably would have come to Canada sooner or later. His country and Canada share the Arctic zone and have a mutual in terest in the problems of de veloping Arctic regions. In Montreal the Soviet Premier wanted especially to visit plant making prefabricated houses for frontier areas.

title: Moscow Denies Charges on Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 23The So viet Government newspaper Iz vestia published a lengthy denial today of charges here and abroad that mentally stable persons were being detained in psychiatric hospitals because of dissident activities.

title: Blacks Advised to Transcend Ghetto Politics'
description: PLAINVIEW, L. I., Oct. 23Delegates to the 35th annual conference of the New York State chapters of the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People were urged today to go beyond the concept of ghetto politics, where they depend on large concentrations of black voters to elect black officials.

title: Movies
description: AN early morning scene: chaos in a chic New York hotel suite; beds unmade; two large breakfast tables in cluttered disarray; two British film lu minaries, director Bryan Forbes and his actresswife, Nanette Newman (In town to promote their latest film, Long Ago, Tomorrow), speak animatedly on two sep arate phones; a pressagent hovers, all smiles and atten tiveness; a photographer and his assistant swiftly move lights; an interviewer stands to the side, waiting, looking on, listening.... We've got a full day of interviews, dar ling... Sheilah Graham for lunch, then someone from Women's Wear Daily... no, we've already done David Frost... a lateish drink, perhaps... divine... good bye, love. Bryan Forbes hangs up the phone.

title: New Census Forms Resented In Italy as Invasion of Privacy By MARVINE HOWE
description: ROME, Oct. 23The Roman office clerk examined the thick questionnaire gingerly, as if it were a time bomb, and then put it into a drawer while he pon dered how he could get around it,

title: EDWIN L. JONES, 80, OF BUILDING CONCERN
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 23 (AP)Edwin L. Jones, under whose guidance the J. A. Jones Construction Company founded by his father became one of the largest in the world, died of a heart attack Friday. He was 80 years old.

title: The Last Word: Freedom to Read (1)Porno
description: Oh! Pornography! Just as one sets out to make a modest comment on the current state of the freedom to read in America, thou raiseth thy serpentine head and flicketh out thy mocking tongue. It is like a lecturer delivering a talk on the nature of comedy being suddenly interrupted by a borschtbelt comedian braying, Good evening ladies and germs, Now take my wife . . please!

title: FolkRocking From Paxton to Happy and Artie
description: TOM PAXTON: How Come the Sun (Reprise). Tom Paxton belongs to that tradition of great Amer ican artists like Sinclair Lewis and Sherwood An derson who expose the flaws of this country and its people through descriptions, not sermons. Rather than adopting one tone ,for his various observations, singer songwriterguitarist Paxton fits his music and voice to each situation. I Had to Shoot that Rabbit tells of a soldier caught between duty and compassion. The melody, voice and arrangement, like the lyrics, keep pounding home the soldier's frantic desperation.

title: Nebraska Overwhelms Oklahoma State, 4113, for 17th Consecutive Triumph
WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe name of Ralph Nader, understand ably, does not arouse the most amicable of feelings among business executives or among those persons in pub lic life who feel that Mr. Nader has unjustly reviled corporations and their leaders

title: SmallBusiness Men Ask Stricter Regulation
description: A number of smallbusiness men and manufacturers called last week for stricter and more comprehensive wageprice con trols, coupled with rigid en forcement, during the second phase of President Nixon's eco nomic stabilization program.

title: Bat Leaders Are Willing to Work for Nixon Plan
description: DETROIT, Oct. 23  They spoke of 56 per cent wage in crases. Well in the building trades where it's $810 an hour, 5 per cent is a decent wage in crease. But for people making $2 an hour it isn't much. They'll just fall further behind.

title: Spell on Audience Is Cast at Garden By Aretha Franklin
description: Aretha Franklin's appear ances in New York City have been rare lately. Too rareas her performance at Madison Square Garden Friday night made amply clear. Use all the catch phrases you like"First Lady of Soul, Queen of Soul, Number 1 Soul Sister and they all say essentially the same thing, that Miss Franklin is head and shoulders above her competition.

title: U.S. Plum Island Lab Holds Its First Open House
description: PLUM ISLAND, L. I.For the first time since it was dedicat ed 15 years ago the Federal Government's highly restricted and, to many who live nearby, mysterious animaldIsease labo ratory on Plum Island opened its doors to outsiders last week.

title: 7 Papers Devoting Front Page To Attack on U.S. Bureaucracy
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 23 (AP)Eugene C. Pulliam, pub lisher of seven newspapers in Indiana and Arizona, devoted the entire front pages of his Sunday editions to an editorial attacking Federal bureaucracy.

title: Letter to the Editor 7  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: David French's article at last brings us a confession of a supposedly intellectual young person that all is not going well with the lives and goals of his generation. What I resent is that he and his col leagues keep insisting that they were channeled into this abysmal squalor because they are convinced that their par ents had lived worthless lives, had ruined our society, and they would do better.

title: Humphrey Courts Party Regulars, the Source of His 68 Strength
description: BELLE VERNON, Pa., Oct. 22It was close to midnight when Hubert H. Humphrey fi nally had his evening meala slab of corn beef and a beer served up tenderly by George R. Sweeney, the whitehaired patriach of Westmoreland County Democratic politics.

title: Miss Nugent Is Bride
description: NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 23Miss Candace Nugent, a reg istered nurse at Nyack Hos pital, was married here this afternoon to Brian John Wil son, a patrolman with the Orangetown Police Force. The. Rev. Alexander J. Smith, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony in Grace Epis copal Church.

title: Bergen; Basile Guides Hackensack's Wishbone? Offense to 400 Rout of Ridgewood; LEONIA, RAMSEY ALSO BLANK FOES; All 3 Still UnbeatenBasile Tallies Once and Pegs for Another Score
Wagner Defeats Kings Point,1714, On Schaffer's Kick
KNAPP UNIT'S HEAD DEFENDS LEGALITY OF INVESTIGATION
description: Whitman Knapp, chairman of the commission investigat ing police corruption here, vigorously defended the com mission's procedures yesterday and declared: In a democracy the only way a condition can be corrected is to bring it forcibly to public attention.

title: A NOTORIOUS BRIG NOW MODEL PRISON
description: CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Oct. 23  The Marine Corps's once notorious Camp Pendleton brig, where recurrent rioting, brutality and corruption led to a Congressional investigation two years ago, completed its transformation this week into a model military prison.

title: Cristin Ayn Delker Is Bride Of Albert Merck Jr. in Jersey
description: MENDHAM, N. J., Oct. 23 In St. Mark's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Cristin Ayn Delker was married to Albert Wall Merck Jr. by the Rev. Phillips S. Watters Jr. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman O. Delker of Fair mount. The bridegroom, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merck of Mendham and Mattapoisett, Mass., is a grandson of the late George Wilhelm Merck, who headed Merck & Co., Manufacturing chemists in Rahway, and a greatgrand son of the late George Merck, founder of the company.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Prof. Paul Griminger objects to con demnation of U.S. support of Saigon's corrupt, antidemocratic regime on the ground that the alternative is domination by the even less demo cratic Hanoi Government (letter Oct. 10). The argument, a common one, ignores both history and inter national law.

title: Sara Marmion Jersey Bride
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 23Miss Sara Katherine ?? of New York and Roger William Seiler of Nyack, N. Y., were married here this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church by the Right Rev. William Hen ry Amnion, the bride's uncle, who is the Episcopal Bishop of Southwestern Virginia. The bride's godfather, the Right Rev. Harry Lee Doll, Epis copal Bishop of Maryland and the Rev. Herbert A. Donovan rector of St. Luke's, assisted.

title: Fog, Light Air Halts Sailing
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 23 Scheduled EastofRye fall se ries racing on Long Island Sound off Indian Harbor Yacht Club was canceled today because of fog and insufficient breeze.

title: For Young Readers; By the Highway Home By Mary Stolz. 194 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $4.95. (Ages 11 to 15)
description: When Mary Stolz first began writ ing teenage fiction, she was hailed not only as a distinguished writer but as a ground breaker, a realist not afraid to introduce a fat heroine into a field dominated by pretty, slim girls, not afraid to let unrequited love go unrequited although tradi tionally romances were expected to produce happy endings. But now it is 20 years later; realism in teenage books means drugs, ghettoes, knives, illegitimate babies, alcoholic fathers, and Mary Stolz, after a sevenyear absence from the teenage field re turns with a story her publishers say is of a modern girl coping with contemporary issues.

title: Theater in London
description: EDWARD BOND'S Lear at the Royal Court and the arrival from Paris of Ariane Mnouchkine's Theatre du Soleil production of 1789 at the Round House bring into sharp focus two radical ly different ways of treating the same problem: namely, how, in a world where non stop media like newspapers and television bombard the senses with political contra dictions, is the theater to fashion its dialectic? Bond's answer is traditional, despite his unconventional treatment of Shakespeare's classic Mnouchkine's is what I sup pose one would call mod ernits form is fragmen tary, its diction spectacle, and its tactic audiencein volvement. Neither answer fully satisfies, and each has virtues from which the other could benefit.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: As American consumers witness every day, Japan has created a huge market in the United States for her auto mobiles, appliances and cam eras.

title: AN OFFICE TOWER TO RISE IN HARLEM
description: A private, blackowned real estate development concern has purchased nine parcels of land valued at more than $1.5mil lion along 125th Street in Har lem.

title: L.I. Wife of Russian.,Gets Visa to Rejoin Her Husband
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 23 (UPI)The American wife of Russian student who was ex pelled from medical school and then drafted into the Red Army received a new Soviet visa to day and plans to fly to Moscow tomorrow night to be reunited with her husband.

title: East Africa: To Visit Villages And Meet People, Rent a ike and Take It With You On the Bus
description: Most of the clients so far, he said, had been white hippies, but the house served chitterlings to African customers.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: In the controversy over the present international mone tary crisis, I find a crucial aspect of the situation totally ignored. This is the contribu tion of United States capital to the present crisis.

title: Music
description: BRIDGEPORT is not nor mally thought of as great center of culture. Many people know it only as the home for many years of P. T. Barnum or as the birthplace of Charles Sherwood Stratton, the fam ous midget Tom Thumb. Yet it is this Connecticut city that has announced the first sizable celebration of the 75th birthday of Virgil Thom son.

title: MRS. TODOR ZHIVKOV
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 23 (UPI)  Dr. Mara Maleeva Zhivkova, wife of Bulgarian President Todor Zhivkov, died today of cancer, the Bulgarian radio announced. Her age was 60.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Pollys Pal 3Length Victor In Rhode Island Handicap
description: PAWTUCKET, R. L, Oct. 23 (AP)James E. Sweeney's Pol lys Pal won the Rhode Island Marathon Handicap by three lengths at Narragansett Park today, covering the 1 Mi miles in 1:56 15.

title: Judaism's own Dan Berrigan
description: Daniel Berrigan, while still a priest on the run, made his celebrated Cornell appearance and escape dur ing the celebration of Arthur Was kow's Peace Sedera liturgy con demned by many Jews, especially those who neglect the conventional Seder. Their attitude seems to be that of lapsed or lukewarm Catholics toward the old Latin MassBy God, if I ever go to Mass again, that's the kind of Mass I want to find. One of Elizabeth Cullinan's characters put it bestthe odd desire to leave the church, go out and find oneself, and then return, a prodigal to be feted. That whole fantasy depended on the church's being there when one de cided to return. The fun goes out of it if you have to keep wondering whether the church will be there, after all, when you turn around. Per haps those who stayed will have ruined it. The traitors, in other words, remained inside the walls, while true defenders went off for a bit of theo R and R.

title: Egypt Opens Sabry Trial On Charges of Corruption
description: CAIRO, Oct. 23 (Reuters)Aly Sabry, the former Vice President of Egypt, went on trial in secret here today on charges of political corruption and misuse of power.

title: Track Coaches Cite Weiss
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 23Irwin W. Weiss, coach of field events at Princeton University since 1957, has been named coach of the year for 197071 by the New Jersey College Track Coaches Association.

title: Autumn's Plenty
description: Autumn is always a season of natural plenty, but this, year seems to have been doubly generous. Summer's growth and fruiting were lush, and autumn has been mild and gentle, with ample time and warmth to ripen late nuts and berries. The birds and animals are having a big harvest, and plenty will be left over to carry them well into the winter.

title: Dr. Carol Dinkelacker Becomes a Bride
description: JERICHO, L. I., Oct. 23Dr. Carol Dinkelacker, a resident physician at Temple University Hospital, Philadel phia, was married here today to Dr. Andrew J. Sheridan 3d, a physician who has a lieu tenant's commission in the United States Public Health Service.

title: Sidney Ansin, Philanthropist And TV Station Owner, 68
description: MIAMI, Oct. 23 (UPI)Sid ney D. Ansin, philanthro pist, civic leader and owner of WCKTTV in Miami, died last night at the Miami Heart In stitute. He was 68 years old.

title: Black Prison Guards Deplore Racial Imbalance in Penal Chain of Command
description: A note of bitter dissent is being sounded within the state's Correction Department by black officers who charge that the causes and lessons of the Attica uprising have been grossly misunderstood by white officers and policymakers.

title: The World
description: LONDON  When a British government under Lloyd George was negotiating with Irish rebel leaders on a peace plan that became the Treaty of 1921,the Deputy Secretary to the Cabi net was a. Welshman named Tom Jones. He kept a diary, and the volume dealing with Ireland has just been published here. It makes fascinatingand depressingreading.

title: Sports Symposium Today
description: Nat Holman, the great player and coach of basketball; Ken Strong, the allAmerica, allpro and HallofFame football, play er; Ruby Goldstein, referee in many Joe Louis boxing bouts, and Ed Weiner, secretary of the New York Touchdown Club, will take part in a sports sym posium today at Mount Neboh Congregation, 130 West 79th Street. The subject will be Sports Today and Yesterday, and the program is to begin at 10:30 A.M.

title: He Reminds Me of Me At That Age, Says Leonard  Bernstein
description: MICHAEL TILSON THOMAS is a young man in a rusheven his name races along, triply trochaicand up to now his career has had only one tempo: allegro molto. His heroes of the moment are Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach and James Brown, the soul singer. When he wearies of study ing and conducting medieval music of Josquin, Ockeghem and Perotin, he can dance all night to The Roll ing Stones, Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin. If someone invented a re versible time machine he would choose to dive back into the past and hear Beethoven C.P.E. Bach improvismg at the keyboard. But if he should find a free moment in the dim future he might like to act (I'd really love to play Dracula, but benign Dracula). He is 26 years old (Nobody believes that but it's trueactually I feel ancient); he is tall and slightly stooped, suggest ing in fact a young and handsomer Bela Lugosi, and he is the hand picked candidate for greatness of formidable lineup of musical spon sors including Gregor Piatigorsky, Pierre Boulez and Leonard Bernstein. improvismg at the keyboard. But if he should find a free moment in the dim future he might like to act (I'd really love to play Dracula, but benign Dracula). He is 26 years old (Nobody believes that but it's trueactually I feel ancient); he is tall and slightly stooped, suggest ing in fact a young and handsomer Bela Lugosi, and he is the hand picked candidate for greatness of formidable lineup of musical spon sors including Gregor Piatigorsky, Pierre Boulez and Leonard Bernstein.

title: Cornell Soccer Victor
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 23Vic tor Huerta's penalty shot late in the first period today gave Cornell a 10 soccer victory over Yale. The victory in creased Cornell's wonlost rec ord to 72 over all and 21 in the Ivy League. Yale is 241 over al and 111 in Ivy play.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: To those whose bowls are empty, to whom starvation appears a cer tainty, the tragedy of our corn crop might not be appreciated. While farm ers would prefer a blight to a bloat for dollar reasons, and officials lament the lack of storage bins, I must once again grapple with the concept of surplus in a world of need.

title: Fans Halt Notre Dame Rout
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI) The Notre Dame freshman football team routed a Mexico City amateur club, Accion De portiva, 820, yesterday before a crowd of 40,000. Fans at Aztec Stadium stole the ball after Notre Dame made it 820 and refused to give it back.

title: Barry Registers 44 On Return but Nets BowtoPros,111103
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 24 Rick Barry, out for two games with a sprained left ankle, returned to action tonight and scored 44 points, but it was not enough to save the Nets. The Memphis Pros, leading almost through out, turned in a 111103 victory in an American Basketball As sociation game.

title: Juilliard Quartet Celebrates Its 25th Anniversary
description: Though not many people could have known about it at the time, it turned out to be one of the blessed events of American musical history: On Oct. 10, 1946, the Juilliard String Quartet was born. Last night at Alice Tully Hall, the Juilliard celebrated its 25th anniversary, a couple of weeks late, with a concert of works by Milton Babbitt, Dvorak and Beethoven.

title: Music:
description: They virtually had to lift Pablo Casals into the con ductor's chair at yesterday afterneon's United Nations Day Concert, but one there, with baton firmly in hand, any sign of weakness van ished. Mr. Casals, in an amazing display of indomita bility at 94 years of age, led a taxing program in the Gen eral Assembly Hall, including the premiere Petformance of his own Hymn to the United Nations and a repeat play ing of the same musical plea for peace through music.

title: UKRAINIANS CALM ABOUT THE VISITOR
description: VEGREVILLE, AlbertaLike a great many of the 500,000 Canadians of Ukrainian birth or ancestry, the people of this farm town on the northern plains have shown little interest in the Canadian visit of the Soviet Premier, Aleksei N. Ko sygin.

title: Sonics Trounce Royals
description: SEATTLE, Oct. 24 (AP)The Seattle SuperSonics led all the way tonight as they crushed the Cincinnati Royals, 119401.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada Wins Crown Golf
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Oct. 24 (AP)Canada's team defeated Australia, 54, today to win the championship of the Commonwealth amateur golf tournament.

title: SOLUTION ELUDES MONETARY GROUP
description: PARIS, Oct. 24If anything, the chances for resolving the world monetary crisis look worse today than in midAu gust when President Nixon launched his policy of trying to force other nations to give trading advantages to the Unit ed States.

title: Brezhnev, Due in France, Seeking to Improve Image
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24Leonid I. Brezhnev, who has moved into the limelight this fall as the predominant figure in Soviet diplomacy, flies to Paris tomor row for a visit intended as much to mellow and enhance his personal image in the West as to show Europe the advan tages of dealing directly with Moscow.

title: Put Down the Barriers
description: When ranked with other democratic countries, the United States has always been at the bottom of the class when it comes to voter participation. In 1968, nearly 37 Million persons who were potentially eligible to vote were not registered. Yet of those who were registered in the last Presidential election, 81 per cent actually voted, an impressively high turnout. That statistic sug gests that what is wrong is the nation's voting laws and not the political vitality of its citizens.

title: Theater: A Marx Brothers Tragedy
description: There is a cold and fine madness to Yale M. Udoff's play A Gun Play, which opened at the Cherry Lane Theater yesterday. It is a comedy about violence, and despite a certain unoriginal ity of subject, it is to be rec ommended, largely for itself but also partly for the very evident promise of Mr. Udoff. When you are seeing his sec ond and third plays, it will be agreeable to recall that you saw his first.

title: PETTY TRIUMPHS IN 500MILE RACE
description: ROCKINGHAM, N.C., Oct. 24 Richard Petty led for the final 150 miles of the wreck filled American 500 stock car race today and registered his 19th triumph of the NASCAR Grand National season.

title: LAKELAND TERRIER WINS BEST IN SHOW
description: VINELAND N.J., Oct. 24Ch. Special Edition, a Lakeland ter rier owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., and handled by Peter Green, captured his 28th best inshow title today in a field of 1,270 at the annual South Jer sey Kennel Club event.

title: Steel Gains Predicted
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24Steel shipments will jump from 17 million tons in the fourth quar ter of this year to 22 million tons in the first quarter of 1972.

title: Women Seek a Bigger Role in Phase 2
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24The National Women's Political Caucus criticized the Nixon Ad ministration today for naming only one woman, out of a total of 22 members, to the price and pay control agencies that will administer Phase Two of the economic stabilization pro gram.

title: Citizens Union Endorses Transportation Bond Issue
description: The $2.5billion transporta tion bond issue that comes be fore New York State's voters a week from tomorrow was en dorsed yesterday by the Citi zens Union.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 23 (AP)Nine persons were killed last night in a twocar collision in a Portland residential area. The victims were Floyd Hamp ton, 26 years old, and Deborah Marie Wood, 23, both of Van couver, Wash.; Mary Ann Higgs, Cathy Maureen Gallagher, Don na Grover, 19, and Nancy Mae Thompson, 17, all of Portland; and David Michael Lehr, 21, and Charles T. Goff, 20, both of Acampo, Calif. One victim was not identified.

title: 2D JERSEY BUS LINE FACES STRIKE TODAY
description: Approximately 45,000 com muters and local users of two New Jersey bus lines face dif ficulties getting to jobs in Manhatan today and finding local transportation as a result of strikes by drivers and other union workers.

title: Sergei Kavtaradze Dies at 86; Stalin Ally Was Purged in 1927
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24Sergei I. Kavtaradze, a Georgian Com munist revolutionary who was purged and then reinstated by Stalin, died Oct. 17 in Tbilisi. He was 86 years old.

title: School Started in Lawrence
description: LAWRENCE, L. I., Oct. 24 Groundbreaking ceremonies for the Lawrence Evan Sloate High School and the expanded Irving Miller Elementary School, part of the new $1,500,000 Brandeis School complex, were held here today at the school at 25 Frost Lane. The complex, scheduled to be ready for use in Septem ber 1972, will accommodate 200 students in the first Jewish Conservative senior high school on Long Island, and 500 ele mentary and junior high school students.

title: WARSAW, BELGRADE WILL EXPAND TRADE
description: WARSAW, Oct. 24Poland and Yugoslavia agreed today to major increases in economic cooperation, both in expanded trade and in broader industrial and scientific coordination.

title: Methodist Women Oppose Plan for School Prayers
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24 (AP) The women's division of the United Methodist Church Board of Missions voted today against a proposed constitutional amendment permitting nonde nominational prayers in schools.

title: A Tombs Prisoner, 22, Hangs Himself
description: A 22yearold prisoner with a history of 11 previous arrests hanged himself in his cell in the Tombs early yesterday. It was the 10th suicide in a city jail this year, the Department of Correction reported.

title: MRS. ROBERT Z. HAWKINS
description: RENO, Nev., Oct. 24Mrs. Katherine Mackay Hawkins, a daughter, of the late Clarence H. Mackay, founder of the Postal Telegraph and the Com mercial Cable Companies, died here today. She was 71 years old and was the wife of Robert Z. Hawkins, a lawyer.

title: Notes On Metropolitan Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 It is not true that the New York Congressional delega tion is just a bunch of East ern liberals. Eastern perhaps, but not necessarily liberal.

title: NEW TOOL ORDERS CONTINUE TO LAG
description: New orders for machine tools (the machines that build other machines) during the first nine months of this year totaled $626.05million, down 14 per cent from $729.2million in the yearearlier period. During the first eight months they were off 16.7 per cent compared with the 1970 period.

title: Doctor Beaten to Death
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 (AP)Dr. Clarence Benson, a 41yearold California gynecol ogist, was found beaten to death here this weekend, the police reported today.

title: Two Hold in Toronto Raid
description: TORONTO, Oct. 24 (UPI) Two persons were arrested and guns, ammunition and knives were confiscated in at least 18 raids in the Toronto area, prompted, the police said, by information that attempts would be made to assassinate Premier Kosygin during his visit here.

title: Muskie Doubts He Is Hurt By Credentials Post Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Senator Edmund S. Muskie said today that he did not think the election of Mrs. Patricia Harris as temporary chairman of the Credentials Committee for the 1972 Democratic Na tional Convention hurt him as a possible Presidential candi date.

title: Orantes Conquers Lutz, 64, 63, 63, In Barcelona Final
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 24 (UPI)Manuel Orantes of Spain beat Bob Lutz of Lancaster, Calif., 64, 63, 64 today to win the Spanish open tennis tournament and $14,706.

title: Israel Weighs New U.S. Plan Aimed at Opening Suez Canal
description: JERUSALEM. Oct. 24  Is rael's Cabinet deferred its de cision today on participating in a reported new attempt of the United States to begin indirect negotiations toward an interim settlement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Curfew in Southern Pines Ordered in Racial Violence
description: SOUTHERN PINES, N. C., Oct. 24 (AP)A state of emer gency was declared and a cur few was imposed today follow ing a second night of scattered racial violence in this resort town in the southcentral part of the state.

title: Meryl Tolle Married
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 24Miss Meryl Rose Tolle and Alexander Cohn of Bayside, Queens, were mar ried here this afternoon in Temple B'nai Sholom by Rabbi Max J. Routtenberg. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Tolle of Cedarhurst. Her husband's parents are Bernard Cohn and Mrs. Stephen Kurdilla of Woodmere. Mr. Cohn is en tertainment editor of News day. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Casals Is Acclaimed in Concert at U. N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24Pablo Casals, widely revered as a tireless laborer for human understanding, today conducted an impassioned mu sical tribute to peace and the United Nations.

title: Memphis Tensions Ease; Conditions Near Normal
description: MEMPHIS, Oct. 24 (UPI) Racial tensions continued to ease here today.

title: Speaks in New Rochelle
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Oct. 24 (UPI)Mayor Lindsay today attacked his former partythe Republicansas arrogant, cal lous and entrenched at a county meeting of his new partythe Democrats.

title: Kosygin Gets an Air View of the Prairies of Canada
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Oct. 24Premier Aleksei Ni Kosy gin of the Soviet Union trav eled by plane today across the prairies, a part of Canada that is highly disturbed by Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's recent overtures of friendship toward the Soviet Union.

title: PHILIP H. CORNICK, LAND TAX EXPERT
description: YONKERS, Oct. 24Philip H. Cornick, tax expert and au thority on public administra tion, died last night in the Hudson View Nursing Home. His age was 87. He lived at 12 Wellesley Avenue.

title: Toure Steers Strict Course for Guinea
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Oct. 14 The socialist Government of Guinea once sponsored a bas ketball team to compete with neighboring West African coun tries. While the other teams de voted most of their time to practicing, the Guinean players spent long afternoons in a party school, studying social theory instead of dribbling and shoot ing.

title: 3DPERIOD SURGE WINS FOR 76ERS
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 24 (UPI) Hal Greer scored 28 points, in cluding 16 in Philadelphia's 36 point third period, to lead the 76ers to a 11193 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers tonight.

title: Lieut. Gen. Stephen Chamberlin, ExHead of 5th Army, Dies at 82
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., Oct. 24 (UPI)  Lieut. Gen. Stephen J. Chamberlin, com manding general of the Fifth Army at his retirement 20 years ago and deputy to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur during World War II, died yesterday at Hoag Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Quite frankly, ever since it was pub lished last month, I had been avoiding Arno Karlen's Sexuality and Homosexu ality: A New View. I had been doing so not only because of its forbidding length and controversial subject, but also be cause I had known of Mr. Karlen some years ago as a freelance journalist and an editor on Holiday magazine. While he may have been extremely able in those trades, such a background hardly seemed to qualify him to write a book whose dust jacket advertised the definite explana tion of human sexuality, normal and ab normal. Not even professionals who had devoted their careers to the study of sex could agree on a definitive explana tion. How then could an amateur like Mr. Karlen even dare to attempt one?

title: Singer Awaits Tests
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (UPI)  Mahalia Jackson rested in the University of Chicago's Billings Hospital today, awaiting tests for a heart ailment that struck while she was on tour in Ger many. The 60yearold gospel singer was flown from Germany to Walter Reed Hospital in Washington, where she stayed for 2 days before entering Billings.

title: Siffert Killed in England As Car Burns After Crash
description: BRANDS HATCH, England, Oct. 24 (AP) Siffert, 35 yearold Swiss driver, died in the flaming wreckage of his BRM Formula I car today in a nonchampionship race.

title: Guam and Virgin Islands Bill Delayed in House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  Guam and the Virgin Islands, which have sought for years to gain representation in the House of Representatives, got caught in the long holiday weekend and the politics of sugar legis lation last week.

title: Unanswered Questions Still Surround H. Rap. Brown
description: Three years ago in the di lapidated storefront headquar ters of the Black Liberators in St. Louis, H. Rap Brown began a relationship with a group of local militant young blacks that ended, according to the police, with a bloody gun battle on a Manhattan street nine days ago.

title: Two S.I. Officials Differ on a Plan for New City
description: To hear them tell about it, the disagreement between two of Staten Island's leading politicians is really not a dis agreement at all, but a simple difference of opinion over the best way to control the borough's growth.

title: Judith Quigley Bride of John Ruse
description: Miss Judith Quigley, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Quigley of Castle ton Corners, S. I., was mar ried last evening to Lieut. John Martin Ruse, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Ruse of Syracuse, Msgr. Vin cent A. Juliah performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Teresa in Castleton Corners.

title: PIANO JUST PART OF DR. JOHN'S ACT
description: When a performer can per suede Mick Jagger to record with him as a backup singer, he has to be considered either a master sweettalker or a pretty good musician. Dr. John, The Night Tripperwho ap peared at the Beacon Theater Friday and Saturday, a few weeks after the release of his Jaggerassisted recordingis a bit of both.

title: Crash in Washington State Kills Eleven in Two Cars
description: WALLA WALLA, Wash., Oct. 24 (AP)Eleven persons were killed near here today in a two car headon collision.

title: Chiefs Rally to Defeat Redskins, 2720
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 24The Kansas City Chiefs scored three touchdowns in the second half today with a longrange pass ing attack and ended Washing ton's unbeaten status by defeat ing the Redskins 2720, before 51,989 cheering fans.

title: Bank Seeks Expansion
description: The Continental Illinois Na tional Bank & Trust Company has applied to the Federal Re serve Board for permission to organize an overseas arm in San Francisco to be known as Continental Bank International (Pacific).

title: Still Stalled on Welfare Reform
description: For two years frustration has attended efforts to translate into some form of reality President Nixon's creative program to move away from the colossal fail ure that public welfare has become. Welfare reform remains stalled on Capitol Hill while welfare recipients and taxpayers alike writhe at the shortcomings of a system that degrades those it is supposed to help.

title: Methods of British Stir Ulster Protest; 1 Killed in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 24British troops strug gling to put down guerrillas in Northern Ireland touched off new controversy today over their methods after soldiers killed three men attempting a robbery in Newry, 40 miles south of here.

title: JAMES A. NIDDS SR.
description: James A. Nidds Sr., a retired assistant chief inspector of the Pollee Department, died at his home yesterday of a heart ail ment. He was 70 years old and lived at 3530 168th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Man in the News
description: One reason that many give for the success of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People has been the organization's ability to amalgamate the elements of family, church, political group and moral crusade into a coherent, vi able whole. Dr. Eugene Tyree

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Withdrawal from the Race
description: INSTALLMENT IX

title: Waste Disposal Creating A Problem for Hospitals
description: Solid waste disposal, a long recognized problem in manu facturing, has become the bane of another industry: health services.

title: Pornography Drive Aimed at Connecticut Bookshop
description: MANCHESTER, Conn., Oct. 24A new bookstore has opened on Main Street, in the heart of this suburban New England community, and many of the townsfolk are in an up roar because they feel that some of the material being sold is pornographic.

title: Iranian Minister Says Fete Cost $16.6Million
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 24 (AP)The Royal Court Min ister, Amir Assadollah Alam, said today that Iran's 2,500th anniversary celebration had cost $16.6million, and de clared figures carried by some papers totally exaggerated.

title: Advertising:
description: Maypo is out to get a big ger bite of the hot cereal market, where the total ad vertising outlay comes to about $10 million, with a little bitty $300,000.

title: A Matter of Boundaries
description: As a longtime admirer of Hubert Humphrey and one who worked ac tively for his election in 1968, I should like to express some serious reserva tions about his prescription for the Middle East crisis [The Soviet Must Get Out, OpEd page, Oct. 6]. It would of course be very convenient to us and Israel if the Soviets would withdraw, in Whole or in part, from the Middle East. I doubt very much, however, that they could be persuaded or obliged to do so by the confronta tion approach Mr. Humphrey suggests.

title: Detroit Lions Player Dies After Collapsing on Field
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24Charles F. (Chuck) Hughes of the De troit Lions collapsed today in the closing seconds of a Na tional Football League game and died.

title: GAMMA GLOBULIN USED IN NEW WAY
description: A Chilean study of nearly 4,000 patients who received blood transfusions has shown that those who got gamma globulin along with the trans fusion were much less likely to contract a severe case of posttransfusion hepatitis.

title: BLACKS MAY LOSE IN REDISTRICTING
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 24Black Congressmen in several states fear that reapportionment may cost them their seats next year.

title: LINDSAY IN SOUTH TO ASSIST EVERS
description: LAUREL, Miss., Oct. 24 Mayor Lindsay of New York, the first major white politician to campaign here for Charles Evers, the Negro candidate for Governor, attempted tonight to turn attacks on him as a car petbagger to his own advan tage by calling for a coalition of outsiders.

title: Music:
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24Following is the poem written by W. H. Auden as a text for Hymn to the United Nations composed by Pablo Casals. It is reprinted with the permission of the United Nations, which holds the copyright.

title: The Screen: 'Is There Sex After Death?':Film Documents Quest for the Answer Movie Called Funniest Since 'Bananas'
description: There are special kinds of people, friends of mine mostly, who go to sex-lecture movies mainly for the lecture. For those, and perhaps a few more, there is now a special kind of movie. It was made by Jeanne and Alan Abel, and it opened yesterday at the Cinema Rendezvous. It is called "Is There Sex After Death?" and it is the only really funny movie since Woody Allen's Bananas." I might have pressed further and said it was the only really funny movie since "Suburbia Confidential" (1967)but nobody would have known what I meant.A documentary of sorts, the film begins at Grant's Tomb, home office of the Bureau of Sexological Investigation, from which its leader, Dr. Harrison Rogers (Alan Abel) sets out on a fact-finding tour that takes him across the breadth of America, from a Florida nudist camp to a California cemetery, always investigating and, from people of every station and any profession, always seeking answerse.g.: "Mr. Nixon, is it possible to have sex in the White House?"Sometimes the film pauses to observe natural phenomena, such as the First Topless String Quartet, or to talk with those for whom natural phenomena have created a way of life, such as the proprietor of a family-style erotic art gallery ("Parents bring their kids"). From time to time Dr. Rogers yields to other professors: the earnest and energetic Dr. Manos (Buck Henry), or the bearded, wise and gently seasoned old Dr. Elevenike (Jim Moran), who is currently "working on a course in sensuality, for young people."On one occasion the film falls prey to the temptation of a celebrity interviewHolly Woodlawn, and no match for the talent that surrounds herbut mostly it sticks with serious laborers in their fields, like Robert Downey, the director, or Richard Nixon (Jim Dixon), the President. Some of its happiest moments are spent with Vince Domino (Marshall Efron), a universal man, a filmmaker who has succeeded in exciting everyone's prurient interests and is proud to have made the first X-rated animal picture. Just hearing Vince Domino describe his work recalls us to the simple pleasure of listening to movie plots.I may have given the impression that the film is all talk and no action, and that is not true. There are many demonstrations, an extensive course in breast development (with the superb Iris Brooks as student), and the climactic contest of the International Sex Bowl. But I prefer the talk because it is of such maniacally sustained good humor that nothing that merely happens can match it.Above all, "Is There Sex After Death?" is a film that asks a questionand for its perseverance it receives two answers. One, given during a sance by the spirit of a departed garment center worker (Larry Wolf), is a satisfied "Nothing but . . ." The other answer comes during an ambulatory graveyard chat between Dr. Rogers and Rubin Carson, my favorite sequence in the movie, in which after hearing much sage sexual advice, Dr. Rogers asks, and Mr. Carson replies, "No, only affection."

title: Chess: Petrosian's Indisposition Common to Fischer Rivals
description: There is something about Bobby Fischer's winning ways that makes his oppo nents sick. The nervous ex haustion suffered by Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union last week that interrupted the original schedule of his match with Fischer for the right to play Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union marked the third straight time that one of the American's rivals in the eliminations had been taken ill.

title: PURGE IS ASCRIBED TO TRANSLATORS
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24The Ameri can Translators Association became embroiled in a bitter fight at its annual convention here today when the board of directors moved to block the presidentelect from assuming office.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 24Around Reservoir Park, Harrisburg's city answer to the Harlem playground circuit, Jimmy Jones was the magic name.

title: PUERTO RICO TIED TO WELFARE RISE
description: New York City's tremendous growth in welfare rolls has been substantially caused by Puerto Rico's welfare policy, a policy in part mandated by the Federal Government, Assem blyman Andrew J. Stein charged yesterday.

title: Missions' Main Concern Is the Gospel, Pope Says
description: ROME, Oct. 24Pope Paul VI declared today that preach ing of the Gospel should be the principal concern of the Roman Catholic Church's missions around the world.

title: TV Review
description: Story Theater comes up with a superb episode this evening at 7:30 and, from several angles, that is heart ening news for viewers con cerned about the future of imaginative programing on television.

title: EGYPT TELLS UNITS FIGHTING IS NEAR
description: CAIRO, Oct. 24  Egyptian antiaircraft missile crews along the Suez Canal have been warned by Gen. Mohammed Sadek, the Minister of War, to be vigilant because warfare with Israel is near, even near er than you imagine.

title: TYPHOON KILLS 36 IN SOUTH VIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24Typhoon Hester killed 36 persons, including three Amer icans, in South Vietnam's five northernmost provinces over the weekend, left tens of thou sands homeless and badly dam aged several American combat bases.

title: JAY G. HAYDEN, 86, OF DETROIT NEWS
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP)Jay G. Hayden, Washington corre spondent of The Detroit. News for half a century and a news paperman for 66 years, died early today. He was 86 years old.

title: Theater Owners to Meet
description: Some 1,800 members of the National Association of Thea ter Owners representing ap proximately 8,000 of the more than 13,000 movie houses in the country will attend the fifth annual convention of the organization, today through Thursday at the Americana Hotel. Special awards will be made on Thursday night to All MacGraw and Clint Eastwood

title: Crime Fought, Soviet Assured
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24The So viet Union's national police chief went on television this weekend to talk about law and order.

title: Test for the Senate
description: The irresponsible vote in the House of Representatives last week against protecting Alaska's natural heritage from depredation cannot be allowed to stand as the final decision of Congress on this critical issue. By 217 to 177, the House turned down an amendment to the Alaskan native land claims bill which would have directed the Secretary of Interior to set aside fifty million acres of publicly owned land in Alaska for study as poten tial national parks, wildlife refuges and wilderness with a final decision to be made within five years.

title: PRESIDENT URGES A REALISTIC VIEW OF HIS TWO TRIPS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24  President Nixon expressed op timism today about the pros pects for lasting peace, but warned at the same time that there are great differences between the Government of the United States and those of the Soviet Union and Communist China.

title: Unruly Movie Crowd Injures 2 Policemen
description: Two youths were arrested and two patrolmen were slightly injured yesterday af ternoon when a crowd of several hundred people be came unruly and refused to disperse from in front of a Brooklyn theater that had sold its 1,200 seats for Shaft.

title: Stars Win in Last Minute
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 24 (UPI) Glen Combs sank a jump shot with 23 seconds left and then made two free throws to night to give the Utah Stars a 119116 victory over the Pitts burgh Condors.

title: Browns Suffer a Rare Shutout
description: The Cleveland Browns en tered the National Football League in 1950 and in their third game of the season were shut out at home by the New York Giants, 60.

title: Lakers Beat Rockets, 113103
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24 (AP) Gail Goodrich and Flynn Rob inson sparked Los Angeles to a 35point fourth quarter tonight as the Lakers stopped the Houston Rockets, 113103. Goodrich scored 31 points and Robinson 23.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: For Chefs of the Grand French Homes, Credit Where Credit Is Due
description: PARIS  Ever since the guillotine was introduced as a cure for conspicuous con sumption, the rich in France have been reticent about their standard of living. Now along comes a group that complains they've overdone it. The Societe des Cuisiniers Francais wants the world to know that the very wealthy eat as well as anybody.

title: MARCOS VISITS FIVE IN MANILA STOCKADE
description: MANILA, Oct. 24President Ferdinand E. Marcos paid visit today to the prisoners' stockade of the Philippine con stabulary and talked with five of 17 political detainees who have been held without the right of recourse to habeas corpus since Aug. 21.

title: TEACHERS ARE URGED TO BE MORE POLITICAL
description: KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., N. Y., Oct. 24  The United Teachers of New York ended its founding convention today with a call for greater political action by teachers and for a revision of state certification standards.

title: EARL WILD ENHANCES KOSTELANETZ'S FARE
description: Earl Wild, a pianist who seems able to play anything easily, did some dazzling finger work Saturday night when he appeared with the New York Philharmonic to play Liszt's Piano Concerto No. 1 and Hungarian Fantasy. The works were part of a colorful program put together by Andre Kostelanetz for the first of the conductor's special Saturday Night concerts with the Phil harmonic this season. The other selections were Webern's Sum mer Breezes, Respighi's The Pines of Rome and three ex cerpts from Berlioz's The Damnation of Faust.

title: Judge Milton Pollack Weds Mrs. Erlich
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 24Mrs. Moselle Baum Erlich, widow of Isadore Erlich, was mar ried here this evening to Judge Milton Pollack of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. Rabbi Hyman Judah Schachtel performed the ceremony at the War wick Hotel.

title: U.S. Defers Reassignment Of Chief Diplomat in Cairo
description: CAIRO, Oct. 24Plans for a reassignment to Washington of the chief United States diplo mat in Cairo, Donald C. Bergus, have been postponed, it was disclosed today.

title: Reed of Militant Wing Elected To Head N.A.A.C.P. in State
description: PLAINVIEW, L.I., Oct. 24 Dr. Eugene T. Reed, a founder of the Young Turk faction of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, was elected president today of the 73 chapters in the association's New York State conference.

title: India Charges Shelling
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 24Indian officials reported today that unprovoked Pakistani mortar shelling of Indian border towns had killed at least five civilians and wounded 25. The towns were in the states of Assam and Tripura, on East Pakistan's eastern border.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Meat Prices Here Raised Illegally
description: Leading retailers in New York City illegally increased the prices of 7 out of 27 meat cuts, ranging from the poor man's pork shoulder to the more affluent family's porter house steak, since President Nixon's Aug. 15 wageprice freeze.

title: Many Accept India Count Of 9.4 Million Refugees
description: The magnitude of one of the biggest human migrations, that of East Pakistanis fleeing to India, remains in doubt but the best estimates put the number between 6.5 and 9.4 million refugees.

title: U.S. LATINS VOTE POLITICAL DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24A conference of Spanishspeaking activists voted today to create a national political action cam paign, including a permanent Washington organization to press for, legislation and act as a watchdog on law enforce ment misconduct.

title: COMPANY PROFITS UP 8% IN QUARTER
description: Corporate profits in the third quarter continued to show a determined effort to forge ahead in the face of economic problems that have impeded the recovery pace.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 24A wideeyed American lady was talking to a British politician who favors bringing his country into the Common Market. Why did it matter so much? she asked. What was the interest that Britain would serve by joining? The politician reflected for a moment and then replied:

title: Sooners' Land Grab (711 Yards) Is Unmatched in Major College Football; OKLAHOMA ROLLS WITH SIX OTHERS; Unbeaten Powerhouses Put Together Impressive Set of StatisticsIrish Fall
description: While Notre Dame suffered its annual shock and defeat at the hands of Southern Califor nia, 2814, Saturday for the first Irish loss of the season, seven of the undefeated teams continued merrily on their way in a crushing display of of fense.

title: Two Crucial Battles Not Yet Won
description: Nearly everyone now takes it for granted that, whatever else may be going wrong in our troubled world, two positive events are assured: West Germany sometime in 1972 will ratify its nonaggression treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland, and Britain will join the European Common Mar ket on Jan. 1, 1973.

title: Fund Feels a Swiss Chill As It Departs for Monaco
description: GENEVA, Oct. 24Investors Capital Trust, one of the lesser lights in the offshore mutual fund field, has been told that it was well advised when it de cided to move out of Switzer land.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Chinese Than Peking
description: The issue that faces the United Nations in its vote tomorrow on the China question has been confused rather than clarified by the pedestrian debate of the past week. A visitor from Mars listening to two out of three speak ers might have thought that the issue was whether to admit Peking. Yet the General Assembly has never been closer to unanimity on any question. Hardly a voice was raised against Peking's admission last week. Only one China issue divides the United Nations. It is whether to expel Taiwan.

title: Economic Impact of Global Politics Viewed
