description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of the nation's leading interna tional bankers took the Nixon Administration to task here last week for its tactics in negotiat ing a limitation on imports of Japanese textiles into the United States.

title: Driver Hurt by Hammer
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Oct. 24 (AP).Hax Findlay, 42 years old, Fort Wayne, was hospital ized here today after a traffic accident. The police said that the driver of the other car in volved had taken a hammer and it Mr. Findlay in the head.

title: BLOCKED PAY RISES MAY BE UNFROZEN
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24Don ald Rumsfeld, director of the Cost of Living Council, said to day that workers might be able next month to retroactively ob tain raises that were negotiated but subsequently blocked by the wageprice freeze.

title: Alberta Is Hopeful on TarSands Oil
description: EDMONTON, Alberta,With Alberta's conventional crude oil reserves declining for the second year in a row, pros pects for largescale develop ment of the Athabasca tar sands have brightened in recent months.

title: SOVIET INCREASES STUDENT STIPEND
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 24The So viet leadership today announced increases in stipends and other benefits for students.

title: CHARLES REGATTA SETS ENTRY MARK
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 The Head of the Charles row ing regatta, which is threaten ing to become to the historic river here what New, Year's Eve is to Times Square, pro duced today the biggest nau tical mob scene in its seven year history.

title: Chili May Revive an Old Mining Town
description: HOUSTON (Reuters)  The ghost town of Terlingua, once a West Texas mining center and more recently the scene of the annual world chili cooking championships, is about to rise again.

title: 3 German Soccer Players Get Life Ban for Bribery
description: FRANKFURT, Germany, Oct. 24 (UPI)A disciplinary court of the West German Soccer Federation suspended three players for life yesterday for their involvement in a bribery scandal which rocked the first division last season.

title: E. ANTHONY ERNST
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 E. Anthony Ernst, manager of market development for Newsweek magazine, died yes terday in a boating accident on Long Island Sound off Noroton. He was 52 years old and lived here at 239 Eden Road.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Oct. 25, 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Major Exchanges Are Open, Banks Shut Veterans Day
description: While banks are closed to day the New York, American and Midwest Stock Exchanges are open on Veterans Day. European and Canadian exchan ges also are open. The New York Coffee and Sugar Ex change, New York Cocoa Ex change and the New York Cotton Exchange will be closed, but the Chicago Board of Trade New York Merchantile Ex change and New York Produce Exchange will be open.

title: 2 Fleeing Prisoners Hurt
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24 (AP)Two prisoners at the Suffolk County Jail were injured tonight when they jumped off an 18foot wall to the outside street in an ef fort to escape, the police said. The prisoners were identified as Daniel LeMieux, 20 years old, of Somerville and Donald Craigie, 20, of Jamaica Plain.

title: 2 Homers Help Orioles Win Second in Row in Japan, 82
description: TOKYO, Oct. 24 (AP)Con secutive homers by Frank Rob inson and Elrod Hendricks gave the Baltimore Orioles a 30 lead in the third inning today and helped the American League champions to an 82 triumph over Japan's champion Yomiuri Giants.

title: Pakistan Reports 2 Raids; India Charges New Shelling
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 24  The Pakistan Government said its forces in East Pakistan repulsed two battalionsized at tacks today by Bengali guer rillas supported by Indian troops and artillery.

title: Casper Wins by 4 Shots, Ending His Longest Slump
description: NAPA, Calif., Oct. 24 (AP) Billy Casper brought an end to the longest slump of his career today with a fourstroke victory in the $150,000 Kaiser interna tional open golf tournament. He carded a final round of 68 for a fourday total of 269.

title: Informer Says Police Prompt Radical Acts
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24A longtime informer for the Los Angeles Police Department ap peared to offer an intriguing glimpse last week into the shadowy world of domestic es pionage against radical politi cal groups. But no one seemed quite sure.

title: White House Parley on Aging May Be Political Arena
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 With more than a year to go before the next Presidential election, politicians seem to be converting the White House Conference on Aging, scheduled for next month, into a 1972 campaign staging ground.

title: COSTIKYAN REBUTS AURELIO ATTACK
description: Edward N. Costikyan, defend ing his appointment as chair man of a task ??orce for a state commission investigating City Hall, criticized Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio yesterday and called on him to cooperate in seeking to establish a better government structure to govern our city, which needs it.

title: Knapp Urges a Permanent Body on Police Corruption to Succeed His Panel
description: Whitman Knapp, who heads the commission investigating police corruption here, called yesterday for the creation of a permanent civilian group to continue the work after his fiveman team has finished its study.

title: PENGUINS GAIN TIE WITH RANGERS,11, ON REBOUND GOAL
description: In a game that tantalized the fans, first bringing them to the edge of their seats then making them sit back in frustration, the Rangers and Pittsburgh Pen guins surprised each other with a 11 tie last night.

title: DR. I. WILLIAM MILLER
description: Dr. I. William Miller, one of the oldest alumni of the New York University College of Dentistry, died Saturday night in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 415 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Return of G.I.'s Delayed
description: SAIGON, Oct. 24 (AP) Thousands of American troops were mobilized to repair dam age estimated in the millions of dollars at three United States bases wrecked by Typhoon Hester. The bases are Chulai, the headquarters of the Amer ical Division, Danang and Camp Eagle, headquarters of the 101st Airborne Division.

title: An Artist Makes House Calls to Treat Her Ailing Works
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J. When Lillian Schwartz, the wife of a pediatrician, gets ready to call upon patients of her own, she puts into a little black bag a hypodermic needle, a bottle of methyl methacrylate, another of toluene, a soldering iron, a blow torch, some fuses and electronic parts and a small hand drill.

title: Bridge: Aces Overwhelm Mathe Team To Represent U.S. in Olympiad
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 24 The world champion Aces scored an overwhelming vic tory in the international team final playoff match which ended in the Sheraton Charles Hotel here this after noon, and so qualified to rep resent the United States in the 1972 world team Olym paid in Miami Beach. The players are Bob Goldman, Bob Harnman, Jim Jacoby, Mike Lawrence and Bob Wolf. Their nonplaying cap tain will be Lee Hazen of New York.

title: 1,200 Attend Irish Benefit
description: More than 1,200 people at tended a nonpartisan Northern Ireland Benefit Concert yester day at the Playhouse Theater, 257 West 48th Street. Proceeds of the concert are to go to peo ple of Northern Ieland, both Catholic and Protestant, who have become homeless in the dispute there, according to the Queens branch of the Irish Northern Aid Committee, the organizer of the event.

title: Swiss Takes Bike Race
description: PARIS, Oct. 24 (AP)Gilbert Bischoff of Switzerland won the Grand Prix des Nations bicycle race for amateurs to day.

title: China Debate Due to End Today; U.N. Voting Outcome Uncertain
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 24The United Nations debate on China is expected to end to morrow. Tonight the outcome was still so uncertain that the seating of mainland China as well as the possible expulsion of Nationalist China still hinged on lastminute decisions by a handful of small countries.

title: Firefight Near Kashmir Cited
description: SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 24 About 35 Pakistani and 8 Indian soldiers have been re ported killed in a series of border clashes in the Uri sector, 64 miles west of here, in the last ten days, Indian official sources said today.

title: EXPLOSION KILLS 2 IN QUEENS BAR
description: Two persons were killed and eleven other seriously injured in an explosion last night after an angry customer poured gaso line over the bar of a crowded tavern in the Hollis section of Queens and died in the ensuing blaze.

title: New Moves Are Planned to Bar Con Edison's Storm King Plant
description: Plans for new attacks in both Federal and state courts against the Consolidated Edison Com pany's hydroelectric project near Storm King Mountain at Cornwall, N. Y., were an nounced last night by the Scenic Hudson Preservation Conference.

title: Colonels Beat Floridians
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 24 (AP)Dan Issel of Kentucky scored 44 points and the Col onels held off a late Floridian rally tonight for a 116110 vic tory.

title: Advertising:
description: Here you go. Here's an op portunity to start your week on a pleasant note.

title: Antiwar Protesters Plan Washington Rally Today
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24, (UPI) Antiwar activists will gather in Dashington tomorrow to be gin what they call Phase One of a twoday plan to evict President Nixon from the White House.

title: Bulls on Top, 105104
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 24 (AP) The Chicago Bulls held off a lastditch rally by the Phoenix Suns for a 105104 victory to night. Otto Moore's jump shot just missed for Phoenix with two seconds left.

title: Pakistan Field Hockey Victor
description: BARCELONA, Spain, Oct. 24 (Reuters)Pakistan, the 1968 Olympic champion, won the first World Field Hockey Cup today with a 10 victory over Spain.

title: The Talk of the Port
description: More than 50 ships are riding at anchor in the harbor, waiting out the end of the longshore work stop page that has kept New York and all other major ports from Maine to Louisiana closed since Oct. 1.

title: Sniper, 18, and Holdup Man Are Slain by Policemen in Two Gun Battles in Harlem
description: An 18yearold sniper who had held three hostages in a Harlem tenement for nearly two hours was fatally wounded by the police yesterday in a gun battle in which 23 shots were fired. The hostages, in cluding a 75yearold man, were freed unharmed.

title: Europeans Find Economy Deterred by U.S. Moves
description: Italians call it the worst eco nomic crisis since World War II. Argentines speak of stag nation. The Germans com plain that the foundations of free enterprise are in danger. The Japanese see a recession.

title: Flying Swami Begins Pakistan Peace Flight
description: NEW DELHI, Oct. 24A 43yearold guru known as the Flying Swami took off in his small plane today on a peace mission to Pakistan where he hoped to drop leaf lets and flowers before land ing at Lahore.

title: Jersey Group Backs Lindsay
description: TRENTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) The formation of a New Jersey citizens group backing Mayor Lindsay for President was an nounced here today.

title: Public Is Found to Resist Prison Reform Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23Re form experts have been saying for more than 40 years that prisons and inmates would be better off in urban areas, but most voters, taxpayers and public officials have steadfastly felt otherwise.

title: Teheran Road Crash Kills 13
description: TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 24 (Reu ters)Thirteen people were re ported killed and 32 seriously injured when a bus and a truck collided last night about 60 miles northeast of here.

title: 4th in Row for Stars
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 24 (AP) Dean Prentice scored twice and added an assist and Mur ray Oliver collected four assists to lead the Minnesota North Stars to their fourth straight victory, by 63 over the Los Angeles Kings tonight.

title: Giants Upset;
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24  In what easily qualified as their worst performance so far, the New York Giants lost today to the previously nonwinning Phil adelphia Eagles, 237, in a heavy rain at Veterans Stadium.

title: Picasso, 90 Today, Assayed By Critic, Curator, 3 Artists
description: The immortal Picasso is 90 today. But like the least of mortals, he must endure the brush strokes of ritual wishes of good health and even longer life. Since he is also Picasso, the man who viewed the world fresh and changed it beyond recall, his portrait today is larger than life.

title: Screen: About 'Joe Hill,' Immigrant:Bo Widerberg Movie Opens at 2 Theaters Career of Unionist and His Execution Traced
description: Bo Widerberg's "Joe Hill" is intendedone must assumeas a, poetic appreciation of the song-writing Wobbly, a Swedish immigrant who was tried and convicted for the murder of a Salt Lake City grocer in 1914 and executed the following year by a firing squad in the yard of the Utah State Penitentiary.However, the movie is so irresolute in making assumption about its hero, about his drives and his dreams, and especially about his guilt, that it is scarcely an appreciation of even the mythical Joe Hill, who was resurrected in 1925 in the mighty organizer's ballad written by Alfred Hayes and Earl Robinson. Without meaning to be, I'm sure, Widerberg's "Joe Hill" is a mildly reproachful view of the manner in which a nice young man, who likes children and fresh air and music, and who has the political passions of a sincere shop steward, can be turned into a martyr by time and circumstance, with the cold collusion of some of his associates.Very little is known about the real Joe Hill, except that he was born Joel Emmanuel Haaglund, that he came to the United States about 1901 or 1902 at the age of 19, and that by 1910 he had become a member of the Industrial Workers of the World and had been active in a number of strikes and free-speech movements on the West Coast.At the time of his arrest in Salt Lake City, he was recovering from a gunshot wound, which was emphasized by the prosecution as the major point in the circumstantial case brought against him. There continues to be debate on whether or not Joe Hill was guiltyhe always declined to explain his wound on the grounds that it involved a woman's honor, which, in the film anyway, is so suddenly courtly as to be ludicrous.There seems to be, however, very little doubt that the evidence was too flimsy to justify a guilty verdict, and that his execution was a political act, on the part of both the state and Joe Hill himself who, until the end, was cheerfully helping to shape his defeat into a victory. On the night before his execution, he wired William D. Haywood, the labor leader: "Don't waste time in mourning. Organize."Widerberg, who acknowledges that very few real facts are known about Joe Hill, has chosen to organize his film as a sappily pastoral ode to a man who, as played by Thommy Berggren, has the clean-cut, utterly nonidiosyncratic character of all great menfrom Julius Caesar and Charlemagne to Stephen Foster and Alexander Graham Bellas they are profiled in juvenile literature of an inspirational nature.With the exception of the early sequences, set in a New York ghetto that is suspiciously picturesque, most of the film takes place in idyllic, fertile landscapes. Joe rides freight trains across the great abundant country, meets colorful, well-fed hoboes, and slips, more or less dreamily, into league with the Wobblies who, according to Widerberg, spend a good deal of their time trying to organize industrial workers in pretty little farming communities.Indeed, "Joe Hill," whose screenplay has all of the substance (and all of the lurching continuity) of a bad musical-comedy libretto, describes so little of the depressed life of the working community, so little of the real vitality (and violence) of the pre-World War I American Labor movement, that the movie becomes a kind of lyrical slander.In his forword to the film, Widerberg quotesfor unfortunate thematic accuracythe slogan carried by women pickets during the bitter, 10-week, 1912 textile strike in Lawrence Mass.: "We want bread and roses too." In one way or another, all of the Swedish director's movies have attempted to have their bread and roses too, most successfully in the early "Ravens End," a movie whose lovely surface solemnity is the visual equivalent to the psyche of the young working class artist within.In the subsequent "Elvira Madigan" and "Adalen '31," Widerberg's social concerns are still apparent, as they are in "Joe Hill," but now they have become the all but invisible undercarriage for a sadly frivolous movie that has teen dolled up and decorated like a Rose Bowl parade float  and with something of the same artistic impact.I suspect that Widerberg would like us to find analogies between Joe Hill's trial and some contemporary prosecutions, especially of Black Panthers, but that, it seems to me, is a presumption his movie simply is not qualified to make."Joe Hill," which opened yesterday at the Paramount and Sutton Theaters, was photographed principally in Sweden, with some locations shot in this country. Most of the dialogue is in English.

title: Cougar II Withdrawn From Turf Race
description: LAUREL, Md., Oct. 24Run the Gantlet and Chompion will be the United States repre sentatives in the 20th running of the $150,000 Washington, D. C. International at Laurel Race Course tomorrow. A field of nine will participate in the 1mile turf event, with four other countries also being rep reented.

title: Dr. J. E. Friedberg Weds Judith Rubin
description: Miss Judith Rubin, daugh ter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Rubin of Pittsfield, Mass., and Hallandale, Fla., was married here yesterday noon to Dr. Jonathan Eliot Fried berg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Friedberg of Brook lyn. Rabbi Robert Marx per formed the ceremony at the Hampshire House.

title: Personal Finance
description: Despite the recession, there's a shortage of middle managers developing. This indicates a good opportunity for many working wives.

title: Veterans' Parade Is Canceled by Rain
description: Rain and, demonstrators yes terday marred the 50th anniver sary festivities of the Military Order of the World Wars, an organization of retired officers who served in World Wars  and .

title: Dolphins Sink jets, 3014;
description: Two workhorses and a race horse stomped the New York Jets, 3014, for the Miami Dol phins yesterday at Shea Stad ium.

title: Heart Experts Ask Hospitals to Press Equipment Safety
description: A group of heart specialists has called far hospitals to adopt new safety programs for elec trical equipment, which is being used with increased frequency in direct patient care.

title: Grant Wins Seniors
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 24 (AP)Bryan (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta defeated Len Hartman of Long Island City, Queens, 75, 60, today for his sixth United States Lawn Tennis As sociation seniors title.

title: 3D VICTORY IN ROW SCORED BY FISCHER
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 24 Bobby Fischer of the United States won for the third time in succession tonight, scoring in 40 moves in the eighth game of his match with Tigran Petro sian of the Soviet Union.

title: McCarthy to Send Letters Announcing He'll Be Candidate
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 24The expected candidacy of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota for the Democratic Presidential nomination will be officially announced by Mr. Mc Carthy in a letter to 100,000 supporters to be mailed from his Washington office on Tues day.

title: Kiick and Csonka Are Slow But Sure As Ground Gainers
description: Two of the slowest run ning backs in the West, East, North and South, Jim Kiick and Larry Csonka of the Mi ami Dolphins, came to town yesterday, played a little bit of catchup football with the New York Jets, and won.

title: On Picasso's 90th
description: I remember

title: Blues Beat Sabres
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 24 (AP)A veteran defenseman, Carl Brewer, scored his first goal of the season to provide the mar gin of victory as the St. Louis Blues defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 32, tonight.

title: TEX BENEKE BAND PLAYS AT GARDEN
description: Nostalgia filled Madison Square Garden yesterday after noonmusical nostalgia of the thirties and forties. The occa sion was the Garden's second bigband festival, a followup of a similar event last spring.

title: JOFFREY CONFETTI IS WELCOME FROTH
description: In a City Center Joffrey Bal let program that dealt with the darker side of things, Gerald Arpino's ballet Con fetti stood out as a welcome piece of froth Saturday night at the City Center. It also gave Charthel Arthur an opportunity to appear as the girl in yellow for the first time.

title: FANS OF RAGTIME REPAY A BIG DEBT
description: Scott Joplin, a composer whose work is a landmark in American musical development, died in 1917. For 20 years be fore that, his compositions had been the spearhead of the pop ular music of the period, rag time. On Friday night, 54 years after Mr. Joplin's death, the first concert ever devoted to his Music was presented in the auditorium of the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. These things, apparently, cannot be rushed.

title: Capital Markets Await Treasury Financing Plan
description: The trend toward lower inter est rates slowed last week, but it didn't stop altogeher. What happens this week will largely depend on the Federal Reserve and the Treasury.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorman Advances
description: LONDON, Oct. 24 (Reuters) Tom Gorman of the United States, 1971 Wimbledon semi finalist, scored a 63, 64 vic tory over the British Davis Cup player, Gerald Battrick, today in the first round of the Em bassy open tennis champion ships.

title: BRUINS TRIUMPH OVER CANUCKS,43
description: VANCOUVER, Oct. 24 (UPI) Phil Esposito scored the de ciding goal today from scramble in front of the Van couver net, as the Boston Bruins defeated the Canucks, 43. The tally came midway in the third period.

title: States Move to Compensate Victims of Violent Crime
description: With the Governor's signa ture on a bill this month, New Jersey became the sixth state within six years to provide compensation for the innocent victims of violent crime.

title: Scholars Seeking Right Not to Disclose Sources
description: BOSTON, Oct. 24A con certed legal effort to establish for scholars the same privilege to protect confidential sources that newsmen have won in some cases is being mounted in reaction to the continuing Government investigation into the publication of the Pentagon papers.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: DETROIT, Oct. 24 (UPI) Gerry Pinder's three goals helped the California Golden Seals to a 63 victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 (AP)  Serge Bernier's third goal of the season, at 6 min utes 47 seconds of the third period, gave the Philadelphia Flyers a 21 victory tonight over the Chicago Black Hawks, the Western Division leaders.

title: GEORGE DOCK JR., 77, AN EXAUDUBON AIDE
description: George Dock Jr., an author and former public relations director for the National Audu bon Society who had long been active in advertising for finan cial houses here, died Thursday in Massachusetts General Hos pital, Boston. His age was 77.

title: Deposits Up in September At Savings and Loan Units
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (Reuters) The United States Savings and Loan League said today that new deposits for Septem ber were $6.62billion, up 33.2 per cent from $4.97billion last year.

title: BOND PRICES POST A FEW CHANGES
description: The bond market, largely shut down yesterday because most banks were closed in ob servance of Veterans Day, showed few price changes af ter a day of light trading activity.

title: MANDRILL CONCOCTS OLIO OF ROCK STYLES
description: Imagine a brewing musical cauldron in which a few cups of Santana's rhythms are stirred into jazz improvisations by the Jazz Crusaders, rock electronics by Chicago and vocals by the Chambers Broth ersthe whole batch seasoned with a little colorful showman ship from Sly and the Family Stone.

title: Women Said to Aid I.R.A.
description: BELFAST, Oct. 25 (AP)Se curity forces said today that I.R.A. guerrilla leaders, short of manpower from casualties and internment, were using young women in fighting.

title: Queens and Nassau Will Pick 4 for Assembly and 2 for Senate
description: Voters in Queens and Nassau Counties will pick four new As Semblymen and two new Sen ators in the elections next Tuesday, in lowkey legislative races that are not expected to alter the Republican party's domination of both houses of the Legislature.

title: SMALL BONN PARTY IS REDEFINING ROLE
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, Oct. 25The tiny Free Demo cratic party, battered in recent state elections yet still cocky, began a convention here today aimed at redefining its role as guardian of the middle ground in West German politics.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Because Society Won't Pay the Bill, It's Often Child Who Pays
description: Rarely is a good word said for the New York City Family Court.

title: PAPER SAYS REBOZO WON PACT ON 4TH BID
description: MIAMI, Oct. 25 (AP)The Miami Herald says that Charles G. Rebozo's land title company was given a fourth chance to bid on a lucrative Government contractand won it despite earlier lower bids by its sole competitior.

title: 4 Bar Groups Give Legal Aid to Inmates at Attica
description: Four city and state bar as sociations have appointed a committee to assign lawyers to the inmates of the Attica Cor rectional Facility who want to press civil suits against the state.

title: BREZHNEV IN PARIS, BACKED ON TALKS
description: PARIS, Oct. 25  President Pompidou and Leonid I. Brezh nev, leader of the Soviet Com munist party, agreed quickly today to begin active prepara tion for a European security conference.

title: RECEIVERS URGED IN LOAN FUND CASE
description: Two brotners who borrowed $3,376,000 to renovate eight apartment buildings under the Municipal Loan Program are collecting rents from the com pleted buildings while failing to repay their loans and inter est, the chairman of a City Council committee investigating the program told Mayor Lindsay yesterday.

title: Recurrence of Cancer Is Linked In Study to Continued Smoking
description: Cigarette smokers who con tinue the habit after being suc cessfully treated for cancer face a much greater risk of developing another cancer in their mouths, throats, voice boxes or lungs than do persons who quit smoking after suc cessful treatment, a Louisville physician has reported.

title: Court Support for Freeze Applauded by Nixon Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The decision of a United States District Court upholding the constitutionality of the 90 day wageprice freeze and the law upon which it is based will be a tremendous bulwark to Phase Two of the President's ec onomic policies, a top Govern ment lawyer said today.

title: City Hall Notes
description: Some politicians are insur ance brokers. Others are bankers. John Burns, the State Democratic chairman, is a public relations man.

title: U.S. Advisers Voicing Doubts on Saigon's Desire to Push Operation Phoenix

title: Two Substitutes, a Premiere and a Fine Concert
description: The Boston flu may be a new hierachy of viral disease (in Boston they probably re fer to it as the New York flu). Whatever it is, Michael Tilson Thomas has it, and he was unable to appear as pian ist and conductor at the opening concert of the Cham ber Music Society of Lincoln Center late Sunday after noon at Tully Hall.

title: Sports of The Times
description: After Apollo became enamored with Cassandra, he offered her a most unusual love token, the gift of prophecy. When they quarreled later on, however, he pulled a rather shabby trick on her. He left her the gift, but made it worthless by decreeing that no mortals ever would believe her forecasts.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CLAYTON, N. Y.Mist was on the river and the sun had not yet risen when Capt. James Brabant and I went forth for our second day of muskelunge fishing on the St. Lawrence River.

title: Namath Not Yet Ready To Compete, Jets Report
description: The Jets announced yes terday that Joe Namath would not compete in San Diego next Sunday. The quar terback hasn't progressed sufficiently, according to a club spokesman, to deter mine when he will be restored to the roster.

title: SAIGON SPEEDS AID TO TYPHOON VICTIMS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 26 (AP)  South Vietnam's Government took steps yesterday to aid victims of Typhoon Hester as officials reported 103 persons dead or missing and described the dam age as catastrophic.

description: General Motors, Ford, Chrys ler and American Motors yes terday reported dealer sales of passenger cars for the latest 10 day sales period.

description: PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 25South Africa's secur ity police raided the homes of churchmen, university teachers, student leaders and newsmen over the weekend in what was described as a nationwide drive against subversion.

title: New Democratic Coalition Is Distressed by Some of Lindsay's Endorsements
description: The New Domocratic Coali tion, which helped reelect Mayor Lindsay in 1969, criti cized him yesterday for giving his endorsement around the country to local Democratic candidates who have not been progressive and liberal.

title: STOCKS DECLINE ON BROAD FRONT
description: This stock market is assum ing the very worst, a broker declared yesterday as he gazed at the misting rain in the finan cial district. But Wall Street always overdoes it.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 There is no hard proofjust a general feelingbut Gov ernment officials involved in combating drug abuse be lieve that the use of hard durgs in this country, which has been spiraling upward in the last few years, may have peaked. The State Department plans to announce soon that improved intelligence has led to a star tling increase in the amount of heroin seized at the borders in the last year. Officials there, in the Treasury Department and in other agencies also are encouraged by what they be lieve has been an effective Government propaganda cam paign against drug abuse.

title: ThirdQuarter Volume a Record $1.9Billion Freeze Is Backed
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25The Chrys ler Corporation reported today that thirdquarter sales were a record $1.9billion and net in come was $6.2billion or 12 cents a share.

title: GIANTS DESPERATE TO MAKE A TRADE
description: The New York Giants have until 4 P.M. today to make a trade. They did not succeed in making one yesterday, despite a big phone bill run up by Jim Trimble, their personnel di rector, and the league deadline takes effect today, after all teams have completed six games. Their greatest need, ac cording to Coach Alex Webster, is a defensive tackle.

title: ALBERT J. BELIVEAU SR.
description: RUMFORD, Me., Oct. 25  Albert J. Beliveau Sr., a retired justice of the Maine Supreme Court, died Saturday in the Maine Medical Center, Port land, after a brief illness. He was 84 years old.

title: HENRY HEMPSTEAD
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 25  Henry Hempstead, assistant to the superintendent of public schools here, died Saturday in New York Hospital after a long illness with a heart ail ment. His age was 49.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CLOSE DAY MIXED
description: An early loss of 3 cents a bushel in soybean futures Was nearly erased in a late rally on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. As a result, the prices of these futures closed mixed.

title: Hope Voiced by U.S. Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 State Department officials said today that they remained hope ful that India and Pakistan would refrain from hostilities. They tended not to attach much importance to reports from Pakistan of fighting in the Eastern Region but to see more significance in Prime Minister Indira Ghandi's de cision ?? make her trip to the West as schduled.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Bars Provocation
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 25 (Reuters) Prime Minister Gandhi, prais ing her people's restraint, said here tonight that India would do nothing to provoke war.

title: City Bank's Head Favors Devalued Dollar, If Needed
description: TOKYO, Oct. 25The chair man of the First National City Bank, Walter B. Wriston, said today that President Nixon for mally should devalue the dol lar if that were necessary to induce other nations to increase the values of their currencies.

title: Holiday
description: The Stock Exchange was open, but the banks were closed. Public schools were closed and so was the public library. Most stores were open. In short, it was Veterans Day, another of those semidemiholidays which commemorate no specific event in history and which nobody quite knows what to do with.

title: BankRobbery Suspect Held
description: Melvin Shuman, 35 years old, of 2665 Homecrest Avenue, Brooklyn, was charged with armed robbery of the Empire National Bank office in Pomona on Oct. 8. Yesterday after he surrendered to agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation at the offices of The Daily News. Three men armed with handguns and a sawedoff shot gun held up the bank and escaped with about $17,000 in cash. A gas station manager who confronted the robbers as they made their escape was shot in the head and body and seriously wounded.

title: The Meeting With Premier Kosygin at Glassboro, N.J.
description: AFTER the sixday war be tween the Arabs and Is raelis in June, 1967, as the United Nations tried to find a permanent settlement, we learned that a large Soviet delegation headed by Kosy gin was coming to New York for the U.N. meeting. After his trip was publicly announced, pres sures increased on me, from Senators and others, to work out a meeting.

title: Small Business
description: Leo Martin got in an awful rut a while back. Like every other businessman in this in flationary era, his costs were galloping upward and the prof itabilityindeed the very ex istence of the cafeteria he op erates at 515 Seventh Avenue at 38th Streetwas threatened. This was no small matter to him because he not only, op erates Dubrow's cafeteria in the garment center but since last October he has owned 30 per cent. Every time my costs went up, I would try to pass it onto the customer. Each time I raised my prices I served fewer and fewer customers, he ex plained.

In the case of China, basic power realities and conflicts re main. Furniture sales at retail are showing their best gains in several years, merchants from across the country reported here at the opening of the Southern Furniture Market which continues through Friday. title: Screen: Arrabal's 'Viva la Muerte'
description: Having seen and disliked Alexandro Jodorowsky's screen adaptation of an early Arrabal play, "Fando and Lis," and having duly noted the symbols of horror, the rituals of disgust, the obligatory and unfelt eroticism, and the pervasive allegory, I was in no way prepared for Fornando Arrabal's own first film, "Viva la Muerte," in which those elements reappearbut charged now with an intensity and a complex vitality that I have not seen equalled in recent cinema, especially not in any recent cinema of the absurd. "Viva la Muerte" ("Long Live Death") has begun a series of midnight screenings at the St. Marks Cinema and, though no perfect movie, it seems to me inescapably a major work.Its hero (Mahdi Chauch), a young boy, is also named Fando, and its story closely parallels the early life history of Fernando Arrabal, whose mother betrayed her leftist husband to the Fascists during the Spanish civil warand who taught her son that his father was dead, whereas in fact he was miserably imprisoned. Fando searches for his father and never finds him, as Arrabal never found his, but he remembers him and imagines his fateand in a series of harsh monochrome fantasy passages, memory and imagination largely define the unique life of the film.The imagery of "Viva la Muerte"the defecation, self-mortification, strange and unusual punishmentreads like an illustrative footnote to some Surrealist manifesto. It is as if the famous razor across the eyeball that opens Bunuel's "Un Chien Andalou" had never lost its cutting edge, its sharp capacity to peel back fair surfaces and reveal the soft sources of corruption underneath. As an esthetic program this has its limits, but within those limits it allows for insights not only of hard brilliance but also of a sometimes shockingly compassionate humanity.The enemy in "Viva la Muerte" seems not so much the Fascist state or its police, as the women who fear it and collaborate with it: the mother, an aunt, a grandmother, all in black, like ministers of death, and yet in mourning for the suffering caused by their own ministry. The mourning is genuine, as is the crueltyand it is Arrabal's great distinction not to undercut the one by the other, but rather to hold each in balance so that no contradictory impulse is lost on us. He is fortunate in having as the mother Nuria Espert, an actress of striking beauty, strong and graceful gestures and an emotional range that takes her from near frenzy to a languid sensuality without ever losing contact with a role that might seem to comprise half a dozen different characters.Near the end of "Viva la Muerte" it is discovered that Fando has tuberculosis (as Arrabal bad), and he is taken to a hospital ship and eventually operated on. From his recovery room he is abducted by a mysterious little girl, also in black, who keeps a pet turkey and whom he has known and casually tormented all through the film. A captive now of his own sweet bitter fate he is wheeled off into a part of the gorgeous arid landscape that is the film's locale. And by, and girl, and great improbable bird enter a configuration that outlasts the generations and is not explained but is somehow understood as an emblem of unending torture and delight.

description: The owner of a Queens gro cery store who has shot and killed two robbers and wounded four others in the course of seven holdups since opening his business a year ago, shot and killed another suspect yester day.

title: 35 ARE RELEASED IN TAIWAN AMNESTY
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 25 The Government today released 35 political prisoners, including Chen Yuhsi, a 32yearold for mer graduate student in econom ics at the EastWest Center of the University of Hawaii.

title: Einstein Medical Post Filled
description: The appointment of Dr. Neal S. Bricker, an expert in kidney diseases, as professor and chairman of the department of medicine at Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University was announced yesterday. Dr. Bricker, who is presidentelect of the American Society of Clinical Investigation, is a member of the executive com mittee of the National Kidney Foundation and treasurer of the International Society of Ne phrology.

title: Milton S. Fox, Editor, Is Dead; Official of Art Book Company
description: Milton S. Fox, editor in chief and vice president of Harry N. Abrams Inc., artbook publish er, died early yesterday at his home, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old and lived at 160 Riverside Drive.

title: CLARK TO REJOIN BULLETS TONIGHT
description: Archie Clark and Earl Mon roe, the Baltimore Bullets' starting backcourt duo, went their separate ways yesterday. Clark said he would rejoin the Bullets in Milwaukee tonight for their National Basketball Association game against the Bucks. Monroe held firm to his demands that he wants to be traded.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25Sam Ervin and other civil libertarians no doubt will want to question William H. Rehn quist extensively on his Bill of Rights views, but no serious threat to Senate approval of President Nixon's two Supreme Court nominees is likely. A few ironies of the situation are never theless worth pointing out.

title: $8,348 Stolen From Bank
description: The North Side Savings bank on White Plains Road near 233d Street in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx was broken into last night and $8,348 stolen from tellers' drewers, the police reported. Detectives said that when they responded to a silent alarm, they found a broken window in the side of the bank.

title: RETREAT REPORTED BY CAMBODIAN UNIT
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 25 (AP)Cambodian troops fighting to hold a country road that once served as an enemy supply route have reportedly been forced into retreat south of here.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 With the vote at the United Nations tonight, China burst fully and finally from the isolation first imposed on her by the United States a gener ation ago and periodically preferred by her own Commu nist Government.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREERIST, SEA SAGA ARE JERSEY VICTORS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Oct. 25 (AP)H. P. Oliver's Careerist and Buckland Farm's Sea Saga won divisions of the Vineland Handicap for fillies and mares before a crowd of 21,033, at Garden State Park today.

title: MAXIM CAPTURES OPEN JUMP EVENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  Maxim, a failure in his first ap pearancce in the United States last week, found the right an swers tonight and won the first international open jumper event for Argentina at the Washing ton International Horse Show.

title: BRITISH SUPPRESS ULSTER CAMP RIOT
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 25Four guards were Held hostage when prisoners at an internment camp rioted to night. They were later released unharmed.

title: Pakistanis Report 501 of Foe Killed In Eastern Area
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 25 The Government reported to night that its forces had killed 501 enemy troopsdefined as Indians and Indian agents in heavy fighting in East Pakistan.

title: PAUL H. TERRY, 84, DREW TERRYTOONS
description: Paul H. Terry, a pioneer in animated cartoons whose Ter rytoons gave the world such creations as Farmer Alfalfa, Mighty Mouse and Heckle and Jeckle, died yesterday at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. Mr. Terry, who made his home at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y., was 84 years old.

title: Voting Since '50 On China Question
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25Following are the votes on questions relating to China representation since they first came before the United Nations in 1950.

title: Capital Group Buys Condors; Team to Stay in Pittsburgh
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) A Washington area business group announced tonight it had purchased the Pittsburgh Con dors of he American Basketball Association, subject to league approval.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DIARY OF ANAIS NIN: Volume 4, 1944 47. Edited and with a preface by Gunther Stuhlman. 235 pages. Harcourt Brace Jov anovich. $7.50.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam Declines to 202,000
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)The United States command announced today that American troop strength in South Vietnam dropped by 4,000 men last week, bringing the force still remaining to 202,000.

title: Steinberg Recital Delayed
description: The piano recital scheduled by Michael Steinberg for to night had been postponed until Jan. 6, because of an injury to the artist. Tickets for tonight will be honored on the future date.

title: Bridge: Young Players Take Titles In Metropolitan Tournament
description: Young players captured most of the titles in the Metropolitan Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, which ended at the New York Hilton last night. Among them were Steve Goldstein and Ken Lebensold of New York, winners of the threesession open pairs, Judi Solodar and Amalya Kearse of New York, winners of the women's pairs, and Michael Rosmarin of Roslyn, L.I., and Robert Yellis of Great Neck, L.I., winners of the men's pairs.

title: Use of City Funds to Take Sides In Election Issue Is Criticized
description: Two City Councilmen charged yesterday that city of ficials had improperly used taxpayers' funds to promote passage of the community de velopment amendment to the State Constitution that will ap pear on the ballot on election day.

title: Miami Mayor Praises Lindsay but Stops Short of Endorsing Him
description: MIAMI, Oct. 25David Ken nedy, the Mayor of Miami, stopped short today of endors ing Mayor Lindsay of New York for the Democratic nomination for President but praised him as a man who knew more about urban prob lems than anyone else in teh country.

title: International No Windfall For OTB or for the Bettor.
description: Yesterday's $150,000 Wash ington D.C. International in Maryland caused an intriguing, if moderate, stir of interest here among offtrack bettors.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Banks were closed in observ ance of Veterans Day yesterday, and there was no trading in United States Government bonds. Foreignexchange mar kets also were closed. Because of the closing of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, the New York Cocoa Exchange and the New York Cotton Exchange, there was no futures trading in sugar, cocoa, coffee, copper, orange juice and silver.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, OCT. 25  From time to time, in response to reader de mand for more fuel for paranoia, this space will be filled with Hot From the Feedbag, the infamous syndicated column by Albert Bustard, which specializes in inside information, ma licious rumor, character assassination, breezy assertion and random mendac ity. Mr. Bustard's first column fol lows.

title: Shy Roth Emerges: New Book and Play
description: He strides toward an in conspicuous table in the back of the carpeted lounge of the Algonquin Hotel, seem ingly confident that his tweedy appearance and bushy black mustache will go un noticed in the plush Victorian setting.

title: Merger News
description: A merger or consolidation of the U.S. Smelting, Refining and Mining Company and the Federal Pacific Electric Com pany is under consideration by directors of the two companies, it was announced yesterday. U.S. Smelting recently com pleted the purchase of about 986,700 shares of Federal Pacific at a cost of about $20.7mil lion. This raised its holdings from 42.6 per cent to about 85.7 per cent. The announcement said each company will retain in vestment bankers to advise on terms and methods for the pro posed amalgamation. Directors of both concerns will meet again within the next three weeks on the possible consoli dation.

title: Edward J. Clark Is Dead at 74; City's Water Supply Engineer
description: Edward J. Clark, former chief engineer of the city's Bureau of Water Supply, died of a heart attack yesterday at the age of 74. He lived at 675 Walton Avenue, the Bronx.

title: 3 Missing After Explosion
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 25 (UPI)Three men were re ported missing and three others injured today when 2,000 pounds of dynamite exploded and destroyed a building of the Independent Explosives Com pany in nearby Suscon. The missing were identified at Donald Apple of Suscon, Mar lin B. Umbach of White Haven and John Lopata of Dupont.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) The White House said today that Henry A. Kissinger had remained an additional day in Peking and would return here Tuesday afternoon to report to President Nixon on arrange ments for the President's forth coming visit to China.

title: DDT's Fate May Be Sealed Soon as Long Fight Over Pesticide Nears Series of Key Decisions
description: The fate of DDT in the United States may be deter mined soonperhaps by Mon day, but apparently no later than the start of the next spring planting season.

title: By Lyndon B. Johnson: First Steps Toward Peace
description: INSTALLMENT X

title: Nevele Freight Wins Pace at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Oct. 25 Nevele Freight, the wrong half of the entry from the Stanley Dancer stable, captured tonight's New York Sire Stakes onemile test for 2yearold pacing fillies at Yonkers Raceway. Walter (Pee wee) Welch, driving Nevele Freight, a daughter of Romeo Hanover, saved the bankroll for the chalkplayers, who had fig ured on Verna Rainbow, a Tor pid lassie, to win her seventh in a row.

title: Fischer Is Talk of Manhattan Chess Club
description: At the Manhattan Chess Club these days, the talk is all of Bobby Fischer. At the moment, Fischer is happily eating up Tigran Petrosian in Buenos Aires, and needs only one more point to win the match and the right to play Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union for the world cham pionship.

title: Postman Finally Rang for Phelps
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 25  On Oct. 30, 1965, the new head basketball coach at St. Gabriel's High School in Hazleton, Pa., mailed a personal, handprinted letter to Ara Parseghian, the Notre Dame football coach.

title: C.I.T., in Wall St. Talk, Cites a 17% Profit Gain
description: The C.I.T. Financial Corpora tion, the parent company of a $3.5billion financial  services conglomerate, reported yes terday a sharp increase in net income for the third quarter as well as the first nine months of 1971.

title: G.I. Beaten by Civilians After Danang Traffic Crash
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 25 (AP)An American soldier was severely, beaten Sunday by an angry mob of Vietnamese civilians in DaNang and his vehiele was firebombed after it colided with a motor bike and injured two South Vietnamese, the United States command said.

title: McMurry Drops Football Aid
description: ABILENE, Tex., Oct. 25 (UPI) McMurry College, a Metho dist institution of 1,605 stu dents, announced today it was abandoning its scholarship ath letic program in football and track but would continue it in basketball.

title: Small Weather Station Developed by Air Force
description: ANDREWS AIR FORCE BASE, Md., Oct. 25 (AP)The Air Force Systems Command has developed a miniature automatic weatherreporting station that can be dropped from aircraft into battle fields, inaccessible terrain or remote areas.

title: HUGHES SUFFERED A HEART ATTACK
description: DETROIT, Oct. 25  An au topsy disclosed today that a heart attack had caused the death of Chuck Hughes, the 28 yearold wide receiver for the Detroit Lions.

title: Market Place: Why Wall St. Sold Wrigley
description: If the small shareholders of William Wrigley Jr. swal lowed their Doublemint yes terday, nobody could blame them.

title: Philadelphia Unions Found in Contempt For Dock Walkout
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 (AP) A Common Pleas Court judge found three locals of the Inter national Longshoremen's Asso ciation in contempt of court today for noncompliance with his injunction against a strike that shut down the Port of Philadelphia for 25 days.

title: Death of Buddy Stuns Maynard
description: After the Jets' game Sunday, Don Maynard was driving to Gerry Philbin's restaurant in Amityville, L. I., for dinner.

title: WASHINGTON CALM
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Official Washington reacted with outward calm tonight to the crushing, American defeat in the United Nations on the China issue. But there was un certainty as to the effect the historic vote would have on future United States relations with Taiwan, the United Na tions and the Peking Govern ment.

title: Carl Ruggles, Composer, Is Dead at 95
description: Carl Ruggles, who is generally bracketed with Charles Ives as one of the pioneering composers in Ameri can history, died Sunday night in a nursing home at Benning ton, Vt. He was 95 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Kosygin, Ending 8Day Canadian Trip, Asks Mutual Confidence
description: TORONTO, Oct. 25Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin tonight ap pealed to all Canadians to join the Soviet Union in a bond of mutual confidence in the search for peace and economic prosperity.

title: Juilliard Quartet Marks 25th Year With Tully Concert
description: As symbols of durability in a shaky world, Beethoven and the Juilliard String Quartet will do. Fittingly, the Juilliard observed its 25th anniversary year Sun day night at Alice Tully Hall by opening the concert with Beethoven's Quartet in E flat (Op. 127). If there is a 50th anniversary, no doubt there will be a reprise. Age does not wither Op. 127.

title: Jess Petty, Who Pitched In Majors 9 Years, Dies
description: ST. PAUL, Oct. 25 (AP) Jess Petty, who pitched for four major league teams from 1921 to 1930, died here Saturday at the age of 76.

title: SENATORS ASK HALT IN EARMARKED AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25  The Senate Foreign Relations Committee has called for end ing the Congressional practice of earmarking special foreign aid funds for schools and hos pitals abroad.

title: College Sports Notes
description: Army will be the next foot ball team to try out the sur face of the Orange Bowl grid iron in Miami, that artificial lawn that professional teams have criticized as being too slippery. The cadets play Miami Friday night in the big arena.

title: Data Bank on the Arts Is Established
description: A National Research Cen ter of the Arts has been established by Louis Harris and Associates to collect and analyze data on the arts.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Buehler Corporation of Indianapolis an nounced yesterday that James T. Reilly, formerly vice presidentoperations of the Hamilton Standard Division of the United Aircraft Corporation, has been elected chairman, president and chief execu tive officer. John L. Buehler, who retired June 1, previously held these positions.

title: REA Express Files Suit
description: REA Express, Inc., said yes terday that it had filed a suit asking triple damages of more than $75million against the Travelers Insurance Company and 27 major railroads. The REA complaint charges that the railroads  former owners of the express companyhad caused REA to purchase group insurance coverage for its em ployes under an insurance policy already owned by the defendant railroads.

title: Dissidents in Soviet Active
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 25 Soviet dissidents sought today to use the Brezhnev visit to France to call attention their plight as the publicity surrounding the party leader's first trip to the West intensified.

title: Picasso Ignores Party For His 90th Birthday
description: VALLAURIS, France, Oct. 25 (UPI)Pablo Picasso, re fusing to be counted among the aged, ignored his 90th birthday today and refused to take part in an elaborate party given by the residents of this Riviera community.

title: OIL PROFITS SHOW A MIXED PICTURE
description: A number of major oil com panies reported earning figures yesterday, with the majority an nouncing improvements over the third quarter and first nine months of 1970.

title: WNYCFM Stereo Changes
description: The Municipal Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it has made extensive changes in its technical equip ment to permit the broadcasting of all musical programs in stereophonic sound on WNYC FM. During the 197172 season, the station said, WNYCFM plans to broadcast more than 40 live stereo concerts, includ ing the Clarion Concerts from Alice Tully Hall, the Frick Co lection Concerts and the Brook lyn Museum Concerts.

title: ExFirst Lady Gets Checkup
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP)  Mrs. Dwight D. Eisen hower was admitted to the Army's Brooke General Hospi tal tonight for an annual physi cal examination after arriving here from Dallas, officials said.

title: This Flapper Altered Fashion's Course
description: Don't worry, girls. No edict of fashion arbiters will ever swathe you in long and cumbersome shirts Long skirts, corsets and flowing tresses have gone The American girl will see to this. She is independent, thinker [who] will not follow slavishly the ordinances those, who in the past, have decreed this or that for her to wear.

title: Textile Unions Release Data On QuotaAffected Imports
description: The textile  and apparel  im port quota agreements with Far Eastern countries account for 57.8 per cent of total im ports of manmadefiber prod ucts to the United States, according to data released jointly yesterday by the Inter national Ladies Garment Work ers Union of America and the United Textile Workers Union.

title: Peking's Backers Jubliant Over Vote
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 25Salim Ahmed Salim, the young chief delegate from Tanzania, jumped to his feet tonight and led his colleagues in a victory jig in front of the Tanzanian seats in the front row of the General Assembly hall.

title: Shop Talk
description: Some people will view John Kostick's stars and spheres as he doesmathematics in three dimensions. But most people who encounter them through tomorrow in a special display arranged on Bloom ingdale's sixth floor will con sider them as decorative ob jects, Christmas tree ornaments, play things or bases for glasstopped tables, Mr. Kos tick's bronze and stainless steel wire constructions vary in height from 3 inches to 3 feet and in price from $3 to $750. There are, in addition, sev eral earring designs from $28 to $70.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts Abroad
description: STUTTGARTSixteen ma jor West German theaters, although none in the East, are in the process of staging a new play by Peter Weiss. No other play by Weissa writer of partly Jewish de scent who holds a Swedish passporthas thus far had a triumph comparable to his Marat/Sade, even though his experimental prose has been immense ly influential here. His earlier plays on Auschwitz, Vietnam and Portuguese colonialismhad merely been successes. His most recent play before the new one, Trotsky in Exile, was rather weak both as a documentary and as a drama. Now Hlderlin, whatever its qualities and shortcom ings, is truly a major event, a play about the poet Fried rich Hlderlin.

title: SMITH, ROSEWALL AND RIESSEN LOSE
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 25 (UPI)Stan Smith, Ken Rose wall and Marty Riessen were upset today in the $48,000 Wembely opens tennis tourna ment.

title: ColorTV Homes Gain
description: The National Broadcasting Company estimated yesterday that 50.1 per cent of homes in the United States, or 31 million housing units, are now equipped with color television sets. At the end of 1969, it was 32 per cent.

title: Court Is Asked to Doom Former Egyptian Official
description: CAIRO, Oct. 25  Egypt's prosecutor demanded the death penalty today for Lieut. Gen. Mohammed Fawzi as the former Minister of War went on trial on charges of high treason for collusion in a challenge to President Anwar elSadat last May.

title: A Front of Catholic Dissenters Is Formed by 38 Groups in Italy
description: ROME, Oct. 25  Thirty eight progressive Roman Cath olic communities and groups have formed a front for dis sent and independence from the church hierarchy.

title: 32 Senators Urge Full Backing of U.N., EvenWithout Taipei
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 Thirtytwo Senators expressed support today for continued full United States participation in the United Nations even if Nationalist China lost its seat.

title: Thant Cables Peking
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Tuesday, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Secretary General Thant cabled to Peking today the text of last night's resolution admiting Pe king to the United Nations and expelling the Nationalists. A spokesman said the cable was addressed to the Chinese For eign Ministry.

title: Canners Petition F.D.A. For Stiffer Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (UPI)  The canning indus try called today for stricter Government regulation of canneries to prevent crises akin to last summer's dis covery of deadly botulinum bacteria in canned soup.

title: Mr. Hoffman's Seedbed
description: In order to build a united Europe, Paul G. Hoffman once said, you first have to build Europeans. In pursuit of this ideal, now seemingly near fulfillment, Mr. Hoffman as head of the Marshall Plan for European recovery after World War II stressed selfhelp and cooperation among Europeans to solve their common problems.

title: China in the United Nations
description: The admission of Communist China to the United Nations is a historic step that was long overdue; but the way in which this act was accomplished reflected little credit on the U.N., did deep injustice to a member government in good standing and could, if regarded as a precedent, be dangerous to other states in the future.

title: Con Ed Gains
description: The Consolidated Edison Com pany reported yesterday gains in revenues and net income for the nine and 12 months ended Sept. 30. The giant New York utility said operating revenues for the nine months were $977, 695,867, a record, against $811, 006,728 a year earlier.

title: TAIPEI CLINGS TO AFFILIATE TIES;
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 26  President Chiang Kaishek of Nationalist China denounced the General Assembly today for having voted Communist China into the United Nations and said his Government would never recognize the validity of this illegal action.

title: G.E. IS OPTIMISTIC ON 1971 EARNINGS
description: The General Electric Com pany views the present year as shaping up to be a fair to good year with earnings im proving on last year's levels, Fred J. Borch, chairman and chief executive officer, told newsmen prior to yesterday's annual stockholder information meeting at Houston.

title: China Rich in Ore Deposits
description: TOKYO (AP)  Geological studies show that mainland China's deposits of tungsten, tin, molybdenum, antimony, zinc, manganese, aluminum and lead rank among the largest in the world, Peking's New China News Agency, reported.

title: Albania Hails Result As Major Blow to U.S.
description: TIRANA, Albania Oct. 26 (Agence FrancePresse)The decision to admit Communist China to the United Nations was welcomed here today as historic, a great victory for China and a serious defeat for the United States.

title: 300 Arrested in Antiwar Protest Near White House
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 More than 300 antiwar demon strators were arrested a block from the White House tonight when they sat down in the middle of Pennsylvania Avenue at the height of the evening rush hour.

title: AIRPORTUSE CURB VOTED IN SUFFOLK
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., Oct. 26 The Suffolk County Legislature today, took a major legislative step toward preventing the de velopment of the Suffolk Coun ty Airport at Westhampton into a jetport.

title: Samuel Starobin Is Dead; Coat Manufacturer, 63
description: Samuel Starobin, president of Samuel Starobin, Inc., a coat manufacturer at 265 West 37th Street, and vice president of the New York Coat and Suit Association, died yesterday at University Hospital after a long illness. He was 63 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Bulls Top Blazers, 123111
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 26 (AP)The Chicago Bulls open ed a 28point lead in the first half and then coasted to a 123 111 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers tonight.

title: Fischer Beats Petrosian to Gain Right to Play Spassky for Title
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 26 Bobby Fischer of the United States defeated Tigran Petro sian of the Soviet Union for the fourth straight time tonight, winning their chess match and the right to play the world champion for the title.

title: WRVRFM Will Broadcast All of the Knapp Hearings
description: Radio station WRVR, the only radio outlet that has been carrying the Knapp Commission hearings on police corruption live, will rebroadcast the entire proceedings in a 27hour mara thon program, beginning at 7 A.M. Saturday and ending at 10 A.M. Sunday.

title: VIRUSLIKE SPECKS IN HUMANS' MILK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 About 100 American women with family histories of breast cancer have been found to carry particles in their milk that appear indistinguishable from viruses that cause breast cancer in mice, a specialist in virus research said here today.

title: MRS. LARRY LOWENSTEIN
description: Mrs. Larry Lowenstein, the former Muriel Weingast, wife of a press agent, died last eve ning of cancer in Doctors Hos pital. She was 49 years old and lived at 1035 Fifth Avenue.

title: Women Golfers: They're Shedding the Tugboat Annie Image
description: If you were a woman who played golf for a living, would you rather (A) risk, being called a sex object by your sisters in women's lib, or (B) keep the same old Tugboat Annie image that's been around since the first woman pro picked up a putter?

title: Excerpts From Secretary of State Rogers's News Conference on Assembly's Vote on China
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Following are excerpts from a news conference by Secre tary of State William P. Rogers today on the result of the United Nations vote on the representation of China:

title: Man in the News
description: The Tanzanians danced in jubilation, and other dele gates cheered and clapped.

title: A Controversial Call
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI)  A controversial goaltending call with four seconds to play to night gave the Houston Rockets a 104103 victory over the De troit Pistons in a national bas ketball association game. It was their first triumph of the season.

title: Shop Talk
description: What distinguishes the col lection of 30 furniture de signs introduced recently by the Handex Corporation, a Federally sponsored crafts program, is the provincial character of all the pieces. Both the woods (mountain chestnut and weathered barn siding and the finishes (handrubbed oil and untreated) establish the country character of all the designs. The collection represents an unusual mix of periods that might be broad. There are chairs and a settee in Spanish Renais sande. Queen Anne, Chippen dale, American Empire and modern styling. Tables and chests echo East Indian, 17thcentury English, Italian 18thcentury and American Shaker designs. Prices range from $35 for a tray to $700 for a 9footlong desk.

title: Amex Prices Decline as Rally Fails to Last
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower yester day in steppedup trading, after selling pressure in the after noon erased earlier gains.

title: Shipping Line Drops Taiwan
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26 (UPI)A Japanese shipping line today canceled its contract to pro vide a youth ship for a good will visit of Japanese young sters to Taiwan. Officials of the line, Shosen Mitsui, said that the parent company, MitsuiOsk Lines, had reached an agreement with the Chinese Communist Government to open service to the Chinese mainland

title: Article 3  No Title
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Nationalist China suspended diplomatic relations with Belgium today after the announcement that Brussels had agreed to open diplomatic ties with Peking.

title: CAFE OPERATOR KILLED IN HOLDUP
description: The operator of a restaurant in a Queens motel was shot and killed during a holdup last night.

title: Poles to Aid Private Farms in Move to Spur Output
description: WARSAW, Oct. 26Poland's Parliament today approved a farreaching agricultural reform program intended to assist the nation's private farmers.

title: KNAPP UNITHEARS OF POLICE DEALS IN HARLEM DRUGS
description: A former policeman who ac knowledged he took up to $1,500 a month in bribes charged yes terday that policemen in Har lem paid off their informants with heroin in return for such stolen goods as suits, cigarettes and whisky.

title: Market Place:New Way to Cut Brokers' Rates
description: When Sam Skurnick was 16 in the Depression year 1936, he opened a stand at Battery Park, offering a look at the amazing world of living microbes in a drop of water.

title: 101 Labor M.P.'s Urge Jenkins To Vote Against Market Entry
description: LONDON, Oct. 26Growing Labor party pressure on mem bers who favor entry into the Common Market reached a peak tonight with a direct move against Roy Jenkins, the party's leading market opponent.

title: Sentiment Developing in Congress to Reduce Financial Support to U.N. Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26In an emotional, often angry re action to the expulsion of Na tionalist China from the United Nations, a strong sentiment de veloped in Congress today to reduce American contributions to the organization's various agencies.

title: 'Twas a Braw Nicht at the Plaza
description: A band of authentically elegant Scots, mostly kilted peers and clan chieftains from the better Highlands, were at the Plaza Hotel with pipers last night making an awful racket.

title: Stage: Philip Roth's Unlikely Heroes
description: Problems of Jewish iden tity in Columbus's new found land are the central matter of Unlikely Heroes: 3 Philip Roth Stories, which opened at the Plymouth Theater last night. These japes of Roth all find their key in the juxtaposition of an old order and old loyal ties with a new world.

title: Fighting Addiction
description: A number of the 56 mem ber voluntary, nonprofit hos pitals of the United Hospital Fund have be gun to fill the need for comprehen sive programs designed to treat the massive prob lem of drug addiction in New York City. The most debili tating kind of addiction is heroin addiction. Because the addict needs doses of the drug every few hours, heroin consumes not only his health but also every aspect of his personal life.

title: 4 CHOICES IN ROW WIN AT AQUEDUCT
description: Followers of form had just cause to celebrate at Aqueduct yesterday as four straight choices romped home first.

title: Midwest Exchange Qualifies Approval For Membership
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Midwest Stock Exchange told the Securities and Ex change Commission today that no organization should be per mitted to be a member of any exchange unless it performed either a brokerage or a market making function on the ex change.

title: Weyerhaeuser Net Lags;
description: Septemberquarter net in come of the Weyerhaeuser Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers of paper, lumber and other forest prod ucts, was down 14 per cent from the 1970 period, the com pany announced yesterday.

title: High Court Backs A Penalty Clause Of the Taylor Law
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26A provision of New Yorw State's Taylor Law that permits offi cials to dock the pay of public employes who stay away from their jobs on strike passed a test in the United States Su preme Court today.

title: Faulkner Outlines Ulster Reform Plans
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 26The Government pre sented its preliminary plans to day for a possible enlargement of Northern Ireland's Parlia ment and suggested how elec ticin procedures might be re formed.

title: RESERVE UNIT URGED LESS MONEY GROWTH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (Reu ters)The openmarket com mittee of the Federal Reserve Board voted unanimously at its July 27 meeting to work to moderate money growth, the Federal Reserve reported to day. Details of the meetings customarily are disclosed about three months after they are held.

title: M'NEIL OF GIANTS SENT TO REDSKINS FOR 3 DRAFT PICKS
description: The Washington Redskins, one of the National Football League leaders in player deals as well as winning percentage this year, made another trade yesterday. They acquired Clif ton McNeil, wide receiver, from the Giants for Washing ton's fifth, sixth and seventh draft choices in 1972.

title: 2 Groups Oppose Federal Insurance On Health as Costly
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Two major lobbying groups representing smallbusiness men and farmers told the House Ways and Means Committee today that they oppose compul sory national health insurance.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Heath Criticizes Kennedy
description: LONDON, Oct. 26 Prime Minister Heath today dismissed as an ignorant outburst Sena tor Edward M. Kennedy's call for immediate withdrawal of all British troops from Northern Ireland.

title: Ortiz Plans Comeback In Boxing Next Month
description: Carlos Ortiz, former world lightweight boxing champion, will return to the ring next month for the first time in two years.

title: Blue Wins American League's Cy Young Award
description: Vida Mile was named the winner of the Cy Young Award yesterday as the best pitcher in the American League and became the youngest player in baseball history to be elected.

title: Rails' Earnings Are Mixed
description: Two of three of the nation's biggest and most profitable railroads reported yesterday sharply improved earnings for the third quarter, while the third, the Southern Railway, which regularly pays more in taxes to the Federal Govern ment than any of the 76 big lines, reported a slight dip in its profits for the period, re flecting an 18day strike.

title: Chaparrals Acquire Hill
description: DALLAS, Oct. 26 (UPI)The Dallas Chaparrals today ob tained Simmie Hill, a 6foot 7inch forward from West Texas State, who last played with the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Associa tion. Hill had cleared N.B.A. waivers. To make room for Hill, Dallas placed Ron Sanford on waivers.

title: Idyllic Island 50 Miles From Coast Is Picture of What Vietnam Might Be
description: PHUQUY ISLAND, South Vietnam, Oct. 21The surf of the South China Sea breaks on the black volcanic rock and gently flows to the white beaches. The palm trees, heavy with coconuts, lean slightly with the breeze. The South Vietnamese who live in this idyllic setting 50 miles from the mainland worry not at all about the Vietcong but about market ing their fish, educating their children, caring for their sick, fixing the leaky roof on village headquarters and building an airstrip some day.

title: AMTRAK OPPOSES A HIGHER SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Executives of Amtrak, the rail passenger corporation, found themselves in the position to day or fighting off offers of an even larger subsidy than they requested from the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: A Gypsy Cab Driver Accused of Attack On Policeman Here
description: A gypsy cab driver was held in $50,000 bail in Criminal Court yesterday for allegedly shooting at a policeman who was driving the suspect to a police station for questioning.

title: Tito and Foreign Minister Heading for Washington
description: BELGRADE, Yugolsavia, Oct, 26 (UPI)President Tito left today on a trip that will take him to Canada and to Washing ton for talks with President Nixon.

title: METHOD TO THWART DISK PIRATES SHOWN
description: A new concept designed to foil record pirates, who report edly deprive the industry of more than $100million in sales annually, was demonstrated yesterday at the United States Bank Note Corporation, 200 Park Avenue.

title: ROGERS CALLS OUSTER A MISTAKE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Nixon Administration today welcomed Communist China's admission to the United Nations but said that the General As sembly's decision to expel Na tionalist China was a mistake of major proportion.

title: Excerpts From City Hearings on Police Corruption
description: Following are excerpts from testimony given yesterday before the Knapp Commis sion during its sixth day of Public hearings.

title: This Book Might Even Help Bacchus Find His Way Around the Vineyards
description: With the flavor of the grape to cheer their enterprise, a team of moderately bibulous Britons has finally put wine on the map.

title: Stans Says Economy Needs SST More Than Clean Air
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The supersonic transport, the transAlaska pipeline and phos phate detergents are needed more for the economy than is clean air, Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans said today.

title: Canada to Honor Herve Filion
description: YONKERS, Oct. 26Herve Filion, a man on the move, on foot, in the air or in a sulky, has been the recipient of so many honors he has lost count of them. As the North American harness driving champion over the past three years (he's head ed for his fourth straight), the FrenchCanadian ace from Angers, Quebec, has been honored in numerous countries and has worn his laurels well.

title: Bonn Hails U.N. Action
description: BONN, Oct. 26  The West German Government today wel comed Communist China's ad mission to the United Nations as an event corresponding to political realities and the in ternational balance of power. The Government, which main tains no relations with either Peking or Taipei, refused to comment on the Nationalists' expulsion from the world or ganization.

title: Peking: Leaders Indicate Early Move to Accept Seat
description: PEKING, Oct, 26Exuberant Chinese leaders hinted strongly tonight that they would move before long to take up Peking's newly won seat at the United Nations.

title: More U.S.East Trade Is Urged
description: Pleas for greater participa tion by the United States in EastWest trade were sound ed here yesterday by a group of business executives.

title: Governor Commutes Life Term of Winnie Ruth Judd
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 (UPI)Gov. Jack Williams granted a commutation of sen tence tonight to Winnie Ruth Judd, the trunk murderess of the nineteenthirties.

title: Justice of the Peace: Vanishing Rural American Under Attack
description: REDDINGTON, Ind.Did you hear about the jus tice of the peace who kept all the unregistered bond money? Or the justice of the peace who tried to arrest a neighboring jail warden? And what about the justice of the peace who raised speeding fines so he could send his son through college?

title: Giant Mushroom Is Found
description: RALEIGH, N. C. (AP)Mrs. M. J. Brown found a 22inch long mushroom with a 6inch wide cap in a crawl space under her house. Dr. Larry Grand, North Carblina State University plant pathologist, said the amanita, which is poi sonous, is the longest of kind he had heard or read of.

title: 2 Robbers With Hostages Captured on West Coast
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 26 (AP) Two armed robbers with two terrified hostages led the police on a highspeed, 165mile chase today until they were captured and the hostages released un harmed at a sheriff's roadblock.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The proposed merger of North east Airlines, a chronic money loser, and Delta Airlines, the most profitable of the big air carriers, won Initial approval today from a staff examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The chief gain from the mer ger, wrote Arthur S. Present, the examiner, is the substitution of a strong card rler for a weak carrier.

title: Busing Foes Press House For Action on Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Busing opponents from 32 states began a threeday lobby ing effort today to force House action on a proposed constitu tional amendment that would outlaw the transportation of pupils to achieve a racial bal ance in public schools.

title: ExCity Commissioner Is Fined For Filing 2 Tax Returns Late
description: Vincent A. G. O'Connor, a lawyer who formerly served as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan and as the city's Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, was fined $1,000 in Federal Court here yesterday for failing to file his income tax returns on time for two years.

title: JET WITH 221 ABOARD DELAYED IN HAVANA
description: MIAMI, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The return of a hijacked Boeing 747 jet with 221 passengers aboard, held overnight in Havana, was further delayed today by the arrival at Jose Marti Airport of Soviet Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

title: Executive Changes
