description: The International Business Machines Corpora tion announced yesterday the election of Bart M. Stevens asa vice president. Mr. Stevens who joined in 1946 as as sale representative in Los Angeles, will continue as president of the company's office products division.

title: STEMKOWSKI GETS TESTS IN HOSPITAL
description: Pete Stemkowski, who hadn't missed a Ranger game or prac tice since suffering a mild con cussion 11 days ago, was ad mitted to Lenox Hill Hospital last night to undergo exten sive tests for recurring head aches.

title: SUPPOSE UNITAS HAD CONNECTED?
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct 26There were 118 plays in the game, but only one really mattered at the end and it was a failure because the football grazed the goal post.

title: Horse Show Adds A Carriage Event To Program Here
description: The National Horse Show will hold a carriage exhibition in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 5, Josh Barney, the Na tional's president, announced yesterday.

title: At Taipei Mission, It Was Morning After
description: The morning after at the Chinese Nationalist Mission to the United Nations was one or much movement, much discus sion and a longer than usual conference of the 25 fulltime diplomats assigned to the mis sion.

title: 19 CUBANS FLY IN FOR SUGAR TALKS DESPITE U.S BAN
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 26 Nineteen Cubans aboard a Rus sianbuilt plane flew into New Orleans without United States authorization today to attend an international meeting on sugar cane production, then rejected a State Department, order that they immediately re turn to Havana.

title: Met Revives Cosi Fan Tutte With Tightly Performing Cast
description: Difficult as it is to perform, Mozart's Cosi fan tutte is the darling of opera workshops and is usually being done by one of them around town. It thrives on intimacy and the fact that it needs only six solo sing ers. Just because it is so inti mate, the big companies pre sent it less often, but this sea son both the New York City Opera and the Metropolitan have revived it.

title: U.N. AWAITS PEKING DELEGATES;
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26  A delegation repre senting Communist China, which was voted into the United Nations last night, is expected to arrive here this week to take its seat, diplomats close to the Chinese said today.

title: Mrs. William H. Long jr. Dies; Breeder and Exhibitor of Dogs
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 26 Mrs. William H. Long Jr., a wellknown breeder and ex hibitor of dogs and one of a small group of women awarded the American Cross of Honor, died at her home here today. She was 66 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: It was a strange game that had to enthrall millions of fascinated televiewers down to the last tingling seconds. That's when the bid for a tie by the Baltimore Colts was balked on the goal line as the Minnesota Vikings clung desperately to their victiory margin in a 103 thriller. Who said that a defensive game had to be dull? It doesn't, the way these masters of the art handle it.

title: CHINA LOBBY SAYS IT WILL STILL FIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Despite the expulsion of Na tionalist China from the United Nations, what is left of the China lobby in Washington said today it would fight on.

title: Saura Describes Film Spain Banned
description: MADRIDCarlos Saura, who makes darktoned, fit fully funny pictures about the fitfully violent silences of modern Spain, has been tem porarily silenced himself.

title: RUSSIANS REPORT ON ATOM SMASHER
description: MOSCOW. Oct. 26The So viet Union disclosed yesterday that its nuclear research insti tute at Dubna had accelerated ions of xenon, the heavy rare gas, as part of a continuing ef fort to produce stable new superelements.

title: Longines in F.T.C. Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (Reu ter)The Federal Trade Com mission announced today that it had provisionally accepted an agreement by Longines Wittnauer, Inc., to limit its use of promotional games in the sale of records. The company, under the agreement, is pro hibited from using such games unless it awards all prizes and discloses the odds of winning and other information, the com mission said.

title: HOMBRE WINNER ON 4TH JUMPOFF
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26El eanor MacCowan, a newcomer to the Canadian Equestrian Team, rode Hombre to victory in the internationalopen jump er puissance (high jump) event tonight at the Washington in ternational horse show.

title: Award Winners Listed For Previous Years
description: Following are the previous winners of the Cy Young Award (until 1967, one award was given for both leagues; since then, one for each league):

title: Nationalists Pledge Battle to Keep Place in World Bank and Other U.N. Agencies
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26  Nationalist China vowed today to fight to keep its place in the World Bank and a dozen other agencies with formal ties to the United Nations.

title: BONDISSUE DRIVE STEPPED UP IN CITY
description: A new civic group and the city's five county Democratic chairmen endorsed Governor Rockefeller's proposed $2.5bil lion transportation bond issue yesterday as necessary to re tain the 30cent transit fare for two years.

title: MILLIONAIRES ASK POLITICAL REFORM
description: A group of 60 millionaires decided at a luncheon meeting here yesterday to ask Presi dential candidates to support series of Congressional, gov ernmental and campaignfi nancing reforms as the price for their contributions.

title: G.M. Quarter Net Off From 1969;
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26  The General Motors Corporation re ported today thirdquarter sales of $5.6billion and net income of $217million, or 75 cents a share, but said that profits were adversely affect ed by the wageprice freeze.

title: School Board Warned on StarGazing
description: City Councilman Howard Golden said yesterday that he would start a public campaign to remove the Board of Educa tion unless the other board members refuted their presi dent's recent advocacy of as trology as one means of pre dicting pupil behavior and improving classroom relation ships.

title: Israel Says U.S. Now Backs Egypt On a Suez Accord
description: JERUSALEM, Oct. 26Pre mier Golda Meir accused Secretary of State William P. Rogers today of having aban doned previously expressed support for Israel's negotiat ing position and of having embraced instead Egypt's principles for an interim agreement to reopen the Suez Canal.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's monthly com petitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Suns Rout Royals, 12699
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 (AP) The Phoenix Suns went on a scoring spree early and never let up, to record a 12699 vic tory tonight. Over the Cincin nati Royals.

title: Brezhnev, Pompidou in Day of Talks
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Leonid I. Brezhnev, head of the Soviet Communist party, held a sec ond day of intensive talks with president Pompidou today amid firm indications that he Would return to Moscow Satur day with a new political agree ment.

title: U.S. Steel in Loss
description: The United States Steel Cor poration, the nation's leading steel producer, reported yes terday a net loss of $10,515, 826 for the third quarter in contrast to a net income of $33,585,000, or 62 cents a share, in the three months last year.

title: GORMAN UPSETS KODES IN TENNIS
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 26 (AP)Tom Gorman of Seattle added another upset to the $48,000 Embassy tennis cham pionships today with a come back victory over fourthseed ed Jan Kodes of Czechoslo vakia.

title: G.O.P. Files Alleging Kickbacks Seized in Philadelphia Suburb
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26A special prosecutor looking into allegations of official corruption in nearby Delaware County to day seized records that al legedly show a system of kickbacks paid by county em ployes to the Republican party in the county.

title: HALPERN SAYS U.N. LAGS ON DRUG TASK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  Representative Seymour Hal pern of Queens, who recently completed a worldwide survey of traffic in narcotics, charged today that international organ izations, notably the United Na tions, were failing to meet their responsibilities.

title: UNITED NATIONS
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26 The vote to bring Peking into the Unit ed Nations and expel Taipei changes the procedures but not the realities of world politics.

title: Holmes, Chiefs' Back, Sent To Oilers for Frazier, End
description: KANSAS CITY, Oct. 26 (AP)  The Kansas City Chiefs traded a fullback, Robert Holmes, to the Houston Oilers in a National Football League exchange for a tight end, Willie Frazier. The trade also included an undisclosed future draft choice for Houston.

title: By Lyndon B.Johnson: '68 Election and Final White House Days
description: Following is the last in the series of excerpts from the memoirs of Lyndon Baines Johnson, which will be published by Holt, Rinehart & Winston on Nov. 7 under the title The Vantage Point: Perspectives of the Presidency, 19631969:

title: Prisoners Burn Down Stockade Barracks in Georiga
description: Some 100 prisoners burned a stockade barracks to the ground tonight in a disturbance reportedly touch ed off when an inmate's re guest for a home parole was denied, an Army spokesman said.

title: NETS WIN,128118, IN 2 OVERTIMES
description: TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 26Bill Melchionni broke a 112112 tie early in the second overtime with a hook shot and the New York Nets went on to a 128118 victory over the Floridians in an American Basketball Asso ciation game tonight.

title: California Supreme Court Rejects Appeal by Newton
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (UPI)The California Supreme Court turned down today an appeal by Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther party leader, to have the judge in his third man slaughter trial removed on the ground of racial prejudice.

title: BRUSSELS AND PEKING ESTABLISHRELATIONS
description: BRUSSELS, Oct, 26 (AP) Belgium and China announced today that they had established diplomatic relations and would exchange ambassadors within three months.

title: Notes on People
description: Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands made their first state visit to West Germany, where they were greeted by President Gustav Heinemann and a 21 gun salute at the Bonn air port. The visit, returning one President Heinemann made to the Netherlands in 1969, was considered a final step in the postWorld War II reconciliation between the two neighboring countries.

title: Price of Fanny May Stock Raised to $65 From $59
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (Reut ers)  The Federal National Mortgage Association an nounced today an increase to $65 a share fom $59 in the price at which it issues stock to sell ers of singlefamily mortgages.

title: Tunisian Cabinet Resigns
description: TUNIS, Oct. 26  President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia today asked his Premier, Hedi Nouira, to form a new Cabinet after its members resigned ear lier in the day. Mr. Bourguiba, at a meeting of the newly formed political bureau of the country's only party, the Neo Destour Socialist party, also ap pointed Mr. Nouira as party secretary general.

title: CONTRACT LOWS HIT BY PLATINUM
description: Platinum futures hit lows for the life of the contract yester day in steppedup trading on the New York Mercantile Ex Change. A total of 551 sales were made, up from 19 the day before.

title: FATHER C. J. STEINER ; LED U. OF DETROIT
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26The Very Rev. Celestin J. Steiner, former chancellor and president of the University of Detroit, died of cancer yesterday at the infirm ary of Colombiere College in Clarkston. He was 73 years old and lived at Gesu parish, where he had been associate pastor since 1968.

title: Walter Gillorist Dies at 42; Counsel for Mine Workers
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) Walter Gillcrist, assistant general counsel for the United Mine Workers of America, died yesterday apparently of a heart attack, at his home. He was 42 years old.

title: Grain Elevators Bulge With Record Corn Crop, as Prices Fall
description: JEFFERSON, Iowa, Oct. 26 The grain elevators and storage bins in the Middle West were bulging this week with part of the largest corn crop on record, and many farmers were facing lower market prices and the prospect of little improvement for 1972, regardless of anything the Nixon Administration may accomplish with the economy.

title: Knapp Commission Witness Decries Missed Chances to Be an Honest Policeman
description: By his own account, Waverly B. Logan had two chances to be an honest cop and failed both times.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Upholds Arms Aid
description: BRUSSELS, Oct. 26 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said here today that there was noth ing unusual in massive arms deliveries to India by the Soviet Union, as reported in the press.

title: About Motor Sports
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 There may still be some edgy spots in the twoyearold love affair between the United States Auto Club and Marl boro cigarettes, but they were diplomatically glossed over at the annual awards dinner Sunday at the Cen tury Plaza Hotel. A caricature of smoking by Mark Donohue, who does not smoke, was ac cepted in stride, and so was a hard sell by a Marlboro rep resentative. There were lots of speeches, injokes and en tertainment, but the empha sis was on all that elegant money for the drivers, with Joe Leonard taking $44,700 of it.

title: Court Upholds Proposal for Tower at Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 26 The Adams County Court denied today Gov. Milton J. Shapp's petition to bar con struction of a 307foot commer cial observation tower overlook ing the Civil War battlefield here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox Get Phils' Palmer
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The Chicago White Sox today acquired Lowell Palmer, a relief pitcher, from the Philadelphia Phillies for Bob Spence, a first baseman, and Don Bolte, a left handed pitcher.

title: Pakistan Lists Toll of 78 More In Fighting in Eastern Region
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 26 Pakistan reported today that her army continued mopping up Indian troops and agents in the Kasba area of Comilla Dis trict in East Pakistan and as serted that 78 more bodies of enemy personnel had been found.

title: Shield for Police Integrity
description: Any interference with the Knapp Commission's inves tigation into police corruption would be a gross dis service to the integrity of the Police Department and to public confidence in the police force.

title: Steamroller Tactics of U.S. Are Blamed for Defeat
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26American attempts to employ steamroller tac tics and inherent con tradictions in Washington's China policy were cited by many diplomats here today as the principal reasons for the stunning defeat suffered by the United States last night in its efforts to save Nationalist China's seat in the United Nations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Monday Night Fight
description: Nagoya, JapanRuben Olivares, 118 pounds, Mexico, knocked out Kazuyoshi Kanazawa, 118, Japan, 14 rounds.

title: Regime in Turkey, In Office 7 Months, Quits After Dispute
description: ANKARA, Turkey, Wednes day, Oct. 27 (AP)The Govern ment of Premier Nihat Erim re signed early today. The Turkish Premier was installed March 26 after military commanders forced out the administration of Premier Suleyman Demirel of the conservative Justice party.

title: Advertising:
description: The Bureau of Advertising may be taking over the prin cipal functions of News paper 1.

title: RONDON REGISTERS KNOCKOUT IN 13TH
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 26 (UPI) Vicente Rondon of Venezuela retained his World Boxing As sociation lightheavyweight title tonight by stopping Gomeo Brennan of the Bahamas in the 13th round of a scheduled 15 round bout.

title: Jersey Joblessness Up
description: TRENTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The seasonally adjusted unem ployment rate rose to 7.3 per cent in September in New Jer sey even though 30,200 fewer persons were out of work than in the previous month, the State Labor Department an nounced today. The rate was 7.2 per cent in August.

title: A Growing Range of Molecules Is Detected in Interstellar Space
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26  A group of radio astronomers told the National Academy of Sciences today that ever in creasing types and amounts of complex molecules were being detected in the supposed void of interstellar space.

title: Taiwan Once a Major Base for the U.S.
description: The Government of National ist China on Taiwan has only one alliance: a mutual security treaty with the United States. Since 1951, the United States has provided $2.8billion in military assistance. At present, military aid is running at less than $100,000 a year.

title: Dickman Looks for More Suits Seeking End of I.L.A. Strike
description: James J. Dickman, president of the New York Shipping As sociation, said yeaterday that he expected management in other ports besides Philadelphia and New Orleans to go to court in an effort to end a work stoppage begun by the Inter national Longshoremen's As sociation on Oct. 1.

title: Goldberg Disputes Johnson Memoirs on U.N. Post
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Arthur J. Goldberg today at tacked as false President Lyn don B. Johnson's version of how Mr. Goldberg left the Su preme Court to become the United States delegate to the United Nations in 1965.

title: For the U.N., a Whole New Phase
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26Salim A. Salim, the chief delegate from the United Republic of Tanzania, was elated at the results of the voting on China last night; he was described as having danced a victory jig. When he turned up at the United Nations this morning, a num ber of delegates asked him for dancing lessons.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brooklyn Judge Is Relieved of Duty
description: Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo of Brooklyn has been relieved of his judicial assignments pending a hearing on charges that he interfered with a Waterfront Commission investigation in February, 1967.

title: DARTMOUTH ACTS TO ADMIT COEDS
description: Dartmouth College, a 202 yearold Ivy League institution that has awarded undergradu ate degrees only to men, is moving toward coeducation and yearround operation by 1972 73.

title: American Express Net Up;
description: The American Express Com pany achieved the highest earn ings and the largest percentage profit gain for any quarter on record in the three months ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday. This lifted the results for the nine months to the largest profit ever at tained by the company, accord ing to Howard L. Clark, chair man and chief executive officer.

title: Drug Price Posting By Chain in Illinois Pleases Trust Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Justice Department's Anti trust Division gave a formal blessing today to the decision of an Illinois drug chain to let the public know' in advance what it charges for prescriptien drugsa policy that may be in violation of Illinois law.

title: Members of the Price Commission Take Oath of Office and Promptly Hold First Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)The seven members of the Price Commission were sworn in today to fight in flation when the current wageprice freeze expires. They now have 17 days to plan how to do it.

title: U.N. RollCalls on China
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 26Following are two roll call votes taken in the General Assembly last night on seating Communist China and expelling Nationalist China. Typo graphical errors that appeared in the tabulation in The New York Times today have been corrected in the version below.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: GANDER, Newfoundland, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press)  President Tito arrived here late today for an overnight stop at the beginning of his visit to Canada and the United States. The police maintained tight se curity at Gander Airport, where Marshal Tito was greeted by Canadian and Newfoundland officials.

title: Adult Education Post Filled
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)President Nixon named Donald F. Rodgers of New York today to the National Advisory Council on Adult Ed ucation for a term expiring in 1974. Mr. Rodgers, 45 years old, a construction industry ex ecutive, succeeds Ernest G. Green, whose term expired in July.

title: ShortTerm Rates Drop, But Bond Rally Is Stalled
description: While a wide variety of moneymarket rates were low ered yesterday, the bond mark et's recent advance in prices sputtered to a stop. New is sues of corporate and taxex empt bonds sold slowly and recently marketed bonds de clined.

title: JAMES J. DRENNAN
description: James J. Drennan, a cus tomer's representative with Smith, Barney & Co., member of the New York Stock Ex change, died yesterday at his home. He was 60 years old and lived at 7627 173d Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: Radio Reports U.N. Move
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 26The Peking radio today announced the United Nations decision to seat Communist China and to expel Nationalist China in a re port condemning past efforts of the United States to keep the Chinese out.

title: Beaty Paces Stars' Rout
description: DALLAS, Oct. 26 (AP) Zelmo Beaty scored 32 points tonight to lead the Utah Stars to a 131116 rout of the error prone Dallas Chaparrals.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISUnless the six members of the Common Market, combined to gether with Great Britain, join swiftly in a collective action fixing currency parities and negotiating as a single unit with the United States, a trade war may erupt in the Western world.

title: Elite Police Patrol Here Is Stunned by Accusation
description: The preventive enforcement patrolor PEP squadcele brated its second birthday in Harlem last Saturday. Yester day the elite black and Puerto Rican police unit was stunned by the allegation of a former member that all but two of the team's 20 patrolmen were ac tively involved in scores on policy operators, narcotics pushers and other criminals.

title: MODIFICATION UAGED IN BANK HOLDING LAW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (Reu ters)  The Federal Reserve Board announced today it had proposed a regulatory amend ment to clarify the status of one  bank holding companies that fall within one or more of the so  called grandfather clauses of the 1970 amend ments to the Bank Holding Company Act.

title: Canada and Soviet Stress Peace
description: TORONTO, Oct. 26  As Premier Kosygin left Canada to day after an eightday visit, the Soviet and Canadian Gov ernments issued a communiqu stating that they attached great importance to personal contacts between the Govern ment leaders and reaffirmed the attachment of Canada and the Soviet Union to peace and security and the development of international peace.

title: What Price Health Care?
description: The current hearings before the House Ways and Means Committee on proposals for a national health insurance program could affect every American as a potential patient. They will also influence areas of medical and hospital care in which millions of workers and thousands of organizations are involved.

title: Bogdanovich: Director Still Fan
description: Critics of various cine matic persuasions have lav ished praise on Peter Bog danovich's The Last Picture Show ever since it was in troduced at the New York Film Festival. At the same time, many of them predicted that the movie would have great popular appeal. In The New Yorker Pauline Kael, one of the film's admirers, wrote, Even Nixon could like The Last Picture Show.

title: ERNEST HABERLE, 60, OF BOHACK, IS DEAD
description: MANHASSET, L. L, Oct. 26 Ernest J. Haberle, former president of the Bohack Cor poration and a lawyer, died at his home here Sunday. He was 60 years old and had been convalescing after brain sur gery.

title: Airlines Open Talks To Avert Fare War On Atlantic Flights
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 26The 25 airlines flying the North Atlantic on regular schedules began a new effort here today to avoid a possible fare war on Feb. 1.

title: Delaware Mud Gap?
description: New developments concerning the controversial Tocks Island Dam do credit to the President's Council on Environmental Quality but they do more than that: they strongly suggest that the project be abandoned.

title: U.S. SAYS IT MET GOAL ON MINORITY BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 Under Secretary of the Treasury Charls E. Walker said today that the Administration had met, and exceeded, its commit ment of a year ago to place $35million in Federal Govern ment deposits in minority owned banks by early October.

title: Airline Is Suspended
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (UPI) The Illinois Commerce Com mission ordered today a tem porary suspension of all flights of Chicago and Southern Air lines, operator of the commuter airline that crashed at Peoria, Ill., Thursday with the loss of 16 lives. The commission said that the suspension of the air line's operations would remain in effect pending completion of hearings.

title: MARTIN G. CAINE
description: LIVINGSTON, N. J., Oct. 26 Martin G. Caine, president of the plastics division of Tenneco, Inc., Piscataway, died today in St. Rumbas Medical Center here, of a heart attack. He was 55 years old and lived at 25 Bonnyview Road.

title: LINDSAY WEIGHS FLORIDA PRIMARY
description: If he is to run for the Demo cratic Presidential nomination, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday, he will have to go into the Florida primary.

title: U.S. CONTRIBUTES MOST U.N. MONEY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The annual financial crisis that besets the United Nations has reached the stage where they worry every couple of weeks about their ability to meet the payroll, according to a mem ber of the United States dele gation.

title: BIRTHS
description: BASKINOMr. and Mrs. Alan (nee Toby ??) joyfully announce the birth of their son, David Harris, on October 20, 1971.

title: N.C.A.A. Council Rejects Playoff for National Title
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 26 (UPI)The National Collegiate Athletic Association Council turned down today a proposal to match the nation's No. 1 and No. 2 college football teams in an early December television game.

title: Bridge: Deceptive Play Is Helpful To Metropolitan Winners
description: The Swiss team event that concluded the Metropolitan Championships at the New York Hilton Hotel Monday was won by five New York experts: Fred Dossenbach, Frank Mela, Merle Tom, Jay Wendt and Jeff Westheimer. They made sure of victory by scoring well in the last round against the reigning Spin gold team champions.

title: STRIPMINING FOE IN HEARING CLASH
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 An emotional appeal by a wit ness before a House subcom mittee for an end to strip min ing in the Appalachian Moun tains ended in an angry ex change today between the wit ness and Representative Ed Edmondson, Democrat of Ok lahoma.

title: Gulf Oil, Phillips, Sun and Marathon Increase Earnings
description: Increased earnings and exec utive changes were the order of the day yesterday among several major oil companies.

title: Ivy League Roundup
description: In 1881 Dartmouth fielded an intercollegiate football team for the first time. Three years later one of the estab lished powers, Yale, jour neyed to Hanover, N. H., and rolled over the Indians, 113 to 0.

title: Seattle Blood Bank Cuts Cost and Risk of Infection
description: SEATTLE  When patients need blood here, their phy sicians say they get it for the least cost anywhere in the country and with a minimal risk of contracting hepatitis, a serious and sometimes fatal liver infection that is becom ing a growing national public health problem.

title: PRODUCTION OF STEEL ADVANCES FOR WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended Oct. 23 rose by 2.3 per cent to 1,886,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday. This compared wtih 1,843,000 tons a week earlier. However, for the year to date, production dropped to 101,300,000 tons, or 6.5 per cent below the 108, 342,000 tons produced in the comparable period of 1970.

title: RAY W. SHERMAN, 87, WRITER AND EDITOR
description: Ray W. Sherman, author and former automotive editor, died Sunday in Genesco, N.Y., after a brief illness. He was 87 years old.

title: Hasidic Jews in Brooklyn Seize 2 Holdup Men
description: Two alleged gunmen were seized by bands of angry Hasidic Jews in the Williams burg section of Brooklyn last night, the police said. One of the gunmen was badly injured when he was run down by a pursuing car.

title: L.I.R. Fare Outlook
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 26 A fare increase of at least 30 per cent will be required in January for the Long Island Railroad if the proposed $2.5 billion transportation bond issue is not approved by voters next week, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metro politan Transportation Au thority, said today.

title: Sony to Build Coast Plant
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26 (Reuters) The Sony Corporation said today it plans to build a factory in San Diego, Calif., to assemble color television sets, starting next May.

title: JUSTICES REBUFF PONTIAC ON BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25The Supreme Court declined today to review a Federal court order for school busing that has touched off violence and boy cotts in Pontiac, Mich.

title: CITY AIDE'S LINK TO CAFE IS BARRED
description: The city's Board of Ethics has ruled that it would be a conflict of interest for an im portant Lindsay administra tion official to invest in a mid town restaurant and bar.

title: 4 Services to Renew Liberal Holiday Policy
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP)The armed forces will adhere to their traditional policy of early discharges and liberal leaves during the Christmas season, the Penta gon announced today.

title: A PANTHER CASE NEARING ITS END
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26The final chapter in the Black Panther murder case that fo cused national attention on New Haven and the militant organization opened here this morning as two men pleaded guilty of conspiracy to murder.

title: 3 BIG COMPANIES TO OMIT DIVIDEND
description: Dividends bowed to market softness and pressure on earn ings as five wellknown com panies yesterday announced re ductions or omissions of their normal quarterly payouts.

title: Texas Gulf Sulphur Explores Australian Iron Ore Plan
description: PERTH, Western Australia, Oct. 26 (Reuters)The state government of Western Aus tralia has started negotiations with the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company for a possible $300 million iron ore export project, Herbert Graham, the state's Minister of Development, said today.

title: 5 IND Riders Hurt When Youths Stone 7 Express Trains
description: Five subway passengers were injured, one of them requiring hospital treatment when a group of teenagers threw rocks at seven passing IND express trains from the uptown plat form of the 72d Street station yesterday.

title: MRS. HERMAN LEFFERT
description: Mrs. Dorothy Eisenberg Lef fert, who was national treas urer of Hadassah for its first 12 years, beginning in 1912, died yesterday at the Jewish Home for the Aged, Amsterdam Avenue at 106th Street. She was 94 years old and was the widow of Herman Leffert, a manufacturer of rubber goods.

title: Injured Baker to Start At Linebacker for Jets
description: It will be easy to pick the Jets' new starting linebacker Sunday against the Chargers in San Diego. He will be the one with the cast on his right wrist.

title: BIG BOARD STOCKS CONTINUE DECLINE
description: The stock market, enveloped by clouds of pessimism, drop ped yesterday for the 10th straight session and neared a critical test area on the charts.

title: McIntire Protests Vote
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The New Jersey radio preach er Carl McIntire said today that the United Nations vote was a diplomatic Pearl Harbor and he pledged to devote his time pro testing it. The disaster is the direct result of the Nixon pol icy of retreat, appeasement and his soft talk of peace, he declared.

title: TV: WNYC Outshines Networks on U.N. Drama
description: News specials and public affairs programingsudden ly, even if only momentarlly, the supply is plentiful.

title: 3 CANADIAN BANKS LOWER PRIME RATE
description: TORONTO, Oct. 26 (Cana dian Press)Three of the largest banks in Canada an nounced today cuts in their prime lending ratethe second reduction in a weekand lowered personal  savings  ac count interest rates.

title: Chinatown: Glee, Gloom, Shrugs
description: Chinatown was divided yesterday on the wisdom of the admission of Communist China into the United Nations and the exclusion of Nationalist China.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26The Bureau of Labor Statistics re ported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Oct. 19;

title: Special RushHour Bus Lane Makes Expressway a Breeze
description: Rapturous bus riders breezed into Manhattan from Queens during yesterday morning's rush hour on a special lane set aside for express buses on the congested Long Island Express way, which has been dubbed the world's longest parking lot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Gielen Faces Conflict in Double Role
description: Like one of those modern monarchs who would rather be a commoner, Michael Gielen is torn between his autocratic role of conductor and a youthful enthusiasm for the participatory democracy he advocates in his composi tions.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Does bearish Wall Street know something that most economists cannot see or understand? The standard eco nomic forecast calls for a gross national product in 1972 to climb by $90billion to $100 billion, with twothirds of the gain real and only onethird due to inflation, and with a 12 to 15 per cent increase in after tax profits. But the stock market, after its initial burst of en thusiasm for Mr. Nixon's New Eco nomic Policy, has gone into a sink ing spell that has carried the Dow almost back to the sum mer low of 839.59 it reached just before the President's Aug. 15 bombshellsthe wageprice freeze, the package of tax cuts, the suspension of convertibility of the dollar into gold and the 10 per cent surcharge.

title: U.S. TRUCK CONVOY ATTACKEDINVIETNAM
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 26 (AP)A daylight ambush of an Ameri can truck convoy and four other enemy attacks were re ported yesterday north of Sai gon.

title: HAWKS TRIUMPH OVER WINGS, 52
description: DETROIT, Oct. 26 (UPI)  Stan Mikita scored a goal and added two assists tonight, leading the Chicago Black Hawks, to a 52 victory over the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League.

title: Blount Reported Ready To Run for the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI)  Postmaster General Winton M. Blount will leave his job soon to run for the United States Senate from Alabama, according to re ports here and from Ala bama. The announcement could come within a matter of days, sources said.

title: Bucks Take 7th in, Row, Beating Bullets, 120 to 90
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 26 (AP)The Milwaukee Bucks, led by Bob Dandridge's 27 points and Kareem Abdul Jabbar's 24, lifted their National Basketball Association wonlost record to 70 tonight by de feating the Baltimore Bullets, 12090.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE PROFESSOR'S DAUGHTER. By Plers Paul Read. 276 pages. Lippincott $6.95.

title: HARRY BENDA, 52, A YALE PROFESSOR
description: NEW HAVEN, Oct. 26  Harry J. Benda, history profes sor at Yale University and a leading authority on Southeast Asia, died today at Yale New Haven. Hospital, where he had been recuperating from a heart attack. He would have been 52 years old on Thursday.

title: City Block: Aged Live in Seclusion
description: The elderly on West 85th Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue lead lives that are at least as disparate, and perhaps more so, than those of the young, and if they are joined in anything besides their age it is their seclusion.

title: F.D.A. Plans a Paint Rule To Fight Lead Poisoning
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (UPI) An official of the Food and Drug Administration, Jerome J. Donovan, said today that the agency planned to sharply restrict, to 0.5 per cent, the lead content of many paints.

title: Bishop Says He Ordained 5 on False Data
description: ROME, Oct. 26A Roman Catholic Bishop from Ghana has written to the Vatican stating that he acted on the basis of misleading information when he ordained five Ameri can priests who had previously been refused ordination by John Cardinal Carberry of St. Louis.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26A spokesman for the Govern ment's antihijacking program said today that officials had long anticipated the capture of a plane with sky marshals aboard.

title: Absentee Ballot Curb Upheld
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upheld today the consti tutionality of Pennsylvania laws that bar absentee ballots to per sons confined in penal or mental institutions. The ruling, written by Judge Ruggerio Aldisert, up held a lower court order that dismissed a complaint on behalf of about 2,000 persons who were in city prisons awaiting trial.

title: Driver Accused of Bribery After Narcotics Are Found
description: A driver stopped for a routine traffic check in South Queens allegedly offered two patrolmen $5,00 to let him go last night, according to the police.

title: YIDDISH TROUPE ON SOVIET STAGE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 26  Anna Guzik, once the queen of the Yiddish variety stage in the Soviet Union, reappeared re cently for a onenight stand and her old fansplus some younger onesturned out to give her a warm, emotional welcome.

title: Advertising:
description: Wells, Rich, Greene hinted last week that it might soon be announcing some new rather smallish accounts with big growth potential.

title: DRUGTRAFFIC FIGHT REPORTED GAINING
description: Customs Commissioner Myles J. Ambrose said here yester day that substantial progress had been made in the drive to curb the international traffic in illegal narcotics.

title: The Science of Caring
description: BRISTOL, EnglandIt is not given to us mortals to perceive the full consequences of our actions. Moral responsibility is therefore an issue that cannot be decided by scientific pro cedures. When an evil is traced back to a cause that we have freely created, we can almost always produce an excuse.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today Oct. 27. 1971
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Formosa's Future
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.The U.N. deci sion seating Peking and expelling Taipeiplus President Nixon's pro posed visit to the mainlandunder score the tangle of the Formosan is sue. And now as world leaders finally admit the absurdities of Nationalist Chinese fantasies, a new myth emerg es: that Formosa has been and must be an integral part of China, and that in order for China to achieve, full sovereignty she must annex Formosa.

title: MRS. PRESTI REPORTS $120,000 L.I. THEFT
description: MUTTONTOWN, L. I., Oct. 26The wife of a building and construction contractor al legedly involved in a scheme to conceal the ownership of race horses told the police here tonight that $120,000 in cash had been stolen from her home.

title: Germans Design Car to Withstand Major Crashes
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Oct. 26 (AP)DaimlerBenz un voiled a now experimental safety automobile today that is designed to enable its occu pants to survive a 50milean hour headon crash into a brick wall.

title: MRS. JAMES WATSON, WIDOW OF JUDGE, 80
description: Mrs. Violet Lopez Watson, widow of James S. Watson, the first black judge in New York State, and mother of United States Customs Court Judge James L. Watson, died on Monday in Washington at the home of a daughter, Miss Barbara Watson. She was 80 years old and lived at 676 Riverside Drive. Her daughter is administrator of the Bureau of Security and Consular Af fairs of the State Department.

title: The Blackfriars Present a Comedy on Women's Lib
description: A pleasant little play and a wryly turned earful is now being offered by the Black friars' Guild under the title Lib Comes High. In her snugly structured but abso lutely unbelievable comedy, the playwright, Joan T. Nourse, has this to say: Any women's lib leader who gal lops full tilt all over the country stands a pretty good chance of losing her sobriety, her husband and her soul in one fell swoop.

title: Braves 9189 Victors
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 26 (UPI)Bob Kauffman scored 24 points and Elmore Smith, a rookie, made a strong showing tonight, leading the Buffalo Braves to a 9189 victory over Golden State Warriors.

title: Squires Defeat Condors
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 (AP) Charlie Scott and Julius Erving combined for 74 points in leading the Virginia Squires to a 149136 victory over the Pittsburgh Condors tonight.

title: MIKHAIL YANGEL, SOVIET SPACE AIDE
description: MOSCOW, Oct 26Mikhail K. Yangel, chief designer of the Soviet. Union's space pro gram for the last five years, died yesterday after a heart at tack. He was 60 years old.

title: Alleged Link to City Housing Loan Denied by Beame
description: Two officers of a bank for which Abraham D. Beame, was finance chairman owned 60 per cent of a corporation that ob tained a $2million loan from the Municipal Loan Program for the rehabilitation of nine buildings in Williamsburg, it was disclosed yesterday at a hearing of a City Council com mittee. Mr. Beame is now City Controller, but did not hold that office at the time of the loan.

title: Reorganization Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) Representative Chet Holifield, Democrat of California, an nounced today that the House Government Operations, Com mittee, whith he heads, would begin hearings Nov. 3 on legis lation to establish a new Department of Community Development. The proposed department is one of four rec ommended by President Nixon in his State of the Union Message this year.

title: ILEANA SONNABEND SUING FRANK STELLA
description: Ileana Sonnabend, the owner of art galleries in New York and Paris, sued in State Su preme Court here yesterday to prevent Frank Stella, the artist, from selling or disposing of one of his paintings that is now in his possession but which Miss Sonnabend says she owns.

title: Actions of Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Buffalo G.I. Killed in Action
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that Pfc. Wil liam J. Makowski of the Army, of Buffalo, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: INTERNATIONAL UNIT OFFERS INDIA HELP
description: PARIS, Oct. 26Thirteen na tions and five international or ganizations agreed here today to a worldwide effort to meet the cost of the growing refugee problem in India.

title: MISS CURRY OFFERS 16THCENTURY SONGS
description: Looking rather like a fey Me lisande with her waist  length blond hair and suggestively Renaissance gown, Donna Cur ry offered an extensive selec tion of 16thcentury lute songs and dances Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Miss Curry complemented the visual picture with the cameolike fragility of her sensitive lute playing, her small but sweet soprano and uncannily pure intonation.

title: Tug Crew Licensing Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (Reu ters)The National Transporta tion Safety Board recommended today Congressional action to require the licensing of tugboat crew members and called for a study to determine the need for inspection of towing vessels. The call was made in a report on the sinking of the 52foot tug Joan Ellis, owned by the Inland Towing Company of Galveston, Texas. The vessel went down in Galveston Bay with the loss of two lives in June, 1970.

title: Rockets Down Pros
description: DENVER, Oct. 26 (AP)The Denver Rockets broke open a tight game midway in the fourth period tonight on the shooting of Ralph Simpson and the rebounding of Julius Key to defeat the Memphis Pros, 115100. Simpson led all scor ers with 32 points. Key had 10 of his 16 rebounds in the final period.

title: WarnerLambert Rises
description: Record earnings and sales in the third quarter and first nine months for the WarnerLambert Company were reported yester day by Stuart K. Hensley, chair man and chief executive.

title: Kosygin Gets a Warm Welcome From Castro and Cuban Crowds
description: HAVANA, Oct. 26 (Reuters) Thousands of Cubans crowded the streets of Havana today to give Premier Aleksei N. Kosy gin of the Soviet Union a warm welcome as he arrived for a visit.

title: TOKYO: SATO ROLE ON CHINA ASSAILED
description: TOKYO, Oct. 26The over whelming vote in the United Nations to expel Nationalist China and to admit Communist China broke like a thunder storm today over the Japanese Government, which had worked hard to preserve a seat for Taiwan in the General Assem bly.

title: PAUL A. BERNSTEIN, EXSALES EXECUTIVE
description: Paul A. Bernstein, a business executive and former biology instructor at City College, died of a heart ailment Monday in Ithaca, N. Y., where he had been visiting. He was 66 years old and lived in Teaneck, N. J.

title: WILLIAM J. NEIL
description: NEW SHREWSBURY, N. J., Oct. 26William J. Neil, a re tired stock transfer specialist with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old and lived at 180 Clo verdale Circle.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawning of the Age of Aquarius Scheduled 600 Years From Now
description: The Age of Aquarius, con trary to the assurances of the popular song, will not dawn for another 600 years.

title: 34 Children Killed By Abuse in City, Legislators Told
description: Thirtyfour battered and bruised children have died here since January from the suspected physical abuse of their parents, the New York State Assembly Committee on Child Abuse was told yester day.

title: Knicks Down Celtics Here
description: Track meets are never sched uled for Madison Square Gar den in October, but that's what the New York Knicks and Boston Celtics seemed to stage last night as the Knicks emerged with an exciting 106 101 victory.

title: GERRI GRANGER AT THE ROYAL BOX
description: Although Gerri Granger is telling her audience at the Royal Box of the Americana that she is making her New York debut there, this is diffi cult to believe because this brighteyed, joyful, assured and beautifully polished young sing er has attributes that suggest that she has been around for a long time.

title: DOUGLASS SEMONIN, ARTIST, DEAD AT 45
description: Douglass Semonin, well known in the homefurnishings field as an awardwinning art ist, died at his home, 214 East 17th Street, Saturday. His age was 45.

title: Echo From '20's: Browning's Moral Uplift Grants
description: A foundation set up by the late Edward W. (Daddy) Brown ing, whose middleaged marital entanglements with a 15year old called Peaches enlivened the nineteentwenties, has granted its first awards for uplifting the moral condition of the world, as provided in his will.

title: Most Asian Nations Applaud U.N. Action
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 26The decision of the United Nations General Assembly to seat Com munist China and to expel the Chinese Nationalist Govern ment was criticized today by South Korea and South Viet nam, two countries that face rival Communist regimes.

title: Protest in Alabama
description: ANNISTON, Ala., Oct. 27 (UPI)  City and County po licemen arrested 140 persons, including the president of the local chapter of the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People, in the second day of protests of the expulsion of a black student from Walter Wellborn High School.

title: On the Edge of the Precipice
description: The growing threat of war between India and Pakistan creates an urgent need for United Nations intervention but not on the terms proposed by Islamabad.

title: Synod Weighing a Wider View of Sin
description: ROME, Oct. 27Delegates to the world Synod of Bishops are moving toward a convic tion that the Roman Catholic Church Must broaden its un derstanding of sin to include the structural injustice of major social institutions that many people assume to be mor ally neutral.

title: NEED STILL SEEN FOR ONSITE CHECK
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27  Defense Department scientists told Congress today that their research had shown that there still was need for onsite in spection to verify compliance with any ban on underground nuclear tests.

title: Market Place: A Big Bank Tells What Its Goal Is
description: The bank's image is famil iara sort of benign giant with a social conscience. Yes, that's the First National City Bank, second in size only to the Bank of America in the free world.

title: Merger News
description: Joseph S. Tushinsky, presi dent of Superscope, Inc., an nounced yesterday that his company had acquired 50 per cent of the capital stock of the Standard Radio Corporation of Japan. Mr. Tushinsky said that this was the first time that the Japanese Government had per mitted a foreign corporation to obtain 50 per cent of a publicly owned Japanese company. The Superscope president noted that, if the Super scope agreement set a pattern for the future among multina tional industrial companies, the Japanese Government's ac tion could have as farreaching effects as the original opening of Japan to foreign trade.

title: Gunman Robs Store Opposite City Hall And Escapes Police
description: Just across Broadway from Mayor Lindsay's office window, an armed robber held up a women's apparel shop yester day evening.

title: Edmund Reek Dies at 73; Newsreels Won 3 Oscars
description: Edmund H. Reek, a pioneer newsreel executive who re ceived many awards for his work over a 45year period, died on Sunday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived in Juno Beach, Fla.

title: Mrs. Eisenhower Resting
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 27 (UPI)Mrs. Dwight D. Ei senhower was reported rest ing comfortably today at the Army's Brooke General Hos pital, where she is undergoing tests. She'll be here for three or four days for tests, said Tom Matthews, a spokesman for the hospital. The late Pres ident's wife is 74 years old.

title: Super Bowl, $5, Wins Harriman Trotby Head
description: YONKERS, Oct. 27Nearly everything that happened in the $45,948 E. Roland Harri man Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight benefited the favored Super Bowl. Breaking horses, colts with early speed, a flaw less drive by Vernon Dancer and a measure of racing luck figured in Super Bowl's head decision at a mile over the Delvin Millerdriven Delmonica Hanover, one of two fillies in the ninth annual stakes test for 2yearolds.

title: AnheuserBusch
description: Earnings of AnheuserBusch, Inc., for the third quarter were $21,062,000, or 47 cents a share, on sales of $248,665,000, compared with income of $18, 009,000, or 41 cents a share, on sales of $214,932,000, for the 1970 third quarter.

title: Christy Brown: A Life Centered on Typewriter
description: DUBLIN  Christy Brown, the Dublin  born crippled writer whose autobiograph ical novel, Down All the Days, has become a best seller in 14 languages, is half way through another book.

title: Two Are Named as Heads of the Jewish Theological Seminary
description: A new chancellor, Rabbi Bernard Mandelbaum, and a new president, Dr. Gerson D. Cohen, have been chosen to head the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

title: Eastern College Football
description: Six athletic directors in the New York area have agreed on plans for a smallcollege football league to be known as the Metropolitan Intercol legiate Football Conference. The conference will not be established until the govern ing bodies of each institution approve the charter. The col leges are Ford ham, Hofstra, C. W. Post, St. Peter's, Merchant Marine Academy (Kings Point) and Wagner. Plans call for the conference to start operations in 1973, with a roundrobin to establish the winner.

title: Miss Vanderbilt Becomes Bride Of Jones Harris
description: Miss Heidi Vanderbilt, daughter of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt and Mrs. Jeanne Murray Vanderbilt, was mar ried last Sunday to Jones Harris, son of Ruth Gordon, the actress, and Jed Harris, the theatrical producer. Su preme Court Justice Theo dore R. Kupferman officiated at the home in Oyster Bay of the bride's father and step mother, the former Jean Harvey.

title: The Newark News And Guild Agree On Contract Terms
description: NEWARK, Oct. 27  The North Jersey Newspaper Guild announced today that it had reached final agreement on a contract that union sources hoped would end the 155day strike at The Evening News of Newark.

title: Jenkins Collects 3 Titles in Show And 2 Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Rod Jenkins, a 27yearold profes sional from Orange, Va., could do no wrong today at the Wash ington International Horse Show and took three championships. Moreover, he rode the reserve champion in two of the divi sions.

title: Corroboration Held Vital to Protection Of Rape Suspects
description: A woman lawyer from the New York City Legal Aid So ciety said yesterday at hearings of the State Senate's Commit tee on Codes that corroboration in rape cases was essential to the protection of the innocent and asked that this legal re quirement not be eliminated from current state law.

title: Jersey Inquiry Told of Container Port Extortion
description: TRENTON, Oct. 27An offi cer of a corporation developing a large container port in Jersey City and Bayonne testified to day that a payment of about $5million5 per cent of the project cost  had been de manded for governmental co operation.

title: IN THE NATION
description: In politics and diplomacy, facing reality seems the exception rather than the rule, and the halftruth, the half measure and the blindfold are com monplace. If for no other reason, the United Nations' clearcut decision to seat the Peking Government and oust the Nationalist Chinese was exciting and unusual. Unfortunately, the poli tics of unreality already has started to reassert itself.

title: 5 Policemen Hurt In a School Clash At Charlotte, N. C.
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Oct. 27 (UPI)  Seven white students and five policemen were injured today in an apparent racial brawl at Myers Park High School that involved about 150 students.

title: SMITH, BARNEY FUND AND MOODY'S IN DEAL
description: Moody's Capital Fund, Inc., and Smith, Barney Equity Fund, Inc., announced an agreement yesterday under which all of the assets of the Moody's fund would he exchanged for shares of the Smith, Barney fund.

title: Express Buses to Link The Bronx to Midtown
description: Express weekday bus serv ice will be started next Mon day between Midtown Man hattan and the Soundview section of the Bronx, Robert Abrams, the Bronx Borough president, announced yester day.

title: Nixon Deplores Jubilation of Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 The White House expressed shock and dismay today at the behavior of some United Na tions delegates after the vote Monday night to admit main land China and expel the Na tionalists and said that such behavior might impair United States support for the world body.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Rangers Win as Rousseau, Gilbert Star
description: Pete Stemkowski, who is in the hospital for a recurring headache, could have left his bed and played for the Rangers last night and wouldn't have felt a thing.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey an nounced yesterday the election of Dr. Guido Colon na di Paliano of Milan, Italy, and Otto Wolff von Amerongen of Cologne, Germany, as directors. This makes them the first Europeans named as outside directors since it began naming nonemploye direc tors in 1966. Mr. di Paliano, a former diplomat, is now president of the Rinascente chain of depart ment stores. Mr. von Amerongen, is president of Otto Wolff A. G. and president of the German As sociation of Chambers of Commerce and industry. Today's election in New Orleans brought the oil company's board to 16 members seven of them non employe directors and nine employes.

title: Syria Reports Driving Off Incursions by Israeli Planes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 27 A Syrian military spokesman reported in Damascus that Syr ian air defenses today drove off Israeli fighter planes that had violated the Syrian air space over the ceasefire lines between the two countries.

title: A TwoforOne Split in Stock Announced by Westinghouse
description: Directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation voted yes terday to split the common stock on a 2for1 basis. The action would be subject to approval of stockholders, who will be asked to vote on the measure on Nov. 29. The board also declared a dividend of 45 cents a share on the common stock and 95 cents a share on the 3.80 per cent preferred stock, both payable Dec. 1 to holders of record Nov. 5.

title: INA Corporation
description: The INA Corporation, the holding company that owns the Insurance Company of North America, had net operating in come of $24,443,000 for the third quarter, up 51 per cent from $16,155,000 a year ago. Revenues and net income were not disclosed.

title: CUT IN U.S. TROOPS EXPECTED IN NATO

title: Private Clubhouse For Golfers on L.I. Destroyed by Fire
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Oct. 27 The clubhouse of the Tam O'Shanter Golf Club was de stroyed by fire here today.

title: 76ERS OVERCOME CAVALIERS,120106
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 (AP) Billy Cunningham and Fred Foster provided the spark in the fourth period that enabled the Philadelphia 76ers to pull away from the Cleveland Cava liers for a 120106 victory to night.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Vietnam Reduces Storm Toll
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 27 (AP)  As extensive new flooding was reported in the northernmost part of the coun try in the wake of last Satur day's typhoon, the Government today revised downward from 100 to 89 the South Vietnamese death toll in the storm. It said the number of deaths in a C47 crash as a result of the weather was 22, not 33 as reported earlier.

title: Bridge: Play in Long Island Regionals Begins Today in Westbury
description: After a twoday breather following the fourday Metro politan Championships in Manhattan, New York tour nament enthusiasts will be at it again.

title: Ellis Says Slump May Have Started With Sickle Cell
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) Dock Ellis, pitcher for the world champion Pittsburgh Pi rates, told a Senate subcommit tee today his poor record in the last half of the season may have been caused by sicklecell trait.

title: Pakistanis Charge Indian Shells Killed 64 Civilians in East
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 27 The Pakistan Government charged that Indian troops fired nearly 3,000 shells into border villages in East Pakis tan today, killing 64 civilians.

title: New Orleans Strike Ends
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 (UPI) Presidents of the six striking New Orleans longshoremen's unions tonight ordered their men back to work in compliance with a Federal court order signed earlier in the day. We declare the current strike or work stoppage or refusal of our members to perform services is hereby terminated, they said.

title: Israel Reported Refusing to Join Talks on Suez Unless U.S. Lifts Embargo on Jets
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27Is raeli diplomatic sources said today that their country would not agree to join in American sponsored indirect talks with Egypt on reopening the Suez, Canal until the current United States embargo on the delivery of jet aircraft to Israel was lifted.

title: Thant Asks China to Name Delegate to Council Soon
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 27  Secretary General Thant urged Communist China in a telegram today to name its representative to the United Na tions Security Council as soon as possible so that the Council would be able to function.

title: Seals Down Penguins, 64
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 27 (AP) Bobby Sheehan scored two goals including one in the first period tonight when California ?? for three goals within 3 minutes 24 seconds, as the Golden Seals deleated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 64.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by listed companies' major stockholders, directors and officers. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a list this week.

title: BEAME DEMANDS POSTEL APOLOGIZE
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame demanded a public apology from Councilman Robert I. Postel yesterday, declaring your gratuitous injection of my name into the Council's hearings on the Municipal Loan Program Was a gratuitous in sult.

title: U.S. F111 Supplement Set
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (Reu ters)The General Dynamics Corporation is to receive $92, 868,231 in a supplemental agree ment for previously approved engineering changes on the F111 fighterbomber, the Pen tagon announced today.

title: GAS SUPPLIER LISTS GAIN FOR EARNINGS
description: The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation and sub sidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the Sep tember quarter.

title: Inland Steel
description: Like most steel producers, the Inland Steel Company had a thirdquarter net loss. The Inland deficit was $3,292,000, its first quarterly loss since 1959. In the September quarter last year, the seventh largest domestic steel producer had a profit of $14,387,000, or 74 cents a share.

title: Egyptians Are Silent
description: CAIRO, Oct. 27Silence was the only response today by Egyptian officials to a nine point policy statement yester day by Premier Meir on terms for an interim agreement with Egypt for a reopening of the Suez Canal.

title: Shop Talk
description: Spurred by the success of merchandise culled from Charles M. Schulz's comic strip, Peanuts, F.A.O. Schwarz has decided to give Joan Walsh Anglund the same sort of play. The au thor of A Friend Is Some one Who Likes You, and countless other books, Mrs. Anglund has her own corner on the third floor filled with all manner of things patterned after her whimsical characters. A delightful new group is built around The Brave Cowboy. It includes a wrist watch ($16), a paperweight ($3), a red white and blue poster measuring 22 by 28 inches ($2.50), a papiermch bank ($6), an alarm clock ($8.95) and the book itself (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $2.50).

title: Films: Two Westerns Made in Spain
description: Two Spanish-made Westerns, "Captain Apache" and A Town Called Hell, make for hard, double-bill sitting, take it from us. Thundering, clanging, spilling blood like catsup, they run for exactly 189 minutes. Neither amounts to a hil of beans. One of them, the least painful, doesn't even try.This is "Captain Apache," whose mean, funny opening line, not suitable to a family newspaper, pegs the entire jape. Anyway, this slapdash slaughterfest has Lee Van Cleef, as an iron-jawed Indian captain in the Union Army, trying to solve an officer's murder. Peering in, under the broiling sun, are such artists as Carroll Baker and Stuart Whitman, who must have been hankering for Hollywood greenery.Generally, under Alexander Singer's direction, the film simply lets fly, as the chips and bodies fall. In the last reel the story rather snugly works in a surprise or two aboard one of those old-time trains, carring the principals. You can't criticize a choo-choo."A Town Called Hell" could have used one. Simulating Old Mexico, it looks even more sun-baked than the other picture, with some revolutionaries, soldiers, civilians and a priest murderously bunched up inside a fortress. With Robert Parrish's direction trying to add tone and dignity, the film lumbers uneasily between allegorical drama and bang-bang adventure.How a fine actor like Robert Shaw got trapped into this stumps us. It's a strange cast, indeedStella Stevens, Martin Landau, Michael Craig, Fernando Rey, Telly Savalas and Dudley Sutton, all of them looking about as Mexican as Fifi D'Orsay. The wonder is she didn't turn up in it somewhere.

title: Retailers to Keep Option of Supplying the Data by Mail on Request
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27  Under heavy business pressure, the Government dropped plans today to require merchants by Nov. 1 to provide customers on request with lists of maximum prices that can be charged un der the 90day freeze.

description: ALBANY, Oct. 27Governor Rockefeller promoted his pro posed $2.5billion transportation bond issue before an en thusiastic audience of business and labor leaders here today.

title: Aznavour Heir To Piaf Mantle
description: When a French singer sings a song, he is more concerned with the experience than the music. In the long line that stretches from the trouba dours to Piaf and Montand, it has always been sofirst the lyrics, the sheer theatri cal sensations of telling the story, and then, almost as an afterthought, the music.

description: This excerpt from a statement by Daniel P. Moynihan, U. S. representa tive to the third committee of the General Assembly, is followed by a re sponse from Kurt Janson, director of the social development division.

description: Probably any bass or bass baritone covets the title role of Boito's Mefistofele. It is singingactor's dream, dominat ing the opera from beginning to end. The latest person to as sume it in the New York City Opera's notable production is William Chapman, who sang it Tuesday night.

The American, who had blanked two previous oppo nents in the elimination trials leading to the world chal lenge match, was determined to make his triumph over the former world champion as convincing as possible.

Thirdquarter earnings rose 27.8 per cent to $28,203,000, or $1.12 a share, from $22, 074,000, or 96 cents a share, a year ago. Revenues were up 19.3 percent to $488,581,000, from $409,695,000.

Net income for the quarter was $15,338,363, or 51 cents a share, up from $14, 194,718, or 48 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose to $515, 790,173 from $452,745,671.

Now, when all courts are burdened and challenged, it is especially important that men and women of substance be elected to the bench when the voters go to the polls next Tuesday.

description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I. Just as soon as the sitter, his sister, arrived, Gary Walter checked on the chil dren: Ira, 8, was doing his homework; Lori, 6, was set tled in front of the television set. Mr. Walter then grabbed his looseleaf Parent's Man ual and hustled his wife, Marlene, into the car.

title: Screen: One Night in a Gay Bar
description: "Some of My Best Friends Are . . ." is a very sad gay movie about one night  Christmas Eve in a homosexual New York bar called the Blue Jay, a long, narrow firetrap with a bar in front and a large room in back for dancing, Christmas carols, frottage, hysterics and the exchanging of tearful confidences.In almost every way, including its ad campaign, it's a second-rate spin-off from "The Boys in the Band." Yet, because of this second-rateness, which includes hammy performances and a sentimental screenplay that sounds as if it had just been let out after 30 years in a closet, "Some of My Best Friends Are . . ." may well be more accurate than the slicker, wittier "Boys in the Band."When most of the characters in a movie are as full of dopey sentiments, as well as of self-hatred and of self-exploitation, as the movie that contains them, it's almost impossible to differentiate between an intentional second-rateness and serious moviemaking of no great quality.It's impossible, that is, until it becomes obvious that Mervyn Nelson, who both write the screenplay and directed the film, shares with his characters not only a large amount of boozy self-pity, but also the sort of romanticism that permits characters to define themselves-without ironyin the clichs of old-fashioned Hollywood soap opera.There are echoes of ancient Bette Davis laments when one young man wonders, aloud, if he's been living a lie, and when another fellow, a handsome Swiss ski instructor, tells his married male lover. "Facing death does not take courage. Two men facing a life together does."Better performances might possibly have given some life to such lines and situations, but under Mr. Nelson's solemn direction, they sound like parodies of real emotions.At one point or another in the film, Mr. Nelson manages to discover and exploit every stereotype of homosexual literature. In addition to the confused married man, there are the kid who is new to the game ("I'm from Nebraska and this is my first Christmas away from home"); the hustler who hates himself; the wise-cracking swish; the defrocked choirmaster; the straight guy who comes into the Blue Jay by mistake, and the angry mother who tells her homosexual son that from now on she considers him dead.Not all of the performances are bad, but I find it curious that the only decent performances are given by women  Sylvia Syms, as the Blue Jay's tough-talking sentimental hostess; by Rue McClanahan, as a rich, aging beauty who seeks out gay company, and by Candy Darling, the Andy Warhol superstar-transvestite who, in drag, looks like a pretty Barbra Streisand.Carleton Carpenter appears in what seems to be a cameo role as a prissy, eyeball-rolling old queen. As with the performances of the rest of the actors, I couldn't really tell whether his was purposely grotesque or just bad. Within the context of the rest of the movie, I suspect the latter."Some of My Best Friends Are . . ." opened yesterday at the 59th Street Twin Theaters.

title: Merchant Who Slew Hero Wounds Robbery Suspect
description: DETROIT, Oct. 27 (AP)  Charles Lee Van Landeghem, the store owner who shot and killed a Vietnam Medal of Honor winner, Sgt. Dwight H. Johnson, in a holdup attempt April 29, has shot and seriously wounded another apparent rob ber.

description: To the Editor:

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The Senate Finance Committee decided today to give the President discretionary author ity to continue indefinitely the buy American feature of the investment tax credit.

description: THINGS. By Francis Ponge. Translated by Cid Conran. 123 pages. A Mushinska Book by Grossman. $12.95, cloth. $4.95, paper.

description: Because of a clerical mixup Richmond Flowers, former Dal las defensive back, came to New York yesterday by way of Washington, replacing one of the three draft choices the Giants acquired Tuesday for their wide receiver, Clifton McNeil.

description: PEKING, Oct. 27The offi cial newspaper Jenmin Jih Pao, read by millions throughout China, gave over almost its en tire front page today to reports of the United Nations's decision to eject the Chinese Nationalists and hand the China seat to Peking.

title: Lawyer Group Acts To Block Publicity On Court Nominees
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27The American Bar Association's Committee on the Federal Ju diciary has taken steps to avoid news leaks as it plans to meet this weekend to evaluate the qualifications of Lewis F. Powell and William H. Rehn quist for the Supreme Court.

title: Economic Indicators Show No Clear Business Trend
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 New Government figures on re tail sales, productivity and other measures of the economy showed no cleat trend today either in business activity or in the battle against inflation.

description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange took another beating yesterday as trading activity increased.

description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 26 In 15 years, William H. Rehn quist's goals have shifted from winning the local toastmaster's speech contest to becoming an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court.

description: The Internal Revenue Serv ice, enforcement agency for President Nixon's wageprice freeze, since last Friday has been bringing pressure on re tailers to make ceiling prices available to consumers and warning them that failure to do so would make them liable to a $5,000 fine.

description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 27 (UPI)Rod Laver of Australia struggled for more than two hours today to beat Georges Goven of France, 57, 86, 63, and move into the quarter finals of the $48,000 Embassy tennis tournament.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Tenneco Advances
description: Reflecting record revenues, thirdquarter earnings of Ten neco, Inc., increased 9 per cent, the company said yesterday. For the first nine months, the Houston  based conglomerate concern had a 15 per cent profit gain.

title: 2 Dock Unions Warn of a Strike If U.S. Halts Wage Settlements

title: Stage:Comedy vs. Drama
description: As the second part of its Brown Bag project, the Chelsea Theater Center un veiled two more new plays by new American play wrights, David Wiltes and David Kranes, Tuesday eve ning at the Brooklyn Acad emy of Music.

title: AMNESTY GRANTED TO 3,000 VIETCONG

description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 27 (UPI)  Chuck Hughes, the wide receiver of the Detroit Lions football team, was buried today amid the rolling Green Hills of the state where he grew up. All 49 members of the Lions team attended the funeral.

title: UAL Shows a Profit

But this was not enough to wipe out large losses sustained earlier this year, and for the nine months the concern's net loss was $8.1million.

title: OBSERVER

title: PROMOTER PLEADS GUILTY TO PERJURY

title: Advertising:
description: As they are in Disneyland in California, both CocaCola and Pepsi Cola are being served in the new Walt Dis ney World near Orlando, Fla. Neither seems to have any definite ideas about tying that fact into any promotions.
