description: Glen Leet has been named president and David L. Guyer has been named executive di rector by the boards of direc tors of the Save the Children Federation and its cooperating agency, the Community Devel opment Foundation, it was an nounced yesterday.

title: CORPORATE BONDS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: The credit markets yesterday continued to question whether, the lower yields they had reached this week would hold for long.

title: Some Labor Aides Linking Wage Demands to Profits
description: A number of regional labor leaders, pointing to what they call windfall corporate profits, are demanding retroac tive wage increases for their members.

title: Schools, Not Pupils, Are Found at Fault in Reading Failures
description: A research report released yesterday by the Council for Basic Education charges that the failure in beginning read ing typical of innercity schools is the fault not of the chil dren or their background but of the schools.

title: 7 Americans Killed In Action Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 28 (AP)  The United States command reported to day that seven Americans were killed in action in Indo china last week, two more than the week before.

title: FLORIDIANS' RALLY TOPS COUGARS, 10491
description: MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 28 (AP) Larry Jones scored 30 points and the Floridians rallied in the fourth quarter for a 10491 American Basketball Associ ation victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight.

title: Sports of The Times
description: During his reign as baseball commissioner, Ford Frick was troubled by a procedure that had been nagging him ever since his early days as an active member of the Base ball Writers Association. It bothered him that so many of his lodge brothers repeatedly shortchanged the pitchers almost every balloting for most valuable player.

title: McNamara Sees World Perils
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 28 (Reuters)Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, called today for urgent measures to deal with rising unemployment, wide spread malnutrition and an ex ploding world population that he predicted would reach 10 billion before it was checked.

title: Defects in Terns Linked To L.I. Sound Pollution
description: A threeyear study of a colony of terns on Long Is land Sound has disclosed a rising incidence of birth de formities that researchers suspect may be caused by pollutants in the Sound's waters.

title: MARSEILLES GREETS BREZHNEV QUIETLY
description: MARSEILLES, France, Oct. 28 The Socialist Mayor of Mar seilles treated the Communist leader of the Soviet Union to day to a vintage display of southern French temper and politics.

title: BRONXITE CONVICTED IN CORRUPTION CASE
description: A Bronx jury deliberated for four hours yesterday before pronouncing Pasquale Trozzo guilty of perjury in the first degree in a case in which De tective Frank Serpico was a principal witness for the prose cution.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $815mil lion, up 11 per cent from the yearearlier $732million. Last week's total retail store sales were about $7,942,000,000 up 11 per cent from $7,186,000,000.

title: From the Pesto to the Pasta, Their Dishes Are Authentic
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and d cor (four triangles to none).

title: 2 Women Held as Rustlers
description: WARRENTON, Va., Oct. 28 (UPI)A 50yearold Virginia woman and her daughter have been charged with cattle rus tling. Mrs. Claudia Rakes and her daughter, Charlene, 20, of Deleplane, were arrested yes terday and charged with grand larceny in connection with the theft of 40 head of cattle. Sher iff Luther Cox said that the cattle had been loaded onto trucks and taken to neighbor ing counties for sale.

title: PARISHES ADOPT 1,500 JAIL INMATES
description: Thirty church parishes have adopted the 1,500 prisoners in the Brooklyn House of Deten tion for Men and a union has offered to stand moral bail for members accused of crimes in two new projects that in volve the community in the lives of prisoners.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
WPIX GETS BACKING OF PUBLIC OFFICIALS
description: Attorney General Louis J Lefkowitz, Controller Abra ham D. Beame and two former top city officials testified yes terday in support of WPIX news and public affairs pro gaming as a hearing into the television station's application to renew its license to operate Channel 11 resumed in New York.

title: Stars Post 6th in Row
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 28 (AP)The streaking Minne sota North Stars rolled to their sixth straight victory to night as Cesare Maniago stopped the Pittsburgh Pen guins, 20. Bill Goldsworthy had a secondperiod goal.

title: U.S. PRESENTS CASE ON AUSTIN SCHOOLS
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 (AP)  Government attorneys argued today that a school desegregation plan ordered for Austin, Tex., would accomplish only parttime integration for blacks and leave discrimination against MexicanAmericans vir tually untouched.

title: Letter of Intent Is Signed For 2 Lockheed Tristars
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration announced yesterday that it has signed a letter of intent with Court Line Aviation, a British charter airline, for the sale of two L1011 Tristar jet liners. The planes, with special modifications for highdensity seating, spare parts and spe cialized ground equipment, will cost about $48million.

title: Westinghouse and G.E. Set Price Rises on Transformers
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Electric Company announced yesterday price increases on transformers.

title: Unemployment a Factor
description: PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP)Observers viewed the bank rate cut as an effort to cure a nagging French unemployment problem.

title: An Open Letter to Gloria Steinem
description: Dear Miss Steinem:

title: 2 SENATORS URGE 6YEAR PRESIDENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Would a President of the Unit ed States be able to do a better job if he were limited to a single sixyear term?

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 28 (AP)Heavy fighting was reported today for a second day in the area of Rumlong, 52 miles northeast of here. The two days of enemy attacks came after enemy frogmen blew up a bridge on Route 6, cutting off movement of sup plies and reinforcements by land for the 20,000 troops on the northeastern front.

title: Shadow Star Captures Sheppard Pace
description: YONKERS, Oct. 28  Jack Kopas, who has won a lot of races, money and stature by training and driving Super Wave to several victories in this area, expanded each cate gory by steering Shadow Star to an easy triumph in the $44, 948 Lawrence B. Sheppard Pace before 15,363 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: 'Bless the Beasts & Children' Bows
description: In his latest movie, "Bless the Beasts & Children," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and Trans-Lux West, Stanley Kramer directs his attention to the American buffalo. Actually, he divides his attention between buffalo, who are going to be shot, and a group of six right-minded misfit rich kids who set out to save them. The kids, you see, are really like buffaloa trapped and endangered speciesand if they save the beasts they save themselves. I don't think I am being too subtle in making this point. The film makes it perhaps three dozen times, and the film is never too subtle.The kids all attend a Western riding camp ("Send Us a Boy; We'll Send You a Cowboy") where they share the misfits' bunk with an incredibly Yahoo counselor (Ken Swofford) who one day takes them to watch him help destroy a corral-full of superfluous buffalo. The kids are horrified. More buffalo will be killed in the future, and so the kids set out by horse, on foot, by stolen truckto perform their defiant act of mercy. Throughout their mission of mercy they experience many crises, and for each crisis somebody has a flashback that explains him.One kid isn't loved by his mother; another is loved too much; a pair of brothers suffer from sibling rivalry; one boy's father pays him no attention, while another boy's father pays him so much attention that he gets flustered and messes up his bar mitzvah. Everybody's character is thus an open book, a text book, and this raises a problem that the film doesn't faceas opposed to all the Problems it is so eager to face.What would have happened if the kids weren't disturbed? Would they still have freed buffalo if their parents had loved them  and/or kept their proper distance? Or would they have adopted the monstrous callousness that the film sees as "normal"without, however, doubting its normality? It seems reasonable to question the thesis of a thesis movie as feeble as this one. And although there is nothing else in Stanley Kramer's work to admire, I think it is worth pointing out that this time he also fails to deliver his standard humanitarian message."Bless the Beasts & Children" misuses a number at Western settings, several stock items of adventure and suspense, and all of its actors. It is difficult to discuss performance in a film such as this, in which most resources remain basically untapped. But before the movie ended I came to dislike Barry Robins who played his role as the maniacal master sergeant of the group with more hoked-up emotion than seemed necessary. And I came to admire Bill Mumy, the long-haired laconic leader, who managed to suggest a certain subversive independence and a depth of personality the movie could never begin to fathom.

title: U.S. May Give Saigon New Light Planes
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The Nixon Administration is considering providing South Vietnam with a new force of light armed aircraft to better equip it to take over the job of attacking supplies and troops moving down the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos.

title: WILLIAMS TO MODEL STRATEGY ON MAO'S
description: A black American civil rights leader said his recent four week visit to China helped him to see the many mistakes we have made in our struggle and helped him to formulate new strategies for the black movement in the United States.

title: Ski Show Opens Here With Spring Conditions
description: The annual fourday inter national ski and winter sports show opened at the New York Coliseum yesterday in weather that must have struck even the most zealous ski enthusiasts as being un seasonable.

title: Student Demonstration Ends in Melee
description: A demonstration by three separate groups of students outside Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn ended in disorder yes terday, with four youths and an adult taken into police custody.

title: SCHOOL BUS PASS MAY BE RESTORED
description: A plan to restore reduced fare passes for more than 60,000 public and parochial school children, whose passes were terminated by the Board of Education in September in an economy move, was disclosed at a City Council meeting yes terday.

title: Ballet: Joffrey Weewis
description: The City Center Joffrey Ballet's latest and last pre miere of the season is Margo Sappington's Weewis, a comicstrip ballet for people who read Dear Abby.

title: U.S., a Strong Supporter of Market, Now Finds It Very Tough Competitor
description: The European Economic Community, which Britain voted to join yesterday, is a bloc of sixsoon presumably to become 10Western Euro pean nations that joined to gether 15 years ago in a his toric effort to create unity in their divided continent.

title: ARREST OF BLACKS ENDS NEVADA SITIN
description: RENO, Oct. 28 Seventeen black students were arrested at the University of Nevada at Reno this evening when they refused to end their occupation of an office in the Student Union Building.

title: A DEATH DISPUTED IN JOHANNESBURG
description: CAPETOWN, Oct. 28  The death of a detained Indian in Johannesburg yeterday has re inforced pressure from the Asian community here and from civil rights advocates throughout South Africa for a judicial inquiry into allegations that political suspects have been tortured.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: BERLIN, Oct. 28East bloc diplomats said today that Mr. Brezhnev was expected to press for a speedy conclusion of the Germanlevel talks on Berlin during his stopover in East Germany this weekend on his way home from Paris.

title: Court of Appeals Refuses To Halt Amchitka ABlast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia refused today to halt the under ground nuclear test on Amchit ka Island pending the outcome of litigation by seven environ mental organizations.

title: Reverse Hijacking
description: The hijacking of airplanes to Cuba has by now become routine. Paranoids, political adventurers, and even dis contented husbands find perverse fulfillment in rerouting airplanes to Havana at gunpoint. But it is something new when the Cuban Government sends a delegation to this country without an invitation, without visas, without clearance to land its plane.

title: A Scientist Can Always Say No to Secrecy
description: LOS ANGELESWhen I was a schoolboy in the 1950's, I wanted to become a scientist, but I doubted that I could. It appeared to me that scien tists were more intelligent, more highminded and ultimately more re sponsible than men in other fields. In the years since then I have had some exposure to science and scientists and I have lost many of my illusions. But so far as I can tell, the general public has not.

title: U. N. Diplomats, Awaiting Chinese Team, Feel Its Impact Will Not Be Disruptive
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Oct. 28  Now that a Chinese Communist delegation is being awaited, delegates here are turning away from debating points that have occupied them for so many weeks and are studying the impact that Pe king is likely to have on the world organization.

title: Sadat's WarorPeace Deadline Nears
description: CAIRO, Oct. 28  Sadat: War or Peace This Year at Any Cost, Cairo's newspapers proclaimed in banner head lines last July 24 after Presi dent Anwar elSadat had promised the Egyptian people, impatient to be rid of the eter nal conflict with Israel, that they would not be asked to bear the frustrations of no war no peace beyond 1971.

title: Isolating America
description: The devastating diplomatic defeat sustained by the United States in the U.N. General Assembly vote on China raises serious questions about the conduct of American foreign policy not only in recent days but in recent years.

title: Merger News
description: The U. S. Home Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed definitive contracts to acquire three homebuilding companies for stock. Based on yesterday's closing price of U.S. Home on the New York Stock Exchange, at 28, the transactions have a total value of $38,014,000. The three companies to be acquired are Norwood Homes, Inc., Houston; Witkin Homes, Inc., Denver, and the Page Cor poration, Washington, D. C.

title: More Police Planned in Garment Area
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy unveiled a plan yesteday for the saturation patrolling of the garment dis trict in an effort to reduce street crime and pilfering.

title: Entire Gain Attributed to Foreign Results
description: DETROIT, Oct. 28  The Ford Motor Company reported today record sales for the third quarter of $3.8billion and net income of $86million, or 83 cents a share, but said that its entire improvement in earnings over 1970 came from its foreign operations.

title: Man in the News
description: For years, the question of who might succeed President Tito in Yugoslavia has been a matter of lively guesswork, speculation and suggestions, including some from Tito himself.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Drop
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 28 (Canadian Press)  The Government to day auctioned $175million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.142 and average yield of 3.47 per cent, compared with last week's 99.065 and 3.78 per cent. To day's $45million of 182day bills brought 98.244 and 3.58 per cent, against last week's 98.122 and 3.84 per cent.

title: British Withdraw in Irish Border Clash
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 28British and Irish so diers faced each other across the IrishUlster border today before the British withdrew, defeated in an argument about which side of the frontier a bridge was on.

title: One Dead in Pacific Quake
description: NOUMEA, New Caledonia, Oct. 28 (Reuters)One person was killed and many were in jured today by a severe earth quake that shook the town of Santo, on Espiritu Santo Is land in the French/British New Hebrides, official sources said.

title: Boeing Wins Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (Reuters)  The Defense De partment announced today that it would award to the Boeing Company two Minuteman weapons contracts worth more than $47million.

title: About Pro Football
description: The odds are against both the local teams in their games on Sunday. The Giants play Minnesota here while the Jets are at San Diego. The latter will be on televi sion, Channel 4 at 4 P.M., while Channel 2 will have New Orleans at Washington at 1 P.M. The Monday night game, Channel 7 at 9, is Green BayDetroit from Milwaukee. Here is a preview of all games won losttie records in parentheses.

title: SENATE, 47 T0 44, KILLS FUND CURB ON VIETNAM WAR
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Senate, by a threevote margin, today rejected a proposed amendment that would have specified that the President could not use funds in Indo china except to withdraw all American forces.

title: WILLIAM LEVI ALLEN
description: SUN CITY CENTER, Fla., Oct. 28 (UPI)William Levi Allen, former international president of the Commercial Telegraphers Union, died here Tuesday. His age was 76.

title: SENATORS PUT OFF TAX BILL DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  The Senate Finance Committee put off major decisions on the tax bill today as growing pres sure developed elsewhere in the Senate for increasing the im mediate individual income tax reductions that the committee had planned.

title: Gilbert Foyle, CoFounder Of Big London Bookstore
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP)Gil bert Foyle, cofounder of W. & G. Foyle, Ltd., one of the world's largest bookstores, died today at his seaside home in East bourne. He was 85 years old.

title: Wildenstein Holds Albert Marquet Retrospective
description: The French painter Albert Marquet (18751947) is an artist at once immensely ap pealing but essentially unas sertive, who seems to have got caught up in the storms of the avantgarde almost by chance. Known to art his torians and collectors as one of the Fauvist painters who caused a sensation at the Salon d'Automne in 1905, he is the sort of artist we now adays value more for his del icacy of perception than for any weighty historical influ ence. At his best, he was one of the sweetest land scape painters of the 20th century.

title: Rehabilitating a Loan Program
description: Designed to pump public money into the rehabilita tion of private housing in New York City, where hous ing deterioration has for several years been outstrip ping housing construction, the Municipal Loan Program has itself had worse than a leaky roof. The program was erected on the shifting sand of inadequate pro cedures; there were no checks or reviews.

title: ALBERT Z. CARR, AN ECONOMIST, 69
description: Albert Z. Carr, a writer, an economist and a consultant to two Presidents, died apparently of a heart attack at his home yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived at 290 Ninth Avenue.

title: GORMAN, NASTASE GAIN SEMIFINALS AT WEMBLEY NET
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 28 (AP)  Tom Gorman of Seattle powered his way into the men's semifinals and favored John Newcombe fell before Ilie Nastase of Rumania today in the $50,000 Embassy tennis tournament.

title: 2YearOld Falls to Death
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Two yearold Paulette MacDonald of the Dorchester section died to day after she fell from the thirdfloor rear porch of her home, the police said. The child fell to the pavement after she climbed on a table and then fell over a fourfoothigh railing.

title: Chiang Won't Yield Isles
description: TAIPEI, Oct. 28 (UPI)Presi dent Chiang Kaishek told Chi nese Nationalist party support ers today that his Government had no intention of surrender ing Taiwan or the offshore islands of Quemoy and Matsu because of the loss of its United Nations seat.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Denies Motion by Gravel To Halt Pentagon Papers Jury
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28A motion by Senator Mike Gravel, Demo crat of Alaska, to halt a grand jury investigation into the pub lication of the Pentagon papers was denied today, but Federal District Judge W. Arthur Gar rity Jr. barred testimony by two key witnesses for 10 days.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISBritish entry into the Com mon Market, one of the most im portant political events since World War II, became a certainty last year when Edward Heath's Conservative Government took power in the United Kingdom and General de Gaulle died in retirement. The general had in sistently blackballed the membership application of this Continent's most important offshore island.

title: Twins Police Delivered Are Fighting for Lives
description: A pair of premature twin girls, delivered to an unwed mother in the East New York section of Brooklyn by two policemen Wednesday night, were fighting for their lives in Kings County Hospital last night.

title: Romney Asks City Planning With System Used in Spain
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Develop ment, said today that the United States needs to plan and develop its cities the way it is being done in Spain.

title: MARKET EDGES UP AFTER 11 LOSSES
description: The stock market scored a token gain yesterday, after dropping for 11 straight ses sions. There was no compelling news to account for the small recovery and Wall Street ana lysts labeled it as a technical move.

title: Metal Concern Off 54% Alcan in Decline
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corpo ration followed the trend among steel companies and re ported yesterday lower sales, revenues, net income and pro duction for the third quarter and first nine months of 1971. In fact, thirdquarter net in come dropped to its lowest lev el for any quarter since the third quarter of 1959, when there was a steel strike.

title: Economic Analysis
description: TORONTO, Oct. 28In his 1970 book Canada and the Canadians, George Woodcock recommended that his country men take measures to dimin ish the United States influence over the Canadian economy.

title: U.S. Aid to Addicts In Military Called Farcical and Inept
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Representative John M. Murphy of Staten Island said today that execution of Administration programs for voluntary rehabil itation of military drug addicts ranged from the farcical to the inept.

title: PLAN CHIEF FEARS A CITY FUND CRISIS
description: If the amendment to increase the city's borrowing power is defeated in Tuesday's election, the municipal capital construc tion program for 197273 will be intolerably slashed, City Planning Commissioner Donald H. Elliott warned yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Angry Hangover
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 28The net of the China debate for President Nixon is that he has lost influence in the world and picked up popularity at home. This paradox is worth examin ing.

title: Strikes Reduce Profit of Union Pacific
description: The 18day strike that the United Transportation Union called last July against the Union Pacific Railroad cost that carrier more than $7million in excess of strike insurance, the railroad's parent, the Union Pacific Corporation, reported yesterday.

title: EARLY AMEX LOSS ERASED BY RALLY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended practically un changed yesterday in moderate trading. A midsession rally erased most of the earlier losses.

title: Woodcock Asks Health Plan Modeled on Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, Oct 28 (AP) Leonard Woodcock, presi dent of the United Auto Work ers, called on Congress today to enact a Social Security type of health plan and to reject President Nixon's health pro posal.

title: Officials Stress That Freeze Won't Automatically End
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28The Government reminded the pub lic repeatedly today that the freeze on wages, prices, and rents would not end auto matically on Nov. 13.

title: Foreman Faces Pires on Road to Title
description: George Foreman brings his touring boxing show to Madison Square Garden tonight, and Luis Pires, the costar, hopes to make it last longer than most of the unbeaten heavyweight's other appearances.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: British Journal Says Tests Hint Diabetes May Be Caused by One or More Viruses
description: American scientists' experi ments on animals and British physicians' observations on hu mans have raised the possibili ty that one or more viruses may cause diabetes in some pa tients, particularly children, ac cording to a leading medical journal.

title: Orioles Battle to 33 Tie In Japan Exhibition Game
description: KORIYAMA, Japan, Oct. 28 (AP)  The Baltimore Orioles battled through 10 innings today to a 33 tie with the Yomiuri Giants after Andy Etchebarren blasted a home run with two out in the ninth.

title: Nixon and Capital Greet Tito Warmly
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  President Nixon conferred with President Tito of Yugoslavia on a wide range of issues today as official Washington gave the 79yearold Communist leader an unusually warm welcome on his first state visit to this country.

title: U.S. TROOPS ON ALERT FORTHIEUINAUGURAL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 29 (AP)Expect ing increased enemy attacks, the United States command issued an order yesterday plac ing American troops on the alert for the weekend, cover Nguyen Van Thieu's inaugura tion for a second term.

title: JAMES G. ARGYROS
description: ROSELLE, N. J., Oct. 28 James G. Argyros of 715 Golf Terrace, an insurance broker here who served as Mayor for four twoyear terms, died today at his home of a heart attack. His age was 57.

title: I.R.S. Is Investigating Reports Of MeatPrice Violations Here
description: The Internal Revenue Serv ice is conducting an investiga tion to determine if there have been violations of the price freeze here in the retail sale of meat.

title: EFFORT BY BRITISH BEGAN DECADE AGO
description: LONDON, Oct. 28On July 31, 1961, Britain began her decadelong struggle to join the European Common Market. On that date Prime Minister Har old Macmillan told the House of Commons that the Govern ment, then as now under the Conservative party, intended to make the application.

title: FOOD PROCESSOR HAS PROFIT GAIN
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 28  Share holders of the Consolidated Foods Corporation got some good news about increased earnings today and some less happy news that dividends won't be increased at present because of the President's re quest that payouts not be in creased as part of his econom ic program.

title: Had Trouble With Moving Man? Here's the Place to Complain
description: The furniture is scratched, a box of ornaments is missing and the final bill is double the original estimate.

title: DICKSON CARDS 68 FOR STROKE LEAD IN LAS VEGAS GOLF
description: LAS VEGAS, Oct. 28 (AP) Bob Dickson shot a fourunder par 68 in bitter cold and gusty winds today to take the first round lead in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tourna ment.

title: BRUINS LOSE, 20, TO SEALS' ROOKIE
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28 (AP)Gil les Meloche, a rookie goalie making his first start of the season, turned in a spectacular performance tonight by frus trating the Boston Bruins and sparking the California Golden Seals to a 20 victory.

title: Kosygin and Castro Hold Their Second Round of Talks
description: HAVANA, Oct. 28 (Reuters) Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin and Premier Fidel Castro today held their second round of official talks since the Soviet leader's arrival in Cuba Tuesday.

title: Helio Bonus Wins Dash For Pincay's 3d Victory
description: Helio Bonus was guided along the rail through most of the running of the feature event at Aqueduct yesterday, and this aroundsaving tactic enabled Rose Mistretta's filly to regis ter a neck triumph over Wil Jim Haggin Perry's Equinoce.

title: BASIL STAROS DEAD; SPERRY RAND AIDE
description: Basil Staros, an aeronautical engineer, died yesterday in Memorial Hospital after a brief illness. He was 51 years old and lived at 12 Tuxedo Drive, Melville, L. I.

title: Agnew Leaves His '72 Role Up to Practical Politics
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)  Vice President Agnew says he wants President Nixon to decide in a cold, hard, prac tical political way whether to keep him on the Republican ticket in 1972.

title: 77 A Day for Philosophers
description: First it was funny furs, then fake furs, then the econ omy gets worse than bad, then we're going to recognize Red China with its fursit's not enough we get Greek furs and Russian fursthen the ecologists scream we're killing animals, and now it's 74 degrees and it's almost November. It's beautiful but it's not going to sell many minks.

title: Casper Ahead in Japan
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 28 (Reuters)Billy Casper of the United States shot a first round fourunderpar 68 today in the Tokai Golf Classic for a twostroke lead over Jiro Matsuda of Japan.

title: F.B.I. Questioning Possible Opponents Of 2 Nixon Choices
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 The F.B.I., in gathering inform ation on President Nixon's two nominees to the Supreme Court Lewis F. Powell Jr. and Wil liam H. Rehnquist has taken the unusual step of pressing in quiries among possible oppon ents of the two choices.

title: Fischer Is Honored; He Hails Petrosian As a Good Sport
description: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 28  The American chess phenom enon, Bobby Fischer, stayed long enough here tonight to receive a medal, make a short but gracious speech and sign a few autographs before fleeing an adoring multitude.

title: Abs Asks TopLevel Decisions on Money
description: One of Europe's leading fi nancial thinkers called yester day for political agreement at the highest level to resolve the world monetary crisis.

title: Bard College Fund Drive For $6Million Announced
description: The Bard College Twelfth Decade Fund campaign was an nounced last night at a meet ing at the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. L. Gardiner. Mr. Gardiner is a member of the college's board of trustees.

title: U.S. Trade Surplus Is First in 6 Months
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  The United States had a trade surplus in September for the first time in six months, but there was no telling whether the change represented a trend.

title: The British Are Coming!
description: Prime Minister Heath has won with astonishing ease the first round of his battle in Parliament to get Britain into the European Economic Community. The majority in the House of Commons of 112 in favor of entry far surpassed the hopes of even the most optimistic Euro peans. By way of sealing this historic decision, the House of Lords also approved entryby the lopsided margin of 451 to 58.

title: Farce, Vietcong Charge
description: PARIS, Oct. 28  The Com munist delegations to the Viet nam peace talks refused today to accept the liberation of pris oners by the Saigon Govern ment as a gesture of goodwill, and instead condemned it as a farce.

title: RAIL TONNAGE OFF; TRUCK VOLUME RISES
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended Oct. 23 was considerably below the volume in the correspond ing week of last year. Intercity truck tonnage in the period registered an increase.

title: HERRMANN EAGER TO RETURN SUNDAY
description: Ask Don Herrmann what bone is the easiest to break and the New York Giants' 24 yearold split end will tell you it's the collarbone.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES REGISTER A GAIN
description: Active buying of commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday was one result of the announcement that longshoremen at New Orleans and Philadelphia had returned to work.

title: British Order Five Tristars
description: LONDON, Oct. 28 (UPI) Court Line Aviation Ltd., a British charter airline, said to day it has ordered two Lock heed Tristar jets, a $50million order, and signed options for three more.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Last Monday rifle  toting deer hunters were abroad in New York State's northern zone and on Nov. 15 the big game firearms season opens in the southern half of the state.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 0.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 106.5 from 106.4 last week.

title: MRS. MURCHISON, 76, SPEED TYPIST, DEAD
description: Mrs. Bessie Friedman Mur chison, whose 1918 speed rec ord on a manual typewriter is believed never to have been exceeded, died on Tuesday at the New York Infirmary. She was 76 years old and lived at 444 East 20th Street.

title: SATO FOILS FOES IN UPPER HOUSE
description: TOKYO, Oct. 28The be leaguered Government of Pre mier Eisaku Sato won another skirmish with its critics in Par liament today when it turned back another motion of no con fidence.

title: DONNY HATHAWAY PLAYS BITTER END
description: Donny Hathaway, appearing at the Bitter End this week, should be heard. That's the way one usually ends a re view, but in this case I'm much more concerned with urging you to go experience his music for yourself than I am with making critical points.

title: BAN ON REPORTERS AT ATTICA UPHELD
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 28Federal Judge John T. Curtin refused today to order the Attica Cor rectional Facility to permit newsmen to interview inmates.

title: Notes on People
description: Under the proud eye of his granduncle, Earl Mount batten of Burma, former Admiral of the Fleet, Prince Charles of Britain marched with 12 other student of ficers in a graduation parade at Dartmouth, the Royal naval academy. The 22year old heir to the throne had completed six weeks of basic training and next week he boards the guided missile de stroyer Norfolk for nine months of duty as a deck sublieutenant. The Prince, who has already qualified as an Air Force pilot, climbed into a helicopter with Lord Mountbatten after the grad uation ceremony, officially becoming a midshipman, and flew off to lunch with his mother, Queen Elizabeth , at Buckingham Palace.

title: Lynch Asks British to Halt
description: DUBLIN, Oct. 28A state ment issued tonight by Prime Minister John Lynch called on Britain to end the futile and dangerous bordersealing op eration.

title: The Cry in Nebraska Is Beat Colorado
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 28 Mediocre Supreme Court Justices may be fine for some Nebraskans, but football fans in this state have come to ex pect nothing less than the best from their college team, No. 1 in the current national rankings.

title: COAL INDUSTRY AIDES DENY TIMES REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28  Coal industry officials cate gorically denied a report in today's New York Times that the mine operators had offered to increase wages by $9 a day over a threeyear contract, to $46 a day.

title: The Screen The Railway Children
description: What's this? A clean pic ture? A family picture? Yes, and a good one at the right roost, the showplace of the nation.

title: ExCity Detective Gets Year On an Obstruction Charge
description: A former city detective who pleaded guilty to a charge of obstruction of government ad ministration was sentenced to a year in prison yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Harold Birns.

title: Reserves Decline
description: PARIS, Oct. 28 (Reuters) France's gold and currency re serves fell 373 million francs to 35,581 million in the week ended Oct. 21, the Bank of Frence said.

title: AMEX EXHEAD ASKS SHIFT BY BIG BOARD
description: Edwin D. Etherington, former president of the American Stock Exchange, last night called for a rebalancing of the governing board of the New York Stock Exchange to include larger numbers of persons who are not members or allied members.

title: Morality and Controls:
description: ELY, Vt.Enforcement of the price and wage controls, as of the freeze, must depend heavily on encouraging ordinary citizens to be informersto report violations to Government of ficials.

title: GAINS REPORTED FOR L.I. LIGHTING
description: The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the September quarter.

title: Bank Rate Is Lowered by France To 6% to Stimulate Economy
description: PARIS, Oct. 28 (Reuters) France today lowered its bank rate from 6 to 6 per cent in a mainly psychological move to stimulate the economy.

title: CAMBODIA MOVES TO HALT INFLATION
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 28  Cambodia announced to day a stringent program to halt inflation. The program was worked out in close liaison with the United States and the International Monetary Fund.

title: Jordan Links Gangemi to Underworld
description: JERSEY CITY, Oct. 28Dr. Paul Jordan, the reform candi date in Tuesday's special mayoral election, said today that Thomas Gangemi Jr., one of his two major rivals in the city campaign, once was a business partner of the reputed Mafia leader in Detroit.

title: A LEBANESE DENIES HALPERN'S CHARGES
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 28 A member of the Lebanese Parliament condemned today, as an outright lie the charges by a United States Representa tive that he was the owner of hashish fields that include a landing strip heavily guarded by machine guns.

title: FederalMogul Operation Cut
description: DETROIT, Oct. 28 (UPI)  FederalMogul Corporation has announced it is gradually get ting out of the business of making tapered roller bear ings for the passenger auto mobile original equipment mar ket. It will close the Shoe maker plant in Detroit in 12 to 24 months and the Hart plant in 24 to 48 months. Over the whole period, about 1,900 em ployes will be dropped. The company said the decision, which ultimately would result in a $10million writeoff, was made because of profit erosion in this part of the bearing market.

title: The Greening of Reform
description: Sixty millionaires have taken a pledge to finance only those Presidential candidates who are committed to reforming the very system that has made them candi dates. European observers who are normally bewildered by politics in the United States should be altogether dazed by this attempt at the figurative greening of Amer ica through the literal greening of its leaders.

title: Saint Laurent's Giant Step Away From Haute Couture
description: PARIS, Oct. 28Yves Saint Laurent, the designer who feels that he can be more influential in readytowear than in haute couture, showed a 300piece boutique col lection today. It included everything from beach dresses to city separates to meet the needs of women throughout the world next spring.

title: Market Place: NoLoad Fund: A Real Saving?
description: The Little Guy has grown increasingly aware of and in terested in the noload mu tual fund.

title: Bridge: Jay Wendt Leading '71 Race For Spero Memorial Trophy
description: The most reliable measure of expert performance in the New York metropolitan area is given by the results of the team events in sectional and regional championships. Leading the 1971 race for the Richard Spero Memorial Trophy, based on these re sults, is the New York ex pert Jay Wendt.

title: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY SURGING FORWARD
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 28 Taiwan's gross national produce this year will rise by 10 to 12 per cent and, in view of the problems that have beset Japan South Korea and other fast growth countries, this will be among the world's best eco nomic performances for 1971.

title: Jewish Group Says Nixon Trip Spurs a Wave of AntiSemitism
description: BOSTON, Oct. 28The Amer ican Jewish Committee said today that extremist rightwing publications were utilizing President Nixon's coming visit to China as a new stratagem for intensifying an antiZionist and antiSemitic campaign in the United States.

title: Ray Palmer in Semifinals Of Pinehurst Seniors Golf
description: PINEHURST, N.C., Oct. 28 Ray Palmer of Grosse Isle, Mich., got a birdie today on the last hole after losing the 16th and 17th for a 1up victory over Tom Draper of Troy, Mich., in the quarterfinals of the North and South seniors golf tourna ment.

title: VINCENT M. KELLY SR.
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., Oct. 28 Vincent M. Kelly Sr., who re tired in 1968 as an assistant vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank after 43 years with the company, died today apparently of a heart attack at Syosset Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 175 School Street.

description: NAPOLEON. By Andr Castelot. Translated by Guy Daniels. 622 pages. Harper & Row, $12.50.

title: Books of The Times
description: OUR GANG (Starring Tricky and His Friends), By Philip Roth. 200 pages. Random House. $5.95.

title: Additional Rivals Threaten Muskie and McGovern in Wisconsin
description: MILWAUKEE, Oct. 27Wis, consin's critical Presidential primary election will take place on April 4, 1972, only five months from now.

title: THERMAL POLICIES SCORED BY LILCO
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 28A Long Island Lighting Company official said today that four Federal and state agencies, in a largely unintentional juris dictional struggle for control of thermal discharges, were impeding the development of critically needed nuclear and conventional power plants.

title: Output and G.N.P. Are Found at Odds
description: Industrial production, a meas ure of the nation's factory output, is running contrary to gross national product, the sum of total output of goods and services, Pierre Rinfret, con sulting economist, pointed out yesterday.

title: Giants to Offer Free Tickets Tomorrow at Special Event
description: Rocky Thompson, Bobby Du hon and Roland Lakes of the New York Giants will demon strate football fundamentals at Yankee Stadium tomorrow morning in a special show spon sored by the Giants and the Getty Oil Company.

title: Some Excerpts From Testimony at Knapp Hearing
description: Following are excerpts from testimony heard by the Knapp Commission yesterday during its eighth day of pub lic hearings arising from its inquiry into police corrup tion.

title: Protests Made at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 28The planned United States nuclear test on Amchit ka Island drew protests today in the Political Committee of the United Nations.

title: The Talk of Marshalltown
description: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa, Oct. 28When the Marshall town Kiwanis Club met this morning for its weekly hour of breakfast brotherhood, Representative John C. Cul ver showed up to politick a little and to discuss Com munist China's admission to the United Nations. Emotionally, and at some length, the Democrat ap plauded the decision to let Peking in and deplored the decision to throw Taiwan out. Then he asked: Any questions?

title: Greyhound Had 20% Gain In ThirdQuarter Profit
description: The Greyhound Corporation, a diversified holding company that operates the nation's larg est bus system, had a 20 per cent gain in thirdquarter earn ing and 32 per cent rise in the latest nine months.

title: Estimate Board Backs 2 Big Waterfront Projects
description: Two city waterfront projects  industrial development on the old Brooklyn Navy Yard site and the world's largest convention center, on the Hud son River shore  were ad vanced yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: Police Sergeant Gets a Raise For His Team's Work in Slums
description: The head of the Police De partment's first neighborhood police team, set up in Jan uary to reduce crime and bring the police closer to the people of a slum section of Brooklyn, was cited for outstanding per formance yesterday and re warded with a rise in pay.

title: Callas Stars in Pasolini 'Medea'
description: Pier Paolo Pasolini's very free, very barbaric "Medea," which is less an adaptation of the Euripides play than an interpretation of it, is not completely successful, but it is so full of eccentric imagination and real passion that I'd rather sit through the 10 worst minutes of it than the five best minutes of Michael Cacoyannis's reverential adaptation of "The Trojan Women."If your priorities are such, Pasolini's "Medea" can be an excellent argument for the kind of literal movie made by Cacoyannis, in which the audience is treated to an articulate recitation of a text that has survived 2,400 years with its power intact. This sort of film provides a valuable service if you can't read, or if you never have access to decent stage productions."Medea" is something else entirely. Pasolini has the monumental and marvelous presumption to put himself ahead of Euripides (who was not, after all, a moviemaker), in an attempt to translate into film terms the sense of a prehistoric time, place and intelligence in which all myths and rituals were real experiences.This is Pasolini's interest, and in casting Maria Callas in the title role he has visualized his theme with extraordinary success, I was never much taken by Callas's acting at the Metropolitanit tended to be a bit broad for even that broad stage. Under Pasolini's direction, she becomes a fascinating cinematic presence, possessed with a power that has, I suspect, less to do with an ability to act, in conventional terms, anyway, than with her grace of movement (which is a part of acting, I admit), and with her magnificent face.The profile, which Pasolini obviously adores, looks like the model for something on an ancient coin. Full face, you see a bone structure that defies all enemies, including age. The huge, dark eyes seem so heavily lashed that the effort taken just to shift a glance becomes the physical equivalent of the emotional upheavals within the mind.Almost half of the film, which has practically no dialogue, concerns itself with the events that precede the Euripides playwith Jason's early education at the feet (four) of a philosophical centaur, and with the subsequent voyage of the Argonauts to Colchis, where, with Medea's help, Jason successfully steals the Golden Fleece.These sequences are brilliant and brutal, and run the very close risk of seeming ludicrous. Pasolini evokes Medea's heritage in terms that I'm sure Euripides would find unspeakableincluding a human sacrifice shown in respectful detailin order to establish the basis for her later, terrifying bloodbath in Corinth when Jason decides to take a new wife.Pasolini's Medea is no longer a rather ill-tempered woman spurned, an early Women's Liberationist, a mother guilty of the sort of murders that were as appalling to the ancient Greeks as it was to a Queens jury earlier this year.In Pasolini's conception, Medea is a primeval soul who erupts almost spontaneously when transplanted into a civilization ruled by order. And this, I think, is where the film goes awry.There is no real conflict between Pasolini's conception and Euripides's Pasolini's supplements the other's, but because nothing in Pasolini's imagery in the scenes in Corinth is equal to the passion of the original text, or to Pasolini's own scenes early in the film, the movie seems to go thin and absurdly melodramatic.Some of this has to do with the performers with which Pasolini has surrounded CallasJason, for example, looks like the rather nice, blank-faced Olympic athlete that Guiseppi Gentile, who plays him, is. One also begins to become aware of the dcor and the costumes, which are beautiful, but would not look out of place in a Broadway musical, and I, for one, was brought up short when Jasonfriend to Hercules, future son-in-law of Creonis shown blowing kisses to Medea, daughter of the Sun."Medea" is uneven, but I admire the reckless courage of its conception, even when it goes wrong. When it is right, as in the poetic and funny prologue, delivered by the centaur (Laurent Terzief), and in its eerie evocation of Medea's world, which (according to Pasolini) is our subconscious world, it is superb."Medea" opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.

title: SIPHONING IS LAID TO RAIL COMPANY
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UPI)  Interstate Commerce Com mission investigators have ac cused a conglomerate that oper ates the Kansas City Southern Railway of siphoning off the railroad's assets to finance moneylosing business ventures.

title: NICKLAUS 68 SHARES AUSSIE OPEN LEAD
description: HOBART, Australia, Oct. 28 (UPI)Jack Nicklaus of the United States, despite putting lapses on the final two holes, shared the lead at 68 in the opening round of the $22,400 Australian open golf tourna ment today with Graham John son of Australia.

title: Montreal Paper Shuts Down
description: MONTREAL, Oct. 28 (Cana dian Press)La Presse suspend led publication today. The larg est Frenchlanguage daily in North America, with a circula tion of about 225,000, La Presse announced that it would remain shut down until its long and at times violent labor dispute with 350 production and distribution workers had been settled.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: MRS. RAYMOND GRAY
description: NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 28Mrs. Raymond Gray, court stenog rapher for Rockland County Surrogate John F. Skahen and a member of the Rockland County Republican Committee for 43 years, died this morning in Nyack Hospital after a long illness. She was 64 years old. Her husband had been Ny ack's police chief for many years.

title: RIGHTS ACT URGED FOR HANDICAPPED
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith said yesterday that Federal equal rights legis lation was needed now to assure the integration of the blind, and all the handicapped, into American life.

title: Jewish Theological Choices Confirmed by Selection Unit
description: A spokesman for the Jewish Theological Seminary con firmed yesterday that the se lection committee advising on the new leadership of the in stitution had recommended Dr. Gerson D. Cohen for pres ident and Dr. Bernard Mandel baum for chancellor.

title: StudentBusiness Groups Grow
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A week after a conference of 215 students and more than 150 corporate executives, a national network of groups for student business interaction is being organized.

title: CABINET IN FINLAND QUITS OVER PRICES
description: HELSINKI, Finland, Oct. 29 (Reuters)Finland's fourparty coalition Government resigned today over its inabilty to resolve a threeweekold dispute over agricultural prices.

title: Daylight Time to End At 2 A.M. Tomorrow
description: Daylight saving time will end at 2 A.M. tomorrow, when standard time returns for six months.

title: Film of Comedians on C.B.S. Is Protested by Haitian Envoy
description: The Haitian Embassy in Washington issued a statement yesterday protesting Thursday night's telecast on the Columbia Broadcasting System network of The Comedians, a 1967 MetroGoldwyn  Mayer film based on Graham Greene's novel about political terror in Haiti.

title: BELFAST POLICEMAN IS KILLED BY BOMB
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Oct. 29 (Reuters)A policeman was killed and two were injured when a police station was blown up here today.

title: AMEX POSTS GAIN AFTER 12 DECLINES
description: The American Stock Exchange registered its first advance in 13 sessions yesterday as most issues rose in slower trading.

title: Heavy Cost Seen in U.N. Defeat
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The dimensions of the United States effort to prevent the expulsion of Nationalist China from the United Nations have raised questions here about the overall political and diplomatic cost of the campaign.

title: Shock Expressed in U.N. On Defeat of Aid Measure
description: United Nations officials and delegates expressed shock last night that the Senate had killed the foreign aid bill.

title: MOUNT HELPS PACERS DOWN STARS, 121109
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 29 (AP)The Indiana Pacers, with Rick Mount's 24 paints leading a balanced scoring attack, beat the Utah Stars, 121109, tonight and strengthened their hold on the Western Division lead.

title: ELECTRICITY USED TO HEAL FRACTURE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 University of Pennsylvania surgeons reported today the first successful, case of healing an ununited fracture in a human by electricity.

title: Defiant Laborites Trying to Heal Rift
description: LONDON, Oct. 29Members of the Labor party Opposition who defied their leaders and supported Britain's entry into the European Common Market the position overwhelmingly approved by Parliament last nightmoved today to try to heal the breach in the party.

title: MRS. HARRY J. EVANS
description: Mrs. Margaret Johnson Evans, the widow of Harry J. Evans, former head of a United States mission to Korea and the mother of Llewellyn J. Evans, president of the Grumman Corporation and board chairman of the Grumman Aerospace Corporation, died on Wednesday in Warrenton, Va. She was 83 years old.

title: Knicks Lose Reed for Week
description: A new page in the medical journal on Willis Reed's sore left knee was written yesterday and as a result the Knicks' captain will take a week off from the rigors of the National Basketball Association schedule.

title: The City's Backward Priorities
description: New Yorkers are so bemused by their astronomical budget that they seem indifferent to the accelerating deterioration of the city's economy. The rate of increase in expenditures is even more frightening than the almost unbelievable numbers. Whether or not the Mayor is inept, it is unlikely that future administrations will be any more able to achieve meaningful savings in the performance of essential services. The best that can be realistically hoped for is that the increase in costs will be slowed.

title: A SELLOFF TRIMS SOYBEAN FUTURES
description: Soybean futures soared in early trading yesterday, only to fall just as sharply under profit taking in late dealings on the Chicago Aoard of Trade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Sharp, Bond Expert For Smithers & Co., Is Dead
description: Robert W. Sharp, a member of the municipal bond department of F. S. Smithers & Co., Wall Street, died of cancer yesterday. He was 70 years old and lived at 247 West 4th Street.

title: Sir Hamilton A. R. Gibb Dead; Authority on the Middle East
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 Colleagues at Harvard University received word today of the death in England on Oct. 22 of Sir Hamilton Gibb, an authority on the Middle East and the first director of. Harvard's Center for Middle Eastern studies. He was 76 years old.

title: Shop Talk
description: If your knowledge of African art or crafts is limited to carvings of those sausagebreasted damsels that seem to find their way onto the shelves of the least discern ing of import shops, a visit to Nairobi, Ltd., might be quite an eyeopener. Discount the garishly painted yellow faade and the rather crowded little window of this gallery shop at 209 West, 79th Street (near Am sterdam Avenue), and go inside. As one might expect from a store that names itself after the capital of Kenya, the emphasis is on crafts and artifacts from that country. But the contrasting topography (from desert to rich farmland) and the different tribes, (some agricultural, some nomadic) of that East African country produce a sufficient variety of objects to satisfy a wide range of tastes. And there are things from other parts of Africa as well.

title: Roche of G.M. Finds U.S. Hurt by Productivity Lag
description: James M. Roche, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, yesterday placed much of the blame for America's weakened world trade position on this nation's diminishing rate of productivity growth.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Draper installed at City U.
description: Dr. Edgar D. Draper was officially inaugurated president of the Borough of Manhattan Community College of the City University of New York yesterday afternoon in ceremonies at Alice Tully Hall in Lincoln Center. Dr. Draper became acting president of the college on May 18, 1970, and was named president on Oct. 28 of the same year. He was formerly president of Tubman College in Liberia. He joined the college in 1966 as associate dean.

title: STRIKING I.L.A. GIVES YONKERS EASEMENT
description: The International Longshoremen's Association strike committee gave two locals permission yesterday to unload 18,000 pounds of raw sugar tied up in Yonkers since the start of a job stoppage that has kept most major Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports closed down since Oct. 1.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Norton Company, Worcester, Mass., which says it is the world's largest manufacturer of abrasives, received a patent this week for its revolutionary grinding wheel. The Invention makes possible the treatment of 16,000 linear feet of metal or other surface a minute. Patent 3,615,302 was granted to Robert A. Rowse and Roy S. Nelson, research engineers for the company. The wheel, descendant of the grindstone that Americans once used to sharpen their knives and farm tools, is made of abrasives such as silicon carbide or aluminum oxide, bonded ceramicallylike porous pottery.

title: Youths Advise U.S. on Drug Fight
description: Students at an informal hearing of the National Commission on Marijuana and Drug Abuse testified yesterday that the thing to learn about marijuana is that it's no big deal.

title: STOCKS UP AGAIN BY A THIN MARGIN
description: Stockmarket averages edged higher yesterday for their second successive gain, after having gone down for 11 sessions in a row.

title: United Air Lines Sets Up A Communications Division
description: United Air Lines, Inc., announced, yesterday the establishment of a computer and communicationsservices division, with Donald L. Larson as its president.

title: TREVINO, AT 141, LEADS BY STROKE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 29 (AP)Lee Trevino, wearing a golf glove on each hand to protect against the biting cold and blustery Winds, matched par 72 today and took the secondround lead in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournamenu.

title: Penn Central Co. Lists Loss for '70
description: The Penn Central Company, the holding company that owns all the stock of the bankrupt railroad, reported yesterday a $425,956,000 net loss for 1970. This included the Penn Central Transportation Company's $425,739,000 net loss for last year, previously reported by the railroad's trustees.

title: FOREIGN AID BILL BEATEN, 4127, IN SURPRISE ACTION BY SENATE; NIXON CALLS IT IRRESPONSIBLE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Senate voted unexpectedly tonight to kill the Nixon Administration's $3.3billion foreign aid authorization bill. The tally was 41 to 27.

title: Central Park North: Typically Harlem
description: Central Park North is no Central Park South, No horses pull hansom cabs along the uptown street, no famed hotels or luxury apartments stand there.

title: Blount Resigns as Postal Chief; Alabama Senate Pace Foreseen
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Postmaster General Winton M. Blount handed President Nixon his resignation today, clearing the way for a 1972 campaign against Senator John J. Sparkman of Alabama.

title: Soviet Bars Cuts in Consumer Items in High Demand
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29The Soviet leadership, beset by continuing shortages of some consumer goods as the national holiday approaches, issued stringent instructions today prohibiting industry front reducing or halting production of any items for which demand still far exceeds simply.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Bias Fight Halts Airport Work
description: NEWARK, Oct. 29  A conflict between Newark's black community and construction trade unions has halted new construction in the massive rebuilding of Newark Airport.

title: Brezhnev and Pompidou End Parley
description: PARIS, Oct. 29President Pompidou and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist part leader, wound up weeklong talks today with a session on security and military problems in Europe.

title: BANK TRIMS RATE AS FLOAT SPREADS
description: The banking industry's new floating prime rate actually started to float yesterday in response to market forces while at the same time the concept gained an important new adherent.

title: Court Halts Jury's Inquiry on Pentagon Papers to Consider Appeal by Gravel
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29A grand jury investigation into the release and distribution of the secret Pentagon papers was halted for at least a week today by the, United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: Excerpts From Yesterday's Testimony to Knapp Commission
description: Following are excerpts from testimony heard yesterday by the Knapp Commission on the ninth day of public hearings arising from its inquiry into police corruption here.

title: April in Paris Ball Is a Lavish as Ever
description: The Duchess of Windsor sent her regrets. Mrs. Dwight D.Eisenhower lent her name but not her presence. Mrs. Joseph P. Kennedy slipped off to Paris instead. And even Henry A. Kissinger, who was to have been trotted out as the Glamour Kid of 1971, failed to materialize.

title: New Era Stillborn
description: When the United States and Japan signed a treaty pledging the return of Okinawa to Japan last June, Premier Eisaku Sato hailed the birth of a new era JapaneseAmerican cooperation. Mr. Sato's optimistic expectation has not been fulfilled.

title: A Women's Prison That Resembles a Campus
description: ALDERSON, W. Va.The scene belongs on the inside cover of a yearbook.

title: The Stage: Garbage and Noxiousness
description: Money, flesh and trash comprise the futuristic world of Murray Mednick's Cartoon, which has opened the season at Theater Genesis, The world is full of garbage. Everything is noxious. Instead of love there are neurotic clingings. Energy is harnessed with Domestic Pacification Programs and daily shots of virus juice. Man invents sex objectsa sawhorselike moneymaking machine that disgorges dollar bills when murdered.

title: Marinaro in Football Spotlight
description: If all goes according to schedule, Ed Marinaro should establish a collegiate career rushing record during his first, second or third carry against Columbia today. Then undefeated Cornell and surprising Columbia can settle down to the business of a rather important Ivy League game on the PolyTurf of Schoellkopf Field in Ithaca.

title: Maine Playhouse Burns
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., Oct. 29 (UPI)  The Kennebunkport Playhouse, an ancient barn converted to a summer theater, which has presented many of the big names in show business, was destroyed by fire early today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since William Rehnquist participated closely in the formulation of the Justice Department's wiretapping policies, Tom Wicker in his column of Oct. 26, rightly questioned Mr. Rehnquist's ability to decide objectively cases testing these policies.

title: PANEL SUGGESTED TO MONITOR F.B.I.
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 29A Yale Law School professor opened a twoday conference on the Federal Bureau of investigation here today by calling for the creation of a board of private citizens to monitor the work of the F.B.I.

title: Art:
description: Violent, unfair, sensationalized, scurrilous and scatalogical are not among words that first come to mind as adjectives of praise, yet American Posters of Protest 196670, an exhibition at the New School Art Center, 65 Fifth Avenue, is effective precisely because it deserves them all, The bias in these posters is extreme, the presentation frequently crude, the images offensive as often as not. But anyone who walks out of the show in indignation will be paying it a tribute.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ON STOKELY BEANS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Food and Drug Administration warned today that a batch of StokelyVan Camp canned green beans may contain deadly botulinum toxin.

title: Mexican Actress Scheduled
description: Carmen Montejo, Mexican film, television and stage performer, will make her first appearance here in a Spanishlanguage monologue, Deborah, by Federico S. Inclan, at the Greenwich Mews Theater, 141 West 13th Street, on Wednesday. Performances will be repeated Thursday, Saturday, and Sunday. Miss Montejo's appearance is being made to help raise funds for the blingual Greenwich Mews Theater.

title: Alicia O'Connor, 65, Dies; Judge in Nassau County
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 29Alicia O'Connor, a former Nassau County Family Court judge, died today in the Nassau County Medical Center, East Meadow. She had been stricken by a heart attack earlier in the day at her home.

title: Revolt in the Hospitals
description: Objections by administrators and staffs of the cityoperated hospitals to the selective attrition policy adopted by the Health and Hospitals Corporation board are understandable, but Mayor Lindsay is right in refusing to yield to them. If he does, he will only invite recalcitrance on the part of every other municipal department toward living within the city's $8.5billion budget.

title: British Flags Lowered In Singapore Ceremony
description: SINGAPORE, Oct. 29 (AP) The flags of the British Far East Command were lowered here for the last time today at a parade marking the close of a chapter in British military history that spans two centuries.

title: Leader of the Third World
description: Marshal Tito's state visit to President Nixon comes at an opportune time. In keeping with the Yugoslavian visitor's role as a philosopher of nonalignment in world politics, this visit will balance off his talks in Belgrade last month with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader.

title: HOUSING APPROVED FOR FOREST HILLS
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday upheld the right of the City Housing Authority to build a $28million lowincome project in the Forest Hills section of Queens, and the agency immediately announced that it hoped to start construction next month.

title: Letters to the Editor What Estrangement?
description: To the Editor: In a recent news story from Lagos, William Borders set out so resolutely to prove his thesis that a new estrangement is growing between Africans and American blacks that he conveniently overlooked the mass of evidence on the other side. Out of the hundreds of blacks happily resident in Africa and the thousands who have visited there this year alone, he called to witness only a cultureshook black tourist up against an implacable airport bank clerk and a Foreign Service officer anxious to show he was as American as his white counterparts in the embassy.

title: BURLINGTON MILLS SEEKS TO RAISE PAY
description: The country's largest manufacturer of textiles, Burlington Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it had applied to the Government's new Pay Board for permission to give pay increases to about 55,000 hourly wage workers.

title: Inco to Pare Output 15%, Cut 1,690 Canadian Jobs
description: TORONTO, Oct. 29The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., disclosed today that it was abolishing 1,690 jobs and would slash production of nickel by 15 per cent. The statement, which followed a 7 per cent cut in production announced in August, brought to a climax a savage costcutting program that has sent rumors and tremors reverberating through the company, known as Inco, for months.

title: TV: Like It Is Plans Special Tomorrow on Attica
description: Like It Is, moderated by Gil Noble and Geraldo Rivera, is a weekly series on WABCTV aimed primarily at the black and Puerto Rican communities in New York. Using a blend of interviews, entertainment and news reports, it attempts to provide material that is in scarce supply on the rest of commercial television.

title: California Acts to Change Classification of Marijuana
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 29 (AP)  The California Legislature has decided that marijuana should be classified in state law as a dangerous drug and no longer as a narcotic along with heroin and other hard drugs.

title: Rockets, Led by Simpson, Victors in Overtime, 119111
description: DENVER, Oct. 29 (AP)Ralph Simpson scored 41 points, 8 in overtime, to lead the Denver Rockets to a 119111 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Senate RollCall Vote To Kill Foreign Aid Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP)Following is the roilcall vote by which the Senate rejected the foreign aid program today:

title: Music: Silent Cadenza
description: The biggest noise associated with the Cello Concerto by Gyorgy Ligeti, on the Thursday night Philharmonic program, came after it was over. There was a healthy chorus of boos, and there also was some laughter. But there was no demonstration, or anything like it. Nobody disliked the score enough to make an issue of it; and nobody liked it strongly enough to make any kind of vigorous defense.

title: Recycling Plant Ordered At Combustion Equipment
description: The City of Brockton, Mass., has placed a $5million order for an automated recycling and incineration plant to be built by Combustion Equipment Associates, Inc.

title: Progress and the History of the Hudson
description: It is hard to quarrel with what is presented as progressin this case, the building of new superhighways along the Hudson. While more superhighways mean more automobiles, more air pollution, more noise and more human displacement, still the growing need for speedy transportation poses a significant competing claim. In the particular case of Tarrytown, however, this competing claim must be weighed not only against the dismal contemporary side effects but against the violence wrought to an Area of peculiar historical importance.

title: Palladium Price Is Reduced
description: The Engelhard Minerals and Chemicals Corporation said yesterday it planned to reduce the price of palladium by $1 a troy ounce to a new selling range of $36 to $38 an ounce. A spokesman said the action was in line with the Soviet price, which is now about $35 an ounce, and was expected to improve its competitive price.

title: CHUNG LEE, PIANIST, IN AMERICAN DEBUT
description: Chopin and Schubert playing of a superior order was heard at Tully Hall Thursday night as Chung Lee played his first American recital. Mr. Lee is a 129yearold Japaneseborn Korean pianist who has studied extensively in Vienna.

title: ROD LEVITT'S JAZZ BRINGS FUN TO CITY
description: Things being as they are in Fun City, a jazz orchestra that is not only imaginative and exciting but filled with Fun should be a welcome to the city's life. Rod Levitt, a trombonist with an apparent passion for privacy, has just such band but in recent years it could be heard only at occasional gettogethers in Mr. Levitt's studio.

title: MORALS AN ISSUE IN CITIZENSHIP BID
description: A Hungarian immigrant says he has apparently jeopardized his immediate prospects of obtaining United States citizenship by admitting that he had had sexual relations with the woman he intends to marry.

title: Judge Tells U.S. to Disclose Documents in AirBag Case
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, won an initial court victory today in his fight against alleged White House interference with rules requiring airbag safety devices in cars.

title: YORKVILLE BLASE ABOUT BOND ISSUE
description: Some said they'd vote for it. Some said they'd vote against it. Some hadn't decided. Some didn't care. But almost to man, they agreed that it probably wouldn't make much difference, no matter what they did.

title: ... and Prices
description: Laxity in holding the general price line is the surest way to doom any program for curbing wages, however wellconceived. While the new Price Commission debates the rules it will promulgate to check the upsurge living costs, the Administration is casting fresh doubt on the adequacy of available enforcement procedures.

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK SHOWS HIGHER NET
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the 9 months ended Sept. 30.

title: Bridge:
description: The Long Island Regional Championships continue today at Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., with 16 teams surviving in the ploy for the knockout team championship.

title: Seton Hall Defeated
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 29Sarge. Taylor scored the first 26 points as the William Paterson College club football team beat the Seton Hall University club team, 326, to night. The Pioneers are now 51 wonlost and Seton Hall is 42. Taylor kicked a 30yard field goal in the first period to open the scoring.

title: Monetary Crisis Called a Danger for E.E.C.
description: Former French Premier MauCouve de Murville warned here yesterday that there was a big risk that the current international monetary crisis could lead to a wave of protectionism.

title: CELTICS SUBDUE BUCKS, 125 TO 114
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (AP)The Boston Celtics, employing a tight press most of the way, conquered the Milwaukee Bucks and toppled them from the unbeaten ranks tonight with a 125114 victory over the defending National Basketball Association champions.

title: A.E.C. to Give judge Data on ABlast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Nixon Adminstration decided today to obey a court order directing, the Atomic Energy Commission to produce for court inspection certain documents that seven environmental organizations say demonstrate the environmental hazards of the planned nuclear test on Amchitka Island.

title: 32 Moore Etchings Inspired by a Skull
description: Exhibitions of the work of the British sculptor Henry Moore are not exactly an uncommon occurrence in New York, yet this remarkable artist has not lost the power to surprise us. This week the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, mounted an exhibition of Mr. Moore's recent etchings, and it turns out to be a show of extraordinary force.

title: Nancy L. Bowen Bride Of Steven Bragonier
description: MANHASSET, L. I., Oct. 29Miss Nancy Lynn Bowen was married here this evening to Steven Rogers Bragonier. The Rev. Keith Payne performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Congregational Church.

title: MIAMI OVERTAKES ARMY TEAM, 2413, IN SECOND HALF
description: MIAMI, Oct. 29 (AP)Tom Sullivan ran 99 yards on a kickoff return and John Hornibrook ran for two touchdowns tonight to spur Miami to a 2413 victory over Army.

title: 300 Cambodians Reported Slain In Attacks on Relief Task Force
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 29 (Reuters)More than 300 Cambodian soldiers were reported killed or wounded as enemy forces mounted renewed attacks today against a Government task force trying to relieve the provincial capital of Kompong Thom, in northeastern Cambodia.

title: Floridians' 2dHalf Rally Turns Back Nets, 11095
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Oct. 29A thirdquarter scaring burst of 20 points by Al Tucker led the Floridians to a 11095 victory over the New York Nets tonight before a crowd of 5,680 in the Island Garden.

title: CHARGER'S HANDS QUICKER THAN EYE
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 Throughout their history, the Chargers have had wide receivers bloom like the desert sage. In the beginning, there was Lance Alworth, and lately Gary Garrison. Now there is Billy Parks, a rookie who is the surprise leader of the National Football League with 29 receptions.

title: ITALY AND CHINA SIGN 3YEAR TRADEACCORD
description: ROME, Oct. 29  Italy and China signed a threeyear trade agreement today.

title: WOOLWORTH NET AND VOLUME RISE
description: The F. W. Woolworth Company, the nation's largest variety chain and a diversified retailer, reported yesterday a 7 per cent increase in thirdquarter earnings on a sales gain of 12 per cent. Earnings for the latest nine months declined.

title: REFINANCING IS SET BY FOX FILM CORP.
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation announced yesterday the completion of an $80 million, three  year refinancing plan with six banks.

title: Restrictive Zoning Is Upset in Jersey
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 29  In a ruling hailed by organizations striving to open suburban areas to lowerincome housing, a State Superior Court judge has struck down the entire local zoning ordinance of a Middlesex County community on the ground that it ignored the desperate housing needs of urban New Jersey.

title: NICKLAUS, WITH 133, LEADS BY 5 SHOTS
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Oct. 29 (AP)  Jack Nicklaus shot equaled the course record of 65 today and gained a fivestroke lead over two other Americans after two rounds in the $24,200 Qantas Australian open golf championship.

title: FINAL APPEARANCE FOR SHUVEE TODAY
description: Shuvee, Mrs. Whitney Stone's redoubtable 5yearold mare who is the top moneyearner of her sex, will make the final appearance of her career today. She will oppose eight rivals, seven of them males, in the 53d running of the Jockey Club Gold Cup of two miles at Aqueduct.

title: Dr. Claude E. Hawley, 56, Dies; John Jay College Vice President
description: Dr. Claude E. Hawley, vice president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University of New York, died Thursday at Trafalgar Hospital, of cardiac arrest following a respiratory illness. He was 56 Years old and lived at 5 Tudor City Place.

title: Texts of China Statements
description: Following are the texts of a cablegram to Secretary General Thant from the acting Minister of Foreign Affairs of mainland China, Chi Pengfei, and of a Chinese Government statement issued by the Chinese press agency, Hsinhua, and distributed by Agence FrancePresse.

title: ProTaiwan Conference Here Questions U. N. Role of the U.S.
description: More than a thousand prominent conservatives and friends of Nationalist China heard their leaders declare here yesterday that the Taiwan Government's expulsion from the United Nations raised basic new questions regarding the United States relationship toward the world organization.

title: UNESCO Declares Peking the Legal Representative of China by a Vote of 25to2
description: PARIS, Oct. 29 The Peking Government was declared the only legal representative of China tonight by the executive board of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

title: UGANDA, TANZANIA REACH AGREEMENTS
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Oct. 29Uganda and Tanzania, which have been exchanging shots along their border for weeks, agreed today to reconcile some of their differences and to keep alive an economic union in East Africa.

title: Auto Sales Director Resigns at B. M. W.
description: BONN, Oct. 29  Paul G. Hahnemann, regarded as a top sales wizard in West Germany's highly competitive automobile industry, resigned today from his post as sales director and deputy board chairman of Bayrische Motorenwerke, widely know as B.M.W.

title: PRODUCER PLEDGES LIBRARY UNIT AID
description: An Off Broadway producer Thursday pledged one night's gross receipts from each of his three productions this season and called on other producers to do the same in an allout drive to save the Research Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center. The library, which houses research collections on the theater, dance and music, needs $250,000 for operating expenses by Jan. 1 or it will close.
