title: Legal Aid Files Suit on Behalf of the Clinton Inmates
description: A suit asking for $1.5million in damages was filed yesterday on behalf of the inmates of the Clinton Correctional Facility in Dannemora by the Legal Aid Society in Albany.

title: REGENTS PROPOSE NEW SCHOOL SETUP UNDER THE MAYOR
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29The appointment of a New York City Education Commissioner by the Mayor to replace and take over the duties of the present interim Board of Education and the position of School Chancellor was proposed today by the State Board of Regents.

title: COPPER CONCERNS APPEAL IN CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 29Two American copper companies whose properties have been nationalized by Chile have appealed the Government's ruling that they are due no compensation and owe Chile money for excess profits and other charges.

title: SQUIRES TROUNCE COUGARS, 142121
description: ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) The Virginia Squires jumped to a 73.63 halftime lead, then added 45 points in the fourth period tonight to trounce the Carolina Cougars, 142121, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: OTB Handle: $877,181
description: A record daily handle of $877,181 was recorded yesterday by Ithe Offtrack Betting Corporation, its chairman, Howard Samuels, reported. Aqueduct Race Track accounted for $413,897 of the OTB's largest amount ever, while the other $463,284 came from Yonkers Raceway.

title: Hystron Changes Name
description: Hystron Fibers, Inc., a major producer of polyester fiber, said yesterday that it had changed its name to Hoechst Fibers, Inc. Guenther I. O. Ruebcke, president, said the principal reason for the name change was clear identification with the parent company, Farbwerke Hoechst, A. G., the huge West German chemical and fiber producer.

title: Monitoring PostFreeze Wages...
description: Evenhandedness is a must if President Nixon's program for stabilizing the economy after the freeze is to work. But even before Phase Two begins there are disturbing signs of imbalance, Labor is already hinting at a walkout from the new Pay Board if it is dissatisfied with the board's basic decisions, and the Administration itself is undermining the rules for effective enforcement of price ceilings.

title: Johnson, Frederickson Raise Spirits of Giants
description: Watching Ron Johnson and Tucker Frederickson run through their plays at Yankee Stadium yesterday, Coach Alex Webster was almostalmostconvinced that they would be able to start for the Giants tomorrow against the Minnesota Vikings.

title: A New Historical Guide on Jews Is Prepared to Curb Distortions
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29The American Jewish Committee issued today a detailed set of book publisher guidelines aimed at ending what it described as distortions and omissions of the role of Jews and Judaism in world and American history.

title: New Naumburg Fund Head
description: Robert Mann, a founder and first violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet, has been elected president of the Walter W. Naumburg Foundation, Inc.,

title: OPPOSITION VOICED TO REGENTS' PLAN
description: The Board of Regents' proposal to replace the city's Chancellor of Schools and the Board of Education with a single Education Commissioner ran into a wall of opposition here yesterday.

title: Francis Rogers Dies at 74; Long in Publishing Field
description: Francis W. Rogers, since 1961 associate director of Educational Publishers' Center, 432 Park Avenue South, died Tuesday in his home, 5 Pine Street, Port Washington, L. I., of a heart attack. He was 74 years old.

title: Old Tunes Played By Benny Goodman For Dancing Fans
description: The Rainbow Grill seems to be developing a promising format for its presentations  a mixture of show and dance. When Guy Lombardo and his Royal Canadians played there earlier this month, they did a bried concert presentation, followed by about 20 minutes of dancing.

title: Penn Wins, 52, in Soccer
description: Pennsylvania defeated Harvard, 52, in an Ivy League soccer game in Philadelphia last night before 11,500 fans, believed to be the largest crowd to watch a college soccer game. It was the first Ivy League loss in 18 games for Harvard. Pennsylvania now has a wonlost record of 81.

title: Nebraska, No. 1 in Ratings, Goes on TV
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 29Nebraska is not interested in discussing postseason bowl invitations until after its Thanksgiving Day game with Oklahoma, Bob Devaney, the Cornhusker coach and athletic director, said today.

title: Kennedy Blames Nixon for U.N. Attacks
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy accused President Nixon yesterday of lack of leadership on the issue of China in the United Nations and of playing on the worst instincts in his party and the nation.

title: Talks on Coal Strike Recess
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) Negotiations in the fourweekold coal strike were recessed today until Monday. The walkout of some 80,00 union miners has crippled virtually all soft coal production in the more than 20 states that produce it.

title: GERMAN AD AGENCY IN SURPRISE FAILURE
description: BONN, Oct. 29The Adverta Marketing Company of Frankfurt, one of West, Germany's youngest and most enterprising advertising agencies, went to court this week with a petition of bankruptcy, causing a minor sensation in the trade.

title: TWO MORE STUDENTS SHOT IN BALTIMORE
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 (UPI)Two high school students were shot today just off school property during school hours. This followed the shooting of a student yesterday in the hallway of a downtown high school.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, Oct. 29There Is a strain of perfectionist absolutism in American political thought, longing for total solutions to problems and impatient with the compromises of politicians. It exists on both left and right. Each side, curiously, may resent the failures or Ideological impurity of its own people More keenly than the opposition's wrongheadedness.

title: Tass Critical of Move
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 29 (Agence FrancePresse)  Tass, the Soviet press agency, said today that Britain was joining the Common Market against the will of its people.

title: Dance: 2 Kinds of Death From the Joffrey Ballet
description: In recent seasons the tendency of the City Center Joffrey Ballet, at least in its new productions, has been toward the pure dance. It seemsand it is admittedly only a feelingthat the proportion of dramatic works has fallen of late. But certainly lovers of dance drama could have no complaint with the company's program at the City Center on Thursday night.

title: HUGHES TOOL FIGHTS EXTRA APPEAL BOND
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The Hughes Tool Company, under a $145million default levy to Trans World Airlines, today asked the United States Supreme Court to rule that it did not have to put up an extra $85million bond pending appeal.

title: HIGHER RATES SET FOR SOUTHWEST GAS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Federal Power Commission established today substantially higher maximum rates for natural gas produced in an area that comprises all or part of six Southern or Southwestern states.

title: G.M. AND FORD PLAN TO BUY MORE STEEL
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that they planned to begin placing orders next month for steel for January delivery on a normal basis, This would be in line with recent steel industry reports that stockpiles for the possible strike last Aug. 1 were nearing an end. Originally, automobile sources expected supplies to last at least until the beginning of the new year.

title: ARNE TISELIUS, 69; WON NOBEL IN '48
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, Oct. 29 (UPI)Prof. Arne Tiselius, who won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1948, died at his home here today. He was 69 years old.

title: Merger News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) A Civil Aeronautics Board hearing examiner today recommended the board's approval of the AlleghenyIsilohawk Airline merger, which would create an airline with routes stretching from Montreal to Memphis.

title: An Education Trust Fund
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  The United States must adopt an entirely new concept to support the financial needs of the American education system.

title: Tito Reports Soviet Pledge on Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 President Tito of Yugoslavia said today that Leonid I. Brezhnev had told him all Soviet military personnel would be withdrawn from Egypt and other Arab countries once a Middle East peace settlement was reached.

title: Bronx Man Killed by Bomb In Car Owned by Relative
description: A 39yearold Bronx man was killed yesterday morning by a bomb that exploded when he entered a car owned by a relative.

title: New Issues Dipped Along Broad Front In the Latest Week
description: Prices of new issues retreated along a broad front this week before regaining part of the losses on Thursday and Friday, specialists said yesterday. Activity was generally moderate.

title: Peking Makes a Pledge
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, Oct. 30China announced, in a Government statement released today, that it would soon send its representatives to take part in the, work of the United Nations and pledged that it would never be a superpower bullying other countries.

title: Financial Holdings of Powell Family
description: Following is list of investments owned by Lewis F. Powell Jr., who has been nominated for a seat on the Supreme Court, as released yesterday by the Senate Judiciary Committee:

title: CONNECTICUT TOPS BOSTON U. BY 1410
description: BOSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)Lou Allen scored touchdowns on runs of 2 and 3 yards tonight to give Connecticut a 1410 victory over Boston University.

title: PEKING TELLS U.N. THAT IT WILL SEND DELEGATION SOON
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 29The Government of mainland China informed the United Nations today that it would send a delegation to the General Assembly in the near future. It also made it clear that it expected to occupy China's seat in the agencies related to the United Nations.

title: Repeal of TwoTerm Limit On the President is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Senate Subcommittee on Con stitutional Amendments, was urged today to approve an amendment allowing a President to serve more than two elected terms.

title: Toll Collectors Here Gain Accord on Health Hazards
description: A union representing toll collectors reached a tentative agreement last night with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority to reduce health hazards caused by automobile fumes.

title: Symphony
description: The Mahler vogue has not lost any of its impetus. The symphonies turn up regularly on the programs of the orchestras that play here. Wednesday night, in the first of the Boston Symphony's seasonal concerts in Philharmonic Hall, it was the Mahler Sixth that dominated the program.

title: Nominee's Stands Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) The Justice Department disclosed today that Mr. Rehnquist had opposed integration of high schools and public accommodations in his home town.

title: Antiques
description: Was $410,000 a bargain for a complex table that the Marquise de Pompadour once owned?

title: U.S. Aide Cautions On Heater Fumes From '65 Corvairs
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI)  The Government warned owners of 1965 model Chevrolet Corvairs today that carbon monoxide seeping from defective heaters was creating an unreasonable risk of accidents and injury.

title: California Suspect Indicted in Slaying of 2 Policernen in Harlem
description: A man under indictment in San Francisco for assault with a deadly weapon against a policeman there has been indicted by a Manhattan grand jury for the ambush slaying of two policemen in front of a Harlem housing project last May 21.

title: Episcopal Bishops Delay Action On the Issue of Women Priests
description: MOUNT POCONO, Pa., Oct. 29  The bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church today ended a sixday convention in which they stressed the independence of overseas dioceses and put off consideration of three controversial issues.

title: POWELL'S STOCKS PUT AT $1MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Senate Judiciary Committee disclosed today that Lewis F. Powell Jr., one of President Nixon's nominees for the Supreme Court, owns stock in 30 corporations, some of which are frequent litigants in court.

title: AUSTRALIS WINS IN CAPITAL SHOW
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 28Australis of Canada, the onetime United States national highpoint champion, won the international jumper fault and out class tonight at the Washington International horse show.The victory was Canada's third in five classes. Barbara Simpson, who bought Australis from Danny Lopez three years ago was up.

title: The Talk of Gibraltar
description: GIBRALTAR, Oct. 22The rock apes, whose presence traditionally guarantees Gibraltar's survival as an outpost of empire, have multiplied to the point where some will have to be given away.

title: Lieutenant Denies Accepting a Gratuity
description: A tall, straighttalking police lieutenant made an unexpected appearance at the Knapp Commission yesterday and passionately denied an implication that he had accepted a $25 Christmas gratuity from the Statler Hilton Hotel last year.

title: Rev. Alexander Turner, 66, Leader of Orthodox Sect
description: The Right Rev. Alexander Turner, former vicar general of the Western Rite parishes of the Antiochian Orthodox Christian Archdiocese, who retired in 1969, died on Wednesday in Orangeburg, N.Y., after a long illness. His age was 66.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Three Requests to Expand Role in Policing False Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Federal Communications Commission, in three separate decisions, declined today to expand its limited role in the policing of false advertising.

title: BRIBES REPORTED ADDING 5% A YEAR TO BUILDING COSTS
description: The Knapp Commission heard testimony yesterday that virtually all contractors putting up buildings in New York bribe the police and that bribes to them and other governmental agencies add at least 5 per cent to the citys yearly building costs.

title: WASHINGTON HIGH DISRUPTED AGAIN
description: Four students and a patrolman were slightly injured and seven students were arrested today as brief student disorders swept George Washington High School and its neighborhood in Washington Heights.

title: Shuffleboard Hustler Finds Action in Bars
description: MEMPHISGambling is illegal here.

title: British Prisons Draw Criticism
description: MAIDSTONE, England At 6:40 each morning the lights in Maidstone Prison flicker on. The cell doors open, the prisoners walk to communal bathrooms and, by 7:15, they are sitting at long wooden tables sipping tea and eating porridge and bacon or eggs.

title: News Analysis
description: McCarthyism, say the policemen, Civil liberties disaster, say the New York Civil Liberties Union. A spectacular, says the public.

title: Elvin Campbell Jr. Weds Lois Cattail
description: Miss Lois Caffall, a vice president of William Altman Advertising, Inc., was married here yesterday to Elvin Garrett Campbell Jr., chief studio engineer of MCA Records, Inc. The Rev. John N. McCormick performed the Episcopal ceremony at the couple's new apartment.

title: Milestone for Europe
description: LONDON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) Britain's decision to join the Common Market was swiftly hailed by members of the economic community as a milestone for Europe.

title: Foreman Stops Pires in Fourth
description: George Foreman took his 32d step toward a heavyweight title fight somewhere in the future by battering and bloodying Luis Pires in four rounds last night, but the step wasn't a very big one.

title: Steps Taken by U.S In Attempt to Expel Cuban Sugar Men
description: NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29The United States began today expulsion proceedings against the Cuban delegation that arrived here unannounced and without visas to attend an international sugar convention.

title: DRAMA BY BERRIGAN IRKS 2 LEGISLATORS
description: Two Maryland legislators are seeking to decrease current state and Federal grants to the Center Stage Theater of Baltiditre on the ground that it is producing treasonistic plays.

title: Other Agencies Consider Action
description: GENEVA, Oct. 29 (UPI)The World Health Organization said today it was up to its annual assembly to decide who should represent China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 2Part Show: Flavin's Works of Light
description: It is easy to frown upon the light constructions of Dan Flavin, who is having a twopart exhibition at the John Weber Gallery, 420 West Broadway, and the Castelli Gallery, 4 East 77th Street. The constructions don't seem to command much thinking, nor do they seem to require much talent in their composition or craftsmanship. Made out of commercial fluorescent fixtures, they appear in the work of art unchanged, with their nuts, bolts and tubing exposed, much as they would appear in any neon salesman's showcase. But the constructions deserve more serious critical consideration than that. Mr. Flavin is, in fact, one of the best light artists.

title: Market Place: See the World, Boss Tells Men
description: At Creative Management Associates the order of the day is to cut the overhead just like every place else. But there's a big exception to this edict, and It may come as a surprise.

title: SAMUEL J. MATHIS
description: Samuel J. Mathis, an engineering coordinator in the production department of Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died on Thursday at the Duke Medical Center in Durham, N. C., after a long illness. He was 59 years old and had lived in New York until moving recently to Pinehurst, N. C.

title: Duane Allman Dies at 24 In a Motorcycle Accident
description: MACON, Ga., Oct. 29 (AP)Duane Allman, leader of the Allman Brothers, a rock band, was killed today in a motorcycle accident. He was 24 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 29Harry Theofiledes came into professional football five years ago unknown and unheraldeda free agent from Waynesburg College in Western Pennsylvaniaand his status has not changed appreciably. The system worked against him from the start. He left a small mark around Washington and he has some renown in this city as the quarterback for the minor league team, the Jets. But that's all. Harry will try to make it in the Canadian League again next season and if he doesn't, he will turn to other pursuits, bitterly.

title: OTB Is Bullish About Wall Street
description: A new Offtrack Betting Corporation office was opened in the Wall Street district yesterday.

title: From. Crisp Tailoring to Soft Chiffon
description: Hardly anyone had heard of John Anthony six months ago. After his spring fashion show this week, people were calling him a young Norell.

title: HomeMortgage Rates Up Fourth Month in a Row
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today that the rates on conventional home mortgage loans increased moderately during September. It was the fourth rise in as many months.

title: Schools to Get Kosher Beef
description: The United States Department of Agriculture announced yesterday its first purchase, of k6sher ground beef for the National. School Lunch Program. It said the 19 tons of meat would be distributed to Jewish parochial schools in New York City.

title: Condors Top Colonels
description: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Pittsburgh Condors scored a 112102 victory over the Kentucky Colonels tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Aid Wasn't Always Popular at Home
description: Since the Truman Doctrine of 1947, which marked America's first unilateral foreign assistance, the United States has spent $143billion in aid to countries around the world, but the program itself has never won universal popularity at home.

title: Auto Kills Man, 102
description: DULUTH, Minn., Oct. 29 (AP) A 102yearold Duluth man, a onetime Army colonel, died in a hospital of head injuries today after he was struck by a car. The man, Hubert V. Eva, had attended a church supper last evening and was walking with his nurse to a car when the two were hit.

title: Pompidou Hails Heath's Market Victory
description: PARIS, Oct. 29President Pompidou congratulated Prime Minister Heath today on his victory last night in the House of Commons, where he obtained a 112vote majority in favor of British membership in the Common Market.

title: India's Desperate Mission
description: India's Prime Minister Indira Gandhi Is due in Washington next week on a mission that could significantly influence the prospects for war or peace in South Asia. If her visit is to advance the chances for peace, it is essential that Americansand particularly the White House  come to a better understanding of the desperate dilemma posed for India by the sevenmonthold political crisis in Pakistan.

title: NURSE SOVIET JAILED ARRIVES IN TEL AVIV
description: TEL AVIV, Oct. 29 (AP)The young Jewish nurse who recently was released after four months in a Soviet labor camp arrived here last night.

title: Suns Win in 2d Overtime
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (AP) Connie Hawkins scored a basket on an inbounds pass at the buzzer tonight to give the Phoenix Suns a 137135 doubleovertime victory over the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: JOSEPH STRICKS, 60, OF SHERRYLEHMANN
description: Joseph Stricks, an officer of SherryLehmann, Inc., wine merchants of 679 Madison Avenue, died of a heart attack at his home on Thursday. He was 60 years old and lived at 37 East 64th Street.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: ALAN AUDLEY HILDITCH
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 29Alan Audley Hilditch, a certified public accountant, died yesterday in Greenwich Hospital after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 19 Grimes Road.

title: Nastase and Layer Gain Final At Wembley
description: WEMBLEY, England, Oct. 29 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania advanced to the men's final of the $50,000 Embassy tennis championships tonight with a 61, 64 victory over Tom Gorman of Seattle.

title: A Gown for Mrs. Nixon?
description: There was the model, walking down the runway in a flowing, Oriental  looking dress, a red print with green, kimono  like sleeves that would make it seem as much at home in Japan as in China. And then the excitement started.

title: Iona Trounces New Raven.
description: MOUNT VERNON, Oct. 29Iona of New Rochelle defeated the University of New Haven, 4018, in club football tonight, the winners gaining 440 yards rushing and 160 yards passing. Brian Colleary and Chuck Drago scored two touchdowns apiece for Iona.

title: Bond Issue's Supporters Close Ranks
description: Mayor Lindsay took a subway ride yesterday to urge passage of the state transportation bond issue, and Governor Rockefeller and Albert Shanker held a news conference together to promote it.

title: GOLDSAND OFFERS ELEGANT PIANISM
description: Robert Goldsand very nearly decided to cancel his Carnegie Hall recital Thursday night, according to backstage informants, because of a virus attack. But if Mr, Goldsand was feeling below par (he sniffled into his handkerchief a lot between numbers), his pland playing denied the fact.

title: H.E.W. SAID TO BAR DATA FROM PUBLIC
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 19The Department of Health, Education and Welfare was accused today in two separate lawsuits of withholding public information on state applications for welfare changes and on school desegregation in the North.

title: Books of The Times
description: VERLAINE. By Joanna Richardson. 432 pages. Viking. $10.

title: Taipei Premier Bars Peking Deal
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 29Amid heightened speculation, over the future of the Chinese Nationalist Government iii the wake of its expulsion from the United Nations, Premier C. K. Yen declared today that it would never agree to a deal with the Communists on the mainland.

title: Gold Imports in September Dropped to $22,712,554
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (Reuters)September gold imports fell to $22,172,554 from August imports of $47,813,845, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Insurance Earnings Up at Both Aetnas
description: Big Aetna and Little Aetna showed a strong improvement in earnings in the first nine months of this year, both companies reported yesterday.

title: Raid in Westchester Termed a Farce; Charge Is Disputed
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 29The alreadyheated race for District Attorney of Westchester County warmed further today when a candidate described a largescale drug raid carried out earlier this week as a farce.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors of Motel in Queens Charge Police Protection Lags
description: Neighbors of a motel in Queens are incensed over what they charge is a failure of the police to protect them from disturbances by prostitutes and their customers and other couples who overflow the motel onto their formerly tranquil street.

title: Hawks Win on May's Shot
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 29 (AP)Don May connected with a 30footer at the buzzer to give the Atlanta Hawks a 9897 victory tonight over the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: Executive Changes
description: Delta Air Lines yesterday elected William T. Beebe, 56 years old, as chairman and chief executive officer. He had been president since 1970, and joined the company in 1953, when Delta acquired Chicago & Southern Airlines through a merger. In his new position, Mr. Beebe succeeds Charles H. Dotson, 65, who was named chairman of the executive committee, a new position. David C. Garrett Jr., senior vice presidentoperations was named president. Mr. Garrett, 49, joined the airline in 1946.

title: NOME TAX CUT GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29The Senate Finance Committee approved today the $5.7billion package of income tax reductions for individuals that passed the House of Representatives early this month. The action was generally interpreted as guaranteeing that individuals would receive at least this much income tax reduction whenever the over  all tax bill finally passes Congress.

title: Bond Issue Stirs Debate on Politics And Mathematics
description: With three days remaining before the election, the importance of the transportation bond issue in holding down the transit fare has become the subject of a complicated mathematical and politcal debate.

title: New York Warned
description: ALBANY, Oct. 29 (AP)The New York State Health Department issued an urgent warning to the public tonight to avoid eating canned beans from the suspect StokelyVan Camp lot.

title: Midwest Exchange Starts Automated Clearing Plan
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (UPI)The Midwest Stock Exchange Clearing Corporation announced today the start of a new automated computerized stock clearing system called Continuous Net Settlement.

title: Knapp Witness to Tell of Lindsay Officials' Apathy
description: Sgt. David Durk, one of the policemen whose persistence led to the creation of the Knapp Commission, will finally testify how he and another detective went on a lonely odyssey to highranking Lindsay administration officials about police corruption and detail allegations that none of them would do anything about it. In a reversal of his previously stated position, Whitman Knapp, chairman of the commission, announced yesterday that he had invited Sergeant Durk, Detective Frank Serpico and at least two Lindsay officials to testify. The officials are Jay L. Kriegel, who is Mayor Lindsay's chief of staff and the aide in charge of monitoring the police, and Arnold G. Fraiman, formerly the city's Commissioner of Investigation and now a State Supreme Court justice. They were among the highranking city and police officials that Sergeant Durk and Detective Serpico say they went to with information about police corruption, but who, they say, did nothing. Mr. Kriegel said he would testify; Justice Fraiman declined comment. Sergeant Durk said he would testify and Detective Serpico was not available for comment.

title: Notes on People
description: Mary McCarthy returned to her alma mater, Vassar, for the first time since 1963, when her novel The Group disturbed alumnae who felt they had been maligned in the book. While Miss McCarthy lectured at seminars' and took part in other Vassar centennial activities, it was clear that all was not forgiven by the school or by the author. Miss McCarthy, for example, said she had accepted the invitation to the centennial in a moment of generosity. She also said the writing courses She took at Vassar in the nineteenthirties had made her style retrogress. Vassar's attitude toward her seemed expressed on its bookshelves. While the college book store and library had displays of boblcs by alumnae authors, including some by Miss McCarthy, not a single copy of The Group was shown.

title: U.S. Industry Ran at 73.5% Of Capacity in September
description: American industry operated at 73.5 per cent of capacity in September, up 1 per cent from August and 1.5 per cent below the operating rate in September, 1970, McGrawHill Publications reported yesterday.

title: Casper, With 137, Leads Japan Golf by 5 Shots
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Oct. 29 (Reuters)Billy Casper of the United States retained his lead after the second round of the Tokai golf classic today by carding a 3underpar 69 for a total of 137.

title: SADAT SPEEDING PAY FOR EXPROPRIATIONS
description: CAIRO, Oct. 29In another reform to overcome grievances against Egypt's socialist regime, President Anwar elSadat has issued a decree to improve terms of compensation for land taken by the Government in a redistribution program.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29A foreign aid program, begun in humanitarian enthusiasm and sustained in its latter years more by habit than by Congressional conviction, was dealt a possibly mortal blow tonight, the victim of fiscal conservatives and disenchanted liberals.

title: Labor Is Mobilizing Price Watch Here
description: The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is mobilizing its members in the New York metropolitan area into a price watch operation.

title: Pistons Win, 119105
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP)The Detroit Pistons shook up their lineup tonight and it paid off in a 119105 victory over the Baltimore Bullets, snapping a threegame losing streak.

title: CAR OUTPUT DOWN FROM LAST WEEK
description: DETROIT, Oct. 29 (AP) Domestic auto production stood at close to 190,000 units this week, down slightly from last week but more than double the figure for the same period last year when the General Motors Corporation was idled by a strike.

title: E,T.C. CHALLENGES GIMBELS LEASINGS
description: The Federal Trade Commission issued yesterday a proposed complaint challenging as anticompetitive certain restrictive lease provisions used by Gimbel Brothers, Inc., in shopping centers. The lease practice is widely followed in retailing.

title: WHITE CONVICTED IN SLAYING OF GIRL
description: INDIANOLA, Miss., Oct. 29 (UPI)A white man from Memphis was convicted of manslaughter charges today in connection with the graduationnight slaying of a teenage Negro girl at the little Mississippi Delta town of Drew last spring.

title: Mayor of Colorado Town Discounts Peril of Uranium Residues
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 29Mayor Stanley R, Anderson of Grand Junction, Colo., told Congress today that reports of health hazards in his town because of radiation leakage from spent uranium ore were unwararnted, unjustified and harmful to the community.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Chess
description: THE 39th championship tournament of the U.S.S.R. is now under way in Leningrad. Twentytwo players are competing for what is widely regarded to be the most prestigious of all national titles, 10 of them allotted places on the strength of past performance, and 12 qualified from four semifinal tournaments of 18 players each (held at various places throughout that country).

title: Mrs. Ann H. Derby Married Here
description: Mrs. Ann Hesterberg Derby of Brooklyn, widow of John Z. Derby, was married here yesterday morning to Capt. Robert R. Hannan, U.S.A.F. The Rev. Donald Poulin performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: The World
description: This happy breed of men, this little world,

title: For Young Readers
description: We praise the scholarly brothers Grimm for collecting the Kinder and Hausmarchen, charitably forgetting their high and absurd intentions. Sneaking like slapstick Herr Professors from kitchen to kitchen and copying down old women's tales, their object (especially Wilhelm's) was to learn the secrets of the Old Religion, Christianity having been made to look foolishat least to the simpleton scholarly mind  by the socalled higher criticism. What the folktales contained, according to Wilhelm, was clues to ancient mysteries like jewels half hidden in tangled grass and flowers. Great philologists (especially Jacob), they had influence; and the effect of their notions has been devastating. For a hundred years philologists and anthropologists have torn the grass and flowers out of supposed folk literaturefrom the Miirchen to Beowulfin search of elfin treasure.

title: Lolich Named Tiger of Year
description: DETROIT, Oct. 30 (UPI)Mickey Lolich, runnerup to Vida Blue in the Cy Young Award balloting, was unanimousy named today Tiger of the Year for 1971 by the Detroit chapter of the Baseball Writers' Association of America. It was the first time in the sevenyear history of the of the award a Tiger was named on all the ballots. Lolich received all 28 votes cast.

title: Polls Show Most Britons Still Oppose Market Role
description: LONDON, Oct. 30Prime Minister Heath once said that he could not take Britain into the European Common Market without the fullhearted consent of her people and Parliament.

title: 2 Slain in TollBooth Holdup In a Bronx Subway Station
description: Two holdup men were killed last night in a gun battle that followed an attempt to rob a subway change booth in the Bronx, the police said. A third suspect escaped.

title: China Trade: How to Get the Facts
description: A complaint voiced frequently by United States corporations taking their first serious look at the People's Republic of China is that there is hardly any information available that permits them to decide whether there is a potential for their products and services. In fact, there is a wealth of material available directly from China and elsewhere that will allow most companies to come to a valid decision as to whether there are realistic and immediate markets for them in the People's Republic.

title: Glover, ExSeal Coach, Is Hired to Pilot Kings
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (AP)The Los Angeles Kings, mired in last place in the Western Division of the National Hockey League, hired Fred Glover as coach today to replace Larry Regan, who will continue as general manager.

title: GRAMBUNG TOPPLES TEXASSOUTHERN,217
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Grambling took advantage of errors to down Texas Southern, 217, before 33,556 fans in the Astrodome today.

title: Preps
description: SOUTH KENT, Conn., Oct. 30 Dave Fitch passed for three touchdowns today in leading South Kent to a 320 rout of Salisbury. It was the second victory in four games for South Kent.

title: Son for Richard Sterns
description: A son was born on Oct. 20 in the Mount Sinai Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Stern of New York, The child has been named Andrew Howard. Mrs. Stern is the former Miss Phyllis Marlene Edelstein of Rego Park, Queens. Mr. Stern is a first vice president of Newberger, Loeb & Co., Inc., an investment firm of which his father, Leo Stern of Larchmont, N.Y., is a retired senior partner.

title: Park Slope Residents Vs. Hospital On Housing
description: Park Slope residents are fighting to save 17 brownstones scheduled for demolition to make way for the construction of Seney Housea staff residence for Methodist Hospital.

title: Coast Guard Victor, 1917; Ciccalone: Four Field Goals
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 30Steve Ciccalone set a New England college singlegame record of four field goals in the United States Coast Guard Academy's 1917 defeat of Trinity College. The cadet's field goals came at distances of 35, 35, 22, and 23 yards, the last coming with 3 seconds left in the game.

title: Giants Still Show an Interest in Their NeighborhoodThey Hold Clinic for Youngsters
description: Cold reason declares that today's game between the New York Giants and the Minnesota Vikings at Yankee Stadium should be a mismatch, with the Vikings favored by a mere two touchdowns only because they are a notoriously defenseminded, lowscoring team.

title: 200 Youths in Bronx Help Clean A Section of Crotona Park East
description: As hundreds of families watched from the open windows of neighboring apartment houses, 200 schoolage youngsters helped clean a section of Crotona Park East in the Bronx yesterday.

title: Sonsky, With 2598 Throw, Wins St John's Javelin Test
description: Milt Sonsky threw the javelin 259 feet 8 inches yesterday as St. John's annual fall series for field events began at the Jamaica Campus in Queens.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Policeman and 2 Others Arrested on Drug Charge
description: A member of the Mamaroneck Village Police Department and two teenagers were arrested yesterday near the Lincoln Center and charged with possessing a quantity of heroin, the police of the West 68th Street station reported.

title: Decline of the West
description: One of the surprises for the fashionable nostalgia and recrimination about the crushing of Indian culture in North America is that it was perceptively recorded and eloquently lamented in its own time, by both victim and perpetrator. Two of the passages below, taken from T. C. McLuhan's moving anthology of Indian rhetoric, Touch the Earth; a Self Portrait of Indian Existence (Outerbridge and Dienstfrey, $6.95) date from the 18th century, and Miss McLuhan has found others equally poignant from a 100 years before. The illustrations on this page are from The Art of the Oild West (Knopf, $25), rambunctious album based on the eclectic collections of artifacts and texts at the Gilcrease Institute, Oklahoma. The illustrations on the opposite page are from Paul Kane's Frontier (University of Texas Press, $27.50). Kane was a notable Canadian portrait painter who in the 1840's trekked throughout the. Northwest, sketching the Indians and their land. Commissioned by the Anton Carter Museum, Fort Worth, and the National Gallery of Canada, the book sumptuously produced, edited with great care and scholarship by J. Russell Harper. It also contains a book by Kane himself, Wanderings of an Artist Among the Indians of North America, which was a great hit in 1859 and readable today.

title: Stamps
description: STAMP collectors have a doubleheader program of exhibitions late in Novemberthe boursetype 23d National Postage Stamp Show, Nov. 1921, at Madison Square Garden, and on the following Thanksgiving Day weekend, Nov. 26Dec. 1, the $25million ANPHILEX '71 exhibition at the WaldorfAstoria, at which the world's greatest stamp rarities will be on display.

title: 49ers, Broncos to Meet Next Year in Youth Bowl
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 (AP)The San Francisco 49ers will play the Denver Broncos here next year in an exhibition game that could net as much as $110,000 for a new city youth fund.

title: EssexUnion
description: The Suburban Conference had their perfect records marred yesterday. Caldwell upset Madison, 1914, in a comeback victory at Caldwell. Summit was held to a 2020 tie by Verona, which rallied for its entire point total in the fourth period before a home crowd.

title: About Motor Sports
description: TORRANCE, Calif., Oct. 29 The No. 1 driver of a racing team gets his nose out of joint if he suspects a teammate is getting better equipment than he is. But consider a team of two prima donnas and one defending champion: How do you cope with Mario Andretti, AI Unser and Joe Leonard? Maurice Philippe, who had six years of experience designing. Grand Prix cars for such Team Lotus prima donnas as Jim Clark and Graham Hill, says diplomatically that the equipment is usually the same, that the differences are only in the minds of the drivers.

title: In Canton, Ohio, Groza Is No. 1, Blanda No. 2
description: The National Football League already lists 44yearold Georga Blanda of the Oakland Raiders as the career scoring champion, but the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio, does not.

title: The Last Word: Freedom to Read (2)Politics.
description: Last week, in our discussion of the freedom to read, we promptly bumped heads with the problem of pornography and the First Amendment, with a short side excursion into the decline and fall of the American empire due to obscenityrot from within. This week, let us have a brief encounter with political censorship, primarily as it relates to books.

title: National Horse Show: A Blend of Old and New
description: The venerable National Horse Show, which dates back to the first Madison Square Garden in the gaslight era, gets under way for eight days and nights Tuesday. Teams from the United States, Canada and Argentina will meet in the featured international jumping competition.

title: Travel Notes: Pollution in Paradise, Durer's Anniversary, Beer in the Sky
description: THIS year is the 50th anniversary of Sarasota County, Fla. At such a time one would expect the residents of the county and its principal city, Sarasota, to boast of civic achievements, climate, beaches, cultural events and tourist attractions.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISOne must keep certain underlying truths in mind when assessing the importance of Mr. Brezhnev's visit here, during which red flags were as notable in Paris as in the days of the 1870 commune.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: A FOREIGN TRADE SURPLUS, the first in six months, was registered by the United States in September as businessmen rushed to beat the Oct. 1 East and Gulf Coast strikes. Exports far outpaced imports for the month giving the United States a $265.4million surplus. .. . The United States' efforts to correct its balanceofpayments deficit pose a threat of serious disruption of world trade and currency relations, said PierrePaul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

title: AMERICAN BOW MADE BY ARGENTINE CHOIR
description: Pro Musica de Rosario, a carefully polished, superbly trained chamber choir from Argentina, made its North American debut Friday night at the Hunter College Playhouse. Under the direction of Christian HernandezLarguia, the 12 women and 7 men produced a pure, lighttextured, nearlyvibratofree tone, floating their songs with flexible, dynamic shadings and startling rhythmic precision.

title: When N.Y. as a Helluva Town
description: SOME time early in 1945, Mrs. Harold Prince (then Judy Chaplin), wife of the noted producerdirector, was heard to make an unusual comment about The StarSpangled Banner. Upon hearing the strains of our national anthem at a large gathering, she turned to her neighbor, looked up and said in a loud voice, I know that. That's the overture to On the Town.' She had to look up, because she was about 21/2 years old at the time. Though remarkably worldly for her age, she had as yet seen only one Broadway show, but had seen it at least a dozen times, and it happened to be On the Town because her parents were close friends of ours.

title: SENATE REACTION IS ASTONISHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The mood in the Senate the morning after the sudden and unex petted vote that killed the foreign aid bill was one of aston ishment over what had been done.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I am moved by the article on surplus property sales [ Little Guy Plays a GrowMg Role at Auctions of City Property, Oct. 24] to tell of my own experience. I am neither a member of Big Thicket, American Heritage or any other scenic preservation group. But in my own way, I reap a dividend of satisfaction by buying up oddsized surplus vacant properties at the city real estate public auctions.

title: Miss Lucile Walker Is Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Lucile Thornton Walker to William Henry Hays 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hays Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mrs. Elisha Walker Jr. of Syosset, L. I., and Mr. Walker of New York.

title: Dear Sir: Your House Is Built On Radioactive Uranium Waste
description: (SUGGESTED LETTER TO OWNERS OF PROPERTIES WHERE RADIATION LEVELS EXCEED THE SURGEON GENERAL'S GUIDELINES)

title: CENTROWITZ LEADS POWER TO RUN TITLE
description: Matt Centrowitz posted his fifth victory of the season and led Power Memorial Academy to the New York diocese team title yesterday in the crosscountry championships of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association.

title: One bed to a customer
description: An S.R.O. is a singleroomoccupancy hotel, and Robert Pharr makes these initials the title of his latest novel. The setting is the Logan, a welfare hotel somewhere between 119th Street, Amsterdam Avenue and limbo. The author, using a persuasive conversational style, slips the reader past the venal manager in the lobby up to the fifth floor and there one remains until the novel comes to a melodramatic end. Pharr's writing at the beginning, is flawless; his description of narrator Sid Bailey's alcoholic fantasies is so vivid that one is almost forced to look away from the pages to avoid the smell of his putrid breath and the bite of his terror. And the literary device of having an insert in italics in which the narrative switches from the first person to the third (one that has been used so often that it frequently seems pretentious) fits organically into this particular story.

title: Close Bond Vote Forecast; Both Sides Urge Turnout
description: With both sides predicting a close vote on Tuesday, the proponents and opponents of the proposed $2.5billion transportation bond issue urged yesterday a heavy vote on the question.

title: In 2400, it was all cerebromorphs
description: Writers have a bad time writing a second novel, but reviewers and critics usually have a worse time reading it. Almost without exception, they feel compelled to point out that the second novel did not live up to the promise of the first. What they really mean  but do not know is that the writer has gone on to something quite different from what he was dealing with his first time out. Consequently, he has had to solve the problems of telling another story in another way. Reviewers and critics then interpret this as a falling off, as failure.

title: Two Old Men
description: To the Editor:

title: Marine and Son Well; Had Eaten Green Beans
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., Oct. 30 (AP)A Marine captain and his 4yearold son who reported to a hospital after eating from a can of green beans that didn't taste right, show no signs of botulism poisoning, a Navy spokesman said tonight. An official Navy news release said the father and son were completely well.

title: Music
description: FORTUNE my foe, runs the early Elizabethan song. In those days they had the concept of the wheel of fortune, spinning insanely, coming to rest on a certain number. If that number was yours, there you were, whether you were king or commoner. The wheel of fortune operated independently of good or bad; it was spun by an insensate force and the gods looked at it and laughed.

title: Peckinpah's Progress: From blood and killing in the Old West to siege and rape in rural Cornwall
description: ST. IVES, Cornwall.

title: Beeordings
description: SCHOENBERG, Webern & Berg  we lump them k together so often that they come to sound like a Washington law firm. Or, with the mental sloppiness that seems to be a byproduct of most controversy, their enemies telescope them into one ugly, pejorative catchword:.Schoenbergwebernberg. However, though their music to a disquieting extent still lies undigested by the concerthall audience, there seems to be less and less tendency to choose up sides for and against the three Viennese atonalists. Young listeners, including musicians, examine the aging, oncereviled scores with the disinterested curiosity that they might bring to the work of Monteverdi, Gluck or Wagner. The heat generated by reformers dies, but light continues to be shed in those cases that count, and we know, of course, that Schoenberg, Webern and Berg count. But how much? Pierre Boulez, who rightly regards the New York Philharmonic as an educa, tor's tool as well as an artist's expressive instrument, evidently intends to explore that question in some depth over the next few seasons, Good cess to him.

title: Pop
description: DON ELLIS: Tears of Joy (Columbia). Don Ellis has to be the best semianonymous bandleader you've never heard. I describe him as semianonymous because, despite a small, devoted following, he has not yet broken through to the larger pop audience. The more penetrating question of why he is so good and yet so little known is more difficult to answer.

title: Stricken at Game, T.C.U. Coach Dies
description: WACO, Tex., Oct. 30Texas Christian University's football, coach, Jim Pittman, collapsed, on the sidelines tonight during, the T.C.U.Baylor game and died minutes later. He was 46 years old.

title: Art
description: THE big Barnett Newman retrospective and memorial exhibition (Mr. Newman died last year) at the Museum of Modern Art is the strong. est argument I have ever seen in favor of artists keeping their mouths shut entirely and critics maintaining a careful bridle on their pens. I realize, of course, that the second half of that injunction could backfire.

title: Smog Summer
description: Not so many years ago, the appearance of a thin blue ??aze in the autumn sky, accompanied by calm air and mild temperatures, was typical of one of the year's most pleasant interludes, Indian Summer.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) Bonte II, ridden by Joe Vargis of Vienna, Va., sped to victory tonight in the $15,000 international open jumpers banus class, tonight and led the qualifiers for tomorrow's President's Cup competition at the Washington International Horse Show.

title: BRIBE ATTEMPT LAID TO A STORE OWNER
description: A Harlem candystore owner was arrested yesterday after he allegedly tried to bribe two detectives to free three men they had arrested on charges of possessing a narcotic and a loaded revolver.

title: Et Al.
description: Behavior therapy is a cureall. Psychological symptoms need only be measured on a tension curve; then through semihypnosis one is made to relax when thinking of the scary thing. There's even the transcript of a tape that can help one relax. Eighty per cent cure is predicted. Who cares what deep causes lie behind life's troubles? Let sleeping dogs lie. Cure the symptoms and you've done the job. Actually, behavior therapy is a useful tool for specific situations, but a panacea it's not. Remember the old Nichols and May routine about the patient who can't move her leg because she tripped her sister coming down the marriage aisle, then says, Doctor, can't arm!?

Douglass Wallop's nostalgic novel describes Jeffrey's experience in the limbo between Commencement and induction, after he takes a job behind the bar at a beach hotel to await his uncertain future. Uncertainty is aggravated byhis parents' impending divorce and by the ebb and flow of summer people.

title: the travelers world
description: THE key words today are ecology and environment, and with everyone talking about themsome more hysterically than othersit is only natural that the subject is cropping up in debates about travel and tourism. The first subdivision of the two words is pollution, and avantgarde thinkers about tourism now talk learnedly of peoplepollution. By this, they mean, not so much the littering that people doall kinds of people, not only touristsbut the pollution that arises from assembling too many people in one place.

title: There but for the grace of God, went God
description: Such is the present modishness of film that unbelievably windy books proliferate, my current favorite being The Nature of Film, by Siegfried Kracauer, special assistant to the curator of the Modern Art Film Library. In this weighty tome, the outspoken Kracauer comes right out and says, .... films go beyond photography in two respects. First, they picture movement itself, not only one or another of its phases.

title: Education
description: At the heart of the controversy over the quality of urban education is the charge that children of poverty fail to acquire the key to educationthe ability to read well. Ghetto parents blame the schools; the schools often turn the blame back to the dismal slum environment in which the children live.

title: The Vantage Point Perspectives of the Presidency 19631969. By Lyndon Baines Johnson. Illustrated. 636 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $15.
description: The literature on him has always been surprisingly thin, considering the scope, force and range of his life, its sheer excitement and unpredictability. He is after all, a figure worthy of a very great book; nothing about him was simple, nothing about him was boring. Yet the Kennedy literature is thick, and his is thin; magazines soon learned that Kennedy covers, any Kennedy would do, sold extra copies. Johnson covers hurt sales. Rowland Evans, coauthor of Lyndon Johnson and the Exercise of Power, is reputed to have said, after sales proved disappointing, that he and Robert Novak should have called their book Between Two Kennedys.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Start raking . . . . Evergreens can be mulched anytime now until the ground freezes; use pine needles, wood chips, bark chips, peat or compost. . . . Gladiolus, dahlias, tuberous begonias, cannas are tender. Dig them after frost nips the tops, dry for a day or so in the garage and store in a cool place where they will not dry out. Plastic garbage bags are good containers to keep varieties and types separate.

title: RIZZO'S LEAD CUT IN PHILADELPHIA
description: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 They're ganging up on us, Frank L. Rizzo, the former Police Commissioner, said as endorsements of his Republican mayoral opponent, Thacher Longstreth, swelled in the final week of a long campaign. They trot out a new guy every day.

title: Attica: The Hostages' Story
description: AS surgeon at the Wyoming County Community Hospital in Warsaw, New Yorka village some 15 miles south of AtticaI had assisted in the treatment of four of the 12 injured hostages released from the Attica Correctional Facility on the morning of Thursday, September 9, the first day of the fourdaylong prison revolt. Early that evening, I drove to Attica to relieve some doctors who had been standing by outside the prison walls. Upon arriving, I learned that no one knew anything definite about the physical condition of the hostages still held by the inmates, although there were rumors that many were dead or seriously injured. Indeed, at that time no one even knew how many there were. I wanted to find out more if I could. After persuading a State Health Department official to take me through the main gate, I encountered Superintendent Vincent R. Mancusi in the administration building. Once convinced that I was a doctor, he asked me to go upstairs with him, and there I was introduced to State Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald, Deputy Commissioner Walter Dunbar and others. While they had naturally been extremely concerned about the hostages seized that morning, they had apparently only recently been considering the feasibility of getting a doctor into the rebelheld sector of the prison. After some discussion, it was decided that if the prisoners guaranteed my safeconduct I would go in with the threeman negotiating team scheduled to meet with the rebels later that evening. It was shortly after 7, then, when I set out on my first visit to the hostage compound in D yard.

title: New Names in the Board Room
description: Iacocca of Ford, Riccardo of Chrysler, DeNunzio of Kidder, Peabody (and chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange), Halaby of Pan Am, Tavoulareas of Mobil Oil, Krysiak of National Tea, Piore of International Business Machines, Goldman of Xerox. Just a handful of names, but they stand out in ethnic solitude on the canvas of big business' power elite.

title: Negro Named to Cabinet Of Massachusetts Chief
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has announced the appointment of Thomas I, Atkins, 32 years old, a black, as his Secretary of Communities and Development.
