title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE
description: Apparel manufacturers on Seventh Avenue and elsewhere are in the midst of decisions about what to make for next spring. They are casting around for fabrics that are likely to win consumer acceptance and reports from fabric suppliers give some indication of what the market will offer when the crocuses and tulips make their appearance next year.

title: John Mechlin, a Fortune Editor And Foreign Correspondent, 52
description: John Martin Mecklin, a member of the board of editors, at Fortune magazine, who was also an author and foreign correspondent, died Friday of cancer in Carolton Hospital, Fairfield, Conn. He was 52 years old and lived at the Mayflower Hotel, 15 Central Park West.

title: She May Be tinkled Behind the MakeupBut I Love Venice
description: I HAVEN'T written a love letter for years. My wife wouldn't have time to read one, and I'm too cautious to send such things to girl friends. But none of the aforementioned, I'm certain, would object to my composing a love letter to Venice.

title: Justice Douglas Supports Plan To Preserve Leonia Woodlands
description: LEONIA, N. J., Oct, 30 Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court today urged the preservation of a 13acre, publicly owned wooded area threatened by residential development.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Art
description: ONE hears a good deal of talk these daysnot in what we might call the corridors of power, but elsewhere, behind the scene, so to speakabout a return to realism. Certainly the galleries and the art journals seem to be a shade more hospitable to painting of a realist persuasion than they were a few years back. At least they are not quite so automatically hostile. Even the big university art departments where realism of some sort was never entirely out of favor, now seem to accord it a new respect. At least the latest farout inanity is not so often immediately assinned to have a greater artistic importance than a painter working directly from life, a word that for the moment had better be left in quotation marks if we want to avoid some of the ambiguities that discussions of realism inevitably trade in.

title: STONY BROOK CREW FIRST IN REGATTA
description: The New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler staged its first homecoming rowing regatta on the East River yesterday by playing host to Stony Brook and the United States Merchant Marine Academy crews.

title: Bicentennial Time
description: This is my formula for the Bicentennial. Anyone who has wrestled with a national or global exposition knows it takes a small miracle of busy preparation to get it ready. This may sound absurd, but when you think of all the parties at interest, the clashing ideas, the personal ambitions and conflicting regional claims, 1972 is not too early to start. Everyone in the act has his own wristwatch. Hurry, hurry, hurry, say the shill and barker. No rush, says the old boy with the scythe. Get busy, says the engineer. Up with the scaffold, says the billboard man.

title: Writing Awards Announced
description: CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP)Charles Gene McDaniel, Associated Press cience writer, and Sandra Pesmen, Chicago Daily News feature writer, were named winners yesterday of awards for interpreting psychoanalysis for the public.

title: Pedersen Specializes in Wood Craft
description: New boats are not news, but it is when a boat company decides to specialize in wooden yachts. That's what the C. V. Pedersen Boat Yard in Deltaville, Va., is doing, building a 34foot Chesapeake Bay Skipjack for a customer. customer in New Jersey.

title: TRAURIG VICTOR WITH 3 MOUNTS
description: READINGTON, N. J., Oct. 30 Bernie Traurig, master of Bloodstock Farm in Mechanicsville, Pa., rode the winners of three championships and one of his pupils was up on another victor today at the Four Sea sons Farms' Horse Show.

title: British Entry: Bane to U.S.?
description: An American diplomat in London was talking a year or so ago about the prospect of British membership in the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

title: MRS. JAMES L. ASHLEY
description: Mrs. Edith A. Ashley, widow of James Lincoln Ashley, for many years treasurer and a director of the International Nickel Company, died yesterday in Beechwood Manor Convalescent Hospital, New London, Conn. Mrs. Ashley lived in the Sherry Netherlands Hotel here and was 98 years oldd

title: Philharmonic Experiment Poses Questions in Downtown Concert
description: The New York Philharmonic's second Prospective Encounter, held in Martinson Hall of the Public Theater in Greenwich Village on Friday night, may not have answered any questions, but it certainly posed some.

title: AmericaWe're Nobody's Sweetheart Now
description: IT used to be: Americalove it or leave it. To which we may now add  or make a movie about it.

title: Miss O'Toole To Wed Dec. 4
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Oct. 30 Miss Teresa Ellen O'Toole and Edward Necarsulmer 3d, a general partner of Hal(garten & Co., investment bankers in New York, plan to be married on Dec. 4. There engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Aloysius O'Toole, parents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Necarsulmer Jr. of Chappaqua and New York.

title: Free Spirits Pedal Away At a Park In Queens
description: It's funny isn't it how often when you least expect it you're suddenly an eyewitness to history. That's just what happened to my wife and I one recent Sunday morning when we took our youngest for a routine visit to the zoo in Flushing MeadowCorona Park and ended up watching the first official meeting of the Flushing Meadow Cycle Club.

title: Kentucky Triumphs, 3327
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 (AP)Kentucky watched a 20point firstperiod lead vanish, then fought back to put down harddriving Virginia Tech, 3327, today.

title: Clark Leads Bullets
description: BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP)The Baltimore Bullets, with Archie Clark scoring 32 points, beat the Phoenix Suns, 10194, tonight.

title: SOVIET AUTO AGE BEGS CAR THEFT
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30The coming of the automobile age to this capital of the Communist world has given Soviet authorlties a modern headache, one that has long bedeviled the capitalist West  professional car thieves.

title: Garelens
description: THOSE were the days when the landed gentry gardened under glass. Cut flowers, potted palms, whole landscapes flourished under glass roofs. There were parties. Cut flowers grown in the back houses were brought in to trim the lavish dinner tables.

title: Sparing the Horses
description: While its daily handle pushes toward the $900,000 mark, the Offtrack Betting I Corporation continues cutting corners with what strikes I some observers as a pennywise, poundfoolish policy of economy.

title: Canadian Football League Franchise for New York Will Be Discussed Today
description: Richard Aurelio, the Deputy Mayor, will meet with the commissioner of the Canadian Football League today in Toronto to discuss a C.F L. franchise for New York.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Something New

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Senate vote to kill the foreign aid bill Is more symbolic than real. It will be reInbred in some other form long before the $5 billion in the pipeline runs out, but it is one more dramatic illustration of how quickly the world is being transformed.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Marcia Snell Bride Of Dr. Robert Pantell
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 30Miss Marcia Ruth Snell was married here this afternoon to Dr. Robert Howard Pantell. The Rev. Todd Walter, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. John Leslie Snell Jr., parents of the bride.

title: Wyoming and Utah Are Hit By a Heavy Snow
description: LARAMIE, Wyo., Oct. 30 (AP)  Residents of southern Wyoming and northern Utah began digging out today from a massive storm that piled up threefoot snow drifts and was blamed for at least 11 deaths in the Rocky Mountain area.

title: Yen Reaches New High
description: TOKYO, Oct. 30 (Reuters)The yen reached a new high level of 329 to the United States dollar9.42 per cent above its old official parity of 360 to the dollaron the Tokyo exchange market today.

title: Store Sales Slowing Again
description: In Dallas last Wednesday, the temperature took a 25degree drop from the preceding day's level. The managers of the J. C. Penney stores in the area, who had been unhappily eying their accumulating inventories of jackets and coats, suddenly found a sales flurry in just those items.

title: They rote ItAnd They're Glad
description: WERE you there when they crucified my Lord? No? Well, Andy Warhol was. And Radie Harris. And Earl Wilson (with his B.W.). And Sylvia Miles (with and without Tennessee Williams). And Holly Woodlawn. And David Frost. And Rado and Ragni. And Otto Preminger. And Candy Darling.

title: Watts Sparks Vermont Academy
description: ASHBURNHAM, Mass., Oct. 30Bob Watts, a senior halfback, scored four touchdowns today as Vermont Academy romped over Cushing, 326. Vermont won its third game in Pive starts while Cushing dropped to 23.

title: Art Exhibit Stresses Motif of Garden's Horse Show
description: With a special exhibition to coincide with the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, the National Art Museum of Sport will conduct a members show.

title: Correction Officer Shoots And Kills Man in Brooklyn
description: An offduty city correction officer shot and killed a man who had shot the officer in the hand during a traffic dispute in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police of the Classon Avenue station reported.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Preps
description: WINDSOR, Conn., Oct. 30Loomis scored all its touchclowns on the ground today in beating Hotchkiss, 187. Ted Berry was outstanding, scoring on runs of 77 and 2 yards as Loomis won its fourth game in six.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The proud tale of how Mr. Bagson made a quick buck by investments in multifamily houses is, unwittingly, a perfect expos of one of the direct causes of a shocking inflationary situation in rentals [Novice Tries His Hand at Investing and Voila! Oct. 17.]. A dab of paint and the landlord considers himself entitled to raise the rent!

title: Iona Loses 610 Center After Spinal Operation
description: Bernie Socha of Yonkers, 6foot10inches, junior center for the Iona College basketball team, will be sidelined for the season as a result of recent surgery.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: Cheers for Mrs. John S. Hall and her suggestion that airlines designate a nursery area on each plane (Travel section, Oct. 10). It reminded me of an incident involving the late Helena Rubinstein during a transAtlantic flight. Two youngsters seated on the aisle adjoining La Rubinstein were making life miserable for her, and their parents were indifferent. Reaching breaking point, Miss Rubinstein beamed a fiendish smile and boomed, Children, dears, why don't you go outside and play?

title: Mellon, Balding and Piggott Take British Racing Honors
description: LONDON, Oct. 30 (UPI)Paul Mellon of the United States headed the owners' and breeders' table, Ian Balding finished as the champion trainer and Lester Piggott won the riders' championship for the ninth time as the English thoroughbred racing season ended today.

title: Television
description: WE women think that we are in control of our lives, that we are defining ourselves when, in fact, none of us are. Our lives are defined by men, directly by menthe men we live with, or the men we love, or the men we're married to, or the men we work forand, indirectly, through television, film, radio and other media, which are controlled by men.

title: Joseph Williams Jr. to Marry Suzanne Sickler in December
description: CLARKS SUMMIT, Pa., Oct. 30Mr. and Mrs. William J. Sickler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Michaelle Sickler, to Joseph P. Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Williams of Mill Neck, L. I., and Boca Raton, Fla. The wedding Is planned for early December.

title: Preps
description: PAWLING, N. Y., Oct. 30The passing of Marshall Hagen and the running of Steve Joffe lead unbeaten Riverdale to 20.6 victory over TrinityPawling today. It was the sixth victory for Riverdale.

title: Gay Gilpin Tucker Is Fiancee Of Dr. Carlos Juan Alvarado
description: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Oct. 30Miss Gay Gilpin Tucker plans to be married in early January to Dr. Carlos Juan Alvarado of Cambridge, Mass., an instructor in clinical radiology at the Harvard University School of Medicine.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: Yes, Virginia, there is a Disney World! And it's not the psychologically contrived thing that William H. Honan's article about the new resort complex M Florida (Travel section, Oct. 10) presents. Aren't we lucky that someone with all that money and technical genius (Disney with associates) is in businessbusiness isn't a dirty wordto give us the sheer fairyland joy of a whole world of fun, with nothing to prove, no axes to grind, just plain, oldfashioned American cornball plus a trip to the moon? Who else, where else but America? And, Virginia, even if you've joined Women's Lib, take your husband and children and go. To enjoyfor a change?

title: Dance Workshop Presents 6 Pieces In Weekly Series
description: Dance Theater Workshop's program on Friday, part of its current weekend series running through Nov. 27 at 215 West 20th Street, included six pieces by new choreographers. None rose above the student level.

title: COLORADO VICTIM
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30 The great debate continued today as Nebraska mothered Colorado, 31.7, for its 18th consecutive victory.

title: M'GOVERN'S PACE PRODS HIS RIVALS
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., Oct. 30 Senator George McGovern's organization, spreading like an inkblot, is forcing the early pace of New Hampshire's Presidential primary campaign, supporters and rivals here seem to agree.

title: Vietcong Say They Used Bees to Rout U.S. Patrol
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (Reuters)The Vietcong Radio reported that guerrillas had released a swarm of bees toward a United States patrol recently, forcing them to beat panicky retreat.

title: Executive Retreats: Taking the Board Room Into the Wilds
description: THIS neatly typed admonition, tacked onto the notice board as one of a dozen Thoughts for the Day, tells us that despite the sylvan surroundings, we are here to work. All around us, men with briefcases and loud shirts are heeding the call. As they scurry from one building to another, they hardly seem to notice the brilliant sunshine and balmy atmosphere. They know that to be called to Crotonville, N. Y., is a serious matter and they will not permit themselves to be tantalized by the birdsong they hear anymore than, say, the Muzak in the corporate elevator.

title: Rice Subdues Texas Tech On Three Field Goals, 97
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., Oct. 30 (UPI) Mark Williams kicked the Rice Owls to a 97 upset victory over Texas Tech today with field goals of 32, 32 and 21 yards. The last one came with 6 minutes 11 seconds to play.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: The reviewer of Disney World failed to notice the courtesy and friendliness of everyone connected with this wonderful spot. Walt Disney built his creations for pleasure; and I hope visitors will find more than venality and put over in the resort's Magic Kingdom.

title: Bridge Bidding a 3in10 million hand
description: IT is safe to assume that a player who claims to have held a 13card suit has either been the victim of a practical joke or is stretching the truth. Such a hand will occur about once in a hundred billion deals. The practical limit, without straining credibility, is an 11card suit, which should occur three times in ten million deals. This seems to have happened just once in international play a decade agn in Sao Paulo. A local team representing Brazil was contending with the French international team, which was en route to the world championship in Buenos Aires.

title: Right Way for the Gateway
description: A tenth of this nation's population will soon have a national park at its doorstep39 square miles of open space for outdoor recreation. The major question is: Can the open space survive the onslaught?

title: Colonels Beat Rockets
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 30 (AP)With Artis Gilmore scoring 10 of Kentucky's first. 16 points and Dan Issel scoring 26 of his 35 in the first half, the Colonels swept to a 133105 victory over the Denver Rockets tonight.

title: 39 ExAttica Hostages Seeking Special Benefits
description: ATTICA, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) Thirtynine correction officers of Attica state prison, who were held hostage for four days in an inmate rebellion last month, are demanding special benefits from the state, including overtime pay for all the hours they were in captivity.

title: DEMOCRATIC GAIN IN JERSEY IS SEEN
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30Significant Democratic gainsenough to jeopardize the Republicans' heavy majority in the Legislature  were predicted today by leaders in both political parties.

title: Ax for Foreign Aid
description: To Hugh Scott, the Senate Republican leader, it was a manifestation of the new isolationism, an effort to tell the world to stop because we Want to get off. But to Mike Mansfield, Mr. Scott's Democratic counterpart, it was a search for a new foreign aid concept to take the burden off our shoulders.

title: Television
description: IN The Incomparable Max, one of the more tedious exercises in dull theater to open on Broadway recently, the final scene had critic Max Beerbohm speculating, in an age before television, on the future of stage productions. Max, or Clive Revill's unconvincing version of Max, grasped at every sentimental straw available.

title: J.D.L IS CRITICIZED BY JEWISH LEADER
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30The head of the American Jewish Committee, a prominent human relations agency, sharply criticized today the militant Jewish Defense League for what he called its wanton violence and repeated harassments of the Soviet Union's diplomatic personnel in this country.

title: 22 Die in Hong Kong Fire
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 30 (AP)At least 22 persons died today in a fire at a threedeck floating restaurant under construction at the fishing village of Aberdeen, the police reported. The dead and injured were believed to be workmen building the restaurant.

title: NorthSouth Senior Golf Won by Goldman Again
description: PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 30 (AP)David (Spec) Goldman, a 62yearold golfer from Dallas, won the North and South senior tournament for the fourth time today.

title: FOSTER RETAINS SHARE OF CROWN
description: SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 30 (AP) Bob Foster peppered Tommy Hicks with left jabs and hard rights tonight and stopped the schoolteacher in the eighth round of their scheduled 15round bout.

title: Dickson's 4UnderPar 68 for 210 Total Regains Lead in Sahara Tourney
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 30 (AP)Bob Dickson registered three consecutive birdies and surged past the faltering Lee Trevino to regain the lead today in the third round of the $135,000 Sahara Invitational golf tournament.

title: Lions on The Lawn By Mary Chipperfield. Illustrated. 176 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $5.95.
description: Longleat is the seat of the Marquess of Bath, built by Sir John Thynne in 156779 and added to by Wren and Wyatvile. It contains fine portraits (adm. on Mon. and Sat. afternoons). Thus Baedeker in 1927. Longleat still retains its fine portraits, but there is now daily adm. (1 per car) to the grounds, which contain better than half a hundred lions, along with hippos, chimpanzees, giraffes, sea lions, gazelles, zebras, a dule of tortoise and at least one tiger given to taking dips in the swimming pool. (There's a photograph to prove it.)

title: Give a Cheer for Lowly Sponges
description: QUOGUE, L. I.When Dr. Ross F. Nigrelli of the New York Zoological Society gets in his powerboat and goes fishing, he catches animals.

title: Letters
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: MURPHY SAYS HE WITNESSED GRAFT
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy once became so appalled by the corruption he found in a New York plainclothes unit enforcing the gambling laws that he asked to be transferred back to regular patrol duty in a precinct.

title: The World
description: KARACHIEast and West Pakistan are separated by nearly 1,000 miles of hostile Indian territory, and it is often said here that the two parts are strung together only by Pakistan's international airline and the Islam faith. Since last March, these seemingly tenuous bonds have been strained to the utmost, and many diplomats have predicted the immi. nent demise of this bifurcated nation.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Anniversaries 5028

title: 10 IN U.S. COPTER DIE IN NHATRANG CRASH
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (AP)The United States command reported today that a big Army helicopter had crashed at sea Tuesday near Nhatrang, 195 miles northeast of Saigon and that all 10 Americans aboard had been killed.

title: LINES FAIL TO AGREE ON ATLANTIC RATES
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Oct. 30  The 25 major airlines flying the North Atlantic failed today in their latest effort to agree on a new set of passenger fares.

title: The World
description: TOKYOIn many of the Kabuki dramas here, a Samurai warrior plays a scene in which he flashes his sword at the villainous enemies who surround him, fights his way free, and escapes by scampering up a runway known as the hanamichi, or path of flowers, that goes through the audience to the back of the theater. There, he twirls his sword in a final flourish and retires gracefully, beaten but with honor.

title: News of the Rialto
description: REMEMBRANCE of things past is likely to be on the theater's bill of fare during the months ahead. Immediately at hand is the revival of On the Town, that 1944 lark about three sailors on a 24hour pass in Manhattan. There have been hopeful announcements about That's Entertainment, which apparently would put together some of the memorable songs the team of Howard Dietz and Arthur Schwartz contributed to such entertainments as The Bandwagon, Flying Colors, Three's A Crowd and The Little Show. And Harry Rigby, who is involved with the revival of No, No, Nanette, which surely must have started this remembering business, has said that he will present a revival of Irene, a musical that opened in 1919 and delighted audiences through 675 performances.

title: Et Al.
description: An official historian for the Royal Navy lucidly describes the Allied campaign against Hitler's navy. Despite the pocket battleships and submarines, which made the Atlantic hell for transports during 194142, the German navy was ill prepared for a major effort. This is an impeccable book of its kind, encompassing both grand strategy and the fortuitous and individual acts of heroism that often decide battles.

title: Et Al.
description: Life in the Movement. The author, as a Harvard junior, got fed up with the body counts on TV and decided to Do Something about the war. He joined the Moratorium Day committee as an organizer and now reports in great detail on his activities, which culminated in the Washington demonstration. From the trashing of Harvard Square and the internecine strife within the Movement, he emerged sadder but wiser, etc., resolved to undertake the long, hard job of educating others for peace. Wry, introspectivean honest portrait of a young man trying to realize his ideals.

title: NobleGrenough Victor
description: CONCORD, Mass., Oct. 30Touchdown passes of 50 and 60 yards from Pete Alvizof rallied NobleGrenough today and enabled it to defeat Middlesex, 2115. The victory was the fourth in five garnes for Noble  Grenough. Middlesex was beaten for the third time in five games.

title: Saigon, With Officer Problem, Says New Graduates Are Better
description: THUDUC, South Vietnam, Oct. 20When Ding Cong Hai failed the entrance examination to Saigon University last year, he was drafted and ordered to report to the sprawling Vietnamese officer candidate school here. He graduates shortly and will become a combat platoon leader in the infantry, to serve for the duration of the warand who knows what that is, he said.

title: China and Algeria Sign Pact
description: TOKYO, Oct. 30 (AP)China and Algeria have signed a longterm agreement that provides for a sizable increase in trade between the two nations, Hsinhua, Peking's official press agency, reported today.

title: St. Paul's Routed, 4626
description: WINCHENDON, Mass., Oct. 30Jim DeAmaral ran for three touchdowns and Mike Pucko ran for two today as Winchendon overwhelmed St. Paul's, 4626.

title: Movies
description: SHE wasn't thrilled to see me.

title: CUP PLAY OPENS IN SOCCER TODAY
description: Competition for the United States Challenge Cup and the Amateur Cup in soccer will get under way in the metropolitan area and other sections of the country today. There are 115 teams scheduled to play for the Challenge Cup and 153 will bid for the Amateur Championship Award.

title: Dig They Must for Indian Relics on L.I.
description: GLEN COVE, L. I.Four thousand years ago, while the pyramids were rising in Egypt, some archeologists are certain at the same time, a primitive Indian culture flourished on Long Island.

title: Mrs. Walkley Has Child
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., Oct. 30A daughter was born Oct. 16 to Mr. and Mrs. Arthur H. Walkley 4th in the Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco.

title: R. R. Walbridge, Teacher, to Wed Miss Monaghan
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Oct. 30Mr. and Mrs. H. Holt Monaghan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Reynolds Monaghan, to Ryckman Ray Walbridge, son of Mrs. Eugene W. Stetson Jr, of Westport and George O. Walbridge, and the stepson of Mr. Stetson.

title: Loss of Consumer Protection Feared
description: Several law groups and public officials in the metropolitan area have recently mounted a campaign against part of the proposed new Federal Criminal Code because they believe, in the words of one official, that it would be a giant step backward in consumer protection.

title: Synod Draft Opposes. Change in Celibacy Rule
description: ROME, Oct. 30Opponents of any change in the Roman Catholic policy that prohibits the ordination of married men won a major victory at the Synod of Bishops today with the distribution of a draft document on the priesthood.

title: Understanding Vladimir Nabokov
description: MONTREUX, Switzerland.

title: Tito Visits Space Center
description: HOUSTON, Oct. 30Under extremely heavy security measures, President Tito toured the Manned Spacecraft Center and a billiondollar complex of hospitals in Houston this afternoon.

title: ARBITRATION BILL SEEN AS ASSURED
description: New York City will soon become the first major city in the United States to require binding compulsory arbitration of labor disputes involving municipal employes, according to City Council leaders who agree that passage of compulsoryarbitration legislation is assured.

title: The Unbelievable Happens in Bengal
description: ONE day in the summer of 1961 I drove in the monsoon some 40 miles to the north of Calcutta to inspect an unpromising agricultural college which the United States was assisting and to look at the beginning of a new experiment in dairy husbandry. For generations the most congested bustees of Calcutta had harbored a considerable number of dairy stables, each of which added marginally to the filth, stench and flies of the city and some of the world's most polluted milk to its sustenance. Now the cows and buffaloes were to be relocated to solid, concretefloored stables in the marvelously lush green countryside palms, paddy, patches of tall hemp, ponds covered by wastes of water hyacinthof West Bengal.

title: Tech Victor in Soccer
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 30Joe Pinto's three goals led New York Tech's soccer team to a 100 victory today over St. Peter's College.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Clifford Barrett, 76, Dead; Taught Philosophy at Scripps
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., Oct. 30 Clifford Leslie Barrett, Hartley Burr Alexander Professor of Humanities Emeritus at Scripps College, died yesterday at Huntington Memorial Hospital in Pasadena.

title: VERMEER QUARTET PERFORMS DVORAK
description: The Vermeer Quartet, which played Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, is something of an intellectualist group. They deftly uncover all sorts of interesting details in a composition, carefully revealing the structural and thematic framework, while paying less heed to suave intonation or even razorsharp ensemble precision.

title: Reform Priests in Mexico Under Conservative Attack
description: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30Conservative bishops and politicians have launched a fierce attack against a new movement of progressive Roman Catholic clergy who have been increasingly critical of the social, economic and political situation prevailing in Mexico today.

title: BAY STATE APPROVES BILINGUAL TEACHING
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30The Massachusetts Legislature has passed a bilingual education bill that could become a model for other states, including New York, Texas and California, with thousands of children from nonEnglish speaking backgrounds.

title: Mount Hermon on Top
description: NORTHFIELD, Mass., Oct. 30Mount Hermon overcame effective passing by Choate's Ed Kuchar today to register its first victory in five garnes, 3028. Watt Herbert's three touchdowns offset Kuchar, who scored twice and compteted 11 if 17 passes, nine to Ralph DeLucia.

title: Marx a la Mode And Wilted
description: There is the (true) story that following the events of May, 1968, in France, when a radical studentworker rebellion brought the country to the edge of chaos and the Communist party was severely criticized for defending the established order, a party cell meeting attended by a friend of mine was opened by the chairman with these words: Now, comrades, to serious business: the fte of L'Humanit.

title: Oklahoma Crushes Iowa State, 4312, as Mildren Sets TotalOffense Record
description: NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 30 (AP) Jack Mildren fired two touchdown passes and shattered the Oklahoma individual offense record today as the secondranked Sooners hammered out a 4312 victory over Iowa state.

title: Upsala's Defense Contains Lycoming in 2215 Victory
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 30 (AP)Upsala clicked on all defensive cylinders today intercepting three passes, recovering four fumbles and holding Lycoming to 98 yards total offense in a 2215 victory over the visitors from Pennsylvania.

title: Tech Wins Sixth, 300
description: NEWARK, Oct. 30Bob LeVine threw touchdown passes of 17 yards to Dave Bonet and 14 to Hal Marrero today to lead the undefeated New York Tech Club football team to a 300 victory over Newark State, It was the Bears' sixth triumph.

title: Poll in Oregon Finds Big Muskie Lead
description: Campaign No??

title: Article 3  No Title
description: COLD SPRING HILLS, L.I., Oct. 30Pat Hanley threw two touchdown passes to Mike Bean, and Stan Heath scored Eastern Military Academy deon a pair of runs today as feated Brooklyn Prep, 280.

title: Oklahoma State Wins, 1710
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Oct. 30 (AP)Reuben Gant's reception of an 18yard pass from Tony Pounds for a fourthquarter touchdown gave Oklahoma State a 1710 Big Eight Conference victory today over fumbletroubled Kansas.

title: Mrs. Robert Dieter, was Gwynneth Evans.
description: ST. JAMES, L. I., Oct. 30Miss Gwynneth Ann Fletcher Evans and Robert Johann Dieter were married here this afternoon in St. James Episcopal Church by the Rev. Frederick B. Stimson Jr. and the Rev. McCrae Cobb.

title: Sixkiller's Aerials Send U.C.L.A. to 2312 Defeat
description: LOS ANGELES, Oct, 30With two touchdown passes and a rollout run for another touchdown, Sonny Sixkiller guided Washington to a 2312 victory today over the Univer sity of California, Los Angeles.

title: U.S.C. WINS, 280; JONES LEADS WAY
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 30 (UPI)Jimmy Jones, playing his best game of the season, ran for one touchdown and passed or two more toddy In eading Southern California to a 280 victory over California.

title: Religion
description: Within the past decade, many a Catholic collegian taken aside by a doting theology professor learned the secret of what sounded like a daring and glorious new career: the layman as a teacher of religion. The future, the young hopeful learned, was very bright. The Roman Catholic institutions, where theology courses, were generally mandatory, were growing apace, but there was a falling off in the number of priests and religious who could teach such courses. Moreover, in the wake of Vatican II, there was much talk of increased lay involvement in ecclesiastical affairs.

title: Delay on Calley Foreseen
description: ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (UPI)It may be next summer before the courtmartial conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. will be heard by the United States Army Court of Military Review, the chief Judge, Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, said yesterday.

title: Manhattan Sets Back Pace On SecondHalf Rally, 150
description: Manhattan College beat Pace College, 150, yesterday in a defensive struggle. Manhattan did all its scoring in the second half on two touchdowns and a field goal. The first tally came early in the third quarter after Brian Smith connected on a 16yard pass to Dennis Pradier. Smith then went over from the 1yard line.

title: Westchester
description: Port Chester broke Ossining's 12game winning streak, 70, and Sleepy Hollow remained undefeated while nearing the Northern League title with a 200 victory over the defending champion Horace Greeley in games yesterday.

title: Suspect in Slaying of Gill Is Arrested by His Brother
description: CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (UPI) An acting suburban police chief arrested his own brother today in the slaying of a teenafe girl who was stabbed 15 times while on a trickortreat adventure with a neighborhood playmate.

title: N. Hampshire Population Up
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) New Hampshire's population has risen to 762,000, an increase of 3.3 per cent since the census of 1970, the office of Senator Norris Cotton, Republican of New Hampshire, said yesterday.

title: Wilding Gives Up Citizenship
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) Michael Wilding, 18yearold son of Elizabeth Taylor, the actress, has renounced his United States citizenship at the United States embassy in London, State Department officials disclosed Thursday.

title: PRINCETON SQUAD TOPS BROWN 4921
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 30Hopeful Princeton and hapless Brown kept two streaks alive today as Walt Snickenberger and Doug Blake sparked the Tigers to a 4921 trouncing of the Bruins.

title: Music
description: WILL you take me to dinner at the Plaza? said the voice on the other end of the telephone. It was a voice of certain feline languor, touched by an indeterminate accent. It was the voice of Maria Callas. On the previous afternoon, I had attended her first master class in operatic interpretation at the Juilliard School Theater, and had also seen Pier Paolo Pasolini's film Medea in which Callas makes, her debut as dramatic actress. I asked the soprano for an interview. Call me, she had said.

title: Retiring P.S.A.L. Chief to Be Honored
description: The mention of the P.S. A.L. pin holds a special nostalgia for students of the New York City public schools system. The gold, silver and bronze pins, with Winged Victory on the face, are among the memorabilia in thousands of homes. More than 20,000 of these pins have been distributed annually since 1910 in gymnasium classes and field days as achievement awards for rope, climbing, chinning the bar, potato races or making 10 basketball layups in 30 seconds.

title: Chargers Picked by 10 as Jets Still Search for Passing Attack
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 30At the halfway point of their frustrating season, the New York Jets will oppose the Chargers here tomorrow with their wide receivers, young Rich Caster and experienced Don Maynard, under scrutiny.

title: Does the      really exist?
description: Writers have always been fascinated by criminals. Some actually were criminals, such as Francois Villon, the splendid troubadour of the French Renaissance or, in our own day, Jean Genet. Others, like the Elizabethan dramatist Robert Greene, consorted with crooks and wrote learned treatises about themso well informed, indeed, that contemporary gangsters were displeased and may have been responsible for Greene's death in a tavern brawl.

title: 11 U.N. ACTIVITIES SEEN IN JEOPARDY
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30The Senate's vote to kill the Nixon administration foreign aid authorization bill would, if not reversed, hit hard at 11 United Nations undertakings.

title: Local
description: After a scoreless first half, Pat Fallacaro, the Lincoln quarterback, broke the game open with four touchdown passes yesterday to spark a 258 victory over Madison at Lincoln Field.

title: WASH. STATE MAKES OREGON 3121 VICTIM
description: SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 30 (AP) Two fourth  quarter touchdowns by Bernard Jackson gave Washington State a 3121 victory over Oregon today and moved the Cougars a step closer to the Rose Bowl.

title: Dance
description: ETHNIC dance is the poor relation of the dance community. Spanish dance has always been fairly popular in America, and Indian dance has found its devotees, but by and large ethnic dance has never commanued the popularity enjoyed by classic ballet or moderndance.

title: Kentucky Lawyer Is Jailed for Contempt of Court
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 31 (UPI)Daniel T. Taylor 3d, a lawyer who resents raw authority, was in the city jail today facing a possible 41year A sentence for contempt of court.Attorneys for Mr. Taylor were trying to arrange his release pending an appeal, but they were unable immediately to reach an appeals judge who could act in the case.

title: TaxAbatement Plan Seeks To Stimulate City Housing
description: A program of major property taxabatement, involving cuts linked to reduced rents, described as the biggest incentive to privately financed housing construction here in a halfcentury, is to be announced by the city tomorrow.

title: MASSACHUSETTSTOPS VERMONT TEAM, 2415
description: AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 30The University of Massachusetts paralyed a 17point scoring splurge in the first period yesterday into a 2415 victory over the University of Vermont in a Yankee Conference game.

title: POSTAL FACILITY IN JERSEY SCORED
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30A major postal service facility now under construction for the New York metropolitan area in Jersey City has come under attack from a Republican representative who charged that the project was shot through with blunders that border on criminal negligence, nonfeasance or malfeasance, or all three.

title: Six years of short takes in the life of Julian Singer
description: I think Gilbert Rogin has written a great novel, the first new one I've run across in quite some time. Which is as it should be; great novels, almost by definition, should be rarer than trumpeter swans. The odd thing about What Happens Next? is that it's almost not a novel at all. The work of an accomplished shortstory writer, it was first published as a series of stories in several magazines over the last five years. Now that these 22 pieces have at last been brought together in a book, they still retain a shade of the disjunctiveness of individual stories, the more so since they vary widely in form and experimental technique. But the intensity of Rogin's central vision and the virtuosity of his prose are such that they cohere and build more surely, perhaps, than a formal, onepiece novel could have done.

title: Medicine
description: Thirtythree years ago, a British biochemist, Sir Charles Dodds, accidentally discovered diethylstilbestrol, manmade chemical that behaved remarkably like the natural female sex hormone, estrogen. This first synthetic estrongenic drug and others that followed paved the way for a whole new range of therapeutics: treatments for menopausal symptoms, estrogen deficiency diseases and certain forms of cancer and, eventually, the development of oral contraceptives. None of them would have been possible on widespread scale if doctors had had to rely on a limited, costly supply of natural estrogens.

title: Berit Edman Engaged
description: The engagement of Miss Berit Edman, daughter of Mrs. Sven C. L. Edman of Stockholm and the late Mr. Edman of Goteborg, Sweden, to William W. Young, has been announced by the prospective bride's mother. Mr. Young is a son of Mrs. Jean Young of Westwood, N.J. and Robert W. Young of New York.

title: FOOD PRICES RISE DESPITE FREEZE
description: The prices of a number of productsespecially foodstuffs have risen over the last week in the metropolitan area, a survey by The New York Times has indicated.

title: St. Lawrence's Late Surge Trounces Rochester, 350
description: CANTON, N. Y., Oct. 30 (AP) An unyielding defense and an explosive, four touchdown fourth quarter, carried St. Lawrence to a 350 victory over Rochester today.

title: OHIO STATE WINS IN 2D HALF, 1412
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 (AP) The Ohio State Buckeyes, down, 60, and badly outplayed in the first half, scored on Don Lamka's fourthdown touchdown pass and Rick Galbos' 4yard run in the second half to defeat Minnesota, 1412, today in the rain. It was Ohio State's fifth straight Big Ten victory.

title: Horse Show News
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The United States Equestrian Team will honor the owners who have contributed or lent horses to the group at a cocktail party next Friday.

title: ROYAL J D FIRST ON JERSEY GRASS
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Oct. 30 (AP)Royal J D pulled away in the stretch to capture the $29,625 Benjamin Franklin Handicap at Garden State Park today by 1 lengths.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Last year Congress passed and President Nixon signed amendments to the Urban Mass Transportation Act of 1964 to provide $3.1billion over the next five years for upgrading, extending, improving and developing new bus, rapid transit and commuter rail systems in the United States. Beyond this, the amendments expressed the intention of Congress to provide $10billion for nationwide urban mass transportation activities over the next 12 years.

title: MICH. STATE WINS; ALLEN SETS MARK
description: LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 30 (UPI)Eric Allen cracked Ron Johnson's singlegame National Collegiate Athletes Association rushing record in Michigan State's 4310 rout of Purdue.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss., Oct. 30 (AP)  Richmond's head football coach, Frank Jones, was rushed to a hospital here tonight after a couple of players bumped into him as he stood along the sidelines watching his team play Southern Mississippi,

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: How to survive in the jungle
description: Government and March to the Monteria are the first and third, respectively, of the six Jungle novels of B. Traven. The fifth (The Rebellion of the Hanged) was published by Knopf nearly 20 years ago but is now out of print. The second (The Carreta) was published last year by Hill & Wang, who sometimes list March to the Monteria as The March to Caobaland. The Jungle novels are also called Revolutionary novels. All this is typical of the minor mysteries that have always surrounded the work and person of B. Traven, and is therefore quite satisfying.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., Oct. 30East Rockaway whipped Metropolitan Football League opponent, Xavier, 2014, today and raised its season record to 41. East Rockaway drove 90 yards in the final three minutes to pull out the victory.

title: Iraq, North Korea in Pact
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 30 (Reuters)Iraq has agreed to export oil to North Korea over a long period, the North Korean news agency reported today. North Korea, in turn, has agreed to export irrigation equipment, machines and other goods to Iraq. The agreement supplemented a 1959 trade and paymented a 1959 tradeandpay

title: U.S. Expedition Finds Ancient Greek Sanctuary Under the Sea
description: ATHENS, Oct. 30An American archeological expedition exploring the ancient port town of Halieis, in southern Greece, has discovered a large sanctuary dedicated to the sun god Apollo six feet under the sea.

title: Now, Synthetic Fuels
description: The age of synthetic fuels for heating American homes, running factories and powering cars has arrivedbut is not here.

title: TOLEDO WINS, 456; STRING REACHES 31
description: OXFORD, Ohio, Oct. 30 (AP) Toledo used three touchdowns by Joe Schwartz, a tailback, and an alert defense in swamping Miami (Ohio) 456, today. The Rockets ran their winning streak to 31 games, equaling the National Collegiate mark for secondbest string, Oklahoma holds the record with 47.

title: NEW MEXICO TOPS ARIZONA BY 3428
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 30 (UPI)  New Mexico won a battle with the clock today beating Arizona, 3428, in a seesaw Western Athletic Conference game.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: BUCKNELL BEATS RUTGERS BY 1413
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 30Mitch Farbstein plunged over from the 1yard line and Dave Boyer kicked the extra point with 21 seconds remaining to give Bucknell a 1413 victory over Rutgers today before 10,400 fans.

title: Miss Morris Wed in Queens To James Hope
description: Miss Constance Yvonne Morris was married last evening to James Linn Hope at the St. Albans (Queens) Congregational Church by the Rev. Robert Ross Johnson, a Congregational minister, and the Rev. W. Walter C. Wynn, a Baptist misiter.

title: Bobby Seale's Birthday Cake (Oh, Far Out!)
description: IN October, 1969, seven defendants in the Chicago Conspiracy Trial tried to give a birthday party for their colleague, Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party. First, their lawyers asked permission to bring a cake into the courtroom for Seale, who spent most of his day locked in a cell at Cook County Jail. But Judge Julius J. Hoffman said he never allowed cakes in his courtroom. Then the defendants were caught trying to smuggle a cake past marshals in a briefcase. When they finally entered the courtroom, one defendant shouted: Hey, Bobby, they've arrested your cake. Bobby replied, They've arrested a cake, but they can't arrest the revolution.

title: Arkansas Adios By Earl Mac Baugh. 178 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $3.50.
description: What would you think of an 11yearold, whose ideas of fun seem derived from KraftEbing? Imaginative? Cute? Unbelievable? Young Lester Long is all these things and a few more. Even on a routine day, his behavior dramatizes the everwidening gulf between today's small fry and Tom Sawyer. At least, in a certain type of fiction.

title: Nixon at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., Oct. 30 (AP)President and Mrs. Nixon flew to Camp David today for a weekend at the Presidential retreat in the Catoctin Mountains.

title: Sabres, Canucks Tie, 44
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Oct. 30 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres behind Richard Martin's three goals and the outstanding goaltending of Roger Crozier, registered a 44 tie with Vancouver Canucks before 15,570 for tonight.

title: Orioles Rained Out in Japan
description: OSAKA, Japan, Oct. 30 (UPI)Rain forced postponement of the scheduled game today between the Baltimore Orioles and a combined team of the Yomiuri Giants and the Nankai Hawks. The game has been rescheduled for Monday.

title: L. I. Struts to Mummers' Beat
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I. People who stood along the line of march of the Memorial Day parade in Long Beach last May are not liable to forget their surprise when the Long Beach Veterans of Foreign War contingent came along. It was headed by a band dressed in gaily colored costumes, trimmed with ostrich feathers and led by a capering, strutting man in sparkling gold and purple, wearing a panoply of ostrich feathers 10 feet high.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  Seven environmental organizations last week apparently lost their battle to halt Cannikin, the underground test in the Aleutian Islands of a fivemegaton warhead of the Spartan antimissile missile. They may, however, have won a victory of more lasting consequence.

title: National Notes
description: The Counterfeiters

title: 108101 Loss Evens Record
description: With the leading players of both teamsWillis Reed of the Knicks and Billy Cunningham of the 76ersout of action, the Philadelphia 76ers used a zonepress defense to overtake the New York Knicks in the final quarter last night and register a 108101 victory at Madison Square Garden before 19,235 fans.

title: Massachusetts Harriers Win Second Yankee Title in Row
description: STORRS, Conn., Oct. 30 (AP)The University of Massachusetts won the team title for the second straight year in the Yankee Conference crosscountry championships today.

title: Lumpenhippies and their guru
description: The Family is the first complete, authoritative account of the career of Charles Manson. A smalltime thief, forger and pimp who was paroled after seven years in prison at the dawn of San Francisco's 1967 Summer of Love, Manson, hirsute and acideyed, was charged with the TateLaBianca murders less than three years later. In January, 1971, he was convicted of these seven murders. He must still stand trial for'two othersone of them, according to author Ed Sanders, a hideous torture experimentand is implicated in many more.

title: Coins
description: THE SAN FRANCISCO Assay Office will begin accepting orders for 1971 proof coin sets tomorrow, it was announced by Mrs. Mary Thomas Brooks, Director of the Mint. (Nov. 1 has become the traditional opening date for this numismatic offering.) The five. piece sets are priced at $5 each, which fee includes the cost of handling and shipping by registered mail. There will be a limit of five sets per order.

title: T.C.U. VANQUISHES BAYLOR, 34 TO 27
description: WACO, Tex., Oct. 30 (UPI)Steve Judy scored twice and passed for two other touchdowns tonight to lead Texas Christian to a 3427 victory over Baylor.

title: Dayton Schools Face Shutdown in Fiscal Crisis
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 30The Dayton public school system, in serious financial trouble over the defeat of four tax levies since December, 1969, and caught up in the budget problems of the state Legislature, faces a shutdown next week affecting its 54,000 students. Unless the Legislature intercedes, the schools will close for one week, Nov. 5 to 12.

title: HOMECOMING DAY FOR ROLLER DERBY
description: The Roller Derby returns to Madison Square Garden today, conning back to New York on regular basis for the first time since 1959. The sport proved itself last winter when three exhibitions at the Garden produced capacity crowds.

title: FORMAN PREP WINS FOR 50 MARK, 388
description: NORTH WESTBURY, L. L, Oct. 30Joe Shramko, operating from both the halfback and quarterback positions, led undefeated Fordham Prep to 38S trouncing of Wheatley today. Fordham increased its wonlost record to 50. Wheatley slipped to a 33 mark.

title: Blast Rips Post Office Tower, The Tallest Building in London
description: LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 31An explosion damaged Britain's tallest building, the 620foot Post Office Tower, early today.

title: When Two Charities Want the Same Opening Night, Who Wins?
description: It happens here all the time: a glittering movie Premiere for the benefit of sonic charily or other. And then other benefit performances are scattered through the weeks as the picture settles down to a run.

title: A CLOSE CONTEST FACED BY ALIOTO
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30The tall, bald, vigorous man with the flashing eyes and biting tongue moved into the campaign's final days fighting hard to hold onto the job he had come to love. That was Mayor Joseph L. Alioto, 56 years old, and he was at bay.

title: 25 Fresh Yankee Beaten Again As Marlu Pride Wins by Head
description: YONKERS, Oct. 30  A change in equipment apparently helped Marlu Pride, a chronic breaker, to maintain stride tonight and beat Fresh Yankee, the 2to5 favorite, in the $20,000 Porternouse Trot at Yonkers Raceway.

title: I.B.M. Finds Home In BedfordStuyvesant
description: This is a business entity operating with standard measures. It isn't, and never has been, anything related to charity.

title: Happily Barefoot at the Guggenheim: The Performance Was an Experience
description: Is the charity bash taking a turn for the better? Lately, for all the fancy clothes, elaborate decor and freeflowing liquor, most parties for good works have been getting deadlier and deadlier. Although there has been a lot of surface gaiety, most charitycircuit regulars have been secretly agreeing that attending them is an effort.

title: Et Al.
description: For most Americans, C. V. Wedgwood's The Thirty Years War (1938) has, been the last word on the subject. Her thesis that the whole bloody struggle was without paint is especially appealing to contemporary tastes. However, this work by Pages (one of the great French historians), published in 1939 toward the end of his career, thoroughly deserves this belated translation and publication. Instead of concentrating on the Holy Roman Empire (as Miss Wedgwood did), Pages considers all of Europe and especially France. He concludes that the war did leave important legacies: the creation of nation states to replace feudal states, the assurance of the continuation of a variety of religious beliefs. Everyone should know of the book's existence; students of European history should read it.

title: IN THE NATION
description: PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30  Is America possible? No one ever quite defined what was meant by America in the title of a twoday conference just completed at Portland State University, so no answer could be agreed upon. But in different ways, both speakers and audience seemed more hopeful than might have been expected.

title: Clemson 10.9 Victor
description: CLEMSON, S. C., Oct. 30 (AP)  Eddie Seigler's 30yard field goal with 37 seconds left gave Clemson a 109 victory today over Wake Forest.

title: U.S. DOCTOR HAILS CHINA'S MEDICINE
description: HONG KONG, Oct. 30Dr. Samuel Rosen, a 74yearold New York City ear specialist, has returned from a trip into China and reported that a dem onstration of an ear operation he was prepared to give was not needed.

title: The strategy was hit, runand win
description: The resistance of the Yugoslav Communist Partisans against the Germans during World War II is one of the sagas of modern history. Month after monthboth during the bitter winter cold in the mountains of Montenegro, which lie between Sarajevo and the sea, and during the long, stifling summers, when after 10 hours' march they had only the moisture from fir cones to quench their thirstthe Yugoslav Partisans had to keep continually on the move.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Groton hanks 4th Foe
description: GROTON, Mass., Oct. 30Groton School crushed Gov. Dummer, 360, today to record its firth straight victory. The offensive play of Bill Larkin and Dave Key helped raise Groton's point total for the season to 146. The visitors were the fourth team to be shut out by Groton.

title: For All Woods and All Finishes
description: Home Improvement

title: There's hope for the patient, though he's breathing hard
description: When a group of Establishment lawyers convenes a symposium to ask whether law is dead, the answer is as predictable as any we might expect from a Vatican conference on whether God is dead. This book  which consists of the proceedings of a symposium sponsored by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and edited by a former dean of the Yale Law Schoolcontains few surprises. The law is alive and well, we are assured in Whitney North Seymour's foreword; and although it may be breathing hard in certain areas, it is certain to retain its vitality for at least another century.

title: Music
description: IN content it was a resounding statement: My career motivation has solidified in the past two years into being concerned with creating a machine, an organization or a climate in which artists can realize the potential of their imaginations. It was said quietly, however, after much thought, and the speaker clearly meant what he said. The motivated man was John Ludwig, who was talking about the company he manages, Minneapolis's Center Opera of Minnesota. It has made its mark by doing new works with flair and a progressive style.

title: HULME SETS PACE FOR COAST RACE
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Oct. 30If sunny California's cold snap continues, tomorrow's race at Riverside International Raceway, the last of the season's 10race series for $1million in purses and prizes, may have to be run in snowmobiles instead of the usual Group 7 sportsracing cars.

title: BAR UNIT BYPASSES 20 FOR JUDICIARY
description: Twenty among the 51 candidates running for judicial office here on Tuesday were not approved for election in a listing released last week by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

title: Movies
description: ONE of the most enthusiastically received films of the recent New York Film Festival was The Sorrow and the Pity, Marcel Ophuls fourandahalf hour documentary about France under the Nazi Occupation. Now Andre Harris and Alain de Sedouy, the two Frenchmen who conducted the majority of the interviews that are seen in The Sorrow and the Pity, have decided to bring more French history to the screen, They will codirect De Gaulle, a documentary feature that will include newsreel footage of the late Free French leader and President of the Republic, as well as interviews with people who knew him.

title: Emerson is Victor
description: STOCKHOLM, Oct. 30 (AP) Roy Emerson of Australia eliminated Torben Ulrich of Denmark, 61, 62, in the first round of the $50,000 Stockholm open tennis tournament today.

title: NICKLAUS, WITH 66, LEADS BY 9 SHOTS
description: HOBART, Tasmania, Oct. 30 (AP)Jack Nicklaus of the United States shot a 66 today for a threeround total of 199 and a ninestroke lead in the $22,400 Qantas Australian open golf tournament.

title: Met's Nedda Casei Affianced to Singer
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Oct. 30Nedda Casei, mezzo soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, and John A. Wiles Jr., a baritone who is artist in residence at Michigan State University, plan to be martied here in late December at the Hitchcock Memorial Church.

title: Nancy Bristol Bride in Jersey Of S. B. Homer
description: GLADSTONE, N. J., Oct. 30  Miss Nancy Bristol and Stephen Bartlett Homer were married here at noon today in St. Bernard's School Chapel by the Rev. David S. Warren of the United Methodist Church here.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: WITH business and labor both skeptical about the success of the Administration's economicstabilization program, the stock market continued to display a deeply bearish mood last week as it sank to a level within an eyelash of its low point for the year.

title: If You Don't Mind Getting Lost In the Yucatan Jungle, Follow Me!
description: SO there we were in the Yucatan jungle, stuck in the mud in the black of night, with our driver leaning on his hands on the hood of the jeep, slowly shaking his head from side to side. And all I could think was, I should have known; I should have expected something like this.

title: National Issues Play a Role in Acrimonious Race for Erie County Executive
description: BUFFALO, Oct. 30Senator Edmund S. Muskie yesterday joined the list of prominent Democrats who have campaigned here for Mayor Frank A. Sedita of Buffalo, their candidate for Erie County Executive, but his opponent said it was all part of an effort to divert attention from the real issues.

title: AIRPORT'S SYSTEM ON TAXIS SCORED
description: The taxidispatching system at La Guardia Airport violates the law, the Taxi Commission said yesterday fellow union memberthe dispatcheris pliable, the spokesman said.

title: Africa as a catalyst, and a climate of alienation
description: On the edge of a great lake, a long way up Africa, an English journalist halfheartedly filling in on an assignment from a London paper, retraces the steps of Livingstone's last journey. Livingstone, of course, made the journey on foot, with bearem, taking 10 months. The journalist takes a plane, hires a car, gives himself two days to get what he needs for his storyhis wry, copyorientated mind noting the useful irony. By the lake somewhere are the graves of Livingstone's companions the bearers who died, one by one on that last journey.

title: Yale 20 Soccer Victor
description: HANOVER, N. H., Oct. 30Eric Anderson, the Yale captain, scored in the first period today and John Clark tallied in the third to give the Elis a 20 soccer victory over Dartmouth, The triumph lifted Yale's overall wonlosttied record to 341 and its Ivy League mark to 211. Dartmouth, 040 in the league, is 251 on the season.

title: The Nation
description: Among the elections this Tuesday, national interest has focused on four mayoralty contests.

title: A rollcall of rightist touts, from Plato to Goldwater
description: Is it healable, the internal hemorrhage, the secession of youth? Maybe start by taking conservatism away from the conservatives. Here is why.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: AN AMERICAN ASKS CUT IN ARMS RACE
description: MOSCOW, Oct. 30A Columbia University professor, speaking at a scientists' conference on disarmament problems here, aroused Soviet interest today with a proposal that the two nuclear superpowers attempt to slow the arms race by reducing their present overkill potential to a minimum necessary for national security.

title: Montclair State Trounces Trenton State Eleven, 4113
description: TRENTON, Oct. 30Montclair State College opened defense of its New Jersey State College Conference football championship at Hillwood Lakes Field today by trouncing Trenton State, 4113.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Gentlemen of the angling fraternity may be appalled to learn that the first name of their patron saint has apparently been misspelled Izaak for centuries.

title: L. I. Youths Playing Bach for Fun of It
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L. I.When young, longhaired people tell their parents they are getting to gether with some of their friends to play the music of the longhaired greats, they are not referring to the Rolling Stones, The Who or Bob Dylan.

title: MAYOR IN INDIANA FACES CHALLENGE
description: INDIANAPOLIS Oct. 29 Richard G. Lugar, the dynamic young Mayor of Indianapolis who has become one of President Nixou's prized advocates on municipal matters, is facing a vigorous challenge Tuesday by an even younger Democratic opponent.

title: Investment Clubs: Leverage for the Little Guy
description: The hardest thing to learn is when to sell, Mrs. Jean Robinson commented last week during a recess at the National Association of Investment Club's convention in Philadelphia.

title: TAIWAN'S SETBACK SPURS REFORMERS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 29The international reverses suffered by the Chinese Nationalist Government in the last year, culminating in the loss of United Nations membership, have been the chief factor behind the most pronounced political stirrings this island has experienced in years.

title: Nassau South
description: Looking ahead to future opponents is a nono. Berner found that out yesterday when it was dropped from the undefeated ranks by lightly regarded Law rence, 2820, in a South Shore Division I game.

title: Movies
description: THE current antiNixon documentary (it is called Milihouse for anagrammatic reasons which, like the penetration of Oh! Calcutta!, are not worth the archeologist's time) is of course an insult the intelligence, but of course insults to the intelligence can be fun. Not necessarily praiseworthy fun, but who said fun had to be praiseworthy? If Dwight Macdonald could have fun seeing MacBird!, you can have fun seeing Milihouse, and your neighbor can have fun reading the Black Book of the John Birch Society.

title: Scholars See Better Programs For Black Studies in Colleges
description: BIINGHAMTON, N. Y., Oct. 30A number of black scholars said today that they had noticed positive and significant developments in college black studies programs, but that these programs still enjoyed only a tenuous existence.

title: Jail Notes Theft Charged
description: KENT, Ohio, Oct. 30 (UPI)David T. Real, 20 years old, of Stow, Ohio, a freshman at Kent State University, has been charged with stealing from the campus bookstore a volume titled Jail Notes, by Timothy Leary.

title: OFFICIALS SEEKING STOPGAP PROGRAM FOR FOREIGN AID
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30The Administration took steps today to assemble a stopgap foreign aid program from the wreckage of the permanent program in the wake of the Senate's 41to27 vote yesterday killing the $3.5billion authorization bill.

title: Humphrey Stumps In Jersey in Test Of Political Waters
description: NEWARK, Oct. 30Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota tested the political waters in New Jersey today as he stumped for Democratic legislative candidates in Union and Essex Counties.

title: Rough Riders Make Playoffs
description: OTTAWA, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press)  The Ottawa Rough Riders capped a lateseason comeback today by beating the Montreal Alouettes, 97, to assure themselves a playoff spot in the Eastern Conference of the Canadian Football League.

title: Defeated Buffaloes in Awe Of HuskerSooner Battle
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 30It's gonna be unreal, Ken Johnson, the Colorado quarterback said today of the NebraskaOklahoma football showdown next month, for football's No 1 spot. It's gonna be heck of a game.

title: Judicial Canon Revisions Criticized at Hearing
description: Some proposed revisions of the canons of judicial ethics dealing with financial interests and extra activities by judges were criticized here yesterday as too rigid at a hearing by the American Bar Association's Special Committee on Standards of Judicial Conduct.

title: Local
description: Powerful Bayside rolled to a 300 victory over Flushing yesterday in a Public Schools Athletic League Division 1 game at Memorial Field to maintain its untied and unscoredon record.

title: Samuels's Son Seized As a Narcotics Carrier
description: Howard J. Samuels Jr., the 19yearold son of the president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning on charges of carrying cocaine, heroin and barbiturates, the police reported.

title: Dr. Negley K. Teeters is Dead; Advocate of Penal Reforms
description: ONEONTA, N.Y., Oct. 30 (AP) Dr. Negley K. Teeters, a leading American criminologist cited by President John F. Kennedy for bringing light to a field which has long suffered from misunderstanding and indifference, died at a hospital here today. He was 74 years old.

title: Worldwide Slowdown Pushing Money Rates Downward
description: The bond market, as a professional portfolio manager remarked the other day, has fantastically outperformed the stock market this fall.

title: MUSKIE TRAILING NIXON IN 2 POLLS
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30Senator Edmund S. Muskie, widely regarded as the front runner for the 1972 Democratic Presidential nomination, is slipping in the polls.

title: Ducks Win
description: COMMACK, L. I., Oct. 30 (AP)J. P. Mallette, playing his first game of the season, scored two goals and assisted on another tonight, leading the Long Island Ducks to a 51 Eastern Hockey League victory over the Jersey Devils.

title: Scott, Turner, Carrington Advance in Indoor Tennis
description: Gene Scott, Steve Turner and Art Carrington have moved into the third round of the first coca's tournament of the indoor tennis season here.

title: Letters:
description: TO THE EDITOR: I go along with the enthusiastic plug for driving to nearby college football games (Travel section, Oct. 10). To the list of colleges mentioned I would add Lafayette and Lehigh, both in lovely country surroundings and just right for tailgate picnics. (With due respect to Penn's splendid Franklin Field, the parking environs are rather gritty for alfresco lunches.) Princeton is, of course, the queen of them all. Locating convenient bathrooms anywhere is often a puzzler: How do you determine the sex of a dormitory at 50 paces?

title: KENNEDY IS REBUKED FOR ATTACK ON NIXON
description: BOSTON, Oct. 30Elliot L Richardson, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, sharply rebuked Senator Edward M. Kennedy tonight for impugning the integrity of the President's forthcoming trip to China.

title: LEEDS 10 VICTOR ON LORIMER GOAL
description: LONDON, Oct. 30, (Reuters) Manchester United's runaway surge at the top of the English Football League First Division was halted today when it was beaten, 10, by Leeds United.

title: KINGS POINT TOPS LAFAYETTE, 200
description: KINGS POINT, L. L., Oco. 30 The United States Merchant Marine Academy upset Lafayette College, 200, today in football game before 3,450 fans at Captain Tomb Field.

title: Cambodia Devalues the Riel From 55 to 140 to the Dollar
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct 30 (Agence FrancePresse) Cambodia today devalued her currency, from 55.65 riels to the dollar to 140.28 riels to the dollar.

title: Police in California Take to the Sea for Instruction
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 30 Two California highway patrolmen, Floyd Hassell and James Anderson, set out recently to patrol their beat, which extends far out into the Pacific to Pearl Harbor and sometimes Samoa or Tahiti.

title: Preps

title: Law

I.In their personal Dark Ages, the members of the Donald Ward family found themselves becoming rabid fans of the Yale football team and wellversed in the community affairs of southern Connecticut. Harder, chairman of the board of CPC International, Inc., the huge foodprocessing company, was perhaps the first head of a large international company to applaud President Nixon's Aug. 15 freeze of wages and prices and the accompanying 10 per cent import surcharge. title: Late 19thcentury weathervane.
description: Some seven years ago, in O Strange New World, Mtunford Jones discussed among other topics the influence of the Renaissance on early American civilization, illustrating both the interest of colonials in the ideal of the uomo universale and the presence of many such universal men in the colonies. A reading of O Strange New World perforce suggests that Jones himself is such a Renaissance man in the breadth and variety of his intellectual capacities. This impression is strengthened and confirmed by his newest volume, The Age of Energy, a learned and wideranging excursion through the thought culture of the United States between the Civil War and World War I.

title: Verlaine
description: The father, the real father, of all young poets is Verlaine, the magnificent Verlaine. The words are not the biographer's but Stephane Mallarmesquoted by an interviewer in 1891, the gala year of French Symbolism. Nor was Mallarme alone: the most diverse literary figures concurred in their admiration: Huysmans, Zola, Barres, Moreas, For Verhaeren, Paul Verlaine was the man who made the modern school of poetry possible. For Anatole France, he might one day be called the best poet of his time. Almost every major French composer of the day was inspired to set music to his texts: Chausson, Charpentier, Ravel, and especially Faurd and Debussy. When he died on Jan. 8, 1896, in his shabby tworoom apartment in a workingclass quarter of Paris, Verlaine was probably the most celebrated French poet in Europe.

title: Alpha Omega I. The Owl in the Hall: A Newport Childhood. II. Last Poems. By Winfield Townley Scott. Edited by Eleanor M. Scott. Introduction by Webster Schott. 238 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $6.95.
description: In a time of cult, box office and socko, Winfield Townley Scott practiced a disappearing profession: man of letters. Born in Haverhill, Mass., in 1910, he grew up in Newport, R. I., where his family, mildly prosperous middle class, kept a hardware store. There were no great readers' among our immediate relatives, he writes in Alpha Omega. There was no literary consciousness. He discovered books, trash and treasure alike, at The People's Library in Newport, floundered joyously in a sea of print, and then, after getting out of Brown, he made a career as poet, book reviewer, literary editor, essayist, friend and encourager of other writers. He kept steadily at his craft even in the absence of the headier froms of fame.

title: Uchida, With 213, Leads By Shot as Casper Slips

title: Art
description: EVERY artist's career, like every life, has its own mysterious rhythm of ups and downs. One expects of even the best artists that they will sometimes make indifferent works, and one is used to the special pleasure of seeing a firstrate show by an artist one had thought mediocre. In most cases merely interesting, an instance of this phenomenon will now and then seem to have importance beyond itself. Occasionally we will discern, in the creative fortunes of an individual, the influence of social and cultural forces that we recognize because they have affected too.
